name: Rainer WIELAND
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I would like to thank everyone for giving me this opportunity to present, on behalf of the Council, the agenda of the upcoming European Council. I shall try to be short and structured. There are three points on the agenda of the upcoming European Council: migration, trade and Russia. First on migration. The European Council will start and have the discussion within the framework which was given and agreed back in Bratislava. It is given by an agreement that, first of all, we should never allow the return of uncontrolled flows and should bring down the numbers of irregular migrants; secondly, we should ensure full control of external borders; and thirdly – extremely important – should reach consensus on a long-term migration policy.  In more detail, I believe that there are two tracks. One is our constant attention to the developments on the ground, where I would like to mention Bulgaria: I am happy to say, and I am confident, that Member States will be able to assist Bulgaria in its efforts to protect external borders. Secondly, and more importantly, I believe the core of the debate will be about where we stand with our work and what progress has been made when it comes to the building blocks that we have agreed on in order to manage the challenge of migration.  First of all, when it comes to the protection of external borders, I recall that it is tomorrow that the European Border and Coast Guard will enter into force. It will be inaugurated in Bulgaria, and I would like to say that the Slovak Presidency considers it to be its most important work in the remaining months to make the European Border Coast Guard operational. This House and the Council have agreed to the agreement speedily and very quickly, so legally it is in place as of tomorrow, but everyone knows that in order for the European Border Coast Guard to be deployed we need its operational capability. But in order to successfully manage the challenge of migration, we need to look beyond our borders, which means that we have to come back to the agreement that we came to in June in the European Council to engage more actively with the partners outside of the European Union. I recall that we have agreed on migration compacts, and the European Council will certainly review in detail where we stand with this very important building block. Lastly, on the external dimension: there will be an opportunity to review the implementation of the EU-Turkey statement.  On the second point – trade – I see a two-track approach to this debate. First, we need to have a broad political discussion about the future of our trade policy. On the one hand, I think everyone in this House would agree that trade without any doubt is a major source of growth. At the same time, I believe that, if we have a global ambition as a European Union, we need to use trade in order to exert our influence globally. This is an indispensable instrument in our hands. At the same time – and this must be part of a political debate – we need to reflect on how the broad public perceives the trade policy, which we are trying – as I said – to use in our own interests. This will be the political dimension of the discussion about trade, but at the same time, equally important will be the discussion about the respective trade relations that we have and aspects connected to it. I mention here China and, of course, we are aware that we are approaching the deadline of mid—December, by when we have to take a decision on whether to recognise China as a market economy, while at the same time we have clearly—defined interests, bearing in mind the anti-subsidy and anti-dumping dimensions of relations with China. At the same time, it is very important to review where we stand on TTIP, and I hope that we will finally have a very good outcome when it comes to the finalisation of our efforts to conclude an agreement with Canada. Of course, there is the issue of trade defence instruments: this is absolutely part of our efforts when we want to arrange trade in the way I have described.  Lastly, there will be a strategic overall political debate about Russia. That is what I wanted to say at the beginning, and I am ready to respond to your questions if there is interest on your side.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Commission President. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in the State of the Union address I presented to you a few weeks ago, we have proposed, as a Commission, a programme of concrete actions that we would like to see adopted by the co-legislators later this year. We must absolutely have the ambition to reshape the European Union and, in order to do so, we will have to adopt the legislation that is throes.  Two days after the State of the Union address, I, like but one of the other colleagues in the European Council, went to Bratislava where we could see that the Heads of State or Government gathered there welcomed the State of the Union address. I draw your attention to the fact that this is the first time that the members of the European Council have welcomed a speech by the President of the Commission. Previously, they didn't even take note. Progress cannot be stopped.  (Reaction from Mr Verhofstadt) I would like the European Council to welcome all the speeches I make before you, especially when they are received with such benevolence, as was the case with the last one.  In Bratislava, we adopted a roadmap that bears the name of this beautiful Slovak city, but this statement from Bratislava remained below my expectations because it was insufficiently concrete. We, as the Commission, had proposed a timetable that would have obliged both to respect it. However, the Bratislava Declaration is a good platform for us to move forward. The Slovak Presidency, its Prime Minister, has excelled in bringing together the views of each other, which should be welcomed. It is our duty, following the inter-institutional agreement, to agree on a programme of work between the three institutions before the end of the year. I would like us to do it quickly. But this inter-institutional agreement, this idea of the three institutions joining forces to agree on a programme, is a real step forward. I would like the European Council, which will meet in Brussels later this month, to be able to agree on concrete results. We do not need poems, we do not need a solemn declaration, we will have to adopt a program that will allow us to move forward. This is especially true for all the proposals that the Commission has put forward in relation to the European Digital Union. We have presented some 30 initiatives and I would like the Council and Parliament to be able to adopt them before the beginning of the summer, because the proposals we have put on the table seem to me to be the most possible of what can be done. This is true for the telecommunications market, for copyright reform and for the organization of radio spectrum.  These decisions are absolutely necessary for us to make progress on a digital Europe. It will be a difficult debate and I would like the European Council to decide, for itself, whether we leave it to the various ministers to regulate the radio spectrum. I am afraid we will not be able to do that. Let me give you the example of Germany: in this country, at least eighteen ministers are responsible for organising the radio network. Therefore, the chiefs themselves will have to make the decisions that I think are important. With regard to migration, the European Council or the quasi-European Council in Bratislava has decided that we will have to apply the decisions taken to migration and other areas of action in the European Union. As the Hungarian people have spoken in the same direction, I do not see insurmountable difficulties in implementing the decisions we have already taken.  With regard to the post-Dublin regime, which the Council and Parliament are discussing, we will have to see to what extent we will be able to create an intersection between each other's points of view. I have referred to - but I do not, the expression "flexible solidarity". I would like us to find an agreement that stands out for its solidarity dimension. Bulgaria - since today it will be inaugurated the mechanisms of control of the external borders and the coasts - can count on us. We have informed the Bulgarian government that we are going to make 108 million euros available to help this country. We will have to send an additional 130 civil servants there and we must ensure that Bulgaria can buy 50 vehicles that will allow Bulgarians to better control their borders. The arrangement with Turkey is working. A year ago, in October 2015, 10,000 refugees arrived in Greece every day. Today, that number of refugees has fallen to 85, which clearly proves... (Mr Lamberts' reaction) - Italy, Mr Lamberts, has no common border with Turkey, if I may use this little geographical indication - we have an agreement with Turkey that works, which is not to say that everything works in Turkey, of course. Wir haben das Wort gegeben, dass wir uns in Sachen Flàchtlinge auch mit der Ursachenbek-mpfung besch-ftigen messen. Deshalb lege ich groeen Wert darauf, dass die Investitionsoffensive fer Afrika so bald wie meglich Gestalt annimmt. Es wird meglich sein, durch diesen EFSI, der sich in Richtung Afrika bewegen wird, 44 Md. EUR an Investitionen vor Ort in Afrika zu mobilisieren. Wenn dann die Mitgliedstaaten dementsprechend ihren Beitrag leisten, konnten wir 88 Milliarden in Afrika investieren. Anstatt Menschen aufs Meer zu schicken, ist es ratsamer, den Menschen durch 'konomisch zu rechtfertigende Investitionen zu helfen. We have an issue as far as trade is concerned. I am not a blind free trader, but I know that trade is essential. EUR 1 trillion more trade with the outside world leads to the creation of 14,000 jobs. I give you an example: we have concluded a trade agreement with South Korea. The total amount of the exchanges with South Korea is EUR 15 billion. Thanks to this agreement with South Korea, we created in Europe 210,000 jobs. So trade is not neutral, trade is a job-creator, and we have to make sure that the agreement with Canada will enter into force after a certain number of months.  We will have a summit with Canada later this month; I am in ongoing discussions with the Canadian Prime Minister today and tomorrow. I think that we will reach a final agreement, which will take on board - in a specific declaration - the concerns of all the Member States. I was grateful to the President of the Council when he mentioned trade-defence instruments, because trade-defense instruments are of enormous importance. We have to make sure that the proposals that the Commission tabled - back in 2013, the Barroso Commission - will be adopted by the Council of Ministers. The fact is that in the Council of Ministers you have 12 Member States in favor of enhancing, strengthening the trade-defence instruments, and you have a group of 12 Member States who do not like the idea. They have to find an agreement among themselves, because you cannot explain to the public opinion - and mainly to those who are working - that we are opening the way for trade agreements with other nations without reinforcing the instruments we have to defend our industry, and mainly our steel industry.

name: Manfred WEBER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Mr President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the President-in-Office of the Council for his excellent work and for his excellent work. Three weeks ago, Jean-Claude Juncker gave his State of the Union speech, and it shaped it. It has put the pragmatic approach that Europe must deliver on the agenda. This was then carried out in Bratislava, and I would like to congratulate and thank Jean-Claude Juncker for this leader. Europe delivers! In recent days, I was most pleased with a news report that Marianne Thyssen announced that 1.4 million young people in Europe have found a job since 2014 thanks to the job guarantee – a permanent job. 1.4 million since 2014, youth unemployment has been reduced to 19 percent. So Europe delivers – we should also be talking about successes. The forthcoming Council will deal with many issues. I would like to emphasise that my group is in favour of a rapid ratification of CETA, as described by the President of the Commission, and that we are also at his side in flexible solidarity and must now break this Gordian knot. Today, however, I want to focus on two main areas: the first is Brexit. Theresa May will be there for the first time. We, as the European Union, had made a great offer to Cameron. That has been rejected, and now we need clarity. We learned at the Tory party conference that the motion must be made next spring. That is a good thing, because the matter can then be resolved by 2019, before the European elections. However, I would also like to make it clear that, for us as the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, the four fundamental freedoms of Europe are not up for debate in these talks. It is not acceptable for lorries to cross borders, but for citizens to be stopped at these borders. (Applause) Nigel Farage's strategy – he is no longer even here, thank God, I would almost say – has meant that Britain is no longer the second-strongest economy in the European Union, but the third-strongest economy, because the British pound has lost more than 10% of its value and the credit rating agencies have downgraded The UK by two levels. Nigel Farage is very expensive for the British, you have to keep that in mind. What concerns me most is the arrogance that we are unfortunately also experiencing from parts of the British Government. I would like to point out that in Bratislava 27 Heads of State or Government have agreed to move forward in Europe's defence policy and to do more. A week later, the Council of Defence Ministers took place, and the British Minister for Defence stands up and says: as long as we British are members, we will block any initiative to strengthen this cooperation! Ladies and gentlemen, this is arrogant behaviour on the part of the British Government. If we want to go outside, please do not block the further deepening of the European Union.  We probably don't have a government since George III that has less of a plan for how to deal with the situation, so I hope that Theresa May will soon come round the corner with very concrete proposals.  The second thing I want to address is Syria. We are stunned by a human tragedy. The barbarism: 300 000 people now trapped in Aleppo, tens of thousands of children living there under bomb terror. Since the siege of Sarajevo, we have not seen so many human hostages crammed together in one city at once, and the result is more and more refugees. Who is responsible? We know this: Assad, the mass murderer of his own people, and of course Putin, who is bombing, the Russian military is deploying there. I would like to ask the question: where are the mass demonstrations of the peace movement in Europe today, in the face of this madness that Putin is causing there? If the Americans were to bomb there, the roads across Europe would be full. That is why I would ask you to put your finger clearly in the wound that Putin is the biggest problem and that Russia is responsible for this development. (Applause) The European Council must take this up and criticise it, it must focus on humanity, it must provide ideas on how we can help the people on the ground. But politically it is clear that the appeasement has failed. Appeasement towards Russia has failed. Putin is bombing civilians today with bunker-breaking weapons, and everyone in the House and everyone in the European Council must understand that Putin cannot be a partner as long as he believes that weapons can make policy. We must try to stop this madness. Finally, it is important to remember who the henchmen in Europe are for Putin. Nigel Farage "Putin is a statesman he admires most," and Marine Le Pen said" "Putin can save Christian civilization." These were the statements of the right-wing populists in Europe. With Marine Le Pen, I can still understand it, because it is financed by Putin – that is why one has to say positive things about his own donors in the meantime. But true patriots, true representatives of European nations, true representatives of European patriots are not putin's henchmen, as you are.  That is why the request to the European Council to take humanitarian initiatives is, and I would even go so far as to call into question the European Council's dealings with Putin at the moment. I do not believe that a North Stream II project currently fits in with the time that we cannot do business with Russia at a time when Russia is bombing civilians in Aleppo. I believe that we, as the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, stand by the approach of practicing humanity, and we want to stand up to Putin's henchmen in Europe.

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: On behalf of the Group of the Party of European People's Party (S&D). Meanwhile, while Bratislava remained silent, the British Prime Minister, Mrs May, announced that notification of the British withdrawal would perhaps take place in March, first it should be in September, then in December, perhaps in January, now perhaps in March, always perhaps. In the meantime, the most serious thing is that it announces that the UK will unilaterally repudiate all legislation derived from European legislation, with very serious damage to non-BRITISH citizens living in the UK.  If good morning is seen from the morning, Mrs May could not have started worse in her dealings with her European partners. But we have to do our own thing, what we have to do. We must give a signal of change. I sincerely welcome Mr Juncker's report on the state of the Union in this House. We need signals about people's lives. At the economic level, we need to open a season of expansive politics. National budgets for 2017 are ambitious, otherwise Europe sinks into recession again. Let us have a genuine industrial policy, because Europe cannot serve multinationals such as caterpillar, which is stateless, blackmailing workers and firing them after distributing dividends to shareholders, as is currently the case in Belgium and France with Alstom. Fight against tax evasion and fraud, which are the main enemies, not of us Socialists, but of the whole of the European Union.  As far as immigration is concerned, when you play with fears, you end up being overwhelmed by them, as the news from Hungary shows. Like a sorcerer's apprentice, Orban's referendum as an attempted plebiscite has become his disavow. Orban's defeat tells us to move forward with the European asylum and immigration system and, as Mr Juncker said, to put back on the agenda and to move forward on the partnership agreement with Africa, on trade and subsidies. As far as trade is concerned, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, I agree that trade is a driving force for growth, but we must avoid dumping. International trade is fine, but without dumping. We cannot reduce the standards of living, working, social, environmental and health standards of European citizens. This is a prerequisite for us. Progress has been made on CETA, we have and remain highly doubtful about TTIP and we confirm our no to granting Market Economy status to China. With regard to Syria, I believe that it is a crime against humanity. Hospitals and schools cannot be bombed and doctors, young people, girls, children and innocent women killed without any motivation. It is absolutely essential to achieve an immediate cease-fire and to allow immediate and unconditional access to humanitarian aid.

name: Syed KAMALL
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, let me start actually by responding to a couple of points that Gianni Pitella made. Gianni said that the British Government had decided to repeal all EU legislation. Actually what they have decided to do is to transpose, in simple terms, EU legislation to make it stable in UK law. When the UK leaves the EU then you can actually start unpicking the law that has been transposed from the EU into the UK. I would ask you to be factually correct in these debates, especially if we are going to have an atmosphere of good cooperation to get a deal that is good for the EU and the UK at the end.  Secondly, I have to say I do agree with you that Bratislava was a wasted opportunity because if the Bratislava Summit was supposed to show the EU united and reconnecting with the people, then surely it was nothing short of an own goal: EU leaders meeting in a fortress, taking a lunch on a private yacht, followed by the Italian Prime Minister pulling out of a press conference, frustrated that other leaders had failed to agree anything of substance. Perhaps the only difference between this summit and the others that have come before was that this time you could not really blame the UK for the failure to achieve any kind of agreement.  When I saw reports of something not going very far, going round in circles for fear of being grounded, I wondered if they were talking about the summit itself, but it turns out they were talking about the yacht on which the leaders had their lunch. So if we are to truly fix what is broken, if we are to truly offer answers where the public has questions, if we are to truly show strength where there is currently weakness, then the next summit must achieve real results. The leaders of EU countries must show that they can lead because at the moment all the leaders can see is EU leaders pursuing yesterday’s European project rather than addressing today’s concerns.  We all need answers to the big questions: solving the migrant and refugee crisis, encouraging businesses to create more jobs, tackling internal and external security threats. Yet what emerges from this Chamber? Politicians shouting ‘no’ to austerity, politicians proposing free interrail passes, politicians protesting against trade with the US, full of slogans but bereft of action. We need to show our citizens in all our countries that we understand their concerns.  So when our citizens ask for fair but controlled immigration, let us be tough on those that attempt to jump the queue over others applying through legal migration channels, but compassionate to those who deserve our shelter, returning those who are not fleeing persecution or war.  When citizens of all the countries worry about an increasingly arrogant Russia, let us use fewer carrots and more sticks, speaking out on behalf of those Member States that share a border with an increasingly intimidating neighbour, showing Russia that their actions do not come without consequences. As Manfred Weber said, we believe we should be tough and that sanctions should not be lifted until the Minsk Agreement is implemented.  When the citizens of all our countries worry about a lack of jobs, let us remove the red tape holding back entrepreneurs from creating those jobs. Let us sign a trade agreement that offers businesses in all our countries new opportunities. Let us send a clear signal that we are open to trade with Canada and then other countries.  With every summit, with every meeting, we edge closer and closer to the next elections. At best, the EU has a record that shows it ploughed on with more of the same; at worst, that it pushed on with policies that failed. But it is a situation that needs fixing. It is a situation that the ECR Group of MEPs from 18 countries believes can be fixed, if only we were to take a new direction. The results of referenda in Denmark, Netherlands, and the UK show all of us that it cannot be business as usual but neither does it mean that there is not business to be done. Where past summits have failed to meet expectations, let us hope the next summit offers all of us solutions.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, first of all I would like to say to Mr Kirkhope: good luck in the House of Lords. I am pretty sure that we shall have a good defender of the European Union in the House of Lords from now on.  Václav Havel, who was at that moment the Czech President, warned in a speech in this House, I think it was in 1994, that Europe could ‘fall into the hands of a cast of fools, fanatics, populists, demagogues, determined to promote the worst European traditions.’  Havel would have turned 80 today, but I think that his warning is more relevant than ever and I would say to you, President, and also to the President of the Commission, that the challenges of the next European Council are proof of that.  I have, in fact, the same priorities as Manfred Weber has already put on the table. I think you have to talk about the tragedy in Syria. I cannot imagine that you return to your capitals after this European Council without decisive action on what is happening in Aleppo and it will not be sufficient, only to say ‘we are going to liberate EUR 25 million in humanitarian aid’, because you know very well today that it is even impossible to transfer this aid to the poor people in Aleppo. You will need to do other things, more difficult decisions to take, on eventual sanctions against Putin and Assad and on eventually installing a no-fly zone above Aleppo. Otherwise, this tragedy will continue and that is, I think, the first priority we have for this European Council. I can only imagine a situation where you go back and say ‘yes, that is for Ms Mogherini and we have nothing to say about this.’  My second priority is, and that is another point that Manfred Weber did not mention but I will mention it, is finally fixing the cracks in our financial foundations. It is now eight years that we have been discussing this and that we have not definitely cleaned up the financial mess in Europe. That means two things: a fully-fledged Banking Union. We do not have that for the moment. Secondly, economic governance, which is far better than a stability pact – let us be honest – that is never applied, from Greece to Portugal. It is no better in the north of Europe. We have problems with Greek banks, Irish banks, Spanish banks, Portuguese banks, Italian banks, Cypriot banks, Belgian banks, Dutch banks and now it is Deutsche Bank that is on the brink, creating further uncertainty and prolonging, in fact, the credit crunch in Europe. I remind you that the US, immediately after the financial crisis, put USD 400 billion in their system. They cleaned up the banking sector and every penny has been paid back since they did that. What we are doing in Europe is still debating, in fact, a Banking Union, we are still debating an economic governance system, and my plea to the Presidency of the European Council is that finally, in the European Council, work be done, that the Five Presidents report be approved. It is a fundamental mistake, Mr President, to think that we can get rid of it. That is the second priority, in my opinion, for this European Council. The third priority for the European Council is, I think, dealing in fact with the UK decision to leave the Union. I think it is impossible that you say nothing about it, and I think that you have to respond to the announcement by Prime Minister May. In my opinion, you have to say four simple things: first, no pre-negotiations – we can only start negotiations after the triggering of Article 50; secondly, negotiations need to be finished before the next European election – I cannot imagine that Mr Farage coming back to this Hemicycle; thirdly, the new EU relationship with the UK needs to be a close one, not only in our interest, but also in the interest – I should say – of the 48% of British citizens that have voted to remain, and let us not forget that; finally, whatever the new relationship will be, it can never infringe on our four fundamental freedoms.  My conclusion is clear: Europe and European values will never be up for negotiation.

name: Gabriele ZIMMER
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, Mr President of the Commission, I would like to thank the President of the Commission for his work and for his work Mr Juncker, Two weeks ago, or three weeks ago, I had the impression that the State of the Union address was addressed to the Council rather than to us as parliamentarians. I believe that you have also indirectly confirmed this today. They wanted to get the Council to finally understand that it must invoke common foundations of solidarity, return to them and stop cooking their own soup within the Council, within the European Union. I do not believe that this has been achieved. It will not only be reflected in the question of the extent to which the European Union agrees to deepen military cooperation – which, in my view, is the wrong way to go – but it will be particularly evident at the beginning of next year, when it comes to the fact that, on the occasion of the 60th anniversary of the signing of the Treaties of Rome, the question is whether the European Union, and especially the Member States, are prepared to return to a social union – not to return, but to finally build it up, to finally accept that without it there will be no European Union. That is the one point I would like to raise. This also means that, if the Council now wants to discuss the issues of migration, for example, we must also discuss how Member States are trying to evade these same responsibilities for respecting their own values and to reinterpret them for themselves. I am thinking here only of the referendum in Hungary and the announcement that Orban still wants to implement the failed referendum. In order to do this, we also need clear statements from the Council. We also need clear statements on how we deal with women's rights in Poland. It cannot be the case – but it is quite clear – that a majority in the Polish Sejm will stand in favour of a total ban on abortion and will decide so. And when, for example, Archbishop Hoser of the Episcopate's Bioethics Commission declares that abortion is equal to eugenics, it shows in which direction this is heading. The European Union is also in demand here. This is about our values as human beings, as women as a whole, and they apply to everyone and not just to certain Member States of the European Union. On trade, I would like to know whether the Council is also talking about what Mr Gabriel, for example, indicated at the SPD Congress, namely that we want to renegotiate that this will also happen with CETA. Or what kind of conditional approval of the SPD? After all, Mr Gabriel is not only SPD chairman, but also deputy chancellor and economy minister in Germany. So what is happening now? On Russia, I still think the sanctions are wrong, and I am therefore not going to be in a row with Putin. I declare that the bombing of Aleppo is a crime, including on the part of Russia, but there are other people responsible. And I say to you again: please do not fall for the tactic of declaring Russia the realm of evil again. This has never brought us anything. It has never been a good thing for us to try again, practically through sanctions, about exclusion, about this type of policy, to mobilise the Cold War and, ultimately, to re-enter an arms race. That is the fear we face. We have to act on this, and the European Union has a special responsibility not to take over the game in the American election campaign right now.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, like most of us, I have never participated in a European Council, so I can only imagine what the one that will be held in Brussels at the beginning of autumn 2016 might look like. I imagine 28 heads of state or government deeply shaken by the announcements of mass layoffs at Commerzbank, ING, Caterpillar, Alstom, especially in view of this new study which tells us that the full-time equivalent employment rate in Europe is capped at 75% in the countries with the best rates in Europe, falling to 68% in Germany or 53% in Greece. I imagine them concerned about the nagging rise in inequality in our societies. I imagine them worried after another record year for atmospheric temperatures and, above all, after a month of September that is the warmest in the history of mankind - at least, since the beginning of the temperature records. I imagine them horrified by the massacres perpetrated in Aleppo by Assad's army and Putin's army, but also by the death toll in the Mediterranean, which is likely to make this year the deadliest on this front. As I said, we cannot say that the EU-Turkey agreement works. I can imagine them delighted to learn that, even though one referendum before the summer showed the progress of national populist ideas in Europe, another, after the summer, showed that there are still resilient in our societies. But for how much longer? Perhaps they realize that the worst is never safe, as long as we know how to pull ourselves together in time. So I can imagine the turn that their debate might take: they might think that, if the trade treaty with Canada can benefit some of our multinationals, it could well be at the cost of the net loss of 200,000 European jobs, increased pressure on our farmers, who can already no longer afford it, and a further increase in the power of multinationals at the expense of democracy. Knowing that an increase in international trade flows goes hand in hand with an increase in our ecological footprint, they could conclude that, decidedly, this treaty is not the right thing to do. They might decide that instead, the urgency is to fulfil our still very imperfect internal market, a market where fiscal and social competition would give way to cooperation and upward convergence. They could work together to make investment in the energy transition the driving force behind European integration, because they know that it is good for the climate, for our strategic independence, for our balance of payments, for our industrial competitiveness and, of course, for jobs. But they might also realize that there is an urgent need to rethink together the organization of work, our taxation and our social security in a world where the digital revolution is increasingly freeing humanity from work, and this is to ensure that the benefits of this industrial revolution are not confiscated by a few and now leave no one at the edge of the road. They could come to the conclusion, Mr Korok, that containment is not the answer to migration challenges, but that a rich Europe is capable of being a land of welcome and refuge not only by preserving its values, but in reality to be faithful to them. Colleagues, this may be the fruit of my imagination, but I am convinced that, far from being a dream, all this is possible provided, of course, that I want it. This will, ladies and gentlemen, was totally absent in Bratislava and the question is: will this will be present in Brussels?

name: David BORRELLI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, migrant policy is a strategic issue which, if managed superficially, can become a disruptive element in the process of European unification. The institutions must send out a concrete signal of attention, attention to the lives of these desperate people, but above all to the concerns of European citizens, who clearly perceive the inability of their leaders to tackle such a phenomenon, giving rise to fear. The solution cannot ignore three abilities: courage, balance and speed. We expect the next summit to at least come to that. It will also have to respond to the challenges of trade policy. What is happening with TTIP, CETA and even more so with the ESFA in China makes us realise that this is no longer the time for decisions taken by a few just in the interests of specific national and economic powers. A trade policy must be a common good and can be so if it benefits everyone, if it takes on the needs of all. We have often wondered where the Council's strategic capacity is on these matters, which is failing to overcome its internal divisions on strengthening trade defence instruments and protecting 'made in'. Where is the Commission's ability to assert the experience and negotiating strength of a Europe that is certainly not among the last economies and is certainly among the most advanced models of a market economy.  Today there is a danger of putting our legislation, our companies and our workers at risk because of the inability to manage dynamics at global level that are certainly not new or sudden, all due to the fact that work has often been done even without the necessary transparency. But when you do not succeed in a task you must have the humility to ask for cooperation, and that also applies to the European Commission. Institutional transparency is not a limit but a strength for those who are able to have and share a project.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I hear here some of the transatlantic treaty in the media, such as the weather vanes that feel the wind turning, since the people have understood the reality of this transatlantic treaty. At the same time, this does not prevent you from quietly passing his little brother, the treaty between the European Union and Canada, discreetly in October.  This agreement, which, like its big brother, for that matter, will put in place an exceptional private justice so that multinationals can attack states. This is obviously shameful, indefensible and totally contrary to our principles. Even though our breeders are already in agony, you will also increase the pressure on them by putting them in competition with Canadian breeders producing 30-40% cheaper. On the migrant crisis, your own statistics office, pardon Eurostat, announces that only 30% of them come from Syria. Do you draw a conclusion? No, absolutely not. The irresponsible policy that you are pursuing brings us ever more economic migrants, and you have found nothing better than to distribute blue cards that you will offer to asylum seekers in Turkey, which will obviously create a new call for irrepressible air. At a time when people are telling you, by all means, that they do not wish to take in migrants, you are imposing them against their will - but that, I was going to say, you are used to it.  Finally, you have done everything you can to bring down the government of Syria by fighting a terrible civil war in this country. You are discarding today by accusing Russia, which is fighting the Islamic State, of all evils, but, I say very clearly, this does not hide your overwhelming responsibility and that of Mr Weber's American neoconservative masters who, from Iraq, have thrown this part of the world into absolutely appalling chaos. Mr Juncker, you are totally disconnected from reality. Totally! You tell us that you are planning 88 billion investments in Africa, when the European Union is impoverished at breakneck speed. You are talking about job creation, but you just forget to talk about the job losses that are obviously much more significant today. You explain to us that the Hungarian referendum is a victory for the European Union, because there would have been a turnout of less than 50% when 95% of Hungarians, or perhaps 98%, made it clear that they did not want migrants.  I would remind you, Mr Juncker, however, that, if I follow your analysis, then the Hungarians decided not to join the European Union, since the referendum on EU membership had received less participation than the one on migrants.  As for Mr Weber - I am not even talking about his statements, I am not talking about the monomaniacal attacks on Mr Farage or against myself, we are used to it, we are not even paying attention to it, in this case - I will mention his desperate lies to explain to us that Britain is going badly, whereas all the economic indicators of Great Britain show that, in this post-Brexit Period , it is doing much better than before the referendum and much better than all of our own countries, in this case.  So it is because you are disconnected from this reality that people are fleeing you. They turn their backs on you, they want to drop the moorings. This is the case for the Greeks, it is the case of the Danes, the Poles, the Hungarians, the Dutch, the Italians who, tomorrow, will vote in a referendum on the Constitution, which will also be a referendum for or against the European Union, and it will be the case, I hope, as soon as possible, of course, for the French.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI). Mr President, at the forthcoming Council meeting, the Heads of State will once again deal with serious issues. But on the basis of the behaviour of the European Union so far, the question arises: do they have the will to deal with these issues in a way that serves the interests of their peoples? And if so, do they have the ability to do so? Does the European Union, for example, have the option of forcing Turkey to stop sending illegal immigrants to Greece? Can the European Union apply the quota to the distribution of migrants in all the countries of Europe, so that Greece ceases to be a place of accumulation of impoverished and poor people? Does the European Union have the possibility of forcing Turkey to recognise the Republic of Cyprus and stop blackmailing it? Does the European Union have the capacity and the will to implement a trade policy that will set aside multinational companies and support European industries, agricultural and agricultural products? Will it accept the TTIR agreement which is disastrous for Europe's interests? And finally, does it have the political courage to review its relations with Russia and to revise the policy it has been implementing so far and which has led to a deadlock in relations between the two countries, to the detriment of the interests of both countries? We will see in a few days whether logic will eventually prevail or obsessions and ideologies will prevail.

name: Herbert REUL
text: Mr President, Mr President of the Commission, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, I would like to thank the President-in-Office of the Council for his In difficult times, people expect politics to solve problems. There are no plans for what will happen in 100 years' time, but it does not help what the last speakers have done: eternal mockery of how bad the situation is and still deepening the problem. I am extremely grateful to the President of the Commission for once again making specific points today. Politics has something to do with the fact that politics also solves concrete problems. And it is now a matter of whether we in Parliament – we have made 27 000 different proposals again today – just like the Commission or how the Council is trying to focus on a few key points and prove to the people through political action that we can get them resolved. For example, on the refugee issue, we can talk about what is not yet possible. But you can also say. This with the Turkey agreement is already a great success. Not tens of thousands but 86, that is progress. That does not mean that everything is done. And question 2: how can we then achieve solidarity in Europe, which means that everyone must also take in some refugees, some migrants? Perhaps it is also true, as the President of the Commission said, that flexibility should be built in so that everyone can go along with it. It is important, however, that everyone participates in this project. Or on the question of growth: there is no point in tinkering with industry here, but concrete conditions must be created for growth to be created. Or you have to say 'yes' to trade relations and contracts. You can't just chuckle at what's going wrong. We have to say in concrete terms that we are doing this now – with CETA and also in other negotiations. I found the reference, Mr Juncker, extremely helpful as to what has been created in terms of jobs through the South Korean trade agreement. This is the reality when it is done, and when it is not just stupid. For me, this also includes the question of how we deal with real violations of human rights or the killing of people in the world. I am deeply infuriated that there is no outcry in this shop about what is happening in Syria. I am very grateful to Manfred Weber and the other colleagues for mentioning it by their name. We make a minute of remembrance here for every time we do it. Hundreds of thousands are being slaughtered, and we are not saying that this will not continue, nor are we showing the Russians the red card. What kind of morality is that if we simply carry on here as if nothing had happened? Concrete action, values – you can talk about this, or concrete values can be demonstrated concretely by acting. I expect more concrete trade policy and therefore: thank you to the President of the Commission.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: – Mr President, at the beginning of his speech, Mr Juncker stressed that, for the first time, the State of the Union address was held in Bratislava; it is important that, from now on, not only are the speeches held, but that the measures proposed by the Commission are put in place. I believe that, from Bratislava, the unsatable thing about the Declaration is the last point. The time has come to execute what we have already agreed to. That is what is important, because what the Council has done so far has been to approve issues which the Member States have subsequently ignored. This is mostly important when it comes to emigration. Everything has been drifting towards safety; everything has been drifting towards preventing migrants from reaching our shores or our borders; everything has been arising towards matters that have to do with closing us outwards. All right, borders must be protected; Agree, we must give an answer in the places of origin from which refugees and migrants are generated so that they do not have to reach our shores, but we have to give an internal response, with solidarity, with integration and with relocation of those who are already with us. With regard to the economy, the European Council has not been engaged in the economic issue for a long time, but a week ago someone said that we are getting used to too low growth, for too long, for the benefit of too few. I'm not quoting anyone strange: I'm quoting Christine Lagarde. Yesterday, the International Monetary Fund noted that our growth next year will be lower than that of the international monetary fund, and that it will be lower than the previous year's. As long as we do not give answers in job creation, growing, on opportunities for our citizens, absolutely all crises will have a common fund: dissatisfaction with the results provided by the Union.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Mr President of the Commission, I would like to thank the Rapporteur, I think President Kamall was right to say that in relations with Russia you need more stick than carrots, because this carrot has grown into a big carrot and the stick has become a small stick. We must respect our own words and position. After Russia seized Crimea and de facto parts of eastern Ukraine, nothing changed. And if we are to be a serious partner, we should be consistent, including on this issue. When it comes to immigration, this issue should not and must not divide us. We may have different views, but let us draw up a common compromise position. It would be wrong if a temporary majority imposed any decisions on this issue by a temporary minority. I am very respecting of this, and I call for a solidarity position on this issue.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: – Mr President, the Council has increasingly become the bottleneck of European decision—making. We all understand, of course, that it is not easy to reach an agreement between 28 governments, but it is your duty to act and to move forward. Not only European citizens have a right to expect determination, courage and vision from the Council – so do the people in Aleppo. I find it very difficult to explain to people in Aleppo that Europe is not acting because of treaty restrictions, national sovereignty and national electoral considerations. The Council said that we need to end the uncontrolled migration flows. Absolutely, but not by creating Fortress Europe, not by making shady deals with unsavoury regimes – of which we know there are more in the pipeline, and you call them statements rather than deals – nor by ignoring the explosive situation in Lebanon and Jordan, but by working speedily on the adoption of a fully—fledged Community asylum policy. The Commission proposals are on the table, and Parliament is ready to work speedily.  I would like to know if the Council is willing to work with Parliament to make sure that we have a package in place before the summer. You have shown urgency when it comes to passing security measures, and I would expect the same sense of urgency in adopting the asylum package.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is frankly baffled that the agreement with Turkey can be described in this House as a functioning agreement. We obviously see how many people do not arrive in the European Union how many people do not arrive in the European Union, without asking what is going on with those people who would probably have the right to have their right of asylum recognised. We do not wonder what the Erdogan Government does on a daily basis with repression in Turkey and the massacre of Kurdish women and men. I believe that this is shameful and we will not stop calling for humanitarian corridors to be financed instead. Let us turn to trade policy. There were very few of us in this House who said that TTIP should be blocked, while there were many of us outside this House who said that TTIP was dangerous. Now, at last, the European Commission will also have to be aware of this. But what do we do? We ratify COP21 and then ratify treaties such as CETA that contain energy neutrality clauses. I think that is a very great contradiction. Many studies now say that CETA would lead to the loss of 200 000 jobs in Europe alone. So we must stop TTIP, we must stop CETA, because this trade policy only harms the workers of the European Union and beyond.

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: Mr President, Mr President of the Commission, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, I would like to thank the President-in-Office of the Council for his I very much agree, Mr Juncker, when you say that we need a concrete programme. We have a specific programme! But when I hear Mr Korok, it seems to me that he has no idea what that means. I hear a roaring, triple emptiness: disorientation, lack of ideas and lack of drive. It is clear that, in order to restore confidence in this Union to the citizens of the European Union, we must at last move from the wrong austerity orientation to an investment orientation that we have been fighting for so long. We have been fighting for two years, Mr President, for this paradigm shift. This is central to the agenda of our specific programme. And, of course, you are right to strengthen internal and external security together. This includes continuing to act reliably against tax privileges and tax evasion. This includes not being satisfied, Mr Weber, with 19% youth unemployment. And that includes refugee policy. It's all easy to describe. However, I believe that we will only be able to achieve this if we are able to take whole heart on the guiding idea that you formulated in your state of the union speech, namely that it is a question of defending the European way of life. We must defend this internally and externally. That is the common guiding principle. Defending him internally means, for example, defending women's rights, where this is necessary in Poland. And defending him to the outside world, Mr Weber, means that we are not now scolding any other people, but that together we are making sure that we do not use Nord Stream 2 Putin to put extra money into the coffers with which he can continue to wage war in Syria. Let's stop this Nord Stream 2 project together! (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr Bütikofer, I would like to thank Mr Bütikofer for his excellent You deplore the austerity policy that should be abolished, and instead you want investment. After all, we have the Juncker package: EUR 315 billion. More than 100 billion of this has already been invested. And we also have the southern countries, which all have debts. Mr Juncker is very lenient with Spain, Portugal and France – all of them have a deficit of more than 3%. My question is: why does this not work? What do you want to invest even more and save less?

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I think you are succumbing to a misunderstanding, sir. When I talk about investment, I am talking first and foremost not only about public investment, but also, in particular, about private investment. And we must ensure that the framework conditions are set sensibly so that these private investments are made in the transformation of our European economies towards an efficient, ecologically innovative and generally competitive economy. I believe that the framework conditions for this cannot now be described in thirty seconds, but that there is still a lot missing. I have expressly praised the President for his initiative. But if you look at the Member States, you have to say that the message has still not arrived there. Berlin is one of the capitals that still do not understand it.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: – Mr President, there are only a few observations. The first is on migrants. Today, it is clear that the people of European countries do not accept the quota policy. And Hungary, regardless of how we assess the outcome of the referendum, will not accept migrants, as will some other European Union countries. Will the European Parliament and the European Council find the courage to recognise that quota policy has suffered an absolute fiasco? Is there enough determination to understand that the only effective means of dealing with and the problems that come with migration is external border and internal border controls? Secondly, on the Treaty on America and the European Union. Neither the President's name nor the terms of the election campaign can be an excuse to close their eyes to a treaty that will open up the export of unsafe food, chemical and other products to their countries to the people of Europe. The calls to speed up negotiations, in which the aspirations of the parties are so far diametrically opposed and for which no country is compromised, is another irresponsible example of the policy that we have today galore. And thirdly, for the future. Dialogue and dialogue alone are a prerequisite for the continued existence of the European Union. I am not just talking about this treaty here. Dialogue, not confrontation, is necessary both after Hungary and after the British referendums. That dialogue is no less necessary when America and Russia terminate negotiations on a possible peace process in Syria. It is the initiator of the dialogue that should become the European Union in this respect, trying to put both sides together at the table of tripartite or four-party negotiations. (The speaker agrees to answer the blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Liisa JAAKONSAARI
text: blue card question. – You talked about immigration, but we usually confuse the asylum crisis with the refugee crisis with the free movement within Europe, which I personally consider important.  Are you prepared to promote intra-European immigration, for example, so that the posting of workers directive enters into force and people do not get the feeling that mobility will also increase labour dumping? Are you ready to look for these drugs?

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: answer to the blue card question. - Thank you for your question. Of course, the free movement of people is one of europe's four complex freedoms, and I think this is a positive concept, but I do not see a limit and I do not see the end of the reception of those tens or even more millions of people from other countries where we do nothing to create armed conflicts and people from their own country should flee.

name: Marcel de GRAAFF
text: – The european council's agenda once again includes the issue of migration, and rightly so. Migration is destroying the Member States. It destroys our culture, our prosperity and our physical security.  With the flow of migrants, thousands of jihadists have come along. These soldiers of Allah are waiting like sleeping cells for the signal to carry out devastating attacks in the EU. It is now clear that these terrorist units have weapons of war.  The European Council must listen to Viktor Orbán. He recognises the danger and he deserves our full support and support. That is why the EU and the Member States must take the following effective measures: Frontex must stop as a ferry service to pick up jihadists and other migrants in North Africa, the internal and external borders must be completely closed to this invasion and the invading settlers must be returned without mercy.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - Mr Juncker! Dear colleagues, What happened in Hungary in the sense of public law? The Hungarian Government has decided to prevent the European Union from deploying migrants into our country without the authority of our Parliament. It could have gone through legislation with minimal opposition support. He installed a "checks and balances," a power-limiting element, a referendum. And he said that if the people still believe that they want to support the European Union's migration policy, then by taking on the legal obligation, they will back down and not make the legislative amendments or constitutional amendments originally envisioned. The threshold of validity would have been relevant here, if more than 50% had gone, and most of them said yes to the European Union's migration policy, the Hungarian Government would have been obliged under the law to refrain from its original idea. But that is not what happened, but you have been given a huge political mandate to go against you, so please do not misunderstand the situation. Hungary has launched a path that will change your ideas and keep Europe free and independent because it is Hungary lover.

name: Janusz LEWANDOWSKI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioners, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. Let me start by reacting to the words of Mrs Le Pen, who said that Poland is turning away from the European Union. If more than 80% of Poles are invariably, continuously and firmly in favour of the European Union, it means that Mrs Le Pen (already absent) has detached herself from reality. Every summit of the European Union, at a time of ebb and flow of faith in the meaning of being together, a crisis of confidence and a return of fear for the future, is both an opportunity to rebuild trust and a risk of exposing and deepening divisions. So this is a very serious test of european leaders' responsibility not only for the message to a country that is typical: "How much have I won, how bravely have I fought for national interests?" but also: "What common European prescription have I found for common problems that outgrow the capabilities of a single country?" And it's about specifics, not about more political announcements.  The agenda of this forthcoming summit perfectly illustrates both the opportunity and the temptation to reveal differences in areas such as migration, trade and relations with Russia. Of course, the most difficult area for finding a European compromise is migration, because here are the greatest havoc, here the most xenophobia and populism govern, manage people's fears and emotions. What is needed here is the most concrete thing that builds a common European sense of security. There are things in the workshop that are not controversial: aid to Bulgaria or agreements with third countries, but for example, this automatic system of reallocation of refugees is probably not the way to find a common European solution.  Finally, a word about Russia. This, unfortunately, Dear Ms. Zimmer, is again an evil empire. I say this with regret as a lover of Russian music and literature. Who is not convinced by donbass, Georgia, Crimea, this should convince Syria.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: – Mr President, we know very well that the European Union needs a better roadmap, providing better European solutions. This Parliament was able to adopt a strategic resolution with a clear outline of these better European solutions. We also recognise that President Juncker, in his State of the Union speech, delivered a promising perspective on how to build up these better European solutions. Nevertheless, we have to say that the roadmap which was sketched out in the Bratislava summit was behind and below what is really needed. We need to be clear on the scope of better European solutions. When it comes to migration, we need to have European borders and we need to go to the root of the problems, but we also need to host and distribute refugees. We cannot just ignore this: the problem is still there. Secondly, when it comes to trade, we do of course need to be open to trade, but we also need to protect our social standards. Most of all, when we put forward better European solutions to cope with the external challenges, we need to take care of the internal economic and social cohesion of Europe. This has to do with growth, jobs, investment and completing the economic and monetary union in such a way that we again have upward convergence. If we do not tackle this problem, we do not have the necessary conditions to move forward with citizens supporting the European Union. So I very much hope that you can use the next meetings of the European Council to put Europe on the right track regarding this better roadmap.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the We are currently lumping together all sorts of people and calling them migrants. This includes civil war refugees, poverty migrants, but also qualified workers. We urgently need a clear demarcation of these concepts, which must then also be applied politically. Europe must, of course, help with the refugees fleeing civil war, but not as it is currently doing. The young men who made their way to Europe are recognised as refugees. But would it not be more human eased if the EU cared for the really needy – women, children, the elderly and the sick – and not so much for the people who fought their way into Europe against the law?  We must recognise that Russia will not drop the Assad government. Nor are there any moderate rebels interested in a post-war democratic Syria. So a military victory by either side against the Assad regime would not bring any progress. It would make sense for the EU to reflect on its diplomatic traditions, not to let the talks with Russia break down and to have Russia come up with a proposal on what a post-war Syrian order might look like.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: – Mr President, I have a few points of reaction. The agenda for the European Council is right, but if we look at migration we will want to see what the progress really is, and next time we would like to listen to the evaluation of the progress and the timetable. I do not think we will be credible with common defence if we are not able to implement what we have decided and if we are not able to decide what the Commission has proposed, and that is of course still subject to debate. Second, on trade: yes to TTIP, yes to CETA, and – as Jean-Claude Juncker has said – yes to defence instruments. We need to upgrade those so yes, we need to be defensive on dumping steel, but there are solid arguments for CETA and TTIP to go ahead. Finally, on Russia: we will have a strategic debate. We would like to see a strategic debate, but I do not want to see the yellow card that has been mentioned. Too many yellow cards – Mr Putin does not understand yellow cards. We want to see a red card, and then, when he reflects, he may come back to the game again. But I think that we need to show that we have a clear conception, we have a clear strategy, and what is happening today in Syria is totally unacceptable in the civilised world.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: – Mr President, the Commission and the Council intend the CETA, the Agreement negotiated by the European Union and Canada, to enter into force and start to apply before it has been voted on in each of the States of the European Union, that is, they first shoot and then ask. CETA, like TTIP, is not a trade treaty, but is a treaty to alter our legislation, our labour rights, health and environmental standards; which will seriously affect the agricultural sector, small and medium-sized enterprises and which also establishes an arbitration system that places multinationals above Parliaments. Almost nothing.  Faced with this assault on democracy and our rights, we will be found in this House saying "no" to CETA; but, above all, they will find us on the streets, organized in this autumn in resistance.

name: Jordi Vicent SEBASTIA TALAVERA
text: – Mr President, I have heard the representative of the Council say that we must reduce the number of 'irregular migrants', and he has used this expression; and then Mr Juncker say that the agreement between the European Union and Turkey is working.  What does this mean? It means that the physical barriers, the police barriers, the legal barriers we've put to those who try to flee the war, those who try to survive, are working. It means that Europe has abandoned them; who does not recognize them as refugees; that does not give them asylum, which is one of our fundamental rules. These are not the European values that fill our mouths so much, for which I am here and those I want to defend. I've also heard of trade. The representative of the Council says that trade always creates profits. Benefits to whom? If we do not regulate that trade, what grows, the profits, reach the bank accounts that then appear on the Panama papers. Trade has to be regulated, and we have to have the same conditions. I liked that Mr Juncker would ask for more support from our steel industry. I would like you to also remember agricultural producers, those who face products coming from other countries that do not respect our legislation.

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr We are seeing refugee flows that are not declining in any way, and a large part of the reason for this is the situation in Syria. We are seeing an increasingly aggressive Russia, which, together with Assad, has literally bombed the democratic forces that existed to crumbs. After all, this action leaves the people with only two options: to choose between Assad and Russia or IS. Of course this is what Assad wants to achieve in order to stay in power in Syria.  Russia considers itself to be acting in the name of democracy, but when it indiscriminately places bomb mats over hospitals and civilians, then it is not in the name of democracy that action is taken. Then you're part of the terror that makes people flee. Europe must do what it can to get Russia to withdraw. Democracy and peace are in no way benefiting from Russia's actions, and the countries of Europe must also make this clear. In my party, we are very clear in our criticism of Putin's actions.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Once again, there is a Council debate under discussion here, once again it is the same issues that are being discussed here, and once again there are no solutions. Mass unemployment, social degradation across Europe, the problem of migratory flows linked to terrorism moving to the continent, etc.  But what really concerns the House is a very different question. The question is: who will be the future president? The race takes place between the Social Democrat Schulz on the one hand, who realizes that he cannot flee to Germany for the candidacy and wants to keep this post, and on the other hand the conservatives, who also tremble for power, for posts, for money and for influence. I say that it is completely irrelevant who of the two will become the future President, because both belong to the same EU adoration association and nothing changes in the matter. And against this background, it is more than bad to do badly, for example, to make the referendum in Hungary bad, if you put your head in the sand in The United Kingdom, if you do not serve solutions here in the face of mass migration and the problems. I call for a fundamental U-turn on this policy, otherwise you will use this policy to drive the whole of the European Union against the wall. And nobody here wants that.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: NI). Mr President, developments in the European Union are really dense. What do we see? An arena of sharp rivalries, Brexit, underground conflicts, groupings of states. Further European integration, but also centrifugal trends at the same time. Poverty and unemployment everywhere, of course. Competition with China, with the United States - where the transatlantic agreement encounters difficulties, with Russia - where the Union's intervention in Ukraine has repercussions and sanctions weigh on the backs of the peoples of the Union. On the refugee issue, the European Union is not just weak. She consciously refuses to confront the victims of her interventions, the refugees.  With the Joint Military Headquarters it is escalating its interventions in favour of the major interests, multiplying the refugees and trapping them in Greece, reinforcing nationalism, racism and fascists. The situation carries the risk of a general conflict, the victims of which will not be those who incite competition, but the people. Conclusion: it was a great mistake to hope that with the current, more flexible, political situation the situation will change. The common denominator is always the attack on the peoples, inside and outside the Union, which will escalate as the capitalist crisis deepens. The European Union is not getting better, it is only getting worse. Solution: popular indignation become a class struggle for subversion.

name: Alain LAMASSOURE
text: Mr President, as far as migration policy is concerned, the main thing remains to be done. The agreement with Turkey is effective, but it only deals with Syrian refugees. In the meantime, the flow from Africa through Libya - as you well know, Mr President - has picked up again. These migrants now come mainly from West Africa, which is generally at peace, and no longer from countries at war, such as Somalia or Sudan, so controlling migration flows requires that the problem be dealt with upstream at European level. It starts with a common foreign policy: a policy of partnership with the countries of departure and transit, if they are at peace, and a policy of peacemaking, if they are in civil war. Then we need a European border guard corps. It is beginning to take place, but it must be a permanent body that is not limited to partial reinforcements in times of acute crisis. Then the time has come to imagine a new kind of European solidarity to help the most geographically exposed Member States. Authoritarian relocation, definitely, it doesn't work! But there may be other forms of solidarity - true solidarity, as the President of the Commission says - in the form, for example, of a contribution of staff, equipment or money to the implementation of the asylum policy. We can then begin to devise a common policy for economic migrants, based on quotas by country of origin and host country. All legal tools are now available. Will the twenty-seven have the political will to use it? (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: "blue card" question. Mr Lamassoure, we have one thing in common: like you, I am committed to helping Africa to persuade Africans to stay at home and thus avoid increasing the mass of economic migrants. In this regard, Mr Juncker has announced measures. What do you think? On the one hand, does the figure of EUR 88 billion seem reasonable to you and, on the other hand, are you not concerned that nothing concrete has been done to accompany this announcement? It is not clear under what conditions the $88 billion will be paid. Thank you for your response.

name: Alain LAMASSOURE
text: "blue card" answer. Thank you for this question, which is very relevant.  My personal position on the development aid issue is that we are making a considerable waste of this aid. The European budget spends about EUR 9 billion a year on development cooperation, and this is added to a figure almost ten times higher, which is the addition of national aid from the 28 countries to development cooperation.  I think it is time to better coordinate and focus this aid on the countries that need it most, with political conditions; we do not dare to include them in treaties, and when, by chance, we enter them, we do not dare to apply them.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: – Dear Plenum, the summit in 14 days must not become another missed opportunity. Migration – great to have a European border guard, but consider what even the most impermeable borders and fences will help us if we have within the borders of a country, such as Hungary, which sells residence permits for oily earnings. Immoral, quite discriminatory, and it me off that we have such hypocratic practices. What is happening in Syria has crossed the boundaries of understanding. Ban Ki-moon has labelled the situation in Aleppo worse than a slaughterhouse. Where is the European Union, while Russia slaughters innocent people with the Syrian government and rejects peace in Syria? Whose interests are followed by the international community and whose interests the European Union is following, this is what citizens expect. In our midst, in the meantime, many other things are happening that require immediate action. From referendums, the content of which cannot be honoured, to the harsh and direct repression of women's rights, which many in the Union so like to blame for muslim newcomers. We have major economic challenges, starting with preparing businesses for new business with the UK, we need to complete the challenges of tax laws, we need to make sure people work and pay. And words, colleagues, unfortunately, can't be eaten.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: – The Bratislava Summit wanted to be a significant event, but it has already been said that the leaders see it as a missed chance or as an own goal. I think the leaders' meeting was overshadowed by prime minister Robert Fico's unfortunate statement when, as Prime Minister of Slovakia, he threatened to veto Britain's withdrawal from the Union. Let me say here that I consider such a statement to be inadequate. I am not in the position of the Slovak Government, it is not for me, but as an ordinary citizen, I think it is necessary to make an apology for such a statement, for two reasons. Prime Minister Fico said here, in his opening speech at the start of the Slovak Presidency, that he would propose solutions that are good for the Member States, both for the Member States and for the EU as a whole, and that tense relations with Britain or various quarrels certainly fit not well with such an agenda. Secondly, what makes national politicians two-faced when pro-Union statements here in Brussels alternate strong anti-Russian rhetoric at home. Only anger in people, just misunderstanding and alienation of the idea of cooperation between European nations, and eventually populism and extremism will grow. I therefore call on European leaders to give up such populism at the next meeting and, in the words of Donald Tusk, to enter into brutal sincerity.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: – Mr President, the Council has spoken little, but it has made it very clear. He uses the words "irregular migration" to tell us that he has frozen the soul of Europe. There is no longer a refugee crisis.  Mr Juncker has told us that post-Dublin is established, that the time for flexible solidarity is put in the way. Unfortunately, when flexible solidarity is imploding, what is being said is that flexible insolidarity will be tolerated. Mr. Timmermans, you have the opportunity to rebel in the face of this. For the Council there is no Aleppo, there are no bombed-out hospitals, there are no out-of-school children – six years! – in Jordan, in Turkey, in Lebanon. 108 million for Bulgarian borders, yes, and only 191 million to school Syrian children in Lebanon — 250,000 out of school. Those children from Moria, those children from Turkey, those children from Lebanon and Jordan will make us pay for it. If it's not out of solidarity, let's do it out of interest. Let's rebel!

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, you will talk about refugees again, but I do not know whether you are really looking for solutions. I wonder if you're going to go to the root of the crisis, talking about the first enemy in Syria, ISIS, Al Qaeda, and imagining a relationship with Moscow as an alternative to the disorder that reigns in the United States. On the one hand the breakdown of dialogue, on the other the wisdom of Jimmy Carter. Crucial is a Russian-American co-leadership, despite the very serious Russian violence in Aleppo. I do not even know how you are going to discuss the Hungarian referendum. If Orban convinces you that it is an invalid referendum, he will make it valid with more walls. But I know one thing: if we do not start to organise coexistence with refugees, the exit will eat our brains, because the exit is fear, renunciation, nationalism, it is paying dictators to keep the fugitives, Eritrea, Sudan and now Afghanistan. It is the end of the Union, that borders should protect them, but in order to be better able to reopen them.

name: Kristina WINBERG
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Leaders in Europe, such as Angela Merkel, Stefan Löfven and Jean-Claude Juncker, believed that we could afford over a million migrants. Anyone who came to Europe would quickly get into work and save us from alleged demographic challenges. Experts said the influx of migrants will lead to an economic miracle, where they could just jump into the workplace and start working without any longer training. How'd it go? For example, together, Germany's 30 largest listed companies had been able to employ only 63 migrants, according to figures published this summer by the Reuters news agency. It is high time to start talking about priorities of resources. The amount that only Sweden spends on migrants, most of them economic migrants, could have financed the entire UNHCR budget twice over. Unfortunately, this doesn't work anymore. Those of you who have largely created this crisis cannot have the confidence to resolve it.
