I do not want to hear any more excuses that the crisis could not have been foreseen. (The speaker agreed to answer a question (blue card) in accordance with Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: question ("blue card"). Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Neither Stefan Löfven nor Angela Merkel have created the crisis. It has been created by brutal bombing, by terrorism that slaughters people, crucifies and enslaves. It is important to remember one thing: the countries that have received the most refugees in recent years have also been able to reconcile this with the best economic development in the European Union, so Mrs Winberg is wrong on this point.  I'd like to ask her a question. People are fleeing from bombings, rapes, slavery, executions. We have seen how Assad has murdered half a million people. You just said a million refugees is too much. How many refugees do you think we should accept? Or do you want to let people die where they are?

name: Kristina WINBERG
text: answer ("blue card"). Perhaps you did not hear that I also mentioned that we must prioritise the resources we have. I think it is far more important to help real refugees in camps where they suffer from a shortage of supplies. You heard me say here that the amount we spend on migrants in Sweden could cover the UNHCR budget twice over. It is about prioritising the right and helping as many people as possible.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which With all the conceptual cosmetics that we are now hearing, at least from the ranks of the Christian Democrats in this House, I can say that, in terms of content, there are still major differences between what the AfD represents and what the Social Democrats and Christian Democrats represent here. We are clearly opposed to CETA and TTIP, in order to protect German small and medium-sized enterprises. On the issue of migration, Mr Reul said today that the fact that fewer refugees are now coming to Europe thanks to the Turkey deal is a step forward. These are completely new tones from the CDU. Bearing in mind that the mere fact that fewer refugees are coming to Germany is now supposed to be an advantage, it completely ignores the way in which this is happening in Turkey and at what cost in Turkey. At this point, the EU is supporting a totalitarian state under Mr Erdogan, and the development that this will lead to for minorities in Turkey, particularly in the coming years, is worrying. And then one last thing: Russia and Syria. They completely forget that in everything Assad does, his opponents are far more criminal. And you are supporting them by rushing against Syria and Mr Putin at this point.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: – Mr President, Brexit has shown us that the European project is not irreversible. Since then, we have been baffled and have not had a common answer. Some avoid responding on the grounds that the procedure has not yet been initiated; others try to reduce everything to the European Council and return to bilateral relations; others threaten the Union, or blackmail the Union, with new brexit. You will know why, but I do not see European politicians defending the Union with the same passion with which English populists defend Brexit. I think British populists are taking political initiative. The European Union is not a fact. It's still a process. It's under construction. The truth is that it is a dream that has not yet been fulfilled, and I ask you when this project ceased to be exciting. The ancient distinction between Europe and non-Europe has been replaced by another between Europe and anti-Europe. Non-Europe supporters discussed our solutions. Anti-Europe supporters discuss our values; anti-Europe supporters fight our values; anti-Europe supporters defend opposing values. You will know, but there is only one way out of this crisis, which is to restore European solidarity; solidarity between countries suffering from the refugee crisis and those that do not; solidarity between those who suffer the Russian threat and those who do not; solidarity between those who suffer unemployment and those who do not; solidarity between those who are suffering the consequences of the euro having an unfinished architecture and those who are not. Brexit is the most insolidary proposal in contemporary history in Europe. All that looks like brexit is insolidarity, even if it only resembles brexit from afar. Only by rebuilding solidarity will we build Europe, because insolidarity, whatever we call it, is anti-Europe.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Let me make two comments on what Mr Juncker said this morning in the first place. When we talk about migration and when we talk about how we want to prevent migration in the future, it is, of course, primarily a question of helping the countries affected to improve the living conditions of their citizens. This includes the many funds that we have, and that includes – perhaps you take this opportunity – for the Heads of Government to talk about having to fill these funds, and not just the EU coffers and a very few.  The Afghanistan Conference is currently meeting in Brussels. This is a concrete example of how to try to help a country so that people no longer have to run away. And it is also true that the EU Commission has agreed with the country that it must take back refugees. But I do not think that the two things can be combined. You can't say we're giving you money to make people better off, but if you don't take back our refugees, we're not giving you the money to make them worse off and want to get even more. We have to be very careful that there is no link.  My second point, and very briefly on Russia, is that you have initiated strategic discussions on our relationship with Russia, and we really need them very much! That is roughly the opposite of what Mr Weber has done here this morning. I agree with his analysis: of course it is impossible, and of course I am also angry about what is happening in Aleppo and about other things – you could list a lot. But it cannot be just a matter of determining who is good and who is evil. Then the discussion begins on how we deal with each other, and I think that is important. But we also need to talk to each other about this.

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: – Mr President, as part of the Council's prepared agenda, I would like to comment on one item on the agenda, namely EU trade policy. At present, many topics are as if the media overshadowed the seriousness of future trade relations with the European Union. I am one of those who consider trade agreements with America and Canada to be very crucial for the future. I therefore very much dislike the downplaying and dissemination of information called into question the possibility of concluding these agreements. I think that it is at this time of the US presidential election campaign and all the overlapping migration problems in Europe that it is important to clearly declare a fundamental interest in the sensible completion of the common agreements. If the top political representation of the European Union and the Member States does not push this process forward, I am concerned that the chances of signing these trade agreements in the future will be many times smaller. Business activities will then be taken over by Asian companies, which will reap the benefits of already functioning Trans-Pacific Partnership agreements.

name: Charles GOERENS
text: Mr President, in 20 years' time, with the necessary hindsight, it will no doubt be said that 2016 was the year of all dangers. It will no doubt be said that the most reactionary heads of state or government have prevented Europe from behaving in solidarity in the face of the refugee crisis. It will no doubt be said that, at the meetings of the European Council, those who wanted to move forward had to caress in the direction of the hair those who played with fire or who did not oppose anything relevant to the threat of collapse of the European edifice. It will no doubt be said that populists, even in the highest spheres of power, have led those responsible to bow to the leaders of third countries that have already ushered in the post-democratic era.  For some, in 2016, our leaders will have succeeded in closing the gaps. If, in 2035, we can say that we had to stoop to this point and then to return to our fundamental values and with the principle of an ever closer European Union, we may be able to better judge the poor state in which Europe finds itself in 2016. And mitigating circumstances can only be argued to the extent that this unglamorous period of our history has finally given new impetus to European integration.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: – Mr President, yesterday we were witnessing a surreal debate on Greece, in which it defended, once again, to deepen the same policies that have brought the Greek people into the abyss.  You continue to insist on the same roadmap that causes unemployment, precariousness and ruins entire countries and regions, and which forces our young people to emigrate. Threaten Spain and Portugal with sanctions; desoy their cry and mobilizations across Europe against transatlantic free trade agreements and bring us back here an agreement like CETA, which contains the same antisocial logic as TTIP.  You present to us as good the Treaty of Shame with Turkey, a treaty denounced by all humanitarian organizations and which has resulted in more and more people dying in the Mediterranean: 24% more this year than the previous one.  The xenophobic policies of fortress Europe are making the Mediterranean the largest mass grave in the world. Who do you think can identify with this bureaucratic rights-crushing machine in which you have turned the European Union? Fewer Interrail tickets and more policy change! This is what can change Europe and let people stop wanting to leave this European Union. It is in our hands: let us change our policies, change Europe.

name: Tim AKER
text: – Mr President, it has been over 100 days since the United Kingdom and 72% of my constituents in Thurrock voted to leave the European Union, and let’s look at what happened: project Fear has unravelled, countries are rushing to do trade deals with the United Kingdom, and our prospects look better. But people are coming up to me and asking, ‘Well, why haven’t we left yet? What’s stopping them?’ The answer is quite simple. Rule number one: never trust a Tory. Rule number two: obey rule number one. Our newly unelected Prime Minister isn’t an Iron Lady: she is tinfoil Theresa May. And just look at her record. When she was Home Secretary, she oversaw mass immigration that would have made the Labour Party wince. She voted for Remain. She oversaw policies that squeezed the working classes the most. She cannot deliver the deal that the British people voted for. And the message is clear: tear up the European Communities Act, get our borders back, and get our fisheries back. We voted to get our country back, and by God, we will get it back.

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: – Free trade can be a source of economic growth and economic prosperity even on a global scale, but the principle must not be applied with naivety.  We recently had a discussion in Flanders about the partial Chinese acquisition of our energy distribution network. As independent Member States and as a European continent, we must dare to put our own interests first and use our own cultural identity as a starting point and dare to see it as a force.  We, like the Chinese, must activate our own capital and protect our key sectors from aggressive interference without reciprocity. We must replace a lack of vigilance with a belief in ourselves, an active industrialisation policy and sensible economic patriotism.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have to say that Today I was very sorry that both the Council and the Commission did not mention either the Mediterranean or Italy. Yet, two weeks ago Europol stressed that Italy is preferential access for immigration and, also a fortnight ago, Martin Kobler, head of the UN mission in Libya, sounded the alarm, said that 235 000 migrants are ready to leave Libya for Italy, and they will do so. These days we see the numbers. Monday was the day dedicated to the memory of the victims of immigration. On that very day the sea was calm and more than 6 000 people arrived in Italy and in the following hours 4 655 people were recovered at sea, more than 10 000 in two days. We have exceeded last year's level and Italy is the only one in contrast because, while in all the other countries we see a reduction in arrivals, in Italy there is an increase, we have exceeded 150 000 arrivals.  I would have liked to have heard what Martin Kobler said in this House, because Martin Kobler pointed out that trafficking in human beings is a crime and as such must be combated, that legality must be re-established. We need strong and unified action. We cannot have a Europe that simply talk about quotas for refugees to be relocated, we cannot have a Europe that simply increases resources for rescue missions at sea. We need to develop global crisis management proposals. We need answers based on true solidarity at European level.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: Mr President, I regret that we are preparing the European Council without its President.  Mr Council representative, you are going to talk about foreign trade at this meeting. Learn from what happened in Bratislava. At that summit, we talked about defence and, immediately after that, the United Kingdom — the country that decided to leave the European Union — said that we were not allowed to go in that direction. In the area of foreign trade, you must use this European Council to move forward on the issues that concern us. The implementation of a trade defence instrument is a major issue. You must also look at what happened, precisely, in this vote in the United Kingdom: this vote makes it very clear that those who had been sold free trade, practiced unbridledly, as a source of wealth, found themselves on the side of the road and refused this unbridled free trade. That is why you need to rethink the Union's trade policy so that it serves the interests of Europeans and our needs for solidarity with Africa. We are counting on you, but don't forget the lessons of Bratislava.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: We remember the EU-Turkey agreement and the creation of the EU's new border and coastguard. For the first time, concrete steps were taken with regard to the application of European return rules. Through the agreement with Turkey, Greece finally reversed the rules on safe third countries. These rules stipulate that asylum seekers who were effectively safe abroad in advance – including Turkey, Lebanon and Jordan – will no longer be able to apply for asylum in Europe. Frontex was also given full powers to carry out return operations for the first time as a border control agency.  In a few weeks' time, European leaders will meet again and I hope that they will discuss the effective application of existing European asylum legislation. I am now calling on you to talk about anti-drowning agreements, such as the EU-Turkey agreement, with all the countries around the Mediterranean. As soon as the legal possibility is available, Frontex can also send back asylum seekers in respect of those countries who are merely seeking out the European social welfare state.

name: Urmas PAET
text: – Mr President, the European Council will also discuss EU-Russia relations. Since the restrictive measures against Russia were introduced in 2014, nothing has changed for the better with regard to Russian actions in Ukraine. The sanctions must remain in place until the reasons they were introduced are gone. The Minsk agreements, of course, must be implemented, and the Council should not forget the MH17 flight catastrophe. The European Council also needs to address the issue of Russian Duma elections in the Russian—occupied Crimea and produce a clear vision on how it plans to handle those Duma deputies that are considered elected from Crimea. Also, I would once again like to point to the fact that the EU must have one voice when talking to Russia. The Commission and the External Action Service should therefore represent the EU common position in relations with Russia.

name: György SCHÖPFLIN
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European Mr. Secretary, I'm sorry. Mr. Vice President, I'm sorry. Migration, but obviously there's not much new to be said about migration. I've been listening to what's been said, but I haven't heard much new. Fundamentally, the left loves immigration and strongly condemns those who maintain migration processes. This attitude is repeated. It begs the question, why? What's the explanation for all this repetition? I get the impression, over and over again, that the left does not want to hear dissenting opinions. In fact, when you encounter one of these, you'd rather boo them, rule them out. Of course, it's easier that way. So you don't have to deal with reality, with the world that changes every day. But if a political force neglects, ignores the concerns of citizens, European citizens about migration, ignores their diminishing sense of security, then it should not be surprised that more and more people are rejecting left-wing values and looking elsewhere in the political field for a solution, a way out. It is hoped that the forthcoming summit will focus on the diminishing sense of security of citizens and not on the empty points of the left. (The speaker agrees to answer a blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: "blue card" question. "My dear colleague, I do not know where you come from with the certainty that we would be in favour of immigration. You'll have misunderstood us. We are opposed to the forced exile of this immigration, given the economic policies that apply. However, we take note of your advice on how to communicate.  It's amazing that you believe these things; they have nothing to do with reality. How do you explain that you can believe it, when we say otherwise?  Immigration is forced exile. This forced exile is the result of the economic policies and war policies that you are constantly supporting in this Chamber.

name: György SCHÖPFLIN
text: blue-card answer. – Having once been a refugee myself, I actually do know what I am talking about. I think there is a very clear distinction to be made – which you have not made, and which others do not make – between asylum seekers, genuine refugees, and economic migrants. They are a very different kettle of fish.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The forthcoming summit is a summit like any other in recent years: a lot of open construction sites, and once again the Heads of State or Government will deal with the refugee crisis and migration. Once again, the problems will be described and lamented in detail. Once again, after the summit, Heads of State or Government will appear before the cameras and tell their national public that they are right and the others wrong.  I would like it to be different this time. I would like it to finally be recognised that we can only move forward with something common and that it is not a question of having justice, but of pragmatic solutions. The tasks are clear: to stabilise the regions of origin by ending conflicts and dramatic imbalances, to protect common borders and, above all, to relocate.  This problem is not solved by looking away. We need pragmatic solidarity. The best possible support for Greece is if we give the people who are stuck here a new home in the willing countries, and there are positive approaches to this. We need to speed up this process, and we need the courage to act by moving towards creating humanitarian entry corridors to curb smuggling and by taking measures to ensure that people can finally stay in their homeland. Commitments are not enough. It is about concrete projects and real money.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: – Mr President, I would basically begin by saying this: with the fact that the United States is busy with its presidential elections, Europe has increased responsibilities in the Syrian crisis and it is unthinkable that the Council will not deal with this issue, of course, on migration, but essentially on the subject of the tragedy that is taking place throughout Syria and in particular in Aleppo.  Secondly, it is strange that, especially after the announcement made by the British Prime Minister - and in particular after the speech she made - Europe does not have the issue of Brexit in this Council, not to advance negotiations, but to make it very clear to the Prime Minister that after the speech she has given and the guidelines she has given, Europe will have to be fully united with a complete intransigence as to those who are the principles and values of the European Union, in particular, on the freedom of movement of persons and on the four freedoms that are part of the internal market, of the single market. Finally, I believe that it is also very important to give a strong signal to Russia because of its involvement in Syria and that strong signal that needs to be given must be a signal that shows that here in this Parliament the far left and, in particular the far right, are on Russia's side and are therefore complicit in the tragedy that is taking place in Syria.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is difficult, even for an optimistic European like myself, to hope that something good can come from the next Council, after the scorching disappointment in Bratislava. Other than small steps, you were perfectly still. And to stand still after Brexit, in my opinion, is to go back, dangerously backwards. We have seen a Council without the will to lead together and show solidarity in the face of problems. So I would like to remind this Council of some data, some of which have already been mentioned by my colleague: tens of thousands of people saved in a few days, 280 000 people, human lives, human beings who have arrived since January, and I would like to point out more than 15 %, it is also said of 20 %, of unaccompanied minors, girls and children sent alone, sent alone to a possible future. I think it's an extreme gesture of love from parents. So, in the face of all this, where is Europe? But above all, and I say this with great passion, where is the Council? Because the Commission and Parliament have done something, they have put programmes and projects on the table. I believe that we really must take decisions and implement them, forcing the States to be bound by this spirit of solidarity, in the face of the problems that affect Italy and Greece today, have touched other countries, but they could tomorrow manifest themselves in other forms for others and you will come to us to call for solidarity. The relocation plan must be taken up again because it is indispensable. You don't make the corridors if you don't make the plan, you don't do hot spots, every part is tied up. Above all, the plan for Africa, which Juncker mentioned this morning, must be taken up again, so that we can really try at least to get to the root of the problems.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for the work he has said. Having experienced Brexit, with the Hungarian referendum, with the uncertainty about CETA and TTIP in many Member States, I expect this Council to finally decide in a communiqué that all Member States will commit themselves to stand united on European co-responsibility from now on, to inform citizens about the European objectives, decisions and needs. instead of drawing the national map against Europe, instead of playing national, direct democracy against European parliamentary democracy. I expect you to state clearly that you are taking responsibility for the Community, instead of setting the mood against the European Union and then kneeling in front of it and playing with people's concerns and fears.  The European Union must become more capable of action. And the Council can make a contribution by deciding at each Council meeting on each of the issues raised today that will make the European Union more capable of acting towards its objectives. This would also be verifiable and would thus provide confidence and credibility. Yes, I am in favour of the Africa-EFSI for the Africa Marshall Plan. But it is a drop in the ocean if we do not have a common foreign, security and defence policy, a common investment policy, a common development policy, a common migration policy, a common external border protection and a common integration policy. The overall concept solves the problems, not an individual measure.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: – Mr President, brexit, paralysis in the face of a common immigration policy , the high point of which was last week's Hungarian referendum – is also the rejection of the main trade agreements currently being negotiated by the European Union, are the key points of the debate of the next European Council. And they all have a common denominator, which is also well exploited by populism, both left and right, which is a protectionist wave that strikes the European Union as a result of inequality and paralysis, lack of prospects for low growth, low wages and weakening of the social model. I therefore ask the Lords of the Council to take advantage of this meeting not to save one agreement or another, however important, but to end the causes that strike our societies: fear, inequality and uncertainty; ending inequality with more investment, increasing wages, as recently requested by the European Central Bank; also raise the tax burden for those who have the most, who inherit the most; make a fair fiscal policy to maintain the social model. We, as the European Union, must save the social model, and for this we must also take advantage of these debates, in order to get ahead of the substantive issues which today produce fear and uncertainty for European citizens. Only by addressing, as I say, the substantive issues will we be able to save a vision of solidarity and a vision of the future that gives certainty to societies, social justice and equal opportunities.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: – Mr President, the discussions about European policy versus Russia’s policy will be formative for the security of Europe, for the strength and respect of Europe, and also for Europe staying united and strong in the defence of the values of freedom and open society. A lot of people – and I am one of those – would like to go back to business as usual. But we cannot go back to business as usual as long as business is not as usual. Russia is not a partner for peace. We have seen in the war on the territory of Russia, in Chechnya, in Georgia, in Ukraine, and now in the brutal warfare in Syria, that Russia is not a partner for peace; it is a partner for dictators and for brutal warfare. That is the truth, and we need to stay with the requirement that the Minsk agreements must be respected, we must stand strong together, we must discuss energy policy from this perspective – including the Nord Stream II project – and we must require that those who are guilty of the MH17 are found and taken to court. We must stay united and we must stay clear that the only way to secure freedom and security in Europe is to have a strong European Union standing up for its values.

name: Birgit SIPPEL
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Aleppo is experiencing the most gruesome bombardment since the start of the Syrian war, and Europe is working to bring a dead Dublin process out of the coma, possibly extending a dubious Turkey deal to other countries – Egypt, Libya – and protecting its external borders. The message that is received by many citizens is that the main thing is that no one is coming, and that refugees could be dangerous. That is precisely what we continue to fuel populism and xenophobia. This is not helpful, because if we do not succeed in finding sustainable solutions for refugees, then their number will increase. Those who flee from bombs or torture will not be stopped by a Hungarian fence.  We need prospects for people, for refugees inside and outside Europe. That is what we must work on, and we must represent this together to our citizens.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: – Dear President, a few weeks ago we spoke here about the State of the Union and then we said that the Union was shaken: true, but not compromised. After Brexit, after the recent referendum in Hungary, after relations with CETA and TTIP, I understand that uncertainty is born.  However, the fact is that it is not easy to reconcile the interests of the 28 countries, and we must do everything to open up all topics. These topics announced - migration, external relations and trade agreements - are general themes. I believe that all topics will be opened up at the Council. These days we cannot peacefully observe the tragedy that is happening in Aleppo and I agree with Mr. Hökmark who is talking about a Russia that clearly does not want an alliance for peace. That's a big problem. Likewise, we do not use the instruments at our disposal. We have Frontex, we have the European Coast and Border Guard, we have an agreement between the European Union and Turkey. We've brought all this here, but we're not implementing enough.  Yesterday we showed that we are able to ratify the Paris Agreement, which means that the European Union has enough potential to respond with a global solution to the global challenge. So this is an appeal from our side, here from Parliament, on the leaders of the countries, not to react in one way when they are at home and in another way when they are in Brussels. So, consistent policy needs to be conducted, and I am committed to opening all questions and for the European Union not to give up its four fundamental freedoms and to be united and to strive to respond to the challenges that have been ahead in recent years.

name: Kati PIRI
text: – A protracted feud over eastern Ukraine and Crimea, the blackening of the independent investigation into the downing of MH17 and the commission of the most heinous war crimes in Syria: the chilly climate of the Cold War is back.  The Council will meet shortly to discuss relations with Russia. We have seen in recent days that crimes against humanity are being committed in Aleppo by the Syrian government and the Russian army. Devastating bombs are being fired en masse at civilians, humanitarian convoys are being shelled and hospitals are being ripping to the ground. We can no longer stand in power while this massacre in Aleppo is carried out by Assad and Putin. I therefore call on the European Heads of Government to immediately put the people responsible for these crimes on an EU sanctions list.  The continuing search for dialogue is always necessary, but now the time has also come to draw a very clear red line.

name: Elmar BROK
text: Mr President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Vice-President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work and for the work he has said. President Juncker's speech at the last meeting was important, the Bratislava process got under way and we must support this accordingly. I also think that the statements that are here today are important, for example in the economic development with the Digital Single Market; I do not need to explain this further. However, the fight against the causes of flight and the issue of the new Africa policy, support for the Africa Fund and many changes there is also extremely important, as is the fact that we are able to reach agreements with neighbouring countries that are on the sea, such as Turkey, that we get reasonable conditions for refugees, but not leave them at sea. However, my main point, which I would like to mention, is the question of foreign and security policy. I regret the fact that the British Foreign Secretary said at the meeting of defence ministers that they are stopping everything, that they are more in favour of NATO than the SECRETARY-General of NATO, who welcomed European development, that progress is being made here. And I believe that when it comes to the questions of a headquarters, a permanent structured corporation, the issues that have to do with the European Defence Agency and all these issues are important: we are throwing out too much money because the nation states are not cooperating sensibly in these areas. That is why we need the European dimension, which is now under way and which is to be achieved by Rome. The events surrounding Syria show it: we are the world champions in soft power, but we are not sitting at the negotiating table when it comes to war and peace, because we have nothing to contribute to. That is why we need to improve in this area. And sorry, I must also say that I have always preached: we must be tough on Russia on the Ukraine issue, but we need Russia to build peace in other areas such as Syria. This was a misjudgment of me. On this issue, too, Russia is doing pure power politics at the expense of the people – pure power politics, no matter what the price! That is why we need to strengthen our security and defence policy, which is why we need to redefine our Policy on Russia, so that, on this basis, we are able to counter such a sheer claim to power and not to fall apart like the soft eggs, as I sometimes think in our European discussions.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to use my short speaking time to focus on CETA. We are in the post-match period for the negotiating text. The lack of enthusiasm of the Austrian population in particular is not solely based on diffuse fears, no, a group of Austrians is actually quite well informed about the technical details of CETA. Therefore, this replay time should also be used absolutely actively to ensure that public services are excluded, i.e. adequately protected. The same applies to the high standards of labour, social affairs and the environment and the exception of special claims rights.  I do not see social Europe on the agenda of the European Council once again, not surprisingly. I know it is important that we now talk about the Defence Union. However, anyone who talks about security must also talk about social security. This is something that is infinitely important to people: to have a roof over their heads, to have a job, to have basic security. And the social pillar, which is now being worked on tentatively but nevertheless, should be pushed and included in the deliberations of the European Council as soon as possible.

name: Ana GOMES
text: – Mr President, I would like the next European Council to abandon the intergovernmental, anti-European drift of Bratislava, starting with reacting to the financial earthquake that Deutsche Bank is threatening and the latest news on Brexit: it is one thing for the United Kingdom to want to throw itself into the abyss, another to let it drag the European Union.  I would like it to dismantle the anti-European "Fortress Europe" by opening up legal and safe avenues of access to refugees and migrants, without condemning them to surrender to criminal hands and death in the Mediterranean, stopping replicating immoral and ineffective agreements with repressive governments such as the Turk, halting the proliferation of walls, laws and referendums à la Orbán, which, in fact, feed the business of traffickers , threatening our own security. Europe of defence has long been imposed, but it will not go far without strategy or political determination and they have been lacking to send deterrent messages to Russia that from the continued aggression in Ukraine to the merciless bombing of Aleppo cannot get away with it. I wanted the European Union to support the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights, in a sum of courage and resonant of European sanity, demanding restrictions on the veto of The P5 in the Security Council in the face of evidence of war crimes and against humanity that destroy what remains of Syria today and the credibility of the European Union.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: – The debate here in the plenary of the European Parliament also shows a picture that the citizens of the Member States of the European Union cannot like. We who are elected and who are paid to adopt solutions are overtakeing each other in our criticism of individual policies. We cannot agree on a solution to the refugee crisis, we cannot agree on Brexit, we cannot agree on how we should operate in Africa, Syria, what our relationship with Russia should be, ukraine. It must be said very clearly that the Bratislava Summit was a success in this regard, a success just by the fact that the leaders met and by talking about the importance of adopting common solutions, because there are no Brussels officials, there is no indifferent European Union, these are our common solutions, and Prime Minister Robert Fico has shown that he is interested in looking for these common solutions. That is why I will brush off the criticism of the Bratislava Summit. Finally, I would like to say that I expect the Commission to do much more to appeal to the leaders of the Member States, that it is important that they seek common solutions and not that, after the summit, they go to press conferences, where, even after the Bratislava summit, Orbán and Renzi criticised the first summit without coming up with concrete solutions. This is not a solution for the European Union, it is just the destruction of the functioning of the institutions.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: – Grazzi Chair, Commission Vice President, għal darb'oħra fuq l-aġenda tal-Kunsill għandna l-immigrazzjoni. Ser nerġgħu nitkellmu dwar l-immigrazzjoni, okkażjoni oħra fejn l-Unjoni Ewropea għandha l-opportunità quddiemha li turi li mhijiex maqtugħa miħa-ħ大ittadini. U qed ngħid dan fi żmien u f'ikeirkostanzi fejn ta' kuljum l-ikbar problema għall-Unjoni Ewropea hija li qed tkun maqtugħa mir-realtajiet li qeg Ħdin iħossu y-istatidd fl-Istati Membri u mir-realtijiet li l-Unjoni Ewropea kollha u l-Istati Membri kollha kemm huma qegħdin jiffa大大jaw. Jekk nitkellmu dwar sigurtà, jeżistu nuqqasijiet serji fil-mod ta' kif qed jiġu mmaniġġjati l-fruntieri esterni tal-Unjoni Ewropea. Irridu li 4-444 Ewropej iħossuhom qrib l-Unjoni Ewropea? Allura, flock induru ikeirku tond, mingħajr ma jittieħdu d-de大iżjonijiet li suppost, hemm bżonn li l-mexxejja Ewropej jindirizzaw l-issues l-aktar urġenti, fosthom, iva l-immigrazzjoni u t-traffikar tal-persuni. L-Unjoni Ewropea, aktar minn qatt qabel, għandha tibgħat messaġġ ħar u b'saħħtu li t-traffikar tan-nies huwa reat mill-aktar gravi u li gandu jiġi kkastigat bl-istess mod. Inkella se tibqa' l-idea li jaqbillek tapprofitta mill-aktar persuni vulnerabbli.  F'dawn iż-żminijiet kriti大i għall-Unjoni Ewropea għandna bżonn mexxejja li jmexxu lill-Unjoni Ewropea għaliex għandhom valuri ħari u b'saħħithom. Jgħin żgur jekk ikun hemm, iva sforz kollettiv, fejn ir-riżorsi li għandhom l-Istati Membri jiu utilizzati bl-aħjar mod u nevitaw id-duplikazzjoni. Fuq kollox, flimkien, għandna aktar saħħa milli individwalment.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, the citizens of the Member States are clearly showing us what their priorities are. They want security, they want a Union that is actionable and responds to their concerns.  The personality, the European who spoke here in 2000, was Václav Havel, who shared our concerns and also had a vision for a European Union solution. Today he should be 80 years old, and let me quote him: "Another expression of social solidarity is concern for security, which is the task of the state or of a superstate union. The European Union is starting to work intensively on a new concept of its security policy. This policy should be characterised by the ability to make quick decisions and quickly turn joint decisions into action. It seems to me to be extremely important, it seems to me that it is high time for this," said Václav Havel 16 years ago, and I would like to call on the Council representatives, the Representatives of the Commission, to respond quickly so that safety concerns are addressed.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, the Commission and the Council are walking against the clock against a loss of confidence in historical proportions and a point of no return in the European project. Borders, fences, populism, anti-integration referendums, the Visegrad Group, the agreement with Turkey and Brexit unfortunately tarth the image of Europe. But the worst part is that the image would not be complete without the scandalous conflict of interest that has been revealed with former Commissioner Neelie Kroes in the Bahamas or former President Barroso at Goldman Sachs. But also without the threat of an unacceptable fine to Spain and Portugal, countries that have made immense sacrifices with the conditional imposition of unacceptable cuts and in impossible timeframes, because these fines go against the sacrifices of countries that have been Euro-Enthusiastas, against their most vulnerable regions – the outermost ones included – but also and above all against the very idea of Europe. So before it's too late: stop it, Commission and Presidency!

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, Mr Timmermans, the refugee and migration crisis is now taking on explosive proportions. I believe that this is largely due to the fact that too many Member States do not comply with the obligation to relocate. It is something that has been decided; 66,400 relocations will have to be made from Greece. So far there have been 4,077, based on the data you provided.  You realize that this situation cannot continue. Greece cannot afford other refugees and especially other illegal immigrants.  In addition, 14,000 refugees and other illegal immigrants are now crowded into the Aegean islands. That's where something has to be done. There are clashes between refugees in the shelters. The inhabitants themselves are reacting to this explosive situation, and yet I have heard from the Commission that it does not accept that part of these refugees should leave the Aegean islands and come to mainland Greece. Important measures must be taken, Mr Timmermans.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, the people have said no to TTIR in a dynamic way and have thus marginalised it. Now the Commission and the Council are trying to bring it back through CETA. US multinationals will be able through Canada to use CETA tools to attack states' labour, social and environmental standards. This will disappear any barrier to the action and profitability of multinational companies.  Labour legislation, environmental protection standards, consumer safety and public health standards will be drastically squeezed downwards. Democracy itself will be circumvented, since multinationals will be able through ISDS to challenge the decisions of sovereign states by claiming reparations whenever their profits are to be adversely affected. In other words, we will lead to absolute market dominance. We, as GUE, have stood up to TTYR and will stand up to CETA because we are consistently fighting for the strengthening of workers' rights and the social state and against the interests of multinationals.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: I am pleased that there will finally be a full debate on Russia in the European Council and that we will not simply go back to extending sanctions and plunge ourselves into a cold war with Russia. We have to put the various cards on the table: Ukraine, Crimea, Syria, NATO, the European Union.  I also hope that you will finally talk about the consequences of Putin's counter-sanctions, especially on our fruit growers and farmers. I believe that they deserve compensation for the damage suffered. Would there be so little attention to this boycott if german cars were no longer allowed to be imported? The agricultural sector is in a serious crisis and the measures being taken are insufficient. That is why I am asking for real compensation for damages suffered, not from the agricultural budget but from the general resources. It is our farmers who are paying the price for this trade war that they cannot do anything about.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – On the one hand, we are building walls, wires and closing doors against people fleeing wars from violence, because it is obviously difficult to agree on a fair burden allocation. On the other hand, we are broadly opening the door to harmful agreements, which we know far less about than we would like, especially because of the opacity of the negotiations – I am talking about Ceta and, of course, TTIP. In doing so, we are also ignoring the millions of people who oppose these agreements, which will in fact affect standards, both in the areas of the environment, social and also labour rights, which enforce so-called super-courts, which serve only investors and their profits, not, of course, people's rights, and the rights to clean water resources, healthy, impeccable food. And if we sign, and if you sign this provisional application, which is contrary to democracy, then you also ignore national parliaments. So I suggest you don't sign this.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: – Syria must be on the agenda for the next EU Council meeting. We are watching the Syrian government, backed by the Russian air force, conduct an intensive campaign to methodically kill civilians in Aleppo and its surrounding areas. The international community, including the European Union, cannot even deliver humanitarian aid there. What the Russian-backed Syrian government is doing in Aleppo is a stalled campaign that must be stopped, and we look forward to the Decision of the Council of the European Union on this issue. Seeing how Russia allows itself to behave, not only in Syria, but also in Ukraine and Georgia, there is only one way: sanctions against Russia must remain. Russia has not complied with the Minsk agreements and, until they are fulfilled, any proposals to consider lifting sanctions against Russia are unacceptable and, above all, not beneficial to the European Union. On foreign trade issues – CETA'i, a free trade agreement with Canada, must immediately light the green light, everything must be done to ensure that the agreement is not only signed, but also enters into force immediately.

name: Silvia COSTA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the agenda is clear: Syria, immigration, Brexit and the recovery of the economy. The October Council must give answers that can no longer be circumvented, otherwise Europe loses and we are no longer credible. Firstly, it is unacceptable that it was on the very anniversary of the Lampedusa massacre that Orban was chosen for an absolutely illegitimate referendum. Today we are faced with a small fact: 86 refugees have been recognised this year by Hungary and more than 150 000 refugees are welcomed in Italy, which continues to save lives but fails to get people to go to other countries. If this is not there, there will not even be humanitarian corridors. Everything is held. The answer must be global, even after the summit in New York.  Secondly, the European Union must also be at syria's table and we must relaunch the agreement and not get lost, but we must make it clear to Russia that this is a crime against humanity. We must not make diplomatic reasons prevail, but call everyone to account. On Brexit just one joke: 10 000 students have signed up in recent days to ask to be allowed to continue Erasmus in the future. I have asked the Head of the British Government, Mrs May, to make this the first post-Brexit negotiation, but respecting the right of free movement.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, the forthcoming European Council meeting is remarkable, not so much for its agenda as for the issues that are not on the agenda. It is not on the agenda that in Hungary and even more so in Poland far-right governments seek and attempt to build semi-authoritarian regimes, in violation of the fundamental principles of the Union, such as respect for fundamental rights and the rule of law.  But, of course, the Union itself is demonstrating with its attitude towards the Southern Member States, for example, the same lack of respect for other fundamental rights as the social rights of people who also need to be protected. The Union must return to its fundamental and founding values and protect fundamental rights in their entire right because, if it does not, I fear that the British exit will simply be the first of a series of costs of other states.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I would like to stand up for citizens who are being crushed by the Russian procedure in Aleppo. I think that the loss of civilians, the suffering, the damage that is being done there, all of this should lead to a reflection on whether Russia really can be a partner for the European Union and to what extent our sanctions lists are indeed sufficient. In my judgment, we should not sacrifice civilians in this city. On the contrary, we should really stand up for them.  At the same time, I would like to stand up for Britain's participation in the summits. I believe that we should talk to this country, that we should not exclude it, that it is even against the meaning of our applicable law, and that Britain should participate in these summits as long as it is part of the European Union. I'd put in a lot of excuses for that.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: S&D). Mr President, since we are discussing refugees and migrants, I will raise an issue with the Commission, which concerns it and which is a huge outstanding issue relating to Turkey, since there is an express demand from Erdoğan for the liberalisation of procedures for the visas of Turkish nationals. This decision, however, belongs 100% to the European Union itself, it does not belong to Erdoğan. So we have 72 criteria. In a question I put to the Commission and from the reply I received, it is obvious that the Commission is already making rebates in its assessment. While the 72 criteria are indivisible and concern the whole of the European Union, we are beginning to recognise 'partial fulfilment of criteria', 'emerging progress' and so on. I will conclude with this debate: this morning, coming here in the car of the European Parliament, my driver, when he realised that I was from Cyprus, asked me a question which I ask everyone: how is it possible that Turkey holds a third of Cyprus with Turkish troops and has reached the point of the pre-accession talks in which it is today?

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Mr President, Mr Juncker's speech on the state of the Union was appreciated in my country, but it must not remain just a speech. The Council is very important in implementing what the Commission has said, what the President has said and what we, the European Parliament, are saying. Europe must be a Europe with jobs, we must reindustrialise it, we must develop cross-border trade and we must invest in the marginal areas of Europe, we must increase cohesion, and here the Strategic Investment Fund can play a very big role, but it has not shown it so far. Trade defence policies have not yet emerged, the integration of all Member States into the Schengen area has not been achieved. That is why I call on the Council, in particular, but also the Commission to stop blocking Parliament's initiatives and, as I said, when analysing the state of the Union: Europe needs to be better explained, better communication and transparency and step up concrete measures for economic development, support for job-creating SMEs, special measures to increase people's quality of life. Here are some issues that need to be on the agenda of the Council meeting of 20 to 21 October.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, let me dwell on one issue that was raised by most speakers, which is the issue of migration. It is clear to me that the European Union as such cannot survive a situation of uncontrolled mass immigration into Europe. It is equally clear to me that the European Union cannot survive in a situation where we take leave of our fundamental values, refusing international protection to people fleeing atrocities such as in Aleppo, on the grounds that they are migrants and not refugees, which is a false ground. So these are the two guiding principles I would like to apply to our migration policy.  If we want to have controlled migration, and if we want to stick to our fundamental values, which is providing shelter to people fleeing from war and persecution which, I might add, is a fundamental Christian value to those who seem to use Christian values to keep out refugees, then we desperately need a comprehensive approach to the migration issue. We cannot pick and choose. We need to do everything, everywhere, at the same time, which means to do better at protecting our international borders, to do better at redistributing migrants who have arrived according to agreements we have reached, to make sure we also apply resettlement in those areas where refugees are now, and cannot be sustainably housed, to have agreements with third countries so that we provide for development there and that we provide for the right conditions so that economic migrants or people who seek an economic future in Europe but have no right to international protection can be returned to those countries. This is a comprehensive approach and we cannot pick and choose, one or the other. Those who say flexible solidarity means you can pick and choose are wrong. We need to do it all. We do not need to do everything in the same measure everywhere, but everything will have to be done by all of us. I insist on this also because I was in Lampedusa a couple of days ago. And here today I want to salute the incredible efforts of the Italian Navy, of the people of all the international organisations involved, of the Italian coastguard, who daily save hundreds, if not thousands, of people from drowning. And still we have not prevented people from drowning in the Mediterranean, in incredible numbers in the southern Mediterranean, and also here only a sustainable policy will help us solve this problem. Fences and walls will not solve the problem. Those who believe that fences and walls will solve the problem are simply fleeing from reality. Just imagine that Africa and the next generation will have anywhere between 3 and 6 billion people. If we do not help Africa develop itself, if we did not make sure that girls can go to school, and that women do not feel they have to have nine children to survive, if we do not provide for that, no high fence, no barbed wire, no walls will stop people from coming to Europe. Either we help them develop themselves or we will be subject to mass immigration into Europe. That, my colleagues, is something we need to do jointly, and we need to start doing it now.  Finally, I want to pay tribute to Václav Havel. I have strong memories of a speech he made in Prague, and I was present there, where he recalled his memories of fighting for freedom, fighting against walls, fighting against fences, fighting against barbed wire. He said in that speech that he grew up and lived in a society where East and West were moral categories, where East and West defined a difference in values, and he was so happy that now he was President of a country and a society where East and West were reduced to mere geographical qualifications. Please let us stay true to the ideas and idealism of Václav Havel, and please let us make sure that, in our European Union, East and West remain purely geographical denominations.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, frankly it is not easy to conclude this debate while I see that movement in the audience, but I will try to do my best.  (The President asked Members to take their seats) The Bratislava Summit was mentioned quite often in this debate this morning, and I would like to thank all those who said that Bratislava was a useful event. However, I am not ignoring the views of those who obviously believed or expected more to come out from Bratislava. If I may say, we are not among those who are saying that Bratislava was an extraordinary or exceptional success. We see it realistically and we want to measure it against the two objectives that we have set ourselves when the meeting was convened in Bratislava. Number one: there were clear expectations that we would have a serious, open and frank debate after Brexit, but also they wanted to start a debate about the future of the European Union. We have agreed in Bratislava that the reflection process will start, and it will culminate next March when we will commemorate the 60th anniversary of the Rome Treaties, so that is one concrete result of Bratislava. Secondly, in Bratislava, several areas and steps were defined where we agreed that we need to make clear progress in order to show tangible results. I agree with Jean-Claude Juncker, who wished to have a more binding timetable for Bratislava, and let me say that the Presidency will work on the follow-up to this. I am speaking in this House just to recall that this is not only work for the Council or for Parliament or for the Commission. There is common work that we have to do, namely that towards the end of this year, the Commission, Parliament and the Council should agree on a common list or joint declaration of legislative priorities. So this is also the follow-up after Bratislava and this is a good basis for us to work.  May I also say that if Bratislava was not about one thing it was definitely not a demonstration of intergovernmentalism. How otherwise could Heads of State in Bratislava have welcomed the State of the Union speech of the President of the Commission? Jean-Claude was right that it was maybe for the first time that Heads of State had explicitly welcomed a speech that he has delivered, just two days before Bratislava.  Second point. Of course many of you referred to the tragic events unfolding in Syria. Russia is on the agenda of the European Council. I would like to recall that the rationale for including Russia on the agenda was a bit different – it was in the context of Russia’s aggression against Ukraine – but I agree that the events in Syria are prompting us to have a broader debate, a strategic debate, about future relations with Russia.  Lastly, honourable Member in 't Veld asked a question on whether we as a Presidency are ready to work with you on the Asylum Package. I would not see the Council as being a bottleneck on this particular issue. I would like to say that what the Commission has proposed is a far-reaching reform of the asylum system, including Dublin. Member States will feel the impact of this and we simply need more time to explore what can be done. The Presidency wants to organise this work speedily. It took us recently five years to agree on many elements which are on the table right now, but we want to organise our work in a way which will not cause further divisions on these very sensitive issues. But be sure that the Council and the Presidency are working hard towards having agreement on many elements of asylum towards the end of this year.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The debate is closed.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Mr President, this issue is not on the agenda, but I would like to speak here to denounce the fact that a few days ago the Russian authorities arrested a Ukrainian journalist, Roman Souchchenko. The journalist, who was doing his job, was put in prison and charged with espionage. Such situations are unacceptable. We call on the Russian authorities to immediately release this Ukrainian journalist. I repeat his name: Roman Souchchenko.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Thank you for pointing this out, Mr Preda. We are, of course, looking into the case and will intervene. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to I would like to draw attention to the fact that, although the Commission acknowledged as early as December 2015 that Ukraine had complied with the visa liberalisation plan, bureaucratic procedures are still hindering visa-free entry for citizens. While europe is overstreted by hundreds of thousands of illegal immigrants without any id documents or compulsory registration required by the various conventions, Ukrainian citizens belonging to the European community, including Hungarians from Transcarpathia, even with visas, have to wait for hours at the few available border crossing points. The citizens of Ukraine have made many sacrifices for European orientation, in return for which the European Union has not made this symbolic gesture without delay. I therefore call for the Ukrainian dossier to be treated in accordance with its importance and to take the necessary steps to grant visa waivers as soon as possible and to draw up a development and budgetary plan to expand border infrastructure in order to develop international routes and border crossings, because this would finally be a tangible help for citizens.

name: Lorenzo CESA
text: in writing. I have already had the opportunity during the last plenary session during the debate on the state of the Union to highlight the challenges we face in the coming months. The Council of 20 and 21 October will be a decisive hub. By the end of the year we will be called upon to give credible answers to our citizens. The priorities to focus on are security, immigration, work and saving protection. After the disappointing results of the last Bratislava Summit, Europe can no longer afford missteps. I appeal to the leaders of the Member States: let us make the most of the next summit, let us abandon national self-interest, let us use the Community method and let us get our Europe back on track!

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. – In Portugal today, 106 years pass on the implementation of the Republic. A day that, in democracy, was marked as a holiday until the Troika (EU-IMF) and its handmen in Portugal robbed the Portuguese. The struggle of workers and the people Portuguese brought about the defeat a year ago of the PSD-CDS government. With it opened the possibility of interrupting the path of esbulho, exploitation and impoverishment that had been imposed on the country. Some steps have since been taken in this direction. Limited and modest, but important. One of them was the return of the stolen holidays. Including the return of October 5th. Today was a public holiday in Portugal. We do not expect decisions to change the direction that the EU is being followed from the next European Council. Direction that stems from its nature and objectives. Expression of this nature and objectives is the process of threat and blackmail brought against Portugal. Seeking to condition and prevent the possibility of the people Portuguese decide freely of their destiny. Evidencing a process of integration exhausted, eroded by contradictions, with nothing positive to offer to the peoples of Europe. A process that is already passed. The future, that is in the struggle of workers and peoples. After the holidays, other achievements will come.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The situation in Syria, the further implementation of migration policy and the strengthening of border control, as well as the strategy for trade agreements that can have a significant impact on EU industry, are the main topics to be considered at the European Council meeting on 20-21 October in Brussels. Concrete action is needed to pave the way for the implementation of effective migration policies. Strengthen border guards in countries that protect the Union's external borders. Europe is part of a globalised world and should be better equipped to take advantage of the opportunities offered by migration, especially in the face of an ageing population. Nevertheless, preventing and reducing irregular migration is essential. This requires strengthening the EU strategy to combat people smuggling and trafficking in human beings and to deepen cooperation with countries of origin and transit of migrants. The new management of the Schengen area must also ensure a higher level of security. In the context of trade agreements, even though the Commission is in favour of implementing the Trade Agreement with Canada (CETA) as soon as possible, I think it is first necessary to dispel the doubts it raises in our societies. Extensive consultation and real safeguards are needed to protect, for example, the steel industry in Europe.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. - The Council meeting on 20 and 21 October will address essential issues of the European Union. These are the key problems that the EU is currently facing and for which solutions need to be found with the utmost urgency. What is important here is the question of migration, where the necessary choices need to be taken, as well as European trade policy, in which new framework conditions must be created in order to achieve a resilient trade and economic policy for the Member States. The Union's external relations with third countries are also of great importance, where an honest debate is needed, for example, in order to normalise the EU's relations with Russia. Uncontrolled immigration, the threat of terrorism and the economic and social insecurity of citizens are at the heart of Europe's current misocity. In order to meet these challenges, concrete implementation of initiatives is needed. In particular, on migration, on internal and external security issues and in the systematic fight against radicalisation within Europe, it is necessary to support and promote those priorities for which there is a broad basic consensus at Member State level. Sustainable protection of the external borders of the European Union, an end to the flow of refugees, combined with the general fight against reasons for fleeing, are issues that the Council should deal with.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: in writing. – I am appalled by the news that the UK Government plans to introduce lists of foreign citizens working in the UK. Should they as the next step also start wearing an emblem on the shoulder to be noticeable? The UK has been a highly respected, although sometimes a difficult EU Member State. While regretting the outcome of the referendum, the EU is ready to negotiate on fair terms. Now it looks as if the UK has taken the approach of nothing to lose and has decided to mock European principles, ridicule and hinder EU plans for closer cooperation and, worst of all, punish equally Europeans and its own citizens. This is not responsible behaviour. I call on the UK to stop such bullying of the EU. Attempts to conduct an appeasement policy towards Russia have failed. Together with the Syrian dictator Assad, the Russian military is massacring in Syria what is left to massacre. It is highly concerning that a major military exercise, practising total war and nuclear attack, is taking place in Russia. The conclusion must be that EU cannot sink deeper in trying to accommodate itself to Putin’s aggressive politics. A state responsible for committing systematic war crimes cannot be the EU’s partner. Instead, the EU and the US should take joint action to end the war in Syria.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. – All government representatives and presidents at the Bratislava Summit stated that there is nothing better than the EU for their people. This was a strong positive signal for the people of the EU. They have made it clear that we have learned from the migration crisis, including from our own mistakes, that we are ready for the situation not to happen again. They have shown concrete measures that reduce the influx of migrants and solve major problems outside Europe. They have offered measures that will contribute to growth and employment, in particular youth employment. They have set aside half a year, when the process he started in Bratislava will be finalised with the ultimate goal of setting clear priorities and planning concrete steps. This year, we will complete the Border and Coast Guard with new return policy powers, launch a system that records data on people entering and leaving the EU, implementing our priorities such as combating tax fraud, tax evasion, taxing profits where it arises, completing the banking union so that people's deposits are protected and that their owners, and not all residents, are involved in the event of bank problems. , we are continuing the Energy Union project to guarantee security of energy supply and the cheapest possible energy. We will protect our steel industry against low prices from China. We will make sure that people make phone calls in the EU from the summer at the same price as at home.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: in writing. – The European Council must come up with viable solutions for a number of points facing the European Union at the moment.  The cause of migration and the resolution of migration problems at source must be found. Mastering migratory flows requires a new policy of cooperation with third countries. Russia's policy of intervention in Syria must be called into question. Russia is not a European partner in humanitarian measures, as it is not a European partner for energy projects such as Nord Stream 2. CETA and TTIP trade agreements must take into account the concerns of European citizens. The EU must inform the public of every advantage for the citizen: job creation, the development of fair trade, etc. I stress the need to strengthen European legislative instruments for reindustrialisation. These agreements must contribute positively to creating appropriate conditions for EU industry, which faces unfair competition on the world market, where the same standards and rules are not met. With regard to Brexit, I believe that the EU must agree on expectations of the UK's new status. Fundamental freedoms, in particular freedom of movement, must not be achieved by this new status of the UK.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. – One accepts that the EU should not, either on its own or through informal contacts with the UK, start to review options for the Brexit negotiations before these commence. The same need not apply for the EU’s internal arrangements once Brexit has been consummated. This is especially relevant with regard to the financial implications for the Union of being without the UK. Media houses and research bureaus have made their calculations. The Union’s income will suffer a sizeable shortfall with the disappearance of the UK’s net contribution. What will the implications of this be for ongoing and future EU projects? What will be the dimensions of the shortfall, seen from a purely accounting perspective? And from an operational one? How can this deficit be countered? These questions in no way prejudice the conduct of future Brexit negotiations. They relate to the available options for internal reorganisation of the EU post-Brexit. Misinformation about this may be contributing to ongoing uncertainties as much as the wait for Brexit negotiations to start. Deep background provided publicly as of now by the Commission and/or Council about the scale of the challenges and problems in this regard would help dampen such uncertainties.

name: Algirdas SAUDARGAS
text: Writing. – At the forthcoming European Council at the end of October, much attention will be paid to discussing the Issue of Russia. It is likely that the statements calling for a gradual return to the previous relationship will be heard again, so it is worth renewing the facts of recent months. In September, parliamentary elections were held, after which the non-systemic opposition was finally eliminated from the Russian political system. Shortly thereafter, it was announced that the Kremlin was seeking to consolidate security structures and restore the ministry of security, the MGB, which was active in the USSR. At the end of the month, a dutch-led investigation into the MH17 tragedy confirmed that a passenger plane over eastern Ukraine had been shot down by a Russian-led missile complex, BUK, which was later returned to Russia. Although the specific identities of the officials who committed this crime and issued the order have not yet been disclosed, questions about Russia's responsibility in this tragedy should no longer arise. And on October 4th it was announced that a global three-day military exercise would begin in the country, supposedly mobilising 40 million, and thus a third of the total Russian population. It is clear that this is an inflated figure for propaganda purposes, but this kind of unpublished exercise in Russia is being recorded more and more. This should be sufficient to assess the current political situation in Russia and the success of any attempts to normalise relations with it by returning to conventional formats.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. – We can only manage the migration crisis through common action. I expect the Member States to fully support the deployment of the European Coast guard and border guards at our borders. In the light of irreversible evidence of the RF army's contribution to the downing of flight MH17, Europe should also speak with one voice against Russia and insist on punishing the culprits and compensation for the victims.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. – At the next meeting of the EiT, the Heads of State or Government of the Union will meet for the first time to discuss the joint management of the migration and refugee crisis, after one of them – Viktor Orban – faced a harsh, direct political challenge to them, the EiT and even the eu's entire legal order, with its 'anti-quota' referendum on 2 October. Although the referendum has been annuled due to the wisdom of the Hungarian electorate, the Orban government continues its anti-Brussels demagogy, the incition of hatred against migrants, and its d'edgyness from a common European solution, which it now wants to enshrin in the Basic Law. I believe that the current European Council meeting is the only appropriate level and opportunity for EU leaders to confront their Hungarian counterparts with the dangers of their policies, both for the Hungarian people and for the future of the European Union.  To this end, I urge that, in the context of the preparations for the current EiT agenda, it is finally acknowledged that it is not worth talking about an effective and common EU deal with the migrant crisis in the hope of success if Europe's leaders do not put an end to Orban's minework once and for all, thereby preventing the further spread of selfish, nationalist populism among the Member States. Despite the dictatorial methods and inciterative campaign of the Hungarian Government, it is now proven that the majority of the Hungarian electorate can expect the consent of the majority.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. – This structured dialogue is an integral part of an unqualified process of blackmail and conditioning aimed at preventing any deviation of national governments from the neoliberal agenda of the European Union. We are naturally against the suspension of the Structural Funds and we follow much of what was said at this meeting today. But this dialogue, this possibility of suspension of structural funds, sanctions and fines have not fallen out of the sky. It is the application of specific rules that have been adopted by this Parliament and by many Members who are now faced with the consequences of the directives and regulations adopted earlier. They are therefore an integral part of an Economic and Monetary Union which, with its rules, its mechanisms, represents a real obstacle to the development of economically poorer countries and regions. In this sense, more than recommending the non-implementation of the suspension of the Structural Funds, we must demand a deep reflection on the euro, on economic and monetary union and, ultimately, on this process of neoliberal integration which is no longer part of the solution to be part of the problem.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent report, which Several speeches have been made this morning in plenary, including by the Vice-President of the Commission, Mr Timmermans, to Mr Havel. This great European statesman would have reached his eightyth birthday today – a great personality, as many of you have said in your speeches today, a character with a backbone, a man who has devoted his life to the fight against dictatorship, against Soviet oppression, for democracy and for the rule of law. Not only did he liberate Czechoslovakia from the yoke of communism, he also led the Czech Republic as a sovereign state to join the European Union. I believe that Mr Havel and his life's work are a legacy for all those who believe in a Europe of tolerance, respect and the fight for freedom. That is why it is certainly appropriate to remember this great man on his 80th birthday. (Applause) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which We will then have a vote on the need for a European re-industrialisation policy. That is why a number of representatives of Caterpillar's workforce, especially the works councils, are with us today and are following this debate and the vote. In a very difficult situation, not only for Caterpillar, but for the whole of European industry, I welcome our guests to our gallery. (Applause)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The next item is voting time. (For results and other details of the vote: see Minutes). Before the vote.

name: James CARVER
text: – Mr President, Sunday saw the start of Rosh Hashanah, the Jewish New Year. With a rise in anti-Semitism not just across the European Union, but across the globe, and with Jewish communities across the European Union facing greater security issues at their schools and at their synagogues, would it not be a good opportunity to wish Europe’s Jewish citizens a happy and a sweet new year? (Applause)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Thank you very much, Mr Carver, for this comment. It certainly honours you that you point this out.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The following is a non-legislative act ratifying Peru's accession to the Hague Convention on the International Abduction of Children. As this is a formally necessary act, since the Convention does not provide for the possibility of direct approval by the EU, I voted in favour.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP chose to abstain on this vote because it is such an emotive issue.  The right of countries acceding to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is extremely important; however, this should be done at the will of the individual country and not en bloc by the EU.
