name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Peru's accession to the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, since I consider this type of coordination among States to be positive in resolving the sensitive cases of international child abduction, with the aim of moving towards respect for the rights and interests of children.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this report to endorse the Council decision to authorise the accession of Peru to the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. The Convention is a multilateral treaty to ensure that children wrongfully taken into another country, often by a parent or guardian, are brought back to their home country. A ruling of the European Court of Justice in 2014 found that the EU now has exclusive external competence in these matters, but the Convention does not allow for international organisations – such as the EU – to sign the Convention themselves. This Council decision is therefore necessary to allow Member States to accept the accession of Peru to the Convention, bringing the Convention into force between the entire EU and Peru.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to give Austria and Romania permission to accept Peru's accession to the Convention, which will allow the agreement between Peru and the whole of the European Union to enter into force. All other Member States of the European Union have given Peru their approval to join.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the proposal for a Council decision authorising the Republic of Austria and Romania to accept, in the interest of the European Union, the accession of Peru to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. I welcome the accession of Peru to the Convention as EU-wide protection should be ensured for the children in question. The Convention introduces a system of cooperation between the contracting states aimed at settling cases of international child abduction. The Convention also initiates a system which ensures the immediate return of children who have been abducted. Following the accession of Peru to the Convention, a Council decision is therefore necessary to authorise the two Member States which have not yet accepted the accession of Peru – Austria and Romania – to accept that accession. This will allow the Convention to enter into force between Peru and the entire European Union and it has a particular significance because of many EU citizens that are of Peruvian origin. Children with links to the Peruvian community will thus be safeguarded against abduction.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council decision authorising the Republic of Austria and Romania, in the interests of the European Union, to accept Peru's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on Civil Matters of International Child Abduction, because this establishes a system allowing Contracting States to cooperate in finding a solution to such situations.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a legal instrument of the utmost importance and ratified by all the Member States of the European Union. The Convention establishes a system of cooperation between States Parties to resolve cases of international child abduction. Very often these problems occur when a couple has separated. If the parents come from different countries, they may be tempted to take advantage of the lack of cooperation between these states in order to obtain custody of the child.  The aim of the Convention is to provide solutions to these situations at international level by determining that the courts of the child's country of residence have jurisdiction and that the law of the child is applicable. The Convention also introduces a system to ensure that children who have been abducted are returned immediately. Peru's accession to the Hague Convention is to be welcomed. Here, too, the more countries sign this convention, the more effective it is. The European Union is home to many citizens of Peruvian origin. Children with links to this state are thus protected from kidnapping.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which resolves cases of international child abduction by allowing Peru to join the 1980 Hague Convention.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ Under normal circumstances, I would vote against or abstain on resolutions involving the European Union’s participation in international bodies and organisations because I believe that it’s not for the European Union to make such decisions. In this situation, however, the question is whether Peru should be allowed to accede to the Hague Convention. It should be a vote of the British Parliament, but it is not, because such sovereignty has been ceded. If the European Parliament were to vote against accession, it would penalise children at risk of abduction in that country. Therefore I voted in favour of accession, despite my constitutional concerns.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted for this proposal because it appears that Peru's accession to the Convention is a news to be welcomed, especially given the fact that the European Union has many citizens of Peruvian origin on its soil.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal authorising the Republic of Austria and Romania, in the interest of the European Union, to approve Peru's accession to the 1980 agreement. the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. of 25 October 1980 The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a very important instrument providing for a framework for cooperation between the Contracting Parties to deal with cases of international child abduction. In most cases, problems with child abduction arise after the couple divorced. It is also common for the courts of both states to recognise themselves as competent to hear the case, and each child is assigned custody to the parent who is a national of their state. In the light of these examples, I welcome Peru's accession to the Hague Convention in order to establish the competent courts and applicable laws of the state in which the child is habitually resident. It would also ensure that the abducted child is returned immediately.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP chose to abstain on this vote because it is such an emotive issue.  The right of countries acceding to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is extremely important; however this should be done at the will of the individual country and not en bloc by the EU.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction establishes a system of cooperation between contracting states to deal with international child abduction cases. It has been ratified by all EU Member States. The purpose of the convention is to resolve such situations at the international level, by establishing that the competent courts and applicable laws are those of the child's state of residence. The Union now has exclusive external jurisdiction in this area. The convention also introduces a system that ensures the immediate return of children who have been abducted. That is why I voted in favour of Peru's accession to the Hague Convention.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I voted in favour of Austria and Romania's recognition of Peru's accession to the Hague Convention. This will allow the agreement between Peru and the whole of the European Union to enter into force. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction is an instrument of the utmost importance. It has been ratified by all the Member States of the European Union. This convention establishes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in cases of international child abduction.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, ratified by all EU countries, has introduced a system allowing contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution to this type of case. The text of the Treaty contains two main points: jurisdiction to adjudicate and applicability of the laws entrusted to the state of residence of the child and the establishment of a mechanism for the immediate return of the stolen child. The European Union currently has exclusive external competence in this area, but the Convention does not provide for the autonomous action of international organisations. That is why the Member States must act on behalf of the Union with prior authorisation from the Council. The Dzhambazki report, which I supported today, therefore authorises Austria and Romania to accept Peru's accession to the Convention, enabling it to deploy its effects in relations between the South American country and the European Union.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Peru's accession to the Hague Convention in relation to the civil aspects of international child abduction, because it entails greater protection and guarantees for children. The Hague Convention establishes a system that allows the cooperation of Contracting States to find a solution to situations of international child abduction. These cases usually occur in cases of separations with parents from different countries. The Convention regulates that the applicable legislation in such cases is that of the child's State of residence. It also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of the stolen child.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I would like to thank the rapporteur for the work done in this report on Peru's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. It is an instrument of crucial importance. Peru's accession is good news.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on Peru's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. Peru must be free, if it wishes, to join this system of international cooperation, which allows, among other things, to settle cases of international child abduction. There may indeed be a problem in the case of a separated couple whose parents come out of different states. The Convention regulates possible jurisdictional disputes since it stipulates that the applicable laws are those of the child's state of residence. It also allows an immediate return of the abducted child. While I regret that the Union now has exclusive jurisdiction in this area to the detriment of the Member States, Peru, as a sovereign state, has every right to join this Convention and the ratification of this accession will allow it to enter into force between the Union and that country.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction provides for cooperation between signatory states so that a child or child under 16 who has been arbitrarily "abducted" by a parent returns to the place of family residence pending a judicial ruling, unless the return foretooes a serious danger to his or her safety. I believe it is of fundamental importance for the protection of our children that this convention be ratified and respected by more and more States. I therefore voted to support the authorisation for Austria and Romania to accept Peru's accession to the Convention.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The 1980 Hague Convention on civil aspects of international child abduction, signed by all EU Member States, is an instrument of international cooperation that authorizes signatory States to resolve transnational cases relating to the custody and abduction of minors, clarifying the national law applicable in cases where there is a conflict of jurisdiction between two or more national legal systems. The scope of the rule reaches civil aspects, applying mainly to cases of separate parents or other persons who have legal rights over the child. Since the objective of the Convention is to protect minors in a situation of legal uncertainty, it is important to ensure that it is signed by as many States as possible.  Although the EU has exclusive external competence in this area, the Convention does not authorise the participation of international actors, so the EU needs to give all its Member States express authorisation to accept the participation of any new State in the Convention. That is why I voted in favour of authorising the two Member States which have not yet accepted Peru's accession — namely Austria and Romania — to accept it.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which deals with the interests of the European Union in support of Peru's accession to the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. of 25 October 1980 The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a very important document. It has been ratified by all EU Member States. The Convention provides for a framework for cooperation between the Contracting Parties to deal with international child abduction cases. In most cases, these problems occur when the couple divorced. If the mother and father come from different countries, there is a desire to take advantage of the lack of cooperation between these states in order to secure custody of the child. The media is full of reports of international child abduction in the area of separation or divorce. In these cases, the national bias of the legal systems of individual countries is the biggest problem. Often, the courts of both states recognise themselves as competent to hear the case and each child is cared for by a parent who is a national of their state. Following the accession of Peru to the Convention, a Council Decision is necessary for two Member States which have not yet approved the accession of Peru (Austria and Romania) to be empowered to accept the accession of that country. This will allow the Convention to enter into force between Peru and the European Union as a whole. The accession of Peru to the Convention is to be welcomed. The rapporteur fully supports this accession, especially since a significant number of EU citizens come from Peru. So children with ties to the Peruvian community will be protected from abduction.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on civil aspects of the abduction of children established a system allowing cooperation between Contracting States in finding a solution to the issue of the abduction of children abroad. The biggest problem in such cases is the national nature of the legal system of states. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve such situations at international level by determining that the law of the State in which the child is resident applies and that the case falls within the jurisdiction of the court of that State. The Convention also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of a child who has been unlawfully taken abroad. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area, as confirmed by the Court of Justice in Opinion No 1/13. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own competences. The problem arises from the fact that the Convention does not provide for the independent action of international organisations, so that, following peru's accession to the Convention, a decision of the Council is needed authorises the two Member States which have not yet adopted peru's accession, Austria and Romania, to accept the accession of Peru. This will allow the Convention to enter into force between Peru and the European Union as a whole. In view of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. I welcome the accession of Peru to the Hague Convention, so I have no reservations in supporting the proposed decision. The 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abuse is a very important instrument that provides for a system for cooperation in finding solutions to cases of international child abuse. The Convention was ratified a long time ago by all EU Member States. Problems are most often the case in the case of separation between parents who come from different countries. There is a danger that one of the parents may wish to take advantage of the lack of cooperation between those two countries and thus acquire the exclusive custody of the children. In such cases, the biggest problem is the national bias of the legal systems in individual countries, and the judgments often end in such a way that each national court entrusts the child with the custody of a parent who is a national of that country. The Convention, however, lays down jurisdiction on the courts and law of the state in which the child is domiciled, as well as a system for ensuring the immediate return of the child who is wrongfully deprived. In the event of Peru's accession to the Convention, this means that children connected to the Peruvian community in the EU Member States will be protected from illegal withdrawal.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. I support this Report on Peru's access to the Hague Convention, which protects children who find themselves in legal uncertainty. The report aims to allow Austria and Romania to accept Peru's accession to the Convention, which will allow the Entry into Force of the Convention between Peru and the entire EU, as all other EU member states have given their consent.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. I am in favour of the adoption of this text because these countries have made the sovereign choice to apply for membership.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. ‒ I endorsed the authorisation given by the Parliament to Austria and Romania to accept the accession of Peru to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. Indeed, I believe the 1980 Hague Convention is an important and successful instrument aimed at settling cases of international child abduction through cooperation between states. The accession of Peru needs the authorisation of the Council due to the fact that Austria and Romania had not accepted Peru yet. This resolution is important because many EU citizens are of Peruvian origin and as a consequence the Convention will help more European families deal with separations or divorces.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction is an instrument of fundamental importance which has been ratified by all the Member States of the European Union. The Convention introduces a system which allows contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution to cases of international child abduction. The aim of the Convention is to resolve these situations at international level by establishing that the competent courts and applicable laws are those of the child's state of residence. The Convention also introduces a system that guarantees the immediate return of the abducted child, protecting his or her health and fundamental rights. Peru's accession to the Convention is a positive step in promoting the protection of children's rights at global and not just European level.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980, ratified by all EU Member States, establishes a system of cooperation between contracting states to deal with cases of international child abduction. In most cases, these abductions are related to the divorce of the parents, tempted to exploit the lack of cooperation between states to obtain custody of their child. This convention stipulates that the competent courts and applicable laws are those of the child's state of residence. This text aims to give the opinion of the European Parliament on the entry into force of this convention between Peru and the Union, the latter now having exclusive external competence in this area. Although I dispute the loss of sovereignty of the Member States, which leave it to the Union to adopt this type of agreement for them, I have spoken in favour of this text. On the one hand, this convention favours the return of children to their homes, and on the other hand, peru's accession is news that should be welcomed.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is one of the main tools for promoting the rights of the child. The Convention establishes a system of cooperation between central authorities aimed at resolving cases of international child abduction. These cases occur mainly in situations where parents come from different states, states that have not strengthened a cooperation partnership. As a result, a vulnerability is created that favours unlawful actions to obtain the custody of children. Thus, the Hague Convention aims to resolve such cases at international level, providing for a system which ensures the immediate return of unlawfully displaced or detained children.  The accession of the Republic of Peru to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is an action which I consider appropriate, given the considerable number of Union citizens of Peruvian origin who will be able to be protected against child abduction. I was in favour of the accession of the Republic of Peru to the Hague Convention, because I consider it essential that preventing the abduction of children remains a priority for the European Union and third countries.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction was established in 1980. All MEMBER States of the European Union are signatories to this convention. This private international law law imposes a uniform legal basis in the event of a child being abducted by one of his parents during a binational separation. Sometimes a parent abducts his child and receives legal custody in his or her home state. The other parent is then required to comply with this decision because of a lack of legal homogeneity between the two states of which the parents are nationals. Such situations must no longer occur. We must do everything we can to ensure that children's rights are applied in the same way around the world. I voted in favour of Peru joining the Hague Convention.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report today because I consider the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction to be an instrument of vital importance to the Member States of the European Union and not. The Convention introduces a system which allows signatory states to cooperate actively in order to find a concrete solution to cases of international abduction of children. The problem arises mainly as a result of separation or divorce. In the event that the mother and father come from different states, the lack of cooperation between the States concerned could, to date, be used to direct custody.  The tendency of the legal systems of the individual States is to practice favouritism on the basis of nationality. The Convention aims to resolve these situations at international level by establishing that the competent courts and applicable laws are those of the child's state of residence. There is also a system that guarantees the immediate return of the stolen child. Many European citizens are of Peruvian origin and therefore, thanks to the accession of the country in question, children with links to the Peruvian community will be properly protected against abduction.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ This was a vote to endorse the Council's decision to authorise Peru signing up to the Hague Convention of International Child Abduction. The Convention is a multilateral treaty with the purpose of ensuring the immediate return of children wrongfully taken to or retained internationally (usually by one parent or guardian) in their home country, where domestic custody proceedings can take place. While a ruling of the ECJ in 2014 found that the EU now has exclusive external competence in the field, the Convention does not allow for international organisations - such as the EU - to be partners to the Convention themselves. These Council decisions are therefore necessary to allow particular Member States which have not yet accepted the accession of the relevant countries to the Convention to do so, bringing the Convention into force between the entire EU and that country. For these reasons I voted in favour.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I approved the proposal without amendment, in order to ensure that EU-wide protection is afforded to children with links to the Peruvian community, who will thus be safeguarded against abduction.  The Convention introduces a system of cooperation between the contracting states aimed at settling cases of international child abduction. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve such situations at an international level, by establishing that the competent courts and applicable laws are those of the state of residence of the child. The Convention also introduces a system which ensures the immediate return of children who have been abducted. The EU now has exclusive external competence in this field and the Member States therefore no longer act on their own account.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 With the adoption of the act in question, individual Member States are allowed to ratify Peru's accession to the Hague Convention on the International Abduction of Children (since the Convention does not provide for the possibility of direct approval by the EU, this is a formal but necessary act).

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 The 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction established a system of cooperation between the authorities of each Contracting State, which establishes the immediate return of children who have been unlawfully transferred or detained. Since this is an international agreement which aims to protect and protect children in situations of legal uncertainty, it must be ratified by as many states as possible. Given that the European Union has exclusive external competence in the field of child abduction, I am convinced that the European institutions must authorise the Member States to accept Peru's participation. I therefore voted in favour of the decision, hoping for the rapid entry into force of the 1980 Hague Convention between Peru and all EU Member States in order to prevent the abduction of children.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report as many EU citizens come from Peru. This will ensure protection against the abductions of children with ties to the Peruvian community. Peru's accession to the Convention is welcome.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The vote concerned the report authorising the Republic of Austria and Romania to accept, in the interests of the European Union, Peru's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on Civil Matters of International Child Abduction. As this is a question of improving the framework for the protection of citizens, especially children, no objections were raised by either side and I therefore voted in favour.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure in view of the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction is an instrument of fundamental importance that has been ratified by all the Member States of the European Union. It is part of a system which allows contracting states to cooperate and find a solution to cases of international child abduction. Many times the main problem is the tendency of the legal systems of individual States to practise favouritism on the basis of nationality. It is often the case that the courts of both states concerned declare themselves competent and that each of them entrusts the child to the parent who is a national of the State in which the court is located. The aim of the Convention is to resolve these situations at international level by establishing that the competent courts and applicable laws are those of the child's state of residence. The Convention also introduces a system which guarantees the immediate return of the child who has been abducted. Peru's accession to the Convention is to be welcomed. The rapporteur fully supports this position, given the fact that many citizens of the European Union are of Peruvian origin. Children with links to the Peruvian community will thus be protected against abduction.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal authorising the Republic of Austria and Romania to accept Peru's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention. The Hague Convention is a very important instrument ratified by all the Member States of the European Union which allows them to cooperate in resolving cases of international child abduction.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome Peru's accession to the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. This is an important step in the protection of minors, since many European citizens are of Peruvian origin and can therefore be protected from abduction. In particular, the Hague Convention favours a framework for the protection of children's rights at international level, which is particularly effective in the event of a clash between different national legislations. Finally, I welcome the fact that this report can ensure the immediate return of children unlawfully transferred or detained in any Contracting State.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the Report on the proposal for a Council decision authorising the Republic of Austria and Romania to accept, in the interest of the European Union, the accession of Peru to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction and noted no objections.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction is a key instrument in the context of judicial cooperation between contracting States in the resolution of cases of international child abduction. This Convention aims to harmonise the legal systems other than those states which normally declare themselves both competent to adjudicate the action and declare custody of the minor to the national parent of the State they represent, and the criterion of the State of residence of the minor is adopted with the Convention. As this matter currently is the exclusive external competence of the Union, a Council decision is necessary which call for the Member States to accept the access of third countries to the Hague Convention. I support the Dzhambazki report and congratulate the State of Peru on its adoption of the Convention.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – UKIP chose to abstain on this vote because it is such an emotive issue.  The right of countries acceding to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is extremely important; however, this should be done at the will of the individual country and not en bloc by the EU.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ This is an important instrument which has been ratified by all the EU Member States, providing protection for the interest of those children who are victims of abduction. The Convention introduces a system of cooperation, aimed at settling cases of international child abduction, between contracting states which are often at loggerheads declaring themselves competent, with each of them awarding custody of the child to the parent who is a national of their state. An important development introduced by the Convention is a system which ensures the immediate return of children who have been abducted. Following the accession of Peru to the Convention, a Council decision is therefore necessary to authorise the two Member States which have not yet accepted the accession of Peru – Austria and Romania – to accept that accession. This will allow the Convention to enter into force between Peru and the entire European Union.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Peru's accession to the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, since I consider this type of coordination among States to be positive in resolving the sensitive cases of international child abduction, with the aim of moving towards respect for the rights and interests of children.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 1980 was born to prevent and prevent the abduction of children abroad. The Convention has been ratified by all EU Member States. Under the Convention, the law of the State in which the child is resident applies and the case falls within the jurisdiction of the court of that State. The Convention also ensures the immediate return of a child who has been unlawfully taken abroad. The EU now has exclusive external competence in such matters. In the absence of a convention, a party from another State tends to take advantage of the lack of cooperation between States in order to obtain childcare, in which case the courts of both States concerned may classipose the case to its own jurisdiction and award the right to custody to a parent of its own nationality. It is therefore important that as many states as possible become parties to the international convention. Following Peru's accession to the Convention, a council decision is needed authorizing the adoption of two Member States not yet adopted by Peru (Austria and Romania). This will allow the Agreement to enter into force between Peru and the EU. Peru's accession to the Convention will help the number of EU citizens of Peruvian origin. I supported the report.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I fully support Peru's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. The Convention, signed by 93 countries, regulates the legal granting of custody of a child and grants legal force to the laws of the country in which the child is permanently resident. This is a very important regulation, because nowadays more and more marriages are falling apart and, unfortunately, there are even cases of abductions. I voted in favour because it is not possible to prevent any state that meets the requirements from acceding to such an important convention. I also believe that Austria and Romania should give their consent as soon as possible.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of the accession of Peru as the main scope is protecting children which find themselves in legal uncertainty. The Hague Convention is an important international instrument of cooperation which enables signatory states to settle cross border cases regarding child custody and abduction. It is a fundamental tool that clarifies the applicable national law in cases where there is a conflict of competence between two or more national legal systems.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is an extremely important instrument with the main objective of dealing with cases of international child abduction, I welcome the accession of the Republic of Peru to the Convention.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. These reports propose the approval by the European Parliament of a Council decision on Peru's accession to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction. This convention, ratified by all EU Member States, provides for cooperation mechanisms to remedy jurisdictional conflicts when two jurisdictions declare themselves competent for childcare in the context of the separation of a binational couple. Considering that these reports contribute to the harmonization of international regulations on family dispute management, I supported this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the Council's proposed decision authorising Austria and Romania to accept, in the interests of the European Union, Peru's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction. By establishing the primacy of the jurisdiction and laws of the state in which the child resides, the convention plays a decisive role in resolving the issues surrounding the issue of custody of the child during the separation of binational couples. The Convention is an indispensable tool for the international protection of children, which has also enabled the development of an expedited procedure for the return of child victims of abduction. However, for the convention to be implemented, it is necessary for one state's accession to be accepted by the other States Parties to the Convention. Although Peru joined in 2001, Austria and Romania have still not accepted membership. In order to ensure that children linked to the Peruvian community are protected from abduction, we call on the Council to adopt as soon as possible a decision authorising Austria and Romania to accept Peru's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on civil aspects of the abduction of children establishes a system enabling cooperation between Contracting States to find solutions to the issue of the abduction of children abroad. The biggest problem in such cases is the national nature of the legal system of states. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve such situations at international level by determining that the law of the State in which the child is resident applies and that the case falls within the jurisdiction of the court of that State. The Convention also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of a child who has been unlawfully taken abroad. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area, as confirmed by the Court of Justice in Opinion No 1/13. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own competences. The problem arises from the fact that the Convention does not provide for the independent action of international organisations, so that, following peru's accession to the Convention, a decision of the Council is needed authorises the two Member States which have not yet adopted peru's accession, Austria and Romania, to accept the accession of Peru. This will allow the Convention to enter into force between Peru and the European Union as a whole. In view of the above, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU already has exclusive external competence in the field of international child abduction confirmed by the Court of Justice. But in order for this to be applied, the Member States must act in unison. The Council's authorisation of Austria and Romania to accept Peru's accession to the Hague Convention will have beneficial consequences for the whole of the European Union by improving cooperation at Eu ropean level to defend children's rights, such as the right to education and economic opportunities for a prosperous future. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. Every year around the world, several thousand children are abducted by one of the two parents. In the absence of cooperation between the State of origin and the child's state of residence, some cases cannot be resolved. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction is a legal instrument for recognizing the jurisdiction of the jurisdiction of the state in which the child resides. A dialogue can thus be established between the States Parties to this Convention to facilitate the return of the abducted child. The European Union supports the accession of third countries to the 1980 Convention so that its Member States can rely on a common legal framework to deal with international child abductions. In addition to the general objective of developing judicial cooperation, this regulation pursues the general objective of protecting children's rights. Peru's accession to the convention is therefore good news.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 The 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is an important international agreement aimed at finding solutions in situations where the courts of both States (in the case of parents of two different nationalities) declare themselves competent and each of them gives custody of the child to the parent who is its national.  The Convention establishes that the competent authorities are those where the child is resident. The Convention also introduces a system to ensure the immediate return of children who have been abducted. The EU now has exclusive external competence in this area and therefore Member States no longer act at their own expense.  In this report, I propose to give Austria and Romania the right to accept Peru's accession to this international agreement.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 We consider the text to be positive because it is necessary for the Hague Convention on child abductions to be ratified by all states. This will resolve the hands of the authorities for cooperation both in investigations around the world and in the repatriation of the victim. One of the most important problems facing them is the cases of parents who are separated and come from different states. The Treaty simplifies efforts to find a solution for the child.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on civil aspects of the abduction of children establishes a system enabling cooperation between Contracting States to find solutions to the issue of the abduction of children abroad. The biggest problem in such cases is the national nature of the legal system of states. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve such situations at international level by determining that the law of the State in which the child is resident applies and that the case falls within the jurisdiction of the court of that State. The Convention also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of a child who has been unlawfully taken abroad. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area, as confirmed by the Court of Justice in Opinion No 1/13. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own competences. The problem arises from the fact that the Convention does not provide for the independent action of international organisations, so that, following peru's accession to the Convention, a decision of the Council is needed authorises the two Member States which have not yet adopted peru's accession, Austria and Romania, to accept the accession of Peru. This will allow the Convention to enter into force between Peru and the European Union as a whole. In view of the above, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: in writing. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on civil aspects of international child abduction is an instrument of crucial importance, which has been ratified by all member states of the Union. This Convention establishes a system that allows the cooperation of Contracting States to find a solution to situations of international child abduction. Peru's accession to the Convention is good news and the rapporteur shows his full support, given in particular that many citizens of the Union are of Peruvian origin. Thanks to the Convention, minors linked to the Peruvian community will be protected against illegal abduction. The rapporteur therefore proposes that Parliament adopt the proposal without modification in order to ensure the protection of such minors throughout the territory of the Union.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the accession of Peru to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, which is a multilateral treaty that provides a way for abducted children to be returned from one member country to another. Countries need to work together in order to tackle international, cross-border problems like these, and for Peru to join will enlarge this network to fight child abduction more effectively. I support any measures which help safeguard the well-being of children in Wales.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The Convention in question establishes a system of cooperation between Contracting States aimed at finding a solution to cases of international child abduction. This type of situation occurs very often when a couple is apart. There are very frequent cases of international child abductions reported by the press that occur following separations and divorces. The Convention aims to remedy such situations on an international scale by establishing that cases are tried by the competent courts and in accordance with the applicable legislation of the minor's State of residence. The Convention also establishes a system ensuring the immediate return of abducted minors. Peru's convention's adoption deserves my praise and approval.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Vote for: in favour of the adoption of this text because these countries have chosen to apply for membership.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 The report agrees on a Council decision authorising Peru's authorisation to the Hague Convention on civil aspects relating to international child abduction. This Convention establishes a system of cooperation between States aimed at finding a solution to cases of international child abduction. Its purpose is to ensure the return of children unlawfully transferred to or wrongly held in any Contracting State and to enforce effectively in the other Contracting States the custody and visitation rights existing in a Contracting State. The situation of child abduction sometimes occurs when a couple is apart, and parents are originally from different states. It is common for the courts of their respective countries to declare themselves both competent and that the courts grant custody of the minor to the national parent of the State they represent. The Purpose of the Convention is to remedy such situations at international level by establishing that cases are tried by the competent courts in accordance with the applicable legislation of the child's State of residence. The importance of the system ensuring the immediate return of abducted minors is underlined. We voted in favour, since the Agreement is intended to defend the interests of minors.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union has a very strong position in guaranteeing fundamental rights and strives to ensure that citizens of individual Member States are not put at risk and that their fundamental rights are protected. Among the instruments adopted by the European Union to protect children's rights is the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980. The convention in question allows the Contracting Parties to cooperate and seek common solutions in cases of international child abduction, which still happen in the 21st century. Following the accession of Peru to this Convention, it is necessary for the Council to issue a decision authorising two Member States Austria and Romania which have not yet accepted the accession of Peru to accept accession. This will allow the entry into force of the Convention between Peru and the entire European Union.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report which allows states to cooperate in finding a solution to cases of international child abduction.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council decision authorising the Republic of Austria and Romania, in the interests of the European Union, to accept Peru's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on Civil Matters of International Child Abduction, because the Hague Convention on child abductions needs to be ratified by all States.  This resolves the hands of the authorities for cooperation both in the field of investigations worldwide and in the repatriation of the victim. One of the most important problems solved, in fact, is in the case of parents who are separated and belong to different states. The Treaty simplifies finding a solution for the child.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, adopted in 1980, is an international instrument of cooperation, enabling signatory states to settle cross-border cases of child custody. The Convention clarifies the applicable national law in cases when there is a conflict of competence between two or more national legal systems. The scope regards civil aspects, so it concerns mostly situations of separated parents or other persons having legal rights over the child. Given that the scope of the Convention is protecting children finding themselves in legal uncertainty, the aim is to have it ratified by as many states as possible. All EU Member States have ratified. This report aims at giving Austria and Romania the authorisation to accept the accession of Peru to the Convention, which will allow the entering into force of the Convention between Peru and the entire EU. I voted in favour of the report.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of the abduction of children establishes a system enabling cooperation between Contracting States. In such cases, the biggest problem is the national nature of the legal system of states. The Convention establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of a child who has been unlawfully taken abroad. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area, as confirmed by the Court of Justice in Opinion No 1/13. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve such situations at international level by determining that the law of the State in which the child is resident applies and that the case falls within the jurisdiction of the court of that State. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own competences. The problem arises from the fact that the Convention does not provide for the independent action of international organisations, so that, following peru's accession to the Convention, a decision of the Council is needed authorises the two Member States which have not yet adopted peru's accession, Austria and Romania, to accept the accession of Peru. This will allow the Convention to enter into force between Peru and the European Union as a whole. In view of the above, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on civil aspects of the abduction of children establishes a system enabling cooperation between Contracting States to find solutions to the issue of the abduction of children abroad. The biggest problem in such cases is the national nature of the legal system of states. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve such situations at international level by determining that the law of the State in which the child is resident applies and that the case falls within the jurisdiction of the court of that State. The Convention also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of a child who has been unlawfully taken abroad. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area, as confirmed by the Court of Justice in Opinion No 1/13. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own competences. The problem arises from the fact that the Convention does not provide for the independent action of international organisations, so that, following peru's accession to the Convention, a decision of the Council is needed authorises the two Member States which have not yet adopted peru's accession, Austria and Romania, to accept the accession of Peru. This will allow the Convention to enter into force between Peru and the European Union as a whole. In view of the above, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report with the aim of take into account Peru's accession to the Convention. A Council decision is necessary to authorise the two Member States which have not yet accepted Peru's accession, namely Austria and Romania, to accept it, which will allow the Peru-eu-wide Convention to enter into force. There is no doubt that Peru's accession to the Convention is good news, given in particular that many citizens of the Union are of Peruvian origin. Thanks to the Convention, minors linked to the Peruvian community will be protected against illegal abduction.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's legislative resolution on the proposal for a Council decision authorising the Republic of Austria and Romania, in the interests of the European Union, to accept Peru's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, as the last necessary legislative step for the validity between the EU and Peru of a text adopted back in 1980. This was a firm vote in favour of greater protection for minors, who are increasingly the victims of disputes and events alien to them and which trample on their rights. It is therefore important for Austria and Romania to accept, in the interests of the EU, Peru's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Abduction of Children, which is unfortunately increasingly common practice in multi-national families facing separation.  I fully support the Convention's intention to regulate such situations at international level, establishing that the competent courts are those of the child's country of residence, in place of the courts of the parent's state of nationality. This criterion, in fact, protects the child more and is more in accordance with his personal history, linking the applicable law to the actual stay in a territory.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 introduces a system enabling cooperation between States in the settlement of cases concerning the abduduction of children abroad. The purpose of the above Convention is to remedy such situations at international level by establishing the courts competent to hear such disputes. In this case, the laws of the country in which the child resides apply. In addition, the Convention introduces a system to guarantee the immediate return to the country of an abducted minor. Today's vote reflects the fact that we want as many countries as possible to accede to this convention. Many EU citizens come from Peru and children with links to the country will now be protected from illegal abduction.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. The Hague Convention, which has been in place since 1980, focuses on the protection of children. The established civil aspects for the prevention of child abductions and the repatriation of abducted children are part of an incontrovertible strategy to protect the well-being of children. I very much welcome the accession of as many states as possible to this convention.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to abstain on this vote because it is such an emotive issue. The right of countries acceding to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is extremely important; however, this should be done at the will of the individual country and not en masse by the EU.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. As this accession was a manifestation of the will of the States concerned, there was no reason to oppose it by an unfavourable vote. It is absolutely necessary to act to protect children and parents alike.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Peru's accession to the Hague Convention in relation to the civil aspects of international child abduction, because it entails greater protection and guarantees for children. The Hague Convention establishes a system that allows the cooperation of Contracting States to find a solution to situations of international child abduction. These cases usually occur in cases of separations with parents from different countries. The Convention regulates that the applicable legislation in such cases is that of the child's State of residence. It also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of the stolen child.

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Report on the proposal for a Council decision authorising the Republic of Austria and Romania to consent, in the interest of the European Union, to Peru's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on civil aspects of international child abduction. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction is a document of particular importance, since it introduces a system enabling contracting States to cooperate in the settlement of cases relating to the international abduction of a child by one of the parents or legal guardians. It is consistently problematic in such situations to determine the court competent to grant custody of a child to a parent or guardian where each parent or guardian has the nationality of another country.  The purpose of the Convention is to address this problem at international level by establishing that only the courts and laws of the State in which the child resides are competent. The Convention also introduces a system to guarantee the immediate return of the abducted child.  As many EU citizens come from Peru and have links to the Peruvian community and are therefore vulnerable to illegal abducts, it is important for Parliament to approve this proposal to ensure that children are protected throughout the EU.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the accession of Peru to protect children which find themselves in legal uncertainty. The Hague Convention enables signatory states to settle cross-border cases regarding child custody and abduction. It is a fundamental tool that clarifies the applicable national law in cases where there is a conflict of competence between two or more national legal systems.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on civil aspects of the abduction of children establishes a system enabling cooperation between Contracting States to find solutions to the issue of the abduction of children abroad. The biggest problem in such cases is the national nature of the legal system of states. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve such situations at international level by determining that the law of the State in which the child is resident applies and that the case falls within the jurisdiction of the court of that State. The Convention also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of a child who has been unlawfully taken abroad. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area, as confirmed by the Court of Justice in Opinion No 1/13. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own competences. The problem arises from the fact that the Convention does not provide for the independent action of international organisations, so that, following peru's accession to the Convention, a decision of the Council is needed authorises the two Member States which have not yet adopted peru's accession, Austria and Romania, to accept the accession of Peru. This will allow the Convention to enter into force between Peru and the European Union as a whole.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I support Peru’s accession to the 1980 Hague Convention. The Convention is the cornerstone of EU judicial cooperation in matrimonial matters and matters of parental responsibility. Two other EU Member States have already accepted the accession of Peru to the 1980 Hague Convention and should therefore not deposit a new declaration of acceptance, as the existing declaration remains valid under public international law.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour since I have no objections.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on civil aspects of the abduction of children establishes a system enabling cooperation between Contracting States to find solutions to the issue of the abduction of children abroad. The biggest problem in such cases is the national nature of the legal system of states. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve such situations at international level by determining that the law of the State in which the child is resident applies and that the case falls within the jurisdiction of the court of that State. The Convention also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of a child who has been unlawfully taken abroad. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area, as confirmed by the Court of Justice in Opinion No 1/13. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own competences. The problem arises from the fact that the Convention does not provide for the independent action of international organisations, so that, following peru's accession to the Convention, a decision of the Council is needed authorises the two Member States which have not yet adopted peru's accession, Austria and Romania, to accept the accession of Peru. This will allow the Convention to enter into force between Peru and the European Union as a whole. In view of the above, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: In writing. I supported the Council's decision on Peru's accession to the Hague Convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction. This convention, ratified by all EU member states, provides for cooperation mechanisms to remedy jurisdictional conflicts when two jurisdictions declare themselves competent for childcare in the context of the separation of a binational couple.  It is essential to preserve the interests of the child and that is why I welcome the fact that countries in Europe and the rest of the world are making commitments in which they reaffirm their desire to clarify the separation procedure so as not to be indirectly complicit in child abductions.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ This report aims at giving Austria and Romania the authorisation to accept the accession of Peru to the Convention, which will allow the entering into force of the Convention between Peru and the entire EU. I voted in favour.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Proposal for a Council Decision authorisation of the Republic of Austria and Romania to accept Peru's approach to the Hague Convention on civil-legal aspects of international child abduction in 1980 in the interest of the European Union, as this allows the two countries mentioned to accept Peru's access.  The entry into force of the Peru-EU Convention is of particular importance as many European citizens are originally from Peru. It is essential that the problem of child abduction is addressed internationally, and that the applicable laws and competent courts are those of the child's country of residence. I believe it is necessary for Parliament to approve the proposal without amendments, and therefore I support this Report.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. It is necessary to strengthen cooperation between states on international child abduction in order to curb the exploitation of individuals from different states. By establishing jurisdiction over the child's state of residence, the Convention was able to resolve the issue of the return of children and give the European Union exclusive external jurisdiction. Since the Peruvian state has made the sovereign choice to join, I have no reason to oppose the adoption of the text.  I voted for it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – Diane James and her UKIP MEP colleagues chose to abstain on this vote because it is such an emotive issue.  The right of countries acceding to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is extremely important; however, this should be done at the will of the individual country and not en bloc by the EU.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the accession of Peru to the 1980 Hague Convention because the Convention represents the international insurance system of the immediate return of children who have been abducted, which has high importance nowadays. It is in the interest of EU citizens that Peru joins the Convention and enlarges the list of the countries which have already agreed to cooperate in such cases. A functioning system of cooperation ensures children’s rights on the international level.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Angel Dzhambazki's report, which endorses the Council's decision on the implementation of the Hague Convention between the European Union and Peru. This convention establishes a system of judicial cooperation. Widely supported in Parliament, this procedure will put the best interests of the child back at the heart of international justice decisions, particularly in cases of abduction following divorce.  This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on Peru's accession to the Hague Convention because it is necessary to expand the list of States Parties to this text, which guarantees the return of children displaced or illegally detained by one of their parents in a state and aims more broadly to enforce access, custody and accommodation rights.

name: Eva KAILI
text: Writing. – The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on civil matters relating to international child abduction is a vital tool. It has been ratified by all the Member States of the European Union. This Convention establishes a system allowing Contracting States to cooperate in finding a solution to situations of international child abduction. It is therefore necessary, following Peru's accession to the Convention, to adopt a Council decision authorising the two Member States which have not yet accepted Peru's accession, namely Austria and Romania, to do so. This will allow the Convention between Peru on the one hand and the European Union as a whole to enter into force on the other.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I agree with this report. The agreement regulates cases of international child abduction by partners of different nationalities or residences and includes rules for settling custody disputes. Peru's commitment to this agreement is an important step towards strengthening the rights of children.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, as the accession will allow states acceding to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction to participate in enhanced international cooperation with other signatories to the Convention.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the proposal for Peru's accession to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction.  A major problem in cases of international child abduction is the national bias of the legal systems of individual countries in the case of separation of parents. The Convention will help at international level to find a solution to such situations in order to avoid the subjective award of parental rights to the parent who is a national of the State of the court.  Upon adoption of the Convention, the competent court and the applicable law shall be the state of the child's location. I strongly support the introduction of a system ensuring the immediate return of abducted children.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. ‒ The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a multilateral treaty, which seeks to protect children from the harmful effects of abduction and retention across international boundaries by providing a procedure to bring about their prompt return. The treaty has been ratified by all EU Member States. In light of this, it is important to note that the EU now has exclusive external competence in this field as confirmed by the Court of Justice in Opinion 1/13, which means that Member States no longer act on their own account. However, the paradox is that the Convention does not provide for autonomous action by international organisations. In this sense, a Council decision is necessary to authorise the Member States, in particular Austria and Romania, to accept the accession of Peru. Therefore, I call both the EU and Member States to welcome and accept the accession of Peru to the Convention because in this manner children’s rights will be protected and preserved.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. The proposal adopted today will allow the contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution that will enable cases of international abduction of children to be resolved. In most cases the problem arises when a couple separates, specifically when the parents come from different states, giving rise to legal battles to obtain custody of the children. The courts of the states involved tend to entrust the child to the parent who is a national of the State in which the court is located. For these reasons, the intention of this report appears to be to resolve international problems and to ensure that the competent courts and applicable laws are those of the child's state of residence, thus ensuring the possibility of an immediate return of the stolen child. I have therefore chosen to vote in favour.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it helps to deal with cases of international child abduction. Peru has chosen to apply for membership.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on Peru's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction. This convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction establishes a system of cooperation between contracting states to deal with cases of international child abduction. It has been ratified by all EU Member States. In many cases, these problems arise when a couple is separated. If the mother and father are from different states, there is a temptation to exploit the lack of cooperation between states in order to obtain custody of the child. The purpose of the convention is to resolve such situations at the international level, by establishing that the competent courts and applicable laws are those of the child's state of residence. The convention also introduces a system that ensures the immediate return of abducted children. After ratification, the convention will enter into force between Peru and the entire European Union.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction establishes a system of cooperation between contracting states to deal with international child abduction cases. It has been ratified by all the Member States of the European Union. The main purpose of the Convention is to resolve child custody situations at the international level, establishing that the competent jurisdictions and applicable laws are those of the child's state of residence. The convention also introduces a system that ensures the immediate return of children who have been abducted. The Union now has exclusive external jurisdiction in this area, as confirmed by the Court of Justice in its opinion 1/13. After ratification, the convention will enter into force between Peru and the entire European Union. I am therefore in favour of the adoption of this text because these countries have chosen to apply for membership.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of authorization to accept Peru's access to the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, which will allow the rule to enter into force in this country and all the Member States of the Union.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Peru's accession to the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, since I consider this type of coordination among States to be positive in resolving the sensitive cases of international child abduction, with the aim of moving towards respect for the rights and interests of children.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. This draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the proposal for a Council Decision approves authorisation for Austria and Romania to accept, in the interests of the Union, Peru's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on civil aspects of international child abduction, so that this Agreement between the Union and Peru will enter into force.  The Convention is an instrument of vital importance, as it structures the cooperation of participating States in order to find a solution to international child abduction. An example is the case of divorce between two persons of different nationality, since it is often the case that one of the two tries to use his own national legislation, usually favouring his own citizens.  I am voting in favour as this Convention, which protects minors, will be more effective the more States that adhere to it.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour. I consider the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction to be a useful instrument for international cooperation, especially in cases of mixed marriages where one of the parents takes the child to his or her original country. This Decision authorises Austria and Romania to approve the accession of Peru to the Convention. Sadly, Austria and Romania need EU approval to do so.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: in writing. \u2012 Peru recently acceded to the Convention on the Abduction of Children, but Romania and Austria have not yet accepted this. I believe, however, that Romania and Austria must do so, because only in this way will the Convention be able to be applied in relations between the EU in its entirety and this South American country. The Convention adopted in The Hague on 25 October 1980, which defines the legal framework of the United Nations on the abduction of children by one of the parents, is an extremely important tool for the regulation of this crime. Ratified by all EU Member States as well as other countries around the world (93 in total) the document clarifies situations where courts in two different states that have to review a file (if parents have different citizens) are considered competent each individually and therefore grant custody in parallel to the parent of that country. The Convention has shed light on these cases by establishing that the court in the country of residence of the child is competent. As an immediate consequence, if the child is with the parent who does not reside in the same state as the child, then the child must bring him to the country where the parent who has the same residence as the child is located. The European Union has exclusive jurisdiction in these cases, which is confirmed by the European Court of Justice.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ This Convention has been ratified by all EU Member States and introduces a system of cooperation to deal with cases of international child abduction. The purpose of the Convention is to deal with such situations at international level, which determines the jurisdiction of the courts and the applicability of the law and a system that ensures the immediate return of children abducted. In addressing these issues, the EU has exclusive competence. Following Peru's accession to the Convention, it is necessary for council decisions to be approved by two Member States that have not yet approved accession, namely Austria and Romania. This will allow the Convention between Peru and the entire European Union to enter into force, so I supported this report.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. ‒ Austria and Romania to accept, in the interest of the European Union, the accession of Peru to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. I support expanding the possibilities of children’s rights protection.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention has been ratified by all Member States of the Union. It shall provide for the cooperation of the Contracting Parties in ensuring the immediate return of children wrongfully relocated or detained in another State and in ensuring that rights of custody and access rights under the law of one Contracting State are respected in other Contracting States. The Convention shall apply to all children who are habitually resident in the territory of a Contracting State. I therefore welcome the fact that, with Peru's accession to the Convention, such protection will also be afforded to children, who are in some way bound to the Peruvian community.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council decision authorising the Republic of Austria and Romania, in the interests of the European Union, to accept Peru's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on Civil Matters of International Child Abduction, because it is complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted for this text.  It concerns Peru's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction.  This text allows for cooperation between the contracting states and determines the competent jurisdiction when it is necessary to determine custody of the children, in the event of separation of a couple whose parents do not have the same nationality. This text has been put in place and ratified by all Member States, in order to prevent two courts, from two different countries, from declaring themselves competent. The rule is simplified: the applicable laws are those of the child's state of residence. In addition, it establishes the immediate return of the abducted children. Finally, this country has chosen to apply for membership, which we agree with.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council decision on Peru's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on The Civil Matters of International Child Abduction because this Convention is a vital tool because it enables The Contracting States to cooperate in finding a solution to international child abduction issues. At this point it should be stressed that the courts are competent but the law of the State where the child resides should apply.
