For the above reasons, but also because of the humanitarian nature of this convention, Austria and Romania should accept Peru's accession.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. States Parties agree to implement a system of cooperation in the event of child abduction by separate partners of different nationalities. The place of jurisdiction for this shall be the state of residence of the child. Furthermore, as the resolution of the child's return to the appropriate parent is to be speeded up, thereby reducing the burden on the child in international custody disputes, I agree with this request.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the EP's report on the Council decision authorising the Republic of Austria and Romania, in the interest of the European Union, to approve Peru's accession to the 1980 agreement. the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. Peru's accession to the Convention is to be welcomed, especially since a significant number of EU citizens come from Peru. So children with ties to the Peruvian community will be protected from abduction.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. I welcome Peru's accession to the International Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. This convention aims to reduce legal conflicts between different national jurisdictions in cases of difficult separations of binational couples. The signatory states undertake that the court responsible for the right of custody and access be that of the child's state of residence. The aim here is to allow Austria and Romania to recognise Peru's accession to the convention. A surreal vote when the right decision of two sovereign Member States was taken to recognise that a third country would join an international convention. What for? Because, under the 1/13 opinion of the Court of Justice, the Commission now has exclusive jurisdiction over the application of this decision in civil matters on "its" territory. I challenge this limitation of sovereignty. Nevertheless, I vote for this recognition of adherence to the convention for the benefit of the protection of children across borders.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction establishes a system of cooperation between contracting states to deal with international child abduction cases. It has been ratified by all the Member States of the European Union. The main purpose of the Convention is to resolve child custody situations at the international level, establishing that the competent jurisdictions and applicable laws are those of the child's state of residence. The convention also introduces a system that ensures the immediate return of children who have been abducted. The Union now has exclusive external jurisdiction in this area as confirmed by the Court of Justice in its opinion 1/13. After ratification, the convention will enter into force between these three countries and the European Union as a whole. I am therefore in favour of the adoption of this text because these countries have chosen to apply for membership.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 The objective of the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction (hereinafter referred to as the '1980 Convention'), until now ratified by 93 countries, including all EU Member States, is to restore the status quo by the immediate return of children unlawfully transferred or retained through a system of cooperation between the central authorities designated by the Contracting Parties. In 2015, Peru informed the Commission of its interest in the Convention also entering into force in relation to Austria and Romania, which should therefore be authorised by the European Union to accept Peru's accession to the 1980 Convention. The acceptance of Austria and Romania will make the 1980 Convention applicable between Peru and all EU Member States except Denmark. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this legislative resolution as it seeks to provide safeguards to children against abduction.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. International abductions are a particularly complicated subject because of human issues, the international character and the multitude of applicable texts and conventions. The answers must live up to these unacceptable human tragedies. In view of the fact that the European Union has many citizens of Peruvian origin, it is essential that the Union as a whole recognises this accession so that, in the end, children linked to the Peruvian community are protected from illegal abduction. All EU Member States are parties to the 1980 Hague Convention. The EU also encourages third countries to join, which Peru did in 2001. However, in order for the Convention to apply to the Union, peru must accept its accession, which Austria and Romania had not yet done.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report, which aims at giving Austria and Romania the authorisation to accept the accession of Peru to the Convention, which will allow the entering into force of the Convention between Peru and the entire EU. All the other EU Member States have given their approval to Peru to accede. The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, adopted in 1980, is an international instrument of cooperation, enabling signatory states to settle cross border cases regarding child custody and abduction. The Convention clarifies the applicable national law in cases when there is a conflict of competence between two or more national legal systems. The scope regards civil aspects, so it concerns mostly situations of separated parents or other persons having legal rights on the child. Given that the scope of the Convention is protecting children finding themselves in legal uncertainty, the aim is to have it ratified by as many states as possible. All EU Member States have ratified.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of the abduction of children establishes a system enabling cooperation between Contracting States to find a solution to the abduction of children and to ensure the immediate return of the child who has been abducted abroad. The Convention has been ratified by all the Member States of the European Union. Peru has announced its intention to join the Convention. Since the Convention does not provide for the independent action of international organisations, the European Union cannot ratify such an addition to the Treaty.  However, since the opinion of the European Court of Justice dated 14 October 2014 states that the EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area, the Member States which have not ratified this supplement by that date (Austria and Romania) can only do so with the authorisation of the European Council. The Council therefore intends to take a decision which would give Austria and Romania the power to ratify Peru's accession, but it will have to consult Parliament. In its report, the Committee on Legal Affairs proposes that Parliament approve the Council's proposal for a decision. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction establishes a system of cooperation between contracting states to resolve these cases. It has been ratified by all EU member states. Its aim is to resolve such situations at the international level, by establishing that the competent courts and applicable laws are those of the child's state of residence. The Convention also introduces a system that ensures the immediate return of abducted children. The EU now has exclusive external jurisdiction in this area. As a result, Member States are no longer acting on their own behalf. After ratification, the Convention will enter into force between Peru and the entire European Union. We are in favour of the adoption of these texts because these countries have chosen to apply for membership.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction of 25 October 1980 is an instrument of vital importance and has been ratified by all EU Member States. This Convention establishes a system of cooperation between Contracting States with the aim of finding a solution to cases of international child abduction. With Peru's accession to the Convention, a Council decision is needed to authorise the two Member States which have not yet accepted Peru's accession, in particular Austria and Romania, to do so. In this way, the Convention will enter into force between Peru and the entire European Union. I support the adoption of this proposal in order to ensure the protection of the minors concerned throughout the territory of the European Union.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The European Union now has exclusive external jurisdiction in this area as confirmed by the Court of Justice in its opinion 1/13. As a result, Member States are no longer acting on their own behalf. The problem is that the convention does not provide for autonomous action by international organizations. After ratification, the convention will enter into force between these three countries and the European Union as a whole. I am in favour of the adoption of these texts because these countries have chosen to apply for membership.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on Peru's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction. In order to avoid conflicts of laws or jurisdictions as far as possible when it comes to resolving a dispute involving an international situation, international conventions must be signed and ratified by the highest possible number of states.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which endorses a Council decision on Peru's accession to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction. This convention, ratified by all members of the Union, provides for cooperation mechanisms to remedy jurisdictional conflicts when two jurisdictions declare themselves competent for childcare in the context of the separation of a binational couple.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction is an instrument of fundamental importance which has been ratified by all the Member States of the European Union by introducing a system allowing contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution to cases of international child abduction. It is often the case that the courts of both states involved declare themselves competent and that each of them entrusts the child to the parent who is a national of the State in which the court is located. The convention aims to resolve these situations at international level. I therefore voted in favour of Peru's accession to the Convention, thus allowing children linked to the Peruvian community to benefit from protection throughout the European Union.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 The growing trend of disintegrating marriages, open borders and visa waiver make this topic more timely than ever. Even a peaceful divorce of parents is a serious psychological burden for children, so think of families where one of the parties tries to escape a court decision on the placement of the child with different practices. In some cases, this can lead to a parent deciding to abduct their own child and fleeing abroad. The Purpose of the Hague Convention is to avoid this eventuality by proposing solutions such as speeding up judicial proceedings or minimising administrative burdens. I was pleased to vote in favour of peru joining the Convention!

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ The Hague Convention has as its primary objective the cases of international abduction of children due to the separation of the parents who have different citizenship from each other. I have voted for this report that will grant the accession of Peru to the Convention in order to ensure EU’s protection to the children in that specific part.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report because it resolves custody disputes. This provision is particularly advantageous in custody disputes where parents prove different nationalities.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The Convention is crucial to ensure that international child abduction cases are resolved as quickly and effectively as possible. Peru's accession to the Convention is welcome and will therefore be better protected for children associated with the Peruvian community in the future.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The 1980 Hague Convention is a vital tool as it ensures the immediate return of children abducted by a parent in the same State of residence, as well as the protection of the parent's rights of communication with their child. As international abductions of children by parents are a global problem involving thousands of children each year, Peru's accession to the Convention is positive. I voted in favour of the report because, as the rapporteur points out, many EU citizens come from Peru, which means that, with the country's accession to the Hague Convention, protection against abductions of children with ties to the Peruvian community will be ensured.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP chose to abstain on this vote because it is such an emotive issue.  The right of countries acceding to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is extremely important; however, this should be done at the will of the individual country and not en bloc by the EU.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ Preventing child abduction is an important part of the EU's policy to promote the rights of the child, with the aim of adopting the Hague Convention on civil-legal aspects of international child abduction since 25 October 1980. At international level, the European Union is actively working to improve its application and encourages third countries to approach it. In 2001, Peru also passed the instrument of accession to the Convention and was accepted by most Member States with the exception of Austria, Denmark and Romania. In 2011, the Commission adopted eight proposals for Council decisions aimed at accepting the eight countries' access to this Hague Convention. In 2014, the Court of Justice of the European Union stated that the acceptance of a third State's approach to the Convention falls within the exclusive competence of the European Union. Following this decision, in 2015 the Council of the European Union adopted seven decisions based on the 2011 proposals. This proposal takes into account a third country (Peru) that joined the Convention before the EU's external competence was established. Respecting the rights of children as one of the fundamental issues of EU policy and with a desire to remain consistent in implementing our decisions, I support this proposal for a Council decision authorisation of the Republic of Austria and Romania to accept Peru's approach to the Hague Convention on civil-legal aspects of international child abduction in 1980 in the interest of the European Union.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction establishes a system of cooperation between contracting states to deal with international child abduction cases. It has been ratified by all EU member states. In many cases, these problems arise when a couple is separated. If the mother and father are from different states, there is a temptation to exploit the lack of cooperation between states in order to ensure the custody of the child. It is common for courts in the two states concerned to declare jurisdiction and to grant custody of the child to the parent who is a national of their state. The purpose of the convention is to resolve such situations at the international level, by establishing that the competent courts and applicable laws are those of the child's state of residence. The convention also introduces a system that ensures the immediate return of children who have been abducted. I am in favour of the adoption of this text, because Peru is choosing to apply for membership. So I'm voting for the text.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ The Hague Convention on the Civil-Legal Aspects of International Child Abduction is an instrument that primarily addresses international child abductions after the separation or divorce of parents, especially when the mother and father are from different countries. In practice, courts in both countries are declared competent and different decisions are taken, putting children in a position of legal uncertainty. This Convention aims to address this problem internationally by determining that the competent courts and applicable laws are those of the child's country of residence. The Convention also introduces a system to ensure the immediate return of abducted children. The Convention has been ratified by all EU Member States. The EU now has exclusive external competence in this area, as confirmed by the Court, but the Convention does not provide for the independent functioning of international organisations, therefore the EU must give all Member States the power to accept the new Member State's access to the Convention. In the event of Peru's accession to the Convention, a Council decision is needed to allow Austria and Romania to accept Peru's access, allowing the Convention between Peru and the entire European Union to enter into force. All other Member States have given their approval to Peru's accession to the Convention. I support this report as the objective of such a Convention is to be ratified by as many countries as possible, as this is becoming more effective.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. \u2012 This Convention establishes a system of cooperation between contracting States aimed at finding a solution to cases of international child abduction, seeking to ensure the immediate return of children unlawfully transferred to or wrongly held therein. The child abduction situation occurs very often when a couple of people secede and when the parents come from different states. The Convention thus aims to enforce effectively the custody and visitation rights existing in a Contracting State and mitigate responses of nationalist tendency of the legal systems of each State. It is common for the courts of their respective countries to declare both competent and that the courts grant custody of the minor to the national parent of the state they represent, decisions based on motivations which do not necessarily respond to the best interests of the child. The Purpose of the Convention is to resolve such situations at international level by establishing that cases are tried by the competent courts and in accordance with the applicable legislation of the child's state of residence. Peru has deposited the instrument of access and we have spoken in favour, as this Agreement is best to respond to the defence of the best interests of minors.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Abductions is essential and has already been ratified by all European Union countries. I am therefore very glad that Peru has also decided to take this step and thus significantly expand the possibility of cooperation on child abduction, given the large number of Peruvian citizens living in the European Union.  The purpose of the Hague Convention is to protect children from abductions, which occur in particular in cases where divorce occurs between parents from different States. If one of the parents decides to abduct the child to his or her home state and that state is not part of the cooperation in dealing with international child abductions, he can so easily get custody of the child. The courts in a non-cooperating State usually decide to place the child in the care of the parent who is a national of that State.  However, where a State is part of the Hague Convention, this situation may be resolved at international level and the courts and legislation of the State in which the child resides will be determined as final. Today, the European Parliament called on Austria and Romania, the last two countries that have not ratified the agreement, to do so. Of course, I supported this proposal.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe it is necessary, in order to ensure that the children concerned benefit from adequate regulatory protection within the EU, that Parliament approves this proposal. The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction has introduced a system that allows contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution to cases of international child abduction. The main problem in these circumstances is the tendency of the legal systems of individual States to practise favouritism on the basis of nationality. Following Peru's accession to the Convention, we need a Council decision authorizing the two Member States that have not yet accepted this accession – Austria and Romania – to do so. This will allow the Convention to take effect in relations between Peru and the whole of the European Union. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this technical report which endorses a Council decision on Peru's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on civil aspects of international child abduction.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 I support this report on Peru's acceding to the Hague Convention, as the system of that Convention becomes more effective if more countries accede to it. In divorce situations where parents come from different States, there is a temptation to take advantage of the lack of international cooperation to obtain custody of minors. Custody is often granted to the parent who is a national of the State in which the courts are based, there are therefore nationalist tendencies in the legal systems of each State. By establishing that cases are tried by the competent courts and in accordance with the applicable legislation of the minor's State of residence, the Convention permits cooperation between parties, as well as tends to settle such disputes on an international scale. It should be noted that the Commission, together with experts in the field of social justice, has assessed and approved the functioning of Peru's judicial system and its readiness for cooperation. For all this, I'm voting in favor.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP chose to abstain on this vote because it is such an emotive issue.  The right of countries acceding to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is extremely important; however, this should be done at the will of the individual country and not en bloc by the EU.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. I voted in favour, as the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a vitally important instrument that has been ratified by all EU Member States and establishes a system of cooperation between Contracting States aimed at finding a solution to international child abduction cases. In the case of children in which the parents are divorced, each from a different State, it is common for the courts of the two countries concerned to declare themselves competent and that the courts grant custody of the minor to the national parent of the State they represent. There are very frequent cases of international child abductions reported by the press that occur following separations and divorces. The Convention aims to remedy such situations on an international scale by establishing that cases are tried by the competent courts and in accordance with the applicable legislation of the minor's State of residence. The Convention also establishes a system ensuring the immediate return of abducted minors. It is therefore important to praise Peru's acceding to the Convention, as the system of the Hague Convention becomes more effective if more countries accede to it.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. MEPs this afternoon overwhelmingly approved the recognition of Peru's accession to the Hague Convention on International Child Abduction, of which all EU Member States are signatories. By 641 votes to three and 17 abstentions, MEPs welcomed Peru's entry into this system of cooperation that allows solutions to be found in the event of international child abduction.  This often occurs when a couple whose spouse is from another country separates. Sometimes the courts of the two countries concerned declare themselves competent but come to contrary conclusions, particularly with regard to the custody of the child.  The convention aims to remedy such situations: it designates the jurisdictions and law of the state where the child resides as competent, and organizes his immediate return.  The EU has many citizens of Peruvian origin on its soil and Spain, Italy and France, in particular, remain among the first countries of immigration of Peruvians. This accession is therefore very good news for international cooperation and the safety of the child, which must be continued by encouraging the enlargement of the circle of signatory countries, now numbering ninety-four.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 Following Peru's accession to the Hague Convention, a Council decision authorising the two Member States (Austria and Romania) which have not yet accepted accession to do so is necessary. This will allow the Convention to enter into force between Peru and the entire European Union.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. The 1980 Hague Convention on Civil Aspects of Child Abduction, signed by all Member States of the Union, is an instrument of international cooperation that authorizes signatory States to resolve transnational cases relating to the custody and abduction of minors, clarifying the national law applicable in cases where there is a conflict of jurisdiction between two or more national legal systems. The scope of the rule reaches civil aspects, applying mainly to cases of separate parents or other persons who have legal rights over the child. Since the objective of the Convention is to protect minors in a situation of legal uncertainty, it is important to ensure that it is signed by as many States as possible.  Since the Union has exclusive competence in this area, but the convention does not authorise the participation of international actors, the Union needs to give all its Member States express authorisation to accept the participation of any new State in the Convention. That is why I voted in favour of authorising the two Member States which have not yet accepted the accession of Peru, Austria and Romania to accept it.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of Peru's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction. International cooperation in this area is fundamental and is aimed primarily at safeguarding the interests of the child. Each new accession to this Convention is therefore a step forward with regard to the general objective of protecting the rights of the child which is enshrined in Article 3 of the Treaty on european Union.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report authorising the Republic of Austria and Romania, in the interest of the European Union, to support Peru's accession to the 1980 agreement. the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. The purpose of this Convention is to address at international level the problems of national bias in the legal systems of individual States, where the courts of both States recognise themselves as competent to hear the case and each child is assigned custody to the parent who is a national of their State. The Convention avoids this by ensuring that the laws held and applied by the competent courts are those of the State in which the child is habitually resident. The Convention also provides for a system to ensure that the abducted child is returned immediately. Following the accession of Peru to the Convention, a Council Decision is necessary for Austria and Romania, which have not yet approved peru's accession, to be empowered to accept the accession of that country.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation on the proposal for a Council decision authorising the Republic of Austria and Romania to accept, in the interests of the European Union (EU), peru's accession to the Hague Convention (1980) on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. This is a procedure which is the exclusive external competence of the EU (according to an opinion of the Court of Justice on the declaration of acceptance of membership of this Convention), with a view to ensuring the complete protection of minors in Europe in the event of international child abduction.  These are unfortunately recurrent situations, especially when there is divorce of parents with different nationalities. It is customary for each legal system to choose to declare the State from which each parent originates competent, so that the Convention plays a primary role in resolving these transnational conflicts, stipulating the jurisdiction of the court on the basis of the child's place of residence and a system ensuring the immediate return of abducted minors. As Austria and Romania have not yet accepted Peru's accession to the Convention, a Council decision (after consulting the European Parliament) is needed for the Convention to enter into force between Peru and the EU.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this technical text, which deals with the Council's decision authorising the Republic of Austria and Romania to accept, in the interests of the European Union, Peru's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction. The European Union has jurisdiction over this and, for that, a Council decision is needed.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction has finally been ratified by Peru as well. The whole of Europe is happy about this accession, not least because there are many European citizens of Peruvian origin. What is most comforting to me about this report is that children's rights are guaranteed, especially when it comes to abductions.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Peru's accession to the Hague Convention in relation to the civil aspects of international child abduction, because it entails greater protection and guarantees for children. The Hague Convention establishes a system that allows the cooperation of Contracting States to find a solution to situations of international child abduction. These cases usually occur in cases of separations with parents from different countries. The Convention regulates that the applicable legislation in such cases is that of the child's State of residence. It also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of the stolen child.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: in writing. ‒ The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is an important agreement to help avoid legal uncertainty in cases of cross border child custody. In those cases where custody of children is contested, a quick and fair resolution is in the interests of the child. Delays, confusion and uncertainty, not to mention expensive legal bills, should be avoided as far as possible. I welcome the addition of these new countries to this Convention, which is a vital form of cooperation in our increasingly interconnected world.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Peru's accession to the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, since I consider this type of coordination among States to be positive in resolving the sensitive cases of international child abduction, with the aim of moving towards respect for the rights and interests of children.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Today, I voted for the Package on the accession of Peru to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. This is important for engagement in enhanced international cooperation with other signatories to the Convention.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is an extremely important instrument. It has been ratified by all EU Member States. This Convention establishes a system enabling States Parties to cooperate in finding a solution in cases of international child abduction. Following the accession of Peru to this Convention, it was necessary for the Council to issue a decision authorising two Member States — Austria and Romania — which had not yet approved peru's accession to accept accession. This will allow the entry into force of the Convention between Peru and the entire European Union. I support this Council decision, which the Council has already issued in advance, which is why I voted in favour of its adoption. Many citizens of Peruvian origin live in the EU. Children who are in some way connected to the Peruvian community will be protected from kidnapping in this way.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported Peru's accession to the Hague Convention as it is an important international convention protecting the rights of the child. The Convention has been ratified by all EU Member States and today the EU already has exclusive external competence in this area, as the Court of Justice has ruled. It is therefore necessary for the Council to issue a decision authorising Austria and Romania to accept the accession. This will allow the entry into force of the Convention between Peru and the Union as a whole. EU countries will be able to use the system of cooperation with Peru to find solutions in cases of international child abduction. Such cases often occur when parents from different countries divorce. Parents may seek custody of that child when there is no cooperation between them by abducting the child. Individual countries have a strong national character in this matter of their legal systems. Therefore, there are regular situations where the courts of both States concerned are declared competent and that each of them grants custody to the parent. This is to be preceded by this convention, which requires that the competent court and the law of the State in which the child resides be determined at international level. Thus, children of Peruvian origin living in the EU will be better protected from abduction.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention deals with cases where a child is abducted by one of the parents to another state in the hope that the legislation there will give him a better position in the custody dispute. Extending the scope of the Hague Convention narrows the possibilities for such action and increases the international legal protection of children.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil-legal aspects of international child abduction is a key instrument ratified by all EU Member States. The Convention establishes a system of cooperation between Contracting States to deal with cases of international child abductions that often occur when the child's parents are separated. The most common problem is the bias of individual national legal systems and the jurisdiction of courts in both countries. Following Peru's accession to the Convention, a Council decision is needed to allow two Member States that have not yet accepted Peru's approach, Austria and Romania, to do so, as many EU citizens are originally from Peru. I support the draft report of the Committee on Legal Affairs on the proposal for a Council decision authorisation of the Republic of Austria and Romania to accept, in the interest of the European Union, Peru's approach to the Hague Convention on civil-legal aspects of international child abduction in 1980.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The 1980 Hague Convention on Civil Matters of International Child Abduction is a vital tool and establishes a system that enables States Parties to cooperate in finding a solution to situations of international child abduction. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention on child abductions needs to be ratified by all states. This resolves the hands of the authorities for cooperation both in the field of investigations worldwide and in the repatriation of the victim. One of the most important problems solved, in fact, is in the case of parents who are separated and belong to different states. The Treaty simplifies finding a solution for the child.

name: József SZÁJER
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on civil aspects of the abduction of children establishes a system enabling cooperation between Contracting States to find solutions to the issue of the abduction of children abroad. The biggest problem in such cases is the national nature of the legal system of states. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve such situations at international level by determining that the law of the State in which the child is resident applies and that the case falls within the jurisdiction of the court of that State. The Convention also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of a child who has been unlawfully taken abroad. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area, as confirmed by the Court of Justice in Opinion No 1/13. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own competences. The problem arises from the fact that the Convention does not provide for the independent action of international organisations, so that, following peru's accession to the Convention, a decision of the Council is needed authorises the two Member States which have not yet adopted peru's accession, Austria and Romania, to accept the accession of Peru. This will allow the Convention to enter into force between Peru and the European Union as a whole. In view of the above, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of parliament's approval of the proposal because I am convinced that this will also strengthen the international protection of children who have been illegally taken abroad. I am aware that the relevant Hague Convention has proved to be one of the most extensive and successful international instruments in practice over the last three decades, often and actively used by States Parties as a legal basis for establishing jurisdiction and conducting proceedings against children in difficult and contentious situations after their parents' divorce. The EU currently has exclusive external competence to act on such matters, but in the case of newer States acceding to the Convention, member states' ratification and the Council's corresponding decision are necessary for entry into force, where appropriate between Peru and the EU. In view of the fact that the Functioning of the Hague Convention can be more effective the more states are parties to the system, I also welcome peru's accession.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a very important document, adopted at international level in 1980 and ratified by all EU Member States, which established cooperation between signatory States in this sensitive area. This situation arises in particular as a result of divorces of transnational couples and creates difficulties at national level with regard to guardianship of minor children. The Convention regulates the resolution of such cases and establishes the application of the law of the State of residence of the child, as well as the immediate return of abducted children. As the EU has exclusive external powers in this area, Member States must be authorised to accept the accession of third Countries to the Convention. This is the case for the accession of the Republic of Peru, a state which has had a number of internal conflicts in the past but which has successfully overcome that period. Currently, the Council must authorise two Member States, Austria and Romania, to accept this accession, which will allow the entry into force of the Convention between Peru and the whole EU. This is an important step in favour of EU citizens of Peruvian origin, which is why I support the adoption of this report.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. This convention establishes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in cases of international child abduction. This often occurs when a couple separates. For a husband or wife from another country, it may be tempting to take advantage of the lack of cooperation between states to obtain custody of the children. There is frequent press coverage of international child abductions that occur during separation or divorce. The major problem, therefore, is the nationalist conception that underlies the legal system of states. Often the courts of the two states concerned declare themselves competent and each of them entrusts custody of the child to that of the parents who have the nationality of the state in which it sits. The purpose of the convention in question is to remedy this kind of situation at the international level by establishing the jurisdiction of the courts and the law of the state in which the child resides. It also sets up a system to ensure the immediate return of the abducted child.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ The Hague Convention (1980) on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a vitally important instrument, ratified by all EU Member States. The Convention created a cooperative system between the signatory states in the goal of resolving cases of international child abduction. Most often, reports of child abduction are the result of a couple separating, where the mother and father are from different states. States often are unwilling or unable to cooperate with one another during instances of child abduction as a result of national bias of differing legal systems. Parents frequently exploit these legal and judicial disparities in order to secure full custody of the child in a particular state. I voted in favour of the accession of Peru so that child abduction at the international level can be resolved through the competent courts of the state of residence of the child.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I supported Peru's accession to the Hague Convention on civil-legal aspects of international child abduction ratified by all Member States of the European Union. Peru's accession to the Convention will allow the two Member States, Austria and Romania, to accept Peru as one of the states party to the Convention.  This Convention is extremely useful for addressing international child abduction, as national courts are often biased in the case of parents' separation. The Convention introduces a system of cooperation that addresses this problem at international level. As many European Union citizens are originally from Peru, I believe peru's accession will reduce the number of unsolved cases and allow the immediate return of abducted children.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. \u2012 Proposal for a Council Decision authoring the Republic of Austria and Romania to accept, in the interest of the European Union, the accession of Peru to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of international child abuse, I supported. Often problems arise when a couple is a separation. If they are parents from different countries, there is a danger that either of them might try to exploit the lack of cooperation between the two countries and to obtain exclusive custody of the children. The purpose of this Convention is to resolve such cases at international level by determining the courts and the law applicable to the competent courts and the law applicable by determining the courts and the law of the country in which the child is domiciled. The Convention also provides for a system for ensuring the immediate return of an immediately confiscated child.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Peru's accession to the Hague Convention in relation to the civil aspects of international child abduction, because it entails greater protection and guarantees for children. The Hague Convention establishes a system that allows the cooperation of Contracting States to find a solution to situations of international child abduction. These cases usually occur in cases of separations with parents from different countries. The Convention regulates that the applicable legislation in such cases is that of the child's State of residence. It also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of the stolen child.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I support this proposal, which prioritises child welfare in case of legal conflict (separation or divorce) between parents from different countries. This agreement will save time, money and suffering for the affected families and guarantees the protection of children in the entire territory of the Union.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction establishes a system of cooperation between contracting states to deal with international child abduction cases. It has been ratified by all EU member states. In many cases, these problems arise when a couple is separated. If the mother and father are from different states, there is a temptation to exploit the lack of cooperation between states in order to ensure the custody of the child. It is common for courts in the two states concerned to declare jurisdiction and to each assign custody of the child to the parent who is a national of their state. The purpose of the convention is to resolve such situations at the international level, by establishing that the competent courts and applicable laws are those of the child's state of residence. The convention also introduces a system that ensures the immediate return of children who have been abducted. I am voting for the adoption of this text because Peru has chosen to apply for membership.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is an instrument of particular importance. Firstly, it avoids prolonged uncertainty as to the legal status of the child. It is accompanied by a situation in which the child's parents are nationals of two different Member States and a dispute arises as to which of them to be cared for and which court should rule on it. It is undoubtedly in the interests of the best interests of the child to resolve this issue as soon as possible and to guarantee his or her immediate and safe return. Following Peru's accession to the Convention, a Council Decision authorising Austria and Romania to give its consent to this accession is necessary. As a result, the Convention between Peru and the European Union as a whole will be able to enter into force. The Hague Convention has already been ratified by all Member States of the European Union and dozens of other countries. The accession of another country deserves approval and support, which is why I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on civil aspects of the abduction of children established a system allowing cooperation between Contracting States in finding a solution to the issue of the abduction of children abroad. The purpose of the convention in question is to resolve such situations at international level by determining that the law of the State in which the child is resident applies and that the case falls within the jurisdiction of the court of that State. Following Peru's accession to the Convention, a council decision is needed authorizing the two Member States not yet hosting Peru to accept the accession of Peru, Austria and Romania. This will allow the Convention to enter into force between Peru and the European Union as a whole. I voted in favour of the report.

name: Traian UNGUREANU
text: in writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction aims to deal with cases of international child abduction. In 2014, at the request of the European Commission, the Court of Justice of the European Union was consulted on the competence of the Union to accept the accession of a third State to the 1980 Convention. The opinion delivered by the Court in October 2014 confirmed the existence of the Exclusive Competence of the Union as regards the acceptance of the accession of a third State to the 1980 Convention. In May 2001, Peru deposited its instrument of accession to the 1980 Convention, but following its accession to the Convention, a Council decision authorising the last two EU Member States which have not yet accepted accession, Austria and Romania, is necessary. This will allow the effective entry into force of the Convention between Peru and the entire European Union. The report of the European Parliament supports the accession of that State to the Convention and proposes approval without amendment so that the children concerned are guaranteed the protection granted throughout the Union.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Peru's accession to the Hague Convention in relation to the civil aspects of international child abduction, because it entails greater protection and guarantees for children. The Hague Convention establishes a system that allows the cooperation of Contracting States to find a solution to situations of international child abduction. These cases usually occur in cases of separations with parents from different countries. The Convention regulates that the applicable legislation in such cases is that of the child's State of residence. It also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of the stolen child.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council Decision authorising the Republic of Austria and Romania to accept, in the interests of the Union, Peru's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, as I believe it is important that Peru is already an international issue.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council decision authorising the Republic of Austria and Romania to accept, in the interest of the European Union, the accession of Peru to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a vitally important instrument that has been ratified by all EU Member States. The Convention introduces a system of cooperation between the contracting states aimed at settling cases of international child abduction. In many instances, these problems arise when a couple has separated. If the mother and father are from different states, there is a temptation to exploit the lack of cooperation between those states in order to secure custody of the child. The biggest problem in such cases is the national bias of the legal systems of individual states. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve such situations at an international level, by establishing that the competent courts and applicable laws are those of the state of residence of the child. I believe that the accession of Peru to the Convention is to be welcomed, especially as many EU citizens are of Peruvian origin.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on civil aspects of international child abduction, ratified by all Member States of the Union, is an instrument of crucial importance, since the system it establishes allows the cooperation of Contracting States to find a solution to such international conflicts. Since the main problem in these cases is the bias of the legal systems of States in favour of their own nationals, the objective of the Convention is to resolve these situations at the international level, as well as to establish a system to ensure the immediate return of the stolen child. Following Peru's accession to the Convention, a Council decision is necessary to authorise the two Member States which have not yet accepted Peru's accession, namely Austria and Romania, to accept it. This will allow the Agreement between Peru and the entire Union to enter into force. Thanks to the Convention, minors linked to the Peruvian community will be protected against illegal abduction. I therefore considered it appropriate to vote in favour of this text.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Peru's accession to the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, since I consider this type of coordination among States to be positive in resolving the sensitive cases of international child abduction, with the aim of moving towards respect for the rights and interests of children.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'Very often there are problems between couples who break up. It may be tempting for the spouse who comes from another state to exploit the lack of interstate cooperation in order to obtain custody of the children. The press often reports on cases of international child abduction in the case of legal separation or divorce. I welcome Peru's accession to this treaty. The children of the Peruvian community will thus be protected from unauthorized withdrawal. I agreed to this report in order to safeguard the legal certainty of these children.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. It is a proposal for a Council decision on the authorisation of the country's authorisation of the country, there is another, as we all know, to the Hague Convention on the civil aspects relating to the international abduction of children. This Convention focuses on international cooperation, for example in a divorce case where a parent of different nationalities flees with her child to another country. The Convention aims to resolve such situations on an international scale by establishing that cases are tried by the competent courts and in accordance with the applicable legislation of the minor's State of residence. The Convention also establishes a system ensuring the immediate return of abducted minors. In this case, peru is recommended to be taken to the other Member States, as Ireland, the Czech Republic and Lithuania have already endorsed that accession. Denmark is excluded from this cooperation. Support.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The Convention includes a system of cooperation between States Parties to resolve cases of international child abduction by separate partners of different nationalities. This is done by determining that jurisdiction rests with the courts of the child's country of residence and that the law of the child is applicable. The Convention also introduces a system to ensure that children who have been abducted are returned immediately. In view of the increasing number of problematic cases of international custody disputes, I believe that this Agreement is useful and have therefore agreed.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ As a children’s rights champion, I welcome the accession of Peru to this important Convention. This will allow Peru to cooperate with other State Parties to the Convention, including EU Member States, on tackling and combating child abduction.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 In recent years, we have increasingly seen cases of international child abduction, as it is common for mother and father to often come from different countries. In the event of disagreements, they then try to obtain their offspring by taking him to their State of origin, as they rely on the states not cooperating and will therefore find it more difficult to get the child back. I therefore believe that there should be a single system of cooperation between states aimed at finding solutions in the case of international child abductions. At present, there may still be cases where the courts of both countries finally entrust the child to the custody of the parent who is a national of that state. The Hague Convention, ratified by all EU states, addresses these situations and also introduces a system for the immediate return of a abducted child to his or her homeland. I therefore welcome Peru's accession to the Hague Convention and I am sure that this will help to better protect children in the event of their abduction across national borders.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The 1980 Hague Convention on International Child Abduction is an extremely important tool for addressing the civil aspects of international child abduction. International child abduction is a huge negative impact on the life of the whole family and, in particular, on the psyche of the child. The objective of this Convention is therefore to restore the status quo by immediately returning the wrongfully transferred child to his or her country of habitual residence, through a system of cooperation between the central authorities designated by the Contracting Parties. The Convention has so far been ratified by 93 states, including all Member States of the European Union. In view of the objective of the Convention, it is therefore very important that as many countries as possible accede to it, thereby reducing as far as possible situations where a child is abducted abroad, but unfortunately there is no legal instrument to help return the child, as the country to which he or she was abducted has not ratified this convention. For these reasons, I therefore welcomed Peru's decision to accede to the Convention, and I supported the report on the adoption of this accession by the European Union.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \ I supported the proposal for a Council decision authoring the Republic of Austria and Romania to accept, in the interest of the European Union, the accession of Peru to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of international child abuse. The 1980 Hague Convention provides for a system enabling States Parties to cooperate in finding solutions to cases of international child abuse. Following peru's accession to the Convention, the Council should by decision authorise member states which have not yet adopted the accession of Peru, i.e. the accession of Peru. Austria and Romania in order to adopt this approach. This will give the Convention into force between Peru and the entire European Union.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The following is a non-legislative act ratifying Kazakhstan's accession to the Hague Convention on the International Abduction of Children. As this is a formally necessary act, as the Convention does not provide for the possibility of direct approval by the EU, I voted in favour.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP chose to abstain on this vote because it is such an emotive issue. The right of countries acceding to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is extremely important; however, this should be done at the will of the individual country and not en bloc by the EU.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Kazakhstan's accession to the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, as I consider this type of coordination between States to be positive in resolving the sensitive cases of international child abduction, with the aim of moving towards respect for the rights and interests of children.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this report to endorse the Council decision to authorise the accession of Kazakhstan to the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. The Convention is a multilateral treaty to ensure that children wrongfully taken into another country, often by a parent or guardian, are brought back to their home country. A ruling of the European Court of Justice in 2014 found that the EU now has exclusive external competence in these matters, but the Convention does not allow for international organisations – such as the EU – to sign the Convention themselves. This Council decision is therefore necessary to allow Member States to accept the accession of Kazakhstan to the Convention, bringing the Convention into force between the entire EU and Kazakhstan.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to give Member States (with the exception of Denmark to which it is not applicable, and the Netherlands, which has already accepted it) permission to accept Kazakhstan's accession to the Convention, which will allow the convention between Kazakhstan and the EU as a whole to enter into force.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the proposal for a Council decision authorising certain Member States to accept, in the interest of the EU, the accession of Kazakhstan to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. Following Kazakhstan’s accession to the Convention, a Council decision is therefore necessary to authorise the Member States (except Denmark, which is excluded from the Union's civil justice policy, and the Netherlands, which has already accepted the accession of Kazakhstan) to accept that accession. I would like to point out that the European Commission, together with civil justice experts from the Member States, has evaluated the functioning of Kazakhstan's justice system and the country's willingness to implement the Convention, and considers that it is desirable for the Convention to enter into force between the European Union and Kazakhstan. I express my support for this, not only because the Hague Convention system is more effective if more countries sign up to it, but also to guarantee that children in question are provided with EU-wide protection.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council decision authorising certain Member States, in the interests of the European Union, to accept Kazakhstan's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on Civil Matters of International Child Abduction, because this establishes a system allowing Contracting States to cooperate in finding a solution to such situations.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which resolves cases of international child abduction by allowing Kazakhstan to join the 1980 Hague Convention.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ Under normal circumstances, I would vote against or abstain on resolutions involving the European Union’s participation in international bodies and organisations because I believe that it’s not for the European Union to make such decisions. In this situation, however, the question is whether Kazakhstan should be allowed to accede to the Hague Convention. It should be a vote of the British Parliament, but it is not, because such sovereignty has been ceded. If the European Parliament were to vote against accession, it would penalise children at risk of abduction in that country. Therefore I voted in favour of accession, despite my constitutional concerns.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this proposal after a study of the assessment by civil justice experts from the Member States. The functioning of Kazakhstan's judicial system and the will of Kazakhstan allow the convention between the European Union and Kazakhstan to enter into force.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal authorising certain Member States, in the interest of the European Union, to approve Kazakhstan's accession to the 1980 agreement. the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. of 25 October 1980 The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a very important instrument providing for a framework for cooperation between the Contracting Parties to deal with cases of international child abduction. In most cases, problems with child abduction arise after the couple divorced. It is also common for the courts of both states to recognise themselves as competent to hear the case, and each child is assigned custody to the parent who is a national of their state. In the light of these examples, I welcome Kazakhstan's accession to the Hague Convention in order to establish the competent courts and applicable laws of the state in which the child is habitually resident. It would also ensure that the abducted child is returned immediately.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP chose to abstain on this vote because it is such an emotive issue.  The right of countries acceding to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is extremely important; however, this should be done at the will of the individual country and not en bloc by the EU.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction establishes a system of cooperation between contracting states to deal with international child abduction cases. It has been ratified by all EU member states. The purpose of the convention is to resolve such situations at the international level, by establishing that the competent courts and applicable laws are those of the child's state of residence. The EU now has exclusive external jurisdiction in this area. The convention also introduces a system that ensures the immediate return of children who have been abducted.  That is why I voted in favour of Kazakhstan's accession to the Hague Convention.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I voted in favour of Kazakhstan's accession to the Hague Convention, which should be welcomed. The Commission, with the help of civil justice experts from the Member States, assessed the functioning of Kazakhstan's judicial system and Kazakhstan's willingness to implement the Convention, and considered it desirable for it to enter into force. Parliament fully agrees with this position, given that the system established by the Hague Convention will be all the more effective as the number of countries to join will be large. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction is an instrument of the utmost importance. It has been ratified by all the Member States of the European Union. This convention establishes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in cases of international child abduction.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, ratified by all EU countries, has introduced a system allowing contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution to this type of case. The text of the Treaty contains two main points: jurisdiction to adjudicate and applicability of the laws entrusted to the state of residence of the child and the establishment of a mechanism for the immediate return of the stolen child. The European Union currently has exclusive external competence in this area, but the Convention does not provide for the autonomous action of international organisations. That is why the Member States must act on behalf of the Union with prior authorisation from the Council. The Dzhambazki report, which I supported today, authorises some Member States to accept Kazakhstan's accession to the Convention, allowing it to have its effects on relations between the Asian country and the European Union.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Kazakhstan's accession to the Hague Convention in relation to the civil aspects of international child abduction, because it entails greater protection and guarantees for children. The Hague Convention establishes a system that allows the cooperation of Contracting States to find a solution to situations of international child abduction. These cases usually occur in cases of separations with parents from different countries. The Convention regulates that the applicable legislation in such cases is that of the child's State of residence. It also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of the stolen child.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I would like to thank the rapporteur for the work done in this report on Kazakhstan's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. It is an instrument of crucial importance. Kazakhstan's accession is good news.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on Kazakhstan's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. Kazakhstan must be free, if it wishes, to join this system of international cooperation, which allows, among other things, to settle cases of international child abduction. There may indeed be a problem in the case of a separated couple whose parents come out of different states. The Convention resolves any jurisdictional disputes since it stipulates that the applicable laws are those of the child's state of residence. It also allows an immediate return of the abducted child. While I regret that the Union now has exclusive jurisdiction in this area to the detriment of the Member States, Kazakhstan, as a sovereign state, has every right to join this Convention and the ratification of this accession will allow it to enter into force between the Union and that country.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction provides for cooperation between signatory states so that a child or child under 16 who has been arbitrarily "abducted" by a parent returns to the place of family residence pending a judicial ruling, unless the return foretooes a serious danger to his or her safety. I believe it is of fundamental importance for the protection of our children that this convention be ratified and respected by more and more States. I therefore voted to support Kazakhstan's accession to it.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The 1980 Hague Convention on civil aspects of international child abduction, signed by all EU Member States, is an instrument of international cooperation that authorizes signatory States to resolve transnational cases relating to the custody and abduction of minors, clarifying the national law applicable in cases where there is a conflict of jurisdiction between two or more national legal systems. The scope of the rule reaches civil aspects, applying mainly to cases of separate parents or other persons who have legal rights over the child. Since the objective of the Convention is to protect minors in a situation of legal uncertainty, it is important to ensure that it is signed by as many States as possible.  Although the EU has exclusive external competence in this area, the Convention does not authorise the participation of international actors, so the EU needs to give all its Member States express authorisation to accept the participation of any new State in the Convention. That is why I voted in favour of authorising the Member States to accept Kazakhstan's accession to the Convention.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which deals with the interests of the European Union in support of Kazakhstan's accession to the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. of 25 October 1980 The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a very important document. It has been ratified by all EU Member States. The Convention provides for a framework for cooperation between the Contracting Parties to deal with international child abduction cases. In most cases, these problems occur when the couple divorced. If the mother and father come from different countries, there is a desire to take advantage of the lack of cooperation between these states in order to secure custody of the child. The media is full of reports of international child abduction in the area of separation or divorce. In these cases, the national bias of the legal systems of individual countries is the biggest problem. Often, the courts of both states recognise themselves as competent to hear the case and each child is cared for by a parent who is a national of their state. Following kazakhstan's accession to the Convention, a Council Decision is necessary to empower Member States (with the exception of Denmark, which is not covered by the Union's civil justice policy, and the Netherlands, which have already agreed to kazakhstan's accession) to accept its accession. This will allow the Convention to enter into force between Kazakhstan and the European Union as a whole. Kazakhstan's accession to the Convention is to be welcomed.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on civil aspects of the abduction of children established a system allowing cooperation between Contracting States in finding a solution to the issue of the abduction of children abroad. The biggest problem in such cases is the national nature of the legal system of states. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve such situations at international level by determining that the law of the State in which the child is resident applies and that the case falls within the jurisdiction of the court of that State. The Convention also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of a child who has been unlawfully taken abroad. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area, as confirmed by the Court of Justice in Opinion No 1/13. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own competences. The problem arises from the fact that the Convention does not provide for the independent action of international organisations, so that, following kazakhstan's accession to the Convention, a decision of the Council is needed authorises the two Member States which have not yet adopted the accession of Kazakhstan, Austria and Romania, to accept the accession of Kazakhstan. This will allow the Convention to enter into force between Kazakhstan and the European Union as a whole. In view of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. As with peru's accession to the Hague Convention, I have no reservations about kazakhstan's accession to that Convention, and I therefore fully support the proposed decision. The 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abuse is a very important instrument that provides for a system for cooperation in finding solutions to cases of international child abuse. The Convention was ratified a long time ago by all EU Member States. Problems are most often the case in the case of separation between parents who come from different countries. There is a danger that one of the parents may wish to take advantage of the lack of cooperation between those two countries and thus acquire the exclusive custody of the children. In such cases, the biggest problem is the national bias of the legal systems in individual countries, and the judgments often end in such a way that each national court entrusts the child with the custody of a parent who is a national of that country. The Convention, however, lays down jurisdiction on the courts and law of the state in which the child is domiciled, as well as a system for ensuring the immediate return of the child who is wrongfully deprived. In the event of Kazakhstan's accession to the Convention, this means that children connected to the Kazakh community in the EU Member States will be protected from legal deprivation.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. I support this Kazakhstan Access Report to the Hague Convention, which protects children who find themselves in legal uncertainty. The report aims to grant permission for Member States (except Denmark not to which this does not apply and the Netherlands which has already given consent) to accept Kazakhstan's accession to the Convention, which will allow the Entry into Force of the Convention between Kazakhstan and the European Union.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. I am in favour of the adoption of this text, because Kazakhstan has made the sovereign choice to apply for membership.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the accession of Kazakhstan to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction because the European Union supports the accession of third States to that Convention with the aim of increasing the number of members and consequently improving its effectiveness. Moreover, to promote the rights of the child is an EU objective and the Union is active at international level in order to improve the application of that Convention.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction is an instrument of fundamental importance which has been ratified by all the Member States of the European Union. The Convention introduces a system which allows contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution to cases of international child abduction. The aim of the Convention is to resolve these situations at international level by establishing that the competent courts and applicable laws are those of the child's state of residence. The Convention also introduces a system that guarantees the immediate return of the abducted child, protecting his or her health and fundamental rights. Kazakhstan's accession to the Convention is a positive step in promoting the protection of children's rights at global and not just European level.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980, ratified by all EU Member States, establishes a system of cooperation between contracting states to deal with cases of international child abduction.
