In most cases, these abductions are related to the divorce of the parents, tempted to exploit the lack of cooperation between states to obtain custody of their child. This convention stipulates that the competent courts and applicable laws are those of the child's state of residence. This text aims to give the opinion of the European Parliament on the entry into force of this convention between Kazakhstan and the Union, which now has exclusive external competence in this area. Although I dispute the loss of sovereignty of the Member States, which leave it to the Union to adopt this type of agreement for them, I have spoken in favour of this text. On the one hand, this convention promotes the return of children to their homes, on the other hand, the accession of Kazakhstan is news that should be welcomed.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is one of the main tools for promoting the rights of the child. The Convention establishes a system of cooperation between central authorities aimed at resolving cases of international child abduction. These cases occur mainly in situations where parents come from different states, states that have not strengthened a cooperation partnership. As a result, a vulnerability is created that favours unlawful actions to obtain the custody of children. Thus, the Hague Convention aims to resolve such cases at international level, providing for a system which ensures the immediate return of unlawfully displaced or detained children.  Kazakhstan's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is an action I consider appropriate. I was in favour of Kazakhstan's accession to the Hague Convention, because I consider it essential that preventing child abduction remains a priority for the European Union and third countries.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction was established in 1980. All EU Member States have signed this convention, which provides a legal basis for child abduction by a parent. All too often, the media has reported child abduction by a parent who obtained custody of the child in his country during a binational separation. The other parent who is a victim of this situation finds himself unable to claim custody. We were faced with an inconsistency between different national judicial systems and a lack of cooperation between states. I voted in favour of Kazakhstan joining the Hague Convention.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report today because I believe it is in the European Union's interest to accept Kazakhstan's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. As a result of this accession, however, a Council decision is needed authorizing the Member States, with the exception of Denmark, which is not involved in the Union's civil justice policy, and the Netherlands, which has already accepted Kazakhstan's accession, to accept this accession.  The European Commission, assisted by experts from the Member States in the field of civil justice, has already assessed the functioning of kazakhstan's judicial system. It is therefore noted that the country is prepared to implement the Convention and that it hopes that the Convention will actually enter into force between the EU and Kazakhstan.  The system put in place by the Hague Convention will be even more effective with the involvement of a large number of countries. The aim of the proposal is to provide the children concerned with the necessary protection at European level.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ This was a vote to endorse the Council's decision to authorise Kazakhstan signing up to the Hague Convention of International Child Abduction. The Convention is a multilateral treaty with the purpose of ensuring the immediate return of children wrongfully taken to or retained internationally (usually by one parent or guardian) in their home country, where domestic custody proceedings can take place. While a ruling of the ECJ in 2014 found that the EU now has exclusive external competence in the field, the Convention does not allow for international organisations - such as the EU - to be partners to the Convention themselves. These Council decisions are therefore necessary to allow particular Member States which have not yet accepted the accession of the relevant countries to the Convention to do so, bringing the Convention into force between the entire EU and that country. For these reasons I voted in favour.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a vitally important instrument. It has been ratified by all the EU Member States. The Convention introduces a system of cooperation between the contracting states aimed at settling cases of international child abduction. The accession of Kazakhstan to the Convention is to be welcomed.  Following an evaluation of the functioning of Kazakhstan's justice system and the country's willingness to implement the Convention, the green light was given for the Convention to enter into force between the European Union and Kazakhstan. I therefore followed the Rapporteur´s indication that Parliament should approve the proposal, in order to ensure that EU-wide protection is afforded to settling cases of international child abduction in these particular cases.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 This is almost a pro-forma, non-legislative act allowing individual Member States to ratify Kazakhstan's accession to the Hague Convention on the International Abduction of Children.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 The 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction established a system of cooperation between the authorities of each Contracting State, which establishes the immediate return of children who have been unlawfully transferred or detained. Since this is an international agreement which aims to protect and protect children in situations of legal uncertainty, it must be ratified by as many states as possible. Given that the European Union has exclusive external competence in the field of child abduction, I am convinced that the European institutions must authorise the Member States to accept Kazakhstan's participation. I therefore voted in favour of the decision, hoping for the rapid entry into force of the 1980 Hague Convention between Kazakhstan and all EU Member States in order to prevent the abduction of children.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report because we believe that Kazakhstan's accession to the Convention is welcome. The Commission, together with the Member States' civil justice experts, assessed the functioning of the Kazakh justice system and the country's willingness to implement the Convention, and considers it desirable to bring the Convention between the European Union and Kazakhstan into force.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted on the report authorising certain Member States, in the interests of the European Union, to accept Kazakhstan's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on Civil Matters of International Child Abduction. As this is a question of improving the framework for the protection of citizens, especially children, no objections were raised by either side and I therefore voted in favour.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure in view of the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction is an instrument of fundamental importance that has been ratified by all the Member States of the European Union. It is part of a system which allows contracting states to cooperate and find a solution to cases of international child abduction. Many times the main problem is the tendency of the legal systems of individual States to practise favouritism on the basis of nationality. It is often the case that the courts of both states concerned declare themselves competent and that each of them entrusts the child to the parent who is a national of the State in which the court is located. The aim of the Convention is to resolve these situations at international level by establishing that the competent courts and applicable laws are those of the child's state of residence. The Convention also introduces a system which guarantees the immediate return of the child who has been abducted. Kazakhstan's accession to the Convention is to be welcomed. The Commission has assessed, together with experts from the Member States, the functioning of kazakhstan's judicial system and considers the agreement between the European Union and Kazakhstan to be desirable.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome Kazakhstan's accession to the Hague Convention on civil aspects of international child abduction. This is an important step in the protection of minors, since it ensures their immediate return in the event of illegal transfer or detention. In particular, the Hague Convention favours a framework for the protection of children's rights at international level, which is particularly effective in the event of a clash between different national legislations.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the Report on the proposal for a Council decision authorising certain Member States to accept, in the interest of the European Union, the accession of Kazakhstan to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction and noted no objections.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a key instrument in the context of judicial cooperation between contracting States in the resolution of cases of international child abduction. This Convention aims to harmonise the legal systems other than those states which normally declare themselves both competent to adjudicate the action and declare custody of the minor to the national parent of the State they represent, and the criterion of the State of residence of the minor is adopted with the Convention. As this matter currently is the exclusive external competence of the Union, a Council decision is necessary which call for the Member States to accept the access of third countries to the Hague Convention. I support the Dzhambazki report and congratulate the State of Kazakhstan on its adoption of the Convention.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – UKIP chose to abstain on this vote because it is such an emotive issue.  The right of countries acceding to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is extremely important; however, this should be done at the will of the individual country and not en bloc by the EU.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ This is an important instrument which has been ratified by all the EU Member States, providing protection for the interest of those children who are victims of abduction. The Convention introduces a system of cooperation between the contracting states for cases where jurisdictions declare themselves competent, with each of them awarding custody of the child to the parent who is a national of their state. The Convention also introduces a system which ensures the immediate return of children who have been abducted. Following the accession of Kazakhstan to the Convention, a Council decision is therefore necessary to authorise the Member States, with some exceptions, to accept that accession. This will allow the Convention to enter into force between Kazakhstan and the entire European Union.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Kazakhstan's accession to the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, as I consider this type of coordination between States to be positive in resolving the sensitive cases of international child abduction, with the aim of moving towards respect for the rights and interests of children.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 1980 was born to prevent and prevent the abduction of children abroad. The Convention has been ratified by all EU Member States. Under the Convention, the law of the State in which the child is resident applies and the case falls within the jurisdiction of the court of that State. The Convention facilitates the settlement of civil disputes containing an international element, in particular when the parents are separated in different countries. Similarly to Peru, following kazakhstan's accession to the Convention, a council decision is needed authorizing Member States to accept kazakhstan's accession, allowing the entry into force of the Convention between Kazakhstan and the EU. The Commission has assessed the functioning of Kazakhstan's judicial system with civil justice experts from the Member States and concluded that the country is ready to implement the Convention. The hague convention system is more effective the more countries join it. I supported the entry into force of the Convention between Kazakhstan and the EU.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I fully support Kazakhstan's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. This Convention regulates very important issues relating to the granting of custody of a child and the legal application of the provisions of the country in which the child is permanently resident. I voted in favour because the accession of each country to the Hague Convention is my satisfaction, as it improves the resolution of disputes and the operation of the courts.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ The Hague Convention is an important international instrument of cooperation which enables signatory states to settle cross border cases regarding child custody and abduction. I am in favour of the accession of Kazakhstan the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is an extremely important instrument with the main objective of dealing with cases of international child abduction, I welcome Kazakhstan's accession to the Convention.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This report proposes the approval of the European Parliament to a Council decision on Kazakhstan's accession to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction. This convention, ratified by all members of the Union, provides for cooperation mechanisms to remedy jurisdictional conflicts when two jurisdictions declare themselves competent for childcare in the context of the separation of a binational couple. Considering that these reports contribute to the harmonization of international regulations on family dispute management, I supported this report.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP chose to abstain on this vote because it is such an emotive issue.  The right of countries acceding to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is extremely important; however, this should be done at the will of the individual country and not en bloc by the EU.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the Council's proposed decision authorising certain Member States to accept, in the interests of the European Union, Kazakhstan's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. By establishing the primacy of the jurisdiction and laws of the state in which the child resides, the convention plays a decisive role in resolving the issues surrounding the issue of custody of the child during the separation of binational couples. However, for the convention to be implemented, it is necessary for one state's membership to be accepted by the other States Parties. Although Kazakhstan joined in 2013, all EU Member States, with the exception of the Netherlands, have still not accepted membership. In order to ensure that children linked to the Kazakh community are protected from abduction, we call on the Council to adopt as soon as possible a decision authorising THE Member States of the Union to accept Kazakhstan's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on civil aspects of the abduction of children establishes a system enabling cooperation between Contracting States to find solutions to the issue of the abduction of children abroad. The biggest problem in such cases is the national nature of the legal system of states. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve such situations at international level by determining that the law of the State in which the child is resident applies and that the case falls within the jurisdiction of the court of that State. The Convention also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of a child who has been unlawfully taken abroad. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area, as confirmed by the Court of Justice in Opinion No 1/13. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own competences. The problem arises from the fact that the Convention does not provide for the independent action of international organisations, so that, following kazakhstan's accession to the Convention, a decision of the Council is needed authorises the two Member States which have not yet adopted the accession of Kazakhstan, Austria and Romania, to accept the accession of Peru. This will allow the Convention to enter into force between Kazakhstan and the European Union as a whole. In view of the above, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU already has exclusive external competence in the field of international child abduction confirmed by the Court of Justice. But in order for this to be applied, the Member States must act in unison. The Council's authorisation of certain Member States to accept Kazakhstan's accession to the Hague Convention will have beneficial consequences for the whole of the European Union, thus improving cooperation at Community level to defend children's rights, such as the right to education and economic opportunities for a prosperous future. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. Every year around the world, several thousand children are abducted by one of the two parents. In the absence of cooperation between the State of origin and the child's state of residence, some cases cannot be resolved. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction is a legal instrument for recognizing the jurisdiction of the jurisdiction of the state in which the child resides. A dialogue can thus be established between the States Parties to this Convention to facilitate the return of the abducted child. The European Union supports the accession of third countries to the 1980 Convention so that its Member States can rely on a common legal framework to deal with international child abductions. In addition to the general objective of developing judicial cooperation, this regulation pursues the general objective of protecting children's rights. Kazakhstan's accession to the convention is therefore good news.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 The 1980 Hague Convention for the civil aspects of international child abduction, an international agreement is important, the purpose of which is to find solutions in situations where the courts of both countries (in the case of parents of two different nationalities) declare themselves competent and each of them gives custody of the child to the parent who is its national. The Convention establishes that the competent authorities are those where the child is resident. The Convention also introduces a system to ensure the immediate return of children who have been abducted. The EU now has exclusive external competence in this area and therefore Member States no longer act at their own expense. With kazakhstan's accession to this Convention, the European Union should allow Member States to accept such accession. I advise in my report that to accept Kazakhstan is welcome in this Convention.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 We consider the text to be positive because it is necessary for the Hague Convention on child abductions to be ratified by all states. This will resolve the hands of the authorities for cooperation both in investigations around the world and in the repatriation of the victim. One of the most important problems facing them is the cases of parents who are separated and come from different states. The Treaty simplifies efforts to find a solution for the child.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on civil aspects of the abduction of children establishes a system enabling cooperation between Contracting States to find solutions to the issue of the abduction of children abroad. The biggest problem in such cases is the national nature of the legal system of states. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve such situations at international level by determining that the law of the State in which the child is resident applies and that the case falls within the jurisdiction of the court of that State. The Convention also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of a child who has been unlawfully taken abroad. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area, as confirmed by the Court of Justice in Opinion No 1/13. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own competences. In view of the above, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: in writing. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is an instrument of crucial importance, which has been ratified by all member states of the Union. This Convention establishes a system that allows the cooperation of Contracting States to find a solution to situations of international child abduction. The main problem in these cases is the bias of the legal systems of States in favour of their own nationals. It is often the case that the courts of both States involved declare themselves competent and that each gives custody of the child to the parent of his nationality. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve these situations at international level by providing that the competent courts and the applicable legislation are those of the child's State of residence. The Convention also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of the stolen child.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the accession of Kazakhstan to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, which is a multilateral treaty that provides a way for abducted children to be returned from one member country to another. Countries need to work together in order to tackle international, cross-border problems like these, and for Kazakhstan to join will enlarge this network to fight child abduction more effectively. I support any measures which help safeguard the well-being of children in Wales.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The Convention in question establishes a system of cooperation between Contracting States aimed at finding a solution to cases of international child abduction. This type of situation occurs very often when a couple is apart. There are very frequent cases of international child abductions reported by the press that occur following separations and divorces. The Convention aims to remedy such situations on an international scale by establishing that cases are tried by the competent courts and in accordance with the applicable legislation of the minor's State of residence. The Convention also establishes a system ensuring the immediate return of abducted minors. Kazakhstan's adoption of the Convention deserves my praise and approval.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Vote for: in favour of the adoption of these texts, as these countries have chosen to apply for membership.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 The report agrees on a Council decision authorising Kazakhstan's authorisation to the Hague Convention on civil aspects relating to international child abduction. This Convention establishes a system of cooperation between States aimed at finding a solution to cases of international child abduction. Its purpose is to ensure the return of children unlawfully transferred to or wrongly held in any Contracting State and to enforce effectively in the other Contracting States the custody and visitation rights existing in a Contracting State. The situation of child abduction sometimes occurs when a couple is apart, and parents are originally from different states. It is common for the courts of their respective countries to declare themselves both competent and that the courts grant custody of the minor to the national parent of the State they represent. The Purpose of the Convention is to remedy such situations at international level by establishing that cases are tried by the competent courts in accordance with the applicable legislation of the child's State of residence. The importance of the system ensuring the immediate return of abducted minors is underlined. We voted in favour, since the Agreement is intended to defend the interests of minors.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union has a very strong position in guaranteeing fundamental rights and strives to ensure that citizens of individual Member States are not put at risk and that their fundamental rights are protected. Among the instruments adopted by the European Union to protect children's rights is the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980. The convention in question allows the Contracting Parties to cooperate and seek common solutions in cases of international child abduction, which still happen in the 21st century. Following the accession of Kazakhstan to this Convention, it is necessary for the Council to issue a decision authorising Member States other than Denmark not covered by Union civil policy and the Netherlands, which have already adopted the accession of Kazakhstan, to accept the accession of Kazakhstan. This will allow the entry into force of the Convention between Kazakhstan and the entire European Union.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report which allows states to cooperate in finding a solution to cases of international child abduction.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council decision authorising certain Member States, in the interests of the European Union, to accept Kazakhstan's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on Civil Matters of International Child Abduction, because the Hague Convention on Child Abduction needs to be ratified by all States.  This resolves the hands of the authorities for cooperation both in the field of investigations worldwide and in the repatriation of the victim. One of the most important problems that is even solved is in the case of parents who are separated and belong to different states.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, adopted in 1980, is an international instrument of cooperation, enabling signatory states to settle cross border cases of child custody. The Convention clarifies the applicable national law in cases when there is a conflict of competence between two or more national legal systems. The scope regards civil aspects, so it concerns mostly situations of separated parents or other persons having legal rights over the child. Given that the scope of the Convention is protecting children finding themselves in legal uncertainty, the aim is to have it ratified by as many states as possible. All EU Member States have ratified. This report aims at giving Austria and Romania the authorisation to accept the accession of Kazakhstan to the Convention, which will allow the entering into force of the Convention between Kazakhstan and the entire EU. I voted in favour of the report.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of the abduction of children establishes a system enabling cooperation between Contracting States. The biggest problem in such cases is the national nature of the legal system of states. The Convention establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of a child who has been unlawfully taken abroad. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area, as confirmed by the Court of Justice in Opinion No 1/13. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve such situations at international level by determining that the law of the State in which the child is resident applies and that the case falls within the jurisdiction of the court of that State. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own competences. The problem arises from the fact that the Convention does not provide for the independent action of international organisations, so that, following kazakhstan's accession to the Convention, a decision of the Council is needed authorises the two Member States which have not yet adopted the accession of Kazakhstan, Austria and Romania, to accept the accession of Kazakhstan. This will allow the Convention to enter into force between Kazakhstan and the European Union as a whole. In view of the above, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on civil aspects of the abduction of children establishes a system enabling cooperation between Contracting States to find solutions to the issue of the abduction of children abroad. The biggest problem in such cases is the national nature of the legal system of states. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve such situations at international level by determining that the law of the State in which the child is resident applies and that the case falls within the jurisdiction of the court of that State. The Convention also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of a child who has been unlawfully taken abroad. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area, as confirmed by the Court of Justice in Opinion No 1/13. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own competences. The problem arises from the fact that the Convention does not provide for the independent action of international organisations, so that, following kazakhstan's accession to the Convention, a decision of the Council is needed authorises the two Member States which have not yet adopted the accession of Kazakhstan, Austria and Romania, to accept the accession of Peru. This will allow the Convention to enter into force between Kazakhstan and the European Union as a whole. In view of the above, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report to take account of Kazakhstan's accession to it. This Convention establishes a system that allows the cooperation of Contracting States to find a solution to situations of international child abduction. These problems occur very often in couples who have separated. If parents are from different States, they may be tempted to exploit the lack of cooperation between States in obtaining custody of their children. The objective of the Convention is to resolve these situations at international level by providing that the competent courts and the applicable legislation are those of the child's State of residence.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's legislative resolution on the proposal for a Council decision authorising certain Member States, in the interests of the European Union, to accept Kazakhstan's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction, because I believe it is important to reach agreement on jurisdiction and law applicable to the abduction of children involving the greatest number of countries. I fully agree with the rapporteur who proposes that the European Parliament approve the proposal without amendment, in order to guarantee the benefits of uniform legal protection for the children concerned. The press very often reports cases of international abduction of minors that occur as a result of separation or divorce. The Commission has assessed, together with experts from the Member States in the field of civil justice, the functioning of kazakhstan's judicial system and kazakhstan's readiness to implement the Convention and considers it desirable that the Convention should enter into force between the European Union and Kazakhstan. I therefore believe that it is necessary to implement these agreements, including with other countries that have not yet acceded to this agreement, in order to improve international cooperation.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 I welcome the outcome of today's vote in favour of Kazakhstan's accession to the Hague Convention, which concerns the civil aspects of international child abduction. Such problems often arise when the relationships of people from different countries break up. The purpose of the Convention was to establish that the courts and laws of the State in which the child resides are competent to deal with such disputes.  This Convention is an instrument of particular importance, which will be more effective the more states participate. Kazakhstan's accession to the Convention is therefore a cause for satisfaction. The Commission confirmed the country's readiness to implement the principles of the Convention and to protect children in the above-described situation across the EU.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. The Hague Convention, which has been in place since 1980, focuses on the protection of children. The established civil aspects for the prevention of child abductions and the repatriation of abducted children are part of an incontrovertible strategy to protect the well-being of children. I very much welcome the accession of as many states as possible to this convention.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to abstain on this vote because it is such an emotive issue. The right of countries acceding to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is extremely important; however, this should be done at the will of the individual country and not en masse by the EU.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. As this accession was a manifestation of the will of the States concerned, there was no reason to oppose it by an unfavourable vote. It is necessary to act to protect children and parents alike.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Kazakhstan's accession to the Hague Convention in relation to the civil aspects of international child abduction, because it entails greater protection and guarantees for children. The Hague Convention establishes a system that allows the cooperation of Contracting States to find a solution to situations of international child abduction. These cases usually occur in cases of separations with parents from different countries. The Convention regulates that the applicable legislation in such cases is that of the child's State of residence. It also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of the stolen child.

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Report on the proposal for a Council decision authorising certain Member States to consent, in the interest of the European Union, to Kazakhstan's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction is a document of particular importance, since it introduces a system enabling contracting States to cooperate in the settlement of cases relating to the international abduction of a child by one of the parents or legal guardians. It is consistently problematic in such situations to determine the court competent to grant custody of a child to a parent or guardian where each parent or guardian has the nationality of another country.  The purpose of the Convention is to address this problem at international level by establishing that only the courts and laws of the State in which the child resides are competent. The Convention also introduces a system to guarantee the immediate return of the abducted child.  As a system based on the Hague Convention will be all the more effective the more states participate in it and the functioning of the justice system in Kazakhstan allows the country to accede to the Convention, I believe it is appropriate that the Convention concluded between the European Union and Kazakhstan enters into force so that children are protected throughout the EU.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to support the package on the accession of Kazakhstan to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. This is important for engagement in enhanced international cooperation with other signatories to the Convention.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on civil aspects of the abduction of children establishes a system enabling cooperation between Contracting States to find solutions to the issue of the abduction of children abroad. The biggest problem in such cases is the national nature of the legal system of states. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve such situations at international level by determining that the law of the State in which the child is resident applies and that the case falls within the jurisdiction of the court of that State. The Convention also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of a child who has been unlawfully taken abroad. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area, as confirmed by the Court of Justice in Opinion No 1/13. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own competences. The problem arises from the fact that the Convention does not provide for the independent action of international organisations, so that, following kazakhstan's accession to the Convention, a decision of the Council is needed authorises the two Member States which have not yet adopted the accession of Kazakhstan, Austria and Romania, to accept the accession of Kazakhstan. This will allow the Convention to enter into force between Kazakhstan and the European Union as a whole.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ Kazakhstan’s accession to the Hague Convention is a promising development of child protection worldwide. At the international level, the European Union supports the accession of third states to the 1980 Convention in order for its Member States to rely upon a common legal framework to deal with international child abductions. Beside the general objective of developing judicial cooperation in civil matters having cross-border implications, the present proposal is linked to the general objective enshrined in Article 3 of the Treaty on the European Union to protect the rights of the child. The proposal is also consistent with the promotion of the use of mediation in the settlement of cross-border family disputes.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour since I have no objections.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on civil aspects of the abduction of children establishes a system enabling cooperation between Contracting States to find solutions to the issue of the abduction of children abroad. The biggest problem in such cases is the national nature of the legal system of states. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve such situations at international level by determining that the law of the State in which the child is resident applies and that the case falls within the jurisdiction of the court of that State. The Convention also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of a child who has been unlawfully taken abroad. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area, as confirmed by the Court of Justice in Opinion No 1/13. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own competences. The problem arises from the fact that the Convention does not provide for the independent action of international organisations, so that, following kazakhstan's accession to the Convention, a decision of the Council is needed authorises the two Member States which have not yet adopted the accession of Kazakhstan, Austria and Romania, to accept the accession of Peru. This will allow the Convention to enter into force between Kazakhstan and the European Union as a whole. In view of the above, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: In writing. I supported the Council's decision on Kazakhstan's accession to the Hague Convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction. This convention, ratified by all EU member states, provides for cooperation mechanisms to remedy jurisdictional conflicts when two jurisdictions declare themselves competent for childcare in the context of the separation of a binational couple.  It is essential to preserve the interests of the child and that is why I welcome the fact that countries in Europe and the rest of the world are making commitments in which they reaffirm their desire to clarify the separation procedure so as not to be indirect accomplices to child abductions.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ This report aims at giving Member States, with the exception of Denmark to which this is not applicable, the authorisation to accept the accession of Kazakhstan to the Convention, which will allow the entering into force of the Convention between Kazakhstan and the entire EU. The Netherlands already accepted it.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Proposal for a Council Decision authoring certain Member States to accept, in the interest of the European Union, Kazakhstan's accession to the Hague Convention on civil-legal aspects of international child abduction in 1980, as this allows all Member States, except Denmark and the Netherlands, to accept access to Kazakhstan.  Given that Kazakhstan's readiness to implement the Convention has been established, I consider it necessary for Parliament to approve the proposal without amendments. Child abduction cases must be one of the priorities of the international community, as well as a guarantee over the immediate return of abducted children. Furthermore, I support Kazakhstan's accession to the Hague Convention.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. It is necessary to strengthen cooperation between states on international child abduction in order to curb the exploitation of individuals from different states. By establishing jurisdiction over the child's state of residence, the Convention was able to resolve the issue of the return of children and give the EU exclusive external jurisdiction. As Kazakhstan has made the sovereign choice to join, there is no reason to oppose the adoption of the text.  I voted for it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – UKIP chose to abstain on this vote because it is such an emotive issue.  The right of countries acceding to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is extremely important; however, this should be done at the will of the individual country and not en bloc by the EU.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported Kazakhstan's approach to the Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, signed in The Hague in 1980. The Convention constitutes a comprehensive system of cooperation between Contracting States in cases of international child abduction. Due to the increasing mobility of the population, the number of children from nationally mixed marriages is also increasing. In divorce cases, the risk of abuse of lack of cooperation between states by one of the parents increases in this area. I therefore welcome Kazakhstan's approach among the States that have already signed the Convention.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report by my colleague Angel Dzhambazki, which endorses the Council's decision on the application of the Hague Convention between the EU and Kazakhstan. This convention establishes a system of judicial cooperation. Widely supported in Parliament, this procedure will put the best interests of the child back at the heart of international justice decisions, particularly in cases of abduction following divorce. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on Kazakhstan's accession to the Hague Convention, as it is necessary to expand the list of countries parties to this text which guarantees the return of children displaced or illegally detained by one of their parents in a state and aims more broadly to enforce access, custody and accommodation rights.

name: Eva KAILI
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on civil matters relating to international child abduction is a vital tool. It has also been ratified by all the Member States of the European Union. This Convention establishes a system allowing Contracting States to cooperate in finding a solution to situations of international child abduction. It is therefore necessary, following Kazakhstan's accession to the Convention, to adopt a Council Decision authorising Member States (with the exception of Denmark, which is excluded from the Union's civil justice policy, and the Netherlands, which have already accepted Kazakhstan's accession) to accept such accession. This will allow the Convention between Kazakhstan, on the one hand, and the European Union as a whole to enter into force on the other.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I agree with this report. The agreement regulates cases of international child abduction by partners of different nationalities or residences and includes rules for settling custody disputes. The fact that Kazakhstan is committed to this agreement is an important step towards strengthening the rights of children.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, as the accession will allow states acceding to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction to participate in enhanced international cooperation with other signatories to the Convention.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on civil aspects of the abduction of children establishes a system enabling cooperation between Contracting States to find solutions to the issue of the abduction of children abroad. The biggest problem in such cases is the national nature of the legal system of states. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve such situations at international level by determining that the law of the State in which the child is resident applies and that the case falls within the jurisdiction of the court of that State. The Convention also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of a child who has been unlawfully taken abroad. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area, as confirmed by the Court of Justice in Opinion No 1/13. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own competences. The problem arises from the fact that the Convention does not provide for the independent action of international organisations, so that, following kazakhstan's accession to the Convention, a decision of the Council is needed authorises the two Member States which have not yet adopted the accession of Kazakhstan, Austria and Romania, to accept the accession of Peru. This will allow the Convention to enter into force between Kazakhstan and the European Union as a whole. In view of the above, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the proposal for Kazakhstan's accession to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction.  A major problem in such cases is the national bias of the legal systems of individual countries in the case of separation of parents. The Convention will help at international level to find a solution to such situations in order to avoid the subjective award of parental rights to the parent who is a national of the State of the court.  Upon adoption of the Convention, the competent court and the applicable law shall be the state of the child's location. I strongly support the introduction of a system ensuring the immediate return of abducted children.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. ‒ The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a multilateral treaty, which seeks to protect children from the harmful effects of abduction and retention across international boundaries by providing a procedure to bring about their prompt return. The treaty has been ratified by all EU Member States. In light of this, it is important to note that the EU now has exclusive external competence in this field as confirmed by the Court of Justice in Opinion 1/13, which means that Member States no longer act on their own account. However, the paradox is that the Convention does not provide for autonomous action by international organisations. In this sense, a Council decision is necessary to authorise the Member States (except Denmark, which is excluded from the Union’s civil justice policy, and the Netherlands which have already accepted the accession of Kazakhstan) to accept the accession of Kazakhstan. Therefore, I call both the EU and Member States to welcome and accept the accession of Kazakhstan to the Convention because in this manner children’s rights will be protected and preserved.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. Kazakhstan's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the International Abduction of Children is of great importance because it seeks to protect them from cases of international abduction. The problem appears to be the same as that of other States, that is, in the case of the separation of parents from different countries, where there is a tendency to exploit the lack of cooperation between states in order to obtain the custody of children. In order to prevent the courts from establishing custody on the basis of the nationality of one of the parents in which the court is located, the report analysed here aims to resolve the problems that these circumstances generate, ensuring that jurisdiction is conferred on the courts of the child's place of residence. I am therefore voting in favour of this report.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it helps to deal with international child abduction cases. Kazakhstan has chosen to apply for membership.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on Kazakhstan's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction. This convention establishes a system of cooperation between contracting states to deal with cases of international child abduction. It has been ratified by all EU member states. In many cases, these problems arise when a couple is separated. If the mother and father are from different states, there is a temptation to exploit the lack of cooperation between states in order to ensure the custody of the child. The purpose of the convention is to resolve such situations at the international level, by establishing that the competent courts and applicable laws are those of the child's state of residence. The convention also introduces a system that ensures the immediate return of abducted children. After ratification, the convention will enter into force between Kazakhstan and the entire European Union.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction establishes a system of cooperation between contracting states to deal with international child abduction cases. It has been ratified by all EU member states. Its main purpose is to resolve child custody situations at the international level, by establishing that the competent courts and applicable laws are those of the child's state of residence. The convention also introduces a system that ensures the immediate return of children who have been abducted. The EU now has exclusive external jurisdiction in this area, as the Court of Justice confirmed in its opinion 1/13. After ratification, the convention will enter into force between these three countries and the European Union as a whole. I am therefore in favour of the adoption of this text, because these countries have chosen to apply for membership.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of authorization to accept Kazakhstan's access to the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, which will allow the rule to enter into force in this country and all the Member States of the Union.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Kazakhstan's accession to the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, as I consider this type of coordination between States to be positive in resolving the sensitive cases of international child abduction, with the aim of moving towards respect for the rights and interests of children.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. In the interests of the Union, this draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament approves that certain Member States accept, in the interests of the Union, Kazakhstan's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. This Convention is essential as it structures the cooperation of contracting States in order to find a solution to international child abduction. Since external competence belongs to the Union in this area, The Member States need the Union's approval to accept successive accessions to the Convention.  I give my vote in favour as the Convention guarantees the protection of minors throughout the territory of the Union and will be more effective the more countries that join it.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour. I consider the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction to be a useful instrument for international cooperation, especially in cases of mixed marriages where one of the parents takes the child to his or her original country. This Decision authorises Member States to approve the accession of Kazakhstan to the Convention. Sadly, Member States need EU approval to do so.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒The purpose of the Hague Convention on civil justice aspects of international child abduction is to introduce a system of cooperation between states to solve such cases internationally.  International child abductions occur most often when the parents of a child are separated and come from different countries.  Kazakhstan's accession to this Convention is commendable, and before its entry into force it is necessary for all Member States to accept it.  Since I consider it desirable for this Convention between the European Union and Kazakhstan to enter into force, I supported this report.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. ‒ The 1980 Hague Convention has been ratified by 93 countries, including all EU Member States. The convention entered into force in Kazakhstan on 1 September 2013. Only the Netherlands has already accepted the accession of Kazakhstan to the 1980 Hague Convention. I share the goal of the proposed act to authorise certain Member States to accept, in the interests of the European Union, the accession of Kazakhstan to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 The accession of Kazakhstan territorially expands the possibilities of applying child protection to ensure the immediate return of children in the event of unauthorised relocation or detention in another State and in ensuring that rights of custody and access under the law of one Contracting State are effectively respected in other Contracting States.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council decision authorising certain Member States, in the interests of the European Union, to accept Kazakhstan's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on Civil Matters of International Child Abduction, because it is complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted for this text.  It concerns Kazakhstan's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction.  This text allows for cooperation between the contracting states and determines the competent jurisdiction when the custody of the children is to be granted, in the event of separation from a couple whose parents do not have the same nationality. This text has been put in place and ratified by all Member States, in order to prevent two courts, from two different countries, from declaring themselves competent. The rule is simplified: the applicable laws are those of the child's state of residence. In addition, it establishes the immediate return of the abducted children. Finally, this country has chosen to apply for membership, which we agree with.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council Decision on the accession of Kazakhstan to the 1980 Hague Convention on The Civil Matters of International Child Abduction because this Convention is a vital tool because it enables Contracting States to cooperate in finding a solution to international child abduction. I believe, after Kazakhstan's accession to the Convention, that it is necessary to adopt a Council decision authorising the Member States to accept this accession since the Hague Convention system is more effective with the accession of several countries.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. States Parties agree to implement a system of cooperation in the event of child abduction by separate partners of different nationalities. The place of jurisdiction for this shall be the state of residence of the child. Furthermore, as the resolution of the child's return to the appropriate parent is to be speeded up, thereby reducing the burden on the child in international custody disputes, I agree with this request.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the EP's report on the Council decision authorising certain Member States to accept kazakhstan's accession to the 1980 agreement in the interest of the European Union. the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction.  Kazakhstan's accession to the Convention is to be welcomed. The Commission, together with experts in the field of civil justice in the Member States, assessed the functioning of the Justice System in Kazakhstan and its determination to implement the Convention and considers it desirable for the Convention to enter into force between the EU and Kazakhstan. The Hague Convention system will be more effective if more countries join it.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. I welcome Kazakhstan's accession to the International Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. This convention aims to reduce legal conflicts between different national jurisdictions in cases of difficult separations of binational couples. The signatory states undertake that the court responsible for the right of custody and access be that of the child's state of residence. The aim here is to allow certain EU Member States to recognise Kazakhstan's accession to the Convention. A surreal vote on the decision of sovereign member states to recognise a third country's accession to an international convention. What for? Because, under the 1/13 opinion of the Court of Justice, the Commission now has exclusive jurisdiction over the application of this decision in civil matters on "its" territory. The decision does not apply to some Member States: Denmark, which has an exemption clause on the EU's civil justice policy, and the Netherlands, which has already recognised Kazakhstan's decision before it becomes an exclusive EU jurisdiction. I challenge this limitation of sovereignty. Nevertheless, I vote for this recognition of adherence to the convention for the benefit of the protection of children across borders.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction establishes a system of cooperation between contracting states to deal with international child abduction cases. It has been ratified by all EU member states. Its main purpose is to resolve child custody situations at the international level, by establishing that the competent courts and applicable laws are those of the child's state of residence. The Convention also introduces a system that ensures the immediate return of abducted children. The EU now has exclusive external jurisdiction in this area, as the Court of Justice confirmed in its opinion 1/13. After ratification, the convention will enter into force between these three countries and the European Union as a whole. I am therefore in favour of the adoption of this text, because the countries concerned have chosen to apply for this accession.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 The objective of the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction (hereinafter referred to as the '1980 Convention'), until now ratified by 93 countries, including all EU Member States, is to restore the status quo by the immediate return of children unlawfully transferred or retained through a system of cooperation between the central authorities designated by the Contracting Parties. The aim of this Decision is to ensure that the 1980 Convention enter into force between Kazakhstan and the Member States of the European Union. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of accepting Kazakhstan’s accession to the Hague Convention as it furthers the protection that the Union can provide to children.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. Open borders, the free movement of people, more accessible travel lead to an increasing number of mixed marriages, but also divorces, tears between couples and child abductions by one of the two parents. I believe that a situation of profound human distress can only be dealt with effectively if dialogue exists and is based on trust. A decision can only be made in the long term if it is negotiated, balanced and accepted by each parent. Any means, be it mediation or the many international conventions, must be accessible to parents in distress. That is why it is essential that the European Union, i.e. all Member States, accept Kazakhstan's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report, which aims at giving Member States (except Denmark to which this is not applicable; and the Netherlands which have already accepted it), the authorisation to accept the accession of Kazakhstan to the Convention, which will allow the entering into force of the Convention between Kazakhstan and the entire EU. The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, adopted in 1980, is an international instrument of cooperation, enabling signatory states to settle cross border cases regarding child custody and abduction. The Convention clarifies the applicable national law in cases when there is a conflict of competence between two or more national legal systems. The scope regards civil aspects, so it concerns mostly situations of separated parents or other persons having legal rights on the child. Given that the scope of the Convention is protecting children finding themselves in legal uncertainty, the aim is to have it ratified by as many states as possible. All EU Member States have ratified.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of the abduction of children establishes a system enabling cooperation between Contracting States to find a solution to the abduction of children and to ensure the immediate return of the child who has been abducted abroad. The Convention has been ratified by all the Member States of the European Union. Kazakhstan has announced its intention to join the Convention. Since the Convention does not provide for the independent action of international organisations, the European Union cannot ratify such an addition to the Treaty.  However, since the Opinion of the European Court of Justice of 14 October 2014 states that the EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area, the Member States (with the exception of the Netherlands, which has already ratified the supplement and Denmark, which has not yet ratified the supplement) can only do so with the authorisation of the European Council. The Council therefore intends to take a decision which would give the Member States the power to ratify kazakhstan's accession, but to do so it will have to consult Parliament. In its report, the Committee on Legal Affairs proposes that Parliament approve the Council's proposal for a decision. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction establishes a system of cooperation between contracting states to resolve these cases. It has been ratified by all EU member states. Its aim is to resolve such situations at the international level, by establishing that the competent courts and applicable laws are those of the child's state of residence. The convention also introduces a system that ensures the immediate return of children who have been abducted. The EU now has exclusive external jurisdiction in this area. As a result, Member States are no longer acting on their own behalf. After ratification, the Convention will enter into force between Kazakhstan and the entire European Union. We are in favour of the adoption of these texts because these countries have chosen to apply for membership.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction of 25 October 1980 is an instrument of vital importance and has been ratified by all EU Member States. This Convention establishes a system of cooperation between Contracting States with the aim of finding a solution to cases of international child abduction. Kazakhstan's adoption of the Convention means a Council decision to authorise the Member States to accept this (with the exception of Denmark, excluded from the scope of the Union's civil justice policy, and the Netherlands, which have already accepted Kazakhstan's participation). In this way, the Convention will enter into force between Kazakhstan and the entire European Union. I support the adoption of this proposal in order to ensure the protection of the minors concerned throughout the territory of the European Union.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The EU now has exclusive external jurisdiction in this area, as confirmed by the Court of Justice in its opinion 1/13. As a result, Member States are no longer acting on their own behalf. The problem is that the convention does not provide for autonomous action by international organizations. After ratification, the convention will enter into force between these three countries and the European Union as a whole. I am in favour of the adoption of these texts, because the countries concerned have chosen to apply for membership.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on Kazakhstan's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction. In order to avoid conflicts of laws or jurisdictions as far as possible when it comes to resolving a dispute involving an international situation, international conventions must be signed and ratified by the highest possible number of states.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which endorses a Council decision on Kazakhstan's accession to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction. This convention, ratified by all members of the Union, provides for cooperation mechanisms to remedy jurisdictional conflicts when two jurisdictions declare themselves competent for childcare in the context of the separation of a binational couple.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction is an instrument of fundamental importance which has been ratified by all the Member States of the European Union by introducing a system allowing contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution to cases of international child abduction. It is often the case that the courts of both states involved declare themselves competent and that each of them entrusts the child to the parent who is a national of the State in which the court is located. The convention aims to resolve these situations at international level. I therefore voted in favour of Kazakhstan's accession to the Convention, thus allowing the children concerned to benefit from protection throughout the European Union.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 I was pleased to vote in favour of the adoption of Kazakhstan's application to join the Hague Convention. The protection of children's rights must be a priority for all countries. They are the main victims of increasingly frequent divorces, and indeed there are times when non-rational decisions by parents, such as the abduction of their own children before a court ruling or the commencement of proceedings, put them in a situation from which it is very difficult to get out. They often grow up completely separated from the rest of their family, which is a serious psychological burden for them.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ The Hague Convention has as its primary objective cases of international abduction of children due to the separation of the parents who have different citizenship from each other. I have voted for this report that will grant the accession of Kazakhstan to the Convention in order to ensure the EU’s protection to the children in that specific part.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report because it resolves custody disputes. This provision is particularly advantageous in custody disputes where parents prove different nationalities.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The Convention is crucial to ensure that international child abduction cases are resolved as quickly and effectively as possible. The Council Decision allows Member States to give their consent to kazakhstan's accession so that the Convention can enter into force between the EU and Kazakhstan.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The problem of child abduction is becoming more and more important nowadays. Tackling this social phenomenon, within each legal order separately, is difficult. For this reason, the 1980 Hague Convention on Civil Matters of International Child Abduction is a vital tool. The Commission, together with the Member States' civil justice experts, assessed the functioning of the Kazakh justice system and the country's willingness to implement the Convention, and considers it desirable to bring the Convention between the European Union and Kazakhstan into force. I therefore supported the report as the Hague Convention system becomes more effective with the accession of more countries.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP chose to abstain on this vote because it is such an emotive issue.  The right of countries acceding to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is extremely important; however, this should be done at the will of the individual country and not en bloc by the EU.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that the purpose of the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction is to create a system of cooperation between the central authorities appointed by each Contracting State in such a way as to allow the immediate return of children who have been unlawfully transferred or detained, in view also that the European Union has set among its objectives the promotion of the protection of the rights of the child , and has always been active at international level for the protection of the latter, I believe, in order to pursue these primary objectives, to accept kazakhstan's accession, so I feel I must express my positive opinion. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I supported this proposal for a Council decision authorisation of certain Member States to accept, in the interest of the European Union, Kazakhstan's approach to the Hague Convention on civil-legal aspects of international child abduction in 1980. Respecting children's rights as one of the fundamental issues of EU policy and wanting to remain coherent in implementing our decisions, this is one of the necessary steps in this direction. The prevention of child abduction is an important part of the EU's policy for promoting the rights of the child, with the aim of adopting the Hague Convention on civil-legal aspects of international child abduction since 25 October 1980. At international level, the European Union is actively working to improve its application and encourages third countries to approach it. In 2011, the Commission adopted eight proposals for Council decisions aimed at accepting the eight countries' access to this Hague Convention. Kazakhstan only passed the Instrument of Access to the Convention in 2013. In 2014, the Court of Justice of the European Union stated that the acceptance of a third State's approach to the Convention falls within the exclusive competence of the European Union. Following this decision, in 2015 the Council of the European Union adopted seven decisions based on the 2011 proposals. This proposal takes into account a third country (Kazakhstan) that joined the Convention before the EU's external competence was established.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction establishes a system of cooperation between contracting states to deal with international child abduction cases. It has been ratified by all EU member states. In many cases, these problems arise when a couple is separated. If the mother and father are from different states, there is a temptation to exploit the lack of cooperation between states in order to ensure the custody of the child. It is common for courts in the two states concerned to declare jurisdiction and each assign custody of the child to the parent who is a national of their state. The purpose of the convention is to resolve such situations at the international level, by establishing that the competent courts and applicable laws are those of the child's state of residence. The convention also introduces a system that ensures the immediate return of children who have been abducted. I am in favour of the adoption of this text, because Kazakhstan has chosen to apply for membership. So I'm voting for the text.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒In the case of Kazakhstan's accession to the Convention, a Council decision is required to allow Member States (except Denmark, to which Union civil law does not apply, and the Netherlands, which has already accepted Kazakhstan's approach) to accept Kazakhstan's approach. This will allow the Convention between Kazakhstan and the entire European Union to enter into force. The Commission and civil law experts from the Member States have assessed that Kazakhstan is ready to implement the Convention. I support this report as the objective of such a Convention is to be ratified by as many countries as possible, as this is becoming more effective.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. \u2012 This Convention establishes a system of cooperation between contracting States aimed at finding a solution to cases of international child abduction, seeking to ensure the immediate return of children unlawfully transferred to or wrongly held therein. The child abduction situation occurs very often when a couple of people secede, and when the parents come from different states. The Convention thus aims to enforce effectively the custody and visitation rights existing in a Contracting State and mitigate responses of nationalist tendency of the legal systems of each State. It is common for the courts of their respective countries to declare both competent and that the courts grant custody of the minor to the national parent of the state they represent, decisions based on motivations which do not necessarily respond to the best interests of the child. The Purpose of the Convention is to resolve such situations at international level by establishing that cases are tried by the competent courts and in accordance with the applicable legislation of the child's state of residence. Kazakhstan has deposited the instrument of access and we have spoken in favour, as this Agreement is best in order to respond to the defence of the best interests of minors.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Abductions is essential and has already been ratified by all European Union countries. I am therefore very glad that Kazakhstan has also decided to take this step, significantly expanding the possibility of cooperation on child abduction. According to experts and the Commission, Kazakhstan is willing and able to implement this Convention from the point of view of its judicial system. The purpose of the Hague Convention is to protect children from abductions, which take place in particular in cases where parents from different states divorce. If one of the parents decides to abduct the child to his or her home state and that state is not part of the cooperation in dealing with international child abductions, he can so easily get custody of the child. The courts in the non-cooperating State usually place the child in the care of the parent who is a national of that State.
