However, where a State is part of the Hague Convention, this situation may be resolved at international level and the courts and legislation of the State in which the child resides will be determined as final. Ratification by some of the remaining EU Member States is the final step towards the entry into force of this Convention between Kazakhstan and the European Union.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this technical report, which endorses a Council decision on Kazakhstan's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on civil aspects of international child abduction.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 I support this report on Kazakhstan's acceding to the Hague Convention, as the system of that Convention becomes more effective if more countries accede to it. In divorce situations where parents come from different States, there is a temptation to take advantage of the lack of international cooperation to obtain custody of minors. Custody is often granted to the parent who is a national of the State in which the courts are based, there are therefore nationalist tendencies in the legal systems of each State. By establishing that cases are tried by the competent courts and in accordance with the applicable legislation of the minor's State of residence, the Convention permits cooperation between parties, as well as tends to settle such disputes on an international scale. It should be noted that the Commission, together with experts in the field of social justice, has assessed and approved the functioning of kazakhstan's judicial system and its readiness for cooperation. For all this, I'm voting in favor.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP chose to abstain on this vote because it is such an emotive issue.  The right of countries acceding to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is extremely important; however, this should be done at the will of the individual country and not en bloc by the EU.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. I voted in favour, as the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a vitally important instrument that has been ratified by all EU Member States and establishes a system of cooperation between Contracting States aimed at finding a solution to international child abduction cases. In the case of children in which the parents are divorced, each from a different State, it is common for the courts of the two countries concerned to declare themselves competent and that the courts grant custody of the minor to the national parent of the State they represent. There are very frequent cases of international child abductions reported by the press that occur following separations and divorces. The Convention aims to remedy such situations on an international scale by establishing that cases are tried by the competent courts and in accordance with the applicable legislation of the minor's State of residence. The Convention also establishes a system ensuring the immediate return of abducted minors. Kazakhstan's convention's acceding to the Convention should therefore be praised, as the system of the Hague Convention becomes more effective if more countries accede to it.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. By 649 votes to four and 17 abstentions, MEPs this lunchtime approved recognition of Kazakhstan's accession to the Hague Convention on International Child Abduction, of which all EU Member States are stakeholders. Nearly 660,000 people born in Kazakhstan now live in Europe, 92% of them in Germany in germany. The 1980 Convention, which now has 94 signatory countries, establishes a system of cooperation to find solutions in the event of international child abduction. This situation occurs most of the time when a couple separates. If one of the spouses is from another country, sometimes the courts of the two countries concerned declare themselves competent but come to contrary conclusions, particularly with regard to the custody of the child.  The convention aims to remedy such situations: it establishes the jurisdictions and law of the state where the child resides as competent, and organizes his immediate return.  This accession is therefore very good news for international cooperation and the safety of the child.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 Following Kazakhstan's accession to the Hague Convention, a Council decision authorising the two Member States (Austria and Romania) which have not yet accepted accession to do so is necessary. This will allow the Convention to enter into force between Kazakhstan and the entire European Union.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. The 1980 Hague Convention on Civil Aspects of Child Abduction, signed by all Member States of the Union, is an instrument of international cooperation that authorizes signatory States to resolve transnational cases relating to the custody and abduction of minors, clarifying the national law applicable in cases where there is a conflict of jurisdiction between two or more national legal systems. The scope of the rule reaches civil aspects, applying mainly to cases of separate parents or other persons who have legal rights over the child. Since the objective of the Convention is to protect minors in a situation of legal uncertainty, it is important to ensure that it is signed by as many States as possible.  Since the Union has exclusive external competence in this area, but the convention does not authorise the participation of international actors, the Union needs to give all its Member States express authorisation to accept the participation of any new State in the Convention. That is why I voted in favour of authorizing Member States to accept Kazakhstan's access to the Convention.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of Kazakhstan's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction. International cooperation in this area is fundamental and is aimed primarily at safeguarding the interests of the child. Each new accession to this Convention is therefore a step forward with regard to the general objective of protecting the rights of the child which is enshrined in Article 3 of the Treaty on european Union.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which empowers certain Member States in the interest of the European Union to support Kazakhstan's accession to the 1980 agreement. the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. Following the accession of Kazakhstan to the Convention, this Decision is necessary in order to empower Member States to accept the accession of that country. This will allow the Convention to enter into force between Kazakhstan and the European Union as a whole.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention, which dates from 1980 and deals with the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, plays a key role in settling conflicts of jurisdiction in civil justice matters, including the protection of minors, by establishing the jurisdiction of the court of the State of residence of the minor as the competent authority for resolving disputes between parents.  In view of the European legislative framework, this is a procedure which falls within the exclusive external competence of the European Union, and the European Parliament should be consulted before the Council authorises the Member States to accept Kazakhstan's access to the Convention. I would remind you that this country has made reform efforts in its judicial system, and it is logical, appropriate and desirable that the Convention should be applied as soon as possible between both parties in order to ensure enhanced protection of minors covered by it throughout Europe and Kazakhstan.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which is technical in nature and relates to the Council's decision authorising certain Member States to accept, in the interests of the European Union, Kazakhstan's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction. The European Union has jurisdiction over this and, for that, a Council decision is needed.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Kazakhstan's accession to the Hague Convention in relation to the civil aspects of international child abduction, because it entails greater protection and guarantees for children. The Hague Convention establishes a system that allows the cooperation of Contracting States to find a solution to situations of international child abduction. These cases usually occur in cases of separations with parents from different countries. The Convention regulates that the applicable legislation in such cases is that of the child's State of residence. It also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of the stolen child.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: Written. I have voted in favour of this report because I see the accession of Kazakhstan to the Hague Convention as a first step in dealing with the problem of abducted children. By establishing the competent courts and laws to be applied, we are laying the foundations for cooperation between contracting states. However, I do not think that is enough. I see the need for systematic work on this issue, both by the police, prosecutors, civil organisations, etc. Accession to the Convention is a good start, but it will not be enough without systematic work to prevent the problem.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Kazakhstan's accession to the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, as I consider this type of coordination between States to be positive in resolving the sensitive cases of international child abduction, with the aim of moving towards respect for the rights and interests of children.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Today, I voted for the Package on the accession of Kazakhstan to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. This is important for engagement in enhanced international cooperation with other signatories to the Convention.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction is an extremely important instrument. It has been ratified by all EU Member States. This Convention establishes a system enabling States Parties to cooperate in finding a solution in cases of international child abduction. Following the accession of Kazakhstan to this Convention, it was necessary for the Council to issue a decision authorising the Member States (except Denmark, which are not covered by Union civil policy and the Netherlands, which has already adopted the accession of Kazakhstan), to accept the accession of Kazakhstan. This will allow the entry into force of the Convention between Kazakhstan and the entire European Union. I fully support this Council decision, which the Council has already issued in advance. The system established by the Hague Convention will be more effective if more countries join it.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the extension of the Hague Convention to Kazakhstan, as it is an important international convention protecting the rights of the child. The Convention has been ratified by all EU Member States and today the EU already has exclusive external competence in this area, as the Court of Justice has ruled. It is therefore necessary for the Council to issue a decision authorising the Member States to adopt accession. This will allow the entry into force of the Convention between Kazakhstan and the union as a whole. EU countries will be able to use the system of cooperation with Kazakhstan to find solutions in cases of international child abduction. Such cases often occur when parents from different countries divorce. Parents may seek custody of that child when there is no cooperation between states by abducting the child. Individual countries have a strong national character in this matter of their legal systems. Therefore, there are regular situations where the courts of both States concerned are declared competent and that each of them grants custody to the parent. This is to be preceded by this convention, which requires that the competent court and the law of the State in which the child resides be determined at international level. I therefore welcome the fact that Kazakhstan's judicial system also has a willingness to implement this convention, as the functioning of the Convention itself depends on the number of countries joining it.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention deals with cases where a child is abducted by one of the parents to another state in the hope that the legislation there will give him a better position in the custody dispute. Extending the scope of the Hague Convention narrows the possibilities for such action and increases the international legal protection of children. It is particularly important to join countries that do not have a sufficiently developed legislative tradition and the impartiality of their courts is at a lower level.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil-legal aspects of international child abduction is a key instrument ratified by all EU Member States. The Convention establishes a system of cooperation between Contracting States to deal with cases of international child abductions that often occur when the child's parents are separated. The most common problem is the bias of individual national legal systems and the jurisdiction of courts in both countries. Following Kazakhstan's accession to the Convention, a Council decision is needed to allow Member States to accept Kazakhstan's access so that the Convention between Kazakhstan and the entire European Union enters into force. I support the draft report of the Committee on Legal Affairs on the proposal for a Council decision authorisation of certain Member States to accept, in the interest of the European Union, Kazakhstan's approach to the 1980 Hague Convention on civil-legal aspects of international child abduction.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The 1980 Hague Convention on Civil Matters of International Child Abduction is a vital tool and establishes a system that enables States Parties to cooperate in finding a solution to situations of international child abduction. The convention system is made more effective by the accession of several countries. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention on child abductions needs to be ratified by all states. This resolves the hands of the authorities for cooperation both in the field of investigations worldwide and in the repatriation of the victim.  One of the most important problems that is even solved is in the case of parents who are separated and belong to different states. The Treaty simplifies finding a solution for the child.

name: József SZÁJER
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on civil aspects of the abduction of children establishes a system enabling cooperation between Contracting States to find solutions to the issue of the abduction of children abroad. The biggest problem in such cases is the national nature of the legal system of states. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve such situations at international level by determining that the law of the State in which the child is resident applies and that the case falls within the jurisdiction of the court of that State. The Convention also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of a child who has been unlawfully taken abroad. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area, as confirmed by the Court of Justice in Opinion No 1/13. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own competences. The problem arises from the fact that the Convention does not provide for the independent action of international organisations, so that, following kazakhstan's accession to the Convention, a decision of the Council is needed authorises the two Member States which have not yet adopted the accession of Kazakhstan, Austria and Romania, to accept the accession of Peru. This will allow the Convention to enter into force between Kazakhstan and the European Union as a whole. In view of the above, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of parliament's approval of the proposal because I am convinced that this will also strengthen the international protection of children who have been illegally taken abroad. I am aware that the relevant Hague Convention has proved to be one of the most extensive and successful international instruments in practice over the last three decades, often and actively used by States Parties as a legal basis for establishing jurisdiction and conducting proceedings against children in difficult and contentious situations after their parents' divorce. The EU currently has exclusive external competence to act on such matters, but in the case of newer States acceding to the Convention, member states' ratification and the Council's corresponding decision are necessary for the entry into force, where appropriate between Kazakhstan and the EU. In view of the fact that the Functioning of the Hague Convention is more effective, the more States are parties to the system, I also welcome kazakhstan's accession.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a very important document, adopted at international level in 1980 and ratified by all EU Member States, which established cooperation between signatory States in this sensitive area. In order to implement the Convention, in relation to third countries, the European Council needs the authorisation of the Member States throughout the EU. This is also the case for the accession of Kazakhstan, a state close to the EU, with which member states have very good relations. Currently, the Council must authorise the majority of Member States, with the exception of the Netherlands, which has already accepted the accession of the Kazakh State, and Denmark, which is excluded from the Union's civil justice policy, to accept this accession, which will allow the entry into force of the Convention between Kazakhstan and the EU. I believe that this is an important step in favour of EU citizens of Kazakh origin, which is why I support the adoption of this report.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. This convention establishes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in cases of international child abduction. This often occurs when a couple separates. For a husband or wife from another country, it may be tempting to take advantage of the lack of cooperation between states to obtain custody of the children. There is frequent press coverage of international child abductions that occur during separation or divorce. The major problem is the nationalist conception that underlies the legal system of states. In such cases, the courts of the two states concerned often declare themselves competent and each of them entrusts custody of the child to that of the parents who have the nationality of the state in which it sits. The purpose of the convention in question is to remedy this kind of situation at the international level by establishing the jurisdiction of the courts and the law of the state in which the child resides. It also sets up a system to ensure the immediate return of the abducted child.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ The Hague Convention (1980) on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a vitally important instrument, ratified by all EU Member States. The Convention created a cooperative system between the signatory states with the goal of resolving cases of international child abduction. Most often, reports of child abduction are the result of a couple separating, where the mother and father are from different states. States often are unwilling or unable to cooperate with one another during instances of child abduction as a result of national bias of differing legal systems. Parents frequently exploit these legal and judicial disparities in order to secure full custody of the child in a particular state. I voted in favour of the accession of Kazakhstan so that child abduction at the international level can be resolved through the competent courts of the state of residence of the child.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒I voted to join Kazakhstan to the Hague Convention on civil-legal aspects of international child abduction, as the Commission, together with civil law experts from the Member States, deemed it desirable for the Convention between the European Union and Kazakhstan to enter into force. Problems of international child abduction occur when parents from different countries divorce and one parent takes the child to their country without the consent of the other parent. In such cases, most national courts are biased and it often happens that courts in both countries are declared competent.  I support that this Convention addresses the problem internationally by declaring the competent court from the child's country of residence, and introducing a system that guarantees the immediate return of abducted children.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. The proposal for a Council decision authoring certain Member States to accept, in the interest of the European Union, the accession of Kazakhstan to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of international child abuse, I supported. Often problems arise when a couple is a separation. If the parents are from different countries, the risk of either of them attempting to take advantage of this Convention is to resolve such cases at international level by determining the courts and the applicable law for the courts and the law applicable to the courts and the law of the country in which the child is domiciled. The Convention also provides for a system for ensuring the immediate return of an immediately confiscated child.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Kazakhstan's accession to the Hague Convention in relation to the civil aspects of international child abduction, because it entails greater protection and guarantees for children. The Hague Convention establishes a system that allows the cooperation of Contracting States to find a solution to situations of international child abduction. These cases usually occur in cases of separations with parents from different countries. The Convention regulates that the applicable legislation in such cases is that of the child's State of residence. It also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of the stolen child.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I support this proposal, which prioritises the welfare of the child in case of legal conflict (separation or divorce) between parents from different countries. This agreement will save time, money and suffering for the affected families and guarantees the protection of children in the entire territory of the Union.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction establishes a system of cooperation between contracting states to deal with international child abduction cases. It has been ratified by all EU member states. In many cases, these problems arise when a couple is separated. If the mother and father are from different states, there is a temptation to exploit the lack of cooperation between states in order to ensure the custody of the child. It is common for courts in the two states concerned to declare jurisdiction and to each assign custody of the child to the parent who is a national of their state. The purpose of the convention is to resolve such situations at the international level, by establishing that the competent courts and applicable laws are those of the child's state of residence. The convention also introduces a system that ensures the immediate return of children who have been abducted. I am voting for the adoption of this text, because this country has chosen to apply for membership.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is an instrument of particular importance. Firstly, it avoids prolonged uncertainty as to the legal status of the child. It is accompanied by a situation in which the child's parents are nationals of two different Member States and a dispute arises as to which of them to be cared for and which court should rule on it. It is undoubtedly in the interests of the best interests of the child to resolve this issue as soon as possible and to guarantee his or her immediate and safe return. Following kazakhstan's accession to the Hague Convention, a Council Decision authorising Member States to agree to this accession is necessary. As a result, the agreement between Kazakhstan and the European Union as a whole will be able to enter into force. The Hague Convention has already been ratified by all Member States of the European Union and dozens of other countries. The accession of another country deserves approval and support, which is why I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on civil aspects of the abduction of children established a system allowing cooperation between Contracting States in finding a solution to the issue of the abduction of children abroad. The purpose of the convention in question is to resolve such situations at international level by determining that the law of the State in which the child is resident applies and that the case falls within the jurisdiction of the court of that State. Following kazakhstan's accession to the Convention, a council decision is needed authorizing the Member States (with the exception of Denmark, which is excluded from the Union's civil justice policy, and the Netherlands, which has already accepted the accession of Kazakhstan) to accept the accession of Kazakhstan. This will allow the agreement to enter into force between Kazakhstan and the European Union as a whole. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Traian UNGUREANU
text: in writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction aims to deal with cases of international child abduction. In 2014, at the request of the European Commission, the Court of Justice of the European Union was consulted on the competence of the Union to accept the accession of a third State to the 1980 Convention. The opinion delivered by the Court in October 2014 confirmed the existence of the Exclusive Competence of the Union as regards the acceptance of the accession of a third State to the 1980 Convention. In June 2013, Kazakhstan deposited its instrument of accession to the 1980 Convention, but following the accession of that State to the Convention, a Council decision authorising the Member States, with the exception of the Netherlands, which has already accepted accession and Denmark which is excluded from the Union's civil justice policy, is necessary to accept that accession. This will allow the effective entry into force of the Convention between Kazakhstan and the entire European Union. The report of the European Parliament supports the accession of that State to the Convention and proposes the approval without amendment of the Council decision so that the children concerned are guaranteed the protection granted throughout the Union.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Kazakhstan's accession to the Hague Convention in relation to the civil aspects of international child abduction, because it entails greater protection and guarantees for children. The Hague Convention establishes a system that allows the cooperation of Contracting States to find a solution to situations of international child abduction. These cases usually occur in cases of separations with parents from different countries. The Convention regulates that the applicable legislation in such cases is that of the child's State of residence. It also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of the stolen child.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council Decision authorising certain Member States to accept, in the interests of the Union, Kazakhstan's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, as I believe it is important that Kazakhstan is already part of an issue of international scope.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – I welcome kazakhstan's accession to the Convention. The Commission, together with experts in the field of civil justice in the Member States, assessed the functioning of the Justice System in Kazakhstan and its determination to implement the Convention and considers it desirable for the Convention to enter into force between the European Union and Kazakhstan. I agree with this because the Hague Convention system will be more efficient if more countries join it (see Minutes).

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Report on the proposal for a Council decision authorising certain Member States to accept, in the interest of the European Union, the accession of Kazakhstan to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a vitally important instrument that has been ratified by all EU Member States. The Convention introduces a system of cooperation between the contracting states aimed at settling cases of international child abduction. In many instances, these problems arise when a couple has separated. If the mother and father are from different states, there is a temptation to exploit the lack of cooperation between those states in order to secure custody of the child. The biggest problem in such cases is the national bias of the legal systems of individual states. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve such situations at an international level, by establishing that the competent courts and applicable laws are those of the state of residence of the child. I believe that the accession of Kazakhstan is to be welcomed, as the Hague Convention system is more effective if more countries sign up to it.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on civil aspects of international child abduction, ratified by all Member States of the Union, is an instrument of crucial importance, since the system it establishes allows the cooperation of Contracting States to find a solution to such international conflicts. Since the main problem in these cases is the bias of the legal systems of States in favour of their own nationals, the objective of the Convention is to resolve these situations at the international level, as well as to establish a system to ensure the immediate return of the stolen child. Following Kazakhstan's accession to the Convention, a Council decision is necessary for it to enter into force and to ensure that children in Kazakhstan are protected against illegal abduction. I therefore considered it appropriate to vote in favour of this text.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Kazakhstan's accession to the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, as I consider this type of coordination between States to be positive in resolving the sensitive cases of international child abduction, with the aim of moving towards respect for the rights and interests of children.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'This Convention provides for an arrangement whereby states work together to find a solution in the event of international abduction of minors. The main problem in such cases is partisanship of the judiciary in each state. All too often, the judges in each of the states concerned declare themselves competent, after which they each assign the right of custody of the child to the parent of their own nationality. I agreed with the report because Kazakhstan's accession to the Hague Convention will bring legal certainty for children of divorced parents.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. It is a proposal for a Council decision on the authorisation of the country's authorisation of the country, there is another, as we all know, to the Hague Convention on the civil aspects relating to the international abduction of children. This Convention focuses on international cooperation, for example in a divorce case where a parent of different nationalities flees with her child to another country. The Convention aims to resolve such situations on an international scale by establishing that cases are tried by the competent courts and in accordance with the applicable legislation of the minor's State of residence. The Convention also establishes a system ensuring the immediate return of abducted minors. Kazakhstan is recommended in this case to be taken to the other Member States, as Ireland, the Czech Republic and Lithuania have already endorsed that accession. Denmark is excluded from this cooperation. Support.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The Convention includes a system of cooperation between States Parties to resolve cases of international child abduction by separate partners of different nationalities. This is done by determining that jurisdiction rests with the courts of the child's country of residence and that the law of the child is applicable. The Convention also introduces a system to ensure that children who have been abducted are returned immediately. In view of the increasing number of problematic cases of international custody disputes, I believe that this Agreement is useful and have therefore agreed.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ As a children’s rights champion, I welcome the accession of Kazakhstan to this important Convention. This will allow it to cooperate with other State Parties to the Convention, including EU Member States, on tackling and combating child abduction.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 In recent years, we have increasingly seen cases of international child abduction, as it is common for mother and father to often come from different countries. In the event of disagreements, they then try to obtain their offspring by taking him to their State of origin, as they rely on the states not cooperating and will therefore find it more difficult to get the child back. I therefore believe that there should be a single system of cooperation between states aimed at finding solutions in the case of international child abductions. At present, there may still be cases where the courts of both countries finally entrust the child to the custody of the parent who is a national of that state. The Hague Convention, ratified by all EU states, addresses these situations and also introduces a system for the immediate return of a abducted child to his or her homeland. I therefore welcome Kazakhstan's accession to the Hague Convention and I am sure that this will help to better protect children in the event of their abduction outside the borders.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The 1980 Hague Convention on International Child Abduction is an extremely important tool for addressing the civil aspects of international child abduction. International child abduction is a huge negative impact on the life of the whole family and, in particular, on the psyche of the child. The objective of this Convention is therefore to restore the status quo by immediately returning the wrongfully transferred child to his or her country of habitual residence, through a system of cooperation between the central authorities designated by the Contracting Parties. The Convention has so far been ratified by 93 states, including all Member States of the European Union. In view of the objective of the Convention, it is therefore very important that as many countries as possible accede to it, thereby reducing as far as possible situations where a child is abducted abroad, but unfortunately there is no legal instrument to help return the child, as the country to which he or she was abducted has not ratified this convention. For these reasons, I therefore welcomed Kazakhstan's decision to accede to the Convention, and I supported the report on the adoption of this accession by the European Union.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The following is a non-legislative act ratifying the republic of Korea's accession to the Hague Convention on the International Abduction of Children. As this is a formally necessary act, since the Convention does not provide for the possibility of direct approval by the EU, I voted in favour.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP chose to abstain on this vote because it is such an emotive issue. The right of countries acceding to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is extremely important; however, this should be done at the will of the individual country and not en bloc by the EU.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Korea's accession to the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, as I consider this type of coordination between States to be positive in resolving the sensitive cases of international child abduction, with the aim of moving towards respect for the rights and interests of children.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this report to endorse the Council decision to authorise the accession of Korea to the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. The Convention is a multilateral treaty to ensure that children wrongfully taken into another country, often by a parent or guardian, are brought back to their home country. A ruling of the European Court of Justice in 2014 found that the EU now has exclusive external competence in these matters, but the Convention does not allow for international organisations – such as the EU – to sign the Convention themselves. This Council decision is therefore necessary to allow Member States to accept the accession of Korea to the Convention, bringing the Convention into force between the entire EU and Korea.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to give Member States (with the exception of Denmark, to which this is not applicable, and the Czech Republic, Ireland and Lithuania, which have already accepted) permission to accept South Korea's accession to the Convention, which will allow the agreement between South Korea and the EU as a whole to enter into force.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the proposal for a Council decision authorising certain Member States to accept, in the interest of the European Union, the accession of the Republic of Korea to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. The accession of South Korea to the Convention is to be welcomed. The European Commission has evaluated the functioning of South Korea's justice system and the country's willingness to implement the Convention, and considers that it is desirable for the Convention to enter into force between the European Union and South Korea. However, a Council decision is necessary to authorise the Member States (except Denmark, which is excluded from the Union's civil justice policy, and the Czech Republic, Ireland and Lithuania, which have already accepted the accession of South Korea) to accept the accession of the Republic of Korea. This will allow the Convention to enter into force between the Republic of Korea and the entire European Union. I welcome the effort to ensure that EU-wide protection is afforded to the children in question, also having in mind the fact that there is a significant Korean community in Europe, which adds to the relevance of accepting this accession.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council decision authorising certain Member States, in the interests of the European Union, to accept the accession of the Republic of Korea to the 1980 Hague Convention on Civil Matters of International Child Abduction, because this establishes a system allowing Contracting States to cooperate in finding a solution to such situations.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a legal instrument of great importance and ratified by all the Member States of the European Union. The Convention establishes a system of cooperation between States Parties to resolve cases of international child abduction. Very often these problems occur when a couple has separated. If the parents come from different countries, they may be tempted to take advantage of the lack of cooperation between these states in order to obtain custody of the child.  The aim of the Convention is to provide solutions to these situations at international level by determining that the courts of the child's country of residence have jurisdiction and that the law of the child is applicable. The Convention also introduces a system to ensure that children who have been abducted are returned immediately. I welcome South Korea's accession to the Hague Convention. The more countries sign this convention, the more effective it is. There is a large Korean community in Europe, which makes the adoption of this accession all the more important.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which resolves cases of international child abduction by allowing South Korea to accede to the 1980 Hague Convention.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ Under normal circumstances, I would vote against or abstain on resolutions involving the European Union’s participation in international bodies and organisations because I believe that it’s not for the European Union to make such decisions. In this situation, however, the question is whether South Korea should be allowed to accede to the Hague Convention. It should be a vote of the British Parliament, but it is not, because such sovereignty has been ceded. If the European Parliament were to vote against accession, it would penalise children at risk of abduction in that country. Therefore I voted in favour of accession, despite my constitutional concerns.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted for this proposal because it appears that the Republic of Korea meets the criteria for the effective implementation of the Convention. The size of the Korean community in Europe also underscores the value of accepting this membership.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal authorising certain Member States to approve the accession of the Republic of Korea to 1980 in the interest of the European Union. the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. of 25 October 1980 The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a very important instrument providing for a framework for cooperation between the Contracting Parties to deal with cases of international child abduction. In most cases, problems with child abduction arise after the couple divorced. In addition, the courts of both states often recognise themselves as competent to hear the case and each child is assigned custody to the parent who is a national of their state. In the light of these examples, I support Korea's accession to the Hague Convention in order to establish the competent courts and applicable laws of the state in which the child is habitually resident. It would also ensure that the abducted child is returned immediately.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP chose to abstain on this vote because it is such an emotive issue.  The right of countries acceding to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is extremely important; however, this should be done at the will of the individual country and not en bloc by the EU.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction establishes a system of cooperation between contracting states to deal with international child abduction cases. It has been ratified by all EU member states. The purpose of the convention is to resolve such situations at the international level, by establishing that the competent courts and applicable laws are those of the child's state of residence. The EU now has exclusive external jurisdiction in this area. The convention also introduces a system that ensures the immediate return of children who have been abducted. That is why I voted in favour of Korea's accession to the Hague Convention.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I voted in favour of South Korea's accession to the Hague Convention. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction is an instrument of the utmost importance. It has been ratified by all the Member States of the European Union. This convention establishes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in cases of international child abduction.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, ratified by all EU countries, has introduced a system allowing contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution to this type of case. The text of the Treaty contains two main points: jurisdiction to adjudicate and applicability of the laws entrusted to the state of residence of the child and the establishment of a mechanism for the immediate return of the stolen child. The European Union currently has exclusive external competence in this area, but the Convention does not provide for the autonomous action of international organisations. That is why the Member States must act on behalf of the Union with prior authorisation from the Council. The Dzhambazki report, which I supported today, authorises some Member States to accept Korea's accession to the Convention, allowing it to have its effects on relations between the Asian country and the European Union.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Korea's accession to the Hague Convention in relation to the civil aspects of international child abduction, because it entails greater protection and guarantees for children. The Hague Convention establishes a system that allows the cooperation of Contracting States to find a solution to situations of international child abduction. These cases usually occur in cases of separations with parents from different countries. The Convention regulates that the applicable legislation in such cases is that of the child's State of residence. It also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of the stolen child.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I would like to thank the rapporteur for the work done in this report on the accession of the Republic of Korea to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. It is an instrument of crucial importance. The accession of the Republic of Korea is good news.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on South Korea's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. South Korea must be free, if it wishes, to join this system of international cooperation, which allows, among other things, to settle cases of international child abduction. There may indeed be a problem in the case of a separated couple whose parents come out of different states. The Convention settles possible jurisdictional disputes since it stipulates that the applicable laws are those of the Child's state of residence. It also allows an immediate return of the abducted child. While I regret that the Union now has exclusive jurisdiction in this area to the detriment of the Member States, South Korea, as a sovereign state, has every right to join this Convention and the ratification of this accession will allow it to enter into force between the Union and that country.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction provides for cooperation between signatory states so that a child or child under 16 who has been arbitrarily "abducted" by a parent returns to the place of family residence pending a judicial ruling, unless the return foretooes a serious danger to his or her safety. I believe it is of fundamental importance for the protection of our children that this convention be ratified and respected by more and more States. I therefore voted to support Korea's accession to it.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The 1980 Hague Convention on civil aspects of international child abduction, signed by all EU Member States, is an instrument of international cooperation that authorizes signatory States to resolve transnational cases relating to the custody and abduction of minors, clarifying the national law applicable in cases where there is a conflict of jurisdiction between two or more national legal systems. The scope of the rule reaches civil aspects, applying mainly to cases of separate parents or other persons who have legal rights over the child. Since the objective of the Convention is to protect minors in a situation of legal uncertainty, it is important to ensure that it is signed by as many States as possible.  Although the EU has exclusive external competence in this area, the Convention does not authorise the participation of international actors, so the EU needs to give all its Member States express authorisation to accept the participation of any new State in the Convention. That is why I voted in favour of authorising Member States to accept Korea's accession to the Convention.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which deals with the interest of the European Union in supporting the accession of the Republic of Korea to the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. of 25 October 1980 The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a very important document. It has been ratified by all EU Member States. The Convention provides for a framework for cooperation between the Contracting Parties to deal with international child abduction cases. In most cases, these problems occur when the couple divorced. If the mother and father come from different countries, there is a desire to take advantage of the lack of cooperation between these states in order to secure custody of the child. The media is full of reports of international child abduction in the area of separation or divorce. In these cases, the national bias of the legal systems of individual countries is the biggest problem. Often, the courts of both states recognise themselves as competent to hear the case and each child is cared for by a parent who is a national of their state. Following the accession of South Korea to the Convention, a Council Decision is necessary to empower Member States (with the exception of Denmark, which is not covered by the Union's civil justice policy, and the Czech Republic, Ireland and Lithuania, which have already supported South Korea's accession) to accept South Korea's accession. This will allow the Convention to enter into force between South Korea and the European Union as a whole. South Korea's accession to the Convention is to be welcomed.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on civil aspects of the abduction of children established a system allowing cooperation between Contracting States in finding a solution to the issue of the abduction of children abroad. The biggest problem in such cases is the national nature of the legal system of states. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve such situations at international level by determining that the law of the State in which the child is resident applies and that the case falls within the jurisdiction of the court of that State. The Convention also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of a child who has been unlawfully taken abroad. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area, as confirmed by the Court of Justice in Opinion No 1/13. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own competences. The problem arises from the fact that the Convention does not provide for the independent action of international organisations, so that, following Korea's accession to the Convention, a decision of the Council is needed authorizing the two Member States which have not yet adopted korea's accession, Austria and Romania, to accept Korea's accession. This will allow the Agreement to enter into force between Korea and the European Union as a whole. In view of the above, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. As with the accession of Peru and Kazakhstan to the Hague Convention, I have no reservations about korea's accession to that Convention, and I therefore fully support the proposed decision. The 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abuse is a very important instrument that provides for a system for cooperation in finding solutions to cases of international child abuse. The Convention was ratified a long time ago by all EU Member States. Problems are most often the case in the case of separation between parents who come from different countries. There is a danger that one of the parents may wish to take advantage of the lack of cooperation between those two countries and thus acquire the exclusive custody of the children. In such cases, the biggest problem is the national bias of the legal systems in individual countries, and the judgments often end in such a way that each national court entrusts the child with the custody of a parent who is a national of that country. The Convention, however, lays down jurisdiction on the courts and law of the state in which the child is domiciled, as well as a system for ensuring the immediate return of the child who is wrongfully deprived. In the event of Korea's accession to the Convention, this means that children connected to the Korean community in eu Member States will be protected from illegal confiscation.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. I support this South Korea Access Report to the Hague Convention, which protects children who find themselves in legal uncertainty. The report aims to grant permission for Member States (except Denmark not to which this does not apply and the Czech Republic, Ireland and Lithuania which have already given their consent) to accept South Korea's accession to the Convention, which will allow the Entry into Force of the Convention between South Korea and the European Union.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. I am in favour of the adoption of this text because Korea has made the sovereign choice to apply for membership.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. ‒ I decided to support this resolution with the aim of getting the Member States to accept Korea as a contracting party to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. This decision will allow an increase in the number of states which will share that common legal framework upon child abduction.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction is an instrument of fundamental importance which has been ratified by all the Member States of the European Union. The Convention introduces a system which allows contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution to cases of international child abduction. The aim of the Convention is to resolve these situations at international level by establishing that the competent courts and applicable laws are those of the child's state of residence. The Convention also introduces a system that guarantees the immediate return of the abducted child, protecting his or her health and fundamental rights. The accession of the Republic of Korea to the Convention is a positive step in promoting the protection of children's rights at global and not just European level.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980, ratified by all EU Member States, establishes a system of cooperation between contracting states to deal with cases of international child abduction. In most cases, these abductions are related to the divorce of the parents, tempted to exploit the lack of cooperation between states to obtain custody of their child. This convention stipulates that the competent courts and applicable laws are those of the child's state of residence. This text aims to give the opinion of the European Parliament on the entry into force of this convention between South Korea and the Union, which now has exclusive external jurisdiction in this area. Although I dispute the loss of sovereignty of the Member States, which leave it to the Union to adopt this type of agreement for them, I have spoken in favour of this text. On the one hand, this convention promotes the return of children to their homes, on the other hand, the accession of South Korea is news that should be welcomed.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is one of the main tools for promoting the rights of the child. The Convention establishes a system of cooperation between central authorities aimed at resolving cases of international child abduction. These cases occur mainly in situations where parents come from different states, states that have not strengthened a cooperation partnership. As a result, a vulnerability is created that favours unlawful actions to obtain the custody of children. Thus, the Hague Convention aims to resolve such cases at international level, providing for a system which ensures the immediate return of unlawfully displaced or detained children.  The accession of the Republic of Korea to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is an action I consider appropriate. I was in favour of the accession of the Republic of Korea to the Hague Convention, because I consider it essential that preventing child abduction remains a priority for the European Union and third countries.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. The Hague Convention was established in 1980 and deals with the civil aspects of international child abduction. All EU member states have ratified it. The agreement resolves jurisdictional disputes when two jurisdictions each declare themselves competent for custody of children in the context of the separation of a binational couple. Each country must cooperate in the case of child abduction. The same is said for the protection of children. I voted in favour of this resolution which approves Korea's accession to the Hague Convention.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report today because I believe that the accession of the Republic of Korea to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction can have positive effects both in the EU and in Korea.  The children concerned will finally be able to benefit from effective protection in every corner of Europe. To date, the European Union has exclusive external competence in this area; This is confirmed in Opinion 1/13 by the Court of Justice. The Member States can therefore no longer act independently. As the report rightly points out, the real problem is that the Convention does not provide for autonomous action by international organisations. Following the accession of the Republic of Korea to the Convention, a decision is needed by the Council authorizing the Member States, with the exception of Denmark, which is not participating in the Union's civil justice policy, the Czech Republic, Ireland and Lithuania, which have already accepted the accession of the Republic of Korea, to accept the aforementioned accession.  In the light of the substantial Korean community in Europe, the acceptance of accession acquires a very special value.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ This was a vote to endorse the Council's decision to authorise Korea signing up to the Hague Convention of International Child Abduction. The Convention is a multilateral treaty with the purpose of ensuring the immediate return of children wrongfully taken to or retained internationally (usually by one parent or guardian) in their home country, where domestic custody proceedings can take place. While a ruling of the ECJ in 2014 found that the EU now has exclusive external competence in the field, the Convention does not allow for international organisations - such as the EU - to be partners to the Convention themselves. These Council decisions are therefore necessary to allow particular Member States which have not yet accepted the accession of the relevant countries to the Convention to do so, bringing the Convention into force between the entire EU and that country. For these reasons I voted in favour.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ Following the accession of South Korea to the Convention, a Council decision is therefore necessary to authorise the Member States, with some exceptions, to accept the accession of South Korea. This will allow the Convention to enter into force between South Korea and the entire European Union. Following the positive results of the evaluation of the functioning of South Korea's justice system and the country's willingness to implement the Convention, I followed the Rapporteur´s indication that Parliament should approve the proposal, in order to ensure that EU-wide protection is afforded to settling cases of international child abduction in these particular cases.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this non-legislative act which allows Member States to ratify the accession of the Republic of Korea to the Hague Convention on the International Abduction of Children.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 The 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction established a system of cooperation between the authorities of each Contracting State, which establishes the immediate return of children who have been unlawfully transferred or detained. Since this is an international agreement which aims to protect and protect children in situations of legal uncertainty, it must be ratified by as many states as possible. Given that the European Union has exclusive external competence in the field of child abduction, I am convinced that the European institutions must authorise the Member States to accept the participation of the Republic of Korea. I therefore voted in favour of the decision, hoping for the rapid entry into force of the 1980 Hague Convention between the Republic of Korea and all EU Member States in order to prevent the abduction of children.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and note that South Korea's accession to the Convention is welcome. The Commission, together with member states' civil justice experts, has assessed the functioning of South Korea's justice system and the country's willingness to implement the Convention, and considers it desirable to bring the Convention between the European Union and South Korea into force.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted on the report authorising certain Member States, in the interests of the European Union, to accept the accession of the Republic of Korea to the 1980 Hague Convention on Civil Matters of International Child Abduction. As this is a question of improving the framework for the protection of citizens, especially children, no objections were raised by either side and I therefore voted in favour.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure in view of the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction is an instrument of fundamental importance that has been ratified by all the Member States of the European Union. It is part of a system which allows contracting states to cooperate and find a solution to cases of international child abduction. Many times the main problem is the tendency of the legal systems of individual States to practise favouritism on the basis of nationality. It is often the case that the courts of both states concerned declare themselves competent and that each of them entrusts the child to the parent who is a national of the State in which the court is located. The aim of the Convention is to resolve these situations at international level by establishing that the competent courts and applicable laws are those of the child's state of residence. The Convention also introduces a system which guarantees the immediate return of the child who has been abducted. Korea's accession to the Convention is to be welcomed. The Commission has assessed, together with experts from the Member States, the functioning of the Korean judicial system and considers the agreement between the European Union and Korea to be desirable.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the accession of the Republic of Korea to the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. Since the Convention is valid only among the contracting states, this new accession represents a positive goal in the field of child protection. In particular, the Hague Convention favours the creation of a common legal framework for the international abduction of children, which is particularly effective in the event of a clash between different national legislations.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the Report on the proposal for a Council decision authorising certain Member States to accept, in the interest of the European Union, the accession of the Republic of Korea to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction and noted no objections.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a key instrument in the context of judicial cooperation between contracting States in the resolution of cases of international child abduction. This Convention aims to harmonise the legal systems other than those states which normally declare themselves both competent to adjudicate the action and declare custody of the minor to the national parent of the State they represent, and the criterion of the State of residence of the minor is adopted with the Convention. As this matter currently is the exclusive external competence of the Union, a Council decision is necessary which call for the Member States to accept the access of third countries to the Hague Convention. I support the Dzhambazki report and congratulate the Republic of Korea on its adoption of the Convention.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – UKIP chose to abstain on this vote because it is such an emotive issue.  The right of countries acceding to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is extremely important; however, this should be done at the will of the individual country and not en bloc by the EU.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ This is an important instrument which has been ratified by all the EU Member States, providing protection for the interest of those children who are victims of abduction. The Convention introduces a system of cooperation between the contracting states aimed at settling cases of international child abduction addressing the legal systems of individual states.  It may often be that the courts in both states concerned declare themselves competent, with each of them awarding custody of the child to the parent who is a national of their state. An important development introduced by the Convention is a system which ensures the immediate return of children who have been abducted. Following the accession of South Korea to the Convention, a Council decision is necessary to authorise the Member States, with some exceptions, to accept the accession of South Korea. I support this since it will allow the Convention to enter into force between South Korea and the entire European Union.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Korea's accession to the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, as I consider this type of coordination between States to be positive in resolving the sensitive cases of international child abduction, with the aim of moving towards respect for the rights and interests of children.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 1980 is intended to prevent the abduction of children abroad and to resolve legal disputes in this way. The Convention has been ratified by all EU Member States. Under the Convention, the law of the State in which the child is resident applies and the case falls within the jurisdiction of the court of that State. The Convention facilitates the settlement of civil disputes containing an international element, in particular when the parents are separated in different countries. Similarly to Peru and Kazakhstan, following the accession of South Korea to the Convention, a Council decision is needed authorizing the Member States (with the exception of the Czech Republic, Ireland and Lithuania, which have already accepted the accession of South Korea) to accept the accession of South Korea. This will allow the agreement to enter into force between South Korea and the European Union. The Commission and civil justice experts from the Member States support the entry into force of the Convention, which is also justified by the fact that there is a significant Korean community in Europe. I voted in favour of accession to the Convention.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Republic of Korea's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. That Convention regulates important matters relating to the granting of custody of a child where the parents come from different countries and confers legal force on the provisions of the country in which the child is permanently resident. I voted in favour because I believe that the more countries wish to accede to the Hague Convention, the more the resolution of contentious situations and the operation of the courts will be improved. The citizens of these countries will receive a guarantee of stability and legal certainty.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ The Hague Convention is an important international instrument of cooperation which enables signatory states to settle cross border cases regarding child custody and abduction. Considering the importance of this convention, I am in favour of the accession of Korea as the main scope is protecting children which find themselves in legal uncertainty.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is an extremely important instrument with the main objective of dealing with international child abduction cases, I welcome the accession of the Republic of Korea to the Convention.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This report proposes the approval of the European Parliament to a Council decision on South Korea's accession to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on civil aspects related to the abduction of children internationally. This convention, ratified by all members of the Union, provides for cooperation mechanisms to remedy jurisdictional conflicts when two jurisdictions declare themselves competent for childcare in the context of the separation of a binational couple. Considering that these reports contribute to the harmonization of international regulations on family dispute management, I supported this report.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP chose to abstain on this vote because it is such an emotive issue.  The right of countries acceding to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is extremely important; however, this should be done at the will of the individual country and not en bloc by the EU.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the Council's proposed decision authorising certain Member States to accept, in the interests of the European Union, the accession of the Republic of Korea to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction. By establishing the primacy of the jurisdiction and laws of the state in which the child resides, the convention plays a decisive role in resolving the issues surrounding the issue of custody of the child during the separation of binational couples. However, for the convention to be implemented, it is necessary for one state's membership to be accepted by the other States parties to the convention. Although the Republic of Korea joined in 2013, all EU Member States, with the exception of the Czech Republic, Ireland and Lithuania, have still not accepted membership. In order to ensure that children linked to the Korean community are protected from abduction, we call on the Council to adopt as soon as possible a decision authorising the Member States of the Union which have not yet done so to accept the accession of the Republic of Korea to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on civil aspects of the abduction of children establishes a system enabling cooperation between Contracting States to find solutions to the issue of the abduction of children abroad. The biggest problem in such cases is the national nature of the legal system of states. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve such situations at international level by determining that the law of the State in which the child is resident applies and that the case falls within the jurisdiction of the court of that State. The Convention also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of a child who has been unlawfully taken abroad. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area, as confirmed by the Court of Justice in Opinion No 1/13. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own competences. The problem arises from the fact that the Convention does not provide for the independent action of international organisations, so that, following Korea's accession to the Convention, a decision of the Council is needed authorizing the two Member States which have not yet adopted korea's accession, Austria and Romania, to accept Korea's accession. This will allow the Agreement to enter into force between Korea and the European Union as a whole. In view of the above, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU already has exclusive external competence in the field of international child abduction confirmed by the Court of Justice. But in order for this to be applied, the Member States must act in unison. The Council's authorisation of certain Member States to accept the accession of the Republic of Korea to the Hague Convention will have beneficial consequences for the whole of the European Union, thus improving cooperation at Community level to defend the rights of the child, such as the right to education and economic opportunities for a prosperous future. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. Every year around the world, several thousand children are abducted by one of the two parents. In the absence of cooperation between the State of origin and the child's state of residence, some cases cannot be resolved. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction is a legal instrument for recognizing the jurisdiction of the jurisdiction of the state in which the child resides. A dialogue can thus be established between the States Parties to this Convention to facilitate the return of the abducted child. The European Union supports the accession of third countries to the 1980 Convention so that its Member States can rely on a common legal framework to deal with international child abductions. In addition to the general objective of developing judicial cooperation, this regulation pursues the general objective of protecting children's rights. South Korea's accession to the convention is therefore good news.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 The 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is an important international agreement aimed at finding solutions in situations where the courts of both States (in the case of parents of two different nationalities) declare themselves competent and each of them gives custody of the child to the parent who is its national. The Convention establishes that the competent authorities are those where the child is resident.  The Convention also introduces a system to ensure the immediate return of children who have been abducted. The EU now has exclusive external competence in this area and therefore Member States no longer act at their own expense. With the accession of the Republic of Korea to this Convention, the European Union should allow Member States to accept such accession. I advise in my report that the Republic of Korea is welcome in this Convention.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 We consider the text to be positive because it is necessary for the Hague Convention on child abductions to be ratified by all states. This will resolve the hands of the authorities for cooperation both in investigations around the world and in the repatriation of the victim. One of the most important problems facing them is the cases of parents who are separated and come from different states. The Treaty simplifies efforts to find a solution for the child.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
