text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on civil aspects of the abduction of children establishes a system enabling cooperation between Contracting States to find solutions to the issue of the abduction of children abroad. The biggest problem in such cases is the national nature of the legal system of states. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve such situations at international level by determining that the law of the State in which the child is resident applies and that the case falls within the jurisdiction of the court of that State. The Convention also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of a child who has been unlawfully taken abroad. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area, as confirmed by the Court of Justice in Opinion No 1/13. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own competences. The problem arises from the fact that the Convention does not provide for the independent action of international organisations, so that, following Korea's accession to the Convention, a decision of the Council is needed authorizing the two Member States which have not yet adopted korea's accession, Austria and Romania, to accept Korea's accession. This will allow the Agreement to enter into force between Korea and the European Union as a whole. In view of the above, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the accession of Korea to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, which is a multilateral treaty that provides a way for abducted children to be returned from one member country to another. Countries need to work together in order to tackle international, cross-border problems like these, and for Korea to join will enlarge this network to fight child abduction more effectively. I support any measures which help safeguard the well-being of children in Wales.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The Convention in question establishes a system of cooperation between Contracting States aimed at finding a solution to cases of international child abduction. This type of situation occurs very often when a couple is apart. There are very frequent cases of international child abductions reported by the press that occur following separations and divorces. The Convention aims to remedy such situations on an international scale by establishing that cases are tried by the competent courts and in accordance with the applicable legislation of the minor's State of residence. The Convention also establishes a system ensuring the immediate return of abducted minors. The adoption of the Republic of Korea to the Convention deserves my praise and approval.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Vote for: in favour of the adoption of these texts because these countries have chosen to apply for membership.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 The report agrees on a Council decision on the authorisation of the republic of Korea (South) to the Hague Convention on civil aspects relating to international child abduction. This Convention establishes a system of cooperation between States aimed at finding a solution to cases of international child abduction. Its purpose is to ensure the return of children unlawfully transferred to or wrongly held in any Contracting State and to enforce effectively in the other Contracting States the custody and visitation rights existing in a Contracting State. The situation of child abduction sometimes occurs when a couple is apart, and parents are originally from different states. It is common for the courts of their respective countries to declare themselves both competent and that the courts grant custody of the minor to the national parent of the State they represent. The Purpose of the Convention is to remedy such situations at international level by establishing that cases are tried by the competent courts in accordance with the applicable legislation of the child's State of residence. The importance of the system ensuring the immediate return of abducted minors is underlined. We voted in favour, since the Agreement is intended to defend the interests of minors.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union has a very strong position in guaranteeing fundamental rights and strives to ensure that citizens of individual Member States are not put at risk and that their fundamental rights are protected. Among the instruments adopted by the European Union to protect children's rights is the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980. The convention in question allows the Contracting Parties to cooperate and seek common solutions in cases of international child abduction, which still happen in the 21st century. Following the accession of the Republic of Korea to this Convention, it is necessary for the Council to issue a decision authorising Member States other than Denmark not covered by union civil policy and, with the exception of the Czech Republic, Ireland and Lithuania, which have already accepted the accession of the Republic of Korea, to accept the accession of the Republic of Korea. This will allow the entry into force of the Convention between the Republic of Korea and the entire European Union.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report which allows states to cooperate in finding a solution to cases of international child abduction.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council decision authorising certain Member States, in the interests of the European Union, to accept the accession of the Republic of Korea to the 1980 Hague Convention on The Civil Matters of International Child Abduction because the Hague Convention on child abductions needs to be ratified by all States.  This resolves the hands of the authorities for cooperation both in the field of investigations worldwide and in the repatriation of the victim. One of the most important problems solved, in fact, is in the case of parents who are separated and belong to different states.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, adopted in 1980, is an international instrument of cooperation, enabling signatory states to settle cross-border cases of child custody. The Convention clarifies the applicable national law in cases when there is a conflict of competence between two or more national legal systems. The scope regards civil aspects, so it concerns mostly situations of separated parents or other persons having legal rights on the child. Given that the scope of the Convention is protecting children finding themselves in legal uncertainty, the aim is to have it ratified by as many states as possible. All EU Member States have ratified. This report aims at giving Austria and Romania the authorisation to accept the accession of Korea to the Convention, which will allow the entering into force of the Convention between Korea and the entire EU. I voted in favour of the report.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of the abduction of children establishes a system enabling cooperation between Contracting States. The biggest problem in such cases is the national nature of the legal system of states. The Convention establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of a child who has been unlawfully taken abroad. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area, as confirmed by the Court of Justice in Opinion No 1/13. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve such situations at international level by determining that the law of the State in which the child is resident applies and that the case falls within the jurisdiction of the court of that State. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own competences. The problem arises from the fact that the Convention does not provide for the independent action of international organisations, so that, following Korea's accession to the Convention, a decision of the Council is needed authorizing the two Member States which have not yet adopted korea's accession, Austria and Romania, to accept Korea's accession. This will allow the Agreement to enter into force between Korea and the European Union as a whole. In view of the above, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on civil aspects of the abduction of children establishes a system enabling cooperation between Contracting States to find solutions to the issue of the abduction of children abroad. The biggest problem in such cases is the national nature of the legal system of states. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve such situations at international level by determining that the law of the State in which the child is resident applies and that the case falls within the jurisdiction of the court of that State. The Convention also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of a child who has been unlawfully taken abroad. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area, as confirmed by the Court of Justice in Opinion No 1/13. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own competences. The problem arises from the fact that the Convention does not provide for the independent action of international organisations, so that, following Korea's accession to the Convention, a decision of the Council is needed authorizing the two Member States which have not yet adopted korea's accession, Austria and Romania, to accept Korea's accession. This will allow the Agreement to enter into force between Korea and the European Union as a whole. In view of the above, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report to take account of the Republic of Korea's accession to it. Korea's accession to the Convention is good news. The Commission, together with civil justice experts from the Member States, assessed the functioning of the judicial system of the Republic of Korea and the willingness of the Republic of Korea to implement the Convention, and considers it appropriate for the Convention between the Union and the Republic of Korea to enter into force, since an important Korean community resides in Europe, which makes it even more relevant to accept such accession.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 Today, MEPs supported South Korea's accession to the Hague Convention. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 deals with problems that arise when a relationship breaks down. Then it can often be tempting – if the mother and father come from two different countries – to use the lack of cooperation between states to obtain custody of the child.  The biggest problem in such cases is the determination of the competent court and the country where the hearing is to take place. According to the Convention, the courts and laws of the state in which the child resides are competent to deal with such disputes.  Following the accession of South Korea to the Convention, a Council decision will still be necessary authorising the Member States to agree to this accession, which I believe is most desirable.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. The Hague Convention, which has been in place since 1980, focuses on the protection of children. The established civil aspects for the prevention of child abductions and the repatriation of abducted children are part of an incontrovertible strategy to protect the well-being of children. I very much welcome the accession of as many states as possible to this convention.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to abstain on this vote because it is such an emotive issue. The right of countries acceding to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is extremely important; however, this should be done at the will of the individual country and not en masse by the EU.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. As this accession was a manifestation of the will of the States concerned, there was no reason to oppose it by an unfavourable vote. It is necessary to act to protect children and parents alike.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Korea's accession to the Hague Convention in relation to the civil aspects of international child abduction, because it entails greater protection and guarantees for children. The Hague Convention establishes a system that allows the cooperation of Contracting States to find a solution to situations of international child abduction. These cases usually occur in cases of separations with parents from different countries. The Convention regulates that the applicable legislation in such cases is that of the child's State of residence. It also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of the stolen child.

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Report on the proposal for a Council decision authorising certain Member States to give their consent, in the interest of the European Union, for the accession of the Republic of Korea to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of Child Abduction abroad, the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on civil aspects of international child abduction is a document of particular importance, since it introduces a system enabling contracting States to cooperate in the settlement of cases relating to the international abduction of a child by one of the parents or legal guardians. It is consistently problematic in such situations to determine the court competent to grant custody of a child to a parent or guardian where each parent or guardian has the nationality of another country.  The purpose of the Convention is to address this problem at international level by establishing that only the courts and laws of the State in which the child resides are competent. The Convention also introduces a system to guarantee the immediate return of the abducted child.  As the hague convention-based system will be all the more effective the more states participate and the functioning of the justice system in South Korea allows the country to accede to the Convention, I believe it is appropriate that the CONVENTION concluded between the EU and South Korea enters into force so that children are protected throughout the EU.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to support the package on the accession of the Republic of Korea to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. Once again, this is important for engagement in enhanced international cooperation with other signatories to the convention.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on civil aspects of the abduction of children establishes a system enabling cooperation between Contracting States to find solutions to the issue of the abduction of children abroad. The biggest problem in such cases is the national nature of the legal system of states. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve such situations at international level by determining that the law of the State in which the child is resident applies and that the case falls within the jurisdiction of the court of that State. The Convention also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of a child who has been unlawfully taken abroad. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area, as confirmed by the Court of Justice in Opinion No 1/13. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own competences. The problem arises from the fact that the Convention does not provide for the independent action of international organisations, so that, following Korea's accession to the Convention, a decision of the Council is needed authorizing the two Member States which have not yet adopted korea's accession, Austria and Romania, to accept Korea's accession. This will allow the Agreement to enter into force between Korea and the European Union as a whole.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the accession of the Republic of Korea to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. The European Union has set as one of its aims the promotion of the protection of the rights of the child, as stated in Article 3 of the Treaty on European Union, and by supporting Korea’s accession we encourage other nations to follow suit.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour since I have no objections.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on civil aspects of the abduction of children establishes a system enabling cooperation between Contracting States to find solutions to the issue of the abduction of children abroad. The biggest problem in such cases is the national nature of the legal system of states. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve such situations at international level by determining that the law of the State in which the child is resident applies and that the case falls within the jurisdiction of the court of that State. The Convention also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of a child who has been unlawfully taken abroad. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area, as confirmed by the Court of Justice in Opinion No 1/13. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own competences. The problem arises from the fact that the Convention does not provide for the independent action of international organisations, so that, following Korea's accession to the Convention, a decision of the Council is needed authorizing the two Member States which have not yet adopted korea's accession, Austria and Romania, to accept Korea's accession. This will allow the Agreement to enter into force between Korea and the European Union as a whole. In view of the above, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: In writing. I supported the Council's decision on Korea's accession to the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. This convention, ratified by all EU member states, provides for cooperation mechanisms to remedy jurisdictional conflicts when two jurisdictions declare themselves competent for childcare in the context of the separation of a binational couple. It is essential to preserve the interests of the child and that is why I welcome the fact that countries in Europe and the rest of the world are making commitments in which they reaffirm their desire to clarify the separation procedure so as not to be indirect accomplices to child abductions.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ This report aims at giving Member States, with the exception of Denmark to which this is not applicable, the authorisation to accept the accession of South Korea to the Convention, which will allow the entering into force of the Convention between South Korea and the entire EU. The Czech Republic, Ireland and Lithuania already accepted it.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the Proposal for a Council Decision authoring certain Member States to accept, in the interest of the European Union, the Accession of the Republic of Korea to the Hague Convention on civil-legal aspects of international child abduction in 1980, as this allows all Member States, except Denmark, the Czech Republic, Ireland and Lithuania, to accept South Korea's approach. South Korea's legal system has been found to meet certain conditions and criteria, and it is therefore desirable for the Convention to enter into force. It is essential that the problem of child abduction is addressed internationally, and that the applicable laws and competent courts are those of the child's country of residence. The more signatory states, the more effective the Convention, and therefore I support this report.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. It is necessary to strengthen cooperation between states on international child abduction in order to curb the exploitation of individuals from different states. By establishing jurisdiction over the child's state of residence, the Convention was able to resolve the issue of the return of children and give the EU exclusive external jurisdiction. Since Korea has made the sovereign choice to join, there is no reason to oppose the adoption of the text. I voted for it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – UKIP chose to abstain on this vote because it is such an emotive issue.  The right of countries acceding to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is extremely important; however, this should be done at the will of the individual country and not en bloc by the EU.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Angel Dzhambazki's report, which endorses the Council's decision on the implementation of the Hague Convention between the EU and Korea. This convention establishes a system of judicial cooperation. Widely supported in Parliament, this procedure will put the best interests of the child back at the heart of international justice decisions, particularly in cases of abduction following divorce. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on Korea's accession to the Hague Convention because it is necessary to expand the list of countries parties to this text which guarantees the return of children displaced or unlawfully detained by one of their parents in a state and aims more broadly to enforce access, custody and accommodation rights.

name: Eva KAILI
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on civil matters relating to international child abduction is a vital tool. It has been ratified by all the Member States of the European Union. This Convention establishes a system allowing Contracting States to cooperate in finding a solution to situations of international child abduction. It is therefore necessary, following South Korea's accession to the Convention, to adopt a Council Decision authorising Member States (with the exception of Denmark, which is excluded from the Union's civil justice policy, and the Czech Republic, Ireland and Lithuania, which have already accepted South Korea's accession) to accept the accession of the country. This will allow the Convention between South Korea on the one hand and the European Union as a whole to enter into force on the other.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I agree with this report. The agreement regulates cases of international child abduction by partners of different nationalities or residences and includes rules for settling custody disputes. Korea's commitment to this agreement is an important step towards strengthening the rights of children.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, as the accession will allow acceding to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction to participate in enhanced international cooperation with other signatories to the Convention.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on civil aspects of the abduction of children establishes a system enabling cooperation between Contracting States to find solutions to the issue of the abduction of children abroad. The biggest problem in such cases is the national nature of the legal system of states. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve such situations at international level by determining that the law of the State in which the child is resident applies and that the case falls within the jurisdiction of the court of that State. The Convention also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of a child who has been unlawfully taken abroad. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area, as confirmed by the Court of Justice in Opinion No 1/13. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own competences. The problem arises from the fact that the Convention does not provide for the independent action of international organisations, so that, following Korea's accession to the Convention, a decision of the Council is needed authorizing the two Member States which have not yet adopted korea's accession, Austria and Romania, to accept Korea's accession. This will allow the Agreement to enter into force between Korea and the European Union as a whole. In view of the above, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is an essential instrument, ratified by all the EU Member States in order to condemn child abuses. The Convention introduces a system of cooperation between the contracting states to settle international cases in child abduction. Following the accession of South Korea to the Convention, a Council decision is therefore necessary to authorise the Member States to accept the accession of South Korea. I voted in favour of this, to allow the Convention’s implementation between South Korea and the entire European Union.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the report on the proposal for a Council decision authorising certain Member States to accept, in the interest of the European Union, the accession of the Republic of Korea to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. The Convention introduces a system of cooperation between the Contracting States aimed at settling cases of international child abduction. In many cases, these problems arise as a result of separation between parents. If the mother and father are from different countries, there is the possibility that one of them may benefit from the lack of cooperation between these countries so as to ensure custody of the child.  I welcome South Korea's accession to the Convention. The Commission, together with experts from the Member States on civil justice, has assessed the functioning of South Korea's judicial system and the country's readiness to implement the Convention and considers it desirable to enter into force between the European Union and South Korea. I support this because the System of the Hague Convention works more effectively when more states join it. There is a significant Korean community in Europe, which increases the importance of accepting this accession.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. ‒ The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a multilateral treaty, which seeks to protect children from the harmful effects of abduction and retention across international boundaries by providing a procedure to bring about their prompt return. The treaty has been ratified by all EU Member States. In light of this, it is important to note that the EU now has exclusive external competence in this field as confirmed by the Court of Justice in Opinion 1/13, which means that Member States no longer act on their own account. However, the paradox is that the Convention does not provide for autonomous action by international organisations. In this sense, a Council decision is necessary to authorise the Member States (except Denmark, which is excluded from the Union’s civil justice policy, and Czechia, Ireland and Lithuania, which have already accepted the accession of South Korea) to accept the accession of South Korea. Therefore, I call both the EU and Member States to welcome and accept the accession of South Korea to the Convention because in this manner children’s rights will be protected and preserved.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I am voting in favour of the report on the accession of the Republic of Korea to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, as in the two previous cases of Kazakhstan and Peru, due to the need to find concrete solutions to protect minors who are children of separate spouses from different states.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it helps to deal with cases of international child abduction. Korea has chosen to apply for membership.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on Korea's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction. This convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction establishes a system of cooperation between contracting states to deal with cases of international child abduction. It has been ratified by all EU member states. In many cases, these problems arise when a couple is separated. If the mother and father are from different states, there is a temptation to exploit the lack of cooperation between states in order to ensure the custody of the child. The purpose of the convention is to resolve such situations at the international level, by establishing that the competent courts and applicable laws are those of the child's state of residence. The convention also introduces a system that ensures the immediate return of abducted children. After ratification, the convention will enter into force between Korea and the entire European Union.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction establishes a system of cooperation between contracting states to deal with international child abduction cases. It has been ratified by all EU member states. The main purpose of the Convention is to resolve child custody situations at the international level, establishing that the competent jurisdictions and applicable laws are those of the child's state of residence. The convention also introduces a system that ensures the immediate return of children who have been abducted. The EU now has exclusive external jurisdiction in this area as confirmed by the Court of Justice in its opinion 1/13. After ratification, the convention will enter into force between these three countries and the European Union as a whole. I am therefore in favour of the adoption of this text because these countries have chosen to apply for membership.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of authorization to accept the Access of the Republic of Korea to the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, which will allow the rule to enter into force in this country and all the Member States of the Union.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Korea's accession to the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, as I consider this type of coordination between States to be positive in resolving the sensitive cases of international child abduction, with the aim of moving towards respect for the rights and interests of children.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. In the interests of the Union, this draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament approves that certain Member States accept, in the interests of the Union, the accession of the Republic of Korea to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of child abduction.  This Convention is essential as it structures the cooperation of contracting States in order to find a solution to international child abduction. Thus, it resolves the case in which two different nationals divorce and try to use their own legislation in their favor. The Convention protects the child by providing that the competent courts and the applicable law shall be of the child's country of residence.  The large Korean community in the Union makes it relevant to approve Korea's accession to the Convention, as well as the fact that it will be more effective the more States adhere to it. That is why I vote in favour of the report.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour. I consider the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction to be a useful instrument for international cooperation, especially in cases of mixed marriages where one of the parents takes the child to his or her original country. This Decision authorises Member States to approve the accession of the Republic of Korea to the Convention. However, it is sad that Member States need EU approval to do so.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. The Hague Convention is an important instrument ratified by all EU Member States. The Convention introduces a system of cooperation between contracting states to deal with cases of international child abduction. In many cases, these problems arise when a couple has different nationalities, and the biggest problem in such cases is the national bias of the legal systems of individual states. The purpose of the Convention is to deal with such situations at international level, which determines the jurisdiction of the courts and the applicability of the law, and introduces a system that ensures the immediate return of children abducted. Following South Korea's accession to this Convention, Member States must accept this accession in order for the Convention to enter into force. The functioning of South Korea's justice system is ready to implement this Convention, so I supported this report.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. ‒ The Hague Convention of 1980 has been ratified by 93 countries, including all EU Member States. The Convention entered into force in the Republic of Korea on 1st March 2013. Several Member States have already accepted the accession of the Republic of Korea to the 1980 Hague Convention.  I share the goal of the proposed act to authorise certain Member States to accept, in the interest of the European Union, the accession of the Republic of Korea to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 Koreans represent an important community in Europe. The placement of their business activities on the territory of the Union also increases the possibility of forming partnership unions and the birth of children from those relationships. I support the accession of the Republic of Korea to the Convention because it will also allow more effective implementation of protection for children who are in some way linked to the Korean community.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council decision authorising certain Member States, in the interests of the European Union, to accept the accession of the Republic of Korea to the 1980 Hague Convention on Civil Matters of International Child Abduction, because it is complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted for this text. It concerns Korea's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction. This text allows for cooperation between the contracting states and determines the competent jurisdiction when it is necessary to determine custody of the children, in the event of separation of a couple whose parents do not have the same nationality. This text has been put in place and ratified by all Member States, in order to prevent two courts, from two different countries, from declaring themselves competent. The rule is simplified: the applicable laws are those of the child's state of residence. In addition, it establishes the immediate return of the abducted children. Finally, this country has chosen to apply for membership, which we agree with.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council Decision on the accession of the Republic of Korea to the 1980 Hague Convention on The Civil Matters of International Child Abduction, because this Convention is a vital tool since it enables The Contracting States to cooperate in finding a solution to international child abduction. It is therefore necessary, I consider, after South Korea's accession to the Convention, to adopt a Council decision authorising the Member States to accept the country's accession, since this will allow the Convention between South Korea and the EU as a whole to enter into force. Moreover, the presence of the Korean community in Europe is strong, which makes this all the more important.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. States Parties agree to implement a system of cooperation in the event of child abduction by separate partners of different nationalities. The place of jurisdiction for this shall be the state of residence of the child. Furthermore, as the resolution of the child's return to the appropriate parent is to be speeded up, thereby reducing the burden on the child in international custody disputes, I agree with this request.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. The accession of South Korea to the Convention is to be welcomed. The Commission, together with experts in the field of civil justice in the Member States, assessed the functioning of south Korea's justice system and its willingness to implement the Convention and considers it desirable for the Convention to enter into force between the European Union and South Korea. I agree with the provisions set out in this report because I believe that the Hague Convention system will be more effective and that cases involving international child abduction will be easier to deal with if more countries accede to the Convention.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. I welcome South Korea's accession to the International Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. In particular, the signatory states undertake that the court responsible for the right of custody and access be that of the child's state of residence. The aim here is to allow certain EU Member States to recognise Korea's accession to the Convention. A surreal vote on the decision of sovereign member states to recognise a third country's accession to an international convention. What for? Because, under the 1/13 opinion of the Court of Justice, the Commission now has exclusive jurisdiction over the application of this decision in civil matters on "its" territory. The decision does not apply to some Member States: Denmark, which has an exemption clause on the EU's civil justice policy, and the Czech Republic, Ireland and Lithuania, which have already recognised Korea's decision before it became an exclusive EU jurisdiction. I challenge this limitation of sovereignty I nevertheless vote for this recognition of adherence to the convention for the benefit of the protection of children across borders.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction establishes a system of cooperation between contracting states to deal with international child abduction cases. It has been ratified by all EU member states. The main purpose of the Convention is to resolve child custody situations at the international level, establishing that the competent jurisdictions and applicable laws are those of the child's state of residence. The convention also introduces a system that ensures the immediate return of children who have been abducted. The EU now has exclusive external jurisdiction in this area as confirmed by the Court of Justice in its opinion 1/13. After ratification, the convention will enter into force between these three countries and the European Union as a whole. I am therefore in favour of the adoption of this text because these countries have chosen to apply for membership.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 The objective of the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction (hereinafter referred to as the '1980 Convention'), until now ratified by 93 countries, including all EU Member States, is to restore the status quo by the immediate return of children unlawfully transferred or retained through a system of cooperation between the central authorities designated by the Contracting Parties. The aim of this Decision is to ensure that the 1980 Convention enter into force between the Republic of Korea and the Member States of the European Union. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of accepting Korea’s accession to the Hague Convention as it furthers the protection that the Union can provide to children.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. Globalization offers unparalleled opportunities, but it also requires ethical social, economic and political responsibility. Every child has the right to have regular personal relations with both parents. Parental abduction is tantamount to denying this right and places the child, deprived of one of his parents, his extended family, his mother tongue, and one of his cultures, in a state of stress and insecurity. The after-effects of a kidnapping are immeasurable. That is why I urge the Member States which have not yet done so to recognise the accession of the Republic of Korea to the Hague Convention. Child abductions are rightly experienced as tragedies, not only by the child himself who is experiencing a real emotional upheaval, but also by the parent who is the victim of this abduction, constantly anxious to know his child is deprived of his affection and protection. The EU's response must live up to this unacceptable human tragedy, this nameless distress.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report, which aims at giving Member States (except Denmark to which this is not applicable; and the Czech Republic, Ireland and Lithuanian which have already accepted it), the authorisation to accept the accession of South Korea to the Convention, which will allow the entering into force of the Convention between South Korea and the entire EU. The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, adopted in 1980, is an international instrument of cooperation, enabling signatory states to settle cross border cases regarding child custody and abduction. The Convention clarifies the applicable national law in cases when there is a conflict of competence between two or more national legal systems. The scope regards civil aspects, so it concerns mostly situations of separated parents or other persons having legal rights on the child. Given that the scope of the Convention is protecting children finding themselves in legal uncertainty, the aim is to have it ratified by as many states as possible. All EU Member States have ratified.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of the abduction of children establishes a system enabling cooperation between Contracting States to find a solution to the abduction of children and to ensure the immediate return of the child who has been abducted abroad. The Convention has been ratified by all the Member States of the European Union. The Republic of Korea has announced its intention to join the Convention. Since the Convention does not provide for the independent action of international organisations, the European Union cannot ratify such an addition to the Treaty.  However, since the Opinion of the European Court of Justice of 14 October 2014 states that the EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area, the Member States (with the exception of the Czech Republic, Ireland and Lithuania, which has already ratified the supplement, and Denmark, which has not yet ratified the supplement) can only do so with the authorisation of the European Council. The Council therefore intends to take a decision which would give the Member States the power to ratify the accession of South Korea, but it must consult Parliament to do so. In its report, the Committee on Legal Affairs proposes that Parliament approve the Council's proposal for a decision. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction establishes a system of cooperation between contracting states to resolve these cases. It has been ratified by all EU member states. Its aim is to resolve such situations at the international level, by establishing that the competent courts and applicable laws are those of the child's state of residence. The convention also introduces a system that ensures the immediate return of children who have been abducted. The EU now has exclusive external jurisdiction in this area. As a result, Member States are no longer acting on their own behalf. After ratification, the Convention will enter into force between Korea and the entire European Union. We are in favour of the adoption of these texts because these countries have chosen to apply for membership.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction of 25 October 1980 is an instrument of vital importance and has been ratified by all EU Member States. This Convention establishes a system of cooperation between Contracting States with the aim of finding a solution to cases of international child abduction. With South Korea's accession to the Convention, a Council decision is needed to authorise the Member States to accept this accession (with the exception of Denmark, excluded from the scope of the Union's civil justice policy, and the Czech Republic, Ireland and Lithuania, which have already accepted the accession of South Korea). In this way, the Convention will enter into force between the Republic of Korea and the entire European Union. I support the adoption of this proposal in order to ensure the protection of the minors concerned throughout the territory of the European Union.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The EU now has exclusive external jurisdiction in this area as confirmed by the Court of Justice in its opinion 1/13. As a result, Member States are no longer acting on their own behalf. The problem is that the convention does not provide for autonomous action by international organizations. After ratification, the convention will enter into force between these three countries and the European Union as a whole. I am in favour of the adoption of these texts because these countries have chosen to apply for membership.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on Korea's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. In order to avoid conflicts of laws or jurisdictions as far as possible when it comes to resolving a dispute involving an international situation, international conventions must be signed and ratified by the highest possible number of states.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which endorses a Council decision on Korea's accession to the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction. This convention, ratified by all members of the Union, provides for cooperation mechanisms to remedy jurisdictional conflicts when two jurisdictions declare themselves competent for childcare in the context of the separation of a binational couple.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction is an instrument of fundamental importance which has been ratified by all the Member States of the European Union by introducing a system allowing contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution to cases of international child abduction. It is often the case that the courts of both states involved declare themselves competent and that each of them entrusts the child to the parent who is a national of the State in which the court is located. The convention aims to resolve these situations at international level. I therefore voted in favour of the Republic of Korea's accession to the Convention, thus allowing children linked to the Korean community to benefit from protection throughout the European Union.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. Korea is no exception to the increasing disintegration of marriages. As in all countries, we must take into account the possibility of delaying court rulings on the placement of children. I believe that accession to the Hague Convention is also a step in deepening relations between the European Union and South Korea. It is true that the report is more of a technical one, yet it can be seen as a symbol of a thriving cooperation.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ The Hague Convention has as primary objective the international abduction of children due to the separation of the parents who have different citizenship from each other. I have voted for this report that will grant the accession of the Republic of Korea to the Convention in order to ensure the EU’s protection to the children in that specific part.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report because it resolves custody disputes. This provision is particularly advantageous in custody disputes where parents prove different nationalities.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The Convention is crucial to ensure that international child abduction cases are resolved as quickly and effectively as possible. The Council Decision allows Member States to give their consent to the accession of Korea so that the Convention can enter into force between the EU and Korea.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 Prevention of child abduction is an essential part of EU policy to promote children's rights. The European Union is therefore active at international level to improve the implementation of the 1980 Convention and urges third countries to join it. The Commission, together with member states' civil justice experts, has assessed the functioning of South Korea's justice system and the country's willingness to implement the Convention, and considers it desirable to bring the Convention between the European Union and South Korea into force. I therefore voted in favour of the report on Korea's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention because this makes the Hague Convention system more effective with the accession of more countries. The presence of the Korean community in Europe is strong, which makes acceptance of this accession all the more important.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP chose to abstain on this vote because it is such an emotive issue.  The right of countries acceding to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is extremely important; however, this should be done at the will of the individual country and not en bloc by the EU.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that the purpose of the Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction is to create a system of cooperation between the central authorities appointed by each Contracting State in such a way as to allow the immediate return of children who have been unlawfully transferred or detained. Given that the European Union has set the promotion of the protection of the rights of the child as one of its objectives and has always been active at international level for the protection of the child. I therefore feel that, in order to pursue these primary objectives, I must welcome the accession of the Republic of Korea. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ Respecting the rights of children as one of the fundamental issues of EU policy and wanting us to remain consistent in implementing our decisions, I supported this proposal for a Council decision authorisation of certain Member States to accept, in the interest of the European Union, the Republic of Korea's approach to the Hague Convention on civil legal aspects of international child abduction in 1980. As child abduction prevention is an important part of the EU's policy to promote the rights of the child, the Hague Convention on civil-legal aspects of international child abduction has been adopted to this end since 25 October 1980. At international level, the European Union is actively working to improve its application and encourages third countries to approach it. Therefore, in 2011 the Commission adopted eight proposals for Council decisions with a view to accepting the eight countries' access to this Hague Convention. Korea only passed the instrument of access to the Convention in 2012. In 2014, the Court of Justice of the European Union stated that the acceptance of a third State's access to the Convention falls within the exclusive competence of the European Union. Following this decision, in 2015 the Council of the European Union adopted seven decisions based on the 2011 proposals. This proposal takes into account a third country (Korea) that joined the Convention before the EU's external competence was established, and I therefore welcome the decision taken.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction establishes a system of cooperation between contracting states to deal with international child abduction cases. It has been ratified by all EU member states. In many cases, these problems arise when a couple is separated. If the mother and father are from different states, there is a temptation to exploit the lack of cooperation between states in order to ensure the custody of the child. It is common for courts in the two states concerned to declare jurisdiction, with each of them granting custody of the child to the parent who is a national of their state. The purpose of the convention is to resolve such situations at the international level, by establishing that the competent courts and applicable laws are those of the child's state of residence. The convention also introduces a system that ensures the immediate return of children who have been abducted. I am in favour of the adoption of these texts because Korea has chosen to apply for membership. So I'm voting for the text.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒In the case of South Korea's accession to the Convention, a Council decision is required to allow Member States (except Denmark, to which Union civil law does not apply, and the Czech Republic, Ireland and Lithuania, which have already accepted South Korea's approach) to accept Access by South Korea. This will allow the Convention between South Korea and the entire European Union to enter into force. The Commission and civil law experts from the Member States have assessed that South Korea is ready to implement the Convention. I support this report as the objective of such a Convention is to be ratified by as many countries as possible, as this is becoming more effective.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. \u2012 This Convention establishes a system of cooperation between contracting States aimed at finding a solution to cases of international child abduction, seeking to ensure the immediate return of children unlawfully transferred to or wrongly held therein. The child abduction situation occurs very often when a couple of people secede, and when the parents come from different states. The Convention thus aims to enforce effectively the custody and visitation rights existing in a Contracting State and mitigate responses of nationalist tendency of the legal systems of each State. It is common for the courts of their respective countries to declare both competent and that the courts grant custody of the minor to the national parent of the state they represent, decisions based on motivations which do not necessarily respond to the best interests of the child. The Purpose of the Convention is to resolve such situations at international level by establishing that cases are tried by the competent courts and in accordance with the applicable legislation of the child's state of residence. The Republic of Korea has deposited the instrument of adhering and we have spoken in favour, as this Agreement is best to respond to the defence of the best interests of minors.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Abductions is essential and has already been ratified by all European Union countries. I am therefore very glad that South Korea has also decided to take this step, significantly expanding the possibility of cooperation on child abduction. According to experts and the Commission, the Republic of Korea is willing and able to implement this Convention from the point of view of its judicial system. The purpose of the Hague Convention is to protect children from abductions, which occur in particular in cases where divorce between their parents originating in different States occurs. If one of the parents decides to abduct the child to his or her home state and that state is not part of the cooperation in dealing with international child abductions, he can so easily get custody of the child. The courts in the non-cooperating State usually place the child in the care of the parent who is a national of that State. However, where a State is part of the Hague Convention, this situation may be resolved at international level and the courts and legislation of the State in which the child resides will be determined as final. Ratification by some of the remaining EU Member States is the final step towards the entry into force of this Convention between South Korea and the European Union.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction has introduced a system that allows contracting states to cooperate to find a solution in cases of international child abduction. The main problem in these circumstances is the tendency of the legal systems of individual States to practise favouritism on the basis of nationality. The aim of the Convention is to resolve these situations at international level by establishing that the competent courts and applicable laws are those of the child's state of residence. I believe it is important to ensure that the children concerned benefit from adequate regulatory protection inside and outside the EU. This report authorises the Member States (with the exception of Denmark, which does not participate in the Union's civil justice policies, and the Czech Republic, Ireland and Lithuania, which have already accepted the accession of the Republic of Korea) to accept the accession of the Republic of Korea to the 1980 Hague Convention. This will allow the Convention to take effect in relations between the Republic of Korea and the whole of the European Union. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this technical report, which endorses a Council decision on South Korea's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on civil aspects of international child abduction.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 I support this report on the republic of Korea's acceding to the Hague Convention, as the system of that Convention becomes more effective if more countries accede to it. In divorce situations where parents come from different States, there is a temptation to take advantage of the lack of international cooperation to obtain custody of minors. Custody is often granted to the parent who is a national of the State in which the courts are based, there are therefore nationalist tendencies in the legal systems of each State. By establishing that cases are tried by the competent courts and in accordance with the applicable legislation of the minor's State of residence, the Convention permits cooperation between parties, as well as tends to settle such disputes on an international scale. It should be noted that the Commission, together with experts in the field of social justice, has assessed and approved the functioning of the judicial system of the Republic of Korea and its readiness for cooperation. For all this, I'm voting in favor.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP chose to abstain on this vote because it is such an emotive issue.  The right of countries acceding to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is extremely important; however, this should be done at the will of the individual country and not en bloc by the EU.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. I voted in favour, as the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a vitally important instrument that has been ratified by all EU Member States and establishes a system of cooperation between Contracting States aimed at finding a solution to international child abduction cases. In the case of children in which the parents are divorced, each from a different State, it is common for the courts of the two countries concerned to declare themselves competent and that the courts grant custody of the minor to the national parent of the State they represent. There are very frequent cases of international child abductions reported by the press that occur following separations and divorces. The Convention aims to remedy such situations on an international scale by establishing that cases are tried by the competent courts and in accordance with the applicable legislation of the minor's State of residence. It also establishes a system that ensures the immediate return of abducted minors. It is therefore important to praise the republic of Korea's acceding to the Convention, as the system of the Hague Convention becomes more effective if more countries accede to it.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. A very large majority of MEPs this lunchtime approved the recognition of South Korea's accession to the Hague Convention on International Child Abduction, of which all EU Member States are involved. This convention is under eu's jurisdiction and it is in this capacity that Parliament has been referred for consultation. The 1980 Convention, which now has 94 signatory countries, establishes a system of cooperation to find solutions in the event of international child abduction. This situation occurs most of the time when a couple separates. If one of the spouses is from another country, sometimes the courts of the two countries concerned declare themselves competent but come to contrary conclusions, particularly with regard to the custody of the child. The convention aims to remedy such situations: it establishes the jurisdictions and law of the state where the child resides as competent, and organizes his immediate return. This accession is therefore very good news for international cooperation and the safety of the child. It will be all the more effective as the number of countries to join will be large.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 Following South Korea's accession to the Hague Convention, a Council decision authorising the two Member States (Austria and Romania) which have not yet accepted accession to do so is necessary. This will allow the Convention to enter into force between Korea and the entire European Union.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. The 1980 Hague Convention on Civil Aspects of Child Abduction, signed by all Member States of the Union, is an instrument of international cooperation that authorizes signatory States to resolve transnational cases relating to the custody and abduction of minors, clarifying the national law applicable in cases where there is a conflict of jurisdiction between two or more national legal systems. The scope of the rule reaches civil aspects, applying mainly to cases of separate parents or other persons who have legal rights over the child. Since the objective of the Convention is to protect minors in a situation of legal uncertainty, it is important to ensure that it is signed by as many States as possible.  Since the Union has exclusive external competence in this area, but the Convention does not authorise the participation of international actors, the Union needs to give all its Member States express authorisation to accept the participation of any new State in the Convention. That is why I voted in favour of authorizing Member States to accept Korea's access to the Convention.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of Korea's accession to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. International cooperation in this area is fundamental and is aimed primarily at safeguarding the interests of the child. Each new accession to this Convention is therefore a step forward with regard to the general objective of protecting the rights of the child which is enshrined in Article 3 of the Treaty on European Union (EU).

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which empowers certain Member States in the interest of the European Union to approve the accession of the Republic of Korea to the 1980 the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. Following the accession of South Korea to the Convention, this Decision is necessary in order for Member States to be empowered to accept the accession of South Korea. This will allow the Convention to enter into force between South Korea and the European Union as a whole.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 Like the reports on Kazakhstan and Peru on the same Convention, I also supported the proposal for a Council Decision in this vote authorising certain Member States to accept, in the interests of the European Union (EU), and for it to enter into force throughout the EU, the adoption of the Republic of Korea to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. This is a markedly administrative procedure, in so far as it involves a Council decision to allow Member States to accept the convention's membership of the Convention, so that it can be applied fully and effectively throughout the territory of the European Union, ensuring stronger protection for minors who, unfortunately, are increasingly the target of abductions at international level.  South Korea's annexing of the Convention is of even greater importance given the Korean community residing in Europe, which may be covered by the rules enshrined therein, which is why I considered it logical, appropriate and relevant to vote on its adoption, as mentioned above.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this technical text, which deals with the Council's decision authorising certain Member States to accept, in the interests of the European Union, the accession of the Republic of Korea to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of international child abduction. The European Union has jurisdiction over this; and for that a council decision is necessary.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Korea's accession to the Hague Convention in relation to the civil aspects of international child abduction, because it entails greater protection and guarantees for children. The Hague Convention establishes a system that allows the cooperation of Contracting States to find a solution to situations of international child abduction. These cases usually occur in cases of separations with parents from different countries. The Convention regulates that the applicable legislation in such cases is that of the child's State of residence. It also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of the stolen child.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Korea's accession to the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, as I consider this type of coordination between States to be positive in resolving the sensitive cases of international child abduction, with the aim of moving towards respect for the rights and interests of children.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Today, I voted for the Package on the accession of the Republic of Korea to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. This is important for engagement in enhanced international cooperation with other signatories to the convention.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction is an extremely important instrument. It has been ratified by all EU Member States. This Convention establishes a system enabling States Parties to cooperate in finding a solution in cases of international child abduction. Following the accession of the Republic of Korea to this Convention, it was necessary for the Council to issue a decision authorising the Member States (with the exception of Denmark, which are not covered by Union civil policy and with the exception of the Czech Republic, Ireland and Lithuania, which have already accepted the accession of the Republic of Korea) to accept the accession of the Republic of Korea. This will allow the entry into force of the Convention between the Republic of Korea and the entire European Union. I fully support this Council decision, which the Council has already issued. The system established by the Hague Convention will be more effective if more countries join it. There is a significant Korean community living in Europe, which increases the grounds for approving accession.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I agreed to the accession of the Republic of Korea to the Hague Convention as it is an important international convention protecting the rights of the child. The Convention has been ratified by all EU Member States and today the EU has exclusive external competence in this area, as the Court of Justice has ruled. It is therefore necessary for the Council to issue a decision authorising the Member States to adopt accession. This will allow the entry into force of the Convention between the Republic of Korea and the Union as a whole. EU countries will be able to use the system of cooperation with Korea to find solutions in cases of international child abduction. Such cases often occur when parents from different countries divorce. Parents may seek custody of that child when there is no cooperation between states by abducting the child. Individual countries have a strong national character in this matter of their legal systems. Therefore, there are regular situations where the courts of both States concerned are declared competent and that each of them grants custody to the parent. This is to be preceded by this convention, which requires that the competent court and the law of the State in which the child resides be determined at international level. I am glad that the Republic of Korea has also acceded to the Convention and its judicial system is willing to implement this convention also because there is a significant Korean community living in Europe.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention deals with cases where a child is abducted by one of the parents to another state in the hope that the legislation there will give him a better position in the custody dispute. Extending the scope of the Hague Convention narrows the possibilities for such action and increases the international legal protection of children.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil-legal aspects of international child abduction is a key instrument ratified by all EU Member States. The Convention establishes a system of cooperation between Contracting States to deal with cases of international child abductions that often occur when the child's parents are separated. The most common problem is the bias of individual national legal systems and the jurisdiction of courts in both countries. Following South Korea's accession to the Convention, a Council decision is necessary to allow Member States to accept South Korea's access so that the Convention enters into force between South Korea and the entire European Union. In the context of this report, it is important to stress that there is a large community of Koreans in the European Union.  For this reason, I support the draft report of the Committee on Legal Affairs on the proposal for a Council decision authorisation of certain Member States to accept, in the interest of the European Union, the Republic of Korea's approach to the Hague Convention on civil-legal aspects of international child abduction in 1980.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The 1980 Hague Convention on Civil Matters of International Child Abduction is a vital tool and establishes a system that enables States Parties to cooperate in finding a solution to situations of international child abduction. The convention system is made more effective by the accession of several countries. That is why we voted in favour of the report.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention on child abductions needs to be ratified by all states. This resolves the hands of the authorities for cooperation both in the field of investigations worldwide and in the repatriation of the victim.  One of the most important problems solved, in fact, is in the case of parents who are separated and belong to different states.

name: József SZÁJER
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on civil aspects of the abduction of children establishes a system enabling cooperation between Contracting States to find solutions to the issue of the abduction of children abroad. The biggest problem in such cases is the national nature of the legal system of states. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve such situations at international level by determining that the law of the State in which the child is resident applies and that the case falls within the jurisdiction of the court of that State. The Convention also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of a child who has been unlawfully taken abroad. The EU currently has exclusive external competence in this area, as confirmed by the Court of Justice in Opinion No 1/13. Member States can therefore no longer act on their own competences. The problem arises from the fact that the Convention does not provide for the independent action of international organisations, so that, following Korea's accession to the Convention, a decision of the Council is needed authorizing the two Member States which have not yet adopted korea's accession, Austria and Romania, to accept Korea's accession. This will allow the Agreement to enter into force between Korea and the European Union as a whole. In view of the above, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of parliament's approval of the proposal because I am convinced that this will also strengthen the international protection of children who have been illegally taken abroad. I am aware that the relevant Hague Convention has proved to be one of the most extensive and successful international instruments in practice over the last three decades, often and actively used by States Parties as a legal basis for establishing jurisdiction and conducting proceedings against children in difficult and contentious situations after their parents' divorce. The EU currently has exclusive external competence to act on such matters, but in the case of newer States acceding to the Convention, member states' ratification and the Council's corresponding decision are necessary for the entry into force, where appropriate between Korea and the EU. In view of the fact that the Functioning of the Hague Convention is more effective, the more states are parties to the regime, I also welcome the accession of the Koreans.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The adoption of the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction in 1980 was a very important moment at international level. The Convention has been ratified by all EU Member States, establishing cooperation between signatory States in this area. In order to implement the Convention, in relation to third countries, the European Council needs the authorisation of the Member States throughout the EU. This is also the case for the accession of South Korea, an important Asian partner with whom the Member States have very good relations.  Currently, the Council must authorise the majority of Member States, with the exception of the Czech Republic, Ireland and Lithuania, which have already accepted the accession of South Korea, and Denmark, which is excluded from the Union's civil justice policy, to accept this accession, which will allow the entry into force of the Convention between the South Korean State and the EU. This is an important step in favour of EU citizens of Korean origin, which is why I support the adoption of this report.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. This convention establishes a system for contracting states to cooperate in finding a solution in cases of international child abduction. This often occurs when a couple separates. For a husband or wife from another country, it may be tempting to take advantage of the lack of cooperation between states to obtain custody of the children. There is frequent press coverage of international child abductions that occur during separation or divorce. The major problem is the nationalist conception that underlies the legal system of states. Often the courts of the two states concerned declare themselves competent and each of them entrusts custody of the child to that of the parents who have the nationality of the state in which it sits. The purpose of the convention in question is to remedy this kind of situation at the international level by establishing the jurisdiction of the courts and the law of the state in which the child resides. It also sets up a system to ensure the immediate return of the abducted child.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ The Hague Convention (1980) on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a vitally important instrument, ratified by all EU Member States. The Convention created a cooperative system between the signatory states in the goal of resolving cases of international child abduction. Most often, reports of child abduction are the result of a couple separating, where the mother and father are from different states. States often are unwilling or unable to cooperate with one another during instances of child abduction as a result of national bias of differing legal systems. Parents frequently exploit these legal and judicial disparities in order to secure full custody of the child in a particular state.
