I voted in favour of the accession of Korea so that child abduction at the international level can be resolved through the competent courts of the state of residence of the child.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒I voted for South Korea's access to the Hague Convention on Civil-Legal Aspects, as the European Union has exclusive external competence in this area and Member States can no longer act alone. By accepting the approach, the Convention will enter into force between South Korea and all Member States of the European Union. The problem of international child abduction occurs mostly in cases where parents are separated or divorced and have citizenship in two different countries. If a parent takes a child to their country in such a situation, national courts in both countries shall declare them competent and take biased decisions.  By joining this Convention, States accept the decision that the court of the state in which the child resides has jurisdiction and that the immediate return of the abducted children is guaranteed. As there is a large community of Koreans in the European Union, this accession of South Korea will also be of great benefit to the Member States of the European Union and South Korea.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. \ u2012 Proposal for a Council Decision authorising certain Member States to adopt, in the interest of the European Union, the accession of the Republic of Korea to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of international child abuse, I supported. Often problems arise when a couple is a separation. If the parents are from different countries, the risk of either of them attempting to take advantage of this Convention is to resolve such cases at international level by determining the courts and the applicable law for the courts and the law applicable to the courts and the law of the country in which the child is domiciled. The Convention also provides for a system for ensuring the immediate return of an immediately confiscated child.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Korea's accession to the Hague Convention in relation to the civil aspects of international child abduction, because it entails greater protection and guarantees for children. The Hague Convention establishes a system that allows the cooperation of Contracting States to find a solution to situations of international child abduction. These cases usually occur in cases of separations with parents from different countries. The Convention regulates that the applicable legislation in such cases is that of the child's State of residence. It also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of the stolen child.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I support this proposal, which prioritises the welfare of the child in case of legal conflict (separation or divorce) between parents from different countries. This agreement will save time, money and suffering for the affected families and guarantees the protection of children in the entire territory of the Union.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the civil aspects of international child abduction establishes a system of cooperation between contracting states to deal with international child abduction cases. It has been ratified by all EU member states. In many cases, these problems arise when a couple is separated. If the mother and father are from different states, there is a temptation to exploit the lack of cooperation between states in order to ensure the custody of the child. It is common for courts in the two states concerned to declare jurisdiction, with each of them granting custody of the child to the parent who is a national of their state. The purpose of the convention is to resolve such situations at the international level, by establishing that the competent courts and applicable laws are those of the child's state of residence. The convention also introduces a system that ensures the immediate return of children who have been abducted. I am voting for the adoption of this text because this country has chosen to apply for membership.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is an instrument of particular importance. Firstly, it avoids prolonged uncertainty as to the legal status of the child. It is accompanied by a situation in which the child's parents are nationals of two different Member States and a dispute arises as to which of them to be cared for and which court should rule on it. It is undoubtedly in the interests of the best interests of the child to resolve these issues as soon as possible and to guarantee his or her immediate and safe return. Following the accession of South Korea to the Convention, a Council Decision authorising The Member States to give their consent to that accession is necessary. This will allow the agreement between South Korea and the European Union as a whole to enter into force. The Hague Convention has already been ratified by all Member States of the European Union and dozens of other countries. The accession of another country deserves approval and support, which is why I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on civil aspects of the abduction of children established a system allowing cooperation between Contracting States in finding a solution to the issue of the abduction of children abroad. The purpose of the convention in question is to resolve such situations at international level by determining that the law of the State in which the child is resident applies and that the case falls within the jurisdiction of the court of that State. Following South Korea's accession to the Convention, a Council decision is needed authorizing the Member States (with the exception of Denmark, which is excluded from the Union's civil justice policy, and the Czech Republic, Ireland and Lithuania, which have already accepted the accession of South Korea) to accept the accession of South Korea. This will allow the Agreement to enter into force between South Korea and the European Union as a whole. Following S&D's position, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Traian UNGUREANU
text: in writing. \u2012 The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction aims to deal with cases of international child abduction. In 2014, at the request of the European Commission, the Court of Justice of the European Union was consulted on the competence of the Union to accept the accession of a third State to the 1980 Convention. The opinion delivered by the Court in October 2014 confirmed the existence of the Exclusive Competence of the Union as regards the acceptance of the accession of a third State to the 1980 Convention. In December 2012, the Republic of Korea deposited its instrument of accession to the 1980 Convention, but following that State's accession to the Convention, a Council decision authorising Member States, with the exception of those which have already accepted accession, is necessary to accept accession from the Union's civil justice policy. This will allow the effective entry into force of the Convention between the Republic of Korea and the entire European Union. The report of the European Parliament supports the accession of that State to the Convention and proposes approval without amendment so that the children concerned are guaranteed the protection granted throughout the Union.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Korea's accession to the Hague Convention in relation to the civil aspects of international child abduction, because it entails greater protection and guarantees for children. The Hague Convention establishes a system that allows the cooperation of Contracting States to find a solution to situations of international child abduction. These cases usually occur in cases of separations with parents from different countries. The Convention regulates that the applicable legislation in such cases is that of the child's State of residence. It also establishes a system to ensure the immediate return of the stolen child.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – I appreciate the planners because the Convention provides for a system to ensure that the abducted child is returned immediately.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council decision authorising certain Member States to accept, in the interest of the European Union, the accession of the Republic of Korea to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a vitally important instrument that has been ratified by all EU Member States. The Convention introduces a system of cooperation between the contracting states aimed at settling cases of international child abduction. In many instances, these problems arise when a couple has separated. If the mother and father are from different states, there is a temptation to exploit the lack of cooperation between those states in order to secure custody of the child. The biggest problem in such cases is the national bias of the legal systems of individual states. The purpose of the Convention is to resolve such situations at an international level, by establishing that the competent courts and applicable laws are those of the state of residence of the child. I believe that the accession of Korea is to be welcomed, especially as there is a significant Korean community in Europe.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. The Hague Convention of 25 October 1980 on civil aspects of international child abduction, ratified by all Member States of the Union, is an instrument of crucial importance, since the system it establishes allows the cooperation of Contracting States to find a solution to such international conflicts. Since the main problem in these cases is the bias of the legal systems of States in favour of their own nationals, the objective of the Convention is to resolve these situations at the international level, as well as to establish a system to ensure the immediate return of the stolen child. Following the accession of the Republic of Korea to the Convention, a Council decision is necessary for it to enter into force and to ensure that children in the Convention are protected against illegal abduction. I therefore considered it appropriate to vote in favour of this text.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Korea's accession to the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, as I consider this type of coordination between States to be positive in resolving the sensitive cases of international child abduction, with the aim of moving towards respect for the rights and interests of children.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'U2012 The accession of the Republic of Korea to the Hague Convention brings legal certainty to children from an international mixed family, one of whom is Korean, when the parents divorce.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This is a proposal for a Council decision on the authorisation of the Republic of Korea (South) to be granted, there is another, as we all know, to the Hague Convention on Civil Aspects relating to the International Abduction of Children. This Convention focuses on international cooperation, for example in a divorce case where a parent of different nationalities flees with her child to another country. The Convention aims to resolve such situations on an international scale by establishing that cases are tried by the competent courts and in accordance with the applicable legislation of the minor's State of residence. The Convention also establishes a system ensuring the immediate return of abducted minors. It is recommended in this case that the Republic of South Korea should be taken to the other Member States, as Ireland, the Czech Republic and Lithuania have already endorsed that accession. Denmark is excluded from this cooperation. Support.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The Convention includes a system of cooperation between States Parties to resolve cases of international child abduction by separate partners of different nationalities. This is done by determining that jurisdiction rests with the courts of the child's country of residence and that the law of the child is applicable. The Convention also introduces a system to ensure that children who have been abducted are returned immediately. In view of the increasing number of problematic cases of international custody disputes, I believe that this Agreement is useful and have therefore agreed.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ As a children’s rights champion, I welcome the accession of Korea to this important Convention. This will allow it to cooperate with other State Parties to the Convention, including EU Member States, on tackling and combating child abduction.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 In recent years, we have increasingly seen cases of international child abduction, as it is common for mother and father to often come from different countries. In the event of disagreements, they then try to obtain their offspring by taking him to their State of origin, as they rely on the states not cooperating and will therefore find it more difficult to get the child back. I therefore believe that there should be a single system of cooperation between states aimed at finding solutions in the case of international child abductions. At present, there may still be cases where the courts of both countries finally entrust the child to the custody of the parent who is a national of that state. The Hague Convention, ratified by all EU states, addresses these situations and also introduces a system for the immediate return of a abducted child to his or her homeland. I therefore welcome the accession of the Republic of Korea to the Hague Convention and I am sure that this will help to better protect children in the event of their abduction outside the country.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The 1980 Hague Convention on International Child Abduction is an extremely important tool for addressing the civil aspects of international child abduction. International child abduction is a huge negative impact on the life of the whole family and, in particular, on the psyche of the child. The objective of this Convention is therefore to restore the status quo by immediately returning the wrongfully transferred child to his or her country of habitual residence, through a system of cooperation between the central authorities designated by the Contracting Parties. The Convention has so far been ratified by 93 states, including all Member States of the European Union. In view of the objective of the Convention, it is therefore very important that as many countries as possible accede to it, thereby reducing as far as possible situations where a child is abducted abroad, but unfortunately there is no legal instrument to help return the child, as the country to which he or she was abducted has not ratified this convention. For these reasons, I therefore welcomed Korea's decision to accede to the Convention, and I supported the report on the adoption of this accession by the European Union.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \ I supported the proposal for a Council decision authorising certain Member States to adopt, in the interest of the European Union, the accession of the Republic of Korea to the 1980 Hague Convention on the civil aspects of international child abuse. The 1980 Hague Convention provides for a system enabling States Parties to cooperate in finding solutions to cases of international wrongful confiscation of children, which often arise in the event of separation. The Convention lays down international jurisdiction and conflict-of-law rules for the settlement of such disputes and a system for ensuring the immediate return of an immediately deprived child. Following the accession of South Korea to the Convention, the Council should by decision authorise the Member States to adopt south Korea's accession. This will give the Convention into force between South Korea and the entire European Union.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European I was very pleased to see the term food sovereign determination in the report on food and food safety in the world. We have known for a long time that the solution to hunger is food self-determination, which means that every nation, every community, has the right to control and use its own land, which is why land theft is forbidden by foreigners or even by domestic oligarchs. Part of food agency is that every nation, every community, is entitled to its own food. That is why I must say that this objective, which is rightly indicated in this report, is completely contrary to what the European Union is doing on the other hand, for example, the free trade agreement with either Canada or the United States, which brings food from remote areas to Europe in exactly the opposite way.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – Mr President, we are talking about food security in the world. Aristophan told us that "hunger does not recognize a friend other than the one who feeds it." Let us stop feeding hunger and ask the Commission to increase investment in regions where people have nothing to eat. The UN Humanitarian Aid Agency tells us that more than 800 million people in the world do not have enough food to be healthy. In other words, I'm starving sooner or later. More than 200 million children suffer in their development also because of malnutrition and the fact that they have nothing to eat. Let's tell the truth about all these people: they're starving.  Eradicating hunger and malnutrition by 2030, as we propose, can only be done by investing in these regions to create jobs, investments in agriculture or in those areas, in those professions in which they are good or their families.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I supported this proposal, sharing the rapporteur’s belief that policy coherence, with the focus on sustainable agriculture, is central to ending hunger by 2030. Eradicating poverty and hunger are integrally linked to boosting food production, agricultural productivity and rural incomes. From an Irish perspective, I can appreciate the emphasis placed on local food production and share the believe that agricultural systems worldwide must become more productive and less wasteful. This report outlines the ways and means by which such integrated decision-making processes, at national and regional levels, can adequately address trade—offs – among them agriculture and climate change. We find ourselves at a pivotal stage where the effects of climate change will demand greater collaboration between Member States to recognise and address the role of climate—resilient agriculture and food systems in combating nutrition and security. I therefore supported the recommendations.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I also supported this motion for a resolution as a member of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. I believe that it is precisely agricultural production that should be promoted in the states, especially in the poor countries, where their current strength is not enough, and therefore innovation, higher productivity, agricultural production efficiency must be taken. That's very important.  In my own state, I have always been an ardent supporter of local regional agricultural production, because it then has the smallest costs that could harm transport, could be harmful to other emissions within those regions, so regional agriculture must also be encouraged.  I think that sometimes, unfortunately, our politics stand in such contradiction. We want to support those poor countries, but there are often human rights violations. We're going to have to deal with that one day.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The following motion for a resolution, which deals with food and food safety in the world, touches on many fundamental and important points. These include: attention to small producers and family farms, the fight against land grabbing, food sovereignty, the development of sustainable agricultural policies and therefore the focus on the environment, the rejection of GMOs, intensive cultivation, crops that favour exports, the fight against food waste and incentives for sustainable agriculture. As I consider what I said earlier to be of fundamental importance, I voted in favour.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP has voted against the non-legislative motion for a resolution for Global goals and EU commitments on nutrition and food security in the world. This calls on Member States to invest financially in projects, but this could lead to a misuse of funds.  In addition, it calls on the EU to influence countries on nationalising industries, but the EU has no right to intervene in nation state affairs. UKIP does not support the increasing influence of the EU over nation states.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it proposes mechanisms in the face of the situation of nutrition and food security in the world with which I agree. It is the case to support smallholder farmers and farmers, sustainable and climate-resilient agriculture, the establishment of public policy-based rights, effective measures to combat land grabbing in developing countries, the gender dimension and seed privatization.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this report which dealt with the issue of food security, especially in the developing world. There were many excellent points made in this report including highlighting the negative impacts on nutrition of: industrial agriculture; the privatisation of seeds; GMOs; and land-grabbing. Local food production linking in small-scale food producers is key to successfully tackling nutritional issues. This report also highlights that the right to water ‘goes hand-in hand’ with the right to food  and that the UN resolution of 2010 has not yet resulted in decisive action to establish the right to water as a human right.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. I voted for this resolution. The Commission must ensure that it addresses all forms of malnutrition, while closing the current huge funding gap for specific nutrition interventions. The Commission must live up to its commitments. The implementation of SDG 2 plan to combat hunger and malnutrition is a priority!

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted against the motion for a resolution on global goals and EU commitments on nutrition and food security in the world. While I appreciate the effort to call on the Member States to step up with their commitments for global food security, the final document had serious weaknesses, deploring that the EU biofuels policy is encouraging speculation on arable land and urging the EU to remove public incentives for the production of crop-based biofuels. Additionally, despite the fact that this resolution stressed the need for EU trade and development policy to respect the political and economic policy space of developing countries in order for them to establish the necessary policies to promote sustainable development and dignity for their people, including food sovereignty, it failed to respect the right of local food producers to have control over their land, seeds and water, meaning that privatisation of natural resources was not excluded, due to an unsuccessful amending attempt, from the final text.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft resolution on the EU's global objectives and commitments on food and food security on the planet, because it refers to a number of important issues such as tackling malnutrition, malnutrition and food waste.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. 159 million children are stunted, 50 million suffer from emaciation (linked to starvation). The Commission's action plan plans to reduce the number of stunted children by 7 million by 2015. In 2014, only 0.57 per cent of official development assistance was devoted to the immediate causes of undernutrition. The issue encompasses the concepts of taking into account other forms of undernutrition, increasing investment to combat the causes of undernutrition and establishing "social safety nets" in these countries. Indeed, the resolution recalls that by 2030, hunger and malnutrition are supposed to be reduced, in particular by relying on small producers and farms which are essential links. Sustained new crops will have to cope with inevitable climate change, while respecting biodiversity and the environment. Support for food self-sufficiency and localism are essential. In this sense, the genetic diversity of seeds is encouraged. Indeed, food sovereignty is one of the keys for these populations, to avoid emigration to Europe and malnutrition. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ This matter was not the subject of a roll-call vote. In the interests of democracy and transparency, I would therefore like to confirm that I voted against the final resolution.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text because it is important that global, national and local actors really act in a coordinated and accelerated way to combat malnutrition in order to achieve the 2030 sustainable development agenda and achieve the second Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) of eliminating hunger.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for further action to achieve global objectives and on the EU's commitments on nutrition and food security in the world. There are currently 159 million people in the world. children (over the age of over stature) and 50 million children with impaired development. children suffering from exhaustion (underweight, often associated with extreme hunger). Malnutrition weakens physical and perceptual abilities and closes the circle of poverty. The Commission has committed EUR 7 million to the Nutrition Action Plan by 2025. reduce the number of children with impaired development, but investment in nutrition remains insufficient. I therefore agree that the Commission must honour its commitment to invest EUR 3.5 billion. This is not the first time that the eu-25 will be fully affected by the project. reduce the number of children with impaired development.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal for a decision stands up for concepts such as food self-determination with surprising firmness and almost radical wording. Its text repeatedly refers to the importance of this, especially in developing countries. Unfortunately, nowhere does the reference be connected to the counterproductive state of global trade in food. A few years ago, via Campesina, the world organisation for family farmers, formulated the global problem of hunger and malnutrition in such a targeted and clear way. Today's hungry people used to be small farmers capable of caring for themselves, and they were ruined by the influx of cheap food from richer countries, only because of subsidies.  The draft does not recognise that hunger and malnutrition are systemic problems (the role of capital as a resource extractor) which cannot be permanently remedied with aid and political icing. The adoption of the text of the proposal for a decision has profound consequences. If the Commission or the Council wants to comply, this can only be done by reviewing free trade agreements. I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP has voted against the non-legislative motion for a resolution for Global goals and EU commitments on nutrition and food security in the world. The resolution calls on Member States to financially invest in projects, but this could lead to a misuse of funds. Also it calls on the EU to influence countries on nationalising industries, but the EU has no right to intervene in nation state affairs. UKIP does not support the increasing influence of the EU over nation states.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. According to this text, 159 million children worldwide are stunted, 50 million suffer from emaciation (linked to famine). The Commission's action plan plans to reduce the number of stunted children by 7 million by 2015. In 2014 only 0.57 per cent of official development assistance was devoted to the immediate causes of undernutrition. Indeed, the resolution recalls that by 2030, hunger and malnutrition are supposed to be reduced, in particular by relying on small producers and farms which are essential links. Sustained new crops will have to cope with inevitable climate change, while respecting biodiversity and the environment. Of course, all these measures also call for new investments, which this resolution estimates at 7 billion/year to achieve the objectives. This while calling for specific indicators to assess the results of the EU Action Plan. It is obviously better to help people live decently in their homes than to let them come to us.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. It is essential that global, national, local, governmental, non-governmental and private actors act in a coordinated and accelerated way to combat malnutrition in order to achieve the 2030 sustainable development agenda. Food security and nutrition need to be improved through better governance, increased accountability and comprehensive, rights-based food and nutrition policies.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: in writing. This Resolution calls on all actors at the global, national and local levels, both governmentally and privately, to coordinate and accelerate their actions to combat malnutrition in order to comply with the 2030 Agenda and to achieve SME 2 on ending hunger.  The report, in paragraph 12, also highlights the need to ensure access for all peoples to land, as a key element for food sovereignty, and stresses that land grabbing poses a threat to food security and nutrition. It also calls on action from the Commission to combat land grabbing and to develop an action plan to combat it.  Some amendments on GMOs called for not to support GMOs, which I find too generic, since their effects and consequences need to be analysed on a case-by-case basis, and to let scientific bodies determine the potential impact on the environment, the economy or health. In the face of sesorated dogmas, I call for the use of reason and scientific criterion when assessing the effects of such crops.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 The second of the Sustainable Development Goals and the associated goals aim to end hunger and malnutrition in the world by 2030, increasing the productivity of small farmers, creating sustainable food systems that are resilient to climate change. The joint motion for a resolution that I have supported today reaffirms the importance of truly coordinated and faster actions between governmental, non-governmental and private actors at global, national and local level to deal with malnutrition and hunger. The European Union must mobilise, together with the governments of developing countries, to immediately launch long-term financial investments in food and nutrition security and sustainable agriculture. We need to return to investing in local food production, small food producers and agri-ecological practices, including the establishment of social protection systems to ensure that everyone has access to nutritious food on an ongoing basis. EU actions must be aligned with the principle of policy coherence for development, and its Member States must commit themselves not to support GMO crops in meeting their food and food security obligations around the world.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on nutrition and food security which recognises the right to food as a human right. The resolution also refers to the threat that land grabbing in developing countries poses to the overall objectives on nutrition and food security, calling for concrete measures to ensure land tenure security. Finally, we consider it very positive, too, that the resolution emphasizes that privatization of seeds and GMOs poses a threat to countries' food sovereignty.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I would like to thank the rapporteur for this report on the Union's global objectives and commitments on nutrition and food safety materials in the world. I supported the amendment calling on the Union and its Member States not to support GMOs in meeting the commitments on nutrition and food security in the world.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution setting out the European Union's goals and commitments on nutrition and food security around the world. In fact, 159 million children are stunted, 50 million suffer from emaciation (linked to starvation).  As consequential sovereignists, we believe that developing countries, particularly in sub-Saharan Africa, must be empowered to achieve food self-sufficiency by retaining local producers rooted in their territory. These measures will also help combat mass immigration by encouraging people to build the future of their countries.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I wanted to support with my vote the report which analyses the next steps towards achieving the EU's global objectives and commitments on food and food security in the world.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The first "Nutrition for Growth" summit took place in London in 2013, where twenty-three billion dollars and immediate measures to address nutrition problems were committed. The European Parliament's resolution wants to keep nutrition at the heart of the Union's political agenda. Hoping to make a significant impact before the new Tokyo 2020 summit, the importance of a high-level meeting on this issue is underlined with the aim of developing responses to nutrition challenges, encouraging food to boost the economy—at the continental level, Africa loses about 11% of its GDP due to poor food; curb malnutrition, especially during the first 1,000 days of life; and realize the vision of the Decade of Action on Nutrition (2016-2025) — which was launched in September during the United Nations General Assembly. For all this, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, in which the European Parliament stresses the need to address systemic problems that lead to all forms of malnutrition. Reinvestment in local food production, with a particular focus on small food producers and agro-ecological practices, is a key condition for the successful implementation of dietary strategies. It is also essential to establish social security schemes to ensure that all individuals always have access to nutritious food. Parliament also stresses that local food production should be a priority in the fight against the problem of fasting, and stresses the importance of support for small farmers and farmers as food producers. It is therefore important to encourage the EU, in the context of its global nutrition strategy, to help developing countries and small farmers to develop and facilitate local markets, local value chains and food processing opportunities, while implementing trade policies to support these actions.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 When determining my votes on this report, I was guided by two main aspects: on the one hand, in order to significantly reduce or eliminate economic migration, developing countries should promote the production of the necessary quantity and quality of food on the ground in such a way that the process can be sustained in the long term, with minimal pollution of the environment and efficient use of natural resources. On the other hand, in accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law, I am opposed to the use of GMO seeds and the trade in the products thus produced.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. Notwithstanding the abstaining in the final vote on the resolution on the EU's global objectives and commitments on food security and food security in the world, I very much support all the programmes implemented by the European Union, both in the form of humanitarian and development aid to third countries. The time has come to focus on EU development aid to help develop little agriculture in the countries where there is the greatest food shortage, that is to say, Africa. This kind of agriculture is the basis for people to get their food while creating new jobs. Europe can do a great deal in education and exchange of experience. If we are successful in the field of food security in developing countries, we will also partially solve the problem of migration, which we will continue to face around the world.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 The right to food is recognized as an inalienable right for all people indiscriminately and wherever they live. The fight against malnutrition is a key commitment of the European Union, with a view to achieving the Global Sustainable Development Goals by 2030. More than 159 million children have malnutrition. I support this European Parliament resolution, which aims to be a tool for sustainable development that promotes food safety for those 795 million people who do not have enough food to lead a healthy and active life. This figure highlights the need to act directly at the root of the problem, first and for all supporting the development of rural areas, where malnutrition rates are higher. The need is precisely to organise measures to support the agricultural sector, starting with the protection of small and very small farmers, aiming to increase their productivity. These interventions are essential to achieve sustainable and climate-resistant agricultural development, capable of guaranteeing food to a global population of 8.5 billion people by 2030.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ I support this Report, which highlights the importance of achieving sustainable development, aimed at ending hunger and malnutrition by 2030. I believe that the European Commission, the Council, member states and the international community, as well as the governments of developing countries, must immediately move to combat all forms of malnutrition and mobilise long-term financial investments for food, food security and sustainable agriculture and to improve food and nutrition safety through improving governance and accountability.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. This issue and motion for a resolution aims to further increase the EU's financial efforts to combat malnutrition and hunger in the world. Even if the use of funds is insufficiently controlled, I am of course in favour of these provisions which aim at self-sufficiency in the food of the countries concerned. Therefore, I vote for it.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the next necessary steps towards attaining global goals on nutrition and food security because I strongly believe the EU must be better committed to fighting against hunger and poverty in the world. In particular, this resolution reaffirms the importance of common actions addressing malnutrition in order to fulfil the 2030 Agenda and the Sustainable Development Goals.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 It is important that coordinated and faster actions are taken between government, non-governmental and private development actors at global, national and local levels to tackle malnutrition and to end hunger. Long-term financial investments must be made in food and nutrition security and sustainable agriculture. Investment is also needed to reduce the number of children suffering from growth lag and, above all, it is essential that these investments directly address the immediate causes of child malnutrition. In addition to the delay in growth, other manifestations of malnutrition must be addressed by health policies and systems. Humanitarian and development interventions must be joined. Specific indicators for the implementation of the EU Action Plan need to be developed and the collection of comprehensive and disaggregated data on nutrition and related issues needs to be improved, so that future actions can be better planned.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution calls on the European Commission to effectively tackle malnutrition around the world by devoting a budget of 400 million euros per year specifically to food security. As a reminder, 159 million children are stunted and 50 million emaciated. The text therefore calls for the establishment of social protection schemes in the countries concerned and of supporting local producers who contribute to food self-sufficiency. Programmes to get children into school are also mentioned in the text. These commitments obviously require substantial investments estimated at 7 billion euros per year. We are in perfect harmony with the philosophy of the text and we are in favour of increasing the share of development aid devoted to malnutrition, especially as these aids will help to fix the populations in their countries of origin. That is why I voted for this text.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution today because I believe it is right to support measures to put an end to the long-running problem of hunger and malnutrition in the world. The main objective of the motion for a resolution is to ensure opportunities and thus increase the productivity of small farmers, creating sustainable and climate-resilient food systems. By 2030, the food needs of an expected global population of 8.5 billion must be provided, while protecting the environment, biodiversity and the interests of small farmers. In 2012, the World Health Organisation approved important food targets to be achieved by 2025. Of all, the 40 % reduction in the number of children under the age of five suffering from growth retardedness and the 30 % reduction in cases of low birth weight. To date, one third of the food produced worldwide, 1.3 billion tonnes, is wasted. In the light of this, the implementation of European policies developed by the Commission's Action Plan on Nutrition should be implemented.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which deals with food poverty, malnutrition and their causes in the developing world. The right to food can only be fully achieved when poverty and inequality are drastically reduced and resilience to shocks is enhanced. Rights-based public policies and effective measures to combat land grabbing in developing countries, including through concrete options to ensure land tenure security, are essential for attaining global goals and EU commitments on nutrition and food security in the world. For these reasons I voted in favour.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I believe and support the idea that eradicating hunger and malnutrition should be a long-term commitment of the EU.  The EU needs to be ambitious in achieving Sustainable Development. However although progress has been made over the past years, it remains too slow and a significant number of people in the world still lack proper access to food and are malnourished. The resolution aims at taking stock of the progress made and the challenges that remain ahead of the UN High level Summit on Nutrition. Although I agree on many of the points raised in this resolution I do not support all of them, therefore I could not vote in favour of this resolution.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution on the means to be adopted in order to achieve the EU's global objectives and commitments on food and food security in the world. I particularly appreciated, among others, the references to the fight against land grabbing; attention to small producers and family farms; the human right to food and the human right to water; access to natural resources; the 'no' to GMOs.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 It is with great concern that I note that, despite the efforts made, the situation of world malnutrition remains at dramatically high levels. The most alarming fact is that, to date, 159 million children are malnourished and 50 million children are suffering from rickets. Malnutrition has very serious consequences for the development of children and aggravates the spiral of poverty in which they live. Adequate nutrition of newborns and children, especially during the first two years of life, can increase their chances of survival and is essential for good growth and proper development. According to the FAO, although the trend on malnutrition is falling, action must be taken on its main cause, namely poverty. This can be done through a coordinated effort, increasing the production of small farmers, intervening on education, implementing sustainable food chains, improving governance, defending women's rights, improving the sanitation situation and stimulating microcredit. I voted in favour of the resolution, believing that all of us, the representatives of the European institutions, the Member States, the international community and the governments of developing countries, must do our utmost to ensure that the causes of malnutrition are eradicated.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and insist on the need to adopt a holistic approach to the challenge of malnutrition because action is needed in a wide range of economic and social sectors.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution on the EU's global objectives and commitments on food and food security on the planet concerns a positive process of highlighting Europe's role and strengthening efforts to find solutions to the problem of feeding the world's population. As the resolution aims to promote new proposals and ideas, I voted in favour.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 Having seen all the developments that have taken place regarding the right to food as an integral part of the right to an adequate standard of living. I voted in favour of the measure considering that the sustainable development objective and the associated targets aim to end hunger and malnutrition by 2030. Ensuring opportunities and increasing the productivity of small farmers, creating sustainable and climate-resilient agriculture and food systems that deliver food to an expected global population of 8.5 billion people, while protecting biodiversity, the environment, the interests and well-being of small farmers. Although progress has been made in reducing malnutrition, which is too slow and irregular, and which currently 795 million people in the world do not have enough food to lead a normal and active life. It urges the Commission and the Member States to pay attention to the coherence of development policies in their activities and, consequently, to consider the consequences of their policies on trade, agriculture, energy and global food security. It stresses the importance of supporting small farmers and women farmers as producers of nutrition foods.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 Nutrition is the foundation of our living well and is inseparable from a humanity eager to progress. Therefore, in the name of this, I am against what has been proposed. I deplore the many amendments tabled by my fellow Members which have made a proposal with countless repercussions a trivial demonisation of free trade. The right to food is a pillar of the right to an adequate standard of living, so ending hunger and malnutrition, as well directed by the objectives of the 2030 Agenda, involves addressing systemic problems and not planning nutritional strategies based on caloric intakes and prescribing medical remedies. It is therefore necessary to build through political responsibilities and efficient governance faster actions among the actors involved through long-term investments focused on food security and proper nutrition with the knowledge that 1.3 billion tons of food (that is, a third of production) is wasted. I would like to remind you that the Eu ropean Union should feel the problem of malnutrition more acutely, given that more and more families, made poor by the crisis, are forced to resort to the purchase of packaged products close to expiry and often also from dubious origin. In order to state our vanguard on the subject of food, we need to resolve as soon as possible the real problems that our citizens face every day.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. The European Union must play a leading role in the global commitment to the eradication of hunger and malnutrition in the world. This plan, included in Sustainable Development Goal 2 (Eradicating hunger by 2030), is urgent when we consider demographic changes such as the increase in the world population (which is expected to reach 8.5 billion people by 2030) and its movement to urban centres (70% of people are expected to live in large cities by 2050). I am concerned that 795 million people do not have enough food, that one in three suffers from some form of malnutrition and, in particular, that 161 million children are malnourished and that 2 000 children under the age of five die every year from water pollution-related diseases. I therefore believe that the EU must tackle food waste, uphold the 'right to breastfeeding', promote sustainable productive agriculture at all levels (large and small producers), integrate the objective of eliminating malnutrition into internal (Agriculture, Energy or Trade) and external (trade agreements or development aid) policies and define specific indicators for the implementation of the EU action plan in this area. I hereby support this motion for a resolution.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – UKIP has voted against the non-legislative motion for a resolution for Global goals and EU commitments on nutrition and food security in the world. It calls on Member States to financially invest in projects and this could lead to a misuse of funds. Also it calls on the EU to influence countries on nationalising industries but the EU has no right to intervene in nation state affairs. UKIP does not support the increasing influence of the EU over nation states.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 Eradicating hunger and malnutrition is a long-term and priority commitment for the European Union. Despite the efforts made and the progress that has been made in recent years, the path is still too slow and 795 million people still do not have adequate access to food and one in three people is malnourished. I voted in favour of this resolution because, in view of the second UN food summit, the European Parliament insists on the need for greater coordination between all the instruments used and the EU's actors (national, local, governmental, non-governmental, private, scientific and industrial research) in this area. Member States need to step up their commitments to global food security, giving priority to sustainable agriculture and local food production, which must be given priority in order to take action against malnutrition.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ I support the call for local food production to be given priority in actions against under-nutrition, and stress the importance of supporting small farming initiatives and female farmers as food producers.  At the same time I call on the EU to assist developing countries and smallholding farmers in the development of and access to local markets, local value chains and local food processing facilities, combined with trade policies that support such efforts, as part of its global nutrition strategy.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it proposes mechanisms in the face of the situation of nutrition and food security in the world with which I agree. It is the case to support smallholder farmers and farmers, sustainable and climate-resilient agriculture, the establishment of public policy-based rights, effective measures to combat land grabbing in developing countries, the gender dimension and seed privatization.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because it aims to reaffirm the EU's commitment to food security in the world, in line with the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals. In particular, the second objective aims to end hunger and malnutrition by 2030, adopting a bottom-up approach that sees small farmers as the main private sector players in agriculture, food security and nutrition. Coordinated action between government, non-governmental and private actors at global, national and local level will ensure safe access to land and the management of its resources to small farmers and food systems that are sustainable and resilient to climate change, while protecting biodiversity, the environment and the interests and well-being of small farmers. This synergy is, in fact, necessary to address the root causes of hunger and malnutrition, and not only its visible effects, as well as the systemic problems that cause inadequate nutrition in all its forms. These include export-based agricultural production, to the detriment of local biodiversity, and trade agreements that deprive local populations of access to and management of productive resources that are essential for their livelihood.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the EU's global food and food security objectives and commitments. I welcome the fact that the amendments proposed by my group have been included in the text of the revolution. Tackling hunger and malnutrition is very important, and I am therefore pleased to refer to the text of the resolution, which refers not only to ad hoc but also long-term measures, such as the creation of sustainable climate-resilient agriculture and food systems capable of delivering food to the people of the world. We must not forget the importance of increasing investment in this sector. I voted in favour because the resolution details the action that needs to be taken to tackle malnutrition and hunger.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ The Universal Declaration of Human Rights recognises the right to food as part of the right to an adequate standard of living. SDG2 aims to end hunger and malnutrition by 2030 by increasing productivity of smallholders and achieving sustainable agriculture for 8.5 billion people by 2030. The WHA came up with 6 global nutrition targets for 2026. This report is calling for: financial investment, a reduction in food waste, nutrition strategies, public awareness and education on these problems, to support crop genetic diversity and combat land grabbing, prevent trade distortions in agriculture, humanitarian aid, social safety nets and data collection. I am voting in favour of this report so as to ensure that the Commission addresses all forms of under nutrition and combat world hunger.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that long-term financial investments in food and nutrition security and sustainable agriculture must be mobilised in order to improve food security and nutrition through better governance and increased responsibility, through systemic food and nutrition policies, taking into account, on the one hand, the gender dimension, sustainable agriculture, access to and use of natural resources and their use , and on the other hand, the creation and extension of inclusive and rights-based social protection devices, targeting in particular the most vulnerable and marginal groups.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I wholeheartedly supported this motion for a European Parliament resolution on the next steps towards achieving the EU's global objectives and commitments on food and food security in the world. Through this measure, the European institutions, the Member States, the international community and the governments of developing countries are called upon to mobilise rapid long-term financial investments in favour of food and nutrition security and sustainable agriculture. In addition, the actors themselves are urged to enhance food security and food through better governance and accountability and that they are rights-based and take into account, on the one hand, sustainable agriculture, access to and use of natural resources, water, sanitation and sanitation, and, on the other, the creation and expansion of inclusive social security networks based on human rights. , in particular for the most vulnerable and marginal groups.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP has voted against the non-legislative motion for a resolution for Global goals and EU commitments on nutrition and food security in the world. The resolution calls on Member States to financially invest in projects, but this could lead to a misuse of funds. Also it calls on the EU to influence countries on nationalising industries, but the EU has no right to intervene in nation state affairs. UKIP does not support the increasing influence of the EU over nation states.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I supported the resolution on the EU's global goals and commitments on nutrition and food security around the world. Given the economic power of the European Union and its Member States, we have a responsibility to eradicate world hunger, solve nutritional and food problems and promote sustainable agriculture. Our participation in these global projects is all the more necessary as we face increasing the food needs of a rapidly expanding world population and increasingly pressing threats to the environment. We therefore call on the European Commission to establish a roadmap for its action on nutrition and food security around the world and call for an increase in long-term European financial investment in these areas.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. According to the World Food Programme (WFP), 795 million people worldwide were hungry in 2015, or 1 in 9 people. 3.1 million children under the age of five die each year from malnutrition. When it does not kill, this scourge creates irreversible damage to the development of the children who suffer from it. To combat malnutrition, the European Union must act on its merits and in the long term, including on water, schools, agriculture, food self-sufficiency and land management. Development policy must take ownership of humanitarian outcomes and this requires increasing funding and donor coordination, addressing the root causes of malnutrition and intensifying information and prevention campaigns.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the resolution as a whole. However, I have voted against some additions because they are not in line with the overall aim to increase the productivity of smallholders and achieve sustainable agriculture and food systems that are capable of feeding an expected global population of 8.5 billion people, in particular because it calls on the Commission to increase investments on nutrition-specific interventions. I support the proposals to better involve the private sector in order to tackle the main issues more efficiently. At the same time I welcome the approach to focus on the importance of context-specific national targets, as they differ greatly and a one-size-fits-all approach will not solve the problem. Therefore, I support this initiative.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 We are voting against the motion for a resolution because, despite the good direction it had taken initially, it then ended up in a lateral way supporting private interests and mutant products.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU produces 88 million tonnes of food waste annually, while 842 million people worldwide, or 12 % of the world's population, are starving and all food systems need to be adapted to eradicate food loss or waste. The Sustainable Development goals and their associated targets aim to eradicate hunger and malnutrition by 2030, including ensuring opportunities to increase the productivity of smallholder farmers and creating sustainable agriculture and food systems that are resilient to climate change, capable of feeding a global population of 8.5 billion people by 2030. I agree that the EU will fulfil its commitment to invest €3.5 billion to reduce growth delays by at least €7 million by 2025.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Vote for: 159 million children are stunted, 50 million suffer from emaciation (linked to starvation). The Commission's action plan plans to reduce the number of stunted children by 7 million by 2015. In 2014, only 0.57 per cent of official development assistance was devoted to the immediate causes of undernutrition.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. This resolution addresses recurring themes: food security in the world, hunger and malnutrition. We know how often the pious intentions that seem to justify resolutions of this kind do not serve more than to open more doors to the advancement of multinationalagro-business. However, this resolution, which contains positive aspects, should not be stressed, all the more so since some are unusual. To this end, the amendments we have tabled have also contributed, although not all of them have been accepted. Proposals that focused on: - Criticism and condemnation of free trade agreements, in particular their impact on nutrition and food security in the world and their contribution to inequalities; - the defence of the control and public ownership of seeds and the guarantee of affordable prices for it and other factors of production; - the incompatibility between the private logic of maximising profit, in particular of large multinationals in the agri-food sector, and the fight against hunger and food security; - condemning the support and practice of export-friendly agricultural policies, favourable to large agrarians; - The repudiation of land expropriation by foreign "investors" in the least developed countries. We value the fact that some of these points are included in the resolution.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as it is essential for the basic standards of living to made universal.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 According to several forecasts, more than 8.5 billion people will live in the world in 2030. The European Union cannot ignore the fact that 795 million people no longer have enough food to lead a full and quality life. It is therefore very important that we focus more on securing opportunities and increasing the productivity of smallholder farmers, who are the biggest players in agricultural production, and in doing so ensure sustainable agriculture and food systems. It is important that we avoid adopting trade agreements that could have a detrimental effect on food security and contribute to malnutrition if the rental or sale of arable land to private investors leads to locals losing access to the production resources essential for their livelihoods, or if it results in a large proportion of food being exported and sold on international markets , making the exporting host State more dependent on and more vulnerable to fluctuations in commodity prices on international markets.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the EU's global objectives and commitments on food and food security on the planet, as the motion for a resolution, while initially in a good direction, then in a lateral way promotes private interests and mutants.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly support this report, which underlines the importance of the development of social safety nets. I would like to underline the importance of achieving Sustainable Development Goal 2, which aims at ending hunger and malnutrition by 2030, notably by increasing the productivity of smallholder farms and achieving sustainable and climate resilient agriculture and food systems. Currently, 159 million children are stunted and 50 million are affected by wasting. Malnutrition has a tremendous impact on their development and health and fuels the cycle of poverty. The level of investments remains inadequate. The Commission Nutrition Action Plan pledged to reduce stunting by 7 million children by 2025 and should honour its commitments, ensuring that it addresses all forms of undernutrition while also filling the huge current funding gap for nutrition—specific interventions.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution, considering that SDP 2 and its earlier targets aim to end hunger and malnutrition on the 2030 horizon, in particular by creating opportunities for smallholder farmers and increasing their productivity, and achieving sustainable and climate-resilient agriculture and food systems, which can feed a global population expected to reach 8.5 billion people by 2030 , while protecting biodiversity and the environment, as well as the interests and well-being of smallholder farmers. The Union, the international community, as well as the Governments of developing countries, must immediately mobilizing long-term financial investments in food and nutrition security and sustainable agriculture and strengthening food and nutrition security through improved governance and accountability and systematic, rights-based food and nutrition policies.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. \u2012 The one with the targets set for sustainable development by 2030 is an appointment that Europe cannot afford to disregard, because providing more investment in food, ensuring adequate development and strengthening of social safety nets and supporting climate-resilient agriculture could mean being able to save 7 million children, by 2025, from threats related to malnutrition and hunger. The stakes are too high. I therefore agree with Mrs McAvan's request to the Commission to call for a consolidation of current financial commitments and to promote initiatives and strategies aimed at curbing the alarming numbers that we unfortunately see in relation to malnutrition and decay.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the next steps towards achieving the EU's global objectives and commitments on food and food security in the world because I believe that the objective of ending malnutrition in the world by 2030 can no longer be postponed. Despite the progress made in reducing malnutrition, however, there are still too many 800 million people suffering from malnutrition in the world. The target of a 40% reduction in malnutrition among children under the age of 2025 must be a target that cannot be postponed, given that malnutrition and poor nutrition are the main risk factors for the global burden of diseases. I strongly supported the need for coordinated and faster action among government and non-governmental actors at all levels, greater coordination between agricultural, trade and development policies and the leadership action that the European Commission, the world's largest donor, must take in the field of food security and food by strengthening the resources already committed with additional appropriations to be allocated to specific interventions on food in order to make it possible to achieve the WHO food targets and the development strategy (SDO), within a true integrated strategy.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the non-legislative motion for a resolution for Global goals and EU commitments on nutrition and food security in the world. This calls on Member States to financially invest in projects, but this could lead to a misuse of funds. It also calls on the EU to influence countries on nationalising industries, but the EU has no right to intervene in nation state affairs. UKIP does not support the increasing influence of the EU over nation states.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on nutrition and food security which recognises the right to food as a human right. The resolution also refers to the threat that land grabbing in developing countries poses to the overall objectives on nutrition and food security, calling for concrete measures to ensure land tenure security. Finally, we consider it very positive, too, that the resolution emphasizes that privatization of seeds and GMOs poses a threat to countries' food sovereignty.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the motion on Global goals and EU commitments on nutrition and food security in the world. The report highlights the need to end hunger and malnutrition by 2030, through the support of smallholders’ farms and sustainable and climate resilient agriculture and food systems.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: Written. – Increased application of intellectual property protection to seeds in trade agreements with developing countries may reduce choice for farmers while increasing costs, which in turn could jeopardise food safety in these countries. On the other hand, the gradual building up of intellectual property rights on the basis of experience and voluntary cooperation may in some cases be appropriate, and that is why we chose to abstain on the amendment on the privatisation of seeds. The cultivation of GMO crops is in many cases based on the use of herbicide pesticides that have devastating effects on biodiversity, deplete arable land and ultimately threaten sustainable agriculture. That is why we want to see a phasing-out of the use of such GMO crops, so that food production is gradually replaced by more sustainable alternatives. However, this phasing-out must be carried out in a long-term and sustainable way, which is why we have not supported wordings that we fear may make existing food security in countries more difficult.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the resolution on attaining global goals and EU commitments on nutrition and food security in the world. The resolution calls for accelerated action to fulfil the 2030 Agenda and to reach Sustainable Development Goals 2 to end hunger, while it also insists on the   development of social safety nets in order to reduce extreme poverty. As the level of investment in nutrition remains inadequate (with nutrition-specific interventions receiving only 0.57% of global ODA aid in 2014, meeting only 1.4% of the total needs) the resolution calls for additional EU commitment of EUR 1 billion addressing nutrition-specific interventions. I believe that there is an absolute urgency to reach internationally agreed nutrition targets. Inadequate nutrition is one of the most significant impediments to human development. I was also happy to support an amendment, which called for the right of local food producers to have control over their land, seeds and water and also reject the privatisation of natural resources.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: in writing. ‒ Global goals and EU commitments on nutrition and food security in the world: This oral question and its accompanying resolution are centred on Sustainable Development Goal 2 and its targets, which aims at ending hunger and malnutrition by 2030. Since the resolution includes the importance of the private sector and the necessity to include the most affected countries in global trade, my group and I have voted positively. By the way, I believe that the euro must be abolished. It leads to dissension and discord in Europe.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. \u2012 I voted for the motion for a resolution submitted following a question for oral response B8-0717/2016 in accordance with Article 128(5) of the REGULATION. Rules of procedure on the next steps to achieve the EU's global and food security-related objectives and obligations in the world (2016/2705(RSP)), as coordinated action is needed between global, national, local, governmental, non-governmental and other actors to meet the 2nd Sustainable Development Goal of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development.  The EU, Member States and the international community, as well as developing governments, should immediately mobilise long-term financial investments in food security and food security and sustainable agriculture and improve food security. On the other hand, the situation needs to be urgently changed where a third of the world's food – around 1.3 billion tonnes – is thrown in the trash. I would also like to highlight the need for the Commission to support small farmers in implementing innovative more productive agricultural practices that also meet climate change-friendly and agroecology-based criteria.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. No one is insensitive to the dramatic problems posed by hunger and malnutrition in the world, especially when it affects children. All initiatives to promote food self-sufficiency, localism and strengthen the sovereignty of the countries concerned are welcome. In the long run, this will move us forward in the resolution of many issues, both emigration to Europe and hunger itself. I voted for it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – UKIP has voted against the non-legislative motion for a resolution for Global goals and EU commitments on nutrition and food security in the world. This calls on Member States to financially invest in projects, but this could lead to a misuse of funds. Also it calls on the EU to influence countries on nationalising industries, but the EU has no right to intervene in nation state affairs. UKIP does not support the increasing influence of the EU over nation states.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the EU's global objectives and commitments to food and food safety in the world, which is in line with the vision of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, a joint plan agreed by UN states to eliminate extreme poverty and transform the economy into sustainability by 2030. The resolution stresses the need to prevent systemic problems that cause malnutrition through the involvement of all economic and social players and other stakeholders. In the field of food safety, it places particular emphasis on the role of the private sector and on improving approaches and systems in agriculture.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted against Linda McAvan's resolution on the EU's global goals and commitments on nutrition and food security around the world. While I support the initiatives aimed at highlighting the challenges and progress that must be made by the European Union in eradicating hunger and malnutrition in the world, it is nevertheless necessary to maintain a sense of proportion. To want to ban GMO crops as a whole when they can have a role in the fight against world hunger seems to me clearly disproportionate given the stakes.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on materials that can release certain toxic substances into food because I consider this public health issue to be a major one. By expanding the materials involved in specific measures and improving traceability, we are ensuring that measures for consumer health in the single market are taken.

name: Jarosław KALINOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The world's population is growing year on year, increasing the demand for food, and its scarcity is leading to hunger and poverty. Malnutrition is mainly found among children and takes the form of disorders in the body associated with stunted growth or low body weight, slowing down natural development processes, general deterioration of health. In some countries, the problem of hunger is extremely serious and leads to around 15 million deaths worldwide each year. It is therefore important to produce and distribute food rationally so that this problem can be minimised. To this end, smaller food producers should be promoted and a sustainable model of agriculture, efficient and resilient to climate change should be promoted. In order to protect fundamental food needs, social security must be ensured for citizens. Modern food production and distribution systems must have the capacity to feed the entire human population, with an estimated figure of 8.5 billion in 2030. Therefore, the EU must make every effort to achieve these objectives.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of this resolution. In particular, the rejection of privatisation efforts in the field of seeds and the extremely critical attitude towards genetically modified foods are to be welcomed.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, as it underlines the importance of achieving Sustainable Development Goal 2 aimed at ending hunger and malnutrition by 2030, notably by increasing the productivity of smallholders’ farms, achieving sustainable and climate resilient agriculture and food systems.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Given that the Second Sustainable Development Goal and the relevant sub-objectives are aimed at eradicating hunger and malnutrition by 2030, in particular by securing opportunities for small landowners and increasing their productivity, and at achieving sustainable and climate-resilient agricultural and food systems capable of sustaining the world's projected population (8.5 billion inhabitants in 2030) while protecting biodiversity , the environment and the interests and well-being of these small-scale owners, I consider the debate on the next steps to achieve global targets and to meet the EU's commitments in the field of nutrition and food security in the world to be crucial, and I voted in favour of the report. Moreover, I have completely agreed that the privatisation of seeds through the intellectual property rights clauses and GMOs threatens the food self-sufficiency of countries, and I hope that the Commission will also be aware of this when negotiating international treaties.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. – The problems are systemic, as a result of world trade and agricultural support schemes, that today smallholders who have previously provided for themselves, their families and their small communities are starving. Only stopping land thefts and food self-determination can be a real alternative. Indeed, quality and organic food can be essentially produced on small farms, so their ruin must be eliminated and the processes so far reversed. The resolution is clearly worthy of support.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution on the next steps towards achieving the EU's global food and food security objectives and commitments around the world, as this is one of the main and most important objectives set out in the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development.  Solving the problem of nutrition and malnutrition is a long-term commitment of the EU. A key prerequisite for eradicating hunger is to strike a balance in the field of nutrition by ensuring food security, quality food and identifying the needs of the countries concerned.
