I believe that coordination in the area of assistance, funding and increased investment between the EU and other global partners and donors will lead to concrete positive results.  I support the proposal to encourage, support and support farmers, especially small and local farmers, who provide a large proportion of food around the world while supporting the labour market.  Making agriculture sustainable, increasing funding for farmers in less developed regions and using innovation in this field will promote productivity and help solve the problem of nutrition.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. ‒ Fighting hunger is a priority enshrined in the Millennium Development Goals. As the world population continues to grow, much more effort and innovation will be urgently needed in order to sustainably increase agricultural production, improve the global supply chain, decrease food losses and waste, and ensure that all who are suffering from hunger and malnutrition have access to nutritious food. The EU is a champion among donors in the eradication of hunger and malnutrition and is committed to reduce the numbers of people who face hunger and malnutrition by at least 7 million by 2025. However, progress in reducing malnutrition remains too slow; 795 million people in the world currently do not get enough food to lead a decent and active life. Therefore, the EU should continue to support and invest in smallholder farmers to boost food production, achieve nutrition security and sustainable agriculture. In addition to this, the EU should assist smallholder farmers in the development and access to local markets, local value chain and local food processing facilities. In order to facilitate the process even further the Union should provide education and training to smallholder farmers.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution on the EU's global objectives and commitments on food and food security in the world. Today, despite efforts to reduce malnutrition, according to FAO statistics, around 122 million European citizens are at risk of poverty, and more than 100 million tonnes of food are wasted every year in the EU, which could solve the problem of hunger in the world. Each tonne of food waste avoided could also contribute to saving the equivalent of 4.2 tonnes of CO2 by reducing the use of natural resources. I believe it is a priority to put an end to this problem by combating food waste and supporting the most deprived populations. For example, within the new circular economy package, which aims to transform the economy from linear to circular, that is, the new vision of waste as a resource, the fight against food waste can play a central role. Nutritional safety is one of the essential prerequisites for ensuring the sustainable growth of our communities and the whole world, and that is why we must all strive to contribute to achieving these goals.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it recognises the food sovereignty of states while trying to combat malnutrition. However, I regret the rejection of amendments condemning free trade and the abuses of multinationals. But the privatization of seeds is fortunately doomed!

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the EU's global goals and commitments on nutrition and food security around the world. The resolution reminds us that by 2030 hunger and malnutrition are supposed to be reduced, in particular by relying on small producers and farms which are essential links. Sustained new crops will have to cope with inevitable climate change, while respecting biodiversity and the environment. Social protection schemes are supposed to be put in place, guaranteeing, among other things, access to land and its management by these populations. This while avoiding land grabbing by foreign multinationals or countries like China. The aim is to stop this, to prevent them from getting their hands on this land because they are excluding local producers who could use these farms for the benefit of local food crops, helping their people to sustain themselves. Support for food self-sufficiency and localism is essential. In this sense, the genetic diversity of seeds is encouraged. Indeed, food sovereignty is one of the keys for these populations, to avoid emigration to Europe and malnutrition.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. The text here looks back at the Commission's commitment of 3.5 billion euros, of which 400 million are specifically on nutrition. It is therefore a question of treating the problem of the 159 million children who are stunted and the 50 million who suffer from emaciation (linked to famine). The Commission's action plan plans to reduce the number of stunted children by 7 million by 2015. The resolution recalls that by 2030, hunger and malnutrition are supposed to be reduced, especially by relying on small farms, essential links. Sustained new crops will have to cope with climate change, while respecting biodiversity and the environment. Social protection mechanisms must be put in place, guaranteeing access to land and its management by these populations, while avoiding land grabbing by multinationals. Support for food self-sufficiency and localism are essential. Indeed, food sovereignty is one of the keys for these populations, to avoid emigration to Europe and malnutrition. Women's education programmes are also offered. Finally, the issue of food waste is addressed. As a result of all these aspects, I voted for this issue.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it proposes mechanisms in the face of the situation of nutrition and food security in the world with which I agree. It is the case to support smallholder farmers and farmers, sustainable and climate-resilient agriculture, the establishment of public policy-based rights, effective measures to combat land grabbing in developing countries, the gender dimension and seed privatization.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. This motion for a resolution addresses the following steps to achieve the Union's global objectives and commitments on nutrition and food security in the world.  Although progress has been made in reducing malnutrition, there are still 795 million people worldwide without enough food to lead a dignified life. That is why the Union cannot stand by and must take effective and balanced measures to meet the global nutrition targets set for 2025, as set out at the 2012 World Health Assembly.  Among others, the promotion of the 'right to breastfeeding' and the importance of supporting small farmers and women farmers as producers is mentioned in this resolution.  I welcome this proposal, because the measures it contains will help to reduce the number of children who are behind in growth, as well as not to increase levels of overweight in children and will increase breastfeeding rates in the first six months of life, which is capital for children's development.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. I do not agree with the call on the Member States to invest in sustainable agriculture with safe food. This is hypocrisy, because it is eu policies to promote biofuels that make food more expensive and lead poor countries to grow biofuel crops instead of food crops. Instead of this report, the EU should recognise that the problems of nutrition and malnutrition, the rise in food prices, are the result of its policy of promoting biofuels. This report does not say a hint, it just calls for further regulations.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. ‒ Progress in reducing malnutrition has been made but remains too slow and uneven, 795 million people in the world currently do not get enough food to lead a decent, active life, and one in three people are malnourished in one form or another. At the Nutrition for Growth Summit in 2013, the EU committed to reducing stunting by at least 7 million by 2025 and pledged EUR 3.5 billion for the 2014-2020 period to achieve this target. I support the resolution’s call on the Commission, the Council, the Member States and the international community, as well as developing countries’ governments, to mobilise, forthwith, long-term financial investments for food and nutrition security and sustainable agriculture.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 It is alarming that the world cannot cope with poverty, hunger, inadequate and inadequate nutrition in the 21st century. Poverty and hunger mainly affect less developed countries. However, inadequate and inadequate nutrition is also a reality for many developed countries. The weakest groups, children, women and the elderly suffer. These problems have their reflection in mortality, diseases, in the socio-health system and, of course, in the economies of countries. In the European Parliament, we have adopted a number of resolutions concerning nutrition and food security. Many support initiatives have been set up, a considerable amount of money is being spent to tackle the problem. However, we have not come to an agreement with the substance of the problem. There is a need to increase control over the granting of aid in order to prevent abuse and to be directed where it is really needed.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the motion for a resolution on the next steps towards achieving the EU's global objectives and commitments on food and food security in the world, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 3/10/2016 but also because I consider it sufficiently substantiated.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted for this text. The motion for a resolution tabled on behalf of the DEVE Committee aims to draw the European Commission's attention to the problem of hunger and malnutrition of children around the world. Above all, it stresses the need to support food self-sufficiency in developing countries, which can thus protect these populations from malnutrition. Furthermore, we believe that food sovereignty is one of the ways in which we can avoid mass immigration from the regions concerned to Europe. We therefore support this motion for a resolution despite some reservations about the need to commit funds from the EU budget.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the resolution on the EU's next steps on food security issues in the world because, taking into account the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Human Rights, we conclude that the right to food is inalienable since it is part of the right to an adequate standard of living. , bearing in mind. Moreover, the human right to food can only be realised when poverty and inequality are drastically reduced and also when equality is guaranteed. This can be achieved by setting up rights-based social security networks and ensuring full participation of vulnerable and weaker groups. For the above reasons I am voting in favour of the report.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. In order to ensure food security, the Commission is invited to promote small holder farmers. It also calls on the international community to take action to curb malnutrition. I share this view and therefore support this motion for a resolution.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the EU's commitments on nutrition and food security in the world. I believe that all individuals must have access to nutritious food, and it is therefore important to consistently assist developing countries and their small farmers in creating local markets, local value chains and food processing opportunities. This would reduce poverty and the diseases created by non-food in developing countries.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. Following the EU's global food security commitments, this report offers interesting ways to combat malnutrition and famine. Thus the text recalls that "the production of biofuels puts new pressure on the world food system, as it generates competition in terms of access to land and water". It also explains how "seed privatization, through and GMOs are jeopardizing the food sovereignty of countries". Or criticizes the excesses of intensive farming since "one third of the world's cereal production is used for animal feed". To remedy this, the text proposes the promotion of "family farms that produce food crops for local consumption" and promotes "agroecological practices". Nevertheless, I regret the injunctions on breastfeeding that this report develops by proposing to 'increase the exclusive breastfeeding rate by at least 50% during the first six months'. Why not guarantee that infants have access to healthy and nutritious foods that allow breastfeeding to remain an option without being an injunction. Despite these reservations, I'm voting for it.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. It is a question of taking the problem of the 159 million children who are stunted and the 50 million who suffer from emaciation (linked to famine) to bear the problem. The Commission's action plan plans to reduce the number of stunted children by 7 million by 2015. The issue encompasses the concepts of taking into account other forms of undernutrition, increasing investment to combat the causes of undernutrition and establishing "social safety nets" in these countries. The resolution recalls that by 2030, hunger and malnutrition are expected to be reduced, in particular by relying on small producers and small farms which are essential links. Social protection measures are supposed to be put in place, including guaranteeing access to land and its management by these populations, while avoiding land grabbing by foreign multinationals. Support for food self-sufficiency and localism are essential. In this sense, the genetic diversity of seeds is encouraged. Indeed, food sovereignty is one of the keys for these populations, to avoid emigration to Europe and malnutrition. As a result of all these aspects, I voted in favour of this issue.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 Access to food and food security for all are essential for reducing inequalities. Large investments are needed to achieve these objectives. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ Though I fully support the struggle to ensure food security and the need for development policy to be interlinked with trade, agriculture and energy policies I could not support the final version of the text as it would endanger jobs and growth that could form international investment.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. In a world of 9 billion people by 2050, including 2 billion in Africa, it is imperative to combine population growth, productive agriculture and sustainable agriculture. Currently, 842 million people, or 12% of the world's population, are starving. This figure shows us the urgent need to address the problems that cause malnutrition in all its forms. Investments have so far covered only 1.4% of total needs. Proactive dynamics must be engaged in structural food security mechanisms that can replace emergency food aid, a temporary tool, but also help with better regional integration. I fully support this motion for a resolution. Ensuring that every human being has a proper and regular diet is the embassing of a fundamental human right.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – The European Union has the ambition to become a global leader in achieving Objective 2 of Agenda 2030 – Sustainable Development, which aims to eradicate hunger and malnutrition in the world by 2030. At the same time that around one third of the world's food produced is thrown away, some 842 million people worldwide are suffering from hunger. One of the main challenges will therefore be to adapt food systems to eliminate food losses and waste. Greater coherence between all EU actors, but also its instruments, is also needed in the fight against hunger and malnutrition. Member States must strengthen their commitments to global food security by prioritising sustainable agriculture and local food production, and supporting smallholder farmers as food producers is crucial. The EU should assist developing countries and smallho0 farmers in developing local markets and accessing local markets. Although some progress has been made in reducing malnutrition, it has been too slow and unbalanced. Coordination and acceleration of action by global, national and local governmental, non-governmental and private actors, including scientific and industrial research institutions and donors, is therefore essential in order to focus on tackling malnutrition in order to meet the objectives of the 2030 Agenda, as well as SDG 2 to eradicate hunger.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report that underlines the importance of the development of social safety nets. The Commission has to ensure it addresses all forms of undernutrition while also filling the huge current funding gap for nutrition specific interventions. The Commission has to fulfil its commitments. The implementation of SDG 2 fighting hunger and malnutrition is a priority.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 Parliament's motion for a resolution of the Committee on Development deals with global nutrition and food security. It focuses on the importance of breastfeeding for human development and later life, food waste – the European Union produces a total of 88 million tonnes of food waste per year, while 842 million people worldwide, 12% of the world's population, are starving – with the priority of local food production, support for small farmers and female farmers as food producers, access to farmland, the effects of the production of food crop-based biofuels and the right to water. It recalls the Commission's commitment to spend EUR 3.5 billion to reduce the backlog of development by at least EUR 7 million by 2025 and expects the Commission to comply with this commitment. I voted in favour of the draft resolution.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. This is a resolution on the Commission's commitment of EUR 3.5 billion on food security, of which EUR 400 million is specifically on nutrition. Support for food self-sufficiency and localism are essential. In this sense, the genetic diversity of seeds must be encouraged. Food sovereignty is one of the keys for these populations, to avoid emigration to Europe and malnutrition. Women's education programmes are also offered. The issue of food waste is addressed (every year 88 million tonnes are wasted in the European Union).  Of course, all these measures also call for new investments, which this resolution estimates at 7 billion/year to achieve the objectives.  Vote in favour.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. Sustainable Development Goals 2 aims to eradicate hunger and malnutrition by 2030, including by ensuring opportunities to increase the productivity of smallholder farmers and creating sustainable agriculture and food systems resilient to climate change. I believe that the EU should take political leadership in this area and promote globally the achievement of internationally accepted nutrition objectives. I advocate reinvestment in local food production, focusing mainly on small food producers and agro-ecological practices, since in my view it is a fundamental condition for the success of nutrition strategies. It is vital to promote nutrition education programmes in schools and local communities, as well as to advocate "right to breastfeeding" worldwide and to strengthen information campaigns on maternal and child health.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. Support for food self-sufficiency and localism is essential. In this sense, the genetic diversity of seeds is encouraged. Indeed, food sovereignty is one of the keys for these populations, to avoid emigration to Europe and malnutrition. Programmes such as women's education (the right to breast-feeding necessary to combat malnutrition, etc.) are also proposed. The issue of food waste is addressed (recall: every year 88 million tonnes are wasted in the European Union). Of course, all these measures also call for new investments, which this resolution estimates at 7 billion/year to achieve the objectives. This while calling for specific indicators to assess the results of the EU Action Plan. So I'm voting for it.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution on the European Union's global goals and commitments on nutrition and food security around the world. Indeed, I am opposed to the fact that this text calls on the European Union to remove incentives for the production of biofuels from food crops. The introduction of new fuels, which are less harmful to the environment, is fundamental to the survival of future generations.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: in writing. – I supported the resolution as I consider it necessary to take more responsible and long-term financial security measures in the field of food and nutrition. I support the idea of reinvesting in local food production, aimed in particular at small food producers and agri-environmental practices, and I believe this is a key condition for the success of food strategies.  Progress in the fight against malnutrition remains insufficient, given that 795 million people worldwide do not have enough food to lead a decent and active life.  This figure is shocking given that the EU alone throws away 88 million tonnes of food a year. Inappropriate food intake during the first 1 000 days of children's life has decisive health, social and economic consequences.  Given that 161 million children worldwide suffer from chronic malnutrition, I believe that the role of the European institutions on the subject is quite responsible for taking long-term and effective measures to ensure a better way of life for people who are suffering from food and water shortages today. I believe that the creation of social protection schemes that will ensure that all persons have access to nutritious food at all times is of the utmost importance.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the motion for a resolution. We see the European Union as an important global player with certain duties. It is high time we played a role in maintaining the world's food and nutrition security. We must be able to provide rapid and effective assistance, but at the same time offer long-term solutions. I think it is a great idea to set a good example in third countries – teach them how to make good use of their farmland in order to create their own daily living.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ Food as part of the right to an adequate standard of living is recognised by the Universal Declaration of Human Rights of 1948. I have voted for this proposal that reaffirms the importance of ending global starvation through the action of national, local, governmental, non-governmental and private actors.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report as it proposes a realistic approach to the situations that cause malnutrition in all its forms. An important point is the invitation to both the EU and the international community to advocate with a common voice in favour of the 'right to breastfeeding', an extremely important issue for both the mother and the development of children. One aspect taken into account in the report is the one concerning encouraging small farmers to adopt agricultural practices that ensure production in line with market needs, which is a necessary condition for improving food security and nutrition. Last but not least, the report insists on everyone's right to water, an idea not included in human rights, but which is complementary to the right to food.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution, which rightly points to the persistent inadequacy of the level of investment in nutrition, with only 0.57% of total ODA devoted to nutrition interventions in 2014, covering only 1.4% of total needs. The resolution points out that one of the most significant obstacles to human development is the lack of growth, when the child's age is too small and which occurs in the case of chronic inadequate nutrition and repeated infections during the first 1 000 days of life that hinder the normal growth and development of the child. The Commission should therefore fulfil its commitment to invest EUR 3.5 billion in order to reduce by at least 7 million the number of children affected by under-growth by 2025. It should be added, however, that of the EUR 3.5 billion promised, only EUR 400 million is intended to support nutrition interventions, while the remaining EUR 3.1 billion is not for the immediate causes of malnutrition, but for addressing nutrition-related problems such as agriculture, food security, water, sanitation and education.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report because the report opposes the privatisation of seeds. The report also advocates cooperation with local farmers.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. As things stand, one in three people in the world suffers from some form of malnutrition. Around 161 million children worldwide suffer from chronic malnutrition. The EU generates 88 million tonnes of food waste a year, while 12% of the world's population is starving. It is essential to adapt food systems in such a way as to put an end to food losses and food waste. Eu Member States, as well as the Commission, must pay attention to policy coherence for development in their activities and assess the impact of trade, agriculture, energy and other policies on global food security.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. – I support the resolution tabled.  The whole world must work together and contribute appropriately to efforts to eradicate hunger. There is an urgent need to address malnutrition and to implement the 2030 Agenda. In particular, it is necessary to prevent land grabbing and seed privatisation by foreign investors.  EU trade and development policy must help to promote food sovereignty and respect the right of local food producers to manage their land, seeds and water. It is also essential to mobilise long-term financial investments and to establish social protection schemes to ensure that all individuals always have access to nutritious food. It is also essential that the EU and its Member States take a firm stance not to support GMO crops in fulfilling their commitments in the field of nutrition and global food security.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on achieving the objective of eradicating hunger and malnutrition by 2030, in particular by ensuring opportunities to increase the productivity of small farms and by achieving sustainable and climate-resistant agricultural and food systems.  Currently, 159 million children are sick and 50 million are affected by reckless food waste. Malnutrition has a huge impact on growth and health and strengthens the cycle of poverty.  The level of investment remains insufficient. It is also important that the Commission is called upon to establish a clear policy framework to increase support for national social security networks, which have proven in various countries to be an important instrument for increasing resilience and reducing malnutrition.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP has voted against the non-legislative motion for a resolution for Global goals and EU commitments on nutrition and food security in the world. This calls on Member States to financially invest in projects, but this could lead to a misuse of funds. Also it calls on the EU to influence countries on nationalising industries, but the EU has no right to intervene in nation state affairs. UKIP does not support the increasing influence of the EU over nation states.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 The right to food is one of the pillars of the 1948 Universal Declaration of Human Rights. In talking about the right to food, reference is made to a complex right, which can only be fully achieved when poverty and inequalities are drastically reduced. Important steps have now been taken to reduce malnutrition, but these are still too uncertain and irregular. A single response is needed, guaranteeing and also protecting access to land, without which there could be no question of the right to food. Given its position on the international stage, the European Union must necessarily adopt the means at its disposal to eradicate the unfortunately still current problem of malnutrition. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – I supported this resolution as I believe it will be an added value to the fight against under-nutrition and hunger. Eradicating hunger and malnutrition is a long-term commitment of the EU, which has the ambition to be a global leader on the path towards the achievement of Sustainable Development Goal 2 of the Agenda 2030 (ending hunger by 2030). The resolution underlines that local food production should be given priority in actions against under-nutrition and stresses the importance of supporting smallholder and female farmers as food producers.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ Although many Europeans have taken food safety for granted, we must bear in mind that this is not a problem of the past, nor does it exclusively concern developing countries. I support the SDG, which aims to eradicate hunger and malnutrition by 2030 by increasing the productivity of smallholders, achieving sustainable agricultural and food systems resilient to climate change, capable of feeding the world's population. It is our responsibility to provide citizens with sufficient, safe and healthy food at affordable prices. This must be ensured while maintaining the competitiveness of the European agricultural sector and while protecting farmers' living standards. Malnutrition is also a serious public health problem in rich countries where people do not get enough vitamins and minerals that are necessary for growth, functionality of the organism and health and the fight against diseases. Also worrying is the rise in obesity in Europe, where half of adults and one third of children in the EU are estimated to be overweight. Therefore, I believe that we must implement actions and information programs to promote nutrition and healthy eating, especially for children for whom healthy eating is essential.  I supported this resolution, inter alia, because I believe that responsible use of food resources can contribute to the well-being of EU residents and contribute to improving environmental and climate conditions globally.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. Linda McAvan (S-D) proposes a question to the Commission followed by a resolution on the Commission's commitment of 3.5 billion euros, of which 400 million are specifically on nutrition. 159 million children are stunted, 50 million suffer from emaciation. The Commission's action plan plans to reduce the number of stunted children by 7 million by 2015. In 2014, only 0.57 per cent of official development assistance was devoted to the immediate causes of undernutrition. The issue takes into account other forms of undernutrition, increased investment to combat the causes of undernutrition and the establishment of 'social safety nets'. Social protection schemes must thus guarantee access to land and its management to avoid being taken over by foreign multinationals or third countries. Support for food self-sufficiency and localism are essential. In this sense, the genetic diversity of seeds is encouraged. Food sovereignty is one of the keys. Education programs are also offered. The issue of food waste is addressed. These measures require significant investment (7 billion/year) but would be really useful. I therefore vote for this text.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because the achievement of Sustainable Development Goal 2 (SDG2), which aims to put an end to the problem of hunger and malnutrition by 2030, must be a priority for the European Union and, in particular, for the Commission. Currently more than 200 million children suffer from food shortages. Malnutrition has a devastating impact on their health and development. Investment, which is still insufficient, should be increased and focused on improving the productivity of small farms, on building sustainable and climate-resilient agricultural and food systems. Equally important is the development of social safety nets. The Commission, the Council, the Member States and the international community, as well as the governments of the developing countries, must immediately commit themselves to combating all forms of malnutrition by mobilising the necessary long-term financial investments. Through better and more accountable governance, it is necessary to ensure systematic policies on food and nutrition, based on rights, taking into account the gender dimension, access to natural resources, water, sanitation and, at the same time, providing inclusive social safety nets, in particular for the most vulnerable and marginal groups.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. This resolution addresses recurring themes: food security in the world, hunger and malnutrition. We know how often the pious intentions that seem to justify resolutions of this kind do not serve more than to open more doors to the advancement of multinationalagro-business. However, this resolution, which contains positive aspects, should not be stressed, all the more so since some are unusual. To this end, the amendments we have tabled have also contributed, although not all of them have been accepted. Proposals that focused on: - Criticism and condemnation of free trade agreements, in particular their impact on nutrition and food security in the world and their contribution to inequalities; - the defence of the control and public ownership of seeds and the guarantee of affordable prices for it and other factors of production; - the incompatibility between the private logic of maximising profit, in particular of large multinationals in the agri-food sector, and the fight against hunger and food security; - condemning the support and practice of export-friendly agricultural policies, favourable to large agrarians; - The repudiation of land expropriation by foreign "investors" in the least developed countries. We value the fact that some of these points are included in the resolution.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 I believe that it is important to ensure universal access to a healthier and more sustainable diet for all people in all parts of the world. I therefore supported this motion for a resolution proposing measures to improve food security, improve nutrition, promote sustainable agriculture and eradicate hunger. Without coordinated policies at global and local level, we have no chance of improving the situation.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. Eradicating malnutrition and hunger in the world are commitments of the European Union, particularly in the framework of Agenda 2030. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution, which is part of the preparations for the UN High Level Summit on Nutrition to be held in 2016. We call for greater coherence between all EU nutrition and food security instruments. In this context, EU Member States must be aware of their responsibility for the emergence of long-term food security, including promoting the development of sustainable agriculture and local production.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. The eradication of hunger and malnutrition are long-standing commitments of the European Union and are even intended to eradicate this scourge by 2030. It is worrying that today, in 2016, 795 million people in the world do not have a diet that will allow them to lead a dignified and active life; it is truly shameful that one in three people in the world suffers from malnutrition and that, according to UNICEF, 2,000 children die daily from water pollution-related diseases. This report reiterates the importance of truly coordinated and accelerated actions undertaken by different actors at global, national and local level in order to meet the 2030 Agenda and achieve the sustainable development goals for the eradication of hunger. In addition, the report encourages the Commission and the Member States to coordinate their trade, agriculture and energy policies, among others, in view of the teleos mentioned above. I advocate sustainable agricultural production and the fight against food waste. In this sense, it is pressing to reform and adapt food systems with a view to eliminating food loss or waste. So, in going to this report at the heart of this issue, my vote can only be in favour.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the European Parliament's resolution on global objectives and EU commitments on nutrition and food security. One of the global sustainable development targets on the Global 2030 Agenda is to reduce poverty and malnutrition, which is why I support increased productivity of small producers in rural areas, the idea of sustainability in the agricultural sector and responsible management at European and global level in the food industry. Food and nutrition depend on the earth's resources and how they are managed. That is why I believe that at national level, every country must protect these resources and refuse their alienation.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP has voted against the non-legislative motion for a resolution for Global goals and EU commitments on nutrition and food security in the world. This calls on Member States to financially invest in projects, but this could lead to a misuse of funds. Also it calls on the EU to influence countries on nationalising industries, but the EU has no right to intervene in nation state affairs. UKIP does not support the increasing influence of the EU over nation states.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted negatively, although I believe that the human right to food can only be fully exercised when poverty and inequality are drastically reduced, equality is ensured and resilience to shocks is strengthened, in particular by creating rights-based social safety nets and ensuring full participation of vulnerable groups and safe access to land and their control , and the management of resources and other production goods, to smallholder farmers and farming communities. However, I cannot agree with the attempt to find all negative environmental aspects in agricultural activity in an absurd way.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. One of the Sustainable Development goals aims to eradicate hunger and malnutrition by 2030 by creating sustainable agriculture and food systems resilient to climate change, capable of feeding a global population of 8.5 billion people by 2030, while protecting the biodiversity, environment and interests and well-being of smallholder farmers. Progress has been made in reducing malnutrition, but these remain too slow and unequal. 795 million people in the world do not have enough food to lead a dignified and active life. A third of the world's produced food – about 1.3 billion tonnes – is wasted. Most of the waste occurs in North America and Oceania, where about 300 kg of food per person is wasted. The EU produces 88 million tonnes of food waste annually, while 842 million people worldwide, or 12% of the world's population, go hungry. Coordinated and accelerated actions undertaken by government, non-governmental and private actors at global, national and local level, including scientific and industrial research, are needed. Long-term financial investments in food and nutrition security and sustainable agriculture should be mobilised immediately.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. The first "Nutrition for Growth" summit took place in London in 2013, where twenty-three billion dollars and immediate measures to address nutrition problems were committed. The European Parliament's resolution wants to keep nutrition at the heart of the Union's political agenda. Hoping to make a significant impact before the new Tokyo 2020 summit, the importance of a high-level meeting on this issue is underlined with the aim of developing responses to nutrition challenges, encouraging food to boost the economy—at the continental level, Africa loses about 11% of its GDP due to poor food; curb malnutrition, especially during the first 1,000 days of life; and realize the vision of the Decade of Action on Nutrition (2016-2025) — which was launched in September during the United Nations General Assembly. For all this, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the next steps towards achieving the EU's global goals and commitments on nutrition and food security around the world. It calls for European development, trade and agriculture policies to take into account their impact on global food security. The resolution calls on the Commission and the Council to take the lead in nutrition and food security in August 2016 in Brazil and to invest more in this area by taking a comprehensive approach.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution on the follow-up to global objectives and on the EU's commitments on nutrition and food security in the world. Currently, 795 million people worldwide are affected by climate change. people do not receive enough food to live a decent and active life. At the same time, however, one third of the world's food production is around 1.3 billion tonnes. tonnes is wasted. In the European Union alone, 88 million people are wasted. tons of food. Thus, in order to address food shortages, all food systems must first be adapted to avoid food losses. Secondly, it is necessary to promote food production where it is lacking, rather than spending millions on exporting it, thereby increasing the problems of climate change. Therefore, the funds used to address the problem of food security must be used to teach local people and introduce new technologies. On the other hand, it is necessary to ensure that food is safe and healthy. Feeding starving is important, but food can not become poison.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. The eradication of hunger and the fight against malnutrition is a long-term commitment of the European Union (EU), which aims to be a global leader in promoting and implementing the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) contained in the 2030 Agenda. In 2010, the EU adopted a global food security policy framework where it defined food and sustainable agriculture as key priorities, and also aimed to provide support to developing countries facing enormous food security challenges. This framework was followed in 2015 by a food action plan describing how to achieve the commitments to reduce nnoism in children under the age of five by at least 10% by 2025, and where the strategic objectives of the development cooperation policy have been defined in this regard. However, while there has been progress over the past few years, there are currently 795 million people around the globe who do not have access to adequate food. These issues require swift, effective and proactive action, because we are in the presence of a basic condition inherent in human life itself, so I hope that this report can contribute to the resolution of this sad fatality.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on nutrition and food security which recognises the right to food as a human right. The resolution also refers to the threat that land grabbing in developing countries poses to the overall objectives on nutrition and food security, calling for concrete measures to ensure land tenure security. Finally, I think it is very positive, too, that the resolution emphasizes that the privatization of seeds and GMOs poses a threat to the food sovereignty of countries.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report on attaining global goals and EU commitments on nutrition and food security. Achieving the sustainable development goals implies a much more sophisticated management of natural resources than is currently in place. Ending hunger and malnutrition, especially in the context of a growing world population, will require significant improvements in terms of land use and resource efficiency.  Adapting agricultural practices and prioritising resilience to climate change will be essential if we are to increase food production and improve diets without placing unsustainable demands on natural resources and ecosystem services. An integrated approach which addresses issues including land use, agriculture, diet, and climate change is necessary if we are to achieve our ambitious global goals.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on EU global targets and commitments on food and food security worldwide.  Combating hunger and malnutrition is a long-term task of the EU, which has been pursued as a priority since 2010.  Some progress has already been made, and yet they are happening too slowly, as 795 million people still do not have proper access to adequate food. The European Parliament calls for better coordination of the EU's various instruments and programmes and calls on member states to promote sustainable agriculture and local food production.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it proposes mechanisms in the face of the situation of nutrition and food security in the world with which I agree. It is the case to support smallholder farmers and farmers, sustainable and climate-resilient agriculture, the establishment of public policy-based rights, effective measures to combat land grabbing in developing countries, the gender dimension and seed privatization.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Food and food security will be challenging in the near future due to increasing pressure on resources. The number of people in the world is projected to increase significantly by 2050, which will necessitate increased food production, reduced food waste and its availability worldwide, particularly where access is currently limited.  It is very important to promote educational programmes in schools and local communities on nutrition in order to develop healthy eating habits and to develop a culture of sensible food shopping. From the point of view of global food security, support should also be given to small farmers. Increasing awareness and expectations of consumers about food and its quality and impact on human health can also be an opportunity for small family farms.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted for the motion on Global goals and EU commitments on nutrition and food security in the world. The report underlines the importance of ending hunger and malnutrition by 2030, notably by increasing the productivity of smallholders’ farms, achieving sustainable and climate resilient agriculture and food systems. We want to see the European Commission, the Council, the Member States and the international community, as well as developing countries’ governments commit to fighting all forms of malnutrition and to mobilise long-term financial investments for food and nutrition security and sustainable agriculture.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing. ‒ This report calls on the Commission in particular to increase its investment in nutrition-specific interventions, given the current huge funding gap, and to address under-nutrition and food waste. As I believe that the Sustainable Development Goals need to be met, I voted in favour.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒Nutrition and food security poses one of the biggest global challenges.  Devastating data is that today, in the 21st century, 795 million people (one in nine) are malnourished, and 161 million children in the world are lagging behind in growth due to chronic malnutrition, of which 3.1 million die every year. Sustainable development aims to eradicate hunger and reduce unhealthy diets by 2030 by increasing the productivity of small businesses by achieving sustainable agricultural and food systems resilient to climate change. On the other hand, the importance of sustainable agricultural and rural development, responsible and climate-sensitive investments in the agricultural sector and the role of small producers is still neglected, so I believe that these areas are those that need to be highlighted and pointed out again. It is very important to improve the relationship between people and their physical environment in order to implement integration with three dimensions of sustainable development - economic, social and environmental.  If properly handled, agriculture, forestry and fisheries can provide healthy food for all and generate decent income and at the same time support people focused on rural development and environmental protection. Therefore, I hereby call for specialisation in the green technologies and environmental entrepreneurship sectors in order to solve this problem as soon as possible.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Although progress has been made in reducing malnutrition over the last period, it is too slow and unbalanced. At present, 795 million people in the world do not have enough food to lead a dignified active life, and one in three people suffers from some form of malnutrition. The human right to food can only be fully ensured if poverty and inequality are significantly reduced. I find the UNICEF statistics alarming, according to which 2 000 children under the age of five die every day from diseases caused by water pollution, and that half of the hospital beds in the world are taken up by people suffering from diseases caused by poor drinking water quality. On the other hand, statistics show that one third of the food produced worldwide – around 1.3 billion tonnes – is discarded. 88 million tonnes of food waste are produced annually in the EU. That is why the EU must play a greater role in nutrition and food security in the world, take effective action against food waste and ensure sufficient nutrition for children and vulnerable people, especially women, mothers and the elderly.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. Sustainable agricultural policy must necessarily also include combating malnutrition or insufficient nutrition. Support for smaller farmers and family farms, which, through the diversity of the cultures they cultivate, can make a key contribution to the agricultural strategy of emerging countries, must be at the forefront. In this respect, the EU should commit to fundamental shifts towards organic farming. The resolution thus confirms the importance of coordinated and accelerated action by global, national, local, governmental, non-governmental and private actors in addressing the inautrition to meet the objectives of the 2030 agenda and the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goal to end hunger. Parliament, through this resolution, therefore called on the Commission and the Member States to pay attention to PCD in their activities and to give due consideration to changes to their policies on trade, agriculture and energy in favour of global food security. A sustainable agricultural policy that works in favor of meeting the objectives of the 2030 Agenda is crucial for food security. For this reason, I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Bart STAES
text: Written. 'Sustainable Development Goal 2 (end hunger, achieve food safety, improve nutrition and promote sustainable agriculture) and the related targets are designed to end hunger and malnutrition by 2030.  If we want to counter this, we will not only have to focus on calorie intake, but a global food and agriculture approach that ensures a varied diet is much more decisive. Support for family agriculture and small scale must be the cornerstones of agricultural policy in developing countries. If small-scale farms make use of agro-ecological farming practices, they are best able to grow a diverse supply while boosting food production. Studies show this conclusively. Where the resolution was initially somewhat narrow, it now points to some important elements in achieving food security, in particular with regard to availability, affordability and control over seed, the problem of land grabs and the link between development cooperation, world trade and European energy policy.  More specifically, the emphasis now is on the importance of small-scale agriculture, agro-ecology, diversity of agricultural crops through seed legislation, GMOs and intellectual property rights, the negative effects of agricultural liberalisation on food rights and the negative impact of agro-fuels on food security.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 One in three people in the world suffers from malnutrition. Hunger and food shortages are a source of instability in society and a frequent cause of mass migration. It is in the European Union's interest to make such a development policy as to increase food volumes and improve access to them. First of all, we must promote domestic production and avoid creating dependence on tangible humanitarian aid.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒As the population is expected to reach 8.5 billion by 2030, the sustainable development and related tasks aim to eradicate hunger and malnutrition. Therefore, coordinated and as fast as possible action between global, national, local, governmental, non-governmental and private actors, including scientific and industrial research bodies and among donors, is of unassailable, in particular as regards reinvestment in local food production aimed primarily at small producers and agroecological practices, achieving sustainable agricultural and climate resilient food systems to feed the world's population, protecting biodiversity. However, I cannot support this motion for a resolution because I do not think it is well designed, and I certainly cannot agree with Article 13, which calls for the abolition of public incentives for the production of biofuels from crops which is opposed to the principles of our group.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The resolution concerns, in addition to food security, ensuring sustainable agriculture by improving governance and accountability. It also proposes systemic food and nutrition policies that take into account the gender dimension, sustainable agriculture, the use and access to natural resources, public waters, and public sanitation and hygiene. Finally, the rights of vulnerable and marginal groups are respected. For the above reasons we voted in favour.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution while initially in a good direction, then in a lateral way promotes private interests and mutants.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this motion because I believe that we need global solutions for the nutritional and food security of the world. International organisations and governments are seeking to eradicate malnutrition and hunger by 2030. This can be achieved by increasing productivity, sustainable and climate-adaptable agriculture and food production. An explicit aim is to eradicate child hunger in the recommendations of international organisations, which unfortunately can also be found in the EU. It is therefore necessary to put a number of issues in order in relation to the European Union before this issue can be resolved.  The Hungarian Government first began to communicate statistics on poverty more incompletely since 2010, and then simply changed its method of calculation. This masks the identity of disadvantaged families, the elderly and starving children, making it much more difficult to resolve the situation. I believe that making uniform European statistical calculations for children and pensioners mandatory could help to put an end to this outrageous practice. Furthermore, during the debate on the motion, I said that the high tax content of food not only deepens poverty and makes access to food more difficult, but also significantly reduces VAT fraud in the EU through differences in tax burdens. However, there is also a solution to this, namely an EU-wide harmonisation of food taxes.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union supports the achievement of the global sustainable development goals undertaken at international level by member states. These include defending the right to food and, at the same time, eradicating global hunger. Currently, no fewer than 161 million children are affected by chronic malnutrition worldwide, which has a negative impact on their development, and 41 million children under the age of five are overweight or obese. This situation must be adequately managed by specialised international bodies, but also by the EU and the Member States. In 2013 the EU committed to reducing child-rearing retardation by at least 7 million by 2025 and allocating EUR 3.5 billion for this purpose by 2020. However, the level of investment to ensure food security remains insufficient. The combined effort of the European institutions and EU Member States, as well as developing countries, is needed to ensure long-term investment in sustainable agriculture, responsible use of resources, elimination of waste, elimination of gender discrimination, ensuring public hygiene and protecting vulnerable groups. This resolution will help to improve the situation.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. It is important that global, national, local, governmental, non-governmental and private actors, including scientific and industrial research organizations and donors, take real coordinated and accelerated action to combat malnutrition in order to achieve the 2030 sustainable development agenda and achieve the second SDG of eliminating hunger. Food security and nutrition need to be improved through better governance, increased accountability and comprehensive, rights-based food and nutrition policies that take into account the gender dimension, sustainable agriculture, the use of natural resources and access to these resources, a public water service, a public sanitation system and hygiene. , and, on the other hand, the creation and extension of non-person-free social protection schemes focused on payment rights, with a particular focus on marginal and most vulnerable groups.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ Inadequate nutrition is one of the most significant impediments to human development and there is an absolute urgency to reach internationally agreed nutrition targets. Ending hunger and malnutrition by 2030 is the Sustainable Development Goal 2. Further, the Commission’s Nutrition Action Plan pledged to reduce stunting by 7 million children by 2025. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution calling for accelerated action to fulfil the 2030 Agenda and to reach SDG 2 to end hunger and to guarantee the development of social safety nets in order to reduce extreme poverty, as the level of investment in nutrition today remains inadequate. I believe the resolution, which calls for an additional EU commitment of EUR 1 billion addressing nutrition-specific interventions, represents a step in the right direction toward eradicating hunger, malnutrition and food waste.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Although there has been significant progress in improving global food safety, the overall number of chronically malnourished people remains unacceptable. This is why I think it is right that eradicating hunger has become one of the priorities under the SDGs of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. I also believe that among the most important items of the fight of the Agricultural Action Plan is to encourage responsible private sector involvement and learning from inclusive business models. This resolution encourages increased productivity of small businesses and the achievement of sustainable agricultural and food systems, and recognises rural transformation as a key process for job creation, increasing incomes and achieving long-term food security and nutrition. I believe that through the proposed integration of countries most affected by hunger into global trade and by maintaining food security and nutrition at the heart of global and national policies, progress will be made in the fight against malnutrition. Therefore, I supported this resolution.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the european Parliament's motion for a resolution on the next steps towards achieving the EU's global objectives and commitments on food security and food security in the world. The human right to food can only be fully guaranteed if poverty and inequality are radically reduced, equality is ensured and resilience to shocks is strengthened, in particular by establishing rights-based social safety nets and ensuring the full participation of vulnerable groups and ensuring that small farms have access to and control of land and can manage resources and other means of production. The motion for a resolution included some amendments that I could not support, but which were adopted. That is why I could not support the whole resolution.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on nutrition and food security which recognises the right to food as a human right. The resolution also refers to the threat that land grabbing in developing countries poses to the overall objectives on nutrition and food security, calling for concrete measures to ensure land tenure security. Finally, we consider it very positive, too, that the resolution emphasizes that privatization of seeds and GMOs poses a threat to countries' food sovereignty.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly support this report. I believe that nutrition and, in particular, children’s nutrition worldwide is a fundamental right that the EU should champion. This report calls on the Commission, the Council, the Member States and the international community, as well as developing countries’ governments, to mobilise, forthwith, long-term financial investments for food and nutrition security and sustainable agriculture, and to enhance food security and nutrition through improved governance and accountability and systemic policies on food and nutrition. I stress the need to tackle the systemic problems that generate poor nutrition in all its forms; I note with concern that, in the past, the promotion of export-led agriculture has operated at the expense of family farms producing food crops for local consumption.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. 159 million children are stunted, 50 million suffer from emaciation (linked to starvation). The Commission's action plan plans to reduce the number of stunted children by 7 million by 2015. In 2014, only 0.57 per cent of official development assistance was devoted to the immediate causes of undernutrition. Indeed, the resolution reminds us that by 2030, hunger and malnutrition are supposed to be reduced, in particular by relying on small producers and farms which are essential links. Social protection schemes are supposed to be put in place, guaranteeing, among other things, access to land and its management by these populations. This while avoiding land grabbing by foreign multinationals or countries like China. The aim is to stop this, to prevent them from getting their hands on this land because they are excluding local producers who could use these farms for the benefit of local food crops, helping their people to sustain themselves. Support for food self-sufficiency and localism are essential. In this sense, the genetic diversity of seeds is encouraged. Indeed, food sovereignty is one of the keys for these populations, to avoid emigration to Europe and malnutrition. I voted for it.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The European Union's policies and actions for sustainable development have a global impact. An important test of this responsible role is to contribute to the fight against food scarcity in the world. I agree with the assertion that systemic problems must be eliminated to this end. Hunger and malnutrition often result not so much from a lack of food, but from its improper distribution. A third of the food produced is then wasted.  Moreover, as the resolution rightly points out, more support is needed for small farmers and local agriculture. It is crucial to ensure that local people have access to land and to counter land buy-back practices. It is also well-known to call on the European Commission to increase these investments, which will directly address the problem of child malnutrition. Member States should consistently support the steps in the direction indicated. I supported this resolution by vote.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Coordinated and accelerated action is needed to eradicate malnutrition in order to comply with the 2030 Agenda and achieve the 2nd SDGs on the eradication of hunger. A third of the food produced worldwide, some 1.3 billion tonnes, is wasted, while 842 million people worldwide – 12% of the world's population – are starving. The Commission must fulfil its obligations and provide, in accordance with its task, appropriate forms of support for the eradication of hunger. I supported the decision.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on nutrition and food security which recognises the right to food as a human right. The resolution also refers to the threat that land grabbing in developing countries poses to the overall objectives on nutrition and food security, calling for concrete measures to ensure land tenure security. Finally, we consider it very positive, too, that the resolution emphasizes that privatization of seeds and GMOs poses a threat to countries' food sovereignty.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the resolution because in a context where the right to food depends among others on access to land and other productive resources, the EU should strive to remove inconsistencies of its sectorial policies that jeopardise food security and contribute directly or indirectly to land-grabbing, i.e. as in the case of its biofuel policy or its investment trade strategy.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – I agree with the need to address systemic problems that lead to all forms of malnutrition. I believe that reinvestment in local food production, with a particular focus on small food producers and agro-ecological practices, is a key condition for the successful implementation of dietary strategies. I believe that it is also extremely important to establish social security schemes to ensure that all individuals always have access to nutritious food.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the motions for resolutions on the next steps towards attaining global goals and EU commitments on nutrition and food security in the world. SDG 2 and its associated targets aim at ending hunger and malnutrition by 2030, notably by securing opportunities for and increasing the productivity of smallholders, and achieving sustainable and climate-resilient agriculture and food systems which are capable of feeding an expected global population of 8.5 billion by 2030 while protecting biodiversity, the environment, and smallholders’ interests and wellbeing. The resolution stresses the need to tackle the systemic problems that generate poor nutrition in all its forms. It equally underlines that the human right to food can only be fully achieved when poverty and inequality are drastically reduced, equality is ensured and resilience to shocks is enhanced. I voted in favour because I believe that it is essential to establish social protection schemes to ensure that all individuals have access to nutritious food at all times.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. Eradicating hunger and malnutrition is a long-term commitment of the Union, which has set out to lead the world's path towards ending hunger by 2030. In view of this year's United Nations Nutrition Summit, this text seeks to take good note of the progress that has been made, but also of the challenges ahead – as the reality today is that 795 million people do not yet have adequate access to food and that one in three people are malnourished. In this way, the Eurochamber calls on Member States to intensify their commitments to global food security, giving priority to sustainable agriculture and local production. It also calls for clear indicators to be used in monitoring the implementation of measures and in the progress made under the Community Action Plan, as well as the 2030 Agenda. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it proposes mechanisms in the face of the situation of nutrition and food security in the world with which I agree. It is the case to support smallholder farmers and farmers, sustainable and climate-resilient agriculture, the establishment of public policy-based rights, effective measures to combat land grabbing in developing countries, the gender dimension and seed privatization.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted for the motion on Global goals and EU commitments on nutrition and food security in the world. The report underlines the importance of ending hunger and malnutrition by 2030, notably by increasing the productivity of smallholders’ farms, achieving sustainable and climate resilient agriculture and food systems. We want to see the Commission, the Council, the Member States and the international community, as well as developing countries’ governments, commit to fighting all forms of malnutrition and to mobilise long-term financial investments for food and nutrition security and sustainable agriculture.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. A third of global food production – around 1.3 billion tonnes – is wasted every year. In the EU, this means that a total of 88 million tonnes of food waste is produced every year, while 842 million people worldwide, or 12% of the world's population, go hungry. Children in developing countries who are breastfed are 15 times less likely to die from pneumonia and 11 times less from diarrhoea than those who are not breastfed. This report calls on the Commission to show greater leadership in food and nutrition security by taking its promises to a higher level through an additional COMMITMENT of EUR 1 billion to the UN, by developing a clear strategy setting out how it intends to apply and integrate these objectives into its plans and policies and by providing a clear roadmap for the allocation of the committed funds for 2016-2020. I voted for this vital policy.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. Next steps towards achieving the EU's global goals and commitments on nutrition and food security around the world (2016/2705 (RSP)) The completion of the UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), including the second to eliminate hunger and malnutrition by 2030, is expected to be a fundamental issue at European and global level. Today, 795 million people do not have enough food to lead an active life worthy of the name. The resolution passed by the European Parliament stresses the need for public water services, the extension of social protection schemes or the need to promote local production and smallholder farmers. Similarly, the goal of achieving food sovereignty is highlighted especially for the poorest countries. Finally, calling for an increase in EU commitments (an additional $1 billion) specifically for nutrition in order to achieve the SDG targets is also a step in the right direction. I therefore vote for this report, hoping that it will not remain a dead letter.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The question and resolution arise following several objectives outlined and commitments made at international level, and therefore fall within a scenario in which it is necessary to work to achieve the second sustainable development objective – Zero hunger and sustainable agriculture – by 2030. Although the resolution contains positive aspects, it omits key aspects such as the issue of food sovereignty and respect for national decisions in terms of development policies, which contrasts with the apology for the role of the private sector in improving food security and strengthening specific nutrition interventions.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The resolution addresses and criticises increasing privatisation and land grabs as a threat to food security. It also calls on the Commission and the international community to support small farmers and to take action to curb malnutrition. I have therefore voted in favour of this motion.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the next steps towards achieving the EU's global objectives and commitments on food and food security in the world. Sustainable Development Goal 2 and its associated goals aim to end hunger and malnutrition by 2030. However, given that 795 million people in the world currently do not have enough food to lead a normal life and that one in three people suffers from malnutrition, the resolution reiterates the need to create adequate food safety nets and more sustainable agriculture through increased financial investment to ensure that the Commission, the Council, the Member States and the international community actively work together to put an end to this problem.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ As a children’s rights and women’s rights champion, it is important for me to join in the call to eliminate malnutrition and hunger in the world. The EU must ensure policy coherence for sustainable development, trade, and economic and humanitarian assistance in order to achieve that goal and should therefore give more attention to the Alternative Trade Mandate and the field work of organisations such as CARE International and World Vision.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution drawn up following a deve question to the Commission and focusing on further steps towards achieving the EU's global objectives and commitments in the field of nutrition and food security in the world. This resolution aims to eradicate hunger and malnutrition by 2030. It notes that, although some progress has already been made in reducing malnutrition, it is too slow and unbalanced, and therefore looks at ways to accelerate progress in this area and identifies major obstacles. Among other measures, it highlights the benefits of long-term investments, in particular in local food production, the promotion of crop diversity and citizens' access to land. It also calls on the Commission to take a stronger role in the area of food security and stresses the need to combat food waste and to support nutrition education programmes. I consider the resolution as a whole to be balanced and, in my opinion, is right to identify the main objectives and possible ways of achieving them, with a focus on a holistic approach. That's why I gave him my vote.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the EU's overall nutrition and food security commitments in the world because I agree with the urgency of achieving sustainable development goals and their associated goals, such as the eradication of hunger and malnutrition by 2030. I would like to call on this resolution to the European institutions and the international community to immediately mobilise long-term financial investments in food and nutrition security. I also stress the need to address the systemic problems that are the cause of malnutrition, especially when a third of the food produced in the world is wasted (around 1.3 billion tonnes).  To this end, the EU should work with its international partners, including through its network of delegations around the world, to support the definition and implementation of nutrition targets to reduce growth delays and malnutrition.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the resolution setting out the objectives to be achieved by the EU and the instruments it can use to meet its global commitments on food security in the world. The EU is committed to reducing growth delays by at least 7 million by 2025 and to allocating EUR 3.5 billion for achieving this target in the period 2014-2020. So far, progress has been made in reducing malnutrition, but it is still too slow and irregular. Currently, 795 million people worldwide do not have enough food to lead a normal and active life, and one in three people suffer from a form of malnutrition. We need to do more. This report calls for support for small farmers and local farmers to be placed at the centre of action to combat malnutrition in order to give priority to local production. We are talking about agricultural policies for sustainable development with a focus on the environment. All issues that have found my favor.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. - I voted against the resolution because a majority of Members supported Part 2 of paragraph 13, which called on the EU to abolish public initiatives for the production of crop-based bio-fuels. Like my political group, the EES is in favour of a reform that will bring better bio-fuels or second generation bio-fuels.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European The main objective, or at least one of the main objectives of the use of so-called EU funds, would have been to create a strong Hungarian entrepreneurial class, a strong citizenry, who would have received orders from these EUROPEAN Union funds. What happened compared to this? Constantly, through governments, Eu funds were embezzled, stolen in such a way that pals and pals were distributed among themselves, and some oligarchs got rich with this money. It is therefore difficult to vote for the EU Public Prosecutor's Office, because it would be very good if there was an organisation that would control, stop and take action against these stealths. At the same time, this would be a strong interference in our national sovereignty. I have therefore taken a neutral position and I hope that the Hungarian Public Prosecutor's Office will get to the point where it does not fulfill political orders, but enforces the law.

name: Seán KELLY
text: In Uachtariain ars, bhà d'ospàireacht againn faoin 'bhar seo go deanach arerir his Pharlaimint. D'éisteas go géar leis an meid a bhà le rà ag an gcoimisinéir agus ag na feisirà agsa agus bhà suimiil agus bhà se beagnach ar aon fhocal faoi cad ba chàir deinn a rà. No raibh seans agam féin labhairt ach tà an seans agam anois. Ach caithfidh mes a rà gur ceart deinn gach rud a dhéanamh chun troid i gcoinne caimiléireacht de gach saghas. Is cuma an dtagann se sé 'n Stàt no' esapà esasa ne thionscal nà daoine aonar-nacha. Agus chun é sin a dheanamh caithfimid comhoibri, sin an rud is tàbhachta; comhoibri lena cheile le Ballstàit agus uile trasna na hEorpa.
