Agus chun buiséad a thabhairt do Eurojust agus na daoine eile ata ag iarraidh a nd-cheall a dheanamh chun cothrom na Féinne a thabhairt do gach duine agus troid i gcoinne caimileireachta.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – Mr President, European money fraud is estimated at over EUR 500 million each year. And in the last ten years the rate of prosecution has been 31% of the hundreds of judicial recommendations made by OLAF. In short, what we have today is not working and European people, European citizens continue to be stolen. Parliament therefore asks the Council, when it comes to The proposal in Parliament for the creation of the European Prosecutor's institution, at least: the Priority Competence of the European Prosecutor over all the offences of the PIF Directive, including the carousel of VAT. Secondly, sufficient access to investigative means. Thirdly, the importance of avoiding the negative effects of national links. Fourthly, obviously, the protection of the rights of the suspect and the persons indicted. My message to the Council is very simple: we will not accept a weak text, which creates a weak institution, because European citizens' money will continue to be stolen.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I, of course, agree with my pre-ers that we must fight fraud, that it is the task of all institutions within the European Union, but as regards the very establishment and functioning of the Public Prosecutor's Office in criminal matters, I am quite sceptical about its functioning.  Undoubtedly, the investigating authorities must cooperate, that is, the components that we are already setting up, whether it is Eurojust or Europol, but the criminal process, which is controlled quite fundamentally by national principles, that is, it is procedured according to criminal law mostly national, so at that moment, in my opinion, such a public prosecutor will have a very difficult situation. And it would be better if we actually cooperated in the investigation and left the level of the criminal process at that judicial stage to the national prosecutors. For this reason too, I abstained from this vote.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: Written. Today, the European Parliament voted on a resolution on a European Public Prosecutor's Office, with the fight against fraud as its task. Such a proposal was presented last term by the European Commission, and has long been contentious, but has so far not received support in the Council of Ministers. In Sweden, the Riksdag's Justice Committee has in full agreement rejected the proposal in a so-called subsidiarity review. This type of exercise of authority is simply considered to belong at national level. I share that assessment and therefore voted against the resolution.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 It is of paramount importance that the EU and all its Member States effectively and dissuasively detect and prosecute fraud affecting the financial interests of the Union, thereby protecting taxpayers in all Member States. This resolution therefore reiterates Parliament's support for the establishment of an effective and independent European Public Prosecutor's Office, thereby strengthening the fight against fraud in the European Union and reducing the fragmentation of national interventions in this regard. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP MEPs voted against this motion for resolution. UKIP does not support the establishment of a European Public Prosecutor’s Office, which will have powers that greatly infringe on national sovereignty.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. The establishment of a European Public Prosecutor's Office, when there is no legal system at European level, is something on which different organisations of jurists have expressed numerous doubts. We understand that, as the institution thinks in this resolution, born on the right, there is no guarantee of the democratic rights that people accused of a crime in the Member States have today. Moreover, the relationship between this prosecutor's office and the courts of the different States, or with the law forces and law forces, is not clarified. Since the conviction that the principle of transparency is fundamental in law, we cannot accept a model that would delve de further into the deficits already in many States, including Spanish. Our model is the necessary coordination of the different judicial systems of the Union, not in creating structures that act in parallel with them, so I have decided to vote against them.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. Our support for the creation of a European public prosecutor's office is not unconditional. Some of the changes to the Commission's proposal introduced by the Council present real dangers regarding the independence, efficiency and added value of such a floor.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the European Public Prosecutor’s Office and Eurojust. I welcome the fact that the resolution calls on the Council to provide an unambiguous and clear set of competences and proceedings concerning the European Public Prosecutor’s Office (EPPO) as well as to clarify the relations between Eurojust and the EPPO. The resolution also relates to a separate proposal for a directive that aims at combating fraud against the EU’s financial interests – also known as the PIF Directive which is highly relevant knowing that for instance between 2010 and 2012, an average of EUR 500 million were suspected to have been defrauded each year in the Member States, though the actual extent of the fraud is estimated to be significantly greater. I supported this motion for a resolution, especially having in mind that the European Parliament reaffirms its long-standing support for the establishment of an efficient and independent EPPO to reduce the current fragmentation of national law enforcement efforts to protect the EU budget, thus strengthening the fight against fraud in the European Union.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft resolution on the European Public Prosecutor's Office and Eurojust because I support its creation, but some changes to the Commission's proposal by the Council jeopardise the independence and effectiveness of any such project.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The text 'reaffirms its long-standing support for the establishment of an effective and independent European public prosecutor's office to reduce the current fragmentation of national law enforcement efforts to protect the EU budget, which would strengthen the fight against fraud in the European Union'. The fight against fraud is therefore being used to create yet another body of the European Union. It should operate alongside Eurojust and OLAF. Eurojust was created to facilitate coordination and cooperation between national authorities responsible for investigating and prosecuting cases involving several Member States. The creation of a European Public Prosecutor's Office is a new step in the development of a European criminal law, while it must remain a competence of the Member States.  I obviously voted against this report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ This matter was not the subject of a roll-call vote. In the interests of democracy and transparency, I would like to confirm that I voted against.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution because I would like to reaffirm my long-standing support for the establishment of an effective and independent European public prosecutor's office to reduce the current fragmentation of national repression efforts to protect the UNION's budget, which would strengthen the fight against fraud in the European Union. It will be necessary to ensure that this proposal does not become an empty shell.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for the European Public Prosecutor's Office and Eurojust. The final report ing 'Study and reporting on VAT gaps in the EU-28: Final Report 2016' shows that in 2014, a huge amount of value added tax (VAT) revenues amounting to EUR 159.5 billion were lost across the EU in 2014. In the light of the results of this investigation, it is essential that the EU and the Member States detect cases of fraud that are detrimental to the EU's financial interests. It is therefore necessary to establish an effective and independent European Public Prosecutor's Office in order to reduce the current fragmentation of national law enforcement and to protect the EU budget, thereby strengthening the fight against fraud in the EU. Mention should also be made of the importance of Eurojust's role in improving judicial cooperation and coordination between the relevant judicial authorities of the Member States and providing support for investigations involving non-EU countries. I therefore agree that the European Public Prosecutor's Office and Eurojust should operate in one place in order to ensure that cooperation and exchange of information between them take place effectively.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: Writing. \u2012 It is proposed that the EP support the establishment of an effective and independent European Public Prosecutor's Office to reduce the current fragmentation of national law enforcement efforts to protect the EU budget, thereby strengthening the fight against fraud in the European Union. As a reference, vat-related abuses are designated as references. The main problem with the proposal is that a prominent organisational tool in the process of integration, which is intended to gradually abolish nation-state sovereignty, would be the European Public Prosecutor's Office, which could be used abusively against those who act and act against the INTERESTS of the EU, not only against abusive users of EU funds. In 2013, the Hungarian Parliament found the concept of the European Public Prosecutor's Office to be in breach of the principle of subsidiarity and adopted a decision on this. Despite endorsing the aim, I did not support the proposal because of the possibility of abuse and the debasing of the sovereignty of the Member States.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs voted against this motion for resolution. UKIP does not support the establishment of a European Public Prosecutor’s Office which will have powers that greatly infringe on national sovereignty.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. The fight against fraud is therefore being used to create yet another body of the European Union. It should operate alongside OLAF and Eurojust. However, the latter agency was set up to facilitate coordination and cooperation between national authorities responsible for investigating and prosecuting cases involving several Member States. So I spoke out against this project.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. Parliament calls on the Council to define a clear and unequivocal set of powers and procedures relating to the European Public Prosecutor's Office, on the basis of the proposed anti-fraud directive affecting the Union's financial interests through criminal law (the 'PIF Directive'). We also call on it to intensify its efforts to reach an agreement on the inclusion of VAT in the scope of the PIF Directive and to reopen negotiations with Parliament to enable the creation of the European Public Prosecutor's Office.  The Council must abandon the rule depriving the European Public Prosecutor's Office of the possibility of exercising its jurisdiction for all offences under the PIF Directive in which the damage to the EU budget is less than or equal to that suffered by another victim.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on the European Public Prosecutor's Office. Under Article 86 TFEI, the Council, by means of regulations adopted in accordance with a special legislative procedure, may establish a European Public Prosecutor's Office from Eurojust to combat crimes, such as fraud, which affect the financial interests of the Union. The text adopted today reaffirms Parliament's support for the establishment of this instrument and calls on the Council to establish a set of clear and unambiguous competences and procedures for it, reopening the debate on the consolidated text. Above all, it is necessary to clarify the competences of the European Public Prosecutor's Office and national prosecutors in cases of multiple crimes and mixed crimes in criminal matters and to ensure that the public prosecutor's office itself has adequate investigative measures in place to conduct its own investigations. The regulation should also provide for additional rights of defence for suspects, such as the right to legal aid, the right of access to documentation relating to the investigation, the right to information and the right to submit evidence and to ask the European Public Prosecutor's Office to collect evidence on behalf of the suspect.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. I have decided to vote in favour of this resolution, because I understand that the establishment of an independent and effective European Public Prosecutor's Office is of great help in combating crimes comprising several countries and is in line with greater European integration of justice systems. We also note positively that the resolution calls for judicial cooperation, the classification of the system of powers and powers. I understand that a European Public Prosecutor's Office with sufficient powers and funds is a positive step forward and that is why I vote in favour.

name: Joëlle BERGERON
text: In writing. We all agree that the fight against fraud must be a political priority. Fraud and corruption clearly undermine our freedoms and democracies. However, I believe that we have enough European tools at our disposal today, including OLAF, Eurojust and Europol, not to add a new administrative, political and judicial stratum. The European Public Prosecutor's Office will be yet another structure, an umpteenth Theodule committee that will aim to apply a European law that does not yet exist. On the contrary, we should ensure that existing structures are even more efficient and operational. The Commission is working here on its classic technique of small steps by which it wants to impose a European justice system on us in defiance of national courts and rights. Enhanced cooperation between national prosecutors is working well between Member States. I am against the creation of this bureaucratic monster that would be the European Public Prosecutor's Office.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I would like to thank the rapporteur for her work on the Public Prosecutor's Office and Eurojust, which reiterates Parliament's traditional support for the establishment of an effective and independent European Public Prosecutor's Office, in order to reduce the current fragmentation of resources for the implementation of national legislation and to protect the Union budget, therefore strengthening the fight against fraud in the Union.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This proposal for a resolution on the European Public Prosecutor's Office and Eurojust reaffirms its support for the establishment of this effective and independent prosecutor's office. The aim is to reduce the current fragmentation of national enforcement efforts to protect the EU budget, which would strengthen the fight against fraud in the Union.  The fight against fraud is being used to create a new EU body that should operate alongside Eurojust and OLAF. Eurojust was created to facilitate coordination and cooperation between national authorities responsible for investigating and prosecuting cases involving several Member States.  Thus, the creation of a European public prosecutor's office is in fact a new step in the sneaky development of a European criminal law when it must remain exclusively a competence of the Member States. So I voted against it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 We do not need a 'European Public Prosecutor's Office'. It is crazy to think of entrusting the EU with control of the legal and judicial systems of the Member States. This is yet another attempt by the EU to focus these functions on itself, in order to protect the interests of the strong powers. I am therefore totally opposed to this clearly partisan report, so I voted against it.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. U2012 Resolution on the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office, EUROJUST and the Protection of the Union's Financial Interests, in a context where transnational criminal networks and fraud have increased in recent years.  Article 86 of the E TUE provides for the possibility of establishing a European Public Prosecutor's Office to combat offences affecting the Union's financial interests, where Eurojust has been playing a key role in coordinating the different ways of prosecuting fraud.  In a crisis such as the current one, fraud can be tackled and resources recovered, so the resolution adopted insists on strengthening the role of Eurojust and the European Public Prosecutor's Office; VAT is also an important Community resource which must be included in this legislation. For all this, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution in which the European Parliament notes that Eurojust has facilitated coordination and cooperation between national investigating and prosecuting authorities in cases affecting several Member States, as well as eurojust's contribution to building mutual trust and the interconnecting of the eu's various legal systems and traditions. In addition, Eurojust has facilitated cooperation requests and mutual recognition measures, thereby improving cross-border persecution. In this report, Parliament reaffirms the European Parliament's long-standing support for the creation of an effective and independent European Public Prosecutor's Office in order to reduce the current fragmentation of national law enforcement efforts and to protect the EU budget, thereby strengthening the fight against fraud in the European Union. It also takes the view that the European Public Prosecutor's Office should be provided with sufficient investigative tools to enable it to carry out its investigations. Parliament therefore calls on the Council to ensure that appropriate safeguards are in place to ensure the independence of the European Public Prosecutor's Office, such as a derogation from the national reference for reasons of proper functioning of the Public Prosecutor's Office. Parliament also believes that it would be best for the European Public Prosecutor's Office and Eurojust to operate in one place in order to ensure that cooperation and exchange of information between them take place effectively.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 Eurojust plays an important role in improving judicial cooperation and coordination between the competent judicial authorities of the Member States and in supporting investigations involving non-EU countries. I particularly support the part of the report which calls on the Council to clarify the relationship between Eurojust and the Eppo, in particular the implications of the collegiate structure and the EPPO's relationship with OLAF, in order to distinguish between their responsibilities in protecting the EU's financial interests.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. I also supported the proposed resolution on the European Public Prosecutor's Office and Eurojust. The resolution is in response to the findings of the final VAT deficit report in the 28 EU Member States in 2014, which found that as much as EUR 159.5 billion in VAT revenues were lost to the EU this year. As most of the amount lost is the result of fraud, the idea of establishing a European Public Prosecutor's Office must finally be realised. This would reduce the current fragmentation of national law enforcement efforts to protect the EU budget and strengthen the fight against fraud in the EU. Responsibility is now in the Council, which must establish unambiguous and clear competences and procedures for the European Public Prosecutor's Office, on the basis of the proposed directive on the protection of the EU's financial interests. I hope that the consensus on this directive will come as soon as possible, which would also mean the swifter establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. I support this Report on the European Public Prosecutor's Office and Eurojust. The Council has been slow, but there has been steady progress on the text for the establishment of a European Public Prosecution Service. Unfortunately, developments in the Council have created concerns, both within the European Parliament and in the Commission.  The main problems relate to the independence, efficiency and performance of the public prosecutor's office, so support for the establishment of this Office cannot be unconditional.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. I am opposed to the creation of a European public prosecutor's office, which is a new step in the development of a European criminal law, when it must remain a competence of the Member States. I voted against it.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because I support the establishment of an efficient and independent European Public Prosecutor’s Office to better protect the EU budget and fight against fraud. Moreover, I believe the Council should provide a set of clear competences to EPPO including investigation capacities. Last but not least, I think EPPO and Eurojust should operate in the same location in order to facilitate the information exchange.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Parliament is in favour of establishing an effective and independent European Public Prosecutor's Office, in order to reduce the current fragmentation of national interventions and to strengthen the fight against fraud in the European Union.  We must try to ensure the clarity and effectiveness of the European Public Prosecutor's Office and clarify its competences, especially in the field of criminal prosecution, and national prosecutors in cases of multiple crimes and mixed crimes. We must ensure that the European Public Prosecutor's Office has adequate investigative measures in place to conduct its own investigations. In addition, operational decisions of the European Public Prosecutor's Office concerning third parties should be subject to judicial review by a competent national court. The existence of appropriate safeguard measures to ensure the independence of the European Public Prosecutor's Office must be ensured. Eurojust's role is of fundamental importance, especially in improving judicial cooperation and in coordinating the competent judicial authorities of the Member States and in supporting investigations involving third countries. Therefore, relations between Eurojust and the European Public Prosecutor's Office need to be clarified and, in order for the two bodies to cooperate effectively, they should operate under one roof.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This report calls for the establishment of an independent European public prosecutor's office to more effectively combat fraud in the European Union. The fight against fraud is therefore being used here to attack the sovereignty of the Member States and to enable the European Union to grant itself new prerogatives, particularly in the area of criminal law.  As a reminder, Eurojust was created to facilitate coordination and cooperation between national authorities responsible for investigating and prosecuting cases involving several Member States. By contributing to the development of a European criminal law, the creation of a European public prosecutor's office would be a further step towards the federalisation of the Union, which we oppose on a daily basis. That is why I voted against it.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the motion for a resolution on the European Public Prosecutor's Office and Eurojust because I consider it of fundamental importance for the EU to identify and prosecute, in a concrete and incisive way, fraud committed against European finances. I therefore believe it is right to take all appropriate action to protect the taxpayers of the Member States who actively contribute to the EU budget. Eurojust has fostered coordination and cooperation between the various national investigating authorities and has also facilitated the building of a trust relationship between the diverse European legal systems and traditions. Eurojust's work has also seen significant improvements in cross-border prosecutions. As far as the European Public Prosecutor's Office is concerned, the European Public Prosecutor's Office should have more appropriate investigative measures in place to carry out its investigations in the best possible way. Member States must, however, take investigative measures on the basis of the principle of mutual recognition, as laid down in Directive 2014/41/EU on the European Criminal Investigation Order. In order to efficiently organise valuable cooperation and exchange of information between the European Public Prosecutor's Office and Eurojust, the two respective bodies should operate under the same direction.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report which would authorise the Council reopening negotiations with the European Parliament on the establishment of a European Public Prosecutor’s Office. Sinn Féin is opposed to the concept of a European Public Prosecutor’s Office as it would constitute a greater centralisation of judicial autonomy in the EU at the expense of Member States’ judicial structures. There remain serious concerns around the coordination, cost and management of the creation of an EPPO and its potential relationship with existing public prosecution offices. The resolution calls on Eurojust and EPPO to assume the trappings of a federal investigative force and calls for ‘sufficient investigative measures’ to be made available to the EPPO. For these reasons, I voted against.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution which follows an oral question on the subject. I support the establishment of an efficient and independent European Public Prosecutor’s Office (EPPO) in order to reduce the current fragmentation of national law enforcement efforts to protect the EU budget, thus strengthening the fight against fraud in the European Union. The EPPO should have sufficient investigative measures available to conduct its investigations and the Commission should come up with estimations of the budgetary implications of the collegiate structure in order for Parliament to take this information into account before taking its final decision.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution clarifying Parliament's position on the establishment of a European Public Prosecutor's Office. The text of the resolution presents an independent European Public Prosecutor, free from any political influence, who is also responsible for VAT fraud. It is required that competences be clear and defined (including with regard to Olaf and Eurojust) and appeals for the protection of the Union's financial interests can be brought before the Court of Justice. The independence and functionality of this new body is required, not only to prevent the creation of an unnecessary institution; With a view to rationalisation, the location of the seat of the future European Public Prosecutor in the same context as Eurojust is also required.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: in writing. ‒ In general, I believe there is a case for establishment of the European Public Prosecutor’s Office as it would enhance coordination of activities of Member States as well as more effectively facing cross-border crime such as tax avoidance, for instance. I voted in favour of the resolution also because it calls for better cooperation with Eurojust. I think we need to strengthen Eurojust’s role in the judicial cooperation and coordination of relevant authorities of the Member States.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We are voting against the resolution because it contains several points of friction.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution on the European Public Prosecutor's Office and Eurojust had some positive elements. The promotion of procedures which will deal a significant blow to individuals or businesses which are moving at the expense of all European citizens, particularly in cases of tax evasion, is positive. However, these procedures cannot proceed unless we secure the rights of all citizens and a specific regulatory framework. As this has not yet been achieved, I have decided to abstain.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. Whereas Article 86 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union states that in order to combat crimes affecting the financial interests of the Union, the Council, acting by means of regulations in accordance with a special legislative procedure, may establish a European Public Prosecutor's Office from Eurojust, subject to the approval of the European Parliament; Whereas it is important for the EU and all its Member States to effectively and dissuasively detect and prosecute fraud affecting the financial interests of the Union, thereby protecting taxpayers in all Member States contributing to the Union budget; Cross-border crime has increased over the last decade and is committed by extremely mobile and flexible groups operating in multiple criminal jurisdictions and sectors and criminal sectors. The measure calls on the Council to consider various aspects involving the European Union directly in the protection and protection of its Member States. For the various exact considerations requested, I have decided to vote in favour of the document.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: in writing. \u2012 European Public Prosecutor's Office and Eurojust, negative opinion for a resolution that aims to centralise and harmonise areas as sensitive as they are important to protect, perhaps, the financial interests of the Union.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the resolution before us because I am deeply convinced of the urgent need to clarify the tasks and relations between the European Public Prosecutor's Office and Eurojust. The European Public Prosecutor's Office is giving rise to an instrument aimed at reducing the current fragmentation of national measures to combat fraud affecting financial interests. In line with what has been approved, I believe it is appropriate to establish a clear and unambiguous set of competences and procedures for the European Public Prosecutor's Office, on the basis of the proposal for a directive on combating fraud affecting the financial interests of the Union through criminal law (PIF Directive). The Council is urged to step up its efforts to reach agreement on the PIF directive, so that VAT is included in its scope, and consequently in that of the public prosecutor's office. As far as Eurojust is concerned, however, it is a body designed to facilitate coordination and cooperation between the national authorities responsible for investigations and prosecution in cases involving several States. The full and defined implementation of Eurojust will allow greater mutual trust between countries as well as overcoming their systemic differences. In the light of what has emerged, it is essential to clarify the relationship between the two instruments together with the costs and benefits they bring.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the vote on the European Public Prosecutor’s Office and Eurojust and noted no objections.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 The process of setting up a European Public Prosecutor's Office began with the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, which only allows Parliament to give its consent. The Commission's latest proposal dates back to 2013. More than three years later, doubts about the establishment of the Public Prosecutor's Office, as well as its contours, remain. Parliament has repeatedly called for this status quo to be achanged.  Parliament made clear from an early age what it did not give up: that the Public Prosecutor's Office should take into mind the so-called "PIF Directive" on crimes against the interests of the Union; that it should have its action articulated with Eurojust, which should be independent, respect national constitutions and the highest international standards. With regard to this latter parameter, the Public Prosecutor's Office can take inspiration from the Portuguese model, whose institutional architecture is considered the best in the world. In short, a set of clear guidelines, to which the Council has not yet been able to respond.  I therefore support this resolution, which calls for clarification from the Council, calls for the establishment of the Public Prosecutor's Office and rightly points out - that the cost of not having a European Public Prosecutor's Office established rises every year.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the resolution because only with an efficient and independent European Public Prosecutor's Office will cross-border prosecution be effectively enforceable. Only then can Eurojust facilitate coordination and cooperation between national investigative and law enforcement authorities in dealing with cases involving several Member States and help to build mutual trust and bridge the differences between the different legal systems and traditions within the EU.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – UKIP MEPs voted against this motion for resolution. UKIP does not support the establishment of a European Public Prosecutor’s Office which will have powers that greatly infringe on national sovereignty.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution because, while reiterating its support for the establishment of a European Public Prosecutor's Office to reduce the current fragmentation in this area, it is necessary to establish clearly and unambiguously the competences and procedures within its competence in order to make it truly effective and independent. It is also important that an in-depth cost-benefit analysis of the facility is carried out in order to carefully assess its implications for the European budget, and also to clarify the relations between Eurojust and the European Public Prosecutor's Office, with particular attention to the implications of the collegiate structure, as well as the European Public Prosecutor's Office's relations with OLAF, in order to differentiate their roles in financial matters.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ Eurojust has facilitated coordination and cooperation between national investigative and prosecution authorities in dealing with cases affecting a number of Member States, and Eurojust has helped to build mutual trust and to bridge the EU’s wide variety of legal systems and traditions.  I support the work being done by Eurojust and call on the Council to clarify the prosecution competences of the EPPO and the national prosecutors in cases of multiple offences and mixed offences. I emphasise the need for protection of the procedural rights of suspected and accused persons which should be guaranteed; in particular, the regulation should provide for additional rights of defence for EPPO suspects, in particular the right to legal aid, the right to information and access to case materials.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. The establishment of a European Public Prosecutor's Office, when there is no legal system at European level, is something on which different organisations of jurists have expressed numerous doubts. We understand that, as the institution thinks in this resolution, born on the right, there is no guarantee of the democratic rights that people accused of a crime in the Member States have today. Moreover, the relationship between this prosecutor's office and the courts of the different States, or with the law forces and law forces, is not clarified. Since the conviction that the principle of transparency is fundamental in law, we cannot accept a model that would delve de further into the deficits already in many States, including Spanish. Our model is the necessary coordination of the different judicial systems of the Union, not in creating structures that act in parallel with them, so I have decided to vote against them.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 Article 86 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union states that in order to combat crimes affecting the financial interests of the Union, the Council may establish a European Public Prosecutor's Office from the EU Agency for Cooperation in Criminal Matters (Eurojust), subject to the approval of the European Parliament. In this way, the EU and its Member States can effectively and dissuasively identify and prosecute fraud affecting the financial interests of the Union, protecting European citizens as taxpayers in the EU budget. By voting in favour of this resolution, I wanted to support the actions identified to reduce the current fragmentation of national interventions to combat fraud in the European Union. These include the call on the Council to abandon the rule that deprives the European Public Prosecutor's Office of the possibility of being competent for all offences defined in the PIF Directive if the damage caused to the Union budget is equal to or less than the damage caused to another victim. Furthermore, I believe it is particularly important to guarantee the independence of the European Public Prosecutor's Office, in order to avoid cases of disagreement between the European Public Prosecutor's Office and the national prosecutors on the issue of competences, thus depriving the decisions of the Public Prosecutor's Office of operational effectiveness.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted against the resolution on the European Public Prosecutor's Office and Eurojust. The faction to which I belong has always been opposed to the establishment of a European Public Prosecutor's Office, because, in my opinion, as in the view of the other members of the faction, this would violate the principle of subsidiarity. I am also not in favour of the establishment of a European criminal law system. I believe that both the prevention of abuse and the settlement of disputes should take place within the existing legal framework. For the reasons set out above, I voted against.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ The Council is currently proposing the establishment of a European Public Prosecutor’s Office (EPPO) to which the Parliament is being asked to consent. With the risks from fraud estimated at around €3 billion per annum, the Commission is proposing a decentralised EU body with a hierarchical structure to safeguard and protect the rights of individuals involved in the EPPO’s investigations. My main issue to this circle around the fact that VAT offences are included, adequate juridical reviews are needed and procedural rights need to be taken into consideration. Some of the changes to the Commission’s proposal, as introduced by the Council, present some real dangers to the independence, effectiveness and added value to the European Public Prosecutor’s Office. As the resolution outlines these concerns, I voted in favour of it.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that protecting the European Union's financial interests is one of the major concerns of the European Commission and the responsibility for this objective is shared between the competences of the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) and Eurojust – the European Judicial Cooperation Agency, I consider it important to clarify relations between Eurojust and the European Public Prosecutor's Office, on the one hand, between the European Public Prosecutor's Office and OLAF, on the other hand , a clarification that will help improve judicial cooperation and coordination between judicial authorities to protect the financial interests of the European Union.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This resolution, carried out by my political group the European People's Party (EPP), reaffirms the European Parliament's support for the establishment of an effective and independent European Public Prosecutor's Office. The latter would harmonize Member States' efforts in the area of enforcement, and thus better combat fraud within the Union. Supporting these objectives, I voted in favour of this report.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs voted against this motion for resolution. UKIP does not support the establishment of a European Public Prosecutor’s Office which will have powers that greatly infringe on national sovereignty.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption by the European Parliament of this resolution on the European Public Prosecutor's Office and Eurojust, of which I was a co-signer. In the face of the slow pace of negotiations on this major issue, we must regularly and forcefully remind the Council of the importance of setting up an effective and independent European public prosecutor's office to combat offences that undermine the Union's financial interests. In order to strengthen the Europe of Justice and to show Europe's capacity to carry out major projects, I would like to reiterate my commitment to the creation of a European public prosecutor's office with clearly defined competences that can cooperate effectively with the Eurojust agency.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution on the European Public Prosecutor's Office and Eurojust. In July 2013, the Commission presented a proposal for a regulation for the creation of a European public prosecutor's office. This prosecutor's office is designed to be an independent European body capable of prosecuting crimes against the financial interests of the Union.  The proposed regulation must be adopted under the consent process. Parliament will therefore have to say yes or no to the text on which the States have agreed. However, in the last three years the Council has substantially modified the Commission's original proposal.   The resolution reaffirms Parliament's support for the establishment of an effective and independent European public prosecutor's office to reduce the current fragmentation of national repression efforts to protect the EU budget. However, it recalls that the relations between the Public Prosecutor's Office and Eurojust must be clarified and insists that the scope and competences of the Public Prosecutor's Office be based on the directive on the fight against fraud against the financial interests of the Union (PIF Directive) currently blocked in the trilogue phase because the Council refuses the inclusion of VAT fraud.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. To date, the EU does not have its own means to prosecute offences committed against its budget. It is estimated that each year the fraud on the European budget (vat fraud in particular) is in the order of 3 billion euros. The creation of a European public prosecutor's office will therefore ensure that the Union's financial interests are defended. While the European Commission's proposal for a European Prosecutor's Office launched in 2013 is a good move, Member States are still dragging their feet on the idea of creating a supranational body capable of interfering in their own judicial system. The European Parliament, which will have to decide at the end of the negotiations between the Council and the Commission, will support the idea of a European public prosecutor's office with enhanced powers.

name: Diane DODDS
text: in writing. ‒ Northern Ireland has for many years been the focus of organised criminality led by paramilitaries and in particular republican terror gangs in border areas. I have therefore seen the dreadful consequences of fuel and money laundering, of smuggling, on our economy and the success of local communities. It is vital that we combat those involved in this activity. We must break down the structures that govern this illegal behaviour and protect those citizens who are at risk.  It will also come as no shock that I believe it should be primarily the role of national crime-fighting authorities to lead these efforts. Instead of promoting more integration of policing, investigation and legal systems, this Parliament must better support Member States to tackle corruption and organised crime at the grassroots. The National Crime Agency is now fully operational in Northern Ireland, working hard to prevent, detect and punish those responsible in these crimes.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the resolution on the EPPO and Eurojust.  Its basis are two oral questions of the LIBE Committee on the establishment of a European Public Prosecutor's Office (Article 86 TFEU) and the possible reform at Eurojust.   The establishment of a European Public Prosecutor's Office concerns the sovereignty of member states, as its aim will be to investigate and punish financial fraud and other crimes affecting the EU's financial interest. Currently, only the national authorities of the Member States have such powers within their territories, and existing European agencies such as OLAF, Europol and Eurojust do not have the power to conduct a European investigation.  Me and my political group believe that at this stage the best results in the fight against crimes affecting the EU's financial interests can be achieved at national level and with the help of existing coordination and cooperation frameworks between Member States.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution is moving in the right direction, because the European Public Prosecutor's Office and EUROJUST can jointly contribute to the fight against fraud, in particular that linked to the POS Directive and vat revenue, provided, of course, that the observations of the motion for a resolution are taken into account when drawing up the regulation.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU in 2014 raised €159.5 billion in value added tax (VAT) revenues, but it is important that the EU and all its Member States effectively and deter cases of fraud in the EU's financial interests in order to protect taxpayers from all Member States contributing to the Eu budget. I consider it essential that a clear and clear set of powers and procedures be established for the European Public Prosecutor's Office, on the basis of the proposal for a Directive on combating fraud harmful to financial interests through criminal law and that efforts to reach an agreement on the PIF Directive be stepd up so that VAT is included in its scope.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted against: the creation of a European public prosecutor's office is a new step in the sneaky development of a European criminal law, when it must remain a competence of the Member States.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution addresses a controversial topic. Some have long wanted to make a leap forward in the field of federalisation of justice, a leap that is, among other things, the creation of a European Public Prosecutor's Office. The resolution calls for the Council to establish "a set of powers and procedures for the European Public Prosecutor's Office" and to resume "negotiations with the European Parliament with a view to its establishment". It defends the "importance of Eurojust's role in improving judicial cooperation and coordination between the competent judicial authorities of the Member States". And it states that "in order to ensure the effectiveness of cooperation and exchange of information between the European Public Prosecutor's Office and Eurojust, the two bodies should operate in the same place". We are facing another attempt to advance on areas that go to the heart of the sovereignty of states, in this case to justice. The vision set here is to centralise, structure and strengthen entities such as Eurojust, which escape democratic and judicial control, overcoming guarantees as to the rights and freedoms provided for in national legislative and constitutional frameworks. This goes beyond free and sovereign cooperation between national states, and progress is made with the creation of supranational control mechanisms, initiatives inseparable from a security drift that increasingly puts fundamental rights, freedoms and guarantees at risk.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The Council is in charge of the european public prosecutor's office's readiness and progress is very slow in this process, although some progress is noticeable here. The legislative text is being prepared and discussed in a specific legislative procedure, so the European Parliament will only be asked to give its consent to the text in the final text. However, it is very important for the Council to address the European Parliament's concerns and demands regarding independence, efficiency and expediency in the creation and functioning of the EPPO. It is necessary for the Council, when drafting legislation, to bear in mind that it has to deal with a number of problematic issues, such as concluding negotiations on a directive on the fight against fraud and the financial interests of the European Union, where it should be laid down for which crimes the EPPO will have powers, as well as considering the remedies and judicial review of decisions taken by the EPPO after it has been created in the future.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution as it moves in the right direction. The European Public Prosecutor's Office and EUROJUST can, together, contribute to the fight against fraud, in particular that linked to the POS Directive and VAT revenue. It is only when drawing up the Rules of Procedure that the observations of the motion for a resolution are taken into account.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Support for the establishment of a European Public Prosecutor’s Office cannot be unconditional. Some of the changes to the Commission’s proposal introduced by the Council present real dangers to the independence, effectiveness and added value of any such office. For example, the risks of the ‘national link’ introduced by Council, through which national delegated prosecutors are responsible for all prosecutions brought in their Member State. I believe we need to conclude the negotiations on the Directive on the Fight against Fraud to the Union's Financial Interests by means of Criminal Law (PIF Directive) – which will lay down the criminal offences for which the EPPO will have jurisdiction – before Parliament can be asked to consent to the EPPO text. Moreover, we must ensure adequate judicial review in respect of decisions taken by the EPPO, irrespective of whether those decisions are taken at a national or central level. Finally, particular attention shall be paid to procedural rights, in particular legal aid, when establishing a cross-border Prosecutor of this nature.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution convinced that it is necessary to continue for the European integration process. In this regard, it would be desirable to establish an effective and independent European Public Prosecutor's Office, with a view to reducing the current fragmentation of resources for the implementation of national legislation to protect the Union budget, therefore strengthening the fight against fraud in the Union. Similarly, account must be given to the importance of Eurojust's role in improving judicial cooperation and coordination of the competent judicial authorities of the Member States, and in the conduct of investigations involving third countries.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. \u2012 The fight against fraud in the Union is one of the pillars that Europe must support with the utmost commitment and which also translates concretely into combating tax avoidance and evasion, challenging so-called tax havens, trying to stem dark areas, often a basin of illegality and crime. In 2014 alone, EUR 159.5 billion of lost VAT revenue was recorded. We need more control and coordinated and shared cooperation work to improve the exchange of information between individual countries. We need to be able to monitor anomalies more accurately and more quickly and we need decisive and clear action in relation to cross-border prosecution. I therefore share the hope that a European Public Prosecutor's Office will soon be set up which, in cooperation with Eurojust, will have full competence over financial crimes and will succeed in overcoming the fragmentation of national operations in the field of judicial cooperation in criminal matters.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this motion for resolution. I do not support the establishment of a European Public Prosecutor’s office which will have powers that greatly infringe on national sovereignty.

name: Charles GOERENS
text: In writing. From my point of view, the future EU prosecutor should sit in Luxembourg. Indeed, the conclusions of the representatives of the Member States of 12 and 13 December 2003 state that "representatives of the Member States, meeting at the level of heads of state or government, have agreed to give priority to the member states, once they have become members of the Union, in terms of the allocation of the seats of other bodies to be created , without prejudice to the fact that, if a European Public Prosecutor's Office is established, it will be based in Luxembourg in accordance with the provisions of the decision of 8 April 1965" and therefore do not leave any doubt about the location of the Eu Prosecutor's Office by stipulating that all judicial or quasi-judicial bodies are intended to establish themselves in the same place, in Luxembourg. My support for the European Parliament's resolution of 5 October 2016 on the European Public Prosecutor's Office and Eurojust is to be interpreted in this regard.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: In writing. Negotiations in the Council on the creation of a European Public Prosecutor's Office are not moving quickly, and not in the direction desired by the European Parliament. That is why Parliament has decided to discuss it today. For my part, I am resolutely opposed to this European prosecutor's office. Originally intended to centralise investigations in the event of an attack on the Union's financial interests, it promises to be a complex body, creating jurisdictional conflicts, doubling existing European forums for judicial cooperation. The European Parliament wants to over-extend the notion of the Union's financial interests under the jurisdiction of this prosecutor's office, to the point that a good number of general financial offences (money laundering, VAT fraud, etc.) could be completely evaded by national courts even though their authors, their victims or their theatres would be "European" only on the margins. It is clear that the aim is to create a start of purely European law and criminal procedures, above and in place of national rights. It is still this unhealthy dream of the United States of Europe modelled on those of America, which even Mr Juncker, however, seems to have given up.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. I have decided to vote in favour of this resolution, because I understand that the establishment of an independent and effective European Public Prosecutor's Office is of great help in combating crimes comprising several countries and is in line with greater European integration of justice systems. We also note positively that the resolution calls for judicial cooperation, the classification of the system of powers and powers. I understand that a European Public Prosecutor's Office with sufficient powers and funds is a positive step forward and that is why I vote in favour.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I and fellow Labour MEPs abstained on the resolution as the text is still unclear on the EPPO structure and impact on the UK criminal system. We must avoid conflict between national constitutional rules and secondary EU law so not to hinder the work of national practitioners.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of a resolution to set up an independent European public prosecutor's office. This new tool should help us to fight fraud and financial crimes more effectively, by coordinating national justice systems. Eurojust's mission will be to implement requests for cooperation between jurisdictions and to apply mutual recognition instruments to improve transnational prosecutions.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution for a number of reasons. In July 2013, the Commission presented a regulation based on article 86 TFEU on the establishment of a European Public Prosecutor’s Office or EPPO. The EPPO was proposed to fill the institutional gap that currently exists, as only national authorities can prosecute EU fraud but they cannot do this across national borders, which is a serious defect considering the internal market and the free movement of money. Also, considering that the EPPO is being adopted under the consent procedure, which means that the Parliament will have to  say ‘yes’ or ‘no’ to the text that the Member States agree on, it is vital that a resolution is passed giving the institution’s position on it. Thankfully, the resolution highlights the need for the EPPO to be efficient and independent, and its scope and competences should be based on the directive on the fight against fraud to the Union’s financial interests by means of criminal law (PIF Directive). It is estimated by the European Commission that fraud against the EU’s financial interests costs around EUR 3 billion every year. The creation of the EPPO is essential to ensure that fraud against the EU’s financial interests is tackled equally in all Member States.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour since I have no objections.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: In writing. I supported the adoption of the resolution on the European Public Prosecutor's Office and Eurojust, subjects on which work has been stalled in the Council for several years. I believe that it is time for the Council to take a decision on this matter and finally adopt the directive on the fight against fraud which harms the Union's financial interests through the criminal law (PIF directive) which has been on the negotiating table since 2012. The lack of harmonisation and fragmentation of national law enforcement systems have an undeniable impact on the effectiveness of the fight against fraud against the financial interests of the European Union. It is essential that a clarification be made on the division of powers between the European Public Prosecutor's Office and those of national prosecutors when an allegation of fraud concerning EU resources is found.

name: Filiz HYUSMENOVA
text: in writing. – Dear Mr President, Europe faces transnational challenges more than ever. In order to confront terrorism, organised criminal networks, cybercrime and money laundering, we need to adapt the European justice framework to the needs of the present by strengthening the role of Europol and Eurojust and creating a functioning and effective European Public Prosecutor's Office to support and improve the exchange of information and cooperation between them.  I therefore call on the Council to examine the remaining problematic and controversial points with regard to the European Commission's proposal for a regulation establishing the European Public Prosecutor's Office, the proposal for a directive on the fight against fraud to the Union's financial interests and the proposal for a regulation on the Agency for criminal justice cooperation Eurojust, and to proceed with the adoption of decisions in this regard as soon as possible.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ The establishment of a European Public Prosecutor’s Office (EPPO) is welcome. However, there are many questions and concerns that arise from such an establishment regarding independence, efficiency and effectiveness. Changes and improvements must be made to this project before gaining full support.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's resolution on the European Public Prosecutor's Office and Eurojust, as I consider it essential to protect the Financial Interests of the Union in the best and more efficient way possible. Fraud affecting the EU's financial interests is estimated to be around €3 billion each year. The European Public Prosecutor's Office should be an independent and effective body with clear competences to address fraud equally in all Member States. In course, the relationship between Eurojust and the European Public Prosecutor's Office should be clarified in order to facilitate coordination and cooperation between national investigative and law enforcement authorities. However, I believe that it is necessary to further clarify the competences of the European Public Prosecutor's Office and to improve cross-border prosecutions.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – Diane James MEP and her UKIP colleagues voted against this motion for resolution. UKIP does not support the establishment of a European Public Prosecutor’s office which will have powers that greatly infringe on national sovereignty.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the European General Prosecutor's Office, which was prepared by the Green Group and which reaffirms Parliament's position before the next Justice and Home Affairs Council meeting on the General Prosecutor's Office. The motion for a resolution confirms, inter alia, that the General Prosecutor's Office should have an insight into any matter which, for whatever reason, may fall within its competence; that matters relating to VAT as the EU's own financial resources should be the responsibility of the Attorney-General.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on the establishment of a European Public Prosecutor's Office, an idea I defended last year when I was rapporteur for the EPP on the fight against fraud against European funds. The aim of this body will be to find, prosecute and return to trial those responsible for offences that harm the financial interests of the European Union. This novelty brought about by the EPP Group should make it possible to better protect European taxpayers' money by adapting to new forms of fraud, in particular transnational fraud. I welcome this initiative and encourage the continuation of the debate strengthening the Union's cooperation and action in this area.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution in order to call for the creation of a European Public Prosecutor's Office, a fully-fledged and decentralised structure aimed at investigating and prosecuting frauds or crimes that attack the financial interests of the European Union.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I am opposed to this motion for a resolution. The establishment of a European Public Prosecutor's Office and shifts in competence in favour of Eurojust speak against the sovereignty claims of the Member States in the enforcement of their territory.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 On 5 November 2016, we voted in plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on a resolution on the European Public Prosecutor's Office and Eurojust. For more than nineteen years, European politicians have been talking about the establishment of a new EU body – the European Public Prosecutor's Office. This institute, which allows the EU to establish Article 86 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, has been highly criticised for years by both the lay and professional public. In addition to the historically second use of the early warning mechanism, the controversies surrounding the Commission's proposal to set up this office have resulted. The Czech Republic also issued a yellow card for the proposal. I do not think that anything has changed fundamentally since the first proposal was put forward and the concerns of a number of Member States have been dispelling. Moreover, in today's turbulent times, the EU would be very unwise to force member states to do something else that they fundamentally disagree with. Therefore, I could not support the rapporteur's request for the creation of the European Public Prosecutor's Office and the reopening of the debate in the Council on the proposal to create it, and I voted against it.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the establishment of a European Public Prosecutor's Office, as it is crucial that the EU and its Member States disclose and prosecute, in an effective and dissuasive manner, fraud affecting the EU's financial interests, thereby protecting the taxpayers of all Member States that contribute funds to the Union budget.  Organised cross-border crime has been on the rise over the past decade and these crimes are committed by extremely mobile groups operating in multiple Member States and committing different types of crime. With this in this context, I welcome Parliament's support for the establishment of an effective and independent European Public Prosecutor's Office (EPPO) in order to reduce the existing fragmentation of national law enforcement efforts to protect the EU budget, thereby strengthening the fight against fraud in the European Union.  It is necessary to ensure a clear set of competences of the EPPO. It is of paramount importance to avoid the harmful effects of the so-called a 'national unit' must therefore ensure that adequate safeguards are in place to ensure the independence of the EPPO, such as a provision allowing a derogation from the national unit on grounds relating to the proper functioning of the EPPO.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. ‒ Back in 2013, the Commission presented a proposal to reform Eurojust, together with a proposal to establish a European Public Prosecutor’s Office (EPPO). In general, the Commission’s proposal for the establishment of EPPO aims to provide support to Eurojust in the fight against fraud to the EU. Thus, it also aims to increase the democratic legitimacy of Eurojust. Close cooperation between Eurojust and the future EPPO on an operational and administrative level is essential to ensure effective and efficient work in practice. In this context, compatible provisions in both regulations are essential for legal certainty and consistency and will help to realise the full potential of Eurojust and the EPPO. Moreover, in order to ensure judicial coordination from the outset of investigations and prosecutions, Eurojust and the EPPO should inform each other of relevant cases. Therefore, strong information exchange between Eurojust and EPPO should be developed.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. Considerable progress has finally been made in the area of the European Public Prosecutor's Office. The fight against financial fraud is one of the priorities, which today has adequate instruments for its full implementation. The main element is the setting up of a European Public Prosecutor's Office which will contribute significantly to the protection of European taxpayers' money, thus promoting a recovery of funds that may be defrauded. In addition, the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office will ensure homogeneity in the prevention and prosecution of these types of crime throughout Europe. Eurojust and the European Public Prosecutor's Office are invited to work together to facilitate cooperation and the exchange of information, including the implementation of the PIF Directive.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because it uses fraud in the Union to create a European public prosecutor's office. This is a new stage in the development of a European criminal law. I believe that criminal justice should remain a prerogative of states.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution to reaffirm my support for the establishment of an effective and independent European public prosecutor's office, in order to reduce the current fragmentation of national repression efforts to protect the Union's budget. A European prosecutor's office would strengthen the fight against fraud in the European Union.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution on the European Public Prosecutor's Office.  The text 'reaffirms its long-standing support for the establishment of an effective and independent European public prosecutor's office to reduce the current fragmentation of national enforcement efforts to protect the EU budget, which would strengthen the fight against fraud in the European Union'. The fight against fraud is therefore being used to create yet another body of the European Union. It should operate alongside Eurojust and OLAF. Eurojust was created to facilitate coordination and cooperation between national authorities responsible for investigating and prosecuting cases involving several Member States. The creation of a European Public Prosecutor's Office is a new step in the sneaky development of a European criminal law, when it must remain a competence of the Member States.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. The text reaffirms its long-standing support for the establishment of an effective and independent European public prosecutor's office to reduce the current fragmentation of national enforcement efforts to protect the EU budget, which would strengthen the fight against fraud in the Union. The fight against fraud is therefore being used to create yet another body of the Union. It should operate alongside Eurojust and OLAF. Eurojust was created to facilitate coordination and cooperation between national authorities responsible for investigating and prosecuting cases involving several Member States. The creation of a European Public Prosecutor's Office is a new step in the development of a European criminal law, while it must remain a competence of the Member States.  Therefore, I voted against it.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report because, especially in a time of economic and social crisis, it is very important to efficiently recover for the legal and productive economy the resources that are delayed from that flow by fraud. The reality shown by the figures is that transnational criminal networks have increased in recent years and also fraud.  VAT is an important Community resource, as set out in the recent case-law of the CJEO and must therefore fall within the scope of the directive. Eurojust has been playing a key role in coordinating the different ways of pursuing fraud in the Member States. The resolution insists that this role be maintained and strengthened. The decision has an impact on the idea that the European Public Prosecutor's Office should be established as soon as possible and that the system of resources should be examined very well, its operational independence preserved and the relationship with regard to national courts will be established.  We Socialists insist that the Directive, which will be the embryo of the subsequent development of the Public Prosecutor's Office, must be promoted and adopted first.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. The establishment of a European Public Prosecutor's Office, when there is no legal system at European level, is something on which different organisations of jurists have expressed numerous doubts. We understand that, as the institution thinks in this resolution, born on the right, there is no guarantee of the democratic rights that people accused of a crime in the Member States have today. Moreover, the relationship between this prosecutor's office and the courts of the different States, or with the law forces and law forces, is not clarified. Since the conviction that the principle of transparency is fundamental in law, we cannot accept a model that would delve de further into the deficits already in many States, including Spanish. Our model is the necessary coordination of the different judicial systems of the Union, not in creating structures that act in parallel with them, so I have decided to vote against them.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. I am against the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office. Moreover, the EU wants taxes (VAT) to be included in the prosecutor's remit and become a kind of financial police force. I consider this unacceptable interference with the competences of the Member States.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. \u2012 Article 86. the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union states that the Council may establish by regulation the European Public Prosecutor's Office to combat crimes affecting the financial interests of the Union. It is important that the EU effectively detects fraud affecting the financial interests of the Union and prosecutes such fraud, thereby protecting the taxpayers of all Member States. Eurojust facilitates coordination and cooperation between national investigative and law enforcement authorities and helps build mutual trust between different legal systems and traditions in the EU. It also facilitates the enforcement of cooperation requirements and the application of MLAs, thereby improving cross-border prosecutions. An effective and independent European Public Prosecutor's Office should be established which would have priority for the offences laid down in the Directive and the Regulation must ensure the protection of all the rights of suspects.  This would reduce the current fragmentation in law enforcement efforts to protect the EU budget and strengthen the fight against fraud in the European Union, so I supported this resolution.

name: Svetoslav Hristov MALINOV
text: in writing. \u2012 At the beginning of October, we reaffirmed the European Parliament's support for the establishment of an effective and independent European Public Prosecutor's Office, which aims to reduce the existing fragmentation of national law enforcement efforts to protect the EU budget.  On average, nearly 500 million eur 100 million is lost annually to the European budget as a result of alleged abuses, with the cross-border element often hampering quality investigation at national level. Member States need an effective supranational body to work together with national prosecutors' offices and intervene specifically in cases concerning the misuse of European funds. It is important to clarify from now on the relationship between Eurojust and the future EPPO, and in particular the consequences of the establishment of a collegial structure, as well as the actions of the EPPO with regard to OLAF, in order to distinguish between their respective roles in protecting the EU's financial interests.  The majority of our colleagues also stressed the need to ensure a sufficient budget and ensure the financial independence of the future EPPO. Operational decisions of the EPPO must be subject to judicial review before the competent national court and should be subject to the possibility of being heard by the Court of Justice in Luxembourg in order to ensure the necessary supervision and democratic review.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. ‒ I fully share the concerns of Parliament on the effectiveness of the future PIF Directive. The efficiency of the EPPO will depend on the clarification of competences, and if the PIF Directive fails to achieve this, EU legislators will not be able to ensure the effectiveness of the EPPO. That’s why it is important to call on the Council to provide an unambiguous and clear set of competences and proceedings concerning the EPPO based on the proposed directive on the fight against fraud to the Union’s financial interests by means of criminal law (PIF Directive) and to call on the Council to strengthen its efforts to reach an agreement on the PIF Directive which includes VAT in its scope, and to reopen negotiations with Parliament in order to enable the EPPO to be established.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 Tax fraud, corruption, international organised crime cost the Union budget hundreds of millions of euros a year. The European Parliament has unequivocally expressed its support for the establishment of the EPPO, the creation of which is also envisaged by the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU. This will strengthen the protection of the Union's legitimate interests in the area of financial relations and increase the effectiveness of the fight against fraud. There is a need for a uniform basis for institutional protection of the law instead of the current different and fragmented system of protection implemented by the Member States. That is also why we call on the Council to step up cooperation with the Member States in order to achieve a clear, unambiguous and separate determination of the powers of the EPPO and Eurojust, so that these institutions can start implementing effective and effective protection of the Union's interests as soon as possible.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. – I am voting against the motion for a resolution on the European Public Prosecutor's Office and Eurojust, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 5/10/2016, and because this motion for a resolution is not complete and substantiated.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this text.  This text uses the fight against fraud to create a European body that ignores the sovereignty of states. Indeed, it "reaffirms its long-standing support for the establishment of an effective and independent European public prosecutor's office", i.e. it sets up the first elements of a European criminal law, which we oppose. Criminal law must, by definition, remain a competence of the Member States.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the EP resolution on the European Public Prosecutor's Office and Eurojust because I believe that it is very important for the EU and all its Member States to identify and effectively combat cases of fraud against the EU's financial interests, so that the EU can protect the taxpayers of all Member States contributing to the Union budget. In addition, Eurojust has facilitated coordination and cooperation between national investigative and prosecution authorities in cases involving most Member States and has also contributed to the development of mutual trust and to bridging differences between the different EU legal systems and traditions. There is also no doubt that Eurojust has facilitated and improved cross-border criminal prosecution.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing.
