The creation of a European Public Prosecutor's Office and its equipping it with the necessary powers as the centre of a European prosecution represent a further step towards unification and centralisation. Prosecution must remain the competence of the Member States, which is why I reject this request.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the EP resolution on the European Public Prosecutor's Office and Eurojust, which calls for the creation of an effective and independent European Public Prosecutor's Office in order to reduce the current fragmentation of national law enforcement efforts, save the EU budget and strengthen the fight against fraud in the European Union.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. I have already opposed the creation of a European public prosecutor's office many times before. 14 national parliaments also expressed reservations. Justice that is not done in the name of the sovereign people is not one of them. And there is no need to create yet another supranational body when we already see the many complaints of states against the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF). There is also Eurojust created in 2002, whose task is precisely the coordination of investigations and prosecutions between the competent authorities of the States.  In the end, the delimitation of powers between these three bodies is more than unclear, which is what this new text of Parliament points out. However, he maintains his support for the creation of the Public Prosecutor's Office and wants to know here the where the negotiations are between the Commission and the Council. I believe that all this is just a subterfuge for an embryo of "European FBI" compiling files of personal data without proven effectiveness for justice. Brussels would do better to worry about the conflicts of interest of its former leaders such as José Manuel Barroso and Neelie Kroes.  I'm voting against

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The text reaffirms its long-standing support for the establishment of an effective and independent European public prosecutor's office to reduce the current fragmentation of national enforcement efforts to protect the EU budget, which would strengthen the fight against fraud in the Union. The fight against fraud is therefore being used to create yet another body of the Union. It should operate alongside Eurojust and OLAF. Eurojust was created to facilitate coordination and cooperation between national authorities responsible for investigating and prosecuting cases involving several Member States. The creation of a European Public Prosecutor's Office is a new step in the development of a European criminal law, while it must remain a competence of the Member States.  Therefore, I voted against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. Parliament's ambition has always been the ambition to set up an effective and independent European Public Prosecutor's Office in order to reduce the current fragmentation of national enforcement efforts to protect the EU budget, thereby strengthening the fight against fraud in the European Union. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, which clearly outlines Parliament’s support for the creation of an independent European Public Prosecutor’s Office in order to further the fight against fraud in the Union.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. It has been four years since the Commission tabled a legislative proposal to establish a European public prosecutor's office in charge of combating fraud against the financial interests of the European Union. The Council has only just finalized its general approach. And as we feared, the result is worrying. The Council dissected the original proposal to create an independent centralised European public prosecutor's office with a pyramid structure. Instead, he proposes a complex European prosecutor's office bound by the omnipresence of the national link endangering its independence.  Moreover, I have serious doubts about the added value of this European public prosecutor's office as the Council proposes to us today. The Council has added additional limits and there is still some question as to what fraud case the European Public Prosecutor's Office will be responsible for. All the more so if the Council continues to oppose the inclusion of VAT fraud. We must therefore remember that the approval of the European Parliament on the case of the Public Prosecutor's Office is not a given. It is therefore a warning to the Council with a simple message: yes, we are in the interest of setting up a European public prosecutor's office but not at any price.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – Partial harmonisation of the legal systems of EU Member States in the field of criminal law makes no doubt sense and is important in the interests of enhanced cooperation between law enforcement authorities and courts, as well as ensuring the same set of procedural rights of prosecutiones. In this context, I am of the opinion that the existence of a European Public Prosecutor's Office is certainly in place, particularly as regards some coordination between the activities of national prosecutors' offices and courts and ensuring their effective functioning. At the same time, however, I believe that the competences of the EPPO Office should be strictly and clearly defined and, at the same time, not too broad, so as not to interfere with the internal and exclusive competences of the Member States, but also to overlap competences with Eurojust and OLAF.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 On this issue, the PPE, S&D, ALDE and Verts/ALE political groups tabled a joint motion for a resolution. The draft proposes to reinforce Parliament's commitment to setting up an effective and independent European Public Prosecutor's Office in order to reduce the current fragmentation of national law enforcement efforts to protect the EU budget, thereby strengthening the fight against fraud in the European Union. It urges the Council to speed up the preparation of the regulation establishing the European Public Prosecutor's Office. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. We oppose this text, which reaffirms Parliament's support for the establishment of an independent European Public Prosecutor's Office to reduce the current fragmentation of national repression efforts to protect the EU budget. The fight against fraud once again serves as an alibi for the creation of a new body in the European Union, and above all to take a new step in the development of a European criminal law, a right which is still a competence of the Member States today.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. According to the Study and Reports on the VAT Gap in the EU-28 Member States: 2016 Final Report, the amount of EUR 159.5 billion in value added tax (VAT) revenues was lost in the EU in 2014. I support the importance of the EU and its Member States detecting and effectively sanctioning cases of fraud that harm the EU's financial interests, with the aim of protecting the taxpayers of Member States contributing to the Union budget. I support the establishment of an effective and independent European Public Prosecutor's Office in order to reduce the fragmentation of national enforcement efforts to protect the EU budget, thereby strengthening the fight against fraud in the European Union. I believe that it is essential to present a cost-benefit analysis, with estimates of the budgetary implications of the collegial structure of the European Public Prosecutor's Office.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The text 'reaffirms its long-standing support for the establishment of an effective and independent European public prosecutor's office to reduce the current fragmentation of national law enforcement efforts to protect the EU budget, which would strengthen the fight against fraud in the European Union'. The fight against fraud is therefore being used to create yet another body of the European Union. It should operate alongside Eurojust and OLAF. Eurojust was created to facilitate coordination and cooperation between national authorities responsible for investigating and prosecuting cases involving several Member States. The creation of a European Public Prosecutor's Office is a new step in the sneaky development of a European criminal law, when it must remain a competence of the Member States.  I therefore vote against this text.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on the European Public Prosecutor's Office and Eurojust. The aim of this resolution is to strengthen the fight against fraud in the European Union and to protect the EU budget by setting up an effective and independent European public prosecutor's office for better coordination of the enforcement efforts carried out by each Member State of the European Union.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which was carried out by my political group. The resolution reaffirms the European Parliament's long-standing support for the establishment of an effective and independent European Public Prosecutor's Office to reduce the current fragmentation of national enforcement efforts to protect the EU budget, which would strengthen the fight against fraud in the European Union.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the European Public Prosecutor's Office and Eurojust. I believe it is important for the EU and all its Member States to effectively detect and prosecute fraud affecting the EU's financial interests. Through the establishment of an effective and independent European Public Prosecutor's Office, it will help to reduce the current fragmentation of national law enforcement interventions aimed at protecting the EU budget, thereby strengthening the fight against fraud in the European Union. Eurojust has facilitated coordination and cooperation between national investigating and prosecution authorities in cases involving several Member States and has also helped to build mutual trust and overcome the diversity of the European Union's legal systems and traditions.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 I have been waiting for the issue of setting up an independent European Public Prosecutor's Office to be on the agenda. We have finally found a way to effectively control the use of EU funds. This way, on the one hand, we can ensure that the money is used transparently and efficiently and, on the other hand, that it is not lost somewhere in the bureaucratic maze. I also welcomed the proposal that the new agency should be located at eurojust's headquarters. This solution saves time and costs at the same time.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ The European Public Prosecutor’s Office will have the authority to investigate and prosecute EU fraud and other crimes that have an impact on the EU’s financial interests. I have voted for this motion for a resolution that acknowledges the European Parliament’s support for the creation of the European Public Prosecutor’s Office.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: in writing. – I supported the European Parliament resolution on the EPPO and Eurojust, as I believe it is necessary to ensure better protection of the EU's financial interests and more effective prosecution of multiple crimes.  The establishment of the EPPO must also lead to the establishment of adequate protection mechanisms ensuring the independence of that public prosecutor's office, such as a provision allowing a derogation from the national unit on grounds relating to the proper functioning of the EPPO. The EUROPEAN Public Prosecutor's Office will increase citizens' and business confidence in the European institutions. One of the main objectives of the EPPO will be to increase the number of charges raised and maintained, leading to more convictions and the collection of fraudulently obtained Union funds.  Cooperation between Eurojust, Europol and the European Anti-Fraud Office already exists, but there are still numerous problems and limitations in the coordination, cooperation and exchange of information due to the division of responsibilities between bodies belonging to different territorial and functional jurisdictions. Abuses of EU funds are estimated at around EUR 500 million per year, which is why we need to counter the culprits more strongly, creating a strong prosecution.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this report in which Parliament reaffirms its long-standing support for the establishment of an independent and effective European Public Prosecutor's Office. The creation of a European Public Prosecutor's Office is a basic condition for stepping up transnational enforcement efforts, both in the area of crimes against the security of European citizens, cross-border crime and in the field of taxation. The report calls on the Commission to present adjusted estimates of the budgetary implications of the new structure in a cost and benefit analysis and to present to Parliament the results of the 'assessment of the real situation'. Last but not least, for more effective collaboration and exchange of information, the report supports the idea of a joint seat of the European Parliament and Eurojust.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I voted against this report because the report speaks of support for Eurojust.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported.  The creation of the European Public Prosecutor's Office is essential to ensure the protection of the EU's financial interests and the fight against fraud evenly across all EU Member States.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: in writing. That Parliament is calling for a strong and independent European Public Prosecutor's Office is no secret, we have been asking for it for years. We are now at a crucial stage, because negotiation on the Public Prosecutor's Office is finally coming to an end. Although the Commission's ambitious proposal has been diluted by Member States that do not want to cede sovereignty, there has been agreement on many points. This isn't enough. Member States through the Council have been blocking the PIF Directive (full name: Anti-fraud Directive affecting the Union's financial interests through criminal law) for several years, in their efforts to leave VAT out of its application. It's a disgrace. With a strong Public Prosecutor's Office, and a comprehensive directive, we would avoid losing a very significant number of benefits in the Union (as we say in this Resolution, in 2014 some EUR 159.5 billion). It is another sign that the Council prevents any progress in an unfair way, and at the same time hides in the Union when things are twisted. A double betrayal.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. – I support the resolution tabled. More steps are needed to create an effective and independent European Public Prosecutor's Office in the EU.  In particular, the European Public Prosecutor's Office will remove obstacles to the effective fight against crimes affecting the EU's financial interests and strengthen the fight against fraud in the European Union. It will also help to reduce the current fragmentation of national law enforcement efforts. In this context, it is essential that the Council present as soon as possible an unambiguous and clear set of competences and procedures for the European Public Prosecutor's Office. Only in clear legal regulation will this institution be able to effectively prevent the misuse of eu budget funds and further fraud. In order to distinguish between the roles of the institutions concerned in protecting the EU's financial interests, the links and competences between Eurojust and the European Public Prosecutor's Office must be established.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs voted against this motion for resolution. UKIP does not support the establishment of a European Public Prosecutor’s Office which will have powers that greatly infringe on national sovereignty.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. I supported the Resolution on the European Public Prosecutor's Office and Eurojust. I support the work of Eurojust, as it serves to increase the efficiency of the work of national investigative and executive authorities in prosecuting serious cross-border and organised crime so that perpetrators of crime can be brought to justice quickly and successfully. Eurojust's vision is to be an important partner and hub of expertise at judicial level for effective measures against cross-border organised crime in the European Union. Eurojust was established with the aim of fostering and improving coordination and cooperation between national judicial authorities in the prosecution of serious cross-border crime in the European Union. Each of the 28 Member States sends one high-ranking representative to The Hague-based Eurojust. I think a high-quality solution is that representatives are experienced state attorneys, judges or police officers with equal competences. Together, they play the role of Eurojust by supporting coordination between national authorities at all stages of prosecution. In addition, they address challenges and practical problems arising from differences between the legal systems of individual Member States. It is well and certainly useful that Eurojust houses the secretariats of the European Judicial Network, the European Genocide Network, crimes against humanity and war crimes, as well as the Network of Joint Investigation Teams.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. The text 'reaffirms its long-standing support for the establishment of an effective and independent European public prosecutor's office to reduce the current fragmentation of national law enforcement efforts to protect the EU budget, which would strengthen the fight against fraud in the European Union'. The fight against fraud is therefore being used to create yet another body of the European Union. It should operate alongside Eurojust and OLAF. Eurojust was created to facilitate coordination and cooperation between national authorities responsible for investigating and prosecuting cases involving several Member States. The creation of a European Public Prosecutor's Office is a new step in the sneaky development of a European criminal law, when it must remain a competence of the Member States, and the proliferation of bodies is a guarantee of complexity, unnecessary expenditure and inefficiency.  I therefore vote against this resolution.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 According to a recent study, as much as €159.5 billion in value added tax (VAT) revenue was lost in the EU in 2014. It is essential that the EU and its Member States effectively detect and prosecute fraud affecting the EU's financial interests, thus protecting all taxpayers. This is always true, but even more so at a time of financial difficulties and growing mistrust of the institutions, such as the one we are experiencing. I therefore support the request made to the Council by this resolution to commit itself to promoting the establishment of an effective and independent European Public Prosecutor's Office, thereby strengthening the fight against fraud in the European Union. The Council must also ensure that clear and unambiguous competences and procedures are established on the basis of the proposal for a PIF directive, including VAT in its scope. At the same time, it will be necessary to guarantee the protection of the procedural rights of suspects and defendants and to avoid any negative effects of the so-called 'national link'. The Council is proceeding very slowly. I hope that this report will serve as a stimulus to speed up the legislative process and that the indications made by Parliament, which will have to give its consent to the final text, will be taken on board.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ Developments in the Council concerning the text of the proposal on the European Public Prosecutor's Office raise concerns in both Parliament and the Commission. The purpose of this Resolution is to raise Parliament's concerns about the direction in which the draft text is going and to put pressure on the Council to take some of Parliament's proposals into account. According to Article 86(1) of the TFEU, the Council may establish the European Public Prosecutor's Office, but in accordance with the specific legislative procedure – the Council shall decide unanimously with the prior consent of the European Parliament. Negotiations on the PIF Directive (Anti-Fraud Directive harming the Financial Interests of the Union by means of criminal law) should be completed, which will designate the offences over which the European Public Prosecutor's Office will have jurisdiction before parliament's consent on the European Public Prosecutor's Office is sought. I also believe that the scope of the PIF Directive, and thus the Public Prosecutor's Office, should also cover VAT fraud. Furthermore, additional defence rights should also be taken into account for suspects pursued by the European Public Prosecutor's Office and decisions of the Public Prosecutor's Office should be subject to judicial review. Since the Report covers these comments, I support its adoption.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. \u2012 On the pretext of a question on the functioning and articulation of these two institutions, a report promoting the strengthening of the powers of the European Public Prosecutor's Office and the strengthening of relations between it and bodies such as EUROJUST or OLAF is made.  The attack on the sovereignty of states continues, reinforcing the federalist stance of the integration project, through supranational bodies in which increasingly concentrated powers and powers, obliterating the necessary and desirable free and sovereign cooperation between national states. The creation of some and the strengthening of others, of these "European" bodies, aim to protect and overtake the legitimate institutions of the member countries of the European Union. With these proposals, they centralize, structure and strengthen entities such as Eurojust that escape democratic and judicial control, overcoming guarantees as to the rights and freedoms provided for in the national legislative and constitutional frameworks.  We voted against it.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU and all Member States must be able to effectively combat financial fraud that harms their interests and thus protect taxpayers. EU countries are also facing ever-increasing organised cross-border crime. In this respect, I consider Eurojust to be a key instrument, which streamlines cooperation between member states' investigative bodies and helps to build mutual trust and overcome differences between a wide range of different legal systems and traditions. However, in order to improve the fight against any organised crime and to increase mutual assistance in investigations, it is necessary to go further. I therefore also support the creation of an effectively functioning and independent European Public Prosecutor's Office. However, it is necessary to ensure that it is independent and efficient before setting up a new investigative office. In order for the public prosecutor's competences to be sufficient, it is first necessary to approve the Directive on combating criminal law against fraud affecting the financial interests of the Union, which provides for offences falling within the jurisdiction of that office. Last but not least, it will also be necessary to ensure adequate judicial review in relation to the decision of the European Public Prosecutor's Office, regardless of whether such a decision has been taken at national or central level.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which reiterates the European Parliament's support for the creation of a European Public Prosecutor's Office whose action is independent and effective. This would aim to reduce the fragmentation, which we can see at present, of enforcement efforts at the national level, in particular to optimise the European budget and to be in fact part of a dynamic of increased fight against fraud within the European Union.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 In accordance with Article 86 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, the Council may set up a European Public Prosecutor's Office after approval by the European Parliament. This motion for a resolution is precisely in this direction, proposing the creation of an effective and independent European Public Prosecutor's Office, with a clear and clear set of powers and procedures, with a view to combating economic crime, as well as tax fraud and tax evasion. The proposal therefore calls on the Council to waive the rule which deprives the Public Prosecutor's Office of the possibility of intervening in certain cases where PIF offences are committed. The proposal calls for a clear gap between the powers of that body and the powers of national courts, avoiding conflicts of jurisdiction, in what is a negative effect of the so-called 'national link'. At the same time, the document is attentive to the protection of the rights, freedoms and guarantees of the procedural subjects investigated by the Public Prosecutor's Office, as well as the delimitation of the spheres of competence of the Public Prosecutor's Office and Eurojust. I believe it is important for the Union and its Member States to effectively and dissuasively detect and penalise cases of fraud that is harmful to financial interests - because, as Margaret Thatcher rightly points out, there is no such thing as public money; there is only taxpayers money. I therefore support the establishment of a European Public Prosecutor's Office, as proposed in the report.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs voted against this motion for resolution. UKIP does not support the establishment of a European Public Prosecutor’s Office which will have powers that greatly infringe on national sovereignty.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Council, by means of regulations adopted in accordance with a special legislative procedure, may establish a European Public Prosecutor's Office after approval by the European Parliament in order to reduce the current fragmentation of efforts. Parliament calls on the Council to establish a clear and clear set of powers and procedures for the European Public Prosecutor's Office, so that VAT is included in its scope, and to resume negotiations with it with a view to the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office. It also considers that the European Public Prosecutor's Office should have sufficient investigative means to carry out its investigations, and that operational decisions should be subject to judicial review by a competent national court so that they do not affect third parties. It points out that it is necessary to avoid any negative effects of the so-called 'national link', considering it essential to ensure the protection of the procedural rights of suspected and accused persons. The EP calls on the Commission to provide estimates of the budgetary implications of the collegial structure and to pass on to Parliament the results of the real situation assessment exercise. As set out in this report, I voted in favour.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 According to the document "Study and reports on the VAT gap in the 28 EU Member States: final report 2016", the EU lost in 2014 the amount of EUR 159.5 billion in VAT revenues. It is important that the EU and all its Member States effectively and deter cases of fraud harmful to the EU's financial interests in order to protect taxpayers from all MS slugs contributing to the Union budget. This proposal relates to the creation of an effective and independent European Public Prosecutor's Office in order to reduce the current fragmentation of national enforcement efforts to protect the EU budget, thereby strengthening the fight against fraud in the European Union. This Public Prosecutor's Office should have sufficient investigative means to carry out its investigations and, in order to ensure the effectiveness of cooperation and exchange of information between the European Public Prosecutor's Office and Eurojust, the two bodies should operate in the same place.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. U2012 Resolution on the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office, EUROJUST and the Protection of the Union's Financial Interests, in a context where transnational criminal networks and fraud have increased in recent years.  Article 86 of the E TUE provides for the possibility of establishing a European Public Prosecutor's Office to combat offences affecting the Union's financial interests, where Eurojust has been playing a key role in coordinating the different ways of prosecuting fraud.  In a crisis such as the current one, fraud can be tackled and resources recovered, so the resolution adopted insists on strengthening the role of Eurojust and the European Public Prosecutor's Office; VAT is also an important Community resource which must be included in this legislation. For all this, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted today in favour of the resolution on the European Public Prosecutor's Office and Eurojust, as it is essential to strengthen the cooperation and coordination of the judicial authorities of the various Member States. It is by working together that we can conduct investigations effectively. However, it will be up to the Council to clarify the relationship between Eurojust and the European Public Prosecutor's Office, as well as between the European Public Prosecutor's Office and the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) in order to define and better respect the role of each institution, as suggested in the resolution.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution of the European Public Prosecutor's Office and Eurojust. I support the idea of establishing an effective and independent European Public Prosecutor's Office to strengthen the fight against fraud. On the other hand, in the sake of efficiency, it is necessary to improve legal cooperation between judicial authorities, including both Eurojust and the European Anti-Fraud Office.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. I was in favour of this motion for a resolution on the establishment of an effective and independent European Public Prosecutor's Office in the fight against financial fraud in the European Union (EU), as article 86 TFEU states. In fact, the EU cannot take legal action against criminal activities that are harmful to its budget. In fact, a recent study shows that in 2014 around €160 million in value added tax revenues were lost in the EU, a reason to consider rapid and strict regulation that efficiently, combatand deter fraud cases that harm the EU's financial interests. Eurojust's role in this area is crucial in that it makes it possible to establish a link between the various EU legal systems and national authorities responsible for investigation and prosecution, facilitating the implementation of requests for cooperation, the application of mutual recognition instruments and the improvement of cross-border prosecution.  I support the suggestions made, in particular, as to the legitimacy of the Council for the establishment of the framework of powers and procedures for the European Public Prosecutor's Office, while respecting the protection and guarantee of the procedural rights of persons subject to legal proceedings.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I supported this resolution, which aims to reaffirm the European Parliament's position on the creation of a European Public Prosecutor's Office. It calls for the establishment of an effective and independent European public prosecutor's office to reduce the current fragmentation of the repression efforts of each Member State to protect the Union's financial interests. In such a context of increasing cross-border organised crime, particularly in financial matters, such a European Public Prosecutor's Office would effectively and deterrently combat fraud and thus protect the interests of taxpayers in all Member States participating in the EU budget.  As this resolution reminds us, it should be noted the importance of Eurojust's role in improving cooperation and coordination between competent judicial authorities of the Member States. It is therefore urgent that member states set out the modalities and competences of such a European prosecutor's office and its relations with Eurojust in order to be able to fight financial crimes effectively at European level.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. I have decided to vote in favour of this resolution, because I understand that the establishment of an independent and effective European Public Prosecutor's Office is of great help in combating crimes comprising several countries and is in line with greater European integration of justice systems. We also note positively that the resolution calls for judicial cooperation, the classification of the system of powers and powers. I understand that a European Public Prosecutor's Office with sufficient powers and funds is a positive step forward and that is why I vote in favour.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. The establishment of a European Public Prosecutor's Office, when there is no legal system at European level, is something on which different organisations of jurists have expressed numerous doubts. We understand that, as the institution thinks in this resolution, born on the right, there is no guarantee of the democratic rights that people accused of a crime in the Member States have today. Moreover, the relationship between this prosecutor's office and the courts of the different States, or with the law forces and law forces, is not clarified. Since the conviction that the principle of transparency is fundamental in law, we cannot accept a model that would delve de further into the deficits already in many States, including Spanish. Our model is the necessary coordination of the different judicial systems of the Union, not in creating structures that act in parallel with them, so I have decided to vote against them.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Today, along with other Labour MEPs, I have chosen to abstain from the vote on the resolution as it is still unclear what the structure of the EPPO will be and the impact such a structure could have on the UK criminal system. It is essential that we avoid conflict between national constitutional rules and secondary EU law in order to not hinder the work of national practitioners. Failure to do so could lead to a supranational body which may interfere with their daily work and which may influence priority setting at the national level.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Although the issue of the EPPO is currently divisive among Member States, it is important that the EU and all its Member States detect and prosecute fraud affecting the EU's financial interests in an effective and dissuasive manner, thus protecting taxpayers of all Member States contributing to the Union budget. Although Eurojust has facilitated coordination and cooperation between national investigative and prosecution authorities in dealing with cases affecting several Member States and has contributed to mutual trust, we must stress that there has recently been an increase in organised cross-border crime, perpetrated by extremely mobile and flexible groups operating in many Member States and areas of crime. That is why, as MEPs, we have long expressed our support for the creation of an effective and independent European Public Prosecutor's Office in order to limit the current fragmentation of national enforcement efforts aimed at protecting the EU budget, thereby strengthening the fight against fraud in the EU.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. The European Parliament has been supporting for several years the creation of an effective and independent European Public Prosecutor's Office, which would, in particular, reduce the current fragmentation of national law enforcement efforts to protect the EU budget. In its motion for a resolution, parliament therefore called on the Council to establish unambiguous and clear competences and procedures for the European Public Prosecutor's Office on the basis of the proposed directive on combating fraud affecting the Union's financial interests, and to reopen negotiations with parliament to help establish that body. The European Public Prosecutor's Office will, of course, have to have sufficient investigative measures at its disposal to carry out investigations, but at the same time it will also ensure the protection of the procedural rights of suspects and accused. As I believe that the European Public Prosecutor's Office would be a key part of prosecuting abuses of the EU budget, I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 Joint action in the investigation of cross-border crimes, in particular tax crime and terrorism, is key to strengthening European security and law enforcement. However, the investigation itself must be the exclusive competence of the nation states.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒the Lisbon Treaty (TFEU) extends instruments to protect the EU's financial interests. Accordingly, the Establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office by Eurojust is foreseen by the Council Regulation. Eurojust serves to coordinate and cooperate between Member States in investigations and prosecutions.   The particular importance of combating financial fraud in the EU is evident from the data published by the Commission, in 2014. €159.5 billion has been lost in the EU due to uncollected value added tax (VAT) revenues. I support the proposal for a resolution on the European Public Prosecutor's Office and Eurojust, as I believe that the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office would raise the fight against crimes that undermine the EU's financial interests to a higher and more efficient level than existing ones. Better cooperation between Member State authorities involved in prosecution is aimed at protecting member states' taxpayers and the EU budget.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted against the report on the European Public Prosecutor's Office and the Agency for Cooperation in the Field of Criminal Justice, because both the Commission and the Council are still in the process of internal consultations. The attempt to set up the European Public Prosecutor's Office suffers from serious legal ambiguities and uncertainties that have not yet been cleared up. All the relevant reports that have been made to date bypass, on the one hand, the necessary thorough study of the impact that the creation of such a body will have on national criminal proceedings and, on the other hand, the concerns of many national parliaments. There is also particular concern that this proposed institution, in the form and responsibilities provided for, is the most appropriate option to regulate the problem of fraud to the detriment of the EU's financial interests, while also being able to respect the principle of subsidiarity. But we also disagree on the substance with the delegation of more and more powers and responsibilities to the EU, powers which the Member States currently have exclusively.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution is moving in the right direction, as the European Public Prosecutor's Office and EUROJUST can, together, contribute to the fight against fraud, in particular that linked to the POS Directive and VAT revenue. It is only when drawing up the Rules of Procedure that the observations of the motion for a resolution are taken into account.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the European Public Prosecutor's Office and Eurojust, which confirms Parliament's support for the setting up of an effective and independent European Public Prosecutor's Office (EPPO). The prosecution of offences damaging the EU budget is currently the sole responsibility of the Member States. This fragmentation is extremely damaging as member states' investigating and prosecuting authorities are thus unable to ensure the same level of protection and law enforcement. I therefore agree with the motion, which calls on the Council to step up its efforts to reach agreement on the proposal for a directive on the fight against fraud affecting the Union's financial interests by means of criminal law (PIF) and to resume negotiations with Parliament in order to establish the EPPO. I also approve of the EPPO having primary competence for the offences defined in the PIF Directive and its competence to cover cases where EU funding exceeds EUR 10 000 but does not amount to 50% or more of co-financing. This would help the EPPO to act effectively on all crimes that damage the EU budget.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 According to recent analyses, losses in VAT revenues across the Union amounted to an astronomical €159.5 billion in 2014. It is therefore necessary for the EU, as well as all Member States, to take action to prosecute fraud against the EU's financial interests and to discourage such fraud, thus protecting taxpayers in all Member States contributing to the EU budget. Therefore, the proposal to set up a European Public Prosecutor's Office to reduce the current dispersion of national law enforcement authorities to protect the EU budget seems as appropriate as possible. The resolution rightly points out that a clear and clear set of powers and proceedings concerning the European Public Prosecutor's Office should be developed.  I believe that the creation of a European Public Prosecutor's Office to combat the tax losses suffered by all citizens is necessary, which is why I have chosen to vote in favour of the European Parliament resolution on this issue.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. ‒ I support this report, as it is very important that the EU and all its Member States detect and prosecute in an effective manner fraud affecting the EU’s financial interests, thus protecting the taxpayers of all Member States who contribute to the Union’s budget. This is especially relevant since organised cross-border crime has increased in the past decade and is committed by extremely mobile, flexible groups, which are active in many Member States and areas of crime. I stand behind the idea of establishing an efficient and independent European Public Prosecutor’s Office in order to straighten the fight against fraud in the European Union. As stated in this report, the European Public Prosecutor’s Office should have sufficient investigative measures available to conduct its investigations thoroughly and should cooperate and share information with Eurojust, in order to increase the efficiency of its work.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. With this text, we call on the Council to define a clear and unequivocal set of powers and procedures relating to the European Public Prosecutor's Office, on the basis of the proposed anti-fraud directive undermining the Union's financial interests through criminal law (the 'PIF Directive'). We also call on it to intensify its efforts to reach an agreement on the inclusion of VAT in the scope of the PIF Directive and to reopen negotiations with Parliament to enable the creation of the European Public Prosecutor's Office. We stress that the competence over offences set out in the PIF Directive should be the responsibility of the European Public Prosecutor's Office as a matter of priority and strongly regret that the Council does not authorise the competence of the European Public Prosecutor's Office in cases under the PIF Directive where EU funding exceeds EUR 10,000 but does not represent at least 50% of co-financing. The Council must abandon the rule depriving the European Public Prosecutor's Office of the possibility of exercising its jurisdiction for all offences under the PIF Directive in which the damage to the EU budget is less than or equal to that suffered by another victim.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ The European Public Prosecutor’s office, intended to act as an independent EU body that is able to prosecute crimes affecting the EU’s financial interest, would help fill in the current institutional gap that currently exists, as only national authorities can prosecute EU fraud by means of criminal law, however not across national borders. I voted in favour of the EPPO because of its independent nature, which will make way for improved efficiencies in the prosecution of EU fraud cases. It is estimated by the European Commission that fraud against the EU’s financial interests costs around EUR 3 billion every year. The creation of a European Public Prosecutor’s Office is essential to ensure that fraud against the EU’s financial interests is tackled equally in all Member States.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ This resolution was created in response to two oral questions asked by LIBE to the Council and the Commission on the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office (EPPO). The European Public Prosecutor is conceived as an independent Union body, with the authority to investigate and prosecute in cases of fraud at Union level, and in other cases affecting the financial interests of the Union. The current situation is such that only national public prosecutors of individual Member States have the right to investigate fraud cases and their powers cease at their national borders. Existing European Union bodies (such as OLAF, Eurojust and Europol) do not, nor can they be given an EU-level mandate to conduct criminal investigations. This resolution attempts to impose the EPPO as a primary authority in cases of combating fraud, including those with an additional value tax. While I support the call for a clear distinction to be made in protecting the Union's financial interests between pre-existing bodies, I voted against it because it strongly opposes a serious breach of the principle of subsidiarity, underpinning the European Union, which dictates that problems are always solved at the lowest possible level, preferably where they arise. That level in this case is reserved exclusively for individual Member States of the Union. I strongly oppose attempts to create a European Criminal Law.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. \ I supported the motion for a European Parliament resolution on the European Public Prosecutor's Office and Eurojust. It is important that the EU and all Member States detect and prosecute fraud effectively and dissuasively, thus protecting the taxpayers of all Member States contributing to the Union budget. Eurojust has an important role to play in helping to improve judicial cooperation and coordination between the relevant judicial authorities of the Member States and in investigations involving third countries. It is necessary to establish unambiguous and clear competences and procedures for the European Public Prosecutor's Office, on the basis of the proposed directive on combating fraud affecting the Union's financial interests, by applying criminal law (the EU's Directive on the protection of the EU's financial interests).

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. I have decided to vote in favour of this resolution, because I understand that the establishment of an independent and effective European Public Prosecutor's Office is of great help in combating crimes comprising several countries and is in line with greater European integration of justice systems. We also note positively that the resolution calls for judicial cooperation, the classification of the system of powers and powers. I understand that a European Public Prosecutor's Office with sufficient powers and funds is a positive step forward and that is why I vote in favour.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The text 'reaffirms its long-standing support for the establishment of an effective and independent European public prosecutor's office to reduce the current fragmentation of national law enforcement efforts to protect the EU budget, which would strengthen the fight against fraud in the European Union'. The fight against fraud is therefore being used to create yet another body of the European Union. It should operate alongside Eurojust and OLAF. Eurojust was created to facilitate coordination and cooperation between national authorities responsible for investigating and prosecuting cases involving several Member States. The creation of a European Public Prosecutor's Office is a new step in the sneaky development of a European criminal law, when it must remain a competence of the Member States.  I voted against it.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In the light of Article 86 TFEU, the Council may, after obtaining the consent of the European Parliament, establish a European Public Prosecutor's Office. It would investigate and prosecute perpetrators of fraud related to EU funds. The existence and shape of the European Public Prosecutor's Office raises a number of questions. Until now, only national authorities have been authorised to investigate and prosecute perpetrators in this area. Firstly, it appears that the prevention of fraud to the detriment of the Union's financial interests could be achieved by the Member States within the current framework of coordination and cooperation. The rules on the European Public Prosecutor's Office must be assessed from the point of view of the principle of subsidiarity. Nor should the European Union seek to create new universal criminal law rules. Secondly, the analysis of the PIF Directive also raises concerns. It should be emphasised that 90 per cent of VAT fraud is suffered by Member States. It is therefore not clear that the offences in this area should be within the Union domain, within the competence of the new supranational body. If, on the other hand, the European Public Prosecutor's Office is established, it should be a collegial structure and cooperate closely with the states. In the event of further work on the establishment of this body, the Presidency of the Council must have time to consider these concerns and comments. I therefore voted against the resolution.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. I have decided to vote in favour of this resolution, because I understand that the establishment of an independent and effective European Public Prosecutor's Office is of great help in combating crimes comprising several countries and is in line with greater European integration of justice systems. We also note positively that the resolution calls for judicial cooperation, the classification of the system of powers and powers. I understand that a European Public Prosecutor's Office with sufficient powers and funds is a positive step forward and that is why I vote in favour.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution because I think it is important that the EU and all its Member States detect and prosecute in an effective and dissuasive manner fraud affecting the EU’s financial interests, thus protecting the taxpayers of all the Member States who contribute to the Union’s budget;

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the motions for resolutions on the European Public Prosecutor’s Office and Eurojust. The establishment of an efficient and independent European Public Prosecutor’s Office (EPPO) is crucial in order to reduce the current fragmentation of national law enforcement efforts to protect the EU budget, thus strengthening the fight against fraud in the European Union. The resolution underlines that the EPPO should have sufficient investigative measures available to conduct its investigations. I voted in favour because I believe that the protection of the procedural rights of suspected and accused persons must be guaranteed.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. Since 2012, the European Commission has put forward three proposals concerning the establishment of a European Public Prosecutor's Office, the fight against fraud affecting the Union's financial interests through criminal law and the European Agency for Cooperation in criminal justice (Eurojust), respectively. Since the three plans are interrelated, the Commission has been asked what issues are still pending and what is the timetable for their adoption. The Commission has also been required to provide information on the financial and practical implications of the new European Public Prosecutor's Office (following amendments to its document by the Council), in particular as regards the impact on Eurojust's budget. Finally, the Commission has been asked to explain the operational, organizational and administrative links between the two bodies and to provide information on the degree of participation of national parliaments. Given the need to clarify these issues, I voted in the affirmative.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. The establishment of a European Public Prosecutor's Office, when there is no legal system at European level, is something on which different organisations of jurists have expressed numerous doubts. We understand that, as the institution thinks in this resolution, born on the right, there is no guarantee of the democratic rights that people accused of a crime in the Member States have today. Moreover, the relationship between this prosecutor's office and the courts of the different States, or with the law forces and law forces, is not clarified. Since the conviction that the principle of transparency is fundamental in law, we cannot accept a model that would delve de further into the deficits already in many States, including Spanish. Our model is the necessary coordination of the different judicial systems of the Union, not in creating structures that act in parallel with them, so I have decided to vote against them.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'According to the Member States, around EUR 500 million a year in revenue and expenditure is lost to fraud. But there are other amounts circulating that are much higher. In 2013, the Commission came up with a proposal to create an independent European Public Prosecutor's Office. This makes it easier to act against fraud. I voted in favour of this report because we have an EU budget, but we lacked a Public Prosecutor's Office to prosecute fraud at European level. That was weird. Surely there must be someone who prosecutes fraud against the use of European funds. Besides, fraud doesn't stop at the borders. This also applies to the amount of money that is flowing out of the European budget as a result of fraud. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This report aims at "the Council establishing a set of powers and procedures for the European Public Prosecutor's Office" and "to resume negotiations with the European Parliament with a view to its establishment". They say the "importance of Eurojust's role in improving judicial cooperation and coordination between the competent judicial authorities of the Member States". And they say that "in order to ensure the effectiveness of cooperation and exchange of information between the European Public Prosecutor's Office and Eurojust, the two bodies must operate in the same place". This is another attack on state sovereignty and democracy. The creation of some and the strengthening of others, of these "European" bodies, aim to protect and create mechanisms for repression of the legitimate institutions of the member countries of the European Union. With these proposals, they centralize, structure and strengthen entities such as Eurojust that escape democratic and judicial control, overcoming guarantees as to the rights and freedoms provided for in the national legislative and constitutional frameworks. This goes beyond free and sovereign cooperation between national states, and progress is made with the creation of supranational control mechanisms, initiatives that fall into a security drift that increasingly puts fundamental rights, freedoms and guarantees at risk. We voted against it.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The motion aims to establish a European Public Prosecutor's Office as the institutional centre of a European prosecution and takes a path of further unification and centralisation. The power to prosecute criminal offences should lie exclusively with the nation states (prosecution as a monopoly of the state). I have therefore rejected the request.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the European Public Prosecutor's Office and Eurojust. The proposal reiterates Parliament's support for the establishment of an effective and independent European Public Prosecutor's Office, in order to reduce the current fragmentation of national law enforcement interventions aimed at protecting the EU budget, thereby strengthening the fight against fraud in the European Union. The Council is also invited to establish a clear and unambiguous indication of the powers of the public prosecutor's office, giving it appropriate investigative measures to conduct its own investigations and ensuring adequate judicial review of the decisions taken by the public prosecutor' s office.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Writing. \u2012 Speeding up the procedures for setting up the European Public Prosecutor's Office to prosecute offences 'against the EU's financial interests', seeks the joint EPP, S&D, ALDE and Greens resolution adopted by the European Parliament and voted against by the European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party of Greece. The Euro-Prosecutor's Office is being promoted in the name of the 'fight against corruption', a convenient justification for setting up another reactionary mechanism which is gradually being strengthened with other powers to the detriment of workers' interests, with corresponding delegations of competences by Member States in the field of criminal law. It is carefully concealed that EU funds, the product of heavy taxation of the people, are given as hot money through various programmes (ESPA, Juncker package, etc.) to monopolies and business groups.  This is the great challenge to the people and it is legitimate. In any case, the existing and reprehensible phenomena of splitting taxpayers' money could be dealt with by the competent authorities of the Member States. The only way to meet the needs of workers and their own interests is to strengthen their fight against the EU, against its reactionary mechanisms and the monopolies they serve.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the European Public Prosecutor's Office and Eurojust for agreeing on the need to create an effective and independent European Public Prosecutor's Office in order to reduce the current fragmentation of national efforts.  I would like to call on the Council to establish a clear and clear set of powers and procedures for this new European Public Prosecutor's Office and to resume negotiations with Parliament with a view to its establishment. To that end, I believe that the European Public Prosecutor's Office should have sufficient investigative means to carry out its investigations. I recall Eurojust's role in judicial cooperation and coordination between the competent judicial authorities of the Member States, as well as in supporting investigations involving third countries. I therefore support the proposal to have both bodies operating in the same place.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the European Public Prosecutor's Office and Eurojust. The European Public Prosecutor's Office performs an important law enforcement task to protect the EU budget. In order to strengthen the role of an effective and independent institution in the fight against fraud in the EU, it is necessary for the Council to establish unambiguous and clear competences and procedures for the European Public Prosecutor's Office and to clarify the relations between Eurojust and the European Public Prosecutor's Office. On the other hand, it is also necessary to ensure the protection of the procedural rights of suspects and accused persons prosecuted by the European Public Prosecutor's Office, in particular the right to legal aid, the right to information and access to the file, the right to give evidence and the right to ask the European Public Prosecutor's Office to gather evidence on behalf of the suspect.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: – Mr President, we all know the pain and damage of industrial restructuring. Like the examples of Alstom and Caterpillar, many manufacturers are facing tough and uncertain times across the continent, threatening the livelihoods of millions of working people.  Following the decision to leave the EU, this threat is, for British industry, all the more acute than ever before and has been intensified by the threat of the loss of single market access. We need real industrial and trade strategies which provide a clear policy framework and road maps for industrial sectors and the regional economies that support them. While the critical mass of the EU is vital for industrial research and development programs and for fairness in international markets, this can only be achieved with substantial investment in key infrastructure and open dialogue with all stakeholders. We have heard many platitudes, but now we need to see real action in the EU – and especially in the UK – for our manufacturing workforce.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: – Mr President, at the beginning of September, the Caterpillar group announced the closure of its company in Charleroi, Belgium: 2,200 factory employees and around 5,000 subcontractors will lose their jobs in the coming days. The decision to close the factory is quite surprising because, in the first quarter of the year, Caterpillar had announced that the company was again competitive. What's the point of this closure? Caterpillar is headquartered in Switzerland, allowing you to pay 30% less tax. And this has a name, this is tax evasion. Despite this, despite being a profitable company, we witnessed a new relocation of one more company, a company that received public funds. We must urgently establish a mechanism that prohibits these squeezing practices, with which workers pay the consequences in the end.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European It was a touching scene when we saw here in the gallery the working people and their representatives who had lost their jobs, their existentialism because of bad, socially unthinking decisions, factory closures. I ask my fellow Members to magnify this gallery in thought. Let us put there hundreds of thousands, millions of people, such as Hungarians, who had just lost their jobs and had to live the tragic image and scene and the feeling of life that they bulldozed and made equal to the earth the factories where they lived their lives and where they did produce high-quality products, from Ikarus buses to canning factories. Why? This is because privatisations have taken place unthinkingly in line with the expectations of the honourable European Union and the Western world. They wanted to give everything to the West, and to the hands of their well-placed comrades at the right time. We shouldn't have done that, and then maybe we shouldn't be talking about re-industrialization.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: – Mr President, a small example of the state of industry in the European Union this year is: Caterpillar, in Belgium, 2,200 laid-off workers; Ericsson, 1,556 in Sweden and 350 in Spain; in Valladolid, Lauki, final closure and 200 lost jobs; and in Asturias, already, for what to say, with the scheduled closure of absolutely all mines. We are all victims of the deind industrialisation of much of Europe and, from this Commission, with the support of governments that are in addition to financial markets, tell us that they are committed to competitiveness, and I ask them: how can we be competitive if there is no productive fabric or stability?  In the face of this question, we say that reind industrialization must be linked to new employment niches such as the renewable strategies sector, the defence of the role of mining in the energy transition, the commitment to the public sector and public banking for investment and control of the economy and, above all, also the revision of free trade agreements to countries that practice social and environmental dumping.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Mr President, when dealing with massive job losses caused by changes in world trade and technology, I believe we need to follow a comprehensive approach. First, we need to demonstrate true compassion and take care of those who are hurt by open trade or changing global economic patterns. We should also insist more on active employment policies and training for workers to help people get back into the labour market. However, training can only function efficiently if we have dynamic and competitive economies to create new jobs and bring back the dismissed into the labour force. I think the report duly recognised this, and I was glad to vote for it.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, as a co-author of this report, I am very pleased with the eventual outcome and the huge majority that voted in favour of it, because it sends a very strong message to workers – especially in Caterpillar and Alstom – that we stand in solidarity with them. It is not just the preserve of one particular group: my group (the EPP) and others understand their plight very well and stand with them, especially the workers in Northern Ireland who are also affected. This points out to us that we really have to focus on our target of reindustrialising Europe and getting 20% of GDP from industry. To do that, we have to tackle the challenges: first, competition from abroad – from outside Europe; second, climate change; third, finance; and fourth, skill shortages. If we do that, I think we can have a friendly environment for industry and progress and really reindustrialise Europe.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am speaking with the situation at the Ilva steelworks in Taranto in mind, with accidents at work that are on the agenda and with the incidence rate of cancer and respiratory diseases reaching dramatic levels among workers and citizens who also live in the surrounding areas. Interventions that omit or neglect the protection of health and the environment are not acceptable.  Why do we not dare to encourage research and innovation or, where appropriate, the transformation of activity? What is the point of saving jobs if that same job causes death and disease? Who benefits from a kind of political engineering that does not care about the dignity of human life? A real circular economy, with the use of second raw material with high energy efficiency of production plants, can be the revolution necessary to safeguard the level of employment, guaranteeing respect for the environment and the protection of workers. Where it is clear that it is incompatible with the lives of workers and citizens, there must be an obligation to clean up and reconversion the area which can combine employment and health, production and the environment. But this view is not taken into account. That is why I had to abstain.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – Mr President, in September Caterpillar announced that it would lay off 10 000 people. Also in France, Alstom is about to stop production at one of the compounds after 130 years of activity. It is true that industries, especially extractive ones, have been facing a lack of supply for several years and, as such, production is in decline. And in my country, in Romania, the Hunedoara Energy Complex announced that it would lay off more than 800 employees, and the Oltenia Energy Complex gave up more than 1,300 employees in the first six months of this year.  Of course we stand in solidarity with them and at the expense of the state they have to be prepared to be able to do other jobs, to have other work. But we need innovation, we need 21st century industries, and as such, that's what we need to focus our money on, not maintain industries that we no longer need. So: innovation, 21st century industries and that's where our money works.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: Mr President, how long are we going to continue to vote on texts as hypocritical as this one? I abstained because it is a mixture of good intentions and absolutely astonishing silence and unacceptable rejected amendments. How can you talk about Alstom and Caterpillar, which are two leading companies in their technical field, without doing the part that amounts to the greed of shareholders? Alstom has distributed 6 billion euros to its shareholders over the last ten years, and Caterpillar 1.7 billion. The United States denounces them as people who cheat and repatriate their profits. However, you have refused to condemn the transfer of profits that allow companies to declare themselves in deficit, when they are not. You are asking Europe for a strategy in this area, but you are referring to the Europe 2020 strategy, which is at the root of this kind of disaster. At the same time, you refuse to give priority to workers who would like it the opportunity to own their business by making cooperatives. You refuse to transfer to them the globalization funds that you use to compensate for layoffs, but which you do not want to give to employees when they take over their business. I deplore the contempt that this text expresses towards employees by making them believe that it was voted in their favour, when this is not the case.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I am pleased that the Union has recognised the need for reindustrialisation after 20 years of deindustrialisation policies. Yesterday, in this House, we passed idiotic environmental legislation: the Paris Convention, which will cause 15 to 20 million people in Europe to lose their jobs if, of course, this were done. Fortunately, no one will do this, but here in this House Parliament has passed legislation that will cause 15 to 20 million people to lose their jobs, because of the increased taxes needed to fight global warming completely idiotic. Well, ladies and country, this is hypocrisy. I agree with my colleague Mélenchon. Instead, I remember the days of communism, when various working-class delegations were brought to parliaments. It is not about taking care of the rights of individual workers of a particular factory. We need to completely change the policy that was to fight industrialisation, to industry, to capitalism. We need to get back to normal. Thank you for your attention. Furthermore, I believe that the European Union must be destroyed.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding motion for a resolution. While of course UKIP sympathises with the sudden loss of jobs, the resolution was being used as an excuse for the EU to take more action and create an EU ‘reindustrialisation policy’. The only people who should decide economic policy are our elected national governments, not unaccountable bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I abstained in this resolution because, while containing positive elements (improving the use of European funds and public procurement in support of European industry, the role of the social partners, recognition of the importance of industrial policy, the need to reform competition policies to promote employment...) contains hardly any critical references to how European policies , from deregulation and privatization to their aggressive foreign trade policy, are responsible for Europe's industrial crisis.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – Our group in Parliament met with Caterpillar workers and representatives, including those from the north of Ireland, and in view of the situation as they explained it, we drafted a strong motion which put the workers at its heart. In trying to find agreement for a joint motion with the other groups in Parliament, the strong references to workers’ rights were watered down by those on the right of Parliament. In conjunction with this, the right of Parliament not only managed to remove the workers as central, but they shaped the motion in a way which put employers and shareholders as central. We always have had, and always will have, workers, their families, and their communities at heart when we vote on motions in relation to Employment and Social Affairs in the European Parliament. It was for this reason that we couldn’t support the joint motion today that didn’t have them at its heart.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution. We need an ambitious European industrial policy so that whole swathes of our industry do not disappear. The starting point is to anticipate restructuring and strengthen social dialogue with all stakeholders at European, national and local level in order to avoid job losses and redundancies. In June 2016, the European Parliament called on the Commission to boost public orders in the rail sector through the full use of EU funds. This resolution must apply! Finally, the Union must play its role in protecting and defending its industries and jobs in the face of increasing international competition and, in particular, in the face of the emergence of large groups, particularly in China, which benefit from massive public subsidies. The European Union must no longer be the idiot of the global village and must define a more strategic and offensive vision in industrial policy: there is an urgent need, the Alstom and Caterpillar cases remind us!

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: Written. Today, the European Parliament voted on a resolution on industrial policy, on the occasion of recent notices in steel works in France and Belgium. I share the spirit of the text of the resolution on solidarity and support for all the workers concerned and recognise the negative effects on the local communities concerned.  Unfortunately, the wrong conclusions are drawn.  The resolution presents customs duties and supranational industrial subsidies as the way to increased European competitiveness. It's an incorrect analysis.  Nor are various proposals for supranational solutions in the field of labour market and tax policy, which are also included in the text of the resolution, in consistent with the Christian Democrats' view of the role of the European Union.  I therefore chose to vote against the resolution.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution outlines industrial policy objectives at European level for the coming years, in response to redundancies and restructuring by companies in key sectors of European industry. However, there is no adequate emphasis on important issues such as the circular economy, the energy efficiency of production plants, respect for the environment and the protection of workers. For these reasons, I abstained.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the need for a European reindustrialisation policy in light of the recent Caterpillar and Alstom cases. The closure of the Caterpillar site in Belgium and Alstom site in France are reflections of the deindustrialisation of certain sectors in many European countries. The closures reflect current economic changes and require swift action on EU level. The closure will have an enormous impact on the affected regions, which are already under economic pressure. Concerns have been raised about the effects on unemployment in both France and Belgium.  I welcome this resolution, as I think that companies which are active in the EU have the legal and moral responsibility to engage in social dialogue with the workforce and regional and national authorities. Employers should also ensure the reconversion of their employees, so that they can more easily find new employment. Additionally, it is important that we develop a strong reindustrialisation policy that puts focus on attracting foreign investment, increasing competitiveness, digitalisation, research and development.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft resolution on the need for a European reindustrialisation policy in the light of the recent Caterpillar and Alstom cases, because Europe is a social market economy with a dynamic labour market, efficient social security systems and sustainable economic growth for its citizens.

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: Written. 'I express my support and solidarity to the affected workers of the closures. The EU keeps open doors under the guise of 'free trade' and gives competitors from third countries virtually unfettered access to several, often strategic, sectors of its economy without any reciprocity. However, more proactive efforts are needed to save and/or even bring industry back to our continent. In this respect, the EU is, by all the rules and burdens, a brake rather than an engine. The Member States themselves must be able to pursue an active (re)industrialisation policy and adopt an economic patriotism. Some speak of a 'fourth industrial revolution' in Europe, promoting local creativity and local production in a sustainable way.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. This is a motion for a resolution on the need for a European reindustrialisation policy in the light of the current Caterpillar and Alstom cases.  In these sad social dramas, it is extremely important that Parliament should send out a clear signal to the workers concerned and push for a European reindustrialisation policy by a large majority. This includes a consistent fight against tax evasion and a fair and effective industrial policy that safeguards jobs in Europe. In addition, I believe that there should also be a reassessment of the Stability and Growth Pact, which, in combination with ESA standards, significantly affects the investment capacity of the public authorities.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. In September, U.S. construction equipment manufacturer Caterpillar announced plans to close its only Belgian plant in Gosselies, resulting in the loss of 2,200 jobs in the already affected region of Charleroi. Alstom has announced the closure of its Belfort site, which specialises in the construction of railway equipment. The company motivated its decision by the reduction of orders from SNCF, which preferred Bombardier as a supplier for TERs. The French government has announced a solution to maintain employment in Belfort with the order of new TGV trainsets to run on the Intercité network. The majority groups took advantage of the media coverage of these cases to revive the idea of European industrial policy, "without protectionism". The motions of the resolution promote free trade and require reciprocity and open public procurement by other powers. There is no Community preference in sight for rail, which is an industry of sovereignty.
