We want green growth but without massive investments possible only by monetary creation for the benefit of the real economy. Social Europe is a mirage that its promoters no longer even believe in. So I voted against the joint proposal.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst I opposed the final resolution as it calls for more EU legislation, I supported many amendments and parts of the original text which recognise the problems with these cases.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because I want a real long-term European strategy to ensure that industry accounts for 20% of gross domestic product, as indicated in the Europe 2020 strategy. Therefore, I believe it is appropriate to use trade and competition policy to achieve these objectives while ensuring compliance with public procurement legislation. However, Europe cannot replace the Member States for reforms for them.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal on the need for a European policy on reindustrialisation in the light of the recent cases of Caterpillar and Alstom. On September 2, 2016, Caterpillar announced in April 2017 that it would be resigning from the Company. closes its headquarters in Gosli (Belgium) and will result in 2 000 job decommable employees. Alstom also announced on 7 September 2016 that it would be able to shift train production from Belfort in France. Belfort) to the Reichshoffen, which threatens 400 jobs. In view of these emerging problems, which are directly linked to the social security of workers, I support the European Parliament's call for the real economy to be stimulated through sustainable reindustrialisation policies, i.e. to coordinate economic policies based on higher social standards and domestic demand as a driving force, thereby promoting development, energy efficiency, renewable energy, resource efficiency and social innovation.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: Writing. \u2012 The joint proposal for a decision underlines the need for a flexible industrial policy that supports a competitive industry on the world market while meeting social and environmental requirements and complementing it with an appropriate trade policy. In my view, there is nothing new in the proposal that would lead to a real industrial policy. This would need strong defending of eu industry, including a catch-up programme for weaker developed countries. Eu workers should be protected from speculative decisions by multinationals and multinationals should in most cases be replaced by nation-state firms, ensuring public participation in strategic industries. All this is missing, and as long as neoliberal principles (Maastricht criteria, Lisbon Treaty) govern the Union, such a policy cannot be developed. On this basis, the decision was rejected.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding motion for a resolution. While of course UKIP sympathises with the sudden loss of jobs, the resolution was being used as an excuse for the EU to take more action and the create an EU ‘reindustrialisation policy’. The only people who should decide economic policy are our elected national governments, not unaccountable bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. The majority groups want to take advantage of the media coverage of these cases to revive the idea of a European industrial policy "without protectionism": the promotion of free trade on the one hand and the demand for reciprocity and the opening of public procurement by other powers on the other. So, for example, no Community preference in sight for rail, which is an industry of sovereignty. I voted against this motion for a resolution which wants to give new powers to the European Commission, an overly integrated approach to industrial policy which should be based on cooperation between Member States.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I approved the joint resolution because it contains several important priorities. It, of course, calls for strong measures to support European industry, particularly in terms of research and development and innovation. But the resolution also calls for facilitating the takeover of the sites by local authorities, sanctioning stock market layoffs and involving subcontractors in negotiations in the event of collective redundancies. This is an encouraging result. But I will of course continue to defend these social priorities tooth and nail at a time when Caterpillar and ING workers are facing measures of unspoken brutality.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 Caterpillar Holding announced on September 2, 2016 an extensive worldwide restructuring plan that will result in the closure of several plants in Europe. The Gosselies office has already closed its doors, leaving 2 500 people at home and putting another 4 000 related jobs at risk. Similar cases are likely to occur as a result of the feared closure of Alstom plants in Italy and Spain. These are worrying events which, however, make clear the need for a European policy of reindustrialisation, which is the subject of a resolution that I have supported here today. Firstly, we need measures to support workers to help the regions affected by the closures to cope with this difficult economic and social situation. The eu's new industrial policy should be based on ambitious and clear targets for energy efficiency, resources and climate, establishing a life-cycle and circular economy approach. Public action must be shifted from supply-side support to concerted policies that stimulate demand, while also proposing new fiscal measures and guarantees of wage increases. A restructuring of europe's large manufacturing companies, with the emergence of economic operators with sufficient critical mass, will allow in the face of international competition.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I would like to thank the negotiators of this report for their work in reaching a common resolution on such an important issue; have been hard days of negotiations. I voted in favour of this report but I do not agree that every time a company closes a resolution on it. The drama of unemployment is woefully very visible in our society and a general resolution would have been much more objective than a two-company-focused one.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I voted against the resolutions and abstained for the resolution of the ECR group. The proposals are not satisfactory, not least because of the lack of Community preference in the railway sector, which is an industry of sovereignty. The Alstom case is a tragic and absurd demonstration of France's failures since Maastricht: the dismantling of our heavy industry, the blind follow-up of European technocrats who have relied on the services economy since the early 2000s. But also and above all, the shutdown of the Alstom plant demonstrates that economic protectionism, measured and strategic, is a survival imperative for states plunged into globalization.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite some interesting ideas, the text does not present solutions that can really be spent by European industry, which is experiencing a strong period of crisis. The recipe for restarting our industry is not 'more Europe', as this text will make us believe. What we need is new policies that really support the efforts of our territories. For these reasons, I did not support the text with my vote.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. \u2012 The resolution has positive wordings such as that "support for banks in the EU had no impact on employment or improved economic perspectives". At the same time, however, reference is also made to the Europe 2020 strategy, which is linked to European semesters and the austerity policies that have long been established within the EU.  I would have preferred a resolution that clearly rejects austerity policies and advocates that the EU should take a stand in favour of an expansive green economic policy which, through climate-smart investment in industry and the public sector, makes the wheels roll again.  The resolution also contains phrases such as reducing the 'administrative burdens' of businesses and stresses the importance of 'abolishing unnecessary legislation'. As this is not fleshed out, it opens up interpretations that could lead to serious deterioration in the working environment and workers' and consumers' rights.  The resolution also calls for "greater convergence between Member States on fiscal, social and budgetary issues." I am opposed to proposals that have such a federal approach. For these reasons, I choose to abstain

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which was launched at the initiative of the S&D Group, by which the European Parliament urges the adoption of a strategy to re-industrialisation of Europe in the light of Caterpillar's plant closure announcements in Belgium and Alstom in France, and the dismissal of thousands of workers. Situations such as those of these plants reveal the need to develop a true European industrial policy that must be based not only on investment development, but on the implementation of a new competition policy and a new trade policy that curbs social dumping. And they also reveal the need to be demanding with companies that, even making a profit, decide to close their plants leaving thousands of workers in the stale. Today Parliament has raised its voice to demand sanctions, such as the repayment of public aid or the suspension of access to certain EU programmes.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, in which the European Parliament calls on the Council not to take a decision on the modernisation of trade defence mechanisms, so that it can finally respond appropriately to unfair practices in third countries and to protect European industry from dumping on the European market, thereby ensuring fair competition for all. Parliament also calls on the Commission to ensure that EU trade policy is more compatible with industrial policy and that trade policy takes into account the need to protect jobs in EU industry, thus not carrying out new relocations and further deindustrialisation. It is also important for the Commission to ensure that trade agreements include specific provisions that ensure better market access for EU industry and ensure a level playing field for European and non-European market players. Parliament also calls on the Commission to ensure compliance with EU regulations on public procurement, i.e. regulations on state preferences, proposals for abnormally low prices and unfair competition. The European Parliament reiterates the need for the EU to anticipate the negative impact of free trade agreements on employment and EU industry, and European funds must provide support to provide funds to regions and/or sectors of activity that have been adversely affected by these agreements.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 In my opinion, the European Union must do more to create a more competitive European industry and to protect the jobs of those working in the industry. As we know, in 2015 Hungary, the top-10 industry in the European Union, including water and waste management, accounted for more than 27% of its contribution to total gross value added. The EU average was 19% and Hungary fifth place in the EU rankings with an increase of 21.5% compared to 2010. At the same time, we must also pay attention to the world market, because it is becoming increasingly clear that competition is in sharpening and that all actors (employers, workers, government) must pay attention to this and actively contribute to strengthening the European Union at the same time and in support of each other. Since the Hungarian Government also believes, in line with the OSH action plans launched earlier, that the loss of workers' skills and skills must be prevented and that Europe must maintain its industrial capacity to meet its needs without being dependent on manufacturers from third countries. An independent domestic industry cannot be imagined with competitive European industry, markets and multinationals. Since 2013, employers have benefited from more than HUF 360 billion in discounts, preserving the jobs of nearly 900,000 workers a year. In view of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. I also supported the joint resolution on the need for a European policy for reindustrialisation in the light of the recent caterpillar and Alstom cases, as it is precisely these examples that demonstrate the need to re-strengthen industry in Europe. The abandonment of production in those companies risks losing thousands of employees and labour specifics, and there is a high risk of permanent unemployment. I strongly agree with the statement in the resolution that European industry should be seen as a strategic advantage for the EU's competitiveness. It is also necessary to ensure the strength and resilience of economies, and to focus industrial policies in the EU on the future and the creation of new quality jobs. Efforts to achieve the Europe 2020 objectives, i.e. 20% of gross domestic product generated by industry, should also be stepped up, noting that the most resilient are those industries that invest the most in innovation, research and development, energy efficiency, the circular economy, etc. It is precisely the latter, in my opinion, that represents a great opportunity for European industry.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution aimed at re-industrialising the Union will undoubtedly fail its purpose in the glaring absence of any will to protectionism or Community preference on rail. Therefore I vote against it.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe our industry has to face several challenges, such as reindustrialisation, the transition to sustainability and the creation of quality employment. The first challenge needs clear European support for our workers who are dealing with their dismissals. That is the reason why I voted yes to this resolution. Especially concerning the recent Caterpillar and Alstom cases, this resolution expressed the EU’s solidarity to all their workers, showing the social face of our Union. I stand for a Europe closer to its workers.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Industry has played a decisive role both in the process of integrating the European Union and in promoting employment and redistributing wealth among its citizens. We cannot stand by and watch the destruction of European industry, we need a new industrial strategy at EU level. Faced with the new cases under consideration, the Commission must mobilise rapidly all available funds, in particular the European Social Fund and the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, to ensure the occupational reintegration of redundant workers from the Caterpillar plant in Gosselies and Alstom and all their subcontractors as soon as possible and, where appropriate, to provide them with adequate support to acquire new skills; but that is not enough. We need to transform the approach to the industrial sector with a view to support and extraordinary development, which can also derogate from the European strategies used to date. Safeguarding employment and production on the ground is a priority over any political or trade agreement.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. In September, Caterpillar and Alstom announced their intention to close their sites in Charleroi and Belfort, which would result in the loss of several thousand jobs in regions already affected by wild globalization. It is in this context that this motion for a resolution revives the idea of a common industrial policy in Europe. In the face of the failure of the European Union to curb unfair international competition against our companies, this motion for a resolution still stresses the need to increase economic integration between Member States. The distressing banalities found in this text, such as the revival of public and private investment or the increased participation of employees in restructuring plans, do not lessen the harmfulness of this report.  Only a trade policy that respects the strategic interests of everyone that conditions tariff concessions to reciprocity in free trade agreements, accompanied by a return to national currencies to correct competitiveness gaps in the euro area, will help protect our industries and jobs.  I obviously voted against this text.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. This resolution outlines the enormous problems facing the European Union in re-industrializing. The recent cases of Alstom and Caterpillar are particularly representative of this problem. Both companies are forced to relocate, resulting in the loss of many jobs. The closure of the Caterpillar plant in Belgium represents the loss of 2,000 direct jobs and 4 to 7,000 subcontractor jobs and the closure of Alstom's Belfort plant represents the displacement of 400 jobs. The resolution calls on the Commission to put in place a genuine European re-industrialisation strategy so that industry accounts for 20% of European GDP. There is an urgent need to face increased competition from third countries in the industrial sector. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of this resolution to call for measures to support caterpillar and alstom workers and to help the regions concerned to cope with this difficult economic and social situation. I call on the Commission to develop, together with the Member States, a Union strategy for a coherent and comprehensive industrial policy aimed at the reindustrialisation of Europe. This new industrial policy strategy should facilitate investment in new technologies and innovation, improve market conditions both in the internal market and on international markets, extend access to finance and support investment in human capital and skills. I also think that the Commission and the European Investment Bank must focus above all on the regions most affected by deindustrialisation and speed up support for projects in these regions.  Finally, I call on the Commission to work with the various industrial sectors to ensure the best possible use of the European Structural and Investment Funds, in particular the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF), in support of research and development projects at regional level.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report. Sinn Féin met with Caterpillar workers and representatives, including those from the north of Ireland, and in view of the situation as they explained it, we drafted a strong alternative motion which put the workers at its heart. In trying to find agreement for a joint motion with the other groups in Parliament, the strong references to workers’ rights were watered down by those on the right of Parliament. In conjunction with this, the right of Parliament not only managed to remove the workers as central, but they shaped the motion in a way which put employers and shareholders at the centre. Additionally, the references to the Europe 2020 strategy which runs in line with the European Semester means that many of the amendments linked to Europe 2020 cannot be achieved because countries are in fiscal straitjackets. These, as well as other problematic Articles, meant that I could not support the Joint Resolution as a whole. For these reasons, I abstained.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution. This is an important and timely resolution. A reaction was necessary in the face of such a significant amount of dismissals and the spillover effect that this brings with it, affecting subcontractors and related SMEs in the region. Such major industrial restructuring announcements are a hard blow for affected employees, their families and the communities. The text calls for safeguards for dismissed workers, urgent measures for their reinsertion into the labour market, and respect for the legislation on the information and consultation of workers. Furthermore the resolution is calling for a strong European long-term strategy on industrial policy. On the other hand, I voted against references in the text calling for increased convergence among Member States in fiscal matters.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 European industry has high added value. Unfortunately, this fundamental and strategic sector is facing fierce global competition from countries that export cheaper products to the European market through an aggressive and rapidly expanding policy on all continents, often benefiting from the political and financial support of their governments. As the resolution is not ambitious and does not propose concrete solutions, I abstained.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: in writing. ‒ Even though European industry is important part of the EU economy, I voted against the resolution. It uses recent cases of businesses deciding to move their activities to another part of the EU as a case for establishing a European reindustrialisation policy. Yes, there will be employees left without jobs and we have to make sure we help them to cope with their uneasy situation, offer them support and new opportunities. On the other hand, the companies have decided to move within the internal market and they should be free to do so, as this is one of the key principles of EU integration.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We call on the Commission to mobilise all available resources, in particular the European Social Fund and the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, so that the laid-off workers of the Caterpillar plant in Gosselies and that of Alstom, as well as all subcontracted workers, are reintegrated into the labour market as soon as possible and given the appropriate support to acquire new skills.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution on the need to adopt a European reindustrialisation policy, particularly in the light of the recent Caterpillar and Alstom cases, contained positive elements. Indeed, we are called upon to resolve the issue of the ever-declining progress of a large part of European businesses, which directly affects the lives of thousands of European workers. However, we cannot support proposals aimed directly and exclusively at strengthening and supporting industrial plants, if this is not combined with the appropriate protection of workers, but also with specific obligations at economic and environmental level. I therefore did not.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. Having regard to the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, and in particular Articles 9, 151, 152, 153(1) and (2), and Article 173 thereily, and having regard to the various communications from the various institutions and offices; Whereas there is now an absolute need for coherence between the different EU policies in order to define a genuine industrial policy, in particular in the light of the Caterpillar and Alstom cases; given that Caterpillar Holding has announced a worldwide restructuring plan, that the Gosselies site has been closed as part of this plan, with the consequent redundancies of 2 500 direct workers and the risk of some 4 000 jobs; Given that Caterpillar has decided to relocate its plants to other parts where the cost of production has a significant impact and that the plants in question are not the only ones affected by the restructuring and further redundancies are planned at other plants in Spain and Italy, as well as at the Caterpillar plant in Northern Ireland, I agree and voted in favour of the document so that The Member States can guarantee adequate social protection and adequate working conditions. , ensuring effective protection against unfair dismissal.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 With this vote I would like to express my full participation in the pain of those who have suddenly seen their stability falter, so I strongly support the need for an industrial policy for the EU. This is an urgent issue that has emerged for decades and requires the construction of a resilient and future-oriented European industry, capable of making a transition to sustainability, maintaining its identity as a social market economy through quality employment. From this point of view, therefore, common trade and competitive policies must be implemented in order to cope with globalisation and its effects. In this respect, it should be remembered that, although the Union has opened up to competitors from third countries, they have, on the contrary, introduced barriers against our companies by discriminating against them. So they have operated on the one hand aggressive penetration into our markets, also thanks to the support of their own countries, while we have remained inerti. What can be done to relaunch the competitiveness of European industry is a pointless question to ask because the time has come for action. Therefore, an intelligent specialisation agenda must be set and priority given to economic conversion and R&D studies in areas where the EU can be a leader, bearing in mind that those who do not fit will end up dying out.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the joint motion for a resolution on the need for a European reindustrialisation policy in light of the recent Caterpillar and Alstom cases and noted no objections.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. Caterpillar recently announced a major global restructuring plan that led to the closure of the Gosselies facility, leading to the dismissal of 2,500 direct workers, and called into question the jobs of about 4,000 subcontractors. On the other hand, Alstom's Board of Directors announced the transfer of its train manufacturing activity (400 jobs) from the Belfort to Reichshoffen unit. This central and strategic industry for the EU faces strong global competition from countries exporting low-cost products to the European market. European industry must therefore be seen as a strategic asset for the competitiveness and sustainability of the EU. Only a strong and resilient industry and a future-oriented policy will enable the EU to address the different challenges ahead, such as reindustrialisation, the transition to sustainability and the creation of quality jobs. The Commission should develop with the Member States a Union strategy for a coherent and comprehensive industrial policy for the reindustrialisation of Europe, on the basis, inter alia, of digitisation, sustainability, energy efficiency and appropriate resources. For the foregoing, I supported this motion for a resolution.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the resolution because only with an EU-wide strong industrial policy will we remain competitive as a business location. We must further strengthen our industrial policy, investing even more in innovation, energy efficiency, a functioning circular economy and digital development.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding motion for a resolution. While of course UKIP sympathises with the sudden loss of jobs, the resolution was being used as an excuse for EU to take more action and the create an EU ‘reindustrialisation policy’. The only people who should decide economic policy are our elected national governments, not unaccountable bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because the resolution stresses that, although many sectors of the EU economy are largely open to competitors from third countries, these countries have introduced several barriers that discriminate against European companies and, furthermore, competitors from third countries, especially China, are proceeding with a rapid and aggressive expansion in Europe: such practices can constitute a form of unfair competition and actually threaten jobs in Europe, as the Caterpillar and Alstom that have negative employment consequences also in Italy. The Commission must therefore define a long-term Union trade policy that will protection workers, that is in line with its industrial objectives and that it avoids further relocations and deindustrialisation.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ I see scope in the intention of the report to preserve and create jobs.  This can only be done if Member States set the right conditions for EU industry, which is faced with fierce global competition in which not all actors respect the same standards and rules. It is of concern that major industrial restructuring announcements strike a hard blow to the employees affecting their families and the communities in which companies are located.  For such purposes we should foster reindustrialisation to take on the principle of urgency in seeking to address the continuing problems as quickly as possible. We need to reintegrate workers dismissed, for example from Caterpillar Gosselies and Alstom and all their subcontractors, back into the labour market as soon as possible and to give them adequate support to acquire new skills where needed. This can be done if Member States have national employment services to enhance cooperation at national and international level in order to improve information channels and better match job offers with demand. Consequently I support the call upon the Commission and the Member States to boost ICT and STEM training and education in order to equip both the current and the future workforce with the relevant e-skills.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I abstained in this resolution because, while containing positive elements (improving the use of European funds and public procurement in support of European industry, the role of the social partners, recognition of the importance of industrial policy, the need to reform competition policies to promote employment...) contains hardly any critical references to how European policies , from deregulation and privatization to their aggressive foreign trade policy, are responsible for Europe's industrial crisis.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 On September 2, Caterpillar announced a large and savage restructuring plan affecting the Gosselies production site in Belgium, which is expected to close, resulting in the dismissal of 2,500 direct workers, while putting the work of some 4,000 induced washers at risk. This is just the umpteenth restructuring plan for the company, which ends up burdening only workers, who have always been weak in the chain. This is an unacceptable situation which calls into question the absence of a genuine Policy of European Reindustrialisation. A new EU industrial policy, based on clear objectives and indicators, making the best use of available resources, also in line with the principles of the circular economy. A policy that includes an intelligent mix of measures that affect both supply and demand, capable of relocating the economy within the continent and avoiding continuous leaks. An industrial plan that points to investments in creativity, skills, innovation and sustainable technologies, making the most of, rather than continuing to disperse, the human capital of which Europe is rich.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 On the resolution on the need for a European reindustrialisation policy in the light of the recent Caterpillar and Alstom cases, I decided to vote against. The resolution is due to mass layoffs announced by both Caterpillar and Alston. For the first company, the number of job cuts in the world will reach 10,000. The company's declining turnover is due to a global slowdown in oil mining. Alston, which plans to end train production in Belfort, will end a 130-year tradition, despite the layoffs of about 400 people, will offer employees a job at other locations. The situation of the two giant companies – Caterplillar and Alston – should lead us MEPs to think about how to tackle such situations, but I do not believe that there is a need for a European policy of reindustrialisation, which is why I voted against.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ This motion for resolution calls for a policy to ‘reindustrialise’ the EU, in the wake of the closure of factory facilities and redundancy plans announced by Caterpillar and Alstom in Belgium and France respectively. Europe needs a forward-looking industrial strategy to improve operating conditions for companies and protect workers. The European Industry is affected by the financial and legislative frameworks for companies, globalisation, and worldwide competition. Fighting unemployment has always been one of my main priorities, and this is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that European industry is exposed to global competition, I believe that only an ambitious innovation policy, which favours the manufacture of high-quality, innovative and energy-efficient products and promotes new production processes, will enable the European Union to manage on its own in an increasingly competitive global context , thus allowing European industries to create research and development partnerships or strategic alliances and not limit their analyses only to the internal market.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This European Parliament resolution aims to draw the consequences of the industrial news that has brought to light the difficulties of Alstom and Caterpillar, and the impact of layoffs in European industry. The resolution calls for greater mobility in the UNION through greater employability and international recognition of skills, particularly in the area of languages. Considering that European industry must move towards future economic sectors and cutting-edge technologies, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding motion for a resolution. While of course UKIP sympathises with the sudden loss of jobs, the resolution was being used as an excuse for EU to take more action and create an EU ‘reindustrialisation policy’. The only people who should decide economic policy are our elected national governments, not unaccountable bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on the need for a European policy of re-industrialisation in the light of the recent Caterpillar and Alstom cases. Indeed, the closures of these sites, and the numerous layoffs they have caused, are a terrible reflection of a European industry in constant decline. There is an urgent need for Europe to tackle a genuine policy of re-industrialisation in order to boost jobs, growth and competitiveness in Europe. In particular, we call on the Commission to ensure a trade policy consistent with these objectives in order to ensure fair competition for our companies.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe there is an urgent need for more cooperation and convergence between Member States on industrial policy. The example of the recent Caterpillar and Alstom cases shows that more work is needed to strengthen the competitiveness of European industry and re-industrialize our continent. If we want to prevent similar cases from happening again, real structural policies must be put in place for industry that will realistically achieve the target of increasing the share of industry to 20% of GDP by 2020.  This resolution proposes essential measures: to establish coherence between trade and competition policy, to encourage research and development, to combat tax evasion, to encourage vocational training and social dialogue. An ambitious industrial policy at European level would finally enable Member States to protect themselves against potential unfair competition from third countries.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union must do more to create a more competitive European industry and protect the jobs of those working in the industry. As we know, in 2015 Hungary, the top-10 industry in the European Union, including water and waste management, accounted for more than 27% of its contribution to total gross value added. The EU average was 19% and Hungary fifth place in the EU rankings with an increase of 21.5% compared to 2010. At the same time, we must also pay attention to the world market, because it is becoming increasingly clear that competition is in sharpening and that all actors (employers, workers, government) must pay attention to this and actively contribute to strengthening the European Union at the same time and in support of each other. Since the Hungarian Government also believes, in line with the OSH action plans launched earlier, that the loss of workers' skills and skills must be prevented and that Europe must maintain its industrial capacity to meet its needs without being dependent on manufacturers from third countries. An independent domestic industry cannot be imagined with competitive European industry, markets and multinationals. Since 2013, employers have benefited from more than HUF 360 billion in discounts, preserving the jobs of nearly 900,000 workers a year.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: In writing. European industry is in trouble. The cases of Alstom and Caterpillar attract the attention of the media but in reality it is thousands of jobs that, every week, disappear or are threatened with extinction in Europe. We must do everything we can to stop what is akin to industrial desertification, with the same result that the territories are devitalized, jobs are precarious and our societies become more vulnerable.  Skills must be maintained, production sites must be maintained and response must be organized. This involves a relocation of production to Europe. This requires a proactive policy of adapting skills and policies to the changes in the new forms of industry of the future. This requires a training apparatus geared towards the trades of the future. This is accompanied by a specific financing policy to grow our SMEs and a better social dialogue to accompany change. Reindustrialisation also requires the protection of the Union's interests and the establishment of trade defence instruments. It is unthinkable that the Commission will grant China market economy status as long as its industry remains state-subsidized. There is also a need to impose a carbon adjustment on borders.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I gave unconditional support to the resolution on the need for a European re-industrialisation policy. In light of the recent and brutal restructuring announcements at Caterpillar and Alstom, there is an urgent need for the Commission to review EU legislation on collective redundancies, provide support measures for workers and subcontractors, and ensure that any institutional restructuring is carried out in a socially responsible manner, in accordance with European and national regulations on information and consultation local dialogue.  In general, I note that the Union is sorely lacking in a genuine industrial policy. I therefore urge that European industry should really be seen as a strategic asset for growth and jobs. It is time for the Commission to look at the revision of EU rules governing trade defence instruments and the extension of scopes to be taken into account for the application of competition rules. We need European giants to compete internationally.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. In September, within a few days, the Caterpillar Group announced a massive global restructuring plan resulting in the layoff of 2,500 employees and jeopardizing the jobs of some 4,000 subcontractors at the Gosselies site in Belgium, and Alstom Group announced the transfer of its train production business from the Belfort site to the Reichshoffen site. These two events demonstrate the imperative need for coherence between the different EU policies in order to define a genuine industrial policy.  For many, many years, we have faced a total failure of economic, industrial and political management. More than ever, Europe must pursue a genuine economic and industrial policy. We need to rethink the rules of competition, because we need European champions. And the defence of the europeans' own interests must be at the heart of any policy of re-industrialisation.

name: Diane DODDS
text: in writing. ‒ Mr President, recent announcements by Caterpillar have affected Northern Ireland, where up to 250 redundancies are scheduled at plants across NI. Caterpillar has made an enormous contribution to the local economy over decades, and while this announcement is disappointing, we acknowledge that the firm views these actions as a means of consolidating its commitment to Northern Ireland.  However, these job losses will affect families and households very deeply and very directly – and they must receive support. My colleagues at Stormont and Westminster continue to work to assist those workers affected; however, the significance of the UK Government’s long-standing policy of not applying to the Globalisation Adjustment Fund cannot be ignored. Contrary to grandstanding by local politicians, this debate highlights that these jobs have been lost as a result of sensitive economic conditions. Global downturns in demands for raw materials and problems in the oil industry have no doubt made a contribution. While Northern Ireland cannot dictate these forces, we must promote replacement investment in our Province. Our future outside the European Union offers potential external to EU state aid rules and many damaging EU energy policies. It is vital that we harness these opportunities to grow our manufacturing base.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained from the resolution on the need for a European reindustrialisation policy in the context of the recent cases of Alstom and Caterpillar, as such resolutions are largely interventionary in the internal affairs of the Member States and businesses.  The case for closing branches and factories of these large enterprises is really worrying and many people will lose their jobs, but I am not entirely sure whether the European Parliament would have noticed such a case if it had happened in Bulgaria or another smaller Member State and without such a large international media backlash.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 We are clearly in favour of the reindustrialisation of Europe, since we believe that this is the only way that can lead to real growth and prosperity. However, we are opposed to the way in which the Union aspires to achieve it because we believe it will prove ineffective and because we disagree with many of the priorities it sets. That is why we voted against the report.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union must do more to create a more competitive European industry and protect the jobs of those working in the industry. As we know, in 2015 Hungary, the top-10 industry in the European Union, including water and waste management, accounted for more than 27% of its contribution to total gross value added. The EU average was 19% and Hungary fifth place in the EU rankings with an increase of 21.5% compared to 2010. At the same time, we must also pay attention to the world market, because it is becoming increasingly clear that competition is in sharpening and that all actors (employers, workers, government) must pay attention to this and actively contribute to strengthening the European Union at the same time and in support of each other. Since the Hungarian Government also believes, in line with the OSH action plans launched earlier, that the loss of workers' skills and skills must be prevented and that Europe must maintain its industrial capacity to meet its needs without being dependent on manufacturers from third countries. An independent domestic industry cannot be imagined with competitive European industry, markets and multinationals. Since 2013, employers have benefited from more than HUF 360 billion in discounts, preserving the jobs of nearly 900,000 workers a year.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it emphasises the need to support the green economy, including public procurement, energy efficiency and renewable energy as well as the need to stop tax evasion. Saving banks and markets did not improve the economy. Wales needs sustainable development of the economy and social policies which will prevent mass job losses.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Written. \u2012 The resolution on Caterpillar and Alstom puts a number of key aspects at their peak. They are industries whose business is challenged by fierce competition in the global market.  The scenario is not significant for the specified industries but applies to all market players. I therefore believe that the resolution takes the wrong starting point which praises supranational labour market efforts without real success factors. That is why I am voting against.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. Caterpillar announced a major global restructuring plan, which led to the dismissal of 2,500 direct workers and called into question the jobs of some 4,000 subcontractors. Alstom's board of directors has announced the transfer of its train manufacturing activity (400 jobs) from the Belfort plant to the Reichshoffen plant, which actually means the closure of the first. I express my deep solidarity and support to all Caterpillar and Alstom workers and their families and i agree with the adoption of measures to support these workers and local economies and help regions overcome this difficult economic and social situation.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I vote against the resolutions. The resolution's proposals are inconsistent: promoting free trade on the one hand and demanding reciprocity and opening up public procurement by other powers on the other. No Community preference in sight for rail, which is an industry of sovereignty. We want green growth but without massive investments possible only by monetary creation for the benefit of the real economy. Finally, social Europe is a mirage that its promoters no longer even believe in.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. We are in solidarity with the struggle of Caterpillar and Alstom workers, as well as the struggle of all workers facing unemployment and precariousness. We call for all measures to be taken so that, as soon as possible, they can recover their jobs, under conditions of job security, with decent wages, with rights and possibilities for professional and personal development. For these fundamental reasons, we reject this resolution. With an undisguised cynicism, this resolution begins by lamenting the situation of the workers of these companies. But not for a moment does it call into question the policies that underpded so-called deindustrialization, and which allow multinationals to relocate successive, always in search of better conditions for the exploitation of workers, leaving behind a track of misery and destruction. On the contrary, the resolution understems and reaffirms these policies. In essence, what is intended – and "European industrial policy" serves these objectives – is to gain scale at European level, through "restructuring" that strengthens economic groups of the main powers (even if annihilating the industry in the periphery), to better compete internationally. It is to promote monopolistic concentration on a European scale, giving muscle to the great European capital in inter-imperialist competition. For these gentlemen, the workers are cannon meat. Deplorable.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as it is essential that workers are not the pawns of the multinationals.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Caterpillar announced on 2 September 2016 that it would close its headquarters in Gosselies, Belgium, in April 2017, with the salous of more than 2 000 workers. Alstom announced on September 7, 2016 that it would shift production of trains in France from Belfort to Reichsoffen, putting 400 jobs at risk. Unfortunately, it has been a fact in Europe for a long time that branches of large corporations are being closed and redundancies are being gradually made, which also affects the network of subcontractors and small and medium-sized enterprises. A number of large industrial manufacturing companies have pursued strategies aimed at short-term financial returns and, as sustained pressure to increase capital profitability is at the expense of innovation, investment in R&D, employment, wages and skills renewal. The European Union needs an ambitious, environmentally efficient and green industrial strategy to restore production capacity and create highly skilled and well-paid jobs.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report, which contains no criticism of the Commission's failed industrial policies; few and few steps against the uncontrolled relocation of some multinationals.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am clearly in favour of the reindustrialisation of Europe since I believe that this is the only way that can lead to real growth and prosperity. However, I am opposed to the way in which the Union aspires to achieve it, because I do not believe it will be effective and also because I am opposed to many of the priorities it sets. For these reasons, I am voting against the proposals in their entirety.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union must do more to create a more competitive European industry and protect the jobs of those working in the industry. As we know, in 2015 Hungary, the top-10 industry in the European Union, including water and waste management, accounted for more than 27% of its contribution to total gross value added. The EU average was 19% and Hungary fifth place in the EU rankings with an increase of 21.5% compared to 2010. At the same time, we must also pay attention to the world market, because it is becoming increasingly clear that competition is in sharpening and that all actors (employers, workers, government) must pay attention to this and actively contribute to strengthening the European Union at the same time and in support of each other. Since the Hungarian Government also believes, in line with the OSH action plans launched earlier, that the loss of workers' skills and skills must be prevented and that Europe must maintain its industrial capacity to meet its needs without being dependent on manufacturers from third countries. An independent domestic industry cannot be imagined with competitive European industry, markets and multinationals. Since 2013, employers have benefited from more than HUF 360 billion in discounts, preserving the jobs of nearly 900,000 workers a year.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union must do more to create a more competitive European industry and protect the jobs of those working in the industry. As we know, in 2015 Hungary, the top-10 industry in the European Union, including water and waste management, accounted for more than 27% of its contribution to total gross value added. The EU average was 19% and Hungary fifth place in the EU rankings with an increase of 21.5% compared to 2010. At the same time, we must also pay attention to the world market, because it is becoming increasingly clear that competition is in sharpening and that all actors (employers, workers, government) must pay attention to this and actively contribute to strengthening the European Union at the same time and in support of each other. Since the Hungarian Government also believes, in line with the OSH action plans launched earlier, that the loss of workers' skills and skills must be prevented and that Europe must maintain its industrial capacity to meet its needs without being dependent on manufacturers from third countries. An independent domestic industry cannot be imagined with competitive European industry, markets and multinationals. Since 2013, employers have benefited from more than HUF 360 billion in discounts, preserving the jobs of nearly 900,000 workers a year.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution considering that Caterpillar and Alstom, although the reduction in production costs between 2013 and 2015 made the products of these plants more attractive than those from outside the Union, have decided to close their plants to move production to other centres with lower social and environmental protection standards than those applicable to European industry. The railway industry is the backbone of European industrialisation, giving direct employment to 400,000 people across the Union. The Commission should work towards establishing a genuine long-term European industrial strategy, with a view to achieving the target of 20% of gross domestic product coming from industry, in accordance with the European 2020 Strategy, as well as establishing a Union trade policy in line with its industrial policy objectives, en ensures a level playing field for operators inside and outside Europe , thus ensuring fair competition for all.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. \u2012 The S&D Group has made a decisive contribution to the drafting of Parliament's position on the case of the numerous redundancies announced by caterpillar and alstom multinationals. The text we have voted on is an important opportunity to reiterate our appeal to the Commission to introduce as a matter of urgency concrete measures to curb the aggressive competition affecting the European industrial sector. First of all, Europe must find a regulatory solution so that the fundamental choices that affect companies see the workers involved and informed: the relocation of a company or the cutting of thousands of jobs cannot be decisions taken in the knowledge of the workers. And everything must certainly be done to prevent the perverse effects of unfair competition that European production has experienced in recent years. Review of competition policy and state aid rules, increased public intervention to safeguard social and regional cohesion, modernisation of trade defence mechanisms and the fight against dumping are proposals that characterise our commitment as Parliamentarians throughout the coming years.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP resolution on the need for a European reindustrialisation policy in the light of the recent cases of Caterpillar and Alstom because of the importance of these large companies for European industry in the face of fierce global competition from countries exporting cheaper products to the European market through an aggressive and rapidly expanding policy on all continents. The European Union needs foreign investment and multinationals such as these, but it must be clear that, in the presence of tax benefits, financial support from the governments of the countries where they have set up their sites, in the event of restructuring or withdrawal from the territory, these multinationals must act accordingly. First of all, by committing to look for other buyers able to resume and enhance the human capital represented by the workers and to clean up the production site in such a way that it can be put back on the market at no additional cost. Otherwise restructuring would have a much wider negative impact than the mere undertaking concerned and on the economic and social fabric on the territories of the Member States concerned. I therefore hope that the Commission will consult the social partners on the effectiveness of legislation on collective redundancies.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. At present, the industrial sector in the European Union accounts for only around 15.3% of gross domestic product. This negative development must be stopped. We need to make Europe attractive again for private investors. This requires a long-term strategy from the European Union. The objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy to make Europe the most competitive region in the world and to drive smart, sustainable and inclusive growth are the right approach.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this non-legislative and non-binding motion for a resolution. While of course I sympathise with the sudden loss of jobs, the resolution was being used as an excuse for the EU to take more action and to create an EU ‘reindustrialisation policy’. The only people who should decide economic policy are our elected national governments, not unaccountable bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: In writing. The re-industrialisation of many European economies, including the French economy, is a necessity. But it is not at European level that solutions must be sought, since it is at European level that the problems have been created. There has been an industrial policy in Europe. Either this policy was national, a decision of sovereignty, like the French nuclear choice, or it was based on mutually beneficial intergovernmental cooperation to equip participating countries with new and strategic sectors, such as aeronautics or space. This was in the days before the WTO agreements, free trade and widespread dumping, before the single currency that undermines Germany's European industrial competitors, before the ban on national or local preference in public procurement, before the dismantling of public sectors, before the austerity imposed by the Stability Pact and all its avatars, before the financialisation of the economy favoured by the free movement of capital without hindrance , before the ban on subsidies to the sectors of the future... In short, it was at a time when the States had not yet entrusted their entire economic policy to the Europeanist oligarchy of Brussels. Oh yes, they had entrusted him with coal and steel. Remind me of where these two sectors are today?

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. From Podemos we strongly denounce the policy of relocations and mass layoffs carried out by some large companies to benefit from unrettled laws in occupational safety, environmental and occupational safety guarantees, especially when these companies, as is the case with Alstom and Caterpillar, are leaders in their sector and record millions of benefits every year. Our group, the GUE/NGL, drafted its own resolution in line with this position. In addition, we voted in favour of the joint resolution because, although we believe that it could have been more forceful in denouncing these practices, some important amendments on unfair competition from third countries, including China, on the excessive short-term financing of the economy, on the low impact on employment of policies to support Union banks and markets, or on the need to revise commercial and labour legislation to protect workers and subcontractors affected by these unjustified business decisions, have been incorporated into the text.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this resolution because I support the need for reindustrialisation of Europe and job growth. It is necessary for European industry to maintain its competitiveness and ability to invest in Europe. In addition, European industry also faces social and environmental challenges that it must overcome. Unfortunately, some businesses follow strategies that focus only on short-term financial gains, which tend to negatively affect innovation and employment. There is a need for reindustrialisation, but also for the development of technical skills for a competitive industry. I believe that it is essential, in order to maximise the net job-creation potential of the green economy, that the existing workforce has adequate opportunities to acquire the new skills needed for the circular economy. Good collaboration between education systems, universities and the labour market is also vital for the creation of innovative interactive networks.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to support the resolution on the need for a European reindustrialisation policy in light of the recent Caterpillar and Alstom cases, especially important as more reports indicate labour-intensive activities are being positioned outside of Europe. Deindustrialisation continues to affect certain regions acutely and that is why this report calls on the Commission to set up a long-term European industrial strategy alongside rapidly available funds.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution.  The industry in Europe is experiencing a deep crisis of competitiveness and investment. The closures of sites such as Caterpillar and Alstom are symptomatic of this industrial depression. The fundamental problem is the lack of competitiveness of our companies and the lack of willingness of some leaders to create an adequate social and fiscal environment!  We need a real long-term European industrial strategy to provide investors with stability at all levels. The European Union must also use its trade defence instruments to ensure fair international competition and enable our companies to win markets inside and outside the European Union. The response to the closure of Alstom's site in particular is not in artificial orders.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In writing. -Caterpillar and Alstom: two examples of plant closures that illustrate the urgent need for Europe to develop a forward-looking industrial strategy, and to play its role in protecting and defending its industries in the face of ever-increasing international competition.  I voted in favour of a resolution that sets out ways of trying to find solutions to these difficulties: this involves reviving public investment, redefining European competition law rules and promoting state aid, combating unfair competition, saying no to China's market economy status, fostering strategic alliances between companies and research and development partnerships , revise and adopt trade defence instruments, refuse abnormally low offers or when 50% of profit is made outside the EU, make it mandatory to clean up industrial sites and reappropriate them by public authorities, develop information, participation and consultation of workers, or prohibit multinationals from clearing their social responsibility.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union must do more to create a more competitive European industry and protect the jobs of those working in the industry. As we know, in 2015 Hungary was at the forefront of the European Union's contribution to total gross value added, with more than 27% of the water and waste industry. While the EU average was 19%, Hungary ranked fifth in the EU rankings with an increase of 21.5% compared to 2010. At the same time, we must ensure that competitiveness and social security strengthen the European Union at the same time and in support of each other. Since the Hungarian Government also believes, in accordance with the decision, with the OSH action plans launched earlier, that the loss of workers' skills and skills must be prevented and that Europe must maintain its industrial capacity so that it is not dependent on third-country manufacturers. An independent domestic industry cannot be imagined without competitive European industry, markets and multinationals. Since 2013, employers have benefited from more than HUF 360 billion in discounts, preserving the jobs of nearly 900,000 workers a year.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this joint resolution on the need for a European reindustrialisation policy in light of the recent Caterpillar and Alstom cases (2016/2891(RSP)). This resolution expresses strong solidarity and support to all workers of Caterpillar and Alstom and their families, as well as the subcontractors involved. It highlights the detrimental effects that such closures have on local economies and communities and calls for measures to be taken to support these workers and their local economies and to assist these regions in overcoming this difficult economic and social situation. Furthermore, it reminds us that the economic crisis in Europe demonstrated that industries that invest the most notably in innovation, R&D, energy efficiency, circular economy etc. are those who resisted the crisis the most. I was particularly pleased to support the call on the Commission to inform Parliament on its strategy for the main industrial sectors in Europe, namely the rail supply sector and the machinery sector, in order to create a more favourable market environment, on what it intends to do to keep quality employment, know-how and investments in Europe.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour since I have no objections.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union must do more to create a more competitive European industry and protect the jobs of those working in the industry. As is known, in 2015 Hungary was at the forefront of the european Union's contribution to total gross value added, including water and waste management, by more than 27%. The EU average was 19% and Hungary fifth place in the EU rankings with an increase of 21.5% compared to 2010. At the same time, we must also pay attention to the world market, because it is becoming increasingly clear that competition is in sharpening and that all actors (employers, workers, government) must pay attention to this and actively contribute to strengthening the European Union at the same time and in support of each other. Since the Hungarian Government also believes, in line with the OSH action plans launched earlier, that the loss of workers' skills and skills must be prevented and that Europe must maintain its industrial capacity to meet its needs without being dependent on manufacturers from third countries. An independent domestic industry cannot be imagined with competitive European industry, markets and multinationals. Since 2013, employers have benefited from more than HUF 360 billion in discounts, preserving the jobs of nearly 900,000 workers a year.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: In writing. The closures of Alstom's Belfort and Caterpillar plants in Gosselies are dramatic but indicative of the failures of states and Europe to make industrial and strategic choices adapted to global competition and to carry a visionary industrial policy. In the face of large geographic and economic complexes such as the United States and China, we must protect our industries but also encourage them to reorganize their production lines. We saved Alstom but for how long? The order for 16 TGV by SNCF should not reassure us, quite the contrary! Given that it is already burdened by a colossal debt of 44 billion euros, I have the feeling that we have undressed Peter to dress Paul. This is a lie to the employees of the Belfort plant who only got a reprieve and a lie to the French who finance the bottomless pit of the SNCF. Europe and its states must act! We must redefine our industrial priorities, anticipate the inevitable decline of certain sectors and support the attractiveness of industrial basins. We must provide continuous training for employees and support mobility. Finally, we must create industrial champions and support them in their international development.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a motion for a resolution submitted following statements by the Council and the Commission in accordance with Article 123(2) of the REGULATION. Rules of procedure on the need for a European reindustrialisation policy in light of the recent Caterpillar and Alstom cases (2016/2891(RSP)), as European industry is in crisis and the problem of closing or realising large industrial plants, in addition to leading to the redundancies of a large number of employees, it also leads to a lack of work for a large number of small and medium-sized companies that are directly or indirectly related to large industrial groups and all together cause major social problems in individual regions and cities.  Measures are needed to support the modernisation of the industry. In this regard, the EIB's policy as well as future ESI Funds and the European Fund for Strategic Investments should also be oriented and strengthened. Tax burdens that directly affect labour price and employment need to be changed, reindustrialisation should be linked to labour market policies. It is important to implement a strategy to support the digitisation of industry, and to support cluster development and cooperation at European level. The Union needs an overall strategy for a coherent and comprehensive industrial policy with a view to reindustrialisation.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. The Caterpillar and Alstom cases should not be used as an argument for the establishment of a European industrial policy, deprived of any protectionism, and, after all, very equivocal. We do not know whether to promote free trade or encourage the reciprocal opening of public procurement of other countries, nothing is planned for the defence of the railway, which is a symbol of sovereignty, and we refuse to give ourselves the means to achieve the green economy. It's hard to believe in a social Europe. I voted against it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding motion for a resolution. While of course UKIP sympathises with the sudden loss of jobs, the resolution was being used as an excuse for EU to take more action and create an EU ‘reindustrialisation policy’. The only people who should decide economic policy are our elected national governments, not unaccountable bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Dennis de JONG
text: Written. \u2012 The SP abstained on this resolution. Although there are good points in the text, there is a lot of reference to the Europe 2020 strategy. We believe that it is precisely the Europe 2020 strategy, which is part of the European Semester, that creates economic and financial problems in the Member States that make investing in re-industrialisation impossible. The European Semester and the Europe 2020 strategy are therefore not parts of the solution to this problem, but rather an amplifier of the current problems, because countries do not have the freedom to intervene in sectors that are struggling.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the European re-industrialisation policy in order to support employees and subcontractors at the Belfort sites for Alstom and Gosselies for Caterpillar. Artificial rescues in France are only temporary solutions to structural problems such as competitiveness and access to public procurement. However, this resolution marks the starting point for further negotiations, which I hope will very quickly lead to a genuine European industrial policy. The continent is bearing the brunt of a relentless globalization and I reiterate my opposition to china's market economy status until it complies with the rules of competition law.  I am pleased that this text has been adopted by a large majority.

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: in writing. ‒ In trying to find agreement for a JMR, strong references to workers’ rights were watered down. Moreover, the right wing not only managed to remove the workers as central, but they shaped the motion in a way which put employers and shareholders as central. We always have had, and always will have, workers, their families, and their communities at heart when we vote on motions in relation to Employment and Social Affairs.  In our opinion, there are issues around aspects such as:  Point 12 calls for ‘the restructuring of the major European manufacturers to be enabled in order to allow the emergence of players with sufficient critical mass to cope with international competition’. This would without doubt create an industrial policy which squeezes out cooperatives, micro businesses, and SMEs;  Point 24 looks for the market to dictate how education systems should operate: ‘underlines the importance of fostering better synergies between education systems, universities and the labour market, including exposure to the workplace and cooperation with businesses in the creation of innovative ‘clusters’’. There are many other issues with the JMR, and with some of the amendments; hence, EH Bildu has abstain on supporting the JMR. This decision has as much to do with what it left out as what was put in.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution setting out the European Parliament's proposals for a real European re-industrialisation policy. In the light of the recent Caterpillar and Alstom cases, it is clear that it is not enough to do simple "do-it-yourself" to save these jobs. The European Union must be more proactive if it is to maintain a strong and innovative industry. There is therefore an urgent need for a real long-term industrial strategy.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of this motion for a resolution. European industry is struggling with many problems in securing the location of its production sites on the continent and should therefore be supported as best it can. This support must take the form of an improved framework, taking into account the principle of subsidiarity and national workers' rights and social traditions.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: Writing. \u2012 Competitiveness is one of the foundations of prosperity. If we are able to produce goods or provide services better and cheaper than our neighbors, we are rewarded and become more wealthy. The same is the same with foreign investment. They end up where there is good physical infrastructure, a trained workforce, the rule of law and other aspects. In Europe, for some time now, we have been losing the competition battle with other regions of the world, resulting in investment leaving, companies being closed down, workers being made redundant and production being carried over outside Europe. In order for investment to return, Europe's competitiveness needs to be improved. This can be done in many ways, but above all it is necessary to invest in education and to improve labour legislation. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution at the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg.

name: Jan KELLER
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this EP resolution, which aims to kick-start the policy of reindustrialisation of Europe. This priority is all the more significant given that some large industrial enterprises with a long tradition have recently been closed down and unemployment has increased. I supported this resolution on those points that did not pass, in particular, because of the opposition from liberal and part of the People's Deputies. These were mostly points that are of key importance in the next policy of reindustrialisation and without which the reindustrialisation project remains a mere phrase, such as favouring short-term profit at the expense of a longer-term concept or a proposal for employee participation in the development of a restructuring plan.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution. The European Parliament has sent a strong political signal to the Commission that Europe must act to protect its industries and its jobs. The European Parliament voted in favour of sanctions for companies that make redundancies based on stock markets. It is vital that we develop a real industrial policy for Europe, with an investment strategy, a new competition policy and a trade policy to tackle social dumping.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 On Wednesday 5. 10. 2016, we voted in plenary on a resolution on the need for a European policy of reindustrialisation in the context of the recent Caterpillar and Alstom cases. The situation surrounding the massive redundancies in the European part of Caterpillar best illustrates the disgusting behaviour of corporations in today's EU. International corporations in our territory abuse the labor force, make profits abroad, and leave at the first sign of any problems. These moloches will always use us and throw us away like an old toy. This is not unusual behavior for Caterpillar, which has even been investigated by the US Congress for profit and non-taxation. Our faction had the opportunity to meet with Caterpillar staff during the meeting. Therefore, we had a fairly solid idea of what the employees of this company wish to mention. While it must say that the joint resolution has been surprisingly well written, particularly on the need for reindustrialisation and a shift away from the blind closure of heavy industry, which means the loss of thousands of jobs to combat climate change, all the amendments caterpillar workers wished to mention have not passed. That is why I abstained. Employee rights and their protection will always be the primary issues for me, so I mean to continue to fight TTIP, CETA, etc., which caterpillar's behavior only continues to encourage.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union must do more to create a more competitive European industry and protect the jobs of those working in the industry. As we know, in 2015 Hungary, the top-10 industry in the European Union, including water and waste management, accounted for more than 27% of its contribution to total gross value added. The EU average was 19% and Hungary fifth place in the EU rankings with an increase of 21.5% compared to 2010. At the same time, we must also pay attention to the world market, because it is becoming increasingly clear that competition is in sharpening and that all actors (employers, workers, government) must pay attention to this and actively contribute to strengthening the European Union at the same time and in support of each other. Since the Hungarian Government also believes, in line with the OSH action plans launched earlier, that the loss of workers' skills and skills must be prevented and that Europe must maintain its industrial capacity to meet its needs without being dependent on manufacturers from third countries. An independent domestic industry cannot be imagined with competitive European industry, markets and multinationals. Since 2013, employers have benefited from more than HUF 360 billion in discounts, preserving the jobs of nearly 900,000 workers a year.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. "Facts are stubborn things and often lead to uncomfortable conclusions. As long as the Union is governed by neoliberal principles, as clearly shown by the Maastricht criteria and the Treaty of Lisbon, there is no chance of a genuine industrial policy. This would need strong defending of eu industry, including a catch-up programme for weaker developed countries. Furthermore, multinational companies should mostly be replaced by national and public companies. All of this is completely missing from the material, so it is unsustainable. Only the tip of the iceberg is the two major layoffs just announced, which are aftershocks of the decades-old, visiblely flawed economic regulation. China and the Far East should be grateful for european bureaucracy.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
