text: in writing. \u2012 I support the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the need for a European reindustrialisation policy in the light of the recent cases of Alstom and Caterpillar. I believe that this document represents a strong political message of solidarity and support from the European Union towards workers in these enterprises. This resolution would contribute to the effective implementation of the Europe 2020 programme, which provides for each EU country to reach a share of 20% of GDP coming from industry.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. ‒ In light of the recent Caterpillar and Alstom cases, the first point that needs to be taken into account is that the EU should immediately mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGAF) in order to support workers who lost their jobs and give them new opportunities to reintegrate into the labour market. Furthermore, the EU and its Member States should find a common vision for European industry because the sector is shrinking and cannot maintain its global competitiveness. Today European industrial production accounts 24% of world production while during the 1990s it accounted for 36%. Unfortunately, declining industry (deindustrialisation) of Europe has resulted in job losses for employees, failure of SMEs and economic decline. Therefore, the EU should develop consistent and comprehensive industrial policy, which aims to reindustrialise Europe. Importantly, reindustrialisation of Europe should be based on digitalisation (in particular the integration of smart technologies and robotics into industrial value chains), sustainability, energy efficiency and adequate resources. Member States should join efforts and facilitate the emergence of joint industrial projects. In general, reindustrialisation of the EU will create jobs, economic growth and regional integration.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. After the severe crisis, it was necessary to start again with investments and actions in support of the EU's economic recovery and sustainable growth. Globalisation pushes us to focus on innovation and increasing the competitiveness of our industrial system. The proposal adopted today calls on the Commission and the Member States to subsidise public investment in research and development and technology, subject to compliance with environmental and health standards, in order to promote skills and know-how, which is a fundamental prerequisite for increasing the competitiveness and sustainability of strategic sectors. Therefore, action must be taken to find suitable solutions to protect jobs currently at risk by all available means, to ensure transparency in financial transfers, and to protect the competitiveness of our companies in the global scenario.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because it wants to give new powers to the European Commission, by adopting an overly integrated approach to industrial policy. However, I believe that Europe's industrial policy should be based on cooperation between states.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution which affirms the need for a European policy of re-industrialisation, particularly in view of the closure of the Caterpillar site in Belgium (2500 redundancies) and the threats to Alstom's in Belfort (400 jobs). Sustainable solutions must be found to support employees and subcontractors affected by these restructurings. A European policy of re-industrialisation includes the requirement of reciprocity for international public procurement.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: In writing. The joint resolution presented to us on the closure of Alstom's industrial sites in Belfort and Caterpillar in Charleroi considered the closure of these sites to be a fait accompli. I then tabled an amendment to amend this point and replace it with: "strongly condemns these unacceptable closures, restructuring plans and strategic economic decisions made by multinationals, leaving thousands of workers unemployed;" Unfortunately, this amendment did not pass by one vote as it fell by 315 votes to 314 and 44 abstentions. However, in accepting the closure of these industrial sites a red line was crossed, which is why I refused to support this text which was subject to the logics of money at the expense of our industrial tool.  A statement must be made. These closures are purely driven by financial logics and do not take into account the multiple challenges that arise with the ecological transition. That is why we must invest massively in our production capacity, to boost the economy and create quality jobs on European soil.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution on the need for a European policy of re-industrialisation in the light of the recent Caterpillar and Alstom cases. The majority groups want to take advantage of the media coverage of these cases to revive the idea of European industrial policy, "without protectionism".  The resolution's proposals are inconsistent: promoting free trade on the one hand and demanding reciprocity and opening up public procurement by other powers on the other. No Community preference in sight for rail, which is an industry of sovereignty. We want green growth but without massive investments possible only by monetary creation for the benefit of the real economy. Finally, social Europe is a mirage that its promoters no longer even believe in.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. The majority groups want to take advantage of the media coverage of these cases to revive the idea of a European industrial policy, "without protectionism". The joint resolution has several pillars: green economy, renovation of trade defence instruments, revival of public and private investment and increased employee participation in restructuring plans.  The proposals in the resolution are, in my view, inconsistent: the promotion of free trade on the one hand and the requirement of reciprocity and opening up public procurement by other powers on the other, no Community preference in sight for rail, which is an industry of sovereignty. We want green growth but without massive investments; only by creating money for the benefit of the real economy. Finally, social Europe appears to be a mirage that its most fervent supporters no longer even believe in.  Thus, I voted against these resolutions, except that of the ECR group for which I abstained.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the resolution because it addresses the aspects of industrial and international trade policy, and focuses on the main aspects relating to workers and occupation; the resolution focuses on the need to strengthen the legislative package that empowers workers in decision-making related to corporate restructuring. In caterpillar and Alstom cases, restructuring includes layoffs and transfers due to plant closures such as Caterpillar's in Monkstown( Northern Ireland) or Alstom's in Cornell, Barcelona. That is why the Commission is requested, after consultation with social actors, to draw up a proposal for a legislative act on information and consultation of workers for the anticipation of change and restructuring, after assistance to social actors, to submit a review on the approximation of member States' legal frameworks on collective redundancies.  The reform of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is also called for a better improvement in coverage of workers directly and indirectly affected by such processes.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I abstained in this resolution because, while containing positive elements (improving the use of European funds and public procurement in support of European industry, the role of the social partners, recognition of the importance of industrial policy, the need to reform competition policies to promote employment...) contains hardly any critical references to how European policies , from deregulation and privatization to their aggressive foreign trade policy, are responsible for Europe's industrial crisis.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. In this joint motion for a resolution supported by the EPP, Greens, ECR, S&D and ALDE, the European Parliament sends a clear message to the European Commission on the need for a European re-industrialization policy in view of the recent cases of Caterpillar and Alstom, two large companies affected by changes in the world economy and which have announced restructuring plans. Parliament is in solidarity with those affected and indicates the paths it considers important to take so that we have a strong and resilient industry. Only a forward-looking industrial policy will enable the Union to meet the various challenges it faces, including its re-industrialisation, its transition to sustainability and the creation of quality jobs. I welcome this resolution, convinced that many of the ideas provided by the European Parliament will help the European Commission to create ambitious new re-industrialization policies.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion for resolution which aims to address the significant economic challenges Member States face in an ever changing global market place.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. The European Parliament has no comment on corporate restructuring (Caterpillar or Alstom). The resolution calls for a "European industrial policy" to protect EU workers. He wants protectionism at the expense of consumers and taxpayers. Nor do I agree with the call for subsidise information and energy networks. The report is a call for a centrally managed protectionist policy, and I certainly do not support this.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Caterpillar announced a major restructuring plan, which will result in the closure of the Gosselies plant and the redundancies of 2,500 workers. Also, Alstrom's board of directors announced the transfer of train production and the closure of the Belfort plant, and other redundancies are expected at the companies' plants in Spain, Italy and Northern Ireland. These developments confirm the trend of increasing business relocation outside Europe, which contributes to the reduction of employment in the manufacturing and industrial sectors of many European countries and has a negative impact on the overall economic and social structure. European industry has high added value and a recognised level of expertise, but is currently facing strong global competition from third countries, which export cheaper products to the European market and implement an aggressive policy. Europe is a social market economy with a view to achieving sustainable economic and inclusive growth, so it is necessary to create a comprehensive industrial policy that protects EU workers, in order to avoid new production shifts. To this end, support for projects in the regions most affected by deindustrialisation needs to be accelerated, all funds, in particular the ESF and EGF, should be mobilised. The Union industrial strategy must be based on digitalisation, sustainability, energy efficiency and promote the importance of skilled workers and the link between research and industry to strengthen the EU's industrial competitiveness, so I supported this resolution.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. ‒ I share the view that European industry has played an essential role in the history of European integration. At present, this central and strategic EU industry faces strong competition from third countries, which export lower-cost products to the European market by carrying out an aggressive and rapidly expanding policy on all continents. Trade in construction machinery in the EU has suffered strong disruptions in recent years, linked to the reduction of public and private investment. I am convinced that European industry should be seen as a strategic asset for the competitiveness of the EU. A strong industry will allow the EU to face the different challenges ahead. I support calls on the Commission to ensure that EU trade policy is more consistent with industrial policy, so that trade policy takes account of the need to secure European industrial jobs and does not lead to further deindustrialisation.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 The Caterpillar and Alstom cases are examples of moving business and capital to a more cost-benefiting environment for entrepreneurs. Such activities undermine the EU economy, increase unemployment and damage the Union's competitiveness. The Commission must therefore develop an EU trade policy that ensures equal and fair competition for all market operators, in order to maintain and increase employment and to support and maintain the industries on which the EU and its Member States' economies stand.

name: Louis-Joseph MANSCOUR
text: In writing. Following the recent announcements of the closure of the Caterpillar plant in Gosselies (Belgium) and Alstom's Belfort site, the European Parliament had to react officially. This is what this comprehensive and balanced resolution proposes, which calls in particular for the relaunch of public investment to re-industrialise the Union, while stressing the negative impact of austerity policies in this regard.  Highlighting how much the Union would suffer in terms of the loss of know-how and technology, the text calls on the EU and the Member States to fight unfair competition more effectively by revising European trade defence instruments. The resolution also warns that, as it stands, China cannot be recognized as a market economy. This text also proposes ambitious environmental and social measures, notably in the area of clean-up and sales for companies, or the creation of a Florange law at European level. So I'm voting in favor.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 Referring to my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 14/9/2016, I am voting against the joint motion for a resolution because it is neither complete nor substantiated.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: in writing. – In the context of the recent Caterpillar cases, Europe urgently needs a new European reindustrialisation policy. The EU needs to develop border adjustment mechanisms to avoid environmentally friendly dumping and dumping of cheaper but poorly quality products. These products only destroy European standards and affect the competitiveness of European industries. If the EU imposes a number of environmental and social rules, then the same European Union must defend its industry and anticipate the socio-economic situations that lead to the dissolution of industrial capacities and the loss of many jobs. Europe urgently needs to propose a strategy that will face global competition from countries exporting low-cost products to the European market, countries that have a policy of rapid expansion across all continents and that receive political and financial support from their governments. I call on the Commission to urgently start the consultation process with the social partners on the effectiveness of legislation on the legality of collective redundancies. I call on the Commission to propose a revision of the Directive on European Works Councils and to come up with a proposal for a legislative act on information and consultation of workers, anticipation and management of restructurings.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this text. In September 2016, two major industrial groups announced the closure of their factories in Europe, notably in France and Belgium, resulting in the dismissal of thousands of employees and putting at least as many indirect jobs at risk. Centrist and left-wing MEPs, including the French, want to take advantage of the misfortune of French and Belgian employees, as well as the media coverage of these cases, to revive the idea of a European industrial policy "without protectionism".  These Members were so concerned about the willingness to speak with one voice, so-called 'European', that they presented us with an incoherent and unacceptable motion for a resolution. Indeed, it does not take into account the economic sovereignty of the Member States and will not solve the problems of the industrial sector in Europe, which above all needs massive investments, possible only by creating money for the benefit of the real economy.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: In writing. The suddenly unseeded decisions by ALSTOM and Caterpillar's management to close sites and cut jobs in France and Belgium are emblematic of the crisis facing European industry.  In addition to the specifics of each country, European industry is under pressure from triple dumping: social, fiscal and environmental. Many actors take advantage of Europe's ideological attitude, which imposes itself a liberalism that no other great power respects. At issue: our public procurement opened without limitation to international competition; a blind trade policy in which the Commission would be prepared to grant China 'market economy' status, abolishing even more protections for their exports and, ultimately, their social dumping.  Finally, as we vote this week to ratify the Paris Agreement, it must also be remembered that if European industry is at a disadvantage vis-à-vis its Asian competitors, it is also because it strives to comply with environmental legislation absolutely crucial for the energy transition. There is an urgent need to put in place the 'carbon adjustment at borders' scheme.  I voted for this resolution, which recalls these ambitions.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution on the need for a European industrialisation policy in the light of the recent Caterpillar and Alstom cases because European industry has played an important role in the history of European integration and is a pillar for new values in Europe. It should also be borne in mind that the European railway industry is the cornerstone and backbone of European industrialisation and at the same time employs 400,000 people across the EU. On the other hand, it is only through an ambitious innovation policy that promotes the production of innovative products that the EU will be allowed to be self-sufficient in a competitive global environment. Given that the expertise of workers' representatives has not been taken into account in the case of Alstom and Caterpillar and that the closure of factories often entails irreversible losses in the technologies, industrial know-how and skills of industrial workers, I believe that the Commission should submit a proposal to revise the laws of the Member States relating to collective redundancies.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. With much of the intra-European added value owed to industry, economic policy must create the appropriate framework conditions, taking into account subsidiarity, national labour laws and social traditions, in order to avoid mass redundancies, as in the case of Caterpillar and Alstom, in the future. I agree with the substance of the content.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution calling on the Council to take a decision as soon as possible on modernising trade defence mechanisms in order to finally respond appropriately to unfair practices in third countries and to protect European industry from dumping on the European market and to ensure fair competition.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The majority groups want to take advantage of the media coverage of these cases to revive the idea of a European industrial policy, "without protectionism". The joint resolution has several pillars: green economy, renovation of trade defence instruments, revival of public and private investment and increased employee participation in restructuring plans.  The proposals in the resolution are, in my view, inconsistent: the promotion of free trade on the one hand and the requirement of reciprocity and opening up public procurement by other powers on the other, no Community preference in sight for rail, which is an industry of sovereignty. We want green growth but without massive investments; only by creating money for the benefit of the real economy. Finally, social Europe appears to be a mirage that its most fervent supporters no longer even believe in.  Thus, I voted against these resolutions, except that of the ECR group for which I abstained.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. The Caterpillar and Alstom cases show that European industry should be seen as a strategic asset for the competitiveness and sustainability of the EU. Only a strong and resilient industry and a future-oriented industrial policy will enable the EU to address the different challenges ahead, such as reindustrialisation, the transition to sustainability and the creation of quality jobs. The Commission and the Member States must better anticipate these socio-economic situations and ensure the competitiveness of our industrial network. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this cross-party resolution as it expresses the need for an industrial policy that also protects those employed in these sectors. It also stresses that European industry should continue to be seen as a strategic asset and policies formed to make it resilient to future challenges.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. I would like to express my sympathy and solidarity with the workers and subcontractors, victims of a brutal process that has taken everyone by surprise. Like them, we were shocked by the announcement of the closure of the Gosselies site by a company that has already undergone a major restructuring in 2013. In the face of such phenomena, concrete short-term and long-term solutions must be considered without delay. The economic crisis has shown that the strongest industries are those that invest the most in innovation, research and development, energy efficiency, the circular economy, etc. However, the European Union is undeniably short of public and private investment.  We therefore call for the Commission to develop a strategy for an ambitious, forward-looking re-industrialisation policy, promoting the emergence of European champions capable of tackling a globalised market and integrating into global competition. We must give ourselves the means to be the engine of change and innovation. We must also make a point of strengthening defence mechanisms against dumping from third countries, including China. There are rules and they have to be followed.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – At the beginning of September, two companies, Caterpillar and Alstom, announced the closure of their production facilities in Belgium and France and their transfer to other cities within and outside Europe. The closure of Caterpillar is estimated to lead to redundancies of more than 2 000 employees and put at risk an additional 4 000-7 000 jobs in the subcontracting sector and related SMEs, while in alstam more than 400 sites will be transferred to other plants. Both cases are just an example of the much larger problem facing European industry. While European industrial production accounted for 36% of world production in the 1990s, it is now only 24% and continues to decline. Eu policy aimed at promoting reindustralisation must respond sufficiently to this situation. It is essential to complete a competitive single market that can attract and maintain private investment, to develop a long-term European industrial strategy that will help meet the objectives set, to improve access to finance for businesses in the EU, especially micro-enterprises and SMEs. Europe must also exploit the enormous potential of ICT to digitise industry in order to remain globally competitive. In the case of Caterpillar and Alstom, the Commission should release the funds available, in particular the European Social Fund and the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, in order to reintecling redundant workers as quickly as possible.

name: Anne-Marie MINEUR
text: Written. \u2012 The SP abstained on this resolution. Although there are good points in the text, there is a lot of reference to the Europe 2020 strategy. We believe that it is precisely the Europe 2020 strategy, which is part of the European Semester, that creates economic and financial problems in the Member States that make investing in re-industrialisation impossible. The European Semester and the Europe 2020 strategy are therefore not parts of the solution to this problem, but rather an amplifier of the current problems, because countries do not have the freedom to intervene in sectors that are struggling.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the resolution, which calls for a strategy to reindustrialise Europe following the brutal announcements on the closure of the Caterpillar plant in Belgium and the Alstom site in France. It is essential to develop a real industrial policy for Europe, with an investment strategy, a new competition policy and a trade policy to tackle social dumping. However, I have voted against the paragraphs calling on conversion of taxation because in my view, it is also important to recall that the EU is not a homogenous area and this needs to be borne in mind. Not all regions in the EU face the same economic realities, be it for their domestic market size, geographical proximity or resources. Ultimately, regions which find themselves at a disadvantage are equally interested in safeguarding their tax revenues and keeping people-based economic activity in their territory. But to do so, they need latitude in tax policy, especially considering that the EU has a very sophisticated state aid policy which already materially limits what can be done in terms of measures.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 A motion for a resolution was tabled by the PPE, Verts/ALE, GUE/NGL, ECR, S&D, EFDD and ALDE groups on the question indicated. With the exception of the GUE/NGL and the EFDD, the political groups reached an agreement and drafted a compromise motion. I voted in favour of the compromise proposal.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. European industry should be oriented in such a way that it can be regarded as a strategic asset for the competitiveness and sustainability of the EU.  New challenges in the EU, such as reindustrialisation, the transition to sustainability and the creation of quality jobs, can only be successfully addressed with a strong and resilient industry and a future-oriented industrial policy.  I advocate the creation of a genuine Industrial Policy of the Union, which also protects EU workers (adequate social protection, working conditions and wages that allow us to live with dignity, among others), which can aim for a sustainable economy and inclusive growth. I endorse the rapporteur's position on the investment orientation towards creativity, skills, innovation and sustainable technologies and to promote the modernisation of Europe's industrial base through a policy attentive to the value chain, including the basic industries and their regional and local actors. Reindustrialisation will bring enormous benefits to European industry and the economy as a whole.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The resolution's proposals are inconsistent: promoting free trade on the one hand and requiring reciprocity and opening up public procurement by other powers. No Community preference in sight for rail, which is an industry of sovereignty. We want green growth but without massive investments possible only by monetary creation for the benefit of the real economy. Finally, social Europe is a mirage that its promoters no longer even believe in. I therefore vote against this text.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on the re-industrialisation of Europe in the light of the recent Caterpillar and Alstom cases. At European level, the challenge is above all the requirement for reciprocity of open public procurement that our companies need. In addition to its social and environmental constraints, Europe opens its public procurement to the four winds, to subsidised foreign companies. Other countries close their markets or impose production conditions on the spot.  We therefore call for reciprocity in market access, the establishment of a border adjustment mechanism and anti-dumping measures of the same type that we obtained against China with regard to steel.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the motion for a resolution. Re-industrialisation of Europe is important both economically and socially. We have witnessed the decline of the industry, even large and stable companies such as Alstom and Caterpillar, which are then forced to close some of their divisions in the absence of orders. Needless to say, such an event can completely slow down the development of the region concerned.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this motion for a resolution that calls for a reindustrialisation policy in the EU following the redundancy plans of Caterpillar and Alstom.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: in writing. – The dismissal of over two thousand workers from a Caterpillar plant in Belgium and the likelihood of more jobs being closed at the Alstrom plant in France are indicative of the need for a European reindustrialisation policy. The EU needs more than ever an industrial policy that is not led by short-term financial results that are detrimental to attracting investment in innovation and ensuring long-term employment for European citizens.   That is why I supported this resolution, which calls on the EC and the Member States to develop a strategy for a comprehensive industrial policy in key sectors such as rail equipment. I share the view that rail transport is a strong and innovative sector that not only creates many jobs, but also, being environmentally friendly, is fully comparable to the EU's climate and energy objectives. Especially in Bulgaria, the railway transport, which the current government continues to neglect at the expense of the construction of highways, this proposal can create an opportunity for the financing of projects and the increase in employment in our country, which in recent decades has also been badly affected by deindustrialization.

name: Dan NICA
text: in writing. \u2012 The 2015 Paris Agreement is the first multilateral agreement on climate change covering almost all global emissions. The agreement is a worldwide success and a confirmation of the EU's orientation towards a low-carbon economy. The Energy Union project provides a broader framework in which the EU can provide an appropriate favourable environment for the energy transition. According to the International Energy Agency, full implementation of climate plans will lead to $13.5 trillion in investments in energy efficiency and low-carbon technologies between 2015 and 2030, with an annual average of $840 billion. In addition, the future Energy Union Research, Innovation and Competitiveness Strategy will take advantage of synergies between the energy sector, the transport sector, the circular economy, as well as industrial and digital innovation. This should increase the competitiveness of current and future low-carbon and energy-efficient European technologies.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution which offers momentary solutions to two situations with complex economic and social implications, but which at the same time sends a signal of solidarity with the regions of Europe facing relocations of large enterprises. We are all aware that the production of European industry is declining and that we need a European policy of reindustrialisation in order to stop reaching this kind of situation. In this respect, the document adopted today reiterates the need for a European reindustrialisation policy that promotes cooperation between the old and new companies established, which can create a much-needed oxygen bubble for the business environment. In this regard, the European Parliament calls on the European Commission in collaboration with the Member States to promote innovation and digitisation of European industry, taking into account the supply of the labour market and thus create the conditions for the creation of new jobs.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained on the resolution on the need for a European policy of reindustrialisation in the context of the recent Caterpillar and Alstom cases, because from a systemic point of view I do not consider it right and meaningful for the EP to deal with individual cases of companies and management decisions on restructuring. I am against the politicisation of these individual cases, which necessarily leads to the fact that, according to the commission, the resolution is intended to deal with reindustrialisation, but in reality it is rather trade unionist in nature and as such has become a hostage to the left, which in itself makes it impossible to seriously and comprehensively grasp the issue of restructuring large enterprises facing the pressures of economic globalisation. I think that the agenda of reindustralisation, improving the labour market in the Union and negotiating fair conditions for foreign trade (including relations with China) are a very important agenda for the Union, but it should not be confused with specific social problems (although, of course, I feel sorry for people who lose their jobs in this and similar cases, and I believe that the social systems of countries, as well as some EU means, are supposed to help them effectively). A functioning economy or a well-set, sustainable social and budgetary system are the main things that national governments and parliaments should support, thus ensuring a good quality of life for their citizens.

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: in writing. \u2012 The report concerns the closure of Caterpillar's factory in Belgium, which will result in the collective redundancy of over 2,000 employees and threaten up to 7,000 additional jobs, and the closure of Caterpillar's Monkstown plant in Newtownabbey, Northern Ireland, which would result in the loss of 250 jobs. The report calls on the Commission for the rapid mobilisation of the European Social Fund and the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in order to reintegrate workers made redundant by Caterpillar. It also calls on the Commission and the Member States to ensure better access to finance for EU businesses, especially micro-enterprises and SMEs. We need a long-term vision for European industry.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I supported this report as it advocates a better framework in the field of industry. The framework conditions will be created taking into account subsidiarity and national labour laws and social traditions.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. – I support the resolution tabled. It should be noted that the closure of these companies has a particularly serious impact on the local economy and communities. I believe that further efforts are needed to prevent the possible closure of multinationals, restructuring plans and strategic economic decisions, which lead to the loss of thousands of workers in the future. In order to respond to the social emergency caused by globalisation, relocation of production and deindustrialisation, the Commission should establish a European minimum income system.  In this context, it is essential to give greater support to European industrial policy and to develop an effective long-term European industrial strategy as soon as possible. A coordinated policy must be pursued at EU level to stimulate demand, provide fiscal measures and ensure wage growth.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding motion for a resolution. While of course UKIP sympathises with the sudden loss of jobs, the resolution was being used as an excuse for EU to take more action and to create an EU ‘reindustrialisation policy’. The only people who should decide economic policy are our elected national governments, not unaccountable bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I felt obliged to vote in favour of this proposal. In view of the current situation, it is necessary to reach a rapid agreement on the revision of the rules on trade defence instruments, with the aim of considerably strengthening them. The European market is facing fierce global competition, with the Union being forced to improve and make its instruments more responsive, taking into account the need to guarantee industrial employment and to prevent the occurrence of phenomena such as relocation and deindustrialisation. Given that there is a need for coherence between the different EU policies in order to create a genuine industrial policy, I feel I must express myself positively. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: in writing. ‒ Europe has a social market economy which means that large companies have a moral and social responsibility to their employees. On the other hand our duty is to encourage a more friendly context for businesses in Member State and support this from EU level, so businesses will be able to provide the added value, the jobs and the necessary growth which are essential to Europe’s welfare system. Therefore, the EU needs to support jobs with a reindustrialisation strategy to increase industrial activity to 20% of the EU’s GDP by 2020.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I believe that Caterpillar and Alstom's recent announcements of projected closures of major industrial installations in Europe are a major blow to their workers and that this decision is hitting the regions in which they operate hard. Unfortunately, one of these companies is Alstom Croatia from Karlovac, Croatia. It has been announced that 229 workers will lose their jobs, of which as many as 130 are engineers. The potential of employees should not be left to the free market, as the highest quality will be rehired, but not in Croatia or the EU. Due to such circumstances, it is necessary to maintain a targeted policy in order for such skilled workers to find an appropriate alternative to employment within the EU. Without proper initiative in this direction, the EU will lose some important parts of its industry, and what is particularly valuable – its know-how, and thus its place in the global market for specialized products with high added value. At the moment, the first priority should be to support those directly affected, but one should also think in the long term taking the necessary care of the needs and future of European industry. In this way, I think we can send a strong signal about the need to preserve and improve the competitiveness of our industrial economy over the long term with an investment plan for Europe.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. The American construction equipment manufacturer Caterpillar announced on 2nd September 2016 its intention to close its only Belgian plant, in Gosselies, resulting in the loss of 2,200 (6,000 if you include subcontractors) positions in the already disaster-stricken region of Charleroi. Alstom announced on 12 September following the closure of its Belfort site, which specialises in the construction of railway equipment. The company motivated its decision by the reduction of orders from SNCF, which preferred Bombardier as a supplier for TERs. On 4 October, the French government announced a solution to maintain employment in Belfort with the order of new TGV trainsets to run on the Intercité network. The majority groups want to take advantage of the media coverage of these cases to revive the idea of a European industrial policy, "without protectionism". Their proposals are inconsistent and are based on the absurd idea that transferring industrial policy to the Commission in the context of ever-increasing integration would be a good thing. I believe that only sovereign and democratic states are able to define an effective industrial policy that respects the interests of their people and the environment. I therefore vote against this text.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. We are in solidarity with the struggle of Caterpillar and Alstom workers, as well as the struggle of all workers facing unemployment and precariousness. We call for all measures to be taken so that, as soon as possible, they can recover their jobs, under conditions of job security, with decent wages, with rights and possibilities for professional and personal development. For these fundamental reasons, we reject this resolution. With an undisguised cynicism, this resolution begins by lamenting the situation of the workers of these companies. But not for a moment does it call into question the policies that underpded so-called deindustrialization, and which allow multinationals to relocate successive, always in search of better conditions for the exploitation of workers, leaving behind a track of misery and destruction. On the contrary, the resolution understems and reaffirms these policies. In essence, what is intended – and "European industrial policy" serves these objectives – is to gain scale at European level, through "restructuring" that strengthens economic groups of the main powers (even if annihilating the industry in the periphery), to better compete internationally. It is to promote monopolistic concentration on a European scale, giving muscle to the great European capital in inter-imperialist competition. For these gentlemen, the workers are cannon meat. Deplorable.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 In September this year, Caterpillar announced a broad restructuring plan, which included the closure of a factory in Belgium, where more than 2,500 workers in the factory itself will be laid off and more than 4,000 workers in subcontracting firms will be put at risk. All this has happened, even though the eu production price fell in 2013-2015, making production outside the EU more attractive. In my opinion, the European Union must respond in a situation where workers' rights are fundamentally threatened and when large multinational supranational companies refuse to cooperate in the long term in finding solutions that minimise regional social impacts. But in the end, everyone loses. However, I would like to remind you at this point that the European Parliament should pay equally close attention to similar cases that are happening in other EU countries.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. In view of the difficulties faced by European companies, such as recently Caterpillar or Alstom, establishing a European policy of re-industrialisation is a priority. It is in this spirit that I voted for this text.  As we see all too often, large companies in difficulty are subjected, when they are "saved", to often artificial recovery plans. Alstom's case in France demonstrates this. Therefore, the thinking must be more global: how can we meet the structural challenges that are holding back the economic development of our continent today? Global competition is tough, and no growth will be possible without trade defence and the promotion of harmonized rules in globalization. Today, Europe remains open to foreign actors. This openness will only continue to be beneficial if, in return, we ensure that we obtain the same opportunities for development beyond our borders.  But I say this clearly: as long as some national governments, like the socialist executive in France, do not realize the need to reduce administrative burdens, social and employer burdens for our companies, and to put in place a clear foreign trade strategy, no industrial policy worthy of the name will perform in France and Europe.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. European industry has high added value and recognised high quality standards. On the other hand, industry plays a key strategic role in the economic policy pursued by the Union. However, strong competition between the Union and states exporting low-cost products to the European market has threatened the industrial sector. For this reason, recently, two factories of Alstom and Caterpillar, respectively, have removed around 3000 jobs in Europe. The European social market economy must aim for sustainability and inclusive growth objectives due to the importance of the secondary sector. To this end, the creation of a long-term European industrial strategy in order to achieve the 20% of GDP target from the secondary sector - the objective enshrined in the Europe 2020 strategy - is very fundamental. The Commission should develop, with the Member States, a strategy for a coherent and comprehensive industrial policy that favours high-quality, innovative and energy-efficient production, which implements sustainable production processes, thereby enabling the Union to survive in an increasingly competitive global context. For the foregoing, my vote is in favour.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding motion for a resolution. While of course UKIP sympathises with the sudden loss of jobs, the resolution was being used as an excuse for EU to take more action and to create an EU ‘reindustrialisation policy’. The only people who should decide economic policy are our elected national governments, not unaccountable bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: In writing. Today, in response to the announcements of the closure of Caterpillar's plants in Belgium and Alstom's plants in France, the European Parliament adopted, at the initiative of the Group of Socialists and Democrats, a resolution calling for a genuine strategy for the re-industrialisation of Europe.  I voted in favour of this resolution, which takes up several concrete elements to revive European industry in the face of unfair foreign competition, to better defend jobs and finally to call for the reorientation of austere policies that undermine public investment.   With this resolution, MEPs are also sending a strong message to punish multinationals, such as Caterpillar, for favouring blind financial profitability over an industrial approach. Thus, thanks to the commitment of the Socialists, the European Parliament has voted in favour of sanctions for companies that make stock market layoffs. I also welcome the fact that the resolution calls for the implementation at European level of the Florange law, adopted in France, to oblige multinationals to seek a buyer beforehand in the event of the closure of an industrial site.  The Commission must now make proposals to the European Parliament to revitalise the European industrial fabric which is a vital pillar of our economy.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour, because it is imperative to coherence between the various policies of the European Union in order to define a genuine industrial policy, in particular in the light of the Caterpillar and Alstom cases. European industry, such as Alstom and Caterpillar, has a high added value and recognised competence and is central and strategic for the EU, which faces strong global competition from countries exporting low-cost products to the European market, practicing a policy of rapid and aggressive expansion on all continents, often with the political and financial support of their governments. European industry should be seen as a strategic asset for the competitiveness and sustainability of the EU. Only a strong and resilient industry and a future-oriented industrial policy will enable the EU to address the different challenges ahead, such as reindustrialisation, the transition to sustainability and the creation of quality jobs. It is up to the Commission and the Member States to anticipate these socio-economic situations and to ensure the competitiveness of our industrial network.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. U2012 The cases of business restructuring announced by Cartepillar and Alstom in which thousands of workers will be relocated by companies to different points in the European geography demonstrate the need for a European re-industrialization policy, containing a legislative package that gives workers power over these decisions, as well as a reform of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund that improves coverage on affected workers. That is why I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the need for a European reindustrialisation policy in the light of the recent cases of Caterpillar and Alstom. I believe that the very important message of this resolution is the European Parliament's call for the Commission to ensure a level playing field between European and non-European market players, thus ensuring fair competition for all. Last but not least, the text emphasises the importance of the green economy, as the transition to a green economy has a positive impact on employment and provides opportunities for regions to meet their own needs.

name: Virginie ROZIÈRE
text: In writing. I supported the European Parliament resolution, initiated by the Socialists and Democrats, which underlines the urgent need to define a European policy of re-industrialisation. The layoffs announced at the Caterpillar and Alstom plants demonstrate the pressures faced by European industry due to unfair global competition and unacceptable financial practices.  The resolution calls on the Commission to adjust the EU's trade policy to combat anti-competitive practices. It also calls for a redefinition of competition law rules, including the ability of relevant markets to be defined on a global scale. In addition, the resolution urges the contracting authorities to base their procurement decisions on the principle of the most economically advantageous offer. Above all, it highlights the need for effective social dialogue in the event of restructuring and the application of strict rules to combat redundancies without real economic grounds.  Finally, the more effective use of European funds, the intensification and rationalisation of research and development efforts, the targeting of regions most affected by deindustrialization and the consideration of training, health and working conditions are priorities.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this joint motion for a resolution, which draws attention to the need for the European Union (EU) to establish a more effective industrial policy following the recent restructuring cases of Caterpillar and Alstom, which have led to the dismissal of thousands of people and which represent another chapter of the complex and asymmetric phenomenon of European deindustrialisation. The railway industry is a key sector of European industrialisation, lacking robustness, technology and innovation to adapt to modern times while achieving the European Union's climate and energy targets. To that extent, it is a sector that, having recognised added and strategic value in Europe, needs to cope with strong global competition from other low-cost exporting countries. This resolution therefore not only strives for measures to support the workers made redundant from these two companies, but also to call for the need to pursue a genuine long-term, resilient and future-oriented European reindustrialisation strategic policy, capable of overcoming the challenges of competition, capable of creating quality jobs and fostering competitiveness in a sustainable manner. , as enshrined in the Europe 2020 strategy.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I supported this resolution, which reiterates the urgent need for the European Union to adopt a policy of re-industrialisation, particularly in light of the announcements of the closure of Caterpillar in Belgium and Alstom in France. Europe needs a forward-looking industrial strategy to improve the working conditions of companies, make better use of existing European financial instruments and, above all, protect workers. European industry needs a stable social and fiscal environment, which will be conducive to investment and therefore to its competitiveness. The European re-industrialisation strategy must be accompanied by a trade policy that has more efficient, faster and more accessible modernised trade defence instruments, particularly for SMEs. The European Union must be the guarantor of fair competition for our industries. I supported this resolution because it also reiterates the importance of a sustained social dialogue based on mutual trust in order to find consensual solutions and to identify common perspectives in the management of restructuring processes. Europe must support European workers while being a driving force for re-industrialisation.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. From Podemos we strongly denounce the policy of relocations and mass layoffs carried out by some large companies to benefit from unrettled laws in occupational safety, environmental and occupational safety guarantees, especially when these companies, as is the case with Alstom and Caterpillar, are leaders in their sector and record millions of benefits every year. Our group, the GUE/NGL, drafted its own resolution in line with this position. In addition, we voted in favour of the joint resolution because, although we believe that it could have been more forceful in denouncing these practices, some important amendments on unfair competition from third countries, including China, on the excessive short-term financing of the economy, on the low impact on employment of policies to support Union banks and markets, or on the need to revise commercial and labour legislation to protect workers and subcontractors affected by these unjustified business decisions, have been incorporated into the text.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. ‒ Reindustrialisation was supposed to have been a major plank of EU policy in past years. As an issue, it was only promoted sporadically, when major problems arose for major industrial players in major EU Member States. Meanwhile, most other Member States experienced continuing shocks to their industrial systems. They suffered big losses in employment and industrial knowhow. Deindustrialisation affected big and small companies alike. Their worries and the need to promote a really effective reindustrialisation strategy were buried under the preoccupation with a competition policy that screens out all state aid; a strong commitment to free trade under the aegis of globalisation; and a belief that services by themselves would keep Europe’s economies in competitive shape.  Reindustrialisation needs a policy designed for all seasons, not when major companies are about to collapse. It needs consistent and effective application. The European tradition is one which associates public policy with industrial endeavour. Saying so is not a rejection of globalisation. Rather it reflects the need for a European commitment to the planned development of globalisation which avoids social dumping through free trade. There is no other way by which to promote reindustrialisation and to make it applicable equally to big and small.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: in writing. – I support workers who lost their jobs, I share the pain of both workers and their families, and I am aware of the current damage of industrial restructuring. However, I did abstain from voting since I firmly believe that politicians in the EU and its Member States should not decide in specific cases, such as Caterpillar and Alstom. I believe that we need a more ambitious industrial strategy aimed at creating jobs and economic growth and a strategy that is able to provide needed help when necessary. I believe that the authorities should have the power to decide how to implement that strategy in specific cases.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I abstained in this resolution because, while containing positive elements (improving the use of European funds and public procurement in support of European industry, the role of the social partners, recognition of the importance of industrial policy, the need to reform competition policies to promote employment...) contains hardly any critical references to how European policies , from deregulation and privatization to their aggressive foreign trade policy, are responsible for Europe's industrial crisis.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 One of the EU's most important achievements is the creation of a competitive and single common market with the potential to attract investors, maintain strong value chains, create jobs and grow. The economic growth generated under these conditions directly translates into numerous sectors of the economy and the living conditions of people who gain a wide range of opportunities in terms of taking up work and choosing where to live. The social market economy model adopted in Europe aims to ensure that citizens have access to the labour market, social security and economic growth, which also entails respect for the moral and ethical rules of conduct for workers. However, increasingly emerging problems, such as those currently being discussed in the EP, are another signal that should mobilise action to defend jobs in Europe by increasing our competitiveness in an increasingly globalised global market. To this end, efforts to reindustralise Europe must be implemented consistently.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted for the resolution on the need for a European reindustrialisation policy in light of the recent Caterpillar and Alstom cases, this is important in light of the growing number of reports of labour-intensive activities being moved outside of Europe and high unemployment levels. Deindustrialisation continues to impact certain regions which is why the report calls on the Commission to set up a long-term European industrial strategy and also rapidly mobilise all available funds. Notably, this resolution also supports penalties against companies who make redundancies based on the stock market.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Europe has a social market economy that aims to achieve sustainable economic and inclusive growth, but there is no real EU industrial policy that also protects workers in the EU. That is why the Commission must develop a genuine long-term European industrial strategy in order to achieve the target set out in the Europe 2020 strategy, i.e. that 20% of gross domestic product comes from industry. The recent cases of Caterpillar and Alston, which have announced mass redundancies and production cuts in their sectors, which will jeopardise other subcontractors' jobs, must mobilise the Commission to reindustrialise European policy. EU funds, in particular R&D&I, need to be better used as an appropriate tool to support a new industrial policy. In cases of restructuring the EU economy, it is necessary to protect the interests of the workers concerned as regards their health and working conditions, social security, retraining and reintegration into the labour market.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. -u2012 The EU's industrial policy must be forward-looking and enable the economy to meet various challenges, including re-industrialisation, the transition to sustainability and the creation of quality jobs. For this reason, Parliament has drafted a resolution calling on the Member States to ensure adequate social protection, working conditions and decent wages through legislation or collective agreements, and, in the event of redundancies, effective protection against unjustified dismissal. At the same time, it calls on the Commission to develop an EU trade policy that is in line with industrial objectives and takes into account the need to protect jobs in European industry. Furthermore, there must be no further deindustrialisation and it must ensure a level playing field for market participants from Europe and third countries. In this way, fair competition for all will be ensured. All the reasons and calls to the Commission are important to me, which is why I also voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Bart STAES
text: Written. \u2012 September 2016 was dramatic in terms of job losses. The American multinational Caterpillar announced the resignation of more than 2,000 people in Gosselies. An additional 3,000 jobs will be lost at subcontractors. This was despite the fact that between 2009 and 2015 the dividend per share increased by 50% and still 15% of jobs were lost. On top of that, the lost jobs at Alstom in France.  The European Parliament is today calling for a genuine European policy of reindustrialisation. The Greens are calling for a sustainable transition to a green economy with quality jobs. To this end, we need to use EU funds. We also want to set conditions for state aid and see sustainable criteria in public procurement. It cannot be the case that multinationals receive financial support and shortly thereafter move their production to countries with lower social and environmental standards. We need to be able to anchor knowledge and jobs locally. Multinationals must adhere to socially responsible restructuring and respect social dialogue.  Unfortunately, the resolution does not identify a number of causes of such tragedies, such as wage competition, internal inequalities in the EU and lack of demand for raw materials, nor are concrete measures proposed. Nevertheless, we support this text in solidarity with the employees of Caterpillar and Alstom.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union is suffering from a decline in industrial production and a transfer of production capacity to other countries. This trend threatens millions of jobs, European GDP, as well as the stability of society as a whole. Together with the European Commission, we want to prevent this by means of systemic investments in infrastructure, digitalisation, as well as by protecting our industry from dumping and unfair competition. Our goal is to create a stable environment for companies in which they can fully develop and create new jobs.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: Written. The N-VA first of all wishes to express its concern to the thousands of employees and subcontractors affected by this closure. Although it is not equally satisfied with every aspect of the resolution, it therefore wishes to support it. With its 'yes' vote, it wants to send a strong signal that reindustrialisation and employment in Europe must be a top priority. It is true that globalisation requires a policy of perseverance. First of all, we must not give in to protectionist tendencies. International competition leads net to more jobs, not fewer. We must also put job security first. Constant technological change requires a rapidly adaptable labour market. This is the only way to safeguard our prosperity and employment. We can expect the EU to support the European Globalisation Fund (EGF) in the event of collective redundancies. But with a European transfer union, we will not solve unemployment. This ignores the resolution in which it praises the EGF. It is up to the Member States to make a full use of structural reforms that maxim enerti y to promote job creation and entrepreneurship. It is important that the EU respects the member state's powers sufficiently. The resolution once again misses the ball by, for example, calling for EU harmonisation in the fiscal, social and budgetary fields. This is neither legal nor desirable for N-VA.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ New Strategy 2012 The Commission envisaged a 'new industrial revolution' aimed at increasing industrial activity to 20% of EU GDP by 2020. However, caterpillar and alstom cases are negative examples of problems facing European industry where economic growth is still unable to generate improvements in the construction and infrastructure industries, resource industries and energy and transport sectors. It is therefore important to recall the responsibility of policymakers to achieve the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy with a competitive Europe with sustainable and inclusive growth, calling on the Commission and the European Investment Bank to focus in particular on the areas most affected by deindustrialisation. I support the motion for a resolution submitted following statements by the Council and the Commission in accordance with Article 123(2) of the Regulation. Rules of procedure on the need for a European reindustrialisation policy in light of the recent Caterpillar and Alstom cases.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Writing. Parliament's joint resolution did not satisfy us at all. As a Left, we see the need for reindustrialisation but not in the light of supporting multinationals at all costs. Despite having made billions in profits, these two multinationals decided to close their factories, leaving thousands of workers on the road and affecting dozens of other businesses. The resolution condemns in the mildest way this action by multinationals. In our view, it had to require public investment both to create new industrial sectors, as well as safe and decent jobs, and to support workers. We cannot support a resolution that requires the state to be a crutch of profitable multinationals.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 We are clearly in favour of the reindustrialisation of Europe, since we believe that this is the only way that can lead to real growth and prosperity. However, we are opposed to the way in which the Union aspires to achieve it, since we believe that it will not be effective, and we are also opposed to many of the priorities it sets.

name: József SZÁJER
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union must do more to create a more competitive European industry and protect the jobs of those working in the industry. As is known, in 2015 Hungary was at the forefront of the european Union's contribution to total gross value added, including water and waste management, by more than 27%. The EU average was 19% and Hungary fifth place in the EU rankings with an increase of 21.5% compared to 2010. At the same time, we must also pay attention to the world market, because it is becoming increasingly clear that competition is in sharpening and that all actors (employers, workers, government) must pay attention to this and actively contribute to strengthening the European Union at the same time and in support of each other. The Hungarian Government also believes, in line with the decision, that the loss of workers' skills and skills must be prevented and that Europe must maintain its industrial capacity to meet its needs without being dependent on third-country manufacturers. An independent domestic industry cannot be imagined with competitive European industry, markets and multinationals. Since 2013, employers have benefited from more than HUF 360 billion in discounts, preserving the jobs of nearly 900,000 workers a year.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution is about the need for a European reind into industrialisation policy, which I voted in favour of. I agree that European industry has played an essential role in the history of European integration and that it is still one of the pillars of the development of new values and channels in Europe. I believe that today's challenges have changed radically. I agree that an ambitious innovation policy favouring the production of high-quality, innovative, energy-efficient products and supporting new production processes will enable the EU to stand up to increasing global competition.  The motion mentions several companies that have laid off a large number of workers in recent years, most recently Caterpillar Holding, for example, which announced its global restructuring plan. This has left 2,500 workers out of work and some 4,000 subcontractors' jobs at risk. This can already be seen as a systemic problem and we are calling for action. I share the view that European industry should be seen as a strategic tool for the EU's competitiveness. The motion calls on the Council to adopt rapidly the modernisation of trade defence mechanisms so that it can finally respond adequately to unfair practices by third countries and protect EU industry from dumping on the European market, thus ensuring fair competition for all. I am in support of the social partnership consultation to protect workers in the framework of the implementation of the EU industrial strategy.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 On 2 September 2016 Caterpillar has announced a major global restructuring plan m.in close the Gosselies plant, leading to the layoffs of 2,500 direct workers and the threat to the jobs of about 4,000 subcontractors. A similar decision was taken by alstom's management, moving its railway production business (400 jobs) from the Belfort plant to the Reichshoffen plant, which is tantamount to the closure of the first factory. However, these are not the only production facilities to be restructured in Europe. There are likely to be further layoffs at Alstom's plants in Spain and Italy, as well as at caterpillar's plant in Northern Ireland. European industry is facing global competition. Many third-country companies export products with lower manufacturing costs to the European market, often with the political and financial support of their governments. In order to maintain their competitiveness and ability to invest in Europe, and to face societal and environmental challenges, EU companies often have to take difficult decisions that have the most impact on their employees. It is therefore necessary to establish a European strategy for europe's main industrial sectors in order to create a more market-friendly environment and to maintain high-quality employment, expertise and investment in Europe.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: in writing. \u2012 With a view to the exponential materialisation of the negative effects of globalisation, there is absolutely a need for a reindustrialisation of Europe. Obviously, European reindustrialisation policy must focus on the profitability of human capital in particular, as it is the source of innovation and creativity. In this respect, companies must promote proactive behaviour and invest according to a development model focused on the human factor. It should be noted that the assumption of social responsibility by all European companies is the foundation for Europe's viable and sustainable reindustrialisation. Compliance with a Stakeholder Engagement Standard would, at the very least, lead to the protection of workers, respect for their fundamental rights and a viable and sustainable management of their careers, ensuring cooperation and benefit ingudisation of the involvement of all those interested in company decisions and actions, the development of fundamental and experimental research projects financed by European Structural and Investment Funds to the sustainable development of entities communities and regions of Europe, etc. We hope for a coherent strategy on European reindustrialisation policy so that European entities can meet global social and environmental challenges.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The Caterpillar and Alstom cases reflect an increase in restructuring in several EU states as a result of changes in the economic environment. In this context, Member States will face significant economic challenges in the near future and must take all measures to improve industry levels of productivity and innovation. I also believe that informing and consulting workers is an essential element of social models in the Member States. For this reason, stressing that the EU and its Member States must coordinate their policies to ensure that they have sustainable and competitive manufacturing industries, I am voting to support the resolution.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text led by my colleague Maria Arena and with the support of Hugues Bayet, two MEPs from the Belgian PS delegation. I regret, of course, the EPP's attempts to empty the text of its substance, echoing the concerns of Caterpillar's management rather than the victim workers. Nevertheless, we have succeeded in passing important amendments, such as the one on social dumping or the notion of stock market layoffs.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ The European Parliament adopted a resolution on the need for a European reindustrialisation policy in the light of recent cases such as Caterpillar (Belgium) and Alstom (France). I express my strong solidarity and support to all workers of Caterpillar and Alstom and their families, as well as to the subcontractors involved, and regret the detrimental effects that such closures have on local economies and communities. Nevertheless I decided to abstain on the final vote as  the cases at Caterpillar and Alstom were a symptom of Europe’s industrial malaise. Indeed I deplore the absence of a long-term vision for European industry and this text did not propose a sustainable solution and vision for the future.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: In writing. The abrupt announcements of the closure of Alstom's plants in France and Caterpillar in Belgium, disastrous for the employees of these plants and the territories, led the European Parliament to react.  I congratulate the work of my colleagues Marie Arena and Edouard Martin on this initiative.  Through this vote, we reaffirm the will to save industries and jobs in the European Union, by enacting the principle of sanctions against companies that would make stock market layoffs with the reimbursement of public aid.  We also call for the adoption at European level of a 'Florange law', to force multinationals that desert the sites to seek a buyer.  We propose a 'carbon adjustment at borders' to combat unfair competition, particularly from countries with highly carbon-intensive means of production. We call for the resumption of public investment in Europe and the exit of austerity policies. This new European industrial policy must also be accompanied by social and fiscal harmonisation between Member States to avoid any dumping situation.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. \u2012 This resolution was created in response to recent layoff announcements at Caterpillar and Alstom. Namely, caterpillars have announced that they will eliminate 10,000 jobs worldwide. They also confirmed that there will be redundancies of 200-250 workers in Northern Ireland and the redundancies of 2,000 workers in Belgium, all due to declining sales. At the same time, alstom confirmed that they are stopping producing trains in eastern France. Such resolutions have traditionally expressed tendency interventionist views, completely contrary to the fundamental postulates of the European Union aimed at freedom of competition. Those attitudes can't get my support.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. - I supported the motion for a European Parliament resolution on the need for a European policy for reindustrialisation in the light of the recent caterpillar and Alstom cases. It is extremely important to ensure coherence between the different EU policies in order to define a real industrial policy, especially in the light of the cases of Caterpillar and Alstom. The railway industry is a pillar of European industrialisation with more than 175 years of history. The annual growth of the affordable rail supply industry is expected to be 2.8% by 2019. The European rail supply industry directly employs 400,000 people in the EU, many of them in SMEs. European industry should be seen as a strategic asset for the EU's competitiveness and sustainability. Only solid and resilient economies and forward-looking industrial policies will enable the European Union to meet the various challenges that await it, including its re-industrialisation, the transition to sustainability and the creation of quality jobs.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. From Podemos we strongly denounce the policy of relocations and mass layoffs carried out by some large companies to benefit from unrettled laws in occupational safety, environmental and occupational safety guarantees, especially when these companies, as is the case with Alstom and Caterpillar, are leaders in their sector and record millions of benefits every year. Our group, the GUE/NGL, drafted its own resolution in line with this position. In addition, we voted in favour of the joint resolution because, although we believe that it could have been more forceful in denouncing these practices, some important amendments on unfair competition from third countries, including China, on the excessive short-term financing of the economy, on the low impact on employment of policies to support Union banks and markets, or on the need to revise commercial and labour legislation to protect workers and subcontractors affected by these unjustified business decisions, have been incorporated into the text.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The American construction equipment manufacturer Caterpillar announced on 2 September this year its intention to close its only Belgian plant in Gosselies, resulting in the loss of 2,200 (6,000 if you include subcontractors) positions in the already disaster-stricken region of Charleroi). Alstom announced on 12th September the closure of its Belfort site, which specialises in the construction of railway equipment. The company motivated its decision by the reduction of orders from SNCF, which preferred Bombardier as a supplier for TERs. The majority groups want to take advantage of the media coverage of these cases to revive the idea of European industrial policy, "without protectionism". The joint resolution has several pillars: green economy, renovation of trade defence instruments, revival of public and private investment, increased employee participation in restructuring plans. The resolution's proposals are inconsistent: promoting free trade on the one hand and requiring reciprocity and opening up public procurement by other powers. No Community preference in sight for rail, which is an industry of sovereignty. I voted against it.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. From Podemos we strongly denounce the policy of relocations and mass layoffs carried out by some large companies to benefit from unrettled laws in occupational safety, environmental and occupational safety guarantees, especially when these companies, as is the case with Alstom and Caterpillar, are leaders in their sector and record millions of benefits every year. Our group, the GUE/NGL, drafted its own resolution in line with this position.
