In addition, we voted in favour of the joint resolution because, although we believe that it could have been more forceful in denouncing these practices, some important amendments on unfair competition from third countries, including China, on the excessive short-term financing of the economy, on the low impact on employment of policies to support Union banks and markets, or on the need to revise commercial and labour legislation to protect workers and subcontractors affected by these unjustified business decisions, have been incorporated into the text.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution to support the workers of Caterpillar and Alstom because in the text we managed to add important green wording referring to the green economy (need for investments in energy efficiency and renewable energy, green public procurement, improved social and environmental investment criteria), to the need for stopping tax evasion through increased convergence in fiscal, social and budgetary matters, and the need for trade policy consistent with reindustrialisation objectives to preserve quality employment in the EU.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – I welcome the task force set up by the Commission to mediate between the Belgian authorities and the Commission. I believe that links between research and industry are crucial to promoting the competitiveness of EU industry.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the motions for resolutions on the need for a European reindustrialisation policy in light of the recent Caterpillar and Alstom cases. There is an absolute need for consistency between the various EU policies in order to define an actual industrial policy, in particular in the light of the Caterpillar and Alstom cases. The resolution underlines that European industry needs to maintain its competitiveness and capacity to invest in Europe. However, it also faces social and environmental challenges which it must address, whilst remaining a world reference in terms of social and environmental responsibility. The resolution equally underlines that the Member States have to ensure adequate social protection, working conditions and wages that allow people to live with dignity. I voted in favour because I strongly believe that the importance of a sustained social dialogue, at all levels, based on mutual trust and shared responsibilities, is one of the best instruments for finding consensual solutions and common perspectives in the prediction, prevention and management of the restructuring process.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. In view of the closure plans threatening Caterpillar and Alstom factories in Belgium, this non-legislative resolution aims to have the European Commission review Community legislation on mass redundancies. Through it, Parliament asks parliament to consult social actors on the effectiveness of existing legislation in order to ensure that any corporate restructuring is carried out in a socially responsible manner and in line with both regionally applicable regulations and Community values. This resolution also underlines the need to implement a common industrial policy which has real impact and also ensures the protection of European workers. On the basis of my firm belief that European industry should be treated as what it is — a strategic asset for the competitiveness and sustainability of the Union — I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted for the resolution on the need for a European reindustrialisation policy in light of the recent Caterpillar and Alstom cases, this is important in light of the growing number of reports of labour-intensive activities being moved outside of Europe and high unemployment levels. Deindustrialisation continues to impact certain regions, which is why the report calls on the Commission to set up a long-term European industrial strategy and also rapidly mobilise all available funds. Notably, this resolution also supports penalties against companies who make redundancies based on the stock market.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this report to remind the Commission that there is indeed a need to introduce a European reindustrialisation policy. The laid-off employees at Caterpillar and Alstrom need guidance for a new job. We should also stress that labour costs, among other things, affect the competitiveness of European companies; the tax burden should be shifted from labour to other forms of taxation that are less harmful to employment and growth, while ensuring adequate social protection.

name: Paavo VÄYRYNEN
text: Written. \u2012 The resolution was internally contradictory and had a wealth of details that I could not accept. That is why I abstained in the votes on the details and, finally, against the adoption of the resolution as a whole.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. Dividends for Caterpillar shareholders increased by more than 4% between 2015 and 2016 and those of Alstom shareholders by 27%. In both cases, no decrease is expected. However, these multinationals with substantial profits have just announced mass layoffs in Europe, notably in France and Belgium, and other no less massive ones are planned in several Member States. The cause is known: these companies are relocating. The resolution adopted by the European Parliament makes this observation and deplores it. It calls for increased public and private investment in European industry, calls for wage increases to stimulate demand, advocates a European trade policy that avoids relocation, says it must tackle tax evasion and supports the implementation of common European industrial projects. I regret, however, that the right has notably rejected our amendment calling for the recovery of all resources dedicated to the support of companies paid in particular in the form of subsidies and tax advantages when a company decides to relocate or close its production sites. For these reasons I abstained.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. Caterpillar and Alstrom workers and their struggle must deserve all our solidarity and the mobilisation of all measures so that, as soon as possible, they can recover their jobs and can do so on the basis of rights that guarantee them job security with decent wages and possibilities for professional and personal development. The reference to a European industrial policy, or to a strategy and objectives of a European industry, alignment with the Europe 2020 strategy, the search for cosmetic solutions to promote employment, such as the deification of corporate social responsibility, are precisely the basis of the deindustrialisation that this EU now cynically intends to counteract. We believe that reindustrialisation is necessary, but a reindustrialisation based on the qualifications of workers and inserted in development strategies that it is up to each country to decide and which naturally imply public control of the fundamental levers of economic growth.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. Against the background of the mass redundancies at Caterpillar and Alstom, it is clear that the industrial base is of the utmost importance for European prosperity and prosperity. Europe must create a better business environment for industry, taking into account subsidiarity, national labour rights and social traditions, as part of an active economic policy. The motion for a resolution is a step in the right direction.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the need for a European reindustrialisation policy in the light of the recent Caterpillar and Alstom cases. Given that caterpillar announced the closure of its Belgian headquarters in Gosselies last month, which will result in the dismissal of more than 2 000 workers and that Alstom will move its train production operations in France from Belfort to Reichshoffen, putting more than 400 employees at risk, the resolution reiterates the EU's need to rebalance its domestic demand in order to avoid external dependence and contribute to sustainable and equitable growth worldwide. The motion for a resolution stresses the need to stimulate the real economy through a policy of reindustrialisation that aligns trade policy with energy transactions and sustainability, creating quality jobs and, in this case, promoting and intensifying advance measures with regard to the situation of Caterpillar and Alstom.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ As the world’s largest market, and a global actor in trade, the EU is able to shape globalisation. This is something the UK has always benefited from, and risks losing as Brexit unfolds. The EU needs a socially-sensitive industrial policy, which adjusts to the situation regarding global markets, and is compatible with trade policy, in order to safeguard European industries and create real sustainable and inclusive economic growth. The UK requires much the same kind of progressive industrial policy, regardless of the choices we make on Brexit, and Labour will continue to hold the Tory government to account on this.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution by the European Parliament. It is unfortunate that so many people at Caterpillar and Alstom have lost their jobs. This again shows the importance of the EU’s economic strength and competitive position. In order to achieve this, Europe and our industries need to attract investment. As the resolution rightly points out, investment in energy efficiency provides a lot of opportunities here. Such sustainable investment will lead to sustainable economic growth and consequently new jobs for our labour market. Another measure that can attract new investment is a reduction in unnecessary administrative burdens. But when it comes to safeguarding our industry, Europe needs to look at the future and recognise that a reindustrialisation will, for example, find its basis in digitalisation and the development of smart technologies. We also have to focus on giving these people a new future, by offering them new education and training opportunities, so they can keep contributing to society and the economy.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: in writing. The report presented urges the Commission to establish a Union trade policy, which is in line with its industrial objectives and takes into account the need to secure European jobs and prevent relocation and further deind industrialisation. It calls on the Commission to ensure a level playing field for market operators within and outside Europe to allow fair competition for all. It is very important to take into account the social and economic impacts that the closure of these plants entails for the affected regions, improving the understanding of the impact on the employment and European industries. My vote is in favour of this report as we must protect the areas most affected by re-industrialisation in order to go forward and be able to adapt to the new economic needs.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 Unfortunately, today we are here to comment on the Caterpillar affair, a sad situation for the fate of workers and their families, a situation that becomes extremely paradoxical when we consider that in recent years the company has increased the payment of dividends to its shareholders by 50 %. This is not the first case affecting the European industrial sector, which has seen the direct employment share of the sector fall steadily since 2000, and I have the impression that it is not the last. I wonder what future there will be for the European industrial sector and for Europe as a whole, when a number of factors mean that there is no exit at the end of the dark tunnel in which we have entered. I am referring to the austerity measures that reign supreme and prevent all sorts of public investment, blocking growth and contracting demand, wages that have been stuck in relation to increased productivity, the progressive thinning of those social protections, which have always been a source of pride and distinction on the European continent, and non-strategic relocations within the EU, linked to everything but an effective and effective industrial policy project. All this is aggravated by the element that is sinking the European industrial sector and beyond: the euro.

name: Auke ZIJLSTRA
text: Written. \u2012 The PVV voted against a European reindustrialisation policy because the establishment of an industry is heavily dependent on the location. Factors such as the investment climate, accessibility, the level of education of the population, energy prices and statutory worker services are of primary importance. On all these points, the EU is counterproductive. This proposal, which once again places responsibility on the EU, does not help.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the need for a reindustrialisation policy in the light of the recent Caterpillar (In Belgium) and Alstom (In France) cases because I believe that a new investment strategy in Europe based on sustainable growth and combating social dumping is needed. At the initiative of the European Socialist Group, this resolution is a strong political signal from the European Parliament to the European Commission, where it is asked that all restructuring processes be explained and justified to workers through a permanent social dialogue. I would remind you that Europe is a social market economy that aims to achieve a sustainable economy and inclusive growth. To this do so, European industry needs to maintain its competitiveness and capacity to invest in Europe, which should be to focus on innovative production processes that enable the EU to be a leader in an increasingly crowded global context.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. I supported the motion for a resolution on the need for a European policy for reindustrialisation in the light of the recent caterpillar and Alstom cases. I agree with the call for European industry to maintain its competitiveness and investment capacity in Europe by listening to workers' fundamental rights and environmental standards. An effective trade policy aligned with industrial objectives is therefore needed, a competitive European regulatory framework attractive for private investment and the use of research, development and innovation at all stages of the production process.

name: Algirdas SAUDARGAS
text: – Madam President, I would like to raise a point of order on behalf of the PPE Group. I want to object to the minutes of yesterday’s sitting. In point 10 – ‘Approval of the minutes of the previous sitting’ – the minutes take note of Mr Guoga’s objection to the minutes of Monday’s sitting, but at the same time confirm the approval of the minutes of Monday’s sitting. As Mr Guoga had a serious objection to raise, and there was no decision on his objection in yesterday’s sitting, it is the wrong conclusion that the minutes of Monday’s sitting can be deemed to be approved. Before a decision on Mr Guoga’s intervention has been taken, the minutes of Monday’s session cannot be approved and the conclusion in yesterday’s minutes cannot be not correct.

name: Algirdas SAUDARGAS
text: President-in-Office of the Council, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, once again I am representing the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative. She is not able to be here and therefore as usual she has asked the Presidency to speak on her behalf, and it is a great honour for me to participate in this important debate about Syria.  Unfortunately, I have to start by recognising the fact that what we see in Syria right now is the biggest humanitarian catastrophe of the century, and it is getting worse by the day. Our exchange serves as an important input to the discussion among the EU Foreign Ministers at the next Foreign Affairs Council in mid-October. In spite of the international community’s efforts to restore a nationwide ceasefire and press the parties in the conflict to come back to the negotiation table in Geneva, the violence has escalated once again during the last two weeks. We have all seen the dreadful pictures of entire families caught in debris in Aleppo under waves of bombardments. We all condemned the despicable attacks on the humanitarian aid convoy on 19 September and the deaths of the eight workers of the Syrian Red Crescent, who lost their lives while trying to save others. Last month in New York, at the UN General Assembly, a number of attempts were made to get the US—Russia deal on the cessation of hostilities back on track. The High Representative/Vice—president has been actively involved in this effort through meetings with the Syrian Opposition, US and Russian Ministers as well as with the main regional players in the conflict. Two International Syria Support Group ministerial meetings were organised, which tried to salvage the cessation of hostilities and reduce the violence in the country. Neither meeting led to a positive outcome. In fact the Syrian parties are now further away from a negotiated solution for a political transition than before. Let me reassure you that we are incessantly at work to contribute to the ending of the conflict and of the suffering of the Syrian people. The political answers in the case of the Syrian conflict are never straightforward or black and white. As we are working towards a renewed strategy for Syria, let me recall the three policy tracks established by the International Syria Support Group and the EU’s contribution to each: the humanitarian track, the ceasefire and the political track. Firstly, the humanitarian track remains a core mission for the European Union. We are – and always will be – the main donor of humanitarian aid for Syria. The Commission reactivated the ECHO office in Damascus earlier this year. No matter what happens, our first duty is to provide support and hope to the Syrian people, be it to the refugees in Turkey, Lebanon and Jordan, in Europe or inside Syria, and especially in the besieged and hard-to-reach areas. We need to continue to do all we can to push for unhindered humanitarian aid deliveries throughout Syria and an end to the targeting of civilians and civilian infrastructure. We continue to work with the United Nations and with Syrian organisations in this field, including inside Syria, to deliver the aid needed. Therefore High Representative Mogherini and Commissioner Stylianides launched an EU initiative on Aleppo over the weekend, based on two main elements: first, let in humanitarian aid. We are working to facilitate the urgent delivery of basic lifesaving assistance to civilians in eastern Aleppo. If the UN ceasefire of at least two days is agreed, an inter—agency aid convoy will be ready to reach East Aleppo from West Aleppo to let out the wounded and the sick. We are working to ensure medical evacuations from East Aleppo, with the focus on women, children and elderly people. This will be done in close cooperation with UN agencies and other international agencies. In the last few days, the High Representative has discussed this proposal with a number of international players, including the United States, Russia and Iran. The Commission has also made EUR 25 million available in an emergency fund for addressing priority needs, including health, water, food supplies and services. The EU will not be directly involved in operations on the ground but will provide pre-funding and assist in the facilitation operation, reaching out to partners on the ground, as well as to regional players in support of the initiative. But addressing the current emergency is not enough. The Syrians in Syria need access to services, education for their children and hospitals for the injured. They need jobs and functioning local economies if we want to build a strong society, if we want to avoid more refugees fleeing Syria and if we want to avoid the radicalisation of the next generation of Syrians. In the absence of a top—down political solution, we need to start building peace from the bottom up by helping local communities and civilian administration to start functioning and provide services to the local population in areas where this is possible. This is in line with the Foreign Affairs Council conclusions of May 2016 that commit us to investing in civil society and support for local resilience inside Syria. Secondly, on the ceasefire, the EU as such is not a military player in the conflict. The greater responsibility lies with those who are supplying military assets and personnel. They have the leverage to push for an end to hostilities if they choose to, so we must continue to reach out to these regional actors. None of them will want Syria to fall apart, but Syria will fall apart if the war continues. We need to convince all actors that a political solution is the only option ahead of us. No side will win this war on the field. Military offensives cannot bring victory nor impose peace, but only prolong the bloodshed. It took 16 years for the Lebanese people to put an end to their civil war. We cannot afford such a scenario in Syria. This leads me to the final and most important track: the political track. In these times of despair for the Syrians, we must not lose hope in a political process and must never stop working for it. As the UN Special Envoy, Staffan de Mistura, has recently explained in the UN Security Council, losing hope equals abandoning the Syrian people to death and devastation. Many are working and many are now looking to Europe for answers. High Representative Mogherini and her officials are engaged in a constant dialogue with the United States, Russia and the countries of the region. We are thinking out of the box about what can create the conditions for the Syrians to start talking seriously about their future within the parameters that have been set by previous attempts in Geneva and by the UN Security Council. We are aware of the different concerns and interests of the parties in the conflict and their own political objectives in Syria. However, none of them can justify the indiscriminate targeting of civilians and the atrocities committed. In Boston ten days ago, the Foreign Ministers of the United States, the United Kingdom, France, Germany and Italy, and High Representative Mogherini, called on Russia to take steps to restore the credibility of our effort, including by halting the regime’s bombardment of its own people. The High Representative is also in direct contact with the Syrian political opposition. We will continue to engage with them and support their quest for democracy, the rule of law and comprehensive and genuine political transition in the country while also committing to work towards the preservation of state institutions and the protection of minority rights. It is vital to maintain their engagement in the political process and to support the moderate opposition, otherwise we will face a growing process of the radicalisation of the Syrian opposition, especially the armed groups, that could have long—term destructive consequences for the entire region. It is the European Union’s political and moral duty to light the candle of hope again for the Syrian people.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Madam President, Aleppo is experiencing a huge humanitarian tragedy. All the principles of international law are flouted. Civilians, hospitals and humanitarian personnel are the targets of Syrian and Russian shelling. The United States has announced that it can no longer cooperate with Russia on the Syrian issue because Putin has not kept his own commitments. But I ask the following question: when did the Russian leader meet his commitments? In Crimea, has he fulfilled his commitments? I think it is the same in Russia.  It should be stressed that Russia is directly responsible for the escalation of violence in the Syrian conflict. The country has never engaged in Syria to fight terrorism. Putin simply wanted to support his friend Assad.  I would like to welcome the proposal by Mrs Mogherini and Commissioner Stylianides to set up an emergency humanitarian initiative for Aleppo. I regret that neither of them is here with us today. Every way needs to be done to facilitate the delivery of emergency aid to civilians and to ensure medical evacuations. I know that the Union is very involved in this humanitarian aspect. However, we must also invest in other areas, including at the diplomatic level.  The role of the European Union in resolving the Syrian conflict is far too timid, while this war has a significant impact on Europe. But to really play a role in resolving the conflict, we must no longer be under any illusions about Russia. We have to work with the United States, just as the United States has to work with us. It has to be reciprocal. You can't commit yourself.  Thank you very much for your attention, including the communist group that still supports Putin. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr Preda, your classic, repeated Russian bashing and Putin bashing is your right, but I have a question for you: perhaps you are looking a little bit in all directions? And did you notice that, for example, in this sad area of Syria, great activities in cooperation between US troops and Kurds have also been initiated there, but that the Americans then forced the Kurds to go back again in order to free up spaces for Turkey – so that they look at things less one-sidedly ...  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: "blue card" answer. It is not a question, but I say very clearly to my colleague that, yes, you have to choose your side. You can't work with people who go to war. The people who are at war are Assad and Putin, who don't really want to solve this conflict. They have complicated it - as we said a year ago, when we held the first debate after the Russian intervention - and since then the Russian strategy has been clear.

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, since 2011, the war in Syria has been going on, with half a million victims and some 5 million refugees. A humanitarian tragedy, a country reduced to a pile of rubble. Today, the bombing of Russian aircraft and Assad's forces continues non-stop, without respecting any rules, if ever there is or may be an ethic of war. This happens a few kilometres from here, off the Cypriot coast and not far from the Greek islands, and then there are some who are surprised that refugees are arriving, refugees are arriving. But if there is a war, if there are millions of dead! There are bombings on schools, on hospitals, on women, on children, on doctors. But what do those people have to do? They come to us and someone says we didn't welcome them. There is a humanitarian tragedy to which an answer must be given. This can be defined as a crime of humanity. And those who commit this crime, and we do not discount anyone, will forever bear responsibility for it in the face of history. This House has a duty to strongly condemn the infamy of attacks on civilians. The European Union , and I am addressing in particular the High Representative Federica Mogherini, together with the United Nations, must put in place all the instruments at its disposal to stop this massacre, to achieve a ceasefire and the resumption of negotiations. This must be done now, because it is now being bombed. When the lights go out in this Parliament and we go comfortably to dinner or sleep, they will continue to bomb. So it must be done now and with the utmost authority and with the utmost force, Dear President-in-Office of the Council. We must demand immediate and unconditional access to humanitarian aid and personnel, because this is an obligation under international law: cease-fire and immediate access to humanitarian aid.  (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), "blue card" question. Thank you, Madam President, I do not think there is a reasonable person who welcomes the bombing of civilians, no matter who they take place. I wanted to ask this: why do you not recommend the evacuation, with the care of the European Union, of all civilians from the districts of Aleppo held by ISIS, so that the jihadists can no longer use these civilians as a human shield and there are no more casualties among civilians?

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: Answer to a blue card question. The United Nations and the European Union, through the other representative, must use all peaceful means to obtain a ceasefire and access to humanitarian aid. I do not think that wars should be fought and that military action should be taken. We must use the political weapon of negotiation and the strength of political persuasion.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, five and a half years on from the first newspaper reports describing protests in Damascus and Aleppo as rare, it is difficult now to reconcile such media descriptions with the horrors and atrocities we see in Syria. In those five and a half years, in this very House, I have advocated the merits of various policies, including a no-fly zone to curtail the capabilities of Assad’s air force, to reluctantly working with the Russians and the Assad regime to defeat ISIS and other extremist groups like Al—Nusra, now rebranded as Jabhat Fateh al-Sham. Like so many other proposed solutions, these are all now largely unworkable and obsolete in the current context. We have over 1 000 armed groups and militias operating across the country. ISIS continues to hold huge swathes of territory and external interests are taking an ever—greater role in the conflict, and we are now descending into multiple proxy wars.  Russia’s decision to transport S 300 surface-to-air missiles is clearly targeted at further limiting the options of the US-led coalition to act against Assad’s air force and increases the chances of unintentional escalation. Following the recent breakdown of the latest Kerry—Lavrov ceasefire talks and the subsequent diplomatic fallout between America and Russia, any hope now of trying to focus combined military efforts against ISIS and Jabhat seems lost. Russia is now more openly and brazenly than ever allying itself with Assad’s brutal regime and is acting as a joint belligerent in the siege of Aleppo, in addition to the support from Iran. This offensive has the potential to become a turning point in the entire conflict. It could also prove to be one of the most deadly and atrocious. Already we hear of hospitals and aid convoys being hit and the continued atrocious use of barrel and bunker-busting bombs against civilians. Many politicians and voters still question the merits of intervention, and it is vital that we continue to make the case that there is not only a humanitarian imperative to act against authoritarian dictators killing innocent civilians with impunity, but that not acting also poses risks to our own societies. The conflict in Syria has seen millions of people flee for their lives, many of whom have found their way to Europe, as Mr Pittella pointed out. We have seen the huge debate that this has fuelled in Europe and how mainstream parties of government are increasingly being pressured by populist and right-wing parties to bring an end to Mrs Merkel’s – in my view, ill-advised – open door policy. For the first time I see the notion of European solidarity seriously challenged, and I witnessed first-hand how this issue of uncontrolled migration played out during the EU referendum campaign in my country into a Brexit outcome. It is neither right nor possible to ignore what is happening in Syria. We must not allow the legacy of Iraq and Afghanistan to completely tarnish the merits of intervention. After five and a half years of indecisiveness in the West, to limit our options, perhaps a de facto partition of Syria is now the only hope for peace in that country.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I know that after three minutes you will have your hammer and so on, as though this is not important about Syria and the tragedy in Syria. I find it like a kindergarten, the way we are debating such a tragedy there, and I have already used seven seconds now. But I disagree with the Council; I disagree with its analysis. What the Council is saying is: let’s continue with what we did in the past and the problems will be solved, and we are going to help the moderate forces in Aleppo. Well, we are not doing anything for the moderate forces in Aleppo. That is the reality. We are not even capable of sending them aid, as we have tried to do several times, because we have failed in Syria and we failed in Aleppo. We failed first of all because the Americans took a wrong decision years ago by putting a red line on the use of chemical weapons, and once Assad used his chemical weapons we did nothing at all. We stopped our measures against the Assad regime, but we have given the message to the Assad regime that if you don’t use chemical weapons, you can do what you want. Go forward to kill your people: we shall not disturb you. The second thing is the absence of Europe – let’s be honest, we were absent in this whole conflict, and it is the Americans and the Russians who are negotiating above our heads. So, nevertheless, things are crystal clear. There is a problem here: the problem is that we have a key resolution of the UN Security Council: Resolution 2254. That is the key resolution, saying: stop the bombing of civilians, allow humanitarian access, limit the military campaign to fight whom? Daesh and al-Nusra. That is the Security Council resolution. And what the Russians are doing is the exact opposite: they are bombing the civilians. They are stopping – in fact, blocking – humanitarian access, and they are not fighting Daesh and not fighting al-Nusra: they are fighting against the moderate forces in Aleppo. That is what is happening. The only way to come out of this stalemate is to have a new strategy, and for the Council, together with Ms Mogherini, and together with our American allies, to change their strategy. And the strategy can only be, in my opinion, three things. First of all, we need a no-fly zone over Aleppo. We need a no-fly zone over Aleppo, and actually if we don’t do it in the coming days and the coming weeks, it’s over, because the Russians yesterday delivered an anti-air missile system that will make from Aleppo not a no-fly zone but a free bombing zone for their airforce and for the airforce of the Assad regime. That is what is happening. We have only a few days, a few weeks to change the course of Aleppo. Secondly, we also need, as we have discussed this morning, Mr Weber, in my opinion, a credible sanction plan for the non-compliance of Russia and of the Assad regime with the UN Security Council Resolution. Finally, the last lesson to learn: let’s start to make our own defence community and to develop our own capabilities, because that is the only way for the coming years to secure our neighbourhood. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Marek JUREK
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – We must call for an end to the bombing of Aleppo as soon as possible and we must call for peace negotiations without preconditions. But in order to understand your position well, I would like to know who you consider to be a moderate force? Muslim brothers from the ass-Sham legion or salafites from Nur ad-Din Zangi? Who are these moderate forces? Peace is needed, not accusations.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: blue-card answer. – The forces, dear colleague, were the normal, ordinary citizens – the students, the doctors, the lawyers, the people from the middle class – who started the revolution in Syria. The revolution in Syria was not different from the revolution in Tunisia; it was not different from the things that happened in Egypt. It was exactly the same. What happened is that we did not help them, and when you create a vacuum by not helping them, then the most awful forces of the Sunni Jihadi came into that vacuum in 2011: Daesh, al-Nusra and others. The only thing we can do now is go back to the past and say: let’s help at least these moderate people there, these normal civilians who are fighting Assad and who are blocked in Aleppo and who will be exterminated if the US, the international community and we do not take responsibility.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: gue/NGL Group. – Madam President, well, I confess that I have the feeling that I am in the wrong debate because I thought it was to discuss the situation in Syria. What's going on with the Syrian people, and what I see, is a group of men who seem to be playing Risk, that war game that the boys play on the board, each choosing their soldiers, their pawns, but no one mentions the essence of this debate that it is the Syrian people and what is living in Syria. So you are all very entertained playing your games, doing your arm of iron and not really responding to the humanitarian problem in Syria.  I must tell you that the worst example this Parliament can set is exactly what we are having in this debate: it is to equip a conflict, to equip victims to play your war games. We don't need that! We need to be on the side of the Syrian people. No, Mr Verhofstadt, you do - I know you are not listening to me because you must be a woman and not playing the war games that you play with your friends - but I must say, Mr Verhofstadt, what you have said is absolutely unacceptable. We need to support the efforts of the United Nations, a political dialogue, yes, with all actors, excluding terrorists. And as for moderate forces, perhaps we could stop indiscriminately arming so-called "moderate forces" and stop creating terrorist groups, because al-Nusra, before it was a terrorist group, was also a moderate force that should be supported.  So if we don't start treating the deaths seriously, if we don't start to deal seriously with the humanitarian tragedy, we can continue with this fantastic spectacle and I must tell you, it is not only this as a huge lack of respect, that you are so good, so good, so good, better than everyone, who knows everything, who afford to remove their headphones when others speak, because they do not accept to hear criticism from anyone. I'm used to it. I appreciate it, I got a better idea of both of you.

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I believe that in every war there is actually such a moment when, after being blunt for a long time, you are shaken up by images and reports. And I believe that the reports and the images from Aleppo have actually put us in a situation where we have to question the laisser fair and our own ignorance. Aleppo – this is the place that Putin and Assad are turning into hell on earth. I found it very bizarre that Russian media have spoken of Aleppo becoming Syria's Stalingrad, in a situation where Russian troops are turning Aleppo into Syria's Stalingrad. What I have felt over the last few days was not only this cursed impotence, but it was also anger at myself and at ourselves, because I believe that we have not been deceived by Russia and Putin, but that we have been deceived in full consciousness. We wanted to believe that we could go down the road with Putin in peace negotiations. We wanted to believe that we could create an international strategy with Putin against ISIS. Did the West really want to deceive itself? I believe: yes, and I believe that this is at the latest with the attack on the United Nations aid convoy, that this is over at the latest with this situation, that we are allowed to deceive ourselves in this way. I believe that it really must now be a matter of making it clear to Vladimir Putin that this escalation, for which he is responsible, stands in the way of any return to normal relations between the European Union and Russia. The catalogue of demands presented by the Russian side – after it was decided in the United States that this can no longer continue – at the height of its own bombing of Aleppo must not be accepted at all. The European Union – and this must be discussed at the summit – must not begin to engage in a logic in which Ukraine and Aleppo are offset. And the US and Europe must not waste any thought on the fact that Russia could be compensated for sanctions. If we were to get involved in the logic of this catalogue, we would reward the aggressor and establish a dangerous principle that must not exist at all. The European Union must be prepared to use its economic weight consistently in these disputes. We must not talk about reducing garrities, but we must talk about the need for further sanctions and that these sanctions are not only needed against Russia, but that our newly established relations with Iran, our relations with the Saudis, but also our relations with Turkey must be discussed from this point of view. European Union diplomacy can only be successful in these situations that we are experiencing with Russia and others in escalation if we are prepared to let this diplomacy cost us something. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Jacek SARYUSZ-WOLSKI
text: blue-card question. – Ms Harms, I share your assessment. How would you view or assess the situation when – having the same assessment, I understand – Washington breaks the talks with Russia, condemning the Aleppo drama, but Ms Mogherini telephones Mr Lavrov asking him for help to deliver humanitarian aid to those who are bombed by Russians and Syrians at the same time? This is a complete divergence between us and America, which is going against all of us.

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I very much regret that Federica Mogherini is not here, especially because of her proposals, and no one can be against humanitarian aid to Aleppo. But after the bombing of the United Nations aid convoy – the first convoy sent to this city in years – the offer of humanitarian aid must be combined with a concept and the situation for this humanitarian aid must be created. I found the previous demands on the part of the Council and the High Representative, but also, for example, from the German Foreign Minister Steinmeier, simply alien and naive.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in the bloody chessboard that has become Syria, the conquest of Aleppo could be the strategic turning point. The political one, paradoxically, could come not to Geneva, let alone to New York, Damascus, Washington or Brussels, but surprisingly to Istanbul. There, in fact, Putin and Erdogan will meet on 10 October to clearly put their respective demands on the table. On the one hand, there will be a russian and Iranian need to support the ally Assad, so as not to lose the last cornerstones of the Mediterranean, and, on the other, the Turkish will to break the territorial continuity of the Kurds and possibly put them in check with a no-fly zone.  Against the background, the ambiguity of us action, paralysed by the imminent change in the White House, unable to mitigate the agendas of the Gulf allies, to isolate the extremists once and for all, but above all to reconcile the increasingly incoherent alliance with the Turks, with the promise of support for the Kurds, real protagonists of the war against Daesh, precisely those brave Kurds as always used and abandoned by the superpowers engaged in the great Middle Eastern game. The truce and failed attempts at US-Russia coordination have further pushed this strategic rapprochement between Ankara and Moscow. In view of the many interests and mutual mistrust, the draft agreement to be negotiated with the new US Presidency could be decided in Istanbul, perhaps a partition, if not in law at least in fact. In all this, among the protagonists, puppeteers, sponsors and comprimari, we can always see a noticeable absence: ours. Syria is our neighbourhood, we were the first to suffer the disastrous consequences of its destabilisation, primarily in terms of refugee flows. We are still the champions of humanitarian aid, but all the big choices fly over our heads. We remain a dwarf of foreign policy and it is all the cheerful group of Member States that is to blame, as always only agrees that we do not agree. The image we give is of a jammed mechanism, internally torn apart and perpetually waiting for an innovative momentum that never arrives. This absence is being paid by 13.5 million Syrians, who need immediate assistance, more than eleven million refugees from outside and inside and entire cities razed to the ground, more than 400 000 dead, an endless humanitarian tragedy. As Europe speaks, Syria burns, and we, instead of mediating and relaunching solutions with all our weight, stand by and watch those who share the ashes.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union is like the image of Mrs Mogherini, invisible or at least absent, and those who spoke about it on her behalf have made a noble report to us, they have told us about humanitarian aid, but the European Union is not just an NGO, at least we thought it was not. There is not only a war waged, but also a very strong war of words. On the one hand, there are even terrorist attacks on Russian territory, and on the other hand it is replicated with just as many threats. Europe is shutting up, Europe has no role. A war of words that is potentially very dangerous, because unimaginable things could happen. Let us remember that, even when the ceasefire plan was being completed in Geneva, there was almost total opposition to the agreement in Washington. Obama was semi-cold about it. At the first opportunity, the American coalition bombed a Syrian army post and the next day accused the Russians, without actually having evidence that they had bombed a humanitarian aid convoy. The reality is that Putin has come to the conclusion that there is no concrete prospect for Russia to reach an agreement with Obama on Syria and therefore Russia's action has resumed with those serious consequences that we have rightly highlighted. It turns out from intelligence sources that ISIS would prepare chemical attacks in Syria, and particularly in east Aleppo, against the populations, but no one in this house is saying that.  The bloodbath in Syria, iraq and Yemen and the chaos in Libya have highlighted one thing: regional powers are unable to resolve the crisis without the decisive intervention of an external force. Europe is absent and is not aware of it. I doubt that the United States can do so at the end of a presidency as exceptional and terrible as Obama's, especially incomprehensible even at this stage. Perhaps we should realize that there is only one power left, Russia, which, unlike what Obama thinks, is not a regional power.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI). Madam President, Syria is not a theatre of operations but a theatre of absurdity. That is why the promises of a ceasefire on both sides have not been implemented, which is why the UN peace talks have proved meaningless. Two nuclear powers, Russia and Iran, support Assad's government. The United Kingdom, France, the Netherlands, Belgium, Denmark and Germany, under the auspices of the US with nuclear weapons, are trying to bring down Assad's government.  Turkey is openly opposed to the YPG, the Syrian Kurds' army, and secretly deals with Daesh and the jihadists who are opponents of everyone else. This Turkey has suddenly been seen as a reliable force and a creditworthy country in the region, because NATO has convinced you, and you are giving it help, money and promises. That's hypocrisy. The Member States of the European Union support a war under the table and lead people to misery, but the Union itself is arguing for the humanitarian aid it gives to refugees, humanitarian aid reaped by NGOs and Soros. The solution is one: work with Russia and fight Daesh, not Syria.

name: Elmar BROK
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr President, Commissioner, Madam Vice-President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for her excellent work. I think we are dealing with several wars: this is the war of ISIS in Iraq and Syria. In order to end this war together, it has been agreed to conduct an 18-month peace process to pacify western Syria, including with the Assad regime in the Geneva negotiations. For years, we have had a veto by Russia against taking action in Syria. We have also decided as the West not to go to Syria – in hindsight, that may have been a mistake. But we are in the situation today that obviously this process of peace-making within Syria with the regime has been destroyed by Russia, because it has conducted this peace process only in order to gain time, to totally win a war – at whatever cost. And that puts a coalition in the fight against ISIS at risk. That is actually the bad background. We are at a kind of turning point. We have always worked – many of us, myself included – to be clear in Ukraine to Russia, but to work with it in a selective cooperation to solve other problems in the world. But now we see in Syria that it develops the same pure will to power as in Ukraine – pure will to power, at whatever cost. This is a change in the situation. These last ten days are a dramatic change in the international situation, which will have a major impact, also in the economic sense.  We must impose sanctions on Russia on technical products and in many other areas, as was the case during the Cold War, so that Russia can no longer develop arms, and at the same time we must be in a position to help the people there. I think it is right that the Commission is trying to prepare humanitarian measures. That is not ridiculous, that is our opportunity! We must not let people rot because we see some people as particularly bad. We have to try to do that. But the one thing is clear, let me conclude by saying that we are the world champions in soft power and the losers in hard power. And soft power only works if you can show hard power.  We are not at the table of negotiations when it comes to war and peace, and i therefore hope that the British will not stop us – as they did at the Conference of Defence Ministers – and that the European Union will finally be able to find the strength to defend our interests in such wars and for peace. , the happiness of people in the regions can fight.  And not this Russia defense – the further to the right, the more for dictator Putin. This is your camp where you are. You have mistrust of anyone who is a democrat and kindness to anyone who is a dictator. This is FPÖ and other politics. Congratulations! (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Liisa JAAKONSAARI
text: blue card question. – Given your important role as Chairman of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, Human Rights, Common Security and Defence Policy, I would really have expected a little sharper criticism of what the Role of the European Union has been in the investigation of crises. Would it be possible to think that the European Union would be pushing for humanitarian intervention, for example, and in what way in the future? You said that we do not have enough hard equipment in place. How, for example, could such already existing standby forces be used to export humanitarian aid?

name: Elmar BROK
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I have said explicitly that, however difficult it may be, we should prepare the humanitarian missions. And perhaps there is still an opportunity, that is our responsibility to the people. At the same time, however, I said that we lack the hard power. And now we have to see if we are prepared to take military action there. Are you ready to send your country's soldiers to Aleppo in the house fight? Only if you answer yes can you ask such questions. That is the question for each of us, whether they want to explain this at home, that this is being done. But I would like to see that, if we could still do that, we could equip the non-radical insurgents with anti-aircraft weapons. I might like that if it is still feasible.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: – Madam President, as the UN Secretary-General was here yesterday, I would like to start by quoting from him. He has recently stated on Aleppo: ‘Imagine the destruction, people with no limbs – blown off, children in terrible pain with no relief, infected, suffering, dying, with nowhere to go and no end in sight. Imagine a slaughterhouse. This is worse. Even a slaughterhouse is more humane’. Tough words, but the most appropriate description of the carnage in Aleppo. Aleppo reminds us of Coventry, Dresden, and Grozny, the last episode where Russia practised the complete destruction of a human community. As we speak, Assad and Russian forces are continuing and intensifying indiscriminate bombing. The brutal character of the war in Syria, in particular in Aleppo, and the use of the most ruthless practices, including the use of chemical weapons, incendiary and bunker bombs, cannot remain unnoticed, and I would say to my colleagues of other political groups: colleagues, silence can be seen today as complicity. We have to act. There is deliberate targeting of civilians, humanitarian workers and hospitals. The water supply has been cut off. These attacks are not only unacceptable, they are crimes in the spirit and the character of international law and of international humanitarian law, and we should treat them as such. So, what to do? There are three issues. I welcome very much the action taken by the European Union and the humanitarian support to Aleppo. The second: I urge the High Representative to work with the UN to win a ceasefire and to allow the convoy of humanitarian aid to get into Aleppo; and thirdly: consider taking immediate sanctions against the governments committing and aiding to commit despicable crimes. One year ago I alerted this House that this could be a Pax Russica. Colleagues, here we are one year later. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: blue-card question. – I have been debating on Syria for five years in this House and have changed my mind. It is clear now that we should have done an awful lot more at the beginning, but sadly that was not the case. Clearly, there is no good side in this horrible proxy civil war between Sunni and Syrian forces and war crimes have been committed on both sides, but Russia now takes the biscuit – it is beyond the pale, using bombings of aid convoys, hospitals, bunker-busting bombs on underground shelters against civilians. These are war crimes. Surely it is time to find ways to overcome the Russian veto in the Security Council by uniting for peace under Resolution 377. We cannot have Russia abuse its position in the Security Council to actually allow it to commit crimes and ...  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: blue-card question. – The question is whether Mr Boştinaru agrees with me. I am asking what his thoughts are in using the Uniting for Peace 377 procedure in the General Assembly to overcome the Russian veto.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: blue-card answer. – I think we should do. We should start thinking of building up political support for such an action, because if we let things continuously develop in this manner, it will be not only be too late, but there will be nobody surviving in Aleppo and there no possibility to win peace in Syria and stability in the Middle East. Europe cannot continue looking from its windows at what is happening in the Middle East.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: – Syria is the failure of a state, of the international community, of world leaders, of humanity.  Aleppo, one of the oldest permanently inhabited places on our planet, is in ruins. Images of shrouds and complete devastation. Abhorrent. The little boy Omran, one of the symbols of terror, and the many other children who go to bed every night without the guarantee of being there in the morning.  The failure of humanity and everyone is a spectator. The United States is clashing with Russia over its ability or inability to make peace. The United Nations has made yet another cry for help. NATO speaks harsh language. It shows the world's desperation over so much barbarism.  The European Union hardly interferes in this debate. Does the fear of shaving prevail? Missing the vision? Is the strategy lacking? The EUR 25 million of emergency humanitarian aid that the EU is now making and the humanitarian actions it is preparing, however laudable and necessary, are only symbolic because they are not stopping the frenzy in Syria's cities. They are not stopping this immense influx of refugees in our direction.  Nevertheless, the European Union has every reason to speak out strongly against the slaughter that Assad is carrying out with the support of Russian bombs among its own people. I therefore also support the initiative of a group of Dutch academics who recently called for recognition of the seriousness of crimes against humanity. To sanction regimes that are complicit and hold individual those responsible to account.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: – Madam President, it is a crying shame that we stand here again today and that the killing of innocent people continues. The suffering is immense.  A small percentage of the total amount of the historically high numbers of refugees have reached Europe. While many speak of a crisis here and the impact on our societies and politics is clear and we pay a high bill for humanitarian aid, it is hard to understand why, even in the light of this immense crisis, we do not see a common position in the Council. Especially now that US—Russian contacts are at an all—time low, we, the EU, must step up. While hospitals, schools and UN humanitarian convoys are bombed and starved, EU leadership to come to a negotiated peace is still lacking. The suffering and cynicism are unprecedented and we know who is responsible. I call on you, the Member States, to adopt impactful sanctions on Russia for their bombardments of innocent people against the UN Security Council resolution. To Mr Obermayr, I would like to say that this is not a matter of bashing Russia; this is a matter of Russia bombing people, and we have to speak out. The UN Secretary—General has called Aleppo ‘worse than a slaughterhouse’. Worse than a slaughterhouse! What happened to ‘never again’? The Council must also give Iran a clear choice. Stop helping Assad’s killing machine or face the consequences. Today, the leaders of France, the UK, Italy, Germany and the US meet on Syria and Berlin, but we need a common position of 28 countries. The world knows, Mr Assad knows and Mr Putin knows that a divided Europe is a weak Europe. It must end. We must show leadership in the face of this extraordinary suffering, or we will pay the price.  (Applause) (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Afzal KHAN
text: blue-card question. – 95% of the civilians that are being killed are being killed by the Syrian regime, aided and abetted by Iran and Syria. So would it not be appropriate that we should be asking for sanctions against all three?

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you for your question. I do not know whether you heard my statement clearly, but I called on EU sanctions, unity by the Member States for sanctions on Russia, and I also urged them to leverage their weight vis—à—vis Iran to force it to make a clear choice whether to stop the killing machine of Assad and their support thereof or face the consequences. I think my statement was clear, and it seems to be in line with what you are thinking, but we look forward to continuing this discussion. The most important thing is that the Council has to stop being divided, show leadership and adopt a common position.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, where has Europe been in the negotiations between the United States and Russia? Very simple, absent, like Mrs. Mogherini. What have you done to improve an agreement that was insufficient? The short-lived and failed truce is the result of a lack of ambition and political will.  An immediate cessation of bombing and the opening of permanent humanitarian corridors is urgent. We must definitely fight the gangrene of jihadism. But let's get out of the false dilemma of choice between jihadism, imperialist interference or local dictators.  It is the Syrian people who have to lead their future and Europe's role should be to support and promote democratic processes starring Syrian civil society, as well as to defend the experiences of resistance and direct democracy of the Kurdish people in Rojava.  Finally, Europe cannot continue to build walls or pay the Turkish gendarme to control our borders, or stop attending to its duties to refugees. If we keep doing that, we're complicit in their deaths. Accomplices, that's who we are.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Ban Ki-moon speaks of a slaughterhouse, Doctors Without Borders of a death zone, when they describe the situation in Syria, in Aleppo. However, there is no prospect of a no-fly zone, and after the failure of the recent ceasefire, there is no realistic chance that the killing will end in the foreseeable future. On the contrary, all modest hopes for a ceasefire have been dashed. Meanwhile, war crimes or human rights violations continue to be committed, and none of the parties to the conflict currently fear being held accountable. Prisoners are tortured, tortured and killed in government prisons and in opposition militia detention centres. What options does the EU currently have, apart from humanitarian aid and the call for effective peace negotiations? For negotiations to resume, the EU should exert both diplomatic and economic pressure, especially on the Assad regime's main allies: Russia and Iran. Pressure must also be exerted on the states in the region, which in particular support Islamist armed groups. These are the Gulf States and Turkey. As long as there is no end to the violence, however, the EU must also stop its policy of foreclosure at the external borders, which is driving to the death of those who wanted to escape the massacres of the Assad henchmans and the terror of radical Islamists. Not only because we owe it to these people – the war in Syria has long since reached a dimension in which it also significantly determines future developments in Europe.

name: David COBURN
text: – Madam President, we got rid of Saddam. We got rid of Gaddafi. Neither went particularly well, did it? Now you want to get rid of Assad. He may be unpalatable, but at least he ran a secular state protecting minorities, both religious and political. The EU seems to want to change this for an Islamic state. We have a common enemy with the Russians in the potential theocratic governments in the Middle East. We should work with the Russians, rather than against them, to combat the medieval religious anarchy ripping through the Middle East, forcing refugees across the Mediterranean, which in turn disrupts our cities with terrorism and spreads social problems throughout Europe. The EU should stop its absolutely ludicrous posturing and get behind NATO and the Great Powers. There are 400 000 dead in Syria; 11 million displaced; 10 000 refugees picked up in the last two days. Behave responsibly, for a change. Mogherini has zero power. Get behind the Great Powers and NATO, and stop posturing for political reasons.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: Madam President, the city of Aleppo has been cut in two for four years and is in the news, but unfortunately still one-way. Every day in East Aleppo, several hospitals are destroyed. The last doctor in Aleppo was killed, for the 20th time, and bakeries are the main target of the Syrian air force. On the other hand, the shells that are constantly raining down on West Aleppo, which is populated, I remind you, of more than 1.5 million inhabitants, compared to 200,000 people in the east, fall into general indifference. Little Arman (12 years old), young singer Zila or national swimming champion Mireille were all killed by these shells in the name of American fashion democracy. Would a life then be less valuable to the east or west, depending on whether one is on the right or the wrong side of the front line? In recent weeks, the Syrian Arab Army seems able to liberate east Aleppo from the grip of Islamist terrorist groups. So it is not too late to change our position and finally join those who really fight the terror of the jihadists on a daily basis. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation)

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: "blue card" question. "Mrs Arnautu, would I like to know if your party has already obtained the second loan from the Russian banks?"

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: Mr Preda, I still thought that the debate was a little higher than your question, which I find perfectly stupid and inappropriate. Therefore, I will not answer it, and I find it quite offensive in terms of the situation and the subject we are dealing with today.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I really wonder when I follow the debate today about where I am. They are all intelligent people and should actually be able to hear both sides. Instead, I hear Atlanticians here again, as they come from the PPE- and Mr Brok in particular – Mr Preda. What have we heard today? Mr Brok even wants to give anti-aircraft weapons to the terrorists. You have to ask yourself what that means: flying fists. Until now, flying fists have always been outlawed internationally, never passed on to terrorists, because they can also shoot down any civilian aircraft in Paris, Munich or Brussels. Such a release of the weapon for the people you can't control: impossible! After all, there are no more moderate rebels. I have been to Syria twice – the last time this year – and I have convinced myself that the leadership there has long since been taken over by the Al-Nusra Front, by the jihadists. And you want to give the weapon to such killers? Try to inform yourself objectively, and keep in mind that you do not believe everything that the United States of America is telling us. Because they also reported in the Iraq war that huge weapons of mass destruction were there. They have hired a civil company – an advertising company – to make war lies. Why do you believe everything the Americans say and reject objective reporting from the Russians? Stop promoting the international genocide center of the United States!

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: – Madam President, thank you, Minister, for the information you have provided us on the situation in Syria, including your efforts these days on humanitarian aid for Aleppo. Indeed, the situation there is particularly serious. It is the second city in the country. Indiscriminate attacks launched by Syrian regime forces, with Russian air support, are producing numerous civilian casualties, including a very high number of children. We are, as has already been said, faced with a real humanitarian catastrophe, where even hospitals are not being respected. The necessary political solution to the conflict is not moving forward. Even the Russian-American concertation, which had achieved some ephemeral truce a few months ago, does not. Ladies and gentlemen, it is already more than five years of conflict and war. There are many deaths, destruction, suffering, many displaced persons and refugees. We are also in a conflict as fierce as it is complex, because in the war in Syria, in addition to the presence of Dáesh and other terrorist groups, several lines of confrontation intersect; for example, Shiites against Sunnis, Iran against Saudi Arabia, secularists against Islamic radicals, and much more. In this complex situation, with such profound divergences, the margin left to international diplomacy is scarce. The Damascus regime and its allies now seem to be opting for the military solution, as Kerry denounced yesterday in Brussels. The United Nations must redouble its efforts to find a political solution and first and fore all a ceasefire. Permanent members of the Council have a special responsibility, in particular Russia, which has played a key military role for twelve months. Mr Representative of the Council, I encourage you and Mrs Mogherini to continue their humanitarian aid efforts. There is also a need to continue intensive dialogue with the international actors most involved in the conflict, including regional ones, and to assist the United Nations in its peace efforts. These days, at the Security Council, France and Spain are drafting a resolution calling for an immediate ceasefire, with an international supervisory mechanism. The ceasefire is the largest of the emergencies for Aleppo, so tormented by the bombings of recent weeks. We must all help with that goal.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: – Madam President, although there are more than enough and well-founded reasons for the United States, the United Kingdom and France to rise from the Security Council, the truth is that there is only one negotiated exit by the parties in Syria. And it's more urgent than ever.  The bombardment on Aleppo will enter history through the same shameful gate through which Dresden, Guernica or Sarajevo entered. In Syria, all the rules of the international system and international humanitarian law have exploded along with anti-bunker bombs.  It's pretty clear: you have to put your guns down! We have to stop the planes! Except those who are able to bring humanitarian aid to the besieged population. Humanitarian corridors must be opened, and at least the European Union should be effective. We have to negotiate, even though we're probably in a crime scene against humanity.  It is clear that Russia is ready to meet Al-Asad's military agenda, but it is also true that the United States must be aware that an order in that region of the world other than that based on permanent and sound peace is impossible.  The European Union must continue to support, yes, the efforts of the United Nations, and get much more decisively involved, because there is only a glimmer of hope, only one, which is to re-negotiate and, of course, to help the civilian population that bleeds out every day in Aleppo.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Dear! Twelve days ago, I returned from a country that is syria's neighbour, Jordan. I visited syrian refugee camps there. And it is a good sign of the European Parliament that it is not only sending a mission there, but during this session we have a second debate about Syria, because we have been talking about education in Syria. The European Union, we, are giving big money there. And that's what we're different from Russia, which is bombing Syria. We give money there to Syrian refugees. That's a really important difference. That's the first thing.  And secondly, ladies and country, history repeats itself not only with farce. Let us recall what happened after 9/11, 2001, after the attacks on the World Trade Center, when Russia tried to portray itself to the West as an ally in the fight against Islamists. This is the same scenario. Let us not be fooled. They treat this matter absolutely instrumentally. Until recently, they had adopted Hamas at home in the Kremlin. I really appeal here for prudence and sobriety.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: – Madam President, Mr Korčok, as regards Mr Putin, this is a question of a cult of power. This is what you will be told by the Russian opposition – what remains of it – whether it is left, centre or right. This is what you will hear. It was about Georgia, then it was Donbas, Crimea. It is Syria today, and we can speculate on what it is going to be tomorrow. All that is an instrument, an instrument for the recovery of Russia and of Putin. It is an instrument of domestic politics. It is an instrument for increasing influence, and it is an instrument for dividing the European Union and separating us from our allies. This is what it is about. Mr Korčok, if you have a debate in the European Council, two out of the three main issues are related. Migration, where we are heavily affected. Of course what we are seeing today is again intentional. This is intentional because this will produce further migration, which will of course primarily affect Europe. The second issue is the strategy on Russia. What we will also expect is that in this framework, we will see at least the basic points of a strategy on Syria. It is badly needed. If that does not come out of the European Council, then I am afraid this is a failure. And what is it about? Well, we should be at the table. You have said yourself, we are the biggest donor. It is high time that we are a part of the negotiations around the main table and that we really have the hard force. That is another important question: unless we really address the question of our military capacities, integrated ones, we will never be partners.  The final two remarks. A no-fly zone for sure. Sanctions, as has been said, not just against Russia, but also against those that are an active part of that conflict. Finally, as I have said, we need to build our own capacities, our own capabilities, our own abilities, including political and defence. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: James CARVER
text: blue-card question. – You call for greater military powers for the European Union. Don’t you just realise that all you are doing is actually further complicating this tangled web, and don’t the various different political common interests and foreign policy interests within Syria from very different actors just further complicate the situation?

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: blue-card answer. – No, I do not see any association and connection at all with complicating the situation. I fully respect that you are on the way out from the EU. I respect that you do not see any need or prospect for the defence capabilities of the European Union. I fully respect that, but it goes without saying that, without those capabilities, we will not be in a position to really tackle the core of the problem. I have not heard from either you or your colleagues about Russia’s inhumanity.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: – Madam President: a terrible picture of children murdered in Yemen. There is almost never talk of it here, nor in the great press: white phosphorus, cluster bombs; but of course, they're Saudi friends. We are concerned, or everyone says they are concerned about what is happening in Syria, but some worry after saying that Al-Nusra, i.e. Al-Qaeda, was doing well in Syria, or after training, funding and tolerating terrorist groups operating in Syria but in Europe as well. We are immersed in a one-way propaganda campaign that presents us with a single culprit, but always blames the civilian victims of friends, all not to point out that the failure of the last truce was the cause of the U.S. bombardment of Syrian army positions in Deir ez-Zor, for the attack on humanitarian corridors by these terrorist organizations , or the abduction of civilians to be human shields, by those same terrorist organizations. The United States must be required to resume cooperation with Russia and to promote an immediate ceasefire and a table with all non-terrorist political actors.

name: James CARVER
text: – Madam President, Turkey’s intervention in this increasingly complicated war is at the same time both welcome and dangerous and not all as it seems. Kobanî became a recognised symbol of resistance, with brave Kurdish forces drawing a line and pushing Islamic states away from the Turkish border, thus creating a zone of relative safety. As we know, their endeavours were repaid with Turkish bombing raids and armoured convoys. Now we have a key ally fighting Western—backed Kurdish groups and moderate opposition militias using the fight against Islamic State as a smokescreen to spread its military campaign against the Kurds into Syria. Then there are the traditional Russian and Middle Eastern foreign policy interests to consider. Peace cannot be secured and the inhumane actions dealt with until this illogical web of alliances is properly untangled for the benefit of humanity as a whole. The longer we take, the more the Syrian people suffer.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her To mr Brok and his friends, the fanatical transatlantic colleague is consistently opposed to any military terror against the civilian population, against UN institutions, whatever. Whether it comes from Russians, Americans, Germans or Italians, I reject and condemn it, unlike those who seem to ignore the fact that there are very inglorious events here – from Turkey, from Saudi Arabia, from America – which obviously cannot be addressed here. And I'm going to address them. For example, Turkey: Turkey is invading Syria in violation of international law in order to establish stability there, in order to protect the population with the Euphrates Shield action. This is a clear madness if you ignore it simply because it is a NATO partner of Germany. Obviously, there is no fool's freedom here. The fact that Turkey has been doing good business with ISIS for years is evidently forgotten today. Mr President, you have not even been careful before, so you are now also calm. I would just like to propose one thing: let us look wherever something happens! Let us not be blind in the left eye! Then Europe will really regain strength and be taken seriously, if we also stand united accordingly and take care that the states around us do not go up in flames.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support In addition to immediate humanitarian aid, the European Union is responsible for a strong contribution to the political solution. As Deputy High Representative Korčok said, no one here is a white or black actor. This is why it is necessary to mediate between regional actors such as Turkey, Iran and Saudi Arabia and between global players such as the US and Russia. However, what the People's Party's spokesperson said is not the solution: it is up to the EU to work with the US to take action against Russia. Well, the European Union has articulated how it wants to be a major player in global affairs.
