This cannot be solved by set a single task for the European Union to function as an auxiliary team of the United States.

name: David McALLISTER
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Like many other members, i find it very difficult to put the situation in Aleppo into words. Ban Ki-moon, as we have heard several times today, calls what is happening a war crime. The UN envoy for Syria, Staffan de Mistura, calls the situation in the city the worst humanitarian tragedy since World War II. And the UN Emergency Relief Coordinator Stephen O'Brien explains the daily reality with the words: "bloodbath, butchery, abominations". And just as previous speakers – most of the House – have also mentioned this: Russia has repeatedly claimed to be seeking a political solution for Syria. So far, Moscow has not allowed these words to be followed by deeds; on the contrary, neither medical facilities nor humanitarian aid is spared. I find the Russian behaviour outrageous. It is inhumane, and I do not understand why there are still approaches to understanding from the right of this House.  It is a good signal that Parliament's resolution supports the important work of the International Support Group for Syria and the work of the UN envoy. This conflict can only be resolved politically. That is why all parties must return to the table and continue negotiations within the support group. A ceasefire to provide the civilian population with the necessities must be the short-term goal. The European Union could and should play an important mediating role in these negotiations. For this we urgently need European unity and determination. The issue must be on the agenda of the bodies.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her For a long time, it has not been about the concerns that were at the beginning of this conflict: freedom and democracy and a brutal regime that has fought for its survival. Syria is the scene of proxy wars and the enforcement of geopolitical interests. It is about the very existential: it is about the struggle for survival of our civilisation. The brutal terror of Da'esh spreads terror and fear, the systematic starvation of cities like Madaya is reminiscent of the Middle Ages, and the continuing bombardment of Aleppo provides us with unimaginable images of destruction. The effects of this war have long since ceased to be limited in Syria, and the many refugees remind us of this conflict on a daily basis. It is in Europe's interest to end this nightmare. In order to do this, it is necessary for the Member States to finally give the High Representative a clear mandate and not to pursue their individual interests. Europe must speak with one voice, determined and unambiguous, and it must choose the language of humanity, as Mogherini and Stylianides have prepared with their humanitarian initiative for Aleppo. However, this initiative must not be confined to Aleppo. It is also up to those cities that are still starved to be looked after. And we need to create humanitarian corridors so that the injured and vulnerable can be evacuated directly from the threatened areas. Finally, we should also support those regions in northern Syria and Rodshava that have freed themselves from Da'esh, where people want to return, and now feel abandoned by us.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – It is quite obvious that the conflict in Syria is suffering first and for all the citizens of that country and, secondly, the nations of the European Union, which have suffered from the unprecedented migrant wave caused by this war. But it seems that no one in the chamber seriously rebukes the criminal behavior of two other countries other than those mentioned that are involved in this conflict, namely Saudi Arabia and Turkey. For those who do not know, to remind or say, the two dictatorial regimes in Riyadh and Ankara are directly involved in war crimes in Syria – through military occupation and invasion and through the support of man-made barbaric groups, terrorist organizations such as Islamic State and en Nusra.  Colleagues, the serious hypocrisy is someone pretending to be concerned about the victims of the war, but to continue to sell arms to Riyadh and pay bribes and ransoms to Ankara. One-sidedness, propaganda, is detrimental to understanding this war and finding the right solution. It is high time that everyone in this chamber understands that neither Turkish nor Saudi nor Russian interests in Syria are the interests of either Syrians or European Union citizens.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her At the beginning of the conflict, the then German Minister of Defence, Thomas de Maiziére, said: we are keeping ourselves out of here, we are doing nothing, there could otherwise be a conflagration if we Europeans get involved. We now have the conflagration: Turkey, Russia, various European countries, Iran, Saudi Arabia – all are involved in this conflict. And this conflict is now the biggest humanitarian disaster in a long time. As Europeans, we are powerless before we, americans and Russians are negotiating over our heads. We have delegated the solution to the United Nations. Mr de Mistura is an excellent man, but where is Europe? Absent, completely absent! That is why I can only support what has been said here: it cannot go on like this. We need a European foreign policy capability, including a defence component. We need a no-fly zone for Aleppo. Humanitarian corridors are needed, and a political solution is needed in which Europe, under the leadership of Mrs Mogherini, is seriously cooperating. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr Lambsdorff, we have just heard that Europe is one of the world's largest arms suppliers. "We keep ourselves out" – do you really call this a stay out of it, when you are actually actively involved as the main supplier of weapons?

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Oh, Mr Gericke, I actually know you as a more serious partner in the debate. The weapons of the Syrian army come mainly from Russia. Nor have we delivered anything to Iran. The Americans are arming themselves. The English and French missions there are flown with their own equipment. This question really does not matter here at all.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: – Madam President, the war in Syria has raged for over five years now, but despite being an evident threat to European security, it would seem the EU is determined to continue flip-flopping on this issue. There is no better example of this than the recent multi-billion-euro deal approved by the EU to supply Iran Air with up to 118 modern Airbus commercial aircraft. This is an airline associated with accusations of making over 200 flights this year alone to bring military communications equipment, strategic arms and military personnel to supply and support Hezbollah and the Assad regime, both of which are sanctioned by the EU. We are now in a position where European-built aircraft could be used to supply arms and equipment to forces ranged against NATO. That is why I am today calling for the UK intervention in Syria to stop. The EU is simply out of its depth in dealing with this crisis in Syria, despite wanting ever greater involvement. It is time to learn the lessons of Afghanistan, Iraq and Libya, and allow better-qualified actors to solve this most complex of problems.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: Madam President, Mr Weber was concerned this morning about Syria. He spoke against Russia and spoke of his intervention in Syria on behalf of the Americans. He was not speaking on behalf of the French or Italians in his group, which were more nuanced, but on behalf of the German MPs subject to the interests of the United States. He did not speak on behalf of the Syrian people and the Christians of Aleppo encircled by Al-Qaeda, currently delivered by the legitimate forces of Syria, and the only country that intervenes legally in that country. Let him listen to the bishop of Aleppo, who claims to be a Christian-social. Mr. Weber, are you concerned about the sanctions against Syria, which increase the price of wheat by 300% and rice by 650%, and the health system destroyed by those sanctions? The Christians of the East will remind you that we must liberate Aleppo besieged by Daesh and Al-Qaeda in the east, that is what Syria and Syria's allies are doing.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: Mr President, Minister, ladies and gentlemen, the humanitarian situation in Syria is dramatic in Aleppo, but also in other parts of the country.  My intention here is not, as some do, to take a hemiplegic look at history, to see only the crimes of some and not those of others. None of the crimes of civilians is excusable, wherever it comes from, but who could seriously say that the bombing of some would be less destructive than those of others? To stop these crimes, we must first make a good diagnosis. What has been happening in Syria since 2011? The truth is that Syria is a major front of Sunni jihad. It is radical Sunni Islam that is destroying this country, and it is doing so not only with the support of the Sunni monarchies of the Gulf, but also because of our own foreign policy mistakes. We repeat, in fact, in Syria the mistake made in Libya. We do not want to see that allowing Sunni jihad to destroy this authoritarian regime is to let it destroy the nation-state and that, without the nation-state, there is nothing but chaos.  The great paradox of the Western world is that its policy supports in the Middle East the enemy it claims to fight in Europe and which strikes it with terrorism. Fighting Islamic terrorism involves forming a grand coalition of civilizations, which means working with people who have neither our values nor our methods.  Realpolitik is not a defeat, ladies and gentlemen, it is a victory of intelligence, the only one that can produce the defeat of Islamic totalitarianism.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: – That is right, Minister, as you said at the beginning, Syria is the biggest humanitarian catastrophe of our time and it is getting worse. Unfortunately, the European Union, Minister, has no plan for what to do to stop the violence. It is a pity here that we hear from the extreme left and the extreme right the voice of one of the parties responsible for the crash.  The delivery of humanitarian aid is necessary, but not enough. The European Union must have the authority and the power to impose, together with our partners, a plan for peace and an end to barbarism. Syrians must be given hope for the future, for a possible life after this terrible war in Syria.  Until we find a way to prevent the causes of migratory pressure in Syria, the pressure on our external borders will continue.  Europe must speak with a single voice and that voice must be heard.  The Syrian crisis, as well as terrorism, does not remain closed within the relevant borders. Therefore, in order to successfully address these challenges, we need a common European security and defence architecture that complements our commitment to NATO and a pan-European intelligence exchange. The majority of European citizens want this to be a European Union security and defence policy, more shared defence capabilities, joint projects, joint armaments and training of servicemen, European peacekeeping missions, common headquarters and European forces. At the same time, a common migration policy and revision of the Dublin Regulation is also needed, which does not correspond to modern migration dynamics. The decision to deal with the migration crisis must be taken in a spirit of conscious responsibility and unity. Solidarity is a two-way street. It cannot be just countries at the European Union's external borders that bear the brunt of unprecedented migratory flows.

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: Mr President, Minister, ladies and gentlemen, yes, today the city of Aleppo is hell, hell on earth. Hospitals, schools, refugee camps, women, men, children, nothing and no one is spared the deluge of fire that the regime is killing this city. In the face of this violence and massacres, unfortunately we still have to say that the armed solution is a pipe dream. Between pro-Assad forces, rebel movements, Al-Qaeda-affiliated groups such as the Al-Nusra Front, the Kurds, Daesh, or the thinly veiled presence of Iranians and Hezbollah militias, who can still believe that a unilateral solution is possible? Now the urgent need is to provide humanitarian support to Aleppo. Mrs Federica Mogherini decided to propose to mobilise 25 million euros.  Then, the perspective is the sterile head-to-head exit between the United States and Russia. In this respect, Europe has a role to play: we have been the driving forces in the restoration of relations with Iran, so let us use this channel of discussion to put pressure on a key player on the Syrian ground.

name: Mirosław PIOTROWSKI
text: – Today Our Parliament is discussing and tomorrow it will adopt a resolution on the escalation of the conflict in Syria, particularly in Aleppo. In the prepared resolution, we state that the European Union is one of the largest donors of humanitarian aid to people fleeing violence and destruction. I believe that this assistance should not only continue to flow there, but should be increased. The governments of central and eastern European countries, in particular the Polish, have announced an even stronger commitment within the framework of the proposed flexible solidarity. In the third paragraph of our resolution, we call on all parties to the conflict to stop attacking vulnerable civilians and infrastructure. That is why we need to further, realistically support the UN's efforts in this area.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: As everyone has said, this is an absolutely unprecedented humanitarian tragedy unfolding in Aleppo, for the hundreds of thousands of people living under the bombs, throughout the country, for the millions of displaced people, for the millions of hungry people, it is hell, sometimes, as Gilles Pargneaux also said, for refugees fleeing Syria.  This situation cannot last. I don't think the U.S.-Russian head-to-head can have the key to all of this. As we have seen, Putin's role is in strategy. He basically wants to defeat the regime, to move forward on the spot before any peace negotiation. We cannot let that happen. That is why I am telling you that there is only one power that we do not hear enough, and that is not in the game, is Europe. Let's decide to exist, let's decide to speak with one voice!  All this is happening on our doorstep. It is now up to us to act, to have a vision, to have a perspective, to resume language with all the regional powers, namely Turkey, Iran, Saudi Arabia to try, finally, to find a political solution to this major crisis.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, what more can we say. I have actually heard a great deal of hypocrisy from the Council today, which should know that there is a fundamental rule in today's geopolitical framework: voids are created and filled, either we do or others do. If Europe is unable to exercise its protagonism in the Syrian affair, so do others, as are Russia and the United States. And if this happens to us there is only one role left, which is that of spectators, able to watch the Syrian game in the stands, as we have seen, dividing between fans. I would like the Council to ask itself about this. But from what I have heard today he does not seem to be able to do so. We are not doing what is necessary and it would be our duty to do so. Our absence will weigh like a boulder on our conscience, it will weigh on a European ruling class that can only have a place secured in hell.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: – Mr President, Syria has long since become a geopolitical battleground between the West and the anti-Western coalition, best represented by Russia and Iran. That's why Russia keeps the regime that way. However, we still have the so-called Islamic State as literally an anti-civilization movement, and we also have an anti-Assad opposition, which unfortunately often consists of radicals who are not very different from fanatics like The Islamic State or al-Qaeda or the Taliban, and our task is to establish a sequence of steps that we want to achieve, that is, both defeating the Islamic State and not allowing Russia to become a geopolitical hegemon in the region. , so as not to allow the radical Islamisation of the country.  We have not made much progress on this so far and we have not been able to properly evaluate these priorities.

name: Sandra KALNIETE
text: – Mr President, the brutal crimes of the Assad-Putin regime against the civilian population of Syria are abominable. Erasing Aleppo from the surface of the earth and the indiscriminate aerial bombing of thousands of civilians is absolutely intolerable. There is no doubt about Russia’s core responsibility for these criminal actions. Therefore, the question of lifting any European sanctions against Russia should be off the table. Just the opposite, these crimes warrant more measures at the EU level, targeted at individuals and entities enabling the crimes against the Syrian people.  I am sure that Russian intelligence chiefs, whom some colleagues wanted to take off the EU sanctions list a few months ago, are among them. Like it or not, sanctions are one of the very few instruments the EU has in this situation. We do not have either the military capability, or the political will, to seriously project power which would help to stabilise Syria. Our leverages are economic and legal, so we should use them. Make no mistake, the reason for Russia’s intervention in Syria is obvious.  Europe has become a target of a weapon of mass migration. Bombing hospitals and marketplaces drives people out of Syria and creates more waves of refugees. Putin knows too well that sooner rather than later these refugees will undermine stability within our societies. His main target has been, and remains, us, the West – our values, our institutions. It is now up to us to be resilient and respond to this challenge.

name: Arne LIETZ
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I strongly condemn the deliberate violation of international humanitarian law by Assad and his allies, especially – as so often mentioned today – by Russia. It is a war crime to deliberately bomb hospitals and other civilian facilities, as we have seen in recent days. Nevertheless, the channels of dialogue must remain open, because without Russia there will be no political solution.  But I see here, in particular, the duty of the EU Member States to finally reach a common position and strategy for dealing with all the central parties to the conflict in Syria. These include Iran, Saudi Arabia, Turkey, the various rebel groups and Da'esh. Only if we find a common EU strategy can Federica Mogherini play a constructive, diplomatic role for the EU, as she has successfully demonstrated in the Iran negotiations. But the EU must also act in the short term. I therefore warmly welcome the humanitarian initiative of the High Representative and the Commissioner for Humanitarian Aid, which aims to provide aid to 130 000 Syrians.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: – Mr President, the situation in Western and Southern Syria is breaking down. It should be in the highest interest of the EU to help and stabilise Northern and Eastern Syria, alongside the efforts of the US and France in those areas, as some stability and peace is already there.  The US and France cooperate with the Syrian Democratic Forces, and together they are successful in defeating ISIS. They are bringing stability, freedom and democratic, multi-ethnic governance in the liberated regions under the flag of the Democratic Self-Administration of Rojava. The EU should put pressure on the Kurdistan Regional Government to open the Fishkhabour border from the KRG into Rojava so that aid, trade, media and political exchange can come in freely. This one move by the EU would already help millions of people. It is a huge scandal that the KRG is blocking, for example, medicine from reaching children in need. Finally, the EU and the Self-Administration can work together to give aid to the Syrian indigenous people. This will prevent them from running as refugees to Europe.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: – Mr President, all these years and even now, people from Syria have been asking for certain elementary things. They are not just asking for resolutions that deplore or condemn. Human beings in this man—made hell are asking for no-fly zones and safety areas, in addition to humanitarian aid. A no-fly zone over Aleppo immediately – that is the solution. Russia has proved not to be part of the solution, but part of the problem. Putin’s interest clearly is not to fight ISIS, but to support his crony, the Syrian dictator. But the main problem is that you cannot solve such a crisis with the help of people responsible for war crimes, barrel bombs, poison gas, levelling hospitals and killing – just now – hundreds of children. The result is an Orwellian understanding of peace. In the words of John Kerry, ‘Where they make a desert, they call it peace’. The crucial problem for the EU now is that we have still not decided to do something concrete and have left the scene open for destructive forces that care only about their own self-interest. My colleague, Mr Telička, this morning told us that we have shown too many yellow cards – I would add including the one Mr Obama waved three years ago. What we need now is a red card: that is strategic sanctions against Russia and calling this thing what it is – a crime against humanity.

name: Kati PIRI
text: – What has been happening in Aleppo over the last two weeks is nothing but hell on earth. After breaking the ceasefire, the Syrian government, together with the Russian military, deliberately bombed civilians, shelled humanitarian convoys and thrianized hospitals.  UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon said earlier this week: "The constant bombing of Aleppo is a war crime. The situation is worse than in a slaughterhouse."  War crimes must be punished. Justice requires that those responsible for the crimes in Syria be prosecuted and brought to justice. In addition to continuing to search for ever smaller openings for dialogue, the EU must also draw a clear line. Those responsible for these atrocities must be put on an EU sanctions list immediately. I hope that the Council will come to the same conclusion next week.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by We have listened to a lot of different views, different opinions, and I have the impression that we are more concerned with identifying who is more to blame, even more so that someone does not benefit politically if peace is made. Mr. Lambsdorff beautifully said that there is a fire here. It follows from this fire that some of it is heating up, some of the fire is admired, and what Mr van Weidenholzer said is closest to me, namely urgent action, humanitarian aid, but well addressed. Corridors must be created and maintained, our presence should also be created and intensified, and we should think about how to save people and how to spare the potential in Syria that could live its own lives after the end of the war.  I am very much in favour of those views which seek to strengthen support for Mrs Mogherini to represent our interests and to contribute effectively to the resolution of this war.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: – Mr President, the situation in Syria is the world’s worst humanitarian catastrophe since the Second World War. We must now establish a no-fly zone to defend Syrian civilians. Yes, Daesh in Syria is plotting against our security in Europe, but Daesh is only the secondary cancer. Assad’s forces are the primary cancer. They are responsible for 500 000 civilian deaths. Assad has largely refrained from attacking Daesh-controlled territory and also cooperated with Daesh in order to weaken the moderate opposition. Russia is responsible for thousands of deaths since its direct intervention in Syria. The cessation of hostilities a few weeks ago has now collapsed, as Assad and Russia have launched a new onslaught on Aleppo.  Iran, on the one hand, seeks external investment to support a sanction-hit economy, but on the other hand it is projecting power with harmful consequences for the region. By helping Assad it is supporting the Yazidi Government of our time.  I am ashamed that the EU Council cannot agree on a common EU way forward.  Europeans want sanctions against Assad’s regime, Russia and Iran.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: S&D). Mr President, what is the human record so far: more than 300 000 dead, with 15 000 of them children, eleven million refugees and, as we speak, two million people who do not have access to running water. Also, the reality is that Syria has been destroyed by the United States of America, some European countries, the Assad regime and Turkey, which has invaded Syria and is currently continuing its own operations on the pretext of hitting ISIS, when in fact it is after the Kurds. We must also admit that there was no reaction on the part of the European Union and that the reaction came only after Russia's strike in Syria and after the terrorist attacks in Europe. What is the point at the moment: a ceasefire, so that we can send humanitarian aid to those who are suffering.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I share what the debate expresses here. The blood is in the body when you think of the horrors that the people of Syria are experiencing. Bombings of hospitals, children killed, attacked, tortured. Families desperately trying to escape, children washed ashore on beaches in flight towards a safer future.  At the same time, two of the main players in the conflict are now withdrawing and have suspended their ceasefire talks. Then an even greater responsibility rests with us, to put an end to the carnage and, in the long term, to have a sustainable future and peace. As one of the largest donors of humanitarian aid in Syria, the EU must be much stronger and more consistent and put pressure on all parties to bring about a new ceasefire. I would like to support the calls for an EU strategy in place that calls on the Commission to step up its work and press for a strategy that has a real role for Syria.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: " Mr. President, the Syrian people have suffered tremendous suffering for more than 5 years in this terrible conflict that continues to flaming. Hundreds of thousands of dead and millions displaced expect stronger reaction and concrete action from us. I am particularly concerned by the latest developments in the Aleppo area that point to the reluctance of the warring parties to accept a peaceful solution to stopping the conflict. In doing so, those who are the weakest - children - perish. Or those who have different religious beliefs - Christians. Destroying hospitals, disabling humanitarian work and killing innocent civilians must stop. It's about living people.  The situation in Syria is a global problem in the settlement that the West has failed to address. The EU needs to become more involved in efforts to achieve sustainable peace and take concrete actions to address this humanitarian and cultural catastrophe. It is not enough to send money, food or water. It is important to stop Daesh and al-Nusra and ensure peace. Today. Because tomorrow will be too late.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the situation in Syria is now catastrophic. The images that come to us from Aleppo and its devastation weigh on everyone's consciences. The figures are disturbing: 96 children killed in a week, 275 000 people under siege, at least 50 killed in the bombings in the last few hours. The tregues only announced now hold up only a few hours and then we continue to shoot and bomb without taking into account schools, hospitals and helpless civilians.  Europe cannot and must not remain silent in the face of this carnage, it must exercise its international leadership and lay down the conditions for an immediate ceasefire and for the opening of humanitarian corridors. The situation is serious and at the same time complex as a result of the overlapping of various tensions. A political solution is needed and Europe must play an incisive role in reopening the negotiations and in putting an end to this huge humanitarian tragedy. For this to happen, the Member States must first of all allow the European Union to speak with one voice.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, with the end of the ceasefire, the situation in Syria is critical. Daesh must first and foremost be defeated in order to achieve peace. But the defeat of Daesh depends directly on the end of the civil war in Syria and on the launch of a sustainable peace process, a process that is respected by all sides and strictly restricts external interventions in the fight against Daesh. As the war in Syria continues, however, refugee flows into Europe will continue. In Syria, Turkey is, as we know, playing a dirty role, strengthening Daesh and hitting the Kurds. Erdoğan's aim is to overturn the Treaty of Lausanne, as he said, threatening Greece and attacking the Greek Aegean islands and the sovereignty of my country. But the sultan should know that his threats do not pass. But, Mr Korčok, representative of the Presidency, what position does the Presidency take on this serious issue? Will he let Erdoğan threaten Greece and the European Union?

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: – It's dramatic. I think everyone here has already said it today: the attacks on the convoys, the chemical weapons.  The images won't let go of me. Last week in a Belgian newspaper on the front page: a mother in a seat, covered in dust, with her two children pressed by her side, dead. Syrian children as young as five have never experienced a minute without war in their lives. They deserve a life without violence.  Europe also needs to intervene, ladies and gentlemen of the Council. The instability at the external borders, the migration, the rise of religious extremism. We have to step in. Now let Europe show its leadership. It has been said here: install that no-fly zone, stop the bombing, let the humanitarian aid that we are now giving, fight the terrorists, but above all: also consult with America and Russia and build that European defence union. Let's take that step. Let us stop trusting others. It's been enough. Please do something.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: – Mr President, the resolution omits that this is a war between a legitimate government in defence of the integrity of its territory and armed armies trained by western powers. Omit that it was the United States that violated the ceasefire agreed on September 26.  Everyone is certainly recalling a resolution in everything similar to the one adopted in this House on Libya. By then the Libyan government had ceased to serve the interests of the same Western powers that created and armed the militias that destroyed a country and which is now being saqueled.  Let's stop hypocrisy. We call for an end to economic and diplomatic sanctions against the Syrian government. What matters is that the rebels cease to arm and form, replacing the weapons with dialogue and helping to build a political solution that will allow the end of the war, allow humanitarian aid and create conditions for the reconstruction of a country that has already suffered too much from this conflict.

name: Tatjana ŽDANOKA
text: – Mr President, I want to address also the draft resolution on Syria by six political groups since I find it one-sided and prejudiced.  You mention especially Russia and the Assad regime but do not mention Daesh and other radical forces and armed groups. You make an impression that Assad’s troops and the Air Force of Russia, which has come there at an official request are at war not with terrorists, but with some phantoms. The losses of the civilian population are awful. Nobody denies it. In July, together with colleagues, I visited a hospital in Damascus and saw legless and armless people who cannot receive modern artificial limbs because of EU sanctions. A political solution is the only way out of the crisis and of the conflict, including a possible federalisation of Syria, which may be useful especially for the Kurds.

name: Tatjana ŽDANOKA
text: President-in-Office of the Council, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, I would like to thank honourable Members for all the interventions, opinions and views. There were many diverging positions, but I dare say that this House agrees today on at least two important points that we have heard during our discussion on Syria. First, this House is sending a strong message of condemnation of all the atrocities we are witnessing on the ground in Syria. I dare say that there is no difference between this House and the Member States and institutions. Secondly, we could have a very long discussion, and we would certainly need more time on that, but what matters at this moment, as we speak, is what Federica Mogherini has initiated and that is the initiative on Aleppo. People on the ground are desperately waiting for humanitarian assistance and Federica is working very hard to make it possible in that theatre for the convoy to be able to reach the people of East Aleppo.  The third point that I would like to take with me from this debate is a recognition – an admission if you like – that we are reaching the point where we indeed need a deeper debate about the strategy that we have been witnessing on Syria. I would say that the next opportunity for this deeper discussion about strategy will be at the upcoming Foreign Affairs Council, where I am sure that Federica and the Foreign Ministers will engage in a very deep discussion on this overall strategy. Fourthly, I agree with all those who said that this crisis is prompting us to take further steps towards increasing our capability to go beyond what the European Union is mainly doing in international affairs, namely to be a soft power, a power which is unfortunately quite limited and is focused mainly on humanitarian assistance.  Let me say that steps in this direction are underway. I recall that in Bratislava – and we had a discussion this morning about the upcoming European Council – and I quote from the roadmap, ‘The December European Council should decide on a concrete implementation plan on security and defence and how to make better use of the options in the Treaties, especially as regards capabilities’. So, once again, we know that if we want to have more influence in international affairs, we need to work on capabilities. This process was launched in Bratislava and I assure, on behalf of the Council, that we will work intensively in order to implement what was adopted.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, October 6, 2016. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. – After the end of the ceasefire on 19 September, the Syrian army and its Russian ally resumed armed action on Aleppo to capture rebel-control neighborhoods with a damning attack on the humanitarian convoy that resulted in the deaths of eight humanitarian workers of the Syrian Red Crescent. What is it, though, Aleppo? Aleppo numbered more than a million and a half people before the war began and was Syria's second largest city. Today, following the bombardment and destruction, its eastern part is a ghost town. The Syrian conflict began more than five years ago and can only be settled by a clear intention by the world powers to hold negotiations to end it. The terrible attack on the humanitarian convoy in Aleppo last month, as well as the destruction of the M10 hospital by the Syrian regime on Monday, 3 October with Russian support, is expediting the EU's humanitarian aid and ceasefire (although the Union as an entity is not a military player). I welcome the initiative launched by High Representative Federica Mogherini and Commissioner Stylianides so that the EU can support Aleppo, because people urgently need services (especially medical services to ensure their survival).

name: Eugen FREUND
text: Writing. The situation in Syria is becoming more catastrophic by the day and we have been watching for years. As sad as it sounds, the end of the joint actions of the United States and Russia gives us a chance in Europe: it is high time that we demonstrateed our strength with resolute diplomacy. It is not weapons that will resolve this conflict, only negotiations. We can show all the proxy powers that make the Syrian people bleed for their claim to power that we do not agree with their actions – we also have a lot of economic resources in our hands here. I am glad that two key proposals that I made last week have been incorporated into the Syria resolution: firstly, that Europe must become more diplomatically involved. Secondly, I have also proposed that those forces that bombed the aid convoy near Aleppo a few weeks ago, killing many people, should be held accountable. This form of war crime must not go unpunished.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. – The European Union, like the entire international community, has a duty to save Syria, serving both Syrian citizens and the whole region. The negotiations started by the Syrian parties offer a good opportunity to move towards a solution. However, this option will not always be open, so it is vital that all parties engage constructively in a dialogue that leads to tangible results. The EU and its Member States will continue to provide life-saving assistance, while putting pressure on all the other to ensure that humanitarian aid reaches those in need throughout Syria, to put in place a ceasefire and to ensure the protection of civilians. Humanitarian and diplomatic efforts must take place in a coordinated manner, which can strengthen or weaken each other.  Hungary will be committed to significant progress in both areas. We believe that a stronger, more coordinated, effective and burden-sharing international development policy can contribute to the reconstruction of war-torn countries and to making countries that issue masses of economic migrants more livable. The formula is simple: history has repeatedly shown that there is only one effective solution strategy in these situations: to bring help to those in distress, not to bring trouble to Europe!

name: Ana GOMES
text: in writing. – The images that come to us daily of men, women and children being indistinctly massacred in Aleppo confront us with more than the moral failure of the international community: with the diplomatic and political irrelevance of the EU. The UN High Commissioner for Human Rights, Zeid Ra'ad Al Hussein, yesterday touched on the wound calling for restrictions on the veto power of permanent members of the Security Council when there are serious concerns of war crimes, against humanity or genocide: he called for a veto of Russia to bring those responsible for the carnage in Syria to the International Criminal Court. Humanitarian aid and behind-the-scenes diplomacy are useful, but it's not enough. The EU and its Member States have been unable to act strategically, decisively, thereby enabling Russia to exploit the emptiness and the terrorists of Assad, Daesh and the like to massacre the Syrian people, fuelling the reasons why thousands flee and desperately seek refuge in the neighbourhood and Europe; and offering more lost generations to terrorist recruitment. Let us have no illusions: we will not overcome the global threat of terrorism as long as we let the war continue in Syria, Iraq, Libya. It is European security that is also at stake!

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. – It is now clear that in Syria complete chaos has been caused by the numerous particular interests of not only the parties to the conflict. It's disgusting to bomb cities, and in them hospitals and settlements where innocent children and civilians are killed. Attacks on public institutions in Damascus and elsewhere are also unacceptable. It is also unacceptable for the EU that it is practically not participating in the peace process, which is again frozen, but that is why EU members are suffering enormous damage from the migrant crisis. Even the entire European project has been challenged by the migrant crisis. The EU needs to continue its peace-making policy and do everything to stop the horrors.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. - The consistent killing of civilians and the bombing of hospitals in the Syrian city of Aleppo must be stopped immediately. It is deeply regrettable that Russia is not willing to contribute to the ceasefire in Aleppo in order to deliver humanitarian aid to those in need and to allow civilians to leave safely. It is high time for EU foreign ministers to come up with a plan for helping to achieve peace and delivering humanitarian aid to Syria in cooperation with the UN.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: in writing. – Who and especially how will Pax Syriana be written? Syria now has the look of a puzzle whose pieces have been damaged by too many unsuccessful attempts to match them. The actors involved are more and more diverse than in the case of Libya and Iraq, more fierce and determined not to give in to a single plan of political change. But after five years of war in Syria, it is obvious that the wounds are extremely deep for all involved. In order to build a lasting peace, I believe that the European Union should support the crystallisation of two projects that bring together the factions involved in the war, with the exception of terrorist groups. Starting a democratic dialogue would be easier if 10 or 15 factions were not at the negotiating table, but two projects around which to coagulate the other opinions. Once started, the democratic process will generate mutual trust, and the inevitable compromises would be less painful. A real democracy is built through dialogue between power and opposition, which recognise each other's legitimacy. Syria must reach this point for the war to stop and the millions of refugees return to the country.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: in writing. –  When confronted with the horrible savagery of the Russian aerial assaults on Aleppo that deliberately target children’s hospitals with bunker buster bombs, it's terrible to feel that there is nothing we can do but watch with outrage. As the US ambassador to the UN recently said, ‘What Russia is sponsoring and doing is not counter-terrorism, it is barbarism. Instead of pursuing peace, Russia and Assad make war. Instead of helping get aid to civilians, Russia and Assad are bombing the humanitarian convoys, hospitals and first responders who are trying desperately to keep people alive.’ We have to ask ourselves how such a devastation is possible without the international community holding the perpetrators accountable. History will be right in judging us for standing on the sidelines and watching Syria fall prey to such atrocities.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the peace process in Colombia (2016/2895(RSP)) .

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: President-in-Office of the Council, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, honourable Members, on 26 September President Santos and the leader of the FARC, Rodrigo Londono, signed the final peace agreement at a ceremony held in Cartagena  de Indias at which the European Union was represented by the High Representative’s Special Envoy, Eamon Gilmore. The signature of the peace agreement sent a message of hope after 52 years of armed conflict that has caused 8 million victims, including 260 000 deaths. In times of uncertainty and turmoil, in many regions of the world – including our neighbourhood – it reinforces our conviction that dialogue and diplomacy constitute the best means for resolving conflicts. However, last Sunday, 2 October – contrary to forecasts – the Colombian population rejected the final peace agreements in a referendum by a very small margin. I think we would all have welcomed a different result, but we respect the sovereign choice of the Colombian people. The ‘No’ side in the referendum has defended that the government renegotiate the final agreement with the FARC to get a better deal. We can all agree with President Santos’s statement after the results were made public, and I quote: ‘all Colombians seek peace with no exception. Despite the setback, the path towards peace does not end here’. As you are aware, the peace agreement negotiated in Havana is a complex agreement. It aims, not only to end a 52-year armed conflict, but also addresses its root causes, supporting rural development and attacking the problem of illicit drugs. It also includes provisions on transitional justice and the political participation of the FARC, which are the two aspects most contested by the leaders of the ‘no’ campaign in the referendum held on 2 October. This is a delicate moment for Columbia, as the country must now decide on the way forward. It is of great importance that, after the referendum, both the  Colombian government and the FARC have confirmed their commitment to the ceasefire. A solution can only come from politics and from negotiations. For this reason, President Santos’s decision to send the negotiators back to Havana is a step in the right direction. The EU hopes that all sides – the government, the opposition and the FARC – can unite in a renewed effort and continue on the path towards achieving lasting peace. Columbia is one of the EU’s closest partners in Latin America. Our good relations and cooperation is getting deeper and deeper in many areas. We remain fully committed to this partnership. The European Union will keep on supporting all efforts towards a sustainable solution and to secure a permanent end to violence. We will continue to cooperate to bring peace and prosperity to all Colombians. Our commitment to the peace process in Colombia goes beyond symbolism. In the last weeks, we have announced two very concrete measures to support peace in Colombia. First, the European Council has suspended the FARC from our terrorist list. This is a decision that the Council has taken because of the signature of the peace agreement by the group. It concerns the choice made by the FARC to bring the negotiations to a positive end, not the outcome of the referendum. After the vote, FARC have not been moved away from the peace agreement they signed. On the contrary, they have confirmed their interest to find a peaceful solution. For this reason, the result of the referendum does not affect the suspension. Secondly, we have announced an overall package of nearly EUR 585 million to support Colombia’s post-conflict and peace-building efforts. This sum includes an EU trust fund for Colombia, in which 11 Member States have committed contributions. This trust fund is meant to support the implementation of the agreement. So in the current situation we are not moving forward with the launch of the trust fund. The EU’s engagement in supporting peace-building in Colombia will continue. The EU has sound experience in peace-building in the country, with flagship initiatives such as peace laboratories, over the past 15 years. Lastly, I would like to stress that I share the concern of this Parliament in ensuring the effective protection of human rights. It continues to be a priority for the EU, and we will keep on cooperating with the Colombian government in this respect. This includes a strong focus on human rights defenders. Too often they have been the target of threats and violence. The same goes for minorities, such as the indigenous and the descendant communities and the most vulnerable groups, which have been greatly affected by the conflict, including women and children. I would like to conclude by reiterating that the EU is determined to stand by Columbia in its long-term effort in pursuit of durable and lasting peace as well as a brighter future for all Colombians. I am sure that we can continue to count on the European Parliament’s invaluable and active support for peace-building in Colombia.

name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, Mr Minister, Colombia and your Government will find the solution they deserve so much and Europe must help them.  At 7 p.m. on day 2, President Santos said: "I recognize the outcome of the plebiscite, which does not jeopardize the political stability of the country. Bilateral ceasefire remains in place." Although he has said today: "until 31 October". Pure strategy, in my opinion. "I call the political forces for tomorrow." Said and done. He added: "And I immediately resume negotiations with the FARC." Soon after Timochenko said: "This group is going to remain in their will for peace, and we will use only the word as a weapon until the future." And today he questions whether the war will continue after October 31. Pure strategy of response to President Santos.  And now what we say, what I say, witnesses of the plebiscite: we fully respect the decision of the Colombian people who do not question the majority will of peace. We defend the continuity of the negotiations. We support President Santos and his decision to share the peace strategy with all political groups and civil society and call on the undisputed patriotism of 'no' advocates.  I ask the FARC, and we ask, to maintain its commitment to peace, to maintain the ceasefire, to deliver weapons and explosives, and to facilitate demining tasks. We wholeheartedly support all the victims of the conflict and greatly appreciate their generosity and courage. We support Mrs Mogherini and Mr Gilmore's continuity on the ground. We renew our commitment to the peace process we have supported and will continue to support. And I conclude, Mr President, as I started: Colombia and its Government will find the solution they deserve so much and the European Union must help them.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, who have been in Colombia for the last seven days we have become excited and disappointed. Excited, because contact with Colombian society, with the victims, with civil society, with political authorities, has allowed us to see a country in which peace was about to begin, a new time. And disappointed that on Sunday afternoon the result of the "no" gave us a great disappointment. But I want to say clearly that peace has not failed in Colombia. A "no" has triumphed in Colombia, but certainly there is also a will for peace in "no". That is why I believe that the European Union needs to reiterate three clear messages. First, Colombia needs to recompose its domestic reality, its political diversity, and it must commit to continuing negotiations with the FARC. The FARC has to maintain the ceasefire, and so does the government, the bilateral ceasefire, and they have to renegotiate the agreement, probably in terms of what has been the expression of citizenship, which has shown discrepancies with some conditions of that agreement. And thirdly, Europe. Europe must remain behind this agreement. It is too important for us, for the European Union, to support this country, and we have to do so through three important things: by maintaining a commitment to exclude the FARC from the terrorist list, by maintaining financial assistance and by keeping an observer, like Mr Gilmore, as special envoy.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I was delighted last week at the signing of the much overdue Colombian peace deal after 52 years of violent conflict. The result of the referendum, therefore, is hugely disappointing, but we must not allow it to be seen as a knockout blow. It is important that the international community now work to support President Santos in finding a way through and that there be no resumption of violence. Conflicts are always unique, each existing in response to their own context of time, location and history. In drawing comparisons and correlations, we should always do so with caution. But I cannot help but look to Northern Ireland at this moment, or more precisely, the Good Friday Belfast Agreement. We see in that deal the price of peace. Yes, it means accepting amnesties, elements of criminal immunity, and inviting into the political fold those previously seen to be beyond the pale politically, but nearly 20 years on, we do not talk of that price, but of the great success. The peace deal with FARC was about looking to the future. The referendum result has, sadly, been about delivering by looking to the past. Today, I strongly encourage Colombia to look again to the future, peace and prosperity.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I have participated in the European mission to accompany the plebiscite on the peace process in Colombia. In that condition, I appreciate the attitude of colombians on that day. I'm sorry for the difficulties Hurricane Matthew caused the voters of the coast. Without them, there might have been another result, albeit just as tight. The scrutiny disappointed and saddened me. But I soon regained my spirits because the process has many assets: years of dialogue that have woven trust, months without attacks or violence, a seamless international alliance, and an entire society that certainly wants and needs peace. I support President Santos' offer of dialogue and encourage supporters of 'no' to join him in making the agreement more inclusive. I hope that the FARC will make the end of their armed activity final and that dialogue with the ELN will continue with the same objective. The key is to ensure that peace is perceived as an achievement of all Colombians.  That is why, from Europe, we must maintain political, financial, diplomatic and human support for this hope. We owe it to the Colombians, and especially the victims, who asked us not to abandon them.  It is worth it because Marly, Paula or Fernando, who know from their pain and wounds what war costs, believe that the agreement proposes a reasonable price for peace. That is why there has been more support for the process in the areas most punished by violence. Because it offers shared answers to the country's great problems, such as land reform, respect for truth and justice, and methods to repair the victims who will improve with more support. There is a strategy against drug trafficking and demining and new avenues for political participation by those who have decided to exchange arms for peace and word. Bases for a new, socially fairer, more politically freer and more democratic Colombia.  I conclude by congratulating Vice-President Mogherini and her special envoy, Eamon Gilmore, on their work in Colombia, and the Ambassador of the European Union for their role in the process and their assistance in this mission. Factors that are an example of the positive role we can play, if states allow, in other conflicts that haunt us at our very borders.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the results of last Sunday's referendum in Colombia have created a great shock among those of us who wanted a decisive step at the ballot box to end more than fifty years of conflict and suffering in Colombia. It should be noted that, in the first half of 2016 alone, 35 human rights defenders have been killed and 232 threatened with death and, at the same time, that the result of the "no" has left UN monitoring decisions in limbo to verify the laying of weapons or demining operations. However, peace-building efforts must be irreversible, which is why we are seriously concerned that President Santos has marked 31 October as the ceasefire date. Today more than ever we must continue to support peace in Colombia and ask President Santos to maintain the bilateral ceasefire permanently, to maintain democratic progress in the agreements, to continue negotiations and to join them by actors such as the ELN for full peace. The end of the conflict in Colombia is and must be irreversible.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by showing you a survey published in a newspaper in Colombia on Monday: children in Colombia would have voted 'yes'. The children who were orphaned, the recruited, those are the future of Colombia. All of these would have voted 'yes'. The victims voted "yes."  But the "yes" only achieved almost 50%, no more. He won the "no" with just over 50%. In a democracy, even though it hurts, even if it disappoints us, we must respect the will of the electorate, and we all accept this for what we have been with the delegation of the European Parliament, respecting the will of the electorate. But I admit my great disappointment and also sadness that fear apparently gained hope.  But it must be said clearly that these years of dialogue, of effort, of patience, the important achievements that are in this peace agreement must not and cannot have been in vain. We have to start negotiating again with the base that already exists. With a foundation that was achieved by involving victims' organizations, involving women's organizations, calling for comprehensive rural reform— something in the agreement;  also the political participation of those who leave arms; democratic openness in the country and, also, the agreement on victims, reparation, non-repetition.  All that is in this agreement must be the basis on which the future of Colombia will be built - hopefully with the full support of the European Parliament, of the European Union – in order for it to succeed, because the achievements and also the efforts of those who want peace in Colombia and what has been achieved together must not have been in vain with 'no'.  We voted here in Parliament to support 'yes'. And we continue with the support of the Colombian people.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: EFDD Group. – Mr President, in Colombia he won the 'no', and now we can blame Hurricane Matthew, who did not allow many Colombians to leave their homes to vote, or we can blame the fact that it was the first time in twenty-five years that the Colombian people had been called to decide in a plebiscite. We can also convince ourselves that in Colombia there are political forces that do not want peace and that they won. But the reality is that the peace process negotiated in Havana is irreversible. Although what has been agreed in Havana is now going to be without legal effect, the road to peace is already underway and no political or ideological speculation can stop it. We hope that, in the face of this situation, the European Union will continue to support the peace process and, above all, those willing to give up arms and raise hearts. The European Union has to do much more than just freeze the Colombian fund's 70 million euros.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Colombian people, by a narrow majority, certainly rejected the agreement between the government and the FARC, which means how much this people has been bruised by the most barbaric and despicable abuses of the FARC. This Marxist group, like other Marxist terrorist organizations, finds scandalous and unacceptable support in this Chamber. Today, the European Union must above all respect the choice of the Colombian people. The FARC must therefore be kept on the list of terrorist organizations.

name: Thomas MANN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Supporters of the no-campaign led by ex-president Uribe have hit back at the peace deal with the FARC. A positive referendum would have brought more than 50 years of civil war to an official end. But the agreement is not worthless, as the government and the rebels have declared that they will stick to the peace process.  Only 13 of the approximately 35 million citizens took part in the decision. There was considerable criticism that the FARC should be given ten seats in Parliament, and even for the most serious atrocities there should be a maximum of eight years in prison. In September, we were in Uruguay as a Eurolat delegation. In the Montevideo parliament, all but one of the representatives of the various Colombian parties declared their support for the referendum. They impressively described the great efforts made to the peace process. I believe that the negotiations have not been in vain. However, the following questions must be answered: will there be substantial renegotiations? Can the penalty for crimes be increased? How are the victims of massacres and torture compensated? And how can we destroy the cocaine industry, whose huge profits have financed the FARC's struggle for decades?  The EU will not be content with words, but will actively participate in peacemaking in Colombia, including with financial support. The IMF had already pledged aid in the event of a positive referendum.  I hope that a revised and then balanced agreement can be put to the vote again for the people, so that today's hope for peace becomes a real peace for tomorrow.

name: Richard HOWITT
text: – Mr President, I have worked for peace and human rights in Colombia for all the time I have been a Member of the European Parliament, and I am proud to be part of the NGO ‘Justice for Colombia’. We should know with deep sadness the result in the referendum on the Colombian peace deal. Deeper still should be our determination to keep the quest for peace alive. European and international support is now more important than ever for this process.  Why would people vote for more bombings? Why would people vote for more kidnappings? Why would people vote for yet more bloodshed? I do not believe that they did. Too many people thought that this deal involved impunity which it never did, and perhaps they were told so by people who themselves fear going to jail and whose own impunity is their own motivation. If so, what happened last weekend may have delayed the day of justice, but that day will come, and so, for the Colombian people, will peace.

name: Nikolay BAREKOV
text: – Mr. Chairman, I'm coming back from Colombia. Europe must respect and accept the decision of the Colombian people. Even with little, the agreement between the government and the FARC was rejected, but not peace. For now, the fire has to stop, and that's the hope.  I had a meeting with dozens of drug gang victims. People want peace, but just. President Uribe led the "No" vote campaign. He was a symbol of the war on crime and corruption. Uribe thinks the agreement is too sweet for ex-killers and criminals. And so the people of Colombia think clearly.  In front of me, Uribe designated the FARC as the richest criminal cartel in the world. Peace has no alternative to Colombia, but Europe must realize that criminals responsible for 300,000 people killed and tens of millions of victims of drug trafficking around the world cannot be amnestyd. With a "no" vote, nothing ends. Greater efforts are needed to integrate pseudo-left terrorists and eradicate the FARC.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: – Mr President, on Sunday night we were angered to see how the lie and misrepresentations about the peace agreement in Colombia had weighed more than the 'yes' campaign. A campaign in which, by the way, the European Union has been quite absent. As absent he has been throughout the negotiation process. At the official signing event in Cartagena, where we attended by some Members of the European left, we could not see eer the High Representative, the President of the Commission, or the President of Parliament.  There he was grateful for the role played by countries such as Cuba and Norway , guarantor countries – or Chile and Venezuela (accompanying countries). Logically, the European Union was not appointed, because the main concern of European leaders all this time has been how to do a good deal with peace, little else.  The FARC-EP has already reaffirmed its commitment to peace. Now even more than before, the commitment of the entire international community is needed for the Colombian government to maintain the ceasefire indefinitely.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: – Mr President, Mr Minister, of course, Sunday's result was a very hard blow for all of us who are pushing and we believe in peace, but it is time not to put our arms down. It is time to continue to call for a call to return to negotiations and dialogue, a call for the continued ceasefire, and here the European Union must continue to develop all the instruments it has put in place for this to come out successfully. I have listened with pleasure to the Minister to say that the commitment to have taken the FARC off the list of terrorist organizations remains. That's good news, that's the way. I believe that Member States should continue to be asked to contribute financially to support the process, that is very important. And finally, Mr Gilmore's task, especially to continue, which has parliament's support for continuing to play an important role there. And so I think it is time, now, for the European Union and this Parliament to send a message that peace is irreversible, that we must move forward and that we are all going together to do our best to ensure that this ends well.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: Mr President, an agreement has been negotiated and signed under the aegis of Cuba, one of the last communist dictatorships in the world, an agreement which aims to launder a narco-terrorist organisation and absolve hundreds of criminals with unacceptable leniency.  Some would have liked the Colombians to approve of this agreement, but their naivety borders on blindness. It was not the peace of the brave, but a Colombian Munich that they called for.  The proud and courageous Colombian people, speaking sovereignly and freely, despite propaganda that was quick to excuse terrorists when they are Marxists, did not accept the unacceptable. Colombian President Santos is right to say that all Colombians want peace, but not at any cost. It is not the peace that lost on Sunday in Colombia, it is the honour of the Colombian people who won, this honour that refuses the cowardly relief of trampling the memory of the 260,000 murdered, the 45,000 disappeared and the 7 million people displaced by the terrorist abuses of the FARC.  An acceptable agreement is an agreement that does not violate the memory of the victims.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: – Mr President, Sunday's plebiscite in Colombia has developed in a climate of normalcy and democratic coexistence which I have to highlight, but it has not yet yielded the result that the entire international community and many of us wanted. In any case, I believe that Sunday's outcome is not going to be a point and an end but a point and followed in achieving peace in Colombia.  All Colombians, including "no" supporters, have reiterated their support for peace following the counting of votes. It is now a question of achieving a greater number of meeting points that will make greater consensus possible in Colombian society. At these delicate times they do not suit the country, nor a climate of bewilderment or a sense of uncertainty. I therefore welcome the continued unilateral truce, at least for now, or until 31 October, and that the parties have already expressed the validity of their commitment to peace. I also welcome the willingness to dialogue and negotiation expressed by the leaders of the negative vote sector, who have already appointed a negotiating team. I am confident that your leaders will make constructive use of your victory in the referendum and I understand that President Santos is going to meet with former Presidents Uribe and Pastrana today. Inclusive efforts need to be made in Colombia at the moment. If there's one thing they agree on, all parties are in the after-reaching of the conflict. All Colombians have to live up to the crucial moment that the country lives, which has before it a historical opportunity. The sense of responsibility and constructive attitude are indispensable to manage this complex, delicate situation, and to find formulas that allow a successful end to the process.  Mr President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union must continue to accompany this path to peace. Colombia, as you, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, said, is one of our closest and most important partners in Latin America. We must remain committed to all efforts by the Colombian state and society to establish a strong stage of peace and prosperity in the country. This will end decades of conflict and confrontation that so many victims have caused.

name: Soraya POST
text: – Mr President, during the five days I was in Bogota and Cartagena we met with victims – women, farmers, politicians against and in favour of the peace process. I can assure you that the people of Colombia and the victims are not for revenge. They want peace and daily security.  We witness a new chapter in peace-building, and it is crucial that the peace process remain feministic. The participation of the victims and of civil society organisations in the peace process is crucial. Women, as well as the Afro-Colombian community and indigenous people, have to be fully part of the negotiation of the peace agreement. They have to be involved continually in the definition, implementation and control of the political mechanism and financial instruments in the country.  It is also necessary, as soon as possible, to create the Special Tribunal for Peace and the Committee for Truth and Reconciliation, the special unit for missing people and the unit for the investigation and dismantling of the criminal organisations. In this highly sensitive situation, it is essential that we continue to support Eamon Gilmore’s work as EU Special Envoy for the Colombian peace process, including the promised establishment of the European Union Trust Fund for Colombia, as well as the EU decision to suspend FARC from its terrorist list on agreed terms.

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: – Mr President, we welcome and welcome the constructive and full compromise position with the agreements and the final bilateral ceasefire adopted by the FARC. I believe it is a clear sign of its firm will for Colombia to move towards a just and lasting peace. The non-endorsement now requires more work to support a process and agreements that have full legal value, having been deposited in Bern as special agreements, within the framework of the Geneva conventions. The European Union must continue its full support for the process and meet its commitments, such as the withdrawal of the FARC from its outdated list of terrorist organisations. There should be no ambiguous messages on this subject, much less at the moment, so I would like to greet the words of Mr Korok and a number of colleagues in this regard. It's time, ladies and gentlemen, to keep all the commitments, all of you.

name: Jordi Vicent SEBASTIA TALAVERA
text: – Mr President, Mr Minister, the outcome of the referendum on the peace agreement in Colombia has fallen on all of us like a jug of cold water. It was terrible news, because it was also the first point of a peace process that will still be very complicated because we still have other guerrilla groups active in Colombia and there are still paramilitaries, the main causes of death and disappearances in that country.  We have to react with even more strength and energy. We must send a very clear message that the European Union will continue to bet on this peace process without any rift. When peace is sought in a negotiation, the goal is not to overcome the opposite, the goal is to reconcile. And reconciliation can only come if it involves forgiveness. And I dedicate these words to some colleagues who here, in this House, have their mouths filled by claiming Christian values, but they forget that: forgiveness. Without forgiveness there will be no reconciliation or peace, and I believe that we must send a direct and very clear message to President Santos so that he does not place limits on the ceasefire. We cannot limit that peace (small, fragile) that we have achieved so far. We must demand and strongly support the process.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: – Mr President, as a member of the European Parliament delegation, I have been observing the plebiscite in Columbia. Let me share with you my observations and a few conclusions. Last Sunday we witnessed Colombian democracy in action. We should fully respect the will of the Colombian people expressed during the plebiscite. The result of the plebiscite does not question in any way the will of the Colombian people to have peace and reconciliation in that country, which has been facing armed conflict, killings, kidnappings, displacements and all kinds of violence for 52 years. The perception in Europe that the ‘no’ camp voted in favour of war is totally wrong. The Colombian nation wants peace and voted for peace.  The peace process in Colombia is irreversible. Bilateral ceasefire commitments made by the Colombian Government and FARC have been kept. The European Union will continue its support for the peace process in Colombia. President Santos and his government deserve our support in their efforts to reach a de facto peace in Colombia without prejudging the content of the peace agreement, providing that the Colombian people endorse and approve it through the plebiscite.  The result of the plebiscite clearly indicates that the final peace agreement has to be renegotiated and at least two issues are to be addressed, namely participation of FARC in the political process and impunity for FARC. The current peace agreement guarantees ten seats for FARC in the Colombian Congress and five seats in the Senate, without the need to be elected, plus justice reviews for FARC members. Now it is evident that a new phase of dialogue must be opened that should be inclusive and transparent.  My last remark has regard to the delisting of FARC from the EU list of terrorist organisations. Following the signing of the peace agreement, the Council unanimously decided to temporarily delist FARC for six months, and sanctions against the FARC leadership have been dropped. The decision regarding delisting is conditional and is to be terminated immediately if FARC does not deliver on its promises of no violence and full disarmament. I suggest that the issue of the delisting of FARC be high on the agenda of High Representative Mogherini.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: – Mr President, this debate on the peace process in Colombia is a debate with a great impact on international policy, and I therefore can not fail to welcome here at this moment the news of the election a few minutes ago of António Guterres as the new Secretary-General of the United Nations and wish him all the best in the performance of his duties. The will of the peoples is sovereign but the search for peace is a greater good. The intense debate that took place in Colombia as part of the referendum on the peace agreement between the FARC and the government was a dialogue on how best to build lasting peace from the existing bilateral ceasefire.  Similarly, we must think that being able to reverse an obstacle to peace, legitimately created by the democratic auscultation of the people, can only be achieved with a democratic response that is even stronger. This is the challenge for Colombia and the parties involved. This is the challenge that the European Union has to embrace.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I was in Ecuador in 2010 with an INTA delegation. We visited a refugee camp there for people from Colombia. There we met a master craftsman – myself myself – who had to give up his existence, his name, his family , out of fear and as a protection for his family, who remained in Colombia. I believe that, like many millions of other Colombians, he had hoped that not only the signing of the peace agreement, but also a positive result, would result in the referendum and allow a step towards a truly social, peaceful society in Colombia. The open problem of impunity was certainly one reason for the failure of the referendum, and Uribe, as a former president also a major culprit in crimes against many ordinary people – trade unionists, journalists – has made it possible, so to speak, that this fear of impunity has led to a different result. For the European Union, for the European Parliament, it must be a matter of directing what is stated in the roadmap to the EU-Peru-Colombia free trade agreement in a social and democratic direction and enabling a step in the right direction.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: – The process leading to the end of the conflict in Colombia has a long history and will have to continue. The outcome of the plebiscite is undeniably a surprise. However, it must be fully respected. Colombia needs to end this conflict and go through a long path of internal reconciliation. I am pleased that the EU has been present in this process and supported peace negotiations. We must now send out a clear signal to support their continuation. We should therefore insist on maintaining the conditions that led to the signing of the agreement of 26 August and doing everything possible to prevent further violence from spreading. In the meantime, I believe that we should keep the Farc off the blacklist of terrorist organisations and, together with other international partners, offer mediation that would help to resolve the conflict permanently. The European Union can also offer the experience of reconciliation processes that Colombian society will need in the coming years. I trust that the European Union will continue to be active and will continue to support the end of this conflict.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: – Mr President, on Sunday we all received the sad news of the results of the referendum. We received it especially in shock; results that we respect but regret, that leave the country and the peace process in Colombia in a very fragile situation, in the limbo of being warless and without peace. That is why now is the time for the international community at large, but the European Union in particular today to show its commitment to the peace process as never before: its diplomatic commitment to Federica Mogherini and our special envoy; our financial commitment, with the support that is committed to the trust fund; and with the actions that we also have to take internally with the list of terrorist organizations. And it is time to ask the actors in Colombia to be involved in the negotiation, to do so from generosity, and to the FARC and the State, to participate with guarantees in the coming months and, in particular, to take the steps that have been taking into account all those victims who, this weekend, generously , they were supporting the peace process.
