name: Alojz PETERLE
text: – Thank you, Mrs High Representative and Vice-President of the European Commission, for addressing the European Parliament on an issue as important as the Colombian peace process. I welcomed the signing of the peace agreement with enthusiasm. However, I accepted the result of the recent referendum with disappointment, but at the same time with the awareness that this result does not mean that Colombians are against peace. Maintaining the ceasefire is key to a successful political dialogue and new compromises. I welcome the will of the President of Colombia Santos to strengthen the peace process through further and in-depth dialogue and wish him success as soon as possible. However, I would like to make a lasting contribution to the key players of the common European foreign policy, including the European Parliament, to ensure that the excellent results of the peace process so far do not turn back to the conflict situation. I am convinced that an inclusive approach and persistence can finally resolve the 50-year-long conflict. The Colombian peace process has no alternative.

name: Boris ZALA
text: – Mr President, I was a witness to the fully democratic and transparent organisation of the referendum. Its result does not call into question the desire for peace in Colombia. We must welcome the efforts of all parts of the society to find compromise on the way to peace. Our thoughts must be with the victims of violence. I was moved by their generosity; they all support the agreement. Therefore we must develop programmes aimed at the victims’ moral and material compensation. Finally, I support the Council decision to suspend FARC from the terrorist list, but under the condition that they are going to abandoning violence.

name: David McALLISTER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I, too, consider the outcome of the referendum on the peace treaty in Colombia to be a very great disappointment and, ultimately, a victory of emotion over the arguments. What will happen next? We all agree, as the debate today has shown: the political leaders in Bogota must prevent further bloodshed at all costs. This is exactly the will of the Colombian people, who have not spoken out against peace by a majority. This perception, which is partly widespread in Europe, is wrong, as a colleague who knows Colombia well and has been there several times in recent months has told me. Instead, the negotiated terms, in particular impunity for the FARC rebels, were rejected. The extension of the ceasefire until 31 October and the announcement of further negotiations by President Santos are indeed steps in the right direction. At the same time, Colombia will need the help of the international community in particular on the road to a lasting and stable peace. Colombia, as one of the EU's most important partners in Latin America, should also be sure of the European Parliament's support in this regard. That, too, is a message in today's debate.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: – The peace agreement between the Colombian government and the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia is historic, not only because it is an attempt to end the longest conflict in the Western Hemisphere, but because it gives us back the belief that peace is possible even in protracted and seemingly intractable conflicts like the one in which more than 300,000 people have been killed and over 5 million killed. internal and external refugees.  Its importance is also underlined by the decision taken to nominate Colombia for the Nobel Peace Prize. That is why the results of the referendum held, where by 50 000 votes the agreement was rejected, causes huge disappointment in our country. Not only for those who have worked for many years to resolve this conflict, but also for the thousands of families on both sides of the conflict who have sacrificed in it. All those involved in the Colombian peace talks owe it to the victims and their families to make sure that the fragile hope for peace is not lost. Violence, murder and kidnapping should not be allowed to start again. Achieving sustainable peace in Colombia will unlock the country's great economic potential, strengthen, of course, contacts with the European Union and make it a talking point of stability in Latin America.  The peace process is a historic opportunity not only for Colombia, but also for the global war on drug trafficking, as the country still remains the world's largest exporter of cocaine, by removing coca plantations in farc-controlled regions of the country, while helping farmers start growing alternative non-narcotic crops. The referendum is lost for now, but I hope that peace will be won.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: –  Mr President, the 52 year old conflict that has cost the lives of more than 200 000 and caused the displacement of millions in Colombia is about to be over. This is a major relief for all of us. National reconciliation has proved to be an extremely difficult task against the backdrop of so many atrocities, loss of life and injustice. It can be understood that for many of those who suffered, the terms of the agreement seem too generous for the FARC fighters. Now a negative referendum has reintroduced uncertainty. However, it is important to avoid any back-stepping from the historic agreement. The international community should decisively support both partners who have declared that they are prepared to stick to the terms of agreement and that a ceasefire would be extended over the end of October. The fact that almost two-thirds of voters abstained from the vote, and that the result was practically a draw belies claims that the vote was directed against national reconciliation. It was certainly not the case. The vote should be seen as a wake-up call, a crucial opportunity for Colombian citizens to reengage in democratic debate and not leave the national future to be decided by politicians alone. Now a new period of dialog must start. It has to include all the sectors of the Colombian people. Most importantly, the peace process should become irreversible.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, after years of laborious and lengthy negotiations in Havana, the historic agreement was signed between the Colombian Government and the main Farc guerrilla group, in the presence of the UN Secretary-General, Ban Ki-moon, to end a long and bloody war. The news had rekindle the international community's hopes for lasting peace after more than fifty years of conflict. Unfortunately, the referendum held a few days ago for the ratification of the agreement, despite various appeals from the international community, saw the 'no' vote prevail. There are now fears of the international isolation in which the country may fall. Colombia still has a long way to go to achieve peace. With Europe's help, every effort must be made to continue the peace process and to put an end once and for all to an internal conflict which has cost more than 220 000 victims and 6 million internally displaced persons.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, after almost four years of negotiations, the Colombian Government and the FARC rebels signed a peace agreement on 26 September aimed at ending the conflict between them that has lasted almost half a century. This is expected to put an end to the oldest and longest-running conflict in Latin America, which has left at least 220,000 victims and six million displaced and led to political persecution of opposition and trade union leaders.  The agreement also provides for the disarmament of the rebels, since the government has pledged to allocate seats in Congress to the FARC, as well as security guarantees for the rebel fighters. Finally, compensation is provided for the victims of the conflict, as well as measures to combat drug trafficking. However, Mr President, the peace process can only lead to the formation of a democratic Colombia on condition and on condition that the paramilitary organisations are dissolved.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: – Mr President, the result of the referendum in Colombia is very bad news. The war sectors managed to convince a small majority with a grotesque campaign of lies and it is even meaner because it gives a relevant role in the peace process to those who profited from the war, to those who tolerated and propelled the death squads that filled Colombia with graves and millions of internally displaced persons.  The vitality of these sectors was proven when in Cartagena de Indias, at the signing of peace, four Colombian fighters were flying at low level the speech of the FARC representative frightening those present, including fifteen Heads of State.  Now, as the FARC reiterates its firm commitment to peace, Santos sets an expiration date for the ceasefire. It's very bad news.  The European Union must be present to accompany this will for peace — all right to keep the FARC off the list of terrorist organizations — and it must tell the President of Colombia strongly that it does not, to maintain a commitment to peace.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – Twenty-five years of fighting, almost a quarter of a million dead, 45,000 missing, seven million people displaced. Nevertheless, of course, fear prevailed over hope, and the referendum showed that the people had so far rejected the peace agreement. However, the achievements of this peace agreement and the process must not go to waste, including as regards the efforts to abandon arms. The reforms that have been started must continue, we must support the continuation of this process, including financially, because the peace process in Colombia must be irreversible. The people have rejected this peace agreement, and there are certainly reasons that we may not yet understand. However, this surprising result does not mean the continuation of the fighting, the dialogue must continue and, in addition to the financial resources, we must also offer experience, as my colleague Kukan said.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: – Mr President, the result of the referendum in Colombia also stems from a protracted campaign of disinformation and fear of those who have, over the years, fuelled hatred, paramilitarism and state terrorism, of those responsible for almost seven million forced internally displaced persons and hundreds of murders of progressive peace and human rights activists. This is a result that will be nothing more than a short delay in reaching a peace agreement for which the Colombian people are looking forward to and ending an armed conflict that has lasted for 50 years.  The long and exhaustive negotiation process between the Colombian Government and the FARC-EP must remain an important benchmark of the peace process, which must proceed serenely with the maintenance of the ceasefire. The European Union is required to permanently remove the FARC-EP from the list of terrorist organisations. Peace, beyond necessary, will be an absolute inevitability that the Colombian people will reach sooner than later.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: President-in-Office of the Council, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, I would like to thank all of the honourable Members who have intervened. I believe we can conclude from this debate that we all wish for a lasting and durable peace in Colombia. After the rejection of the final agreement in the referendum, it is now for all political forces to unite in a national dialogue and find the path that can lead the country to peace. In this decisive moment for Columbia, I can assure this House that the EU will continue playing an active role in supporting, encouraging and accompanying all steps to end the armed conflict and bring durable peace and prosperity to the country and its people.  Finally, I close my remarks by signalling once again my appreciation for the Parliament's role in keeping this issue on our European agenda.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: in writing. – The negotiations that have taken place between the Colombian government and the FARC in recent years have filled the world with hope. In a bold turn, the decades-old enemies agreed to sit at the negotiating table to try to end a conflict that has claimed eight million lives. What seemed impossible was achieved and a definitive ceasefire was concluded in August, with the demobilization of the guerrillas agreed and their integration into the party-political system. Such an agreement could only involve mutual compromise and would always be based on a difficult compromise between the desire for justice and the desire for peace.  Unfortunately, a majority of Colombians refused this agreement in the october 2 referendum. A historic opportunity for peace has been lost, which can only fill us with sadness. I believe, after all, that this process is irreversible and that neither the government nor the FARC wants to regress to suffering and violence. This is a decisive moment for the future of the Colombian people and the European Union must commit all its efforts to the search for a solution that, while taking into question the fears and doubts expressed at the ballot box by the people, does not let peace escape.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. Colombia is in a very delicate moment following the victory of the No in the plebiscite over the Peace Agreement held on 2 October. But disappointment with this outcome should not lead us to pessimism, but to continue working with renewed efforts for the ultimate triumph of peace. Peace has not failed in Colombia, since even in the No that Colombians expressed on Sunday, a will for peace prevails. Colombia now needs to rebuild its domestic reality, its political diversity and commit to continuing negotiations with the FARC, which have to maintain a ceasefire. The renegotiation of the Agreement must be carried out in the terms in which citizenship has been expressed, which has shown discrepancies with certain conditions of the Agreement. For its part, the Union must contribute to the peace process by fulfilling three conditions: keeping the FARC off the list of terrorist organisations, fulfilling its financial aid commitments and keeping The Union's Special Envoy, Eamon Gilmore, in his post to continue its work as an observer of the process.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. Colombia is in a very delicate moment following the victory of the No in the plebiscite over the Peace Agreement held on 2 October. But disappointment with this outcome should not lead us to pessimism, but to continue working with renewed efforts for the ultimate triumph of peace. Peace has not failed in Colombia, since even in the No that Colombians expressed on Sunday, a will for peace prevails. Colombia now needs to rebuild its domestic reality, its political diversity and commit to continuing negotiations with the FARC, which have to maintain a ceasefire. The renegotiation of the Agreement must be carried out in the terms in which citizenship has been expressed, which has shown discrepancies with certain conditions of the Agreement. For its part, the Union must contribute to the peace process by fulfilling three conditions: keeping the FARC off the list of terrorist organisations, fulfilling its financial aid commitments and keeping The Union's Special Envoy, Eamon Gilmore, in his post to continue its work as an observer of the process.

text: in writing. Colombia is in a very delicate moment following the victory of the No in the plebiscite over the Peace Agreement held on 2 October. Peace has not failed in Colombia, since even in the No that Colombians expressed on Sunday, a will for peace prevails. name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. Colombia is in a very delicate moment following the victory of the No in the plebiscite over the Peace Agreement held on 2 October. But disappointment with this outcome should not lead us to pessimism, but to continue working with renewed efforts for the ultimate triumph of peace. Peace has not failed in Colombia, since even in the No that Colombians expressed on Sunday, a will for peace prevails. Colombia now needs to rebuild its domestic reality, its political diversity and commit to continuing negotiations with the FARC, which have to maintain a ceasefire. name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: President-in-Office of the Council, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, I am grateful to you for organising this debate at a critical moment for the Democratic Republic of Congo. The EU has been a close political and development partner of the Congolese people over many years. We cannot allow the DRC to sink again into a crisis which would, without doubt, spill beyond national borders and across the Great Lakes region.  I would like to begin by reiterating some of the key positions already expressed by High Representative Mogherini and by the EU in recent statements. I must start by addressing the recent violence in the DRC. The level of violence in recent days has been a shock to all of us. The EU has already made it very clear that we attribute individual responsibility to all actors involved in violence, and that of course includes members of institutions in charge of security and justice. Impunity cannot be tolerated. In this respect, I would like to underline the importance we attach to the duty of MONUSCO to document human rights violations and to report on them in line with Security Council Resolution 2277. I would like, on behalf of High Representative/Vice-President Mogherini, but also on my own account, to praise the vital work being done by the United Nations Joint Human Rights Office in the DRC. What the DRC needs is calm, not violence. Calm is needed to focus on finding a solution to the current political crisis, which means to focus on finding a consensus leading to credible and inclusive presidential elections as quickly as possible.  For this to be possible, respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms is essential. Our message is simple: only an inclusive dialogue resulting in an agreement involving the widest range of political actors will pave the way towards peaceful and credible elections in accordance with the DRC Constitution and Security Council Resolution 2277. The EU and other key partners involved in supporting the ongoing national dialogue, among them the African Union, the IOF, the United Nations and the United States, will continue to use the tools at our disposal to make the process work. This includes, of course, diplomatic action and outreach to key partners such as Angola and South Africa, as well as action in the UN Security Council.  It is especially regrettable that the political crisis in DRC is distracting us from the stabilisation and development of DRC and that the Congolese people continue to suffer, especially from the barbarous activities of armed groups operating in the north and east of the country. The current political impasse has to be addressed if we are to get back to the work of supporting state-building, reforming the security institutions of the country, tackling the problem of conflict minerals, contributing to healthcare and building roads. In addition, progress on regional integration across Central Africa will continue to be held back for as long as the DRC remains unstable.  Let me end with an assessment of the ongoing political dialogue launched on 1 September. The dialogue has resulted in some positive steps forward, but the challenge now is to achieve greater inclusivity in participation and greater substance in discussions. The clock is ticking, and both government and opposition have a responsibility to work together in the national interest. No one is excused from this obligation.  We call on the opposition, which have not joined the dialogue process yet. However, the government also has a critical responsibility to ensure that political freedoms are respected and that justice is not used to sideline political actors. Above all, a public commitment by all actors to respect the constitution – in particular, as far as the limit on presidential mandates is concerned – would contribute considerably to easing tensions. We will continue to review the use of all the tools at our disposal to support the dialogue, insisting on its inclusivity and its focus. We will exert pressure to improve the political climate in the country, and in particular to ensure that absolute respect is guaranteed for human rights and fundamental freedoms at this critical time for consolidating DRC’s democratic progress. I look forward to hearing your views.

name: Joachim ZELLER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the It was only in June that we discussed the situation in Congo. At that time, it was particularly about the resurgent fighting in the east of the country, which caused and forced many people to leave their ancestral villages and towns. This has caused a large-scale refugee crisis.  Now we have an intensification of the political crisis. What Minister Korok has called for, calm in this country, is not given to the people there. There is one person responsible for this, and that is President Kabila, who would normally have to leave office after two terms, because that is what the Constitution of the Democratic Republic of Congo provides for. Elections for a new president should have taken place in September. None of this happens. It is a mockery at all that this country calls itself the state name "Democratic Republic". Rarely in the history of this country has the situation there been called democratic, and rarely have people had a say in shaping the fate of this country. The opposition is being persecuted, there are already deaths. Opposition offices have been burned and set on fire. Many have been arrested, and with a ploy that voter registration was no longer possible in time, the President is now trying to artificially extend his term of office. This is unacceptable.  There are already proposals from the United States and France to impose sanctions, as we do in other cases. This should be followed by action, and the EU should be united in this and take stronger action.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, I have just returned from the east of the Democratic Republic of the Congo; an immense country with immense challenges; a country whose soil is immensely rich and its population immensely poor; a country where violence, sometimes very brutal, has become normal, particularly in the Kivús region. This huge country, now key to the region, key to the continent and key to Europe, is directed by its president directly into the abyss. Kabila has decided to cling to power by going over the Constitution, and although that may lead her people into a devastating abyss. I think there's still time to avoid it. It is necessary to recover the path of dialogue, but of inclusive dialogue. The first inescapable issue is setting a certain date for the presidential election. And on that the European Union must dump all its weight, which is a lot. We have in our power the political dialogue provided for in Article 8 of the Cotonou Agreement. But we must also think of Article 96, that is, the imposition of sanctions against those responsible and also the redirection of our aid. That's in our hand, we can't blame others.  Member States, Mr President, must also take action at the bilateral level against prominent members of the authorities of the country holding dual nationality. And europeans are also the very important interests of companies with activities that are also destroying that country. This is the case in eastern Congo, widened by the violence of dozens of armed groups faced by control of those resources that end up being goods on the international market. Massacres take place every day in places like Beni in the face of the practice and total indifference of the international community.  We may also have to activate the International Criminal Court and also act on the disastrous situation of hundreds of thousands of people who continue to live on shear volcanic stones. We have to act now, ladies and gentlemen, before it is too late, as happened very recently in Burundi, remember?

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. I received a letter from Mrs Mogherini in response to our concerns about the human rights situation in the Democratic Republic of Congo and our suggestion for targeted sanctions. Her answer was a commitment, as we know the High Representative. And you know how that goes: through social media, her words reached the other side of the world in no time. Those words create hope.  But I sometimes wonder who opens all our letters, whether or not it reads and classifies, alphabetically or chronologically. There must be palaces full of our admonition letters. Forgive my cynicism, but President Kabila yesterday confirmed with the demise of the elections in congo's interests. For congo's sake, no further details. We did get it from the Chairman of the Electoral Commission: he can not give a date for the presidential elections at the earliest end of 2017.  In other words, no elections before the end of 2018. Protests against this are nipped in the bud. Blood was flowing through the streets of Kinshasa. However, there are many Congolese who are good with their country. Dr. Mukwege, for example, could be seen on Flemish television a few days ago. The gynaecologist and human rights activist who once again made victims of horrific violence human in eastern Congo and was awarded the Sakharov Prize by this Parliament in 2014. He doesn't hide his contempt for what Kabila does, and he names the problems as they are. The constitution is reduced to a piece of paper. The third violence him off.  They're voices like dr. Mukwege's who needs Congo. I believe that citizen movements that subscribe to and embrace the constitution and democracy can restore chaos. But not without international support. It is therefore more than a time for the European Union to exchange its enthusiastic speeches and letters for action.  As far as I am concerned, this could include, for example, a travel ban, the freezing of the accounts of all those responsible for the violent repression. The United States was in favour of us again and decided to take such measures.  The best way to serve the interests of the Congolese people is to ensure that President Kabila resigns in time and presidential elections take place in line with the Congolese Constitution.

name: Charles GOERENS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, the citizens of the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) deserve better. At a time when everything invites the leaders of this country to fight corruption and to equip themselves with the means so that the state can assume its regal functions, the president thinks above all about his retention in power.  Initially scheduled for the end of November, the elections will finally be postponed for two years. Many leaders of other countries, tempted to do the same, have already argued that a census must be carried out first before they can begin the electoral process. In the DRC, it is the same. The pretext that the electoral file should be redesigned first is therefore not very original. The Belgian Foreign Minister reminded Radio la Première again this morning, saying that even if there were to be an overhaul, it could be done reasonably in a few months. This also seems to be the view of the opposition in Congo, which intends to sully the talks on this issue.  Congolese citizens who are committed to democracy and, in general, passionate about politics, are strongly opposed to these acts. They are condemned to suffer the action, if not the inaction, of their leaders more concerned with their personal ambition than with the fate of their people.  And yet, it all started well. The path of transition had allowed us to reconnect with democratic principles and the rule of law. Elections had been held, with the help of the international community, and in particular that of the European Union. Unfortunately, there is no panacea that can solve this problem in the immediate future. The pressure has to come from within. It is up to the Congolese people to move the lines. We can, of course, encourage the responsible currents, but the directions must be taken by the Congolese themselves. As for Europe, it must be said loud and clear, it will always be ready to engage in strong partnerships that will allow the Congolese to get out of the rut, once the conditions for doing so are met.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, we are once again talking about the situation in the Democratic Republic of Congo, a country that is being hit by so-called 'low-voltage' conflicts, which have claimed millions of lives, and one of the poorest countries in the world, while its underground is full of natural resources, including mining. It would be good to ask who funds armed groups and to defend the interests of whom. Joseph Kabila's term of office expires in December, and elections were due to take place in November. Kabila announced that the election would be postponed sine die on the grounds that the electoral file was not up to date and that 10 million young Congolese would be deprived of their right to vote.  For months, civil society and the opposition have been organizing and are victims of a ferocious repression. The events of late September are a sad symbol of this. It is an understatement to say that human rights are being violated in the Democratic Republic of Congo. In this country, as in others in Africa, leaders cling to power, and the only question is: how can we help the peoples of these countries to freely express their choice? In terms of its support, the European Union has a major responsibility in this regard. Every effort must be made to ensure that the Constitution and the rights, including the opposition, are respected to allow elections to be held in the best possible conditions and as soon as possible, so that the Congolese can finally decide their fate.

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. I have not fully understood the perspective the Council now paints in our relations with congo. We have all understood that Kabila wants to stay in power longer, that he follows the example of countries around him. Think of the current terrible situation in Burundi and the fear that everyone has that it will spill over to other countries.  I would therefore like to know what kind of action we have in the direction of Mr Kabila. I heard Mr Demesmaeker talk about sanctions, smart sanctions: the freezing of funds, the withdrawal of travel opportunities for Mr Kabila's entourage. That seems to me to be an incredibly sensible move. I would also like to see the Council's response to it.  I would also like to stress once again that we must complete our legislation to combat trade in conflict minerals as soon as possible. We are in trialogue with you and the European Commission. Let us forge the iron when it is hot and use it quickly as a means of letting Mr Kabila know that we seriously believe that his time has come.  Finally, Mr President, you are calling on the opposition to participate in the national dialogue. That seems to me to be a very difficult question at the moment. Even in view of the fact that the Catholic Church – very important in Congo – does not participate in a national dialogue, this is a question that can count on few or no positive reactions.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Great Lakes region is the greatest humanitarian disaster; it is not Syria that we have been talking about. Millions of people died there. This is a country that I know well, as President of the European Institute for Cooperation. I was the president of the largest NGO, and I was placed with The now deceased Vice-President Z'ahidi Ngoma, a friend who fought for the democratic transition and represented the democratic opposition during the democratic transition in 2004. He gave life for his country. So let's talk about democracy, and I'd like to remind you of a story that I know well, of which I myself was an actor.  In the Democratic Republic of Congo, the so-called "rebel" operation actually masked an invasion organized by the United States, which used Laurent-Desiré Kabila. As he advanced, Clinton's envoys signed mining contracts, like Biden's men currently in Ukraine. Let's talk about democracy! Laurent-Desiré Kabila, stopped by France and Angola, is closing in on France because he believed it was the interests of the Democratic Republic of Congo. You, the Belgians, and I can give clarifications if necessary, with the permission of the Americans, you have decided to assassinate him. Then Joseph Kabila succeeded him. He was your man but, concerned about the sovereignty of his country and its independence, he no longer suits you.  The DRC needs stability, not your interventionism oriented according to varying interests. Any further instability in this area is tantamount to re-condemning millions of civilians to death. All of sub-Saharan Africa will sink if the region falls into chaos again.  What Africa needs is sovereignty and self-centered development. It needs legitimate governments to take care of The Peoples of Africa and its development. Yes to the sovereign democracy of a broad democratic coalition with Joseph Kabila for the future of this region where Western interventionism has killed 4 to 5 million Africans in the Great Lakes region. What Africans need is to be masters at home.

name: Maria ARENA
text: Mr President, I am particularly surprised by the Council's optimism that there has been progress in dialogue. I would like to ask him a question: what progress exactly is he talking about? On the contrary, the violent repressions of 19 and 20 September show that this dialogue is not working. This so-called dialogue put in place by Mr Kabila's majority is not working. Moreover, the Catholic Church, which is an important player in this dialogue, has decided to leave it, as long as it does not have the guarantee of an inclusive framework that allows a compromise acceptable to all to be found. And this compromise must include the following elements: a totally impartial CENI, a credible timetable, important means to hold elections, the fight against impunity and, finally, the release of political prisoners today - not a release as Mr Kabila announced, but an unconditional release of these political prisoners, which also allows them to conduct an election campaign. Indeed, freeing political prisoners by telling them that, if they campaign, they will end up in prison again, I do not think it is an environment conducive to open elections. Finally, I think, and I also share the idea, that we should have targeted sanctions and, again, I ask the Council: what is the position of the Member States with regard to these targeted sanctions as the United States has decided them? We are told that if the United States had not issued these targeted sanctions, the crackdown on the 19th would have been much stronger than it has been today. I will end by referring to the east of Congo, which is once again under the control of rebels. These are the current rebels, but also those who come from South Sudan. It is important to be concerned about what is happening in the east, and in particular the financing of these rebels through the minerals of conflict. We have this legislation, we are waiting for the Council to also be able to adopt what we have adopted here in Parliament.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: – The situation is worse than we think. I hear firsthand from family and friends that the situation is taking on dramatic proportions. Congo has fallen into civil war and is well on its way to becoming a second Syria. Those are not my words, but the words of the people on the ground.  And what do I see? I see the United States freezing the assets of a number of generals. I note that the Americans are putting pressure on the Congolese government to call elections.  Then I ask myself: where is Europe? Are we going to wait for Congo to become a second Syria? Or are we taking action?  Mr. Minister, your statement disenchantes me. We, too, must exert pressure, impose targeted sanctions in the face of elections, freeze assets, impose an entry ban on those who commit human rights violations. And President Kabila must be clear that he cannot avoid a summons to the International Criminal Court if he continues to terrorize his fellow citizens. My heart bleeds when I see what's happening in Congo. I call for action.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Mr President, targeted sanctions against those who have confiscated democracy and are holding the Congolese people hostage. Targeted sanctions against those who violate the Constitution. Targeted sanctions against the perpetrators of crimes against humanity.  No impunity for those who deprive the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) of a true political, inclusive and transparent national dialogue in respect of the institutional framework: the ongoing dialogue is a charade.  No impunity for those who violate freedom of expression, freedom of the press and freedom of demonstration: the right to peaceful protest is a fundamental right, guaranteed by the Constitution in the DRC.  No impunity for those responsible for the multiple massacres in the territories of Beni, Butembo and Lubero and in the cities of Kinshasa, Kananga and Lubumbashi. I offer my condolences to all the families of those who lost their lives fighting for freedom, justice and dignity.  No impunity for perpetrators of all forms of violence against women and children.  We call for free, credible and transparent elections in accordance with the Constitution in the Democratic Republic of Congo and international law. We call for the opening of the political space to all citizens with a project of an alternative society to the power in place. We call for the unconditional release of political prisoners and public opinion and all democracy activists - many of whom face the death penalty - as well as for the liberalisation of the media.  We argue for strict adherence to the principle of the separation of executive, legislative and judicial powers, as enshrined in the Constitution itself.  We pay tribute to all Congolese women at home and abroad who make their voices heard peacefully to defend democracy and the rule of law.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The resolution adopted by the European Parliament in March this year calls on the authorities of the Democratic Republic of congo to take clear action to ensure that the Constitution is respected and that democratic, transparent and timely elections are guaranteed before the end of 2016. According to recent reports, the date of the elections will be postponed, which the authorities explain in order of issues related to the updating of the electoral register and budgetary problems. This decision will increase political tension and protests by the opposition and civil society, which are bloodily suppressed by security forces. As we know, several dozen people were killed in clashes in Kinshasa last week. The current political situation, in particular the uncertainty surrounding President Kabba's attempts to maintain power illegally, requires a strong response, pressure from the international community not to repeat the tragic events of 1996-2003.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Congo is facing a political crisis that threatens to undermine the country's path. The Constitution provides for a maximum term of two presidential terms, but the current President Kabila, who has been in power since 2001, does not seem willing to comply with this provision. The concern is that the instability of the country may spread throughout the Great Lakes region, as has been the case in the past. A scenario that would mainly involve civilian populations and could lead to new internal and neighbouring migrations. This scenario must be averted if we are not to be faced with yet another humanitarian catastrophe. Unfortunately, the continuing postponements of the elections scheduled for November are dragging the Democratic Republic of Congo into chaos and violence. It is absolutely essential to ensure that these elections are held as soon as possible and with due regard for the democratic game and rules that can guarantee fairness and equal opportunities for all participants. Europe must work to respect the Constitutional Pact and to foster dialogue between the parties.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, the latest developments in the Democratic Republic of Congo are causing serious concern in the international community, since the country cannot withstand any more destabilisation, it cannot withstand any more insidious games on the backs of its people. Kabila's decision to extend his presidential term has sparked a storm of opposition reactions and huge protests and bloody riots. At least 17 people have already been killed. European diplomacy must therefore not accept the terms of poker played by Kabila, the so-called guarantor of stability, in order to remain in power. Restoring stability can only be achieved by respecting the Constitution and by holding elections smoothly within the deadlines laid down.  But the existence of military groups and local conflicts in Congo certainly have a specific objective, controlling the exploitation of the rich natural resources of that huge country. So if there is one thing Europe can do to protect the Congolese people, it is to stop the illegal activities of some European multinationals in the country and certainly not to interfere in its internal policy.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, this has been a very useful exchange, and I am grateful to members for their very valuable interventions from this debate. That is my first general remark. I conclude that we all share a common interest in using all the tools at our disposal to encourage all political actors in the DRC to seek consensus within the framework of the Constitution then of UN Security Council Resolution 2277 and to ensure the full protection of the rights and freedoms of all citizens. Honourable Member Arena, you are right. I have referred to progress, but it was rather limited progress and I also stressed that the challenge now is to achieve greater inclusivity in participation and greater substance in discussions.  Secondly, on sanctions, I would like to say and recall that the EU will review the use of all tools at its disposal to act against those linked with violence and incitement of violence. I stress in particular our emphasis on individual responsibility covering all actors, and in addition our insistence that the security forces are responsible for maintaining public order within the rule of law.  Finally, a number of Members referred to the importance of civil society in making democracy work in the Democratic Republic of Congo, I strongly support that and we will continue to use our means to encourage and support these activities.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. – The security situation in the Democratic Republic of congo continues to deteriorate. Since the regime's fall in 1997, the country has waged a constant civil war that has so far taken more than 5 million casualties. Due to the lack of any conditions, people live in extreme misery and poverty, and war has even changed the role of women and children. They must fight on the front line and face the harsh reality every day, being the victims of direct attacks and violence per carried out by the warring parties. Along with the country's military conflict, dozens of people have died in clashes between protesters and security forces in recent days. President Kabila's undemocratic maneuvers to stay in power have unleashed a new wave of violence, and the international community must oppose it. I call for full respect for human rights and protection of civilians, as well as for the possibility of widespread involvement of civil society in the country's political processes. Only then will the Democratic Republic of Congo go down the path of democracy.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, I am pleased to participate in today’s debate on the situation of women’s rights in Poland. Respect for women’s rights and gender equality is part of European integration. However, as you know, the EU has no competences on abortion policy and cannot interfere in Member States’ policies in this area. According to the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, the definition of health policies and the organisation and delivery of health services and medical care is primarily the responsibility of individual Member States.  Having said that, I would very much hope that Poland will not stop progressing towards gender equality but rather continue to build on the genuine achievements of the past years. Poland has, for example, introduced an electoral gender quota system. It has also made great reforms improving work-life balance, such as the extension of the duration of basic maternity leave to 20 weeks, the introduction of paternity leave, parental leave arrangements and an increase in the accessibility of preschool education. Even though the electoral gender quota has increased the number of women on electoral lists it has not translated into a considerable increase of women’s actual participation in politics, yet.  The gender gap in employment rates continues to undermine the potential of many economies in Europe. In Poland it is particularly high among older women leaving the labour market earlier than men, and among young mothers because of still insufficient access to childcare. In the 2016 country specific recommendations Poland was encouraged to step up efforts to increase female labour market participation.  So, let me conclude by restating our genuine commitment to women’s rights and gender equality and my hope that we can continue to work with the Polish authorities to achieve further progress in the area. I am looking forward to today’s discussion, and at the end of this discussion I will enjoy the privilege to add also a few words from my personal side.

name: Barbara KUDRYCKA
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Thousands, tens of thousands of Polek took to the streets with banners on Monday. Strong, united, intransiuous. This black march touched the world. He also touched on the European Parliament because it was not just an opposition to the cruel abortion bill, which piS gave the green light to by adopting it in the Sejm. They want to withdraw from this out of fear today, because this march is a struggle for freedom, for dignity, for the right to choose, for life in a modern European country. We are Polish to this and the current government will not change that. This march is our strong 'no' to PiS's attempts to appropriate further spheres of life, especially those concerning our privacy and our families. I turn to the rulers in Poland. You have hearts of stone. Women are not the commodity to pay off your electoral obligations. You have no right to force a woman to make a decision other than what she feels, because it will settle in her own conscience, especially when pregnancy threatens her life or is caused by rape. For the decision to remove the pregnancy, you wanted to put women in jail. But did you want to put women in jail? There is no permission for this. There is no consent and never will be. If laws were introduced that would strike at women's constitutional rights, no one could challenge them with a paralyzed Constitutional Court. Despite the rejection of them today by a committee in the Sejm, the problem is not solved. Respect the compromise that is currently in place, if only because there is no room for substantive discussion in a country whose government is hitting an independent judiciary and media freedom. We don't need another ideological war – a war in which you have further entangled doctors. It is the responsibility of the doctor to follow medical science and knowledge. All statistics show that tightening the rules does not reduce, but increases the number of abortions. Leave your conscience to women. They should make a choice, often a dramatically difficult, heroic choice. Leave it to us. (The speaker agreed to answer the question asked by raising the blue card article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Bolesław G. PIECHA
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – Madam President, i would like to thank the Rapporteur, Mr S World-view issues, including how abortion is regulated, do not fall within the competence of the European Union. We believe that the European Parliament is not there to discuss moral problems – Mr Janusz Lewandowski a few days ago. What happened that you changed your mind so dramatically and suddenly? Second question: Have you personally congratulated members of your PPE political group, members of the PSL, who have requested that the citizens' law be rejected and have carried it out effectively in the Sejm? They deserve congratulations or relegation from the group.

name: Barbara KUDRYCKA
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Today, the European Parliament does not regulate the affairs of women in Poland. We don't do that. But he can discuss what he wants.

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: On behalf of the Group of the Party of European People's Party (S&D). – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I can say that we have won a first battle: I have just learned that the obscurantist proposal for an abortion law in Poland was rejected in committee. It's not the final decision, but it's a first win we had, which is very important. That is why we, together with the Polish delegation in my group and all our colleagues in the group, were dressed in black on Monday. We have worn black, joining millions of Polish women and men who have courageously stood up for their fundamental rights. This is proof that solidarity knows no borders, it knows how to achieve concrete results. It is an important day for women and for the defence of human rights. My group has always fought to promote a progressive vision of the fundamental rights and values of the European Union. Women's rights are the responsibility of the whole human race. Combating all forms of violation of these rights is an obligation of all. The strengthening of women's power of action means the progress of all humanity. Respect for fundamental rights and equality between men and women is enshrined in Article 2 of the Treaty on European Union and cannot be the subject of negotiation or negotiation. Membership of the European Union means ensuring that certain inalienable principles are fully respected in all Member States. This is under threat in Poland and we are therefore in favour of polish citizens and not, as they say, against them. We do not want to interfere at all, other than when the rights and prerogatives of Polish citizens are threatened.  Now, the proposal has not yet been concluded. We will be watching very closely and we hope that the Polish Parliament will define this proposal in the final negative. Otherwise there will be very strong opposition from the overwhelming majority of this Parliament.  (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Marek JUREK
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – The Lord remembers that the second article of the Charter of Fundamental Rights makes it clear in the first paragraph that every person has the right to life, and the second paragraph of this article states that no one can be sentenced to death even by a public authority, much less by a private person. I understand that you despise those 500 000 Poles who signed this statutory bill and you won today with the Constitutional Court in Poland, which in 1997 said that the right to life is the foundation of a democratic rule of law, that its value cannot be differentiated at any stage. Yes, today ideology has won against constitutional democracy in Poland, and you have shown that the Court in Poland is only a tool for you to fight politics.

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: Answer to a blue card question. There is modern legislation throughout Europe that guarantees the right to termination of pregnancy, which is obviously not an obligation but a choice linked to women's self-determination. Do you want a woman to carry to the end a pregnancy of a foetus who will have died or who will be suffering from enormous pathologies, just because of an abstract principle of the right to life? That is not the right to life, that is the right to death, and we must avoid it.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear! I believe that our discussion is pointless, because you want to discuss a law that is not there and to speak on issues where the European Parliament has no powers. But if you already want to hear about the situation of women in Poland, I would be happy to supplement the Commissioner's knowledge and remind you that Poland, as one of the first countries, recognised women's svoters' rights, that it was in Poland, according to the data – Commissioner – Eurostat, that we have the smallest difference between salaries between men and women in terms of average pay, that it was the research of the Fundamental Rights Agency in 2014 that proved that the number of acts of violence against women in Poland, including rape, is one of the lowest in Europe. It was Poland that developed a very good system for the protection of working pregnant women. It is Polish law and justice government has prepared and implemented a good family support programme. It's worth talking about. Poland is a country that, after 1989, has a prime minister who is a woman for the third time after 1989. And Prime Minister Szydło was here in the European Parliament and she was referring to the issues that you are raising today.  Unfortunately, you probably did not listen attentively, because I cannot – unlike you – assume that you have such a bad will. You are looking for a replacement topic. You want to deal with issues that are not within the competence of the EU institutions. Yet we should look at the migration crisis, the security crisis, the economic crisis, but you want women's rights. Why have we not debated or debated the situation of women in Germany in the European Parliament? Do you remember what happened on New Year's Eve in many German cities and what happened during the last Oktoberfest? Maybe your left-wing sensibility will see the situation of women in Germany, where their rights are being violated? But no, you want to deal with Poland, because Poland is unfortunate, that it has such an opposition that loves to talk badly about its homeland. Let me emphasise once again: none of the EU Treaties confers competence on the Union on philosophical issues, on the contrary, the interference of the EU institutions in these matters is inadmissible, as the EU Court of Justice has also confirmed. Nor is there any justification for interfering with these issues, Commissioner, in the Charter of Fundamental Rights. Yesterday, Prime Minister Beata Szydło once again confirmed that Polish government – maybe this crazy Polish opposition will finally hear, uneasy ears – is not working to change the law in this regard. It turns out that you are outraged that citizens in Poland have submitted a citizens' project to the Polish Parliament on the issue of the protection of life, i.e. the EU Parliament would like to take away the right of Polish citizens to a citizens' initiative. You will not shout the truth. So you want to discuss a law that is not there and on which the European Parliament has nothing to say. (The speaker agreed to answer the question asked by raising the blue card (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: blue-card question. – For somebody who does not want to discuss abortion in plenary, I think it is quite funny that you just spent four minutes talking about it.  The thing is, we hear the argument every time we debate this issue – whether it is about Poland, Spain or Ireland – saying the EU has no competence in this area. Then, I wonder, do you support the citizens’ initiative ‘One of us’, which is actually addressing abortion at European level? Are you not applying double standards a little bit here, saying that we are not allowed to talk about this, but you are allowed to raise the issue of abortion because you are against choice? I would really like to understand.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – Madam President, i would like to thank the Rapporteur, Mr S It seemed to me that I spoke quite clearly, so perhaps the translation did not keep up. But I talked about the situation of women in Poland. Your statement gives evidence that the situation of women in Poland does not care at all, but you are only interested in one question: whether women in Poland will have free access to abortion. So for you, women's rights are equated with free access to abortion. For me, no.

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ALDE Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the I am pleased that we are having this debate here today. I think it is very important that we, as representatives of the European Community of Values, support women in Poland, but also everywhere else, in the fight for their rights and against a ban on abortion. I would like to make one thing very clear here: an attack on women's rights is always also an attack on liberal democracy and an open society. A key part of this is respect for human rights and women's rights.  As soon as we start attacking this in any way, we endanger the value society in which we live and of which we are very proud. And are nitforth our society in which we live and the progressive position of women in it – at least outwardly? Are we not using every conceivable way to teach other cultures about our values and put them on a pedestal? When I look at the increasing number of people in Europe who have recently described themselves as feminists when it comes to condemning people and practices from other cultures or religions, I discover a certain hypocrisy. Because where are these people now when it comes to defending women's rights when it comes to abortion? Within Europe, we often take this very seriously with women's rights and, unfortunately, with human rights. Whether it's Orban's refugee policy or Poland's access to women's rights, we apply double standards. One thing must be clear: the female body has always been a political battleground and will probably remain so for a long time to come. Gender plays a central role in politics. Women are being used to fight disputes between the state and society: this is demonstrated by the excessive debate on the burkini ban this summer. As a woman and as a politician, I can only say one thing: my body belongs to me, and the more often and louder we women repeat this sentence, the sooner it will become a reality!

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: On behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr History shows that women's right to their bodies can never be taken for granted. History also shows that this has never been a strictly national issue. Solidarity has always been cross-border, just as here tonight. More than 40 years ago, Swedish and French women had to go to Poland to be able to decide over their own body and whether they wanted a pregnancy or not. Today Polish women can get to Sweden, you are welcome. The new law is a terrible blow to women's rights and women's bodies. But the current law, the one in force now, is also a violation of women's rights. Let's establish it tonight. There are too many, men above all, in this house who choose to systematically turn their eyes away when it comes to women's human rights. But I'll put it this way: There are few things that are as fundamental as being in charge of one's own body. And that right, it is so central to those of us who believe in equality.  One of our Polish colleagues just said to me: 'I will wear black until this disgusting bill has been scrapped'. To her and my Polish friends who are also here tonight, I would just like to say 'you are not alone'. When the Spanish Conservative Government threatened to ban abortion again in Spain, we – women and men who believe in basic equality – took to the streets of almost every city in Europe. We will do it again, and we will not rest, because the attack on your rights, on your bodies, is an attack on the rights of all of us. We will not give up, we will fight for your freedom, but also for the freedom of all of us to decide over our body and our sexuality.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, dear European women and most of all, dear Polish women, brave women have fought in the past for me to have the right to speak in this Chamber and to address you. I am every day of my life thankful for their struggle to give me this privilege and this right. Today I am going to use the speaking time that I get in this debate in order to make voices heard that have very often been overheard and overlooked in the debate. They are those of the brave Polish activists who have been fighting in the streets, in the parliament and everywhere in Poland in the last weeks and months.  This is what they asked me to say: we demand respect for our dignity and bodily integrity, our right to privacy, health and life protection, restoration of full reproductive rights, effective enforcement of alimony payments, severe punishment for rapists, severe punishment for perpetrators of domestic violence, sexual education for children, access to medical care. We demand equality and respect for women’s dignity. I salute these women because what these women need is not a law oppressing their right to their own bodies. What these women need is equality. What these women need is protection from violence and what these women need is a clear commitment from all of us to fight for their rights and to help them also in times when women’s rights and fundamental rights are being attacked all over the European Union. I want to say to them today that I thank them for their struggle, for their energy and for the hope that they have put into this, over the last weeks and months, and that we will stand side by side with them in solidarity because their struggle is our struggle and their rights are our rights. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – Madam President, do you realise that the pretext for today's debate is that you have misled Members? Polish government has not prepared any drafts, and Polish government in the election campaign has promised to look at all citizens' projects with special attention. And such a project was submitted by 500,000 Polish citizens. And these protests should be against the authors of this project, while the opposition in Poland used this to attack the Polish government that did not prepare this project. I will say more. A few hours ago, this proposal was rejected in its entirety in committee of the Polish Parliament. Do you realize?

name: Terry REINTKE
text: blue-card answer. – You are speaking to a political scientist here. What is very obvious is that this proposal has been moved forward to the Commission by a majority of parliamentarians in the Polish Parliament. You cannot now say that you are not taking the accountability for this move, because the parliamentarians in the Polish Parliament could have said that they were not voting in favour of that and that they were going to have an open debate. There was a counter proposal ‘Save the women’ and you could also have had an open debate looking at liberalising the abortion law that exists in Poland, but you did not. You proposed to move forward only with one of the proposals and you cannot now tell us that you are not taking the responsibility for that, I am sorry.  (Applause)

name: Michał MARUSIK
text: On behalf of the ENF Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by We are not a Polish parliament, so if we are talking about a range of rights, we should be talking about these rights for all the countries of the European Union, not just the Polish, which means that, apparently, this debate here is a kind of gift to Polish pro-abortion circles, because right now the subject of legal protection of life conceived in Poland is a topic being considered by parliament Polish. In Poland, we have the opportunity to get acquainted with the basic facts in this area. The Polish press is just now reminding us of quite shocking facts and information. I will give just one such fact, because there is little time: abortion is subject to meticulous statistical research and includes the so-called civilizational West. It doesn't include buddhists or Islamists, because there's just no right to abortion, and it's not registered there. At the moment we have public press releases in Poland about the number of abortions performed. In all Western countries, a total of 50 million legally registered abortions are carried out each year. Let's think about that figure, I'm shocked by it myself. After all, much fewer people died worldwide throughout The Second World War, and the war lasted six years. This is, after all, more than the size of Polish, that is probably more than the size of the whole of Spain. Isn't this the collective suicide of Western civilization?  So is it any wonder that this depopulated land is now inhabited by Islamists? After all, we forget god's basic command. The Lord God has told man: go, multiply and populate the earth, yet we depopulate this land. Once, with respect for ethics, a great Latin civilization was built here, and today its remnants are dying. The future must be built on the basis of respect... (The President has received the speaker's vote.)  (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – Would you agree that the debate on women's rights is within the competence of the European Parliament? And will you agree with the fact that women from all European countries have still not obtained these rights, and that, therefore, Monday's women's protest, which we watched on TELEVISION and watched on social media, is an example of the fact that this balance is extremely fragile and very easy to break, and it is our duty to uphold these rights and discuss it?

name: Michał MARUSIK
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – Yes, I agree that women's rights are rights that are broader than women's rights in Poland, they affect women in Europe and around the world. All these rights should be universal and created on the basis of universal ethics. If women's rights are violated in some place, it is mainly the right to life of women who have not yet seen the world because they are too young and dependent, because they are still in the womb of mothers and can be completely legally and with impunity deprived of life. These women are really very badly harmed by the law and this should be corrected.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: – Thank you, Mr President. Demonstrations are underway in Poland under the slogan "Let's save women!" This should be supported. However, it is also necessary to think of a reasonable compromise, because society is divided almost equally.  I recall that Article 23 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights states: "Equality between men and women must be ensured in all areas ....  The principle of equality shall not prevent the maintenance or adoption of measures providing specific benefits for persons of the under-represented sex.' This principle must therefore be applied here, because among unborn children the female sex is less numerous. So I propose to assume that abortion is allowed, but little girls must not be killed.  This would almost halve the number of abortions, while at the same time protecting women, as you are concerned. European ethics make it essential for us to protect women and children in the first place. Let's do it finally! The saved girls will be grateful to us. Like the famous blind singer, Mr. Bocelli thanked his mother. However, men's rights must not be forgotten. After all, half of the genetic material belongs to the father. It is therefore necessary that the father's consent must also be required to kill the child. After all, if the birth of a child depended solely on the mother, maintenance would be unjustified, for example. The father and mother have the same rights to the child before birth and must have the same rights after birth, because the child does not belong to the mother – it also belongs to the father. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: "blue card" question. I really want to ask you a question. Imagine you're a woman. You're brutally raped, brutally taken by a man. You're pregnant. You are obliged to give birth to that child and that child looks like your rapist. Do you think that mother can love that child? Do you think that's doing the fetus a service? Please, give women the right to their bodies, protect women's rights and the fetus.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. "Yes, I can imagine someone attacking me and sticking my back, including my back, such a tiny two-month-old baby. And this glue will release only after nine months, before it will not release. I ask you, do I have the right to kill this child then? Because for nine months I have to wear them on my back, the glue will not let go. I have the right to kill or not?

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, the legislation governing access to abortion is exclusively a matter for the EU Member States, but unfortunately in Poland a law was debated at first reading, provoking large protests in Poland. And I understand the Polish colleagues in the European Parliament who have asked us for a gesture of solidarity, and that is why I am ying.  When I tabled a bill in the Czech Parliament in 2003 to protect unborn life and to tighten access to abortion, I was inspired by the law that is in place today in Poland. Poland has a law that allows abortion only in the event of a threat to a woman's life or rape, as well as the number of abortions, 2000 per year, corresponds to this. What does not correspond to this is that poland is failing to increase the number of births.  Colleagues, we can't just protect lives with bans. To encourage young people to have children, mothers, not to be afraid to give birth, we need to create favourable conditions and be able to appreciate motherhood. Today's society values material values, people fear poverty and social insecurity.  Personally, I am against abortion and I think that everything needs to be done to ensure that women do not have to make abortion choices so that they can look forward to their children. These measures, of course, include a number of social measures, affordable housing, affordable care for young children, the offer of work opportunities, but the first condition will always be responsible behaviour, which should also be helped by the education of responsible parenting and the social recognition of the value of motherhood. Ladies and gentlemen, I wish Poland that we do not have to repeat such debates here in Parliament. It is up to the Polish Parliament and the Government to decide on ethical issues in Poland. However, if they provoke protests, citizens in the Member States should know that MEPs will be in solidarity and support the position of their colleagues.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: – Mr President, in January 2014 we were discussing in this House the attack on women's rights in Spain with the change of restrictive abortion legislation by the Spanish Government of the People's Party. They intended to end decades of women's struggle for the right to decide on their bodies, for freedom. Tens of thousands of people took to the streets throughout the Union as a show of solidarity. It was not just an attack on the dignity of Spanish women; it also meant opening the door to those who do not want Europe to be a space of respect and dignity. Two years later we return to the starting point. Today it's Polish women. Who's it going to be tomorrow? Can we accept that in 21st-century Europe our daughters will have fewer rights than our mothers? The law that is being brought to this debate today is a violation of international rights. It prohibits abortion of women who are victims of rape. Health workers who assist these women may be imprisoned. This situation will also lead to economic inequality, because those women with means and money will be able to go out to abort outside Poland and those who do not have them will be forced into clandestine abortions in Poland with the risk of their lives. This situation does not allow our resignation: on the contrary, it forces us to raise our voices, to prevent it from continuing to decide on our lives and on our destiny. From here, my absolute support for the women of Poland. Know that you are not alone, that your freedom is our struggle and that today's black horizon can become, with our efforts, a color of hope. (She agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – Dear Lady, I have a simple question, because from what I have understood and from what you have said, it follows that you are completely, I repeat: you completely do not know what the situation of women in Poland is like. You do not know the facts. You have no idea about this when you talk about going abroad on abortion issues. This simply shows that you are completely unprepared for this debate. But I would like to ask you if you know – if you will get up here and answer my question – that in Poland, in Polish democratic country, the citizens' initiative has been conducted in accordance with the law of a democratic country in the Polish Parliament, that it is the government and the Polish government majority that has nothing to do with this project. Will you answer my question? Do you know this at all?

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: "blue card" response. – It seems that you come to give lessons: and to me, on this subject, none. I know that today women's rights in Poland are threatened: the right to decide on their lives, on their destiny. And when a woman in Europe sees her right threatened, she will have other European women defending freedom and the right to decide.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is a very good one. I clicked through the homepages of the political groups, and see: the EPP "believes in the value of subsidaritiy." The S&D claims that subsidiarity makes Europe strong. The ALDE proudly says: we support the principle of subsidiarity. The Greens even praise the green principle of subsidiarity. And even in the case of the GUE, there is talk of subsidiarity and proportionality. Prima! If you are committed to subsidiarity, please accept it – and not only when it comes to the very interests of your country or your party. Subsidiarity must apply to all, and if a country like Poland today, building on its constitution and the Charter of Fundamental Rights, discusses a law for the protection of unborn life – family policy and not women's policy – then, first of all, it is a sovereign national decision, a decision that the Polish Constitutional Court can overturn, a decision that the people of Poland can protest against. Do not misunderstand me, nor would I sign every passage of this bill at first reading. But let us respect subsidiarity! In other words, it is dangerous for some EU states to give the impression that other Member States ... (The President cut off the speaker) (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: blue-card question. – My question to you is very simple: how do you sleep at night? Do you not realise that dinosaurs like you belong to the past, not to the present and definitely not to the future? How do you sleep at night?

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. When I look back on my life, I can sleep very well. I have a happy wife, I have happy children, and I know that life with some people is not good. But I know that there are many who sometimes fight their way through their lives and end up finding happiness. In this respect, it is easy to iron everything out and that there is only one solution when problems arise, namely abortion, which is too short a thought. It must be possible for there to be countries that simply see it differently than you would like to see.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: – She insulted our colleague Gericke, you did not react. I would ask that we talk like civilised people, so that the Lord, in such a situation, should point out to colleagues that they are behaving inappropriately. And please also consider in the Bureau how to deal with such cases, because in other cases the debate-goers have reacted very harshly and even imposed penalties on participants in such a debate who are unable to behave.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: – Mr President, and also to the colleague who spoke previously, I think a lot has been said in this room that has been pretty insulting to women generally as well. We learned today that, for the time being, the law seems to be off the table, but I would say that is no reason for celebration because even the current Polish law on abortion is still the strictest in the European Union and it still does not give women the choice. Mr Gericke, you say you are happy with the choices you made in life but you had a choice. I think every woman, every man should have that choice, including in Poland.  Madam Commissioner, I heard you say – and I only partially agree with you – that abortion is not an EU matter. It is true that abortion laws are made by national governments and national parliaments, but that is not to say that the European Union has not to say anything. Abortion and sexual and reproductive health rights are part of public health policies in the Member States. We have competence in the area of public health policy. It is limited but it is there.
