I would call on this House to make sure that, in the next public health strategy, sexual and reproductive rights, including abortion, are included. This is also underlined by the fact that there is case law in the area of abortion. The Strasbourg Court has said very clearly that a total ban on abortion is a violation of human rights. We do have instruments, colleagues. This is not only about a debate on subsidiarity. This is on principles, this is on values, and those values apply also to Polish citizens and that is why we are having this debate. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – I would like to ask a colleague, because he seems to know very well the situation in Poland, the history of Polish, this problem that we are talking about. Do you know when the right of choice you are talking about has been introduced in Poland? In what years was it practiced?

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: blue-card answer. – We are talking about civilisation here, where women – do you actually want to have the answer? If you just want to orate here, that is fine as well but then I will sit down. OK?  I happen to believe – and apparently you disagree with me – that women are human beings and that human rights apply to everybody equally.  I also think that women are perfectly capable of taking decisions over their own bodies and their own lives. I have said that in a previous debate, when we were talking about Spain. If we think that women are capable of leading the United States or the IMF, if we think that women should be entrusted with the responsible task of raising and educating children who are becoming people, then surely they can be entrusted with a decision – a responsible decision – over their own bodies and their own lives. That is what I’m talking about.

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Polish draft law is worrying because it prohibits abortion in almost all circumstances. It is so worrying that a large women's movement has overwhelmed the government, which is perhaps thinking of another law that will perhaps exclude rape from the ban. But it will be a no less punitive law. Such laws will not improve, because they are part of a regression, to which Kaczynski gives the name of "cultural counterrevolution", focused on the total state-church merger and the violation of precise EU directives on non-discriminatory access to health. It is not true, therefore, that competence is only national. Even if the current law were to remain, it would not be progress, as it is among the most punitive in Europe. It is time to support the battle of Polish women. Their representatives are with us today, here in Strasbourg, they are up there, and I invite you all to greet them.  (The Speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Czesław HOC
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear Honourable Member, I would like to thank you for your excellent work. You probably know the famous saying of the British Prime Minister of the 1970s, James Callaghan, before the truth put on his shoes, a lie can promise half the world. You say that the Government of Law and Justice, that it is Prime Minister Kaczynski, the church, is making such rigorous changes. I want to tell you that this was and is a citizens' project, it was a citizens' project. You can remember and know that in Poland a fully democratic country citizens have the right to take a resolution initiative.  (The President has received the speaker's vote.)

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: Answer to a blue card question. You are also well aware, as I know, having been to Poland many times, that the weight of the Catholic hierarchy in Poland is extremely heavy. The bishops of the Polish Church have announced a Christian crusade on this law. I believe that the citizens in question are strongly influenced by this type of crusade and therefore by the non-separation of church and state that exists in Poland.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: – Madam President, today I stand by the women of Poland claiming their rights. I guess one of the feelings we have here, when we have all these brilliant men pundits talking about our body, and that we share with the women of Poland, is that we are not incubators; we are not reproductive machines. That is a general shared women’s right, and women’s rights are human rights. It is the right to our health, to our reproductive health, to our body, and to our freedom to choose. And yes, we should talk about that in this House. It should be a public debate.  Those who want to use the democratic rights of the people of Poland to increase nationalism, demagogy and populism are abusing this debate. It is about women that are being raped, women that are victims of incest, possible health complication, miscarriages. What do you men know about that? It is a matter of our health. We cannot be criminalised; no woman in the world can be criminalised for that. No doctor who is trying to help a woman with a health problem related to birth can be sent to prison when doing their job. That is what we are talking about tonight.   And yes, we in the PPE, think that family legislation is a national issue. Yes, we do think that it is up to the Polish Parliament to complete the ongoing process to legislate. And that is why I urge our dear colleagues in Warsaw and a government that seems to start finally seeing that women have a voice in Poland, to revise the law. I am wearing black in solidarity with the women of Poland tonight.

name: Maria ARENA
text: Madam President, it has already been said that the current Polish anti-abortion law is one of the most restrictive in Europe today. Despite this, two citizen initiatives have been put on the table: an obscurantist initiative, which further reduces rights, and a progressive initiative, which expands abortion rights. The Polish Parliament has decided to evacuate the progressive initiative and to examine the regressive initiative in relation to abortion. That is why, when you say that there is no will of Polish political actors to support an obscurantist law, you are lying. That is the one he was chosen to look at.  I will talk about the current law: it is this one, even if it is restrictive, it does not allow legal abortion for three reasons. The first reason is conscientious objection in Poland. While you must, Commissioner, ensure that the State organises this conscientious objection by guaranteeing the alternative, in Poland the alternative does not exist because doctors no longer want to perform legal abortion because of this conscientious objection, which is not properly applied. I therefore ask you, Commissioner, instead of saying that it is not within your competence, to take your competence and to have this conscientious objection properly activated at the Polish level. The second reality is that the lack of antenatal consultation - which is now permitted for abortion in Poland - means that when the malformation can be diagnosed, it is too late, because these antenatal consultations are not organised. Commissioner, you are in charge of this and you have to do it. The third reason is the lack of (inaudible) and education. I am sorry, it is a European competence, you do not activate this competence. It's your ... (The President cuts off the speaker's microphone)

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: – I may start with an answer, because Mrs in 't Veld did not answer my question. I would just like to remind you that the right to such a free choice, which you spoke of, was carried out in Poland in 1942. You can see on Wikipedia what those times were. We in Poland had times of free choice, very long. I remember the days when in Poland it was said that removing a pregnancy is like removing a tooth. And democratic Poland after 1989 broke with this practice, because it was a totalitarian practice, a totalitarian practice based on disrespect for life.  In Poland today we have no problem violating women's rights. And this debate has clearly shown that. In Poland, as everywhere in the world, there is a serious moral and legal problem, namely the dramatic issue of abortion. And you are saying here that this case is not dramatic, that it does not arise from anything. On the other hand, In my opinion, this problem stems from a conflict between two principles that you and we recognise, namely the autonomy of the human person regardless of his or her gender and the right to life regardless of age. Unfortunately, in this case, these two principles are in conflict, and we all know that solving this problem is very difficult, and we also know that pro-life and pro-choice movements exist throughout Europe and throughout the Western world. Discussions on this subject are also ongoing in Poland. Just the majority of Polish society takes a position behind life. (The President has received the speaker's vote) (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – Honourable Member, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Schwa Is it true that the political party you represent in this Parliament has promised millions of Poles that they will consider any citizens' project that will flow into the Polish Sejm? Is it true that, without any discussion, you have broken this promise by rejecting the 'Save women' project at the request of my political leader, who has exposed your hypocrisy? And is it true that you broke the word a second time today by rejecting another civic project, Ordo Iuris, without any discussion, after a game of appearances.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – I would like to point out that my colleague Jurek asked for a formal vote, but as far as your question is concerned, you may not have noticed, you may have checked it on the Pages of the European Parliament, that I am a non-partisan MEMBER, but less so. I represent the Republic of Poland here, all Poles, as do you, as do you. On the other hand, as to what you have asked, I would say this: I believe that it is our commitment, the Lord and mine, to listen to the citizens and to bring in these laws, to take account of the citizens' initiatives that are being put in place. As is well known, the vote on these two citizens' initiatives was guided by conscience, not party discipline. I do not know why this was voted on in the Polish Parliament. Polish Sejm... (The President has received the speaker's vote.)

name: Marek JUREK
text: – I would like to ask why the President so selectively gives blue cards. I understand that one person, but I would like to ask a very important question about Mrs Arena's Polish legal order. But unfortunately the President did not give me a voice... (The President has received the speaker's vote.)

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for We, women of Europe, are tired of men who want to control our bodies. Today we'll say it one more time. And today I hope that, from this House, that message will go out to all Polish women and all the other women around who are fighting against restrictive, reactionary abortion laws, so that they feel that that support exists and that we are sufficient against them at this moment. You are not alone and together we are strong.  We can never accept this barbarity, this abuse on women's bodies. Not today from the dark, reactionary conservative government in Poland, and not from any other government either. That's enough. Abortion must also not become a class issue where anyone who can afford to pay for safe abortion elsewhere, abroad, gets it, because access to sexual and reproductive health and rights is a right for all EU citizens.  I would like to say one more time: we, women of Europe, are tired of men who want to control our bodies. That's enough. (Cecilia Wikström declined a question ("blue card") from Urszula Krupa)

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: – Madam President, what is very clear to us, after taking a little debate here, is that again religious radicalism, in this Catholic case , I don't care what religion it is, Islam, Orthodox, whatever, but religious radicalism - once again attacks the rights, always, always absolutely, of women. It is time for us to understand that in a democratic society religious beliefs must remain in the personal sphere. A government cannot legislate under pressure from any religion. It has to govern, the state is responsible for guaranteeing all rights to all citizens and not just applying what they believe or their religion. It is very clear that, moreover, these reforms are always classists, because they affect those women who are going to play their lives because they do not have the financial resources to pay for a trip and go to abort in the face of incest, which is also forbidden in this bill, and to play their lives in places where you cannot. And, of course, Commissioner, you do have powers over human rights, and that is our rights. (She refused to answer a question from Ivo Vajgl, posed in accordance with the "blue card" procedure)

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: – Madam President, women are human beings and human rights belong to women. Women’s rights are human rights. Sexual and reproductive rights are part of human rights. This is an overall accepted principle in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the Beijing Declaration, even though some people refuse to accept that. On this basis, human rights – saving the dignity of human beings – is never an issue of subsidiarity. Never. You cannot decide that people that are left—handed, dark-haired or blue—eyed do not have services or should be discriminated against because they are different. It is not a matter of a political decision. This is an internationally—agreed and accepted principle. It is as simple as that. Democracy cannot mean that if you accept by democratic procedure violence, oppression or dictatorship, it would be acceptable. No. What this means is that the EU has not only the right, but also the duty to safeguard its core values – democracy, human rights and tolerance – and, if we fail to do that, we fail on our core substance. This is the crux of the matter, of the fight we are leading for Polish women. I am very saddened that we have to have this kind of discussion in this millennium in Europe, after what we have experienced and after what we have done locally, EU—wide and internationally for human rights. So please be civil, to create a civilisation. (Applause)

name: Birgit SIPPEL
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her In 1971, Stern magazine broke a taboo. More than 300 women publicly declared an abortion, sparking a long overdue debate. It is unspeakable that today, 45 years later, we are still arguing about whether women have the right to control their own bodies.  Of course, there are different morals. But that is why we need freedom of choice. Especially in difficult phases of life, women must be free to choose between pregnancy and pregnancy. They need legal access to safe abortion. What the government in Poland wants is to impose its ideas on all Polish women. And the PiS government's refusal to allow abortion sedatout even in 2016 is simply unacceptable to women who have been victims of rape.  At the weekend, thousands took to the streets in Warsaw for the freedom of Polish women and Polish society – it seems, with a first success, and I am glad that I was able to attend, because the protest is the task and obligation of all Europeans – men and women alike. And the same still applies: My belly belongs to me, my body, my rights. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: A question raised by raising a blue card. – We are running an unusual debate here today, so I will also have an unusual question. I would ask you, colleague, but can I apologise on behalf of all those who use this time of utterly inappropriate arguments today and insult women's dignity? Thank you very much. Do you accept an apology?

name: Birgit SIPPEL
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I am, of course, happy to accept any serious apology.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: – You will surely remember the turbulent debate a few months ago in the European Parliament after what happened in Germany on New Year's Eve, after the German women were humiliated, sexual violence was used against them, how they were raped and beaten. Remember this debate? You do not remember this debate because it was not there, because at that time you decided that this was not a topic worth discussing, and these were the real problems of women who were humiliated in their humanity – which I hear about here. At the time, the European Parliament did not have the courage to speak of these humiliated women. It is an example, however, that double standards are also applied in this regard, which I have also heard about here. However, some form of hypocrisy is used. Finally, we here in this parliament will have different views. It is clear from this that there is parliament. But I would ask for elementary respect for the facts. This was not an initiative of the Polish government. Please never say that, because it's just a lie. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: blue-card question. – I just want to remind you what the President said, that we have actually had that debate. Frankly I still do not understand what Cologne has to do with the debate today.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – Of course, unlike some of the ladies who are no longer in this House, such as Mrs Wikström, I will answer this question. Of course, not a debate like this, and if you do not see the problem of German women, that they have been humiliated, beaten, raped, then I will honestly tell you – let you say this to the German people!

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: – Madam President, Mrs Jorová, the party governing Poland is called 'Law and Justice', but the abortion law you have chosen to process is not law, it is cross-crossed; it is not fair, it is degrading; it is unacceptable; is involution and violates the universal human right to health, over which there is no subsidiarity that prevails. The Polish Law of '93 was already one of the most restrictive in Europe, but this new formulation takes us directly to the Middle Ages. It is intended to prohibit termination of pregnancy in any case: neither when a twelve-year-old girl is raped by her uncle, nor when a woman's life is in grave danger.  I know that the Prime Minister of Poland has no daughters, but if she did, I refuse to believe that she would be willing to sacrifice her life and her future.  We Europeans are not going to remain indifferent. We are not going to resign ourselves to the taking away of Polish women, half of Poland, of their dignity, rights and freedom, because this Parliament is the voice of the 500 million Europeans, including Polish citizens.

name: Krystyna ŁYBACKA
text: – I am speaking on behalf of the Polish delegation, the delegation in the social democratic faction, that is, on behalf of members of the Alliance of the Democratic Left and the Labour Union. I would like to stress with full force: I am not speaking out against Poland. I am speaking out in defence of the rights of Polish women, so I am speaking out in defence of human rights and human dignity. Opponents of this debate have repeatedly stressed that the European Parliament has no right to comment on world-view issues. Parliament does not have the right to adopt legislation in the area of worldview, but it even has a duty to speak out when the rights of women citizens of the European Union are at stake. Therefore, we will never remain silent on this matter. We will use every legal place to express solidarity with Polish women and to show them that they are not alone and that we are with them. And this is where the European Parliament's speakere is for us.  We have just learned that in the Polish Sejm the committee proposes to the House to reject a proposal tightening abortion law. Question: is it a belated reflection or is it a fear of mass protests and the screaming blackness of Polish women? I address this question to those who have to answer it for themselves. We won the battle, but we still have the whole battle ahead of us. The Sejm is to decide according to its conscience, as we know, but Polish women have their own conscience and have the right to their own decisions. In the event of further attempts at exacerbation, we will appeal to the will of the sovereign, that is, to the people. (The President received the speaker's vote) (The speaker agreed to answer the question asked by raising the blue card (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Mirosław PIOTROWSKI
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – Honourable Member, I would like to thank you for your excellent work. I would like to ask a question that has already been asked here from a Member of the Citizens' Platform and to which we have not received an answer. Namely, you asked whether today's debate is within the competence of the European Parliament and, in order to help answer this question, I just wanted to point out that less than three years ago, exactly 4 December 2013, our entire European Parliament voted here on Mrs Estrela's resolution on reproductive and sexual health and law in this area, where we voted at the first point, and I quote: Parliament notes that the definition and implementation of... (The President has received the speaker's vote.)

name: Krystyna ŁYBACKA
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – Mr President, I answer with all due respect to you, perhaps I explain. The resolution is not a right. It is also a kind of Parliament's opinion.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her (without microphone)... have this passionate debate. Last weekend, I had the opportunity to be in Poland with colleagues from the S&D Group – as a sign of solidarity and concern about developments in that country. We have spoken to many people and they have told us that European solidarity is important to them. That is why, as a sign of this solidarity, I am wearing black today. Poland is an important part of Europe.  Poland is something crucial for Europe, and that is why we must have European debates. Defending women's rights is a central, original European concern. Women's rights are human rights and women have a right to their own bodies. Under no circumstances should it be a question of punishing women when they claim this right.  Starting a family, having children, cannot and must not be forced. It is a climate of humanity. It is about help, not punishment. The question arises as to why the number of children born per woman is 1.58 on average in the EU, compared to only 1.3% in Poland, 2.0 in France and 1.8 in Sweden.  This situation shows us that we need to create a climate in which children are welcome, as the Polish Save the Women wants initiative. This is a common concern that we all share. I repeat: help, not punishment.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I turn to you, Mrs Wiśniewska, your false conscience speaks of the right to life. You are calling for Europe to deal with real problems, such as immigration. I now come from a meeting of the Parliamentary Assembly of the Union for the Mediterranean, with the presence of the Italian Coast Guard, which has rescued thousands of immigrants in the Mediterranean, but unfortunately many have died, they have not made it. Your country's government rejects European solidarity and supports Orban's initiatives. What right to life do you talk about? This is your false conscience. I fully support the struggle of Polish women and I am convinced that the current movement will defeat conservative and obscurantist positions, overwhelm this patriarchal terrorism present in different sectors of Polish society and return your beautiful country to the Europe of rights, because it is in this Europe of the right that it deserves to be.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: – I am speaking on a formal matter. Please do not apply double standards in this regard too. I understand that you can have different views, but Mrs in t'Veld used both the blue card procedure and the spoke. Why do you then deny this right to Mr Wiśniewska? Because he has different views? I hope not. Please apply really equal measures to everyone.  And yet, while i am at the fore, I would like to inform you that the President has misled our Parliament. There was no debate about women's rights violations in Germany, but in Cologne. These are euphemisms. We wanted a debate on women's rights in Germany, there was no debate.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: I cut off the bull's head. As we do not have time, I do not accept the request at all.  (The speaker refused to answer a blue card question from Mr Sley/ Wiśniewska (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: – Madam President, I am indeed amazed by some of the positions in this debate. This law is a complete setback in women's rights and, by inegency, in human rights. So this is a European issue. It is a repressive law which calls into question all the progress made in gender equality in Poland.  The priority should be to provide appropriate sex education and safeguard reproductive sexual rights. You must be facilitating access to contraception. It should be in the prevention of unwanted pregnancy and not in the limitation of women's choices. Banning and criminalizing abortion does not equate to fewer abortions, but to many more clandestine abortions. It means the use of hangers and needles inside women's bodies. We are talking about women who are at the mercy of infections and death and this law is a death sentence for thousands of women. It's taking away power from women in every way. The suspension of this law is a sign. But how long are we going to get this law suspended? How far will we tolerate a Member State's violation of human rights?

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: Madam President, a woman's body belongs to no one but herself. This is not an ideological battlefield, nor is it a national issue.  To prohibit a woman from freely disposing of her body is to violate her fundamental rights and to perpetrate extreme violence against her. It is to make her the victim of intolerable discrimination. On the contrary, defending the right to safe and legal abortion means protecting women's lives, health and dignity.  The proposed liberticidal and retrograde law threatening to ban abortion altogether in Poland is a disgrace. It is a shame to treat women who choose to have abortions as criminals and send them to prison, even in the most extreme cases of rape or incest. This is a disgrace to the European Union. It cannot remain credible to the rest of the world as long as it continues to turn a blind eye to how women's rights are being violated within itself. In the name of the founding principle of equality between women and men, in support of Polish women who are fighting for their rights and in order to protect all European women in the same way, the right to abortion must finally be recognised and guaranteed as a fundamental right by the European Union.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I will quote one midwife from Polish: "I am a woman, a mother of two adult daughters. I cannot calmly think what might threaten them if the law came into force. I'm also a midwife, so I have the closest contact with the nascent. I participate in the most intimate moments of their lives. I witness unimaginable happiness, but also unimaginable tragedies. I see a woman giving birth to a very sick child, then screaming in despair, and the child's father kicking into the wall with impotence. But it was they who decided to childbirth. It would be bestial to condemn everyone to this."  Finally, I would like to remind The PiS Members, and especially the Ministers of the PiS Government, that the most important issue in Europe is the rule of law and civil liberties. I am ashamed that, for the third time in the last ten months, the European arena has been discussing issues concerning PiS governments that violate and violate the rights of Polish citizens. You are ruining the achievements of the Polish generation, which for 25 years has built a brand and Polish in Europe.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, following the Polish Government's refusal to validate the appointment of five judges of the Constitutional Court and the adoption of laws allowing control of the media and prosecutors, poland is another blow to democracy. Parliament intends to pass a law providing for up to five years in prison for women who perform an abortion and for doctors who care for them, even in the event of rape or incest. My colleague Maria Arena rightly pointed out that the European Court of Human Rights had already challenged poland's existing abortion law, because it placed unacceptable obstacles in the way of access to safe and legal abortion. This rule definitively establishes the right of women to access termination of pregnancy even in serious cases. It is time for the European Union to make its voice heard and prevent further clearly undemocratic measures from being implemented in Poland. Women have the same dignity and rights throughout the continent and their rights cannot be affected at all, especially in a Member State of the European Union.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Madam President, the announcement of a stricter abortion law has alarmed a large number of Polish citizens, many of whom are protesting on the city streets. The responsible government respects the opinion of all citizens and gives clear answers to their questions and fears, so I am convinced that the Polish government will do the same in this particular case. The right to choose a woman must be defended. She must have the right to choose when to have sex, she must have the right to choose the person with whom she will do so and she must have the right to choose between different methods of contraception. If we want a free society, the woman in it must be free to make important decisions that primarily concern herself. But the freedom of each of us ends where someone else's begins. A woman's right to choose ends where the child's right to life begins! How to legisly regulate this in order to get the best results is a member state's question and the European Union has nothing to interfere with.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: – Madam President, with all due respect to the democratically elected government in Poland, I do not understand how she could choose to prefer a dark and reactionary policy in relation to women's rights.  I'm very sad and very proud today. Very sad, because we are talking about a thing that I thought in the 21st century was not possible at all to be on the agenda in any country. And very proud of the majority of the European Parliament, which has shown Polish women that they are not alone in this.  But, Commissioner, let me ask you one thing. We must move from words to action, because if we do not do so, we are in danger of polish women dying as a result of not being able to undergo a life-saving procedure, and we may also be in danger of following similar dark and medieval laws in Poland. I don't want that, and I firmly believe that neither do you.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: – Madam President, first of all, thank you for the presence of the activists who joined us today. Your fight is our struggle, I want to make this very clear first. Secondly, it seems to me that what has become very clear today is that there are members in this House who have neither dared to defend the law of their own Government. They tell us about Cologne... tell us that this has nothing to do with them.... they dare not even defend it, when it is a criminal law, which seeks to criminalize abortion, send women to prison for the right to choose and decide on their own bodies; a law that violates the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union; a law that violates the public health legislation of the European Union, Commissioner; yes, it violates the law. You have instruments to act, we have told you. And the last thing I want to say, and very importantly: this is not an attack on Poland, this is in favor of the rights of Poles, just as when an anti-abortion law was attempted in Spain and which violated the rights of women in Spain, the whole House, many people in the House, wanted to stand in solidarity , and today we do so with Poles and Polish women, because women's rights are universal, indivisible, non-negotiable, firmly rooted in international law and the acquis communautaire, and we do not negotiate or allow it to be negotiated with them.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: – At the outset, I would like to thank Mrs PiS for acknowledging the achievements of the Platform government and the PSL on improving the situation of women in Poland, because in fact we have done a lot in this matter. And now the facts, ladies and about: 230 PiS Members, including many ministers, have supported a citizens' project to tighten abortion law. You were talking about human dignity, about life, about the protection of life. Today you were frightened of the women's protest, you were frightened of this debate in Parliament and you quickly rejected this bill at the request of Mr PiS. Today, women in Poland have won, but you really show that you are a hypocrite, that there is no holiness for you, that you are able to do everything for the pillars and support and out of fear, and that is the misfortune of the Polish. Shame on you!

name: Julie WARD
text: –  Madam President, I want to say thank you to the many ‘black protest’ Polish women who have come here today, and with whom I and others stand in solidarity, speaking up for women’s rights, which are most definitely human rights. You come from all walks of life and many of you have never been active in the public sphere before. You are different ages and from different socio-economic backgrounds and I know that because we have met today.  Faced with the worst kind of misogyny, repression and violation you have found your voices and here in the European Parliament you have found a place to amplify that voice. You are now empowered and you must take courage and continue to occupy public space with your powerful, beautiful, creative actions because the women who come after you and the women and girls in other countries who are also depending, who are also under attack from the right-wing repressive policies, they are also depending on you to lead the way. Thank you. Continue to speak up. Together we can be strong.

name: Julie WARD
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, as Commissioner, I have remained the wife and mother of my daughter, and therefore I would like to express myself as a woman in my final word, and I would like to do so in my native language, I would like to do so in Czech, because I also see a certain symbolism in this.  I think, as a person who has Polish ances, as a person who, I think, quite understands the Polish language and understands Poles in many things, including a certain sensitivity and vigilance to situations where they want, like the Czechs, like all other peoples in Europe, to decide the essential things themselves. I understand the Poles that this vigilance comes from the fact that we have experienced a time in an undemocratic society, a time and a regime that did not recognise the freedom and dignity of the individual. I personally remember it when the revolution was in 1989, I was 25 years old.  What I don't understand is a bill that I hope won't be dragged into final approval because I don't think it's the abortion law, but that it's a law against people, that it's a law against human dignity, against a person's freedom, against a woman's freedom to decide on her body and her life.  It is a particularly powerful moment for me and a symbolic moment that I say here today on the day that Czech President Václav Havel would celebrate his 80th birthday, because he was the one who always championed individual freedom and the dignity of man. Yes, ladies and gentlemen, I have said here before that I completely respect and respect the competence problem in the sense that the European Union does not have the competence to order any state legislation concerning reproductive rights, but at the same time I am in that dilemma, because I value human freedom and dignity above all else.  And I dare remind myself of the very strong moments we had here together, when Pope Francis was here before Christmas in 2014, I was fresh from office, and he made a lot of strong appeals to us as politicians. Among other things, he said, "You have forgotten the dignity of the individual for all institutions, procedures, jurisdictional disputes." And I am reminded of this here today in the sense and in the context that there have been words that the debate is unnecessary, that we should not even be talking about it here, because here we have a problem with subsidiarity. Nevertheless, I think that we should talk about these things here, and that it is very important when each of us walks out in front of the trenches and tells for himself how he perceives it, because the problem that we are talking about here today is also very subtle, very intimate, and I believe that rightly so is called a matter of conscience.  At the same time, I would like to point out that I believe that the vast majority of women who have to have an abortion do not do so out of their free choice, that they do so under the pressure of reality, and that we should not deny them that decision.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: in writing. – Women in Poland and all Europe are astounded by the current debate on abortion rights held in Poland. If the proposed tightening passes, it means nothing less than a woman will not be able to undergo an abortion even after rape or incest – and will not be able to interrupt a pregnancy in cases where it is obvious that the child will be born with severe disabilities. This is not a policy we should ever support in the EU of the 21st century. Every woman should have the right to choose; we all have the right to choose. It is illusory to think that such a law would eradicate abortions. It will just make them illegal and more dangerous. The result will be abortion tourism, and for those who cannot afford it, illegal abortion under terrible conditions risking health and even sometimes the life of a woman. Let me put it clearly: such a proposal brings us back to Middle Ages and has no place in modern European society. It has to be denied strictly and immediately. I want to make sure that Polish women know we are with them in their fight for their rights and freedom of choice.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. – The Polish bill is a violation of international rights because it prohibits abortion of women victims of rape or whose fetuses have serious malformations. Health workers who assist these women may be imprisoned. In addition, economic inequality will occur, because those women with economic means will be able to go out and abort outside Poland and those who do not will be faced with clandestine abortions putting their lives at risk. We cannot resign ourselves to this situation. We must raise our voices to prevent it from continuing to decide on our lives and our destiny. In January 2014 we discussed in this House the attack on women's rights in Spain with the change of restrictive abortion legislation proposed by the Government of the People's Party. Two years later we discussed this issue again. Today it's Polish women. Who's it going to be tomorrow? We cannot accept that in 21st century Europe our daughters will have fewer rights than our mothers. I want to show my unconditional support to the women of Poland and tell them that they are not alone, that their freedom is our struggle and that our effort can bring hope for the future.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The debate on women's rights in Poland, organised in response to an appeal by women's organisations, has demonstrated the strength of solidarity among women, whose rights are still being questioned by important actors in public life and even by those in power in some European countries. Women are a minority in the governing bodies, so in order to achieve an effect, to show their strength, they reach for such a powerful instrument of influence as transnational and bipartisan solidarity. The black protest, in which Poles protested against the announcement of an extremely restrictive, barbaric law completely banning abortion, touched the whole of Europe, social media and spilled widely on various institutions and bodies also outside the European Union. He showed that women, although still in worse-treated situations, have a powerful influence. Poles, as well-educated, entrepreneurial and active, organized this spontaneous protest precisely because they know their rights and have enough knowledge and courage to block harmful, human rights-infringing legislative ideas of politicians and activists who have chosen to ignore European, national and UN rules on civil rights, women's rights and gender equality. Poles have shown the strength of female engagement and set an example to women across Europe that the effective defence of rights and the implementation of often ignored demands is made possible by solidarity and active entry into public debate.

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: Written.  "One of the most important things about modern times is that women can control their reproduction. Not always and far from all over the world, but better than thousands of generations of women before us. Our grandmothers and all generations of women before them have suffered mentally and physically and died in terrible ways because of the inability to prevent reproduction. Women's self-determination has only been taken for granted for a very short time and in a very small part of the world.  Europe is no exception. The current situation, in which women are at least partially allowed to decide on their reproduction, is a fragile condition. Women's and women's rights are not set in stone, but can be attacked and attacked at any time, including in Europe.  The best way to reduce the number of abortions is to prevent unwanted pregnancies. They are prevented by sexual education, cheap and easily accessible contraceptives, and by the fact that society also accepts and supports single mothers. Restricting contraceptives and abortion hurts the poor the most. The rich can have an abortion abroad, the poor have to resort to illegal abortions or give birth to a child, even if the birth of a child plunges the family and the child into intolerable living conditions.  Women's bodies and sexuality are again trying to make policy. I can't do that. Have your political and religious struggles somewhere other than women's bodies, in our bodies. Women's bodies and sexuality have been limited and controlled for thousands of years. We'll never go back to that again.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on – the oral question to the Council on the UN Conference on Climate Change 2016 in Marrakech (Morocco) (COP 22) by Giovanni La Via, Peter Liese, Jo Leinen, Julie Girling, Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy, Estefana Torres Martinez, Bas Eickhout, Marco Affronte on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (O-000103/2016 - B8-0718/2016) (2016/2814 (RSP)) and – the oral question to the Commission on the UN Conference on Climate Change 2016 in Marrakech (Morocco) (COP 22) by Giovanni La La, Via, Via Peter Liese, Jo Leinen, Julie Girling, Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy, Estefana Torres Martinez, Bas Eickhout, Marco Affronte on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (O-000104/2016 - B8-0719/2016) (2016/2814(RSP)).

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Cañete, Minister, yesterday we experienced an historic moment in this very House where, by a large majority, we gave the green light to the effective entry into force of the Paris Agreement before COP22 in Marrakech. After Kyoto it has been a long process and objectively today we have a global agreement, legally binding, to really combat climate change at international level. But after yesterday's success, our minds are already in Marrakech, which will be the place to move from words to actions, that is, to the implementation measures necessary to achieve the objectives set in Paris. We will go to Marrakech with the same determination and leadership ambition that we had in Paris. In detail, the resolution on which we will vote tomorrow will be the mandate for our delegation and agreements and negotiations will be opened on the main elements.  Firstly, a strengthened framework for transparency, details for a global budget, some additional guidelines on INDCs, an understanding of loss and damage differentiation, as well as talking about climate finance, inclusive multi-level governance as well as a mechanism to facilitate implementation and promote compliance.  It will also be necessary to start discussions on the form of the 2018 facilitation dialogue, which will be an important opportunity to bridge the existing mitigation gap, in the light of the current INDCs, and in which the EU can play a proactive role in terms of the level of collective ambition and progress in implementing the commitments made.  The resolution highlights the good progress of the European Union in meeting the 2020 targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions and in achieving the targets set for renewable energy and the efforts that need to be increased in order to achieve the 2050 targets. I would like to highlight an important passage in the resolution: we regret that the international air and sea transport sector is not mentioned in the agreement, even though it is the second largest sector in the amount of greenhouse gas emissions. Parliament therefore stresses the need to implement a number of strategies to reduce emissions in this sector. We know that this is a difficult subject, but Parliament will continue to be the spokesman for this need. Ultimately, climate diplomacy efforts will be needed to ensure that the negotiations are positive and produce real progress towards our common goal. This is an objective which we owe to ourselves and to future generations and which, thanks also to good policy, has been ever closer since yesterday.

name: Peter LIESE
text: Author. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has Yesterday was indeed an historic day: here in plenary, we have created the conditions for the Paris Agreement on climate change to enter into force – in record time. But now the work continues. We must implement Paris and take the next steps in Marrakech. For our group, the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, it is always very important that we jointly focus on ambitious climate protection and the safeguarding and creation of jobs. Yesterday, too, an important step was taken in the negotiations in the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy on emissions trading. If the result is the guiding principle, including for our work here in plenary, then we can combine the two well. I would like to point out that another major conference is currently taking place in Montreal, where the world meets and also talks about climate protection. I fear, however, that there will not be something as good and ambitious as in Paris. IcaO, the International Civil Aviation Organisation, is meeting in Montreal, and we in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety said in our resolution, which I hope the plenary will adopt tomorrow by a large majority, that what is on the table is disappointing. And this also has an impact on European climate protection policy: aviation is included in emissions trading, and it will actually be the case again from next year that intercontinental flights will be included. We say that we only want to change this if an ambitious result is really decided in Montreal. We need more balance here. Climate protection can only work if all shoulders support. It is not acceptable for us to have a proposal where steelworkers are shaking for their jobs, because at the same time other sectors, such as air transport, are taking a slender foot. We need fairness here! Everyone has to get on their bikes so that this becomes something with climate protection.

name: Jo LEINEN
text: Author. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has We cleared the first major hurdle on Tuesday. The ratification of the Paris Agreement here in the European Parliament was indeed an historic day, because it now allows it to enter into force. The second major hurdle comes in Marrakech, namely to come to life with this Paris Agreement. We are talking about the timetables and also the targets and work plans that need to be implemented, and we know that what is on the table is not enough to reach two degrees Celsius. There is much more to come.  That is the task for the European Union. We have our goals of 2030. But there is also air up – it is not set in stone that it has to remain at 40 percent. And if I look at the various sectors, such as transport – Peter Liese mentioned maritime transport, we always keep an eye on air transport, but also, of course, road transport – agriculture and the building sector, then there is still a great deal possible and much still needs to be done.  I wonder whether we should waste many years on these tasks. In my opinion, 2018 or 2020 is far too late to consider a review. This should start now after Marrakech. I also see that our long-term objective needs to be adjusted once again. I don't think we can stop at 80 percent. For 1.5 degrees, we need a 95 per cent reduction and, Commissioner, when do you intend to work out the long-term plan? I also ask the Council what the Member States intend to do in Marrakesh to ensure that success is achieved.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: Author. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Dear Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Almost a year ago, an event of great historical significance occurred in Paris. The vast majority of countries around the world have agreed to take joint action to reduce the impact of man-made greenhouse gas emissions into the atmosphere. Today, this agreement is almost ready for entry into force, as it will reach the thresholds foreseen with ratification by the European Union. I will admit that I myself am surprised at the pace at which countries, which have so far been unsusceptable for their ambitious climate policy, that is, China or the United States, India, have ratified. However, as far as the United States is concerned, the impact of the upcoming presidential elections on the status of this agreement is uncertain in this case. However, it is worth remembering the reasons why this happened: firstly, you probably remember well that at some point the word 'decarbonisation' has become the subject of hard negotiations. Many countries objected to the presence of this word because, seeing the need to reduce emissions, they considered that they could do so without completely abandoning the use of coal, which is an accessible and cheap raw material, and modern technologies significantly reduce its emissivity. The Union had to step down and did well, otherwise there would be no agreement. Secondly, the agreement places reducing emissions and increasing the potential for removals on an equal footing. Thus, states can use their natural predispositions and strengths without enforcing strict measures on them.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: Author. – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to congratulate this House on the adoption yesterday of the rectification of the Paris Agreement and of the efforts that the Commissioner has made in this dossier. As has been said over and over again, the European Union has played a leading role in this process and it is now imperative that it remain in the front group, in defining and coordinating measures for its effective implementation, demanding transparency and ambition. And it is precisely this will that we will have to demonstrate next month in Marrakesh at COP 22.  I believe that the global Paris agreement represents a more level playing field at international level to promote the fight against climate change. The definition of a stable and ambitious legal framework is now essential to mobilise civil society and the private sector for investments in innovative technologies that enable us to have a more sustainable society. There will now be an opportunity for growth and job creation in the green and blue economy that we cannot afford to waste. In European climate policy there are industrial sectors, some of which are subject to carbon leakage, which could be undermined if we focus on them all the effort to reduce emissions. Commissioner, we cannot afford to forget, in this effort that must be everyone's, the transport sector, the second most important sector in terms of emissions and the one whose emissions are still at free growth. Air and sea transport was left out of the Paris Agreement. ICAO and IMO have been remissive and only make significant progress in this area. I would like to express, Commissioner, my deep concern about the agreement under preparation at ICAO on this matter. An agreement that will apply late, only from 2020, which is part of a very high reference level of CO2 emissions and which is anticipated on a purely voluntary basis, without imposing an effective reduction in emissions in the near future, is certainly not the agreement I would like. I also believe that the emission neutralisation measures being negotiated are unclear and their quality and control very dubious. This agreement seems to me, ladies and gentlemen, far from meeting the Paris objectives to which we are committed. I hope, Commissioner, that this agreement will not set the tone and level of ambition for the other transport sectors, in particular maritime transport, and that, in materialising under the conditions I have mentioned, it will not be sold to us as a success.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: Author. – Madam President, today we have before us a new opportunity to make the necessary transition to a more equitable and sustainable model of life a reality. But let us not deceive ourselves, because the Paris Agreement is wholly insufficient to achieve the long-term objective set: not to exceed two degrees of temperature rise. If we do not reduce pollution levels, the annual temperature increase will soon exceed three and a half degrees.  The world's poorest people, many farmers, fish farmers and shepherds, are being hardest hit by high temperatures. It is urgent that States address this issue in their climate action plans. How? For example, it is striking that this agreement does not mention industrial agriculture, one of the main responsible for climate change.  Hunger causes 40,000 deaths a day; however, 60% of the food we produce ends up wasted. We dedicate 30% of the entire production area to producing food that ends up in the trash. This involves the production of 3.3 billion tonnes of CO2 equivalent; that is, food waste is the third largest cause of the world's largest greenhouse gas producers, only below the United States and China. Nothing says about this.  We must influence the right to food and promote agro-ecological production with short circuits: this will sustainably and equitably feed the world and also mitigate climate change.  Ladies and gentlemen, this fight is not solved by agreements on sums and subtractions. The challenge is great and in it smallholder farmers have to stop being the most vulnerable to become the most valuable in history. To do this, we need to reorient agricultural investment towards the needs of these smallholder farmers. As Latouche rightly says, "you cannot save the planet while pretending to save an unjust and unsustainable business." We have to choose which side we're on. We're very clear about that.

name: Claude TURMES
text: Author. Madam President, I will not repeat what my colleagues, Mr Leine, Mr Liese or Mr La Via have said. Parliament is very united on what we want in general. Rather, I would like to return to what I believe has been a success in Paris, namely the fact that we have gone from the "climate problem" to the "climate solutions". Commissioner, my question is: how are we going to continue to energize the Lima-Paris Action Plan, which will now take on a new form? I am very afraid that we will lose this dynamic, which was created and in which France and Mrs Royal have put a lot of energy into it. Is the European Commission ready to commit funds and the expertise of its officials to help really carry out this initiative? I have three concrete ideas. As we go to Morocco, the first is the "Energy for Africa" initiative. I am trying to promote this idea with Mr. Borloo and others here in the house. We welcomed the proposal we call 'Juncker 2', namely a plan to reduce risks to Africa. Could you elaborate a little more on how Mr Borloo's 'Energy for Africa' initiative relates to the Juncker Guarantee Fund? The second is energy efficiency. Africa, Egypt, Algeria, Tunisia and Morocco need improvements in energy efficiency. We are the world champions in terms of ecodesign and the A, B, C and D labels. So what are we doing to help Maghreb countries? The third thing is renewables. For me, Spain, Portugal and Morocco could be the first region beyond the continents where we would move to 100% renewables. Should we not offer African countries the opportunity to export renewables to Europe, thereby increasing our renewable target by 1% to give them access to our market by exporting renewable energy?

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Paris Agreement will enter into force at the same time as COP22 is launched, and that is certainly a good sign. It is necessary to look at the glass half full of this tool to keep high the hope that we can still change a process that is much greater than us, hoping to see at least a slowdown in climate change. But in the half-empty glass of time for reassuring messages and simple hopes there is neither. In this part of the glass, there continues to be a political nebula made up of binding commitments, but for which there are no sanctions. In this part of the glass, echoes the lack of commitment that industrialised countries have shown in funding the Green Fund. In this part of the glass, the sum of the reduction commitments, as stated by the individual contracting parties, is still not sufficient to contain the temperature increase within two degrees, let alone stay within a degree and a half, at the end of the century. In the glass half empty, there is still a lack of serious political will to tackle the stone coert, namely agriculture and animal husbandry, in particular, as Mrs Torres Martínez mentioned, a problem that is as real as it is ignored. According to a very recent UNEP report, food production is second only after the use of fossil fuels in terms of emission liability. And attention, as my fellow Member has said, refers to food production based on waste and the destruction of resources typical of advanced economies, and certainly not to agriculture, which should feed those suffering from hunger. In the half-full glass, on the other hand, there is a risk of an international bond market. This is good news for financial speculators, but much less good for the fate of the planet. A disaster, that of ETS, a global ETS that could only be made worse by continuing to support CCS as a solution to decarbonise production, a practice that describes very well what it means to put dust under the carpet.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, after the consent you voted here yesterday, the Council has adopted its decision on the conclusion of the agreement. This Friday my colleague, Environment Minister Sólymos will deposit, together with Commissioner Arias Cañete, the EU ratification instrument to the United Nations in New York. Again, let me thank you for your cooperation, which allowed us to react immediately to the unprecedented international momentum, which was mentioned yesterday by the UN Secretary-General. The EU ratification will enable the entry into force of the Paris Agreement and make it possible that the first meeting of the parties to the Paris Agreement will be convened in November in Marrakesh. And now specifically on Marrakesh. The outcome of the Paris Conference, including the Agreement, the COP decision and intended nationally determined budget contributions, needs to be implemented in all its elements. Marrakesh will be the first opportunity to start the work on the details of the Paris Agreement and to prepare for its implementation. The EU and its Member States are ready to engage in this work, which will include in particular the following elements: Firstly, the development of common modalities for the transparency and accountability guidelines under the Paris Agreement. This work is critical. The enhanced transparency framework is the key element of the Paris Agreement, helping build mutual trust and underpinning effective implementation. The enhanced transparency process will help parties in preparing, communicating and accounting for successive nationally determined contributions. It will also be critical in providing robust data to support the global stocktake and for the assessment of progress towards the long-term goals of the Paris Agreement. Secondly, the definition of modalities and inputs of the global stocktake (GST): The GST will provide the key political momentum and drive the parties’ domestic and cooperative action. It should drive more ambitious action by parties in their successive efforts, and its outcome will in turn inform parties in updating and enhancing their actions and support, as well as international cooperation. The Paris Agreement already determines some of the key aspects of the GST design, but specification on its inputs and modalities must help deliver its purpose and fulfil its role in the ambitious cycle. Thirdly, further action by all parties individually and collectively will be required to re-orient finance flows and make them consistent with a pathway towards low greenhouse gas emissions and climate-resilient development. The EU and its Member States are taking initiatives both domestically and internationally to support the shift of investments. We are contributing significantly to this transformation. In 2014, we provided EUR 14.5 billion and the 2015 figures will become available before Marrakesh. The EU and its Member States remain committed to scaling up the mobilisation of climate finance as part of the global effort to assist developing countries to implement their low carbon sustainable development and in particular their nationally determined contributions (NDCs). Domestic implementation, climate policies and measures to achieve intended NDCs and their full integration in national policies are of crucial importance. Finally, I would like to briefly highlight at this point the ongoing legislative work on the implementation of the EU 2030 climate and energy framework, namely on the proposal to reform the ETS sector and the proposals on non-ETS. These measures will enable the target to reduce EU greenhouse gases emissions domestically by at least 40 % in 2030 compared to 1990 emissons to be achieved.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first I would like to thank the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI), and indeed the whole Parliament, for their strong support to ratify quickly the Paris Agreement on behalf of the European Union.  Yesterday’s plenary vote in this very Chamber was a historic moment and a further demonstration of European resolve and determination to combat climate change. We can celebrate today the triggering of the entry into force of the Paris Agreement. In view of the COP22, the European Union has a number of key priorities for advancing the Paris Agreement, as mentioned by the Parliament in its oral question and the debate today. We need to be able to show clear progress on the implementation of all elements of the Paris outcome. In particular, we must show that countries are putting in place ambitious climate policies and that they are getting ready to implement the nationally determined contributions under the Paris Agreement. Within the European Union, the recent decision to channel 40% of the European Fund for Strategic Investments towards climate-relevant projects in the infrastructure and innovation window shows how we are aligning our instruments to deliver the Paris commitments. We must also mobilise support for the implementation of the nationally determined contributions. The Commission, through its international development and cooperation action, is already pressing on the ground in the most affected countries and supports national governments in their efforts on mitigation and adaptation.  The European Union’s new external investment plan is designed to leverage strategic investments in our partner countries, not only to support climate action but also to facilitate the delivery of the sustainable development goals. The global climate action agenda will also play a vital role in helping governments, business and other stakeholders to be inspired by the action around the world. When it comes to the negotiating agenda, Marrakesh needs to make tangible progress on developing the detailed rule book of the Paris Agreement, including the five-yearly global stocktakes. We will need to assess where we are, what more needs to be done, and what the opportunities are for future action. At the European Union level, our proposals on the 2030 legislative framework make clear provision for a review from 2024 onwards in order to take account of the results of the global stocktake under the Paris Agreement and evolving national circumstances. The 2018 Facilitative Dialogue will be a key political moment in the international climate negotiations. We will take stock of the collective efforts of the parties in progress towards the long—term emission reduction goal of the Paris Agreement. The dialogue will follow the special report to be published by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change on emissions pathways compatible with limiting global temperature increase to 1.5 degrees centigrade. The Commission supports the active participation of the European Union in shaping the dialogue as the first important opportunity to take stock of the collective efforts of the parties.  Progress on climate finance is also critical. The European Union is working with other developed country parties to deliver in Marrakesh a concrete roadmap to mobilise the USD 100 billion annually by 2020 for mitigation and adaptation. The roadmap should provide greater transparency and bring stability to the collective efforts of developed countries. The European Union remains committed to supporting partner countries in their efforts on climate action and remains the biggest donor region, our highest level ever in 2015. Finally, it is crucial that prior to Marrakesh we recall the need to make progress, as many Members have pointed out, in other international fora. As you know, the ICAO Assembly is taking place right now in Montreal with a view to agreeing a global market—based mechanism in order to achieve the stabilisation of aviation emissions at 2020 levels. Later this month, I will also be present in Kigali with the aim of reaching an ambitious agreement on the global phase—down of HFCs under the Montreal Protocol. We have achieved remarkable progress this year on global climate action. Less than 12 months ago, we adopted the Paris Agreement and its entry into force was triggered yesterday, but we still have much work to do to implement our commitments on the ground. I count on your continued support both here and in Marrakesh, so that together we can make COP22 a real success.

name: Seán KELLY
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. –  Madam President, it was a great pleasure for me to attend in Paris last year, especially as it ended in success with the historic COP21 Agreement. I think the European Union played a huge part in laying the foundations for it and in showing leadership, particularly under Commissioner Cañete, in that. It was great yesterday to see the ratification process being signed here by our President, Mr Schulz, in the presence of Ban Ki-moon, Secretary-General of the United Nations.  We can look forward with confidence to Marrakesh in November. I think that Marrakesh can be seen as the COP22 of action. At long last, we are in the position to actually transfer agreements, commitments into action. The European Union will play a very important part, and in this we need to show especially diplomatic leadership, because we can do all we like here in the European Union, we could have targets to reduce carbon emissions to zero, but unless the world does the same, it is not going to have an impact. We can help, especially in ensuring all countries fulfil their commitments. We can also help in making the technology that we will utilise in relation to renewable energies, energy efficiencies, ETS, you name it, available to third countries.  I think we can look forward with optimism, but also we have to be conscious of the fact that we have three targets here in Europe. Firstly, to meet our targets in relation to climate change; secondly, to reindustrialise Europe – we had a motion for a resolution on that today – and thirdly, to maintain our competitiveness. We will not have to worry that much about carbon leakage if there is a global agreement, because that will establish a global level playing field, and I think it will make everybody happy that this can be done by increasing jobs and growth and at the same time saving the climate for future generations.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: On the other: And on the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Only yesterday we all sat in this House and rejoiced that we have finally ratified the International Paris Agreement. I am pleased that we succeeded in this and that it is in place for the forthcoming climate conference in Marrakech. But we should not pat ourselves on the shoulder too much, but we should also understand and realise that this is the beginning.  It is now that europe and the rest of the world must roll up their sleeves. It is now that we must show that we are capable and prepared to actually work towards the solutions required if we are to achieve the objective of limiting global warming to a maximum of 2 degrees and preferably towards 1.5 degrees. It takes more than fine words to implement this; concrete policies are now needed. If we are to show the seriousness of the fact that climate change is not an obstacle but a lever for a sustainable society and a more resource-efficient green economy, it goes without saying that europe must lead that development.  Europe, like all regions of the world, will need to do much more if we are to achieve the objectives of the Paris Agreement. One of the most important tools is the ETS, which we have at our disposal. I myself and colleagues in this House are currently negotiating the ETS. We must ensure that climate emissions are reduced more and faster than at present, but we must also create the right incentives for industry so that they dare to make climate-smart investments.  I would also like to emphasise that climate change must cover society as a whole. It is not okay for some industries to free ride on others, but to contribute to the climate change transition. Anyone who can do their bit. Similarly, we must also ensure that the transition is solidarity-based and avoids negative social effects. Groups and regions with particular challenges must not be left behind, but must be given specific support in the transition.

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: On behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, the climate agreement is coming to fruition. Great! Let's roll up our sleeves and get to work. It's not a perfect deal, but we have to deal with our lot.  We urgently need to reorient funding on a more environmentally and socially sustainable basis. We are supporting the fossil economy with billions, and by redirecting at least some of these subsidies, we could strengthen energy efficiency and promote research, development and use of renewable energies, including in the employment-friendly SME sector.  Action must be taken to direct the support euros and public money towards action, to reduce emissions, whether we are talking about ETS compensation, general agricultural policy or the EU's energy and transport policy. Otherwise, our agreement will remain nothing more than an empty letter. Every representative can take action on their own government so that something really happens in ICAO and IVO.

name: Julia REID
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, the small increase in temperature we have seen over the past 100 years is entirely consistent with the natural long—term cyclical changes we have seen for at least 10 000 years and there has been no significant increase in warming since 1995. That the entire text of the motion for a resolution is based on the false assumption that climate change due to AGW is occurring.  We in UKIP deny the climate change alarmism supported by green lobbies, often financed by the Commission, who both are responsible for our current damaging and counter—productive energy policies. To date, hundreds of energy—intensive industries, along with thousands of jobs, have left the EU and moved to the Third World. Despite this, the Commission continues to impose never ending unrealistic objectives for emissions reductions. Sadly such policies, which are forcing investment of vast sums of money will have little or no effect on climate.  On leaving the EU, Britain will be free to formulate its own energy policy whereby our poorest citizens will not be forced to choose between heating and eating.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, there is an urgent need to tackle global warming. If left untable, Africa will only be able to meet 13% of its food needs by 2050. This will cause a migration invasion far greater than the one we know.  The COP22 in Marrakech will be an apparent success. 62 countries representing 51% of global greenhouse gas emissions have already ratified the agreement signed in Paris in 2015 under COP21.  But the European Union will nevertheless engage in a market of dupes. It agrees to reduce its harmful emissions by 40%, when the United States is content with 28% and when China does not agree to consider a reduction until after 2030. I therefore denounce the irresponsibility of the Union, which will accelerate the deindustrialisation of Europe, by unilaterally submitting to constraints that will not weigh on its main economic competitors.

name: Pilar AYUSO
text: – Madam President, first of all I would like to congratulate Commissioner Arias Cañete and his team on the efforts made over the years, which have been rewarded with this great success which marks a milestone in their mandate. Yesterday, this House approved by a large majority the ratification of the agreement reached in Paris at the end of 2015. It is the culmination of the leadership that the European Union has maintained at successive conferences of the parties and we must congratulate ourselves on that. The European Union undertook to reduce its emissions by 20% by 2020 compared to 1999 and by 40% by 2030. The first objective is on track to be met and I have no doubt that we will also achieve the goal we have set ourselves for 2030. For many years, we have stressed the need for an international agreement, so that emissions-responsible countries all contribute to the fight against climate change under conditions that are at least comparable. Not all countries are equally responsible, nor do they have the same social, environmental, energy and industrial challenges. It is therefore logical that solidarity mechanisms are in place to finance investment, research and development. At the same time, a mechanism would be needed to monitor the commitments that countries are making and to be able to exert some pressure if the efforts are not sufficient. The Agreement should have positive consequences for reindustrializing the European Union. I also believe that it will allow for rapid progression of renewable energy and energy efficiency in third countries. It is important to expedite further negotiations at the international level so that, in Marrakesh, there are further progress towards the Paris Agreement on transparency, emission control, timetables and compliance.

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: Madam President, Commissioner, Minister; Commissioner, as rapporteur for the European Parliament last year, in the resolution we adopted at COP21, I would like to commend your work, the work you have done and which we did with you last year in Paris to find this historic agreement. I would also like to commend the work you have done over the last ten months to enable the ratification of this agreement, which we formalised yesterday in plenary.  At the same time, Commissioner, we will have to continue and, together in Marrakech, I believe we will address a number of points which I think are essential.  Firstly, the creation of innovative financing to combat climate change, for example, the setting of a floor price for a tonne of carbon or the reform of the European carbon trading system, but also the establishment of a genuine circular economy and the boosting of renewable energies or the abolition of subsidies allocated to the fossil fuel sector- which will lead to , in the long run, the abandonment of fossil fuels - and, finally, also the intensification of efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions in the transport and agriculture sectors.  Finally, as Claude Turmes says, we need to address our cooperation on renewable energy with africa and all of what we need to do with regard to Africa. We are working with Jean-Louis Borloo, but I think it is also a subject that we need to address together.  Yes, Marrakech must be the COP of action.

name: Roger HELMER
