text: – Madam President, I love to drive fast cars, and I just wish we had optional speed limits. But it seems we can have optional emissions limits under the Paris climate deal. We are told again and again that it is legally binding, but in fact it is no such thing. There are no sanctions available, we are all terribly concerned about getting it ratified. But there is precious little hope that it will ever be implemented. If it were implemented, the EU only accounts for about 10% of global emissions, so we shall have no effect at all, while India and China continue to build coal-fired power stations. So what will we achieve? I will tell you what we will achieve: we will set in stone the competitive disadvantage in energy prices which we have chosen to impose upon ourselves. We will accelerate Europe’s relative decline, we will leave our children and grandchildren poorer. The only good news is that after Brexit the UK will be in a position to review the Paris deal. I very much hope we have the common sense to repudiate it.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: - Madam President, I do not believe we will have the opportunity to revise the Paris Agreement when we ratified it in Parliament only yesterday and with an overwhelming majority. This was indeed a historic event and the EU has shown that it is able to be a leader, to be in the lead when it comes to fighting climate change.  (The speech was interrupted due to translation problems and then resumed.) It is now up to member states to ratify it in their parliaments – I hope they will do so in the fastest possible way, but it is also up to them to show their action plans in the fight against climate change. As we have heard from Mr. Cañete, there are European Commission programs and external programs for relations with other countries and investments in other countries, as well as for relations with our partners. It is not enough for the EU it as a matter of time to fulfil its tasks. The Paris Agreement doesn't make sense then. So the big news is that the U.S., China, India and other major powers have already ratified the Paris Agreement and that it will not remain a dead letter on paper. A lot is expected from Marrakech: this Paris Agreement is expected to be implemented, but also more support for the European Parliament delegation in Marrakech so that it can participate in the adoption of all the necessary regulations. In any case, we remain true to the targets we have set out by 2030, namely reducing warming by 2°C and greenhouse gas emissions by up to 40%. We expect 2018 as a very important year when we will be able to check out all this we are talking about and have a dialogue. I believe it will be a very important year, but I also believe that Mr. Cañete's mandate will be marked by rapid ratification and that we can be satisfied with what has been done so far. In any case, we expect the implementation and implementation of all that is written in the Paris Agreement.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this debate is taking place following the adoption by a very large majority, unfortunately not unanimously as we would have liked to see, of the European ratification of the Paris agreements on combating climate change. This was an historic moment – as many have already said – for climate actions, the symbolic value of which we cannot fail to grasp. While many in our Union believe that they face momentous challenges by closing themselves within their borders, the Paris Agreement shows instead that global challenges can and must be tackled with global responses and that Europe can be the protagonist. In November we will be in Marrakech for the twenty-second COP and with other colleagues we will be there to continue the contribution of ideas that have been highlighted in Parliament's resolution. I am not going back over the points that have already been dealt with. , to a circular economy model, which means efficient use of resources, investments in energy efficiency and renewable energy, which alone can hold sustainability and growth together and enforce the Paris agreements.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE). Madam President, first of all I would really like to pay fair praise and all of us to give these congratulations to our dear colleague Giovanni La Via and to commissioner Cañete for the excellent effort and hard work to enable the European Parliament and the European Union to arrive to annul the Paris agreement. An important, historic one that has highlighted the role of the European Union. It has proved once again that the European Union remains strong and the leading force that can tilt the scale in favour of humanity, in favour of a more social Europe, in favour of European citizens, in favour of future generations.  It is for this reason that we say that this agreement is a milestone and we must now implement it and the act of implementation is where it will judge both the European Commission and us in the European Parliament. I believe that in order for this agreement to be implemented and delivered, incentives must be given to the two main pillars that we as the European Parliament have defined: energy saving and renewable energy sources, which are the basic conditions for the European Energy Union, and because I heard earlier that we must incentivise third countries in Africa, I say that in the Mediterranean itself , since the Mediterranean has the comparative advantage of sunshine. My own country, Cyprus, has more than 300 days of sunshine, and may well develop renewable energy sources if it really has the support of European Union programmes. We ourselves can do this and I see no reason why we should look anywhere else.  The other important thing I wanted to stress is that there must also be mobilisation of civil society citizens themselves, for sustainable development, for sustainable development, but also for the fight against energy poverty. By serving and implementing these objectives, we are certainly also fighting energy poverty, they will certainly benefit consumers, and in conclusion, this effort cannot be financed from sources other than the basic principle of all of us being 'polluter pays' and I do not think the financial transaction tax will be related to the financing of any attempt to prevent climate change.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: – Chair, Sur Kummissarju, fil-fatt huwa ta' sodisfazzjon għalija li nkun qiegħda nindirizza proprju din il-plenarja hawnhekk illejla għaliex proprju llejla Malta għadha kif irratifikat il-Ftehim ta' Pariġi u nafu li r-rattifika tal-Ftehim ta' Pariġi mill-Unjoni Ewropea hija su大大ess. Għedniha kemm-il darba u dan grazzi wkoll għall-Kummissarju Miguel Arias Cañete li qiegħed hawnhekk magħna għad-determinazzjoni li wrejt anki fin-negozjati li f'ħafna ħinijiet ma kinuxħnili.  Imma llejla nixtieq inħares ukoll mil-lenti ta' ikeittadina Maltija, gżira żgħira f'nofs il-Mediterran, reġjun li huwa meqjus bħalaħ wied mill-aktar esposti għat-tibdil tal-klima. Dan it-tibdil, diġà qegħdin jesperjenzawh fil-ħajja tagħhom ta' kuljum. Jikkonfermaw dan studji li jindikaw li fost l-oħrajn ix-xita tista' tonqos b'aktar minn nofs sas-sena 2100 u li l-livell tal-Baħar Mediterranju jista' jkompliħ jogla. Għalhekk, iva, hemm bżonn urġenti li jkollna miżuri konkreti u immedjati li jimplimentaw dak li ġie miftiehem f'Pariġi. Għaliex jekk mhux se naġixxu malajr, kwistjonijiet ta' stabilità u sigurtà fil-Mediterran se jsiru aktar inkwetanti u aktarmed imjati.  Għalhekk il-Konferenza ta' Marakexx qed tiġi fi żmien meta nistgħu nbiddlu l-affarijiet u proprju f'reġjun li tant jeħtieġ din il-bidla. Għandna din l-opportunità f'idejna u rridu na大大eraw ruħna li nkomplu nibnu fuq il-momentum li diġà jeżisti.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Madam President, in expressing commitment to a carbon—free future, the signature of the COP21 Agreement represents a remarkable global achievement. What we have to do now is to translate this commitment into action; to implement what has been included in the agreement, but also to go beyond what has already been agreed. One such area would be carbon pricing, an issue rather left out of the Paris Agreement, but which could bear crucial importance in emissions reduction. As opposed to emissions trading schemes – which in the past have often proved less effective because of the inflation in the tradable permits handed out – carbon taxes would represent a more effective way to reduce emissions: they would transform the cost of pollution from a negative externality into actual costs, favouring a change in polluting behaviour. Additionally, revenues from such costs could, in the end, be used for the financing of new renewable energy infrastructures, thus starting a new virtuous cycle.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Marrakesh negotiations must continue in the wake of the key elements of the Paris Agreement, in particular with regard to strengthening the framework for transparency of climate warming mitigation actions, defining the 2018 revisions of national commitments, creating mechanisms to deal with climate losses and damage and promoting compliance with the rules of the climate agreement.  I stress the need to start discussions on the form that the 2018 facilitation dialogue will take, which should make it possible to bridge the existing mitigation gap. The European Union must play a proactive role in this first facilitation dialogue in order to take stock of the level of collective ambition and progress in implementing the commitments made.  Finally, it would be desirable for the Commission and the Member States to present, before the facilitation dialogue, ambitious energy and climate plans at national level, with regard to the implementation of the commitments made under the Paris Agreement.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, I have stressed before that, despite the triumphalisms of the European Union and France, last year's COP21 decision in Paris did not create a clear framework for dealing with the devastating effects of the phenomenon of climate change, because it did not address two major problems that we will have to face in the future. The first major problem is that of the production model which does not change in substance. The large industrial states and their companies finally manage to get rich in the name of so-called ecology and continue to serve the same model of development. The second major issue is that of climate migration.  This is a huge political weakness of the Paris agreement, the lack of any reference to the status of a climate refugee or migrant. For the period 2008-2013 alone, the number is estimated at 166 million. Moreover, research that has been done shows that only when a natural disaster finds a group of people unprepared, do they migrate. It is therefore time for the industrial states of COP22 to take their responsibilities without twists and turns and create real mechanisms for preventing problems because we know how to deal with them.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: – Madam President, when we refer to climate change, we talk as if it were something to be avoided in the future. I will give you a fact, a fact, very of the present: on an island in Alaska you have recently had to vote in a referendum if you migrate to the mainland because your island was being literally flooded by rising sea level. This is just one of the most examples of climate refugee populations worldwide.  Yesterday, the President of the People's Group in this House said yes, that the climate is very important, but it was his group that tabled amendments to Parliament's opinion to limit measures based on economic competitiveness.  The European Commission, Mr Arias Cañete, is also very aware, it seems; but the European Investment Fund has devoted EUR 1.5 billion to fossil fuel infrastructure, when, according to the international IPCC group of scientists, by 2050 the electricity sector would not have to produce a single gram of CO2 anymore.

name: Karin KADENBACH
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The ratification of the climate treaty has been celebrated with big words such as 'historic day' or 'miracle goes on'. And I think the miracle has really gone on. We were very pleased last year when the treaty was signed in Paris. We are now pleased that it really comes into force before COP 22 in Marrakech. It is therefore particularly surprising that there have still been people in this House who seem to deny climate change, who also voted against ratification yesterday. We have received many examples today of the need for solidarity in the future in order to really bring this climate treaty to life now. In this Parliament in the coming weeks and months, we have a great many chances to prove that we are serious about this commitment, whether it is the negotiations on the emissions trading scheme, whether it is a circular economy. This is all evidence where we can show: we are serious, we want a carbon-free future. I call on everyone in this House to continue to have 610 Members on these very issues who say: yes, we want a carbon-free future!

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, we do not flag in the chorus of festive propaganda around the Paris Agreement. There are a number of weaknesses in this agreement and the indisputable need for a comprehensive and binding instrument to reduce greenhouse gas emissions is not worth it. And we are not just referring to the absence of concrete objectives and reduction commitments that would contify the announced objectives of containing the rise in temperature, a relevant issue already mentioned here.  In addition to the targets we must take care of the means to achieve these targets and we therefore deplore the insistence on market mechanisms that have already demonstrated their ineffectiveness and perversity: whether it is the carbon market, the trade in polluting allowances, which are at the price of rain, as we well know, are the instruments of flexibility that come from Kyoto, equally perverse and unfair.  There is still more business intent here than genuine concern for the state of our common House. But there are alternatives. For them we have beaten each other and we will continue to beat.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank all the Members who have participated in this debate for their close interest in the preparations for the COP22 Conference in Marrakesh. Success in Marrakesh means demonstrating that implementation of Paris is moving full steam ahead globally on all the elements of the Paris Package. The agenda for Marrakesh is very rich; unlike in Paris, where there was only one big deliverable, we have a variety of outcomes and the challenge will be to weave them together to tell a convincing story. For us, this story has to be one of real step—change after Paris, the world moving full steam ahead in the implementation of Paris. Marrakesh has to demonstrate that commitments are being implemented all over the world and enable more immediate action.  We can see two very broad areas. First, formal deliverables under the negotiating process. In particular, we have important conclusions to reach on loss and damage, with the review of the Warsaw International Mechanism, which is fundamental for islands, and on capacity building. And, of course, we need to make progress in building the Paris Framework. The second broad area is enhancing action and transparency before 2020, because it is essential that we clearly demonstrate that countries are swiftly putting in place ambitious climate policies, that they are gearing up to implement their NDCs and integrate their NDCs into national development planning in full coherence with SDGs? And we have an opportunity for progress on climate finance with a ministerial event which I hope can be pragmatic and action-oriented.  We will continue the multilateral process for monitoring, reporting and verification, because this raises the profile of all countries’ efforts and is a valuable experience for the future. I would also like to see a politically visible high level event on global climate action agenda that will inspire future action. It is very clear that there is much work still to do. However, as we look to implementing our commitments on the ground and progression in all areas on the Paris Agreement. We in the European Union, already between this year and next year, will deliver all the needed legislation to implement our Paris commitments. We already have the emission trading system, and therefore certain decisions, and we will come forward in December with an ambitious package for electricity market design, energy efficiency directives and energy performance of buildings and a renewables directive, and at the beginning of the year we will come with CO2 standards for cars and light vans.  The European Union not only has ambitious targets, it is enforcing all the policies and is already working with Parliament to deliver our commitments. We are doing our homework and we must help other countries to build capacity to deliver their homework, because for us it is easier, but for developing countries we have to build capacity for everything, for implementing the policies to be able to have monitoring systems, and that is why the Capacity Building Mechanism will be fundamental in Paris. I count on the support of this Parliament and I can assure you of my intention as always to keep Members of the European Parliament very closely informed of developments in the negotiations. These negotiations will be different to the one in Paris but the European Union, with a high ambition coalition, will work steadily so that we make real progress in COP22 in Marrakesh.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I am glad that, after yesterday’s successful completion of ratification of the Paris agreement on behalf of the European Union, today’s debate was already focused on its implementation. Secondly, I would like to say how much we appreciate your support, honourable Members, in outreach efforts to our international partners. This is very much appreciated. Lastly, the Council is of course committed to working together in the run-up to the Marrakesh conference in order to achieve the best possible results.

name: Ivo BELET
text: Written. – With the historically rapid adoption of the Paris agreement, the EU shows that it is in the fight against climate change. It is an immediate step to get things right internally and to achieve EU leadership on climate and energy transition. Such a commitment creates great economic opportunities that benefit all sectors, citizens, businesses and governments. This requires a solid effort from all actors, but offers unique opportunities. We must, of course, do this with caution, so that we do not push our companies out of the EU, but create a framework that encourages and attracts sustainable investment.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: in writing. – Thanks to eu ratification, there are no longer any obstacles to the entry into force of the Paris Agreement in time for the COP 22 Climate Change Conference in Marrakesh from 7 to 18 November 2016.  The EU is a leader in climate policy and the largest financial donor globally, but we cannot tackle this global problem on our own. If only the EU commits itself to meeting certain commitments, our competitiveness and industry will suffer from this. It is also important that ambitious carbon reduction targets do not increase our dependence on energy imports.  It is now important to move towards the implementation of collective global commitments in order to accelerate the transition to a low-carbon and climate-resilient global economy. Early ratification will allow the EU to participate fully in the first meeting of the parties to the Marrakesh Agreement, which will set out the parameters for the implementation of the commitments made.

name: Carolina PUNSET
text: in writing. – Finally, the Union has ratified the Paris Agreement, possibly the most important international agreement to save the common home of humanity. Climate change is already indisputable and the denialist statements of many conservative politicians from just two legislatures seem distant. Most signatory countries have already delivered their contributions to emission reduction at UN headquarters, but estimates say the need for more effort will not be achieved. It's time to move from photo to action and accelerate the energy transition. The Union fills thousands of folios with statements of good intentions, while some Member States record coal burning, such as Spain, and sow investment in clean energy from legal uncertainty. Due to their magnitude and urgency, polluting technologies in power generation must be eliminated. The 2016 United Nations Climate Change Conference in Marraquech is an opportunity for the Union to regain leadership in the fight against global warming, accompanied by actions aligned with climate targets, which have so far not been seen.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you for allowing me to present our proposal for an Interinstitutional Agreement on a mandatory Transparency Register. The Register is the key instrument to shed light on lobbying activities.  The current Register was jointly set up by Parliament and the Commission in 2011. Today it includes slightly over 10 000 organisations and self—employed individuals. It has even surpassed the register they operate in the United States in terms of the number of people and organisations who have registered. All registrants have agreed to adopt a common Code of Conduct, based on a set of ethical rules and principles, governing interactions with EU political leaders and officials.  The current Register remains, however, a voluntary system. If we want to fully meet citizens’ expectations for openness and accountability, we need to go further, and the three law—making institutions must act together to make sure that the rules of the Register are respected by all lobbyists so that everybody can see who tries to influence the EU law—making process and who they represent. You will see that our proposal has taken on board ideas put forward by you, by the Council and by the European Ombudsman. The public consultation we organised led to more than 1 700 replies, the majority of which came from individual citizens who expect us to live up to the highest transparency standards.  On 2 May, Vice-President Sylvie Guillaume and I chaired a public debate in Parliament, bringing together stakeholders from all over the EU. Let me briefly highlight the main elements of our proposal. Firstly, you need to be in the Register before you can have meetings with decision-makers in the three institutions. The Commission already applies this rule. Not on the transparency register – no meeting. This applies to all meetings of lobbyists with Commissioners, their Cabinet members, the Secretary—General and the DGs of the Commission services. Over 4 000 organisations and individuals have registered since this rule came into effect. So we now propose to apply it to meetings also of MEPs as well as the Secretary—General, Directors—General and Secretaries—general of political groups in the European Parliament. Registration will also be a condition for speaking at committee hearings and for holding events on Parliament premises.  In the Council we propose to apply the rule to meetings with the Council Secretary—General, Directors—General, the Ambassador of the current or incoming Presidency of the Council, as well as their deputies. Permanent representations are of course subject to national rules on ethics, but we offer them to join the system voluntarily. Last May, we made listing in the Transparency Register a precondition to sit on our expert groups. This important step forward is also reflected now in our proposal. Secondly, we propose to clarify which activities and entities are covered by the Register. We propose to keep a broad definition of lobbying activities covered by the Register and to set out the exceptions in a clearer way. Public authorities, including at sub—national level, and their associations who directly represent a democratic mandate are clearly excluded, for the reasons that this House and the Committee of the Regions have both underscored.  Thirdly, we propose changes to improve the quality of the data held in the Register and to strengthen monitoring and effective enforcement of the rules. Our proposal not only simplifies the data requirements for lobbyists, but also introduces systematic ex-ante checks on new registrations. We propose to streamline procedures with a view to finding quick, effective solutions if compliance with the Code of Conduct is at risk. If that is not effective, a formal investigation will be opened which can eventually lead to sanctions. Those who do not play by the rules risk being temporarily suspended from interactions with the institutions or removed altogether from the Register. Finally, our proposal creates stronger management structures for the Register and increases the resources at its disposal, subject to a commitment by all three institutions. A well-functioning Register needs adequate resources, a point repeatedly stressed by this Parliament and by stakeholders. We propose a stronger management structure with a management board on top of the Secretariat. An agreement between the three institutions would ensure adequate resource allocation to the Secretariat, as well as a right means to ensure effective redress for registrars in disputed cases.  I have followed with great interest the work of Sven Giegold and look forward to Parliament’s final report on transparency and accountability in the EU institutions. I am convinced that a mandatory Register is a major step forward for transparency and accountability. Let’s make it happen.

name: Danuta Maria HÜBNER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, transparency in the functioning of the European institutions has always been a matter of interest, but also of concern, for its citizens, and it is also essential for the democratic legitimacy of the European Union. For this Parliament, transparency has been the top priority since the first day of our work. It is a fact of life that huge interests are at stake when laws are proposed. European citizens have the right to know which interest representatives are involved in, in each phase of European decision—making. While our duty is to listen to all those whose interests will be affected by decisions we take, the right of citizens is to know whom we listen to.  This interinstitutional agreement proposed by the Commission is the way to answer their concerns. The establishment of a mandatory transparency register framework would be a major step forward in enhancing transparency of our decision—making and the democratic accountability of the European institutions. You might remember that the European Parliament was the first European institution to address the phenomenon of an increasing number of interest groups at European level, as well as potential consequences of this evolution for the legislative process. Today, I am convinced that the Commission proposal for a mandatory transparency register framework covering the three institutions will take us forward but the European Parliament and, in particular, its Committee on Constitutional Affairs, which is responsible for interinstitutional agreements, is fully aware that the mandatory register is only one of the key tools for having more transparency in the EU institutions.  We are happy the Commission has come to Parliament with a proposal that received strong support in public consultation. So let me conclude by stressing that only by working together across all areas of European responsibilities will the European institutions win back the trust of our citizens.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D- Madam President, Mr First Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, the revision of the transparency register presented last week comes against a backdrop of great distrust of the European institutions. I would like to say here that, clearly, the proposals that have been made are going in the right direction, in particular, with the integration, at least partially, of the Council into the scheme or with the exclusion of local and regional authorities which represent public interests. However, there are several elements that need to be addressed. They will surely be discussed in the very near future. On the first point, I would like to say that this is the narrow definition of lobbying, which will have to meet three conditions: interaction, the promotion of interests and a willingness to influence the decision-making process. Therefore, we will have to have clear ideas about who and how these three criteria are audited. The second point is the need for two additional decisions to be made to this institutional agreement that will come into discussion. One to manage the administrative structure and the other, as I understand it, to deal with the budgetary aspects. When did the Commission plan to present them?  The third point, and not least, is the obligation on Members of the European Parliament to meet only registered lobbies. Even if this measure is not required in the publication of appointments, some members will certainly ask whether it is in line with their freedom of mandate, which is a principle in the treaties, and which an inter-institutional agreement cannot sweep away. Again, this is a slippery subject on which we will have the opportunity to discuss. What I take away from the objectives, however, is that we need a system that is readable, easy to access for all citizens, and that does not fuel distrust any more than it does now. It should also be noted that this transparency also applies to other types of issues: conflict of interest rules or codes of conduct.  Mr First Vice-President, the European Parliament is ready to negotiate in the most open way possible, and we hope that the same will be true of the Council, when it enters into dialogue, as soon as possible, certainly.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I would like to thank Commissioner Timmermans for presenting new proposals for an interinstitutional agreement on transparency and to encourage greater courage and consistency, because it is not possible to stop at the creation of new mechanisms for the lobbyist register, but it is necessary to go further precisely in the same spirit as the Giegold report goes, with the need to record all lobbying meetings, but above all with the registration of a legislative footprint. I would be very pleased if the European Commission were the first to declare the impact of lobbying organisations on the content of legislative decisions in its legislative reports.  I therefore encourage greater courage and more precise mechanisms. I also hope that the Sven Giegold report will be approved by a parliamentary majority.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President; Well, I really like to hear from you, Mr Timmermans, and I also congratulate you on your enthusiasm at this hour. It's really remarkable. The proposal for an interinstitutional agreement on the registration of pressure groups is a step forward that we salo add. It is timely and relevant for the European Commission, our Executive, to respond to Europe's transparency needs right now, and the ALDE Group certainly appreciates that transparency has a leading place on the Commission's agenda. Improving data collection should be a palpable advantage in working on information, and efforts to clarify definitions and the spectrum of covered activities and agencies should also facilitate the quality and efficiency of this record. We would like to thank you for increasing resources—we want resources to be increased—so that controls on the activity of the lobbies we are looking for can be effective. Without sufficient means we could, in fact, have a formal but not material requirement. I mean, if unfounded or incomplete statements can sneak in, we would be getting worse and perverting the purpose of the registration. If we make a decision such as the full achievement of this record, we must be able to get it to materialize and not be left in mere words. I would therefore like to stress that giving sufficient economic and staff cover is absolutely essential for this policy of transparency to be coherent and effective. However, let us face it, the European institutions do not enjoy much credibility in these times. Outrageous news of revolving doors in the Commission does not exactly help to believe in the project. And we cannot forget the most important thing: this reform will need the Council to shoulder off and to work together. So far, we've waited for a move on your part that hasn't arrived. The representatives of the Member States must also assume their share of responsibility. In this situation of common benefit we are interested in acting with an integrated policy and being efficient. We have not seen a real Council movement, but we would like to see a loyal collaboration in it soon. In fact, I would like nothing more, on behalf of my Group of Liberals and Democrats for Europe, than to be able to congratulate the Commission, the Council, on a smooth and joint action by the European institutions, if only for once.

name: Dennis de JONG
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – As co-chair of the Transparency intergroup, I offered Vice-President Timmermans a transparent plaque on 2 May to encourage it. At the same time, I have given him our ideas for a mandatory register. I think the plaque has been inspiring, because the proposal for the interinstitutional agreement that we are discussing is a good basis.  But of course there is always room for improvement. I would like to mention five points: vulnerable EU institutions, such as agencies, must be able to join the agreement and become a full party; activities of lobbyists carried out at the specific request of the institutions, their members or officials must also be included, otherwise a huge loophole will arise; complainants should be able to object to the rejection of their complaint, just as lobbyists can oppose exclusion from registration; the Management Board must report periodically to Parliament and the Commission on its activities, and that reporting should be public; fraudulent conduct by lobbyists should lead to investigations by OLAF.  Finally, I am confident that the negotiations on this proposal itself will also be transparent and open to contributions from all stakeholders. In doing so, this Parliament, and I am looking in particular at our Vice-President for Transparency, Mrs Guillaume, has a special responsibility. We know the council's culture of closedness, so let us ensure that at least all the political groups, including the Transparency intergroup, are involved in the negotiations.

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr Timmermans, thank you very much for this proposal. I believe that we are now really one step further. It is a step in the right direction that this proposal for an interinstitutional agreement is now before us. Citizens expect us to promote confidence in the European institutions by also increasing transparency and integrity. And this proposal goes in precisely this direction. It will undoubtedly lead, if it is implemented in this way, to more lobbying organisations and to greater transparency. If we start with the positive things, it can be said that with your proposal you are basically taking Parliament under the same obligation as you yourself as the Commission. That's something I haven't been able to get through here with. That means – and I say this quite openly and honestly : we who are sitting here in our seats would probably agree relatively quickly. But there are some here who are not here, and those who have great problems with taking on commitments there. And I want to make this very clear: the fact that the report, which was supposed to come before your proposal, has not yet been voted on is not because it does not have a majority in the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, but because it has been taken off the agenda by the group leaders – the Conservatives, the Liberals, but ultimately also the Social Democrats – even though there was a majority in the committee to represent a very similar principle, namely that you have only proposed a very similar principle to which you have proposed. Of course, there must be spaces there to meet people who are not registered lobbyists. For a proper balance must be made between the legal principle of freedom of mandate and the legal principle of transparency. I think that you have succeeded in this balance in principle. That is why we, as a Parliament, are now in charge. I would also like to make it quite clear that it would not be acceptable – because your proposal is now before us and because we are also acting on the Rules of Procedure – to put my report on the table now, or even to postpone it for eternity. The report proposes measures for transparency and integrity in many other areas, such as revolving door effects. That is why this report must be put to the vote here. If it continues to be pushed forward here by the large groups, it will in turn be a breach of trust in the citizens. I would also like to mention Mrs Bresso in particular, who is in the crucial situation of producing majorities among the Social Democrats so that we can vote on the report. Because with your vote we could vote on the report. It is also the Social Democrats, with Christian Democrats and Liberals, who are blocking progress here. My appeal is that if you come back into the democratic processes, we will also find majorities, and the majority will also decide here in the House. I would like to thank the Commission for its submission.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, transparency is one of the founding principles of the 5-Star Movement and represents a polar star in our political action here in the European Parliament too. Public institutions, in our view, must be glass palaces, where citizens control the work of their representatives, who are therefore not delegated blankly. That is also why, having read the Commission's proposal, which merely photographs and legalises a current situation, which is not the best given what is happening, for example, with conflicts of interest, I make no secret of the fact that I have felt a sense of frustration and disappointment. I say this in no uncertain terms: I think we are wasting an opportunity! It is these missed opportunities that drive citizens away from the institutions and make the European project something extruded in their eyes.  The register must be contained in an act having legal force, with erga omnes effectiveness, and not in a simple interinstitutional agreement. This is a fundamental point that I would like to highlight, because only by an act with the force of law would lobbyists be obliged to provide truthful and correct information, whereas in this way it is left to their good will.  Law firms, embassies of third countries, permanent representations of the Member States and officials of all levels and levels of the three institutions, including the Council and the preparatory bodies, must be included within the scope of the activities covered by the register. We would also need a mandatory legislative footprint and strict penalties for those who provide incorrect and misleading information. We want a radical paradigm shift: everything must be made public and what happens behind the scenes should be an exception.  Today we do not know what is happening within the European Council or within the Eurogroup and who actually takes the decisions that kill the European project and the citizens. It is a proposal without ambition, in my opinion, made specifically so as not to disturb the real manoeuvrers of the European Union. Lobbies do exist, but we have an obligation to make the activities of all those who work within the European institutions transparent, of those who play politics within the European institutions and of those who carry out lobbying, and this must be done by law.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Vice-President, I too believe that making the European institutions more transparent is our responsibility as the European Parliament, but that it is our responsibility as any public political decision-makers. The crisis of confidence in politics – as has been mentioned – has now reached worrying levels, sometimes because of a lack of clarity with regard to our activities, very often, but sometimes also because, as in my colleague's recent speech, we tend to create a climate of constant suspicion towards ourselves, that we are elected representatives of the citizens who must instead convey confidence and respectability. I believe that the Commission's proposal for an interinstitutional agreement is an interesting step in this direction because it proposes an interesting instrument, even if it is a first step, which allows us to start working towards a common position, because otherwise it is very easy to circumvent the instrument. I would like to point out that the AFCO Committee has in fact done a great deal of work and I believe that we will be able to vote on the agreement – for heaven's sake, mr Giegold rest assured – but we want to get to vote on it by a majority that will allow us to vote on it in plenary as well. I believe, however, that, in the work we are going to do, we will have to address the issue that I think the register is a little moderate as far as the Council is concerned. Those who are legislators are legislators, even if they represent a national government, because that is how European legislation is implemented. I therefore believe that one of the points on which we will have to work is the broadening of the spectrum of those in the Council who are bound to respect the rules and the register that we are going to build together.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – Madam President, it has been eight years since we have discussed the need to introduce a mandatory register for lobbying companies and lobbyists, and nothing has happened, it is also voluntary. It's been six years since Transparency International asked for the same thing and again nothing happened, that's where we are. It is very important this interinstitutional agreement, it is very important the commission's concrete proposal for mandatory registration in this register of lobbyists, lobbying activities in Parliament and in the Commission. But given the long period that has passed and nothing has happened, we have only spoken but the vote has not passed, I am skeptical. However, I hope and want to have a mandatory register.  If each of us had assumed an obligation of integrity and had not spoken to lobbyists who are not enrolled in this voluntary register, then perhaps the situation was different and we would not have reached conflicts of interest or the spade against amendments. I hope that at least in the twelfth hour we will all understand what institutional dignity means and that we are in this House because it has been voted on by people who expect transparency from us and to work for them.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr Timmermans, I too am happy to hear your words. But the GUE/NGL is astonished at how, without a word of explanation, you are simply sweeping Parliament's call for a binding piece of legislation under the table. If I follow your statements, they want to regain the confidence of the citizens through the cooperation of the EU institutions and through greater openness. However, the substance of their proposal for negotiations is reduced to including the Council only in the existing system. There is no doubt that registering lobbyists is an important pillar of transparency – we also urgently need improvements and, yes, the approach. But that is not enough. They are falling by the wayside somewhere on the road to genuine sustainable transparency.  The core of the problem of trust is also the question of how the EU institution itself act or who holds the filler in the legislative work with whom and when. You do not take this aspect into account. They shall allow the institution to make arrangements in-house at its own discretion and independently of each other. I understand that the Commission does not want to extend the scope of application in its own House. Not all the institutions are to be covered unchanged, and a colleague of yours has just said, on behalf of or against you, that he sees no need to question the Commission's code of conduct.  So everything is paletti for you, and if the group chairmen of the Group of the European People's Party, S&D and ALDE, were to say that the same would apply to the EP. So the Council remains, and it has already sent you an answer in persona from diplomats who would like to remain unrecognised via print media: this will not happen.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: – Madam President, I think that we can agree that to restore credibility and trust in the European institutions, what we need is more transparency and more accountability to citizens. Citizens should have the right to have an overview of the full decision-making process and I agree that it is a good approach that, if we require transparency from other institutions, we should start with ourselves. On the other hand, there are the other institutions: the Council is at least on equal footing with Parliament or the Commission in decision-making and I think there is no reason not to require the same rules for the Council to have a mandatory register as for the Commission and the Parliament. So given those circumstances, I believe that a voluntary register is not enough for the Council. Also, we have to take into consideration the possibility to widen to scope to the agencies, as well, and Ceterum censeo the Giegold report should be supported.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Madam President, I say to the Commissioner: I have watched you in this place, many times, often saying some quite uncomplimentary things about those of us on this side of the House. But today I am going to say something that I will probably never say to you again. I think you are right; transparency is absolutely vital. Frankly, this should have been done a long time ago. I was thinking earlier that I do not even remember the European Parliament discussing this before and it turns out that Parliament’s resolution on this was two and a half years ago, before I was even elected as an MEP. So it certainly is something that has taken a long time coming. Transparency, of course, is something that should apply to all institutions, whether in the European Union or elsewhere. I am disappointed at what I am hearing with regard to the Council. The fact that there are more lobbyists on the register here than in the United States, as you said earlier, should not necessarily be a source of pride because actually so much lobbying leads to big-business lobbying, which leads to legislation that suits big business. We need to make sure that legislation that comes in, wherever it comes in, is legislation which suits SMEs and does not give big business a competitive advantage over the small businesses that should be the engine room of the economy.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: – Madam President, first of all, I would like to explain one thing, I have said in advance that I want to exchange with Mr Schöpflin, but i don't think this information came to you because Mr Schöpflin was on his way. I would just like you to take this information, which we have been forwarding to the UShers, into account then in order for Mr Schöpflin to be given the floor.  Otherwise, Commissioner, let me congratulate you today, on today's performance, because when my colleague Arnott said that your proposal is really good, you can congratulate yourself, because he has never said that about any of your proposals, and I think that today you deserve to blow up not a bottle, at least a bass of the best champagne.  And I would like to say on behalf of the PPE on behalf of the Register itself: the PPE has a very accommodating attitude towards this. Of course, we have always supported and supported the register of lobbyists and the transparency register. But we're saying one thing so we don't all be chasing one black cat that's going to be hiding somewhere and running from side to side. Just because I put a lobbyist on some register doesn't mean the lobbyist's actually going to be there, and he's always going to admit my meeting. And the way we're going to enforce it after these individual people is going to be quite difficult, and how it's going to prove it. I am very glad that Jean Claude Juncker has taken this initiative as one of the main priorities of his taking office.  If the European Union is to be transparent, who else should be more transparent than institutions like the Council, the Commission and Parliament, which should lead by example? Above all, the European Parliament must be more open and therefore more trustworthy towards the European citizens who elect us here. So, as the European Commission proposes, let us systematically register lobbyists and other interest groups who can influence us, politicians, and create a working framework for our interaction with this public.

name: György SCHÖPFLIN
text: – Madam President, I apologise for the slight confusion. Let me begin by saying outright that, of course it goes without saying, that the EPP supports transparency. But transparency is actually a much more complex issue than it appears at first sight. I think at the heart of it is the problem of the relationship with transparency and trust. It is not clear cut; it is not automatic; it is not a direct, either causal or correlative, relationship. Indeed, the complexity is such that there is a lot of argument to suggest that the greater the transparency, the lower the trust, because why should people trust if they already have everything written down? Indeed, there are many people – I do not know if it is a majority or a minority – who say, if this much can be made transparent there must be something else that is hidden. It is, therefore, an ongoing, probably an infinitely repeatable process which can never be reached. And therefore I would say that if we are talking about transparency there has to be a finite quality to it, which I do not actually see at this particular time. So, the culture of trust is something that has to be more important, should supersede in some ways transparency itself, in order to generate the necessary trust in the institutions. Now I would go on to say that actually, from what I see, the central difficulty is the remoteness of all the institutions of the European Union from the citizens. Here, and the Vice-President we will know what I am about to say, what is happening to the European citizens’ initiative, which is a way of building trust, separately from transparency? I would also add here the problem of security. Too much openness makes people vulnerable to the various security services, who are very busy indeed in Brussels, in Strasbourg and who knows where else. Lobbying register, yes, I think that is absolutely right. It is not a silver bullet. I think there is no silver bullet, but at the centre of the problem is legitimacy. How can the European Union generate and build on its existing legitimacy, which is a little bit thin in certain parts of the world?

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the proposal for a compulsory transparency register for Parliament, the Council and the Commission is an important step in the process of regaining public confidence in the European institutions. Citizens have a right to know who is trying to influence the EU's legislative process. We must therefore propose a simple rule: no meetings with policy-makers if you have not entered the register first. Through the register, the public will be able to see who carries out lobbying activities, who they represent and how much they spend. The proposal for a transparency register for the three institutions, including the Council, because it is also a legislator, makes it possible to strengthen the monitoring and effective application of the code of conduct of the register for lobbyists. The interinstitutional agreement on the transparency register will also improve the quality of data, thanks to greater quality control, and from this point of view it would be appropriate for the Commission to make more resources available to achieve precisely the objective of transparency.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, the transparency register aims to provide information to citizens about organisations which, through their action, seek to influence decision-making processes in the European Union. Since 1 March the European Commission has launched consultations on the transformation of the system from an optional to a mandatory register of lobbyists in order to have greater transparency and control over the activities of lobbies at European level. Moreover, in a report published by Transparency International on 15 April 2015, of the 19 countries assessed, only seven had a legislative framework in relation to activities around lobbies, while the Commission, Parliament and the Council of the European Union have a modest rating on transparency in relation to the activities of the lobbies. It is therefore clear that a legislative framework should be established to control the activities of the lobbies in the European institutions.

name: Karin KADENBACH
text: Madam President, Mr Vice-President, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for his work We have been calling for this mandatory transparency register for many years. There is hardly any discussion with the population where we are not asked about the lobbyists and why there are still around 90 000 lobbying organisations and lobbyists in Brussels, and just 10 000 of them are registered. I believe that it is an urgent need for the same rules of the game to apply here to all three institutions – the Council, the Commission and Parliament. However, I assume – and I believe that the speeches have shown, as Mrs Guillaume and Mrs Bresso also said in advance – that there is still some need for discussion. Because what we want is a register that we can really rely on, which does not weigh us in false security, because perhaps there were not enough resources to really check all the information, etc. In other words, great accuracy and, of course, a high level of personnel and also financial effort is necessary in advance. I would also like to say one thing: let us put joint pressure on the Member States for similar registers, because lobbying does not start in Brussels or Strasbourg.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, let me start with a general remark triggered by Mr Schöpflin. He is right; transparency on its own will not restore trust in the European Union. But, if I may say, what would help is national leaders not blaming the EU for everything, national leaders not publishing posters with the Presidents of the European Commission and the European Parliament and many, many refugees, and then saying that the presidents of these institutions are responsible for the refugee crisis. No matter of transparency we will put on the table will solve that issue.  Having said that, I do believe – and I get this feeling strongly from discussing with you tonight – that we have taken a step in the right direction. Yes, we are not satisfied on all scores. Yes, we can we can do better in many areas – and I present to you my willingness to work with you to take this even further – if you can agree with this, but I do also believe that it is high time that the three institutions each also take their responsibility in this. Frankly, if Parliament and Council would follow the example the Juncker Commission has taken since the beginning, we would already have made a couple of steps forward. This is also indicated, I think, in the draft Giegold report.  Let me stress once again that we have the possibility now to improve the situation of transparency. It will not be perfect overnight, I know, but at the same time, if we use this interinstitutional agreement, the negotiation on the agreement, as an opportunity to see where we can improve our transparency, I strongly believe we can be more accountable to our citizens. We can prove to them that we are willing to put our cards on the table in terms of lobbying activities directed at lawmakers.  Let me end on a point which I would like to underscore, also made by Mr Giegold. This is not about us wanting to prescribe to every single elected Member of the European Parliament that she or he should register every single individual meeting. It is about meeting with lobbyists, people who come to you because they represent a certain interest and they want something to be done with it, so that people can see and can check which person represents which interest and what they are trying to achieve with that. If we can have that in our three institutions I think this would honestly be a very big step forward and I count on your support to get us all there.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: in writing. – With the aim of regaining citizens' confidence in the legitimacy of political, legislative and administrative processes in the Union, the Commission has submitted a proposal for an interinstitutional agreement to increase the transparency and accountability of members of self-employed stakeholders involved in the development and implementation of European Union policies. I welcome the positive experience of the Transparency Register set out in the Agreement of the European Parliament and the European Commission of 16 April 2014, the three institutions have agreed on the need to establish a compulsory Transparency Register for representatives of interest. This establishes the principle that no meeting with policy makers can be held without prior registration and clarifies the activities and data to be entered, increasing quality control. I am confident that the new interinstitutional agreement will become operational as soon as possible and I welcome the inclusion of the local and regional authorities in the scope of the new agreement, as we had requested.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: – The voluntaryity of the transparency register in the European Union has meant that not all lobbying and influencing is transparent. That is why we lack reliable information, among other things, on the total number of lobbyists, where they come from, what sectors they represent and how large resources they have at their disposal.  Canada, for example, has had a mandatory transparency register since 1989. In 2015, canada's register was nine times larger than the EU equivalent, even though only 35 million people live in Canada and around 510 million live in the EU. This indicates that it is possible to create a comprehensive transparency register. Under the Canadian model, breaches of the transparency register rules can result in a fine of up to €140,000 or two years in prison.  Under the current voluntary system, it is impossible to obtain reliable and comprehensive information on lobbyists affecting EU institutions and their activities. Therefore, the creation of a binding transparency register and effective monitoring of its operation is a necessity.

name: Julia PITERA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – A transparency register was established in 2011. Although it has been in place for five years and has a population of around 10 000 organisations, and with the consent of these organisations is governed by a code of conduct, registration is still based on a voluntary principle and the mechanisms that safeguard decision-making are imperfect. It is therefore important to pay tribute to all those involved in transparency activities in this area: the European Parliament and, in particular, the committees responsible for their responsibilities, the European Ombudsman, the Commission and the Council. It is with satisfaction that the announcement should be made of the definition of the catalogue of activities and entities already covered by the register. It is also important to proposal to broaden the scope of data, to improve the monitoring mechanism and, very importantly, to enforce it effectively. The proposed changes will certainly serve to improve the transparency of the functioning of the European institutions. Transparency is not only of interest to citizens and NGOs acting on their behalf, but above all it is essential in the process of building trust in the European institutions. Transparency is also a very important component of prevention to prevent threats to the interests of the European Union at every stage of the decision. The implementation of the Commission's proposal for a mandatory transparency register will be a great step towards the openness of public life and a very important link in the system of transparency.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. Today we are debating new rules on the transparency register and the supervision of lobbies' activities within the European institutions. In a news marked by the close ties maintained, during and after their tenure by Barroso with the investment bank Goldman Sachs, or Neelie Kroes and his offshore company, the debate comes to a head. Ethics and transparency must be key values in relations between elected officials, citizens and lobby groups.  The proposal made is positive but does not go far enough. I bitterly regret that chiefs of staff, directors and unit heads are not included in the proposal when they have a great deal of responsibility for the European decision-making process. It is also essential to give ourselves the means to monitor and verify the information in the register and to agree on penalties in case of fraud. Strict rules must be applied to ensure transparency and ethics in day-to-day work within institutions. And those who break these rules have nothing to do in our walls!

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Rapporteur. Madam President! Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! This evening we are going to debate the Report of the Committee on the Environment on the implementation of the regulation on food contact material. This may sound a bit technical, but basically it is about how we ensure that the materials that are in direct contact with our food are also safe.  Current EU legislation is a framework law that regulates our materials for our food packaging, etc. The framework legislation provides for the possibility of establishing common EU rules for each of the 17 types of material listed in the act. However, only four of the 17 types of material are currently harmonised at EU level. The rest is up to the Member States to deal with. This poses problems for consumers, for businesses and for the authorities. In fact, this means that the internal market is not a single market but a market with 28 different sets of rules. Some countries have high standards and fine controls, and others have low standards and no controls. The consequence is that our consumers are left behind and that companies compete on completely diverse terms. For example, consumers cannot be sure that they will be protected from hazardous chemistry, either from the coating in the tomato can or from fluoride in the pizza tray. In fact, we know from the research that unacceptably high levels of harmful chemistry occur in many materials we use for our food. We know this from the baking paper, the paper bag to the flour, the pizza tray and microwave popcorn etc. It is worrying when, at the same time, we know from several studies that precisely chemistry in food packaging causes concrete health problems. For example, we know that having excessive amounts of fluoride in your urine increases the risk of involuntarily having an abortion. That is just one example.  Consumers must be protected much better and companies must be given more a level playing field to produce food contact materials. That is why we in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy propose that the European Commission should come up with a proposal for a revision of the current legislation on food contact materials. In particular, we want the European Commission to give priority to the submission of common EU rules for the following materials: paper, cardboard, glue, coating and ink. We also propose that the European Commission should develop uniform testing methods for each material, so that Member States use the same methods to assess safety. Food safety must mean the same thing throughout the EU.  We also want to strengthen EPSA both in terms of money and tougher requirements. We know that chemicals react together, which is why EPSA must of course also check for the so-called cocktail effect. We also want EPSA to include the effect of a low but constant exposure to a substance. It may be that the quantities are low, but if we are exposed to a substance every day, the total amount becomes large. We also believe that it is important for EPSA to take this into account.  We also want specific testing methods for the safety of nanomaterials to be developed, and at the same time we want food contact material with nanomaterials to be labelled.  We also want something else. We find it incredible that we ensure better coordination between the food contact rules and our REACH legislation. It must simply not occur that substances which under REACH are categorised as dangerous are uncritically used in food contact materials. We will have done something about that.  In general, we are also proposing both more and better controls on the production of food contact materials by companies. There are some Member States which have no idea which companies in their country are importing or producing food contact materials. If they do not know about the companies, they cannot control them either.  We also believe that declarations of conformity should not just be a rubber stamp, but a real evidence of safety. In this way, we can ensure that both authorities and businesses have more confidence in each other.  Finally, I should like to say that it is also important to us that we ensure that food materials are covered by the criteria for endocrine disruptors that the European Commission is setting. They must also apply here.  I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs and the political groups very well for their very good cooperation on the report. It is a committee that is almost close to being completely united on this. We really want a review of the rules and we want common rules on food contact material to protect consumers and ensure a level playing field for businesses. It is not just us in this House, it is also European consumers and European businesses who want the same thing. So we hope that the European Commission will listen to us carefully today and come up very quickly with a proposal for a revision of the legislation.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first I would like to thank and congratulate Ms Schaldemose and the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI) for their excellent work in producing this report on the implementation of the Food Contact Materials Regulation. The Commission very much welcomes this timely initiative. It underlines the importance of this topic, particularly in relation to consumer safety.  Food contact materials play an essential role in food supply and distribution, and also of course for consumers. Food packaging preserves or improves the quality of food and determines how it can be processed, transported, sold and consumed. However, some substances may migrate into or onto the food, compromising its safety and quality. Legal certainty on food contact materials is also needed to foster the single market and promote innovation. In the EU we have a broad and flexible framework regulation with fundamental requirements on safety. The powers to adopt specific EU legislation have mainly been used to develop specific rules for plastic materials. The Commission notes the conclusions set out in the implementation report. We note the concerns raised about those materials for which no specific measures have been developed at EU level and that are specifically legislated for only at national level. As you may know, the Commission’s Joint Research Centre has been working on a study looking at this particular area. The study has collected a vast amount of complex information on national measures, as well as on the industry situation, to provide a clear picture of the overall situation. The report, which will be published soon, will highlight the complex and often divergent nature of the current regulatory situation for food contact materials in the EU. The Commission is committed to addressing this important area of risk management of food contact materials in the EU and this key area for the functioning of the internal market, whilst always keeping the safety of consumers at the forefront. I now look forward to hearing the views of honourable Members on this issue.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Christel Schaldemose, very warmly for the close and extremely cooperative cooperation. I am convinced that together we are sending a clear signal to the Commission that there is still a lot of work to be done here. Materials that come into contact with food must meet numerous requirements: they are designed to protect against contamination and to maintain the quality of the food for as long as possible. They shall not, under normal and foreseeable conditions of use, release any constituents into foods which are likely to endanger human health or cause an unacceptable change in the composition of the foodstuffs. These requirements also apply to product groups that have not yet been further harmonised, such as .B paper, cardboard, varnishes, coatings and others. Unfortunately, there are repeated migration of chemicals into food, which poses a threat to human health. In addition, different national approaches hinder the internal market. We therefore agree that we need further harmonisation here.  The report is based on a broad compromise that the rapporteur has reached with all the political groups. This is also reflected in the result of the vote with 61 votes in favour and 3 against in committee. However, there was and still is a red line for the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats: the call for a horizontal, general ban on individual substances, such as mineral oil or biophenol. That goes too far for us, which was important for us during the vote in committee, and we have therefore asked for a split vote here.  Our position is: we need further comprehensible and actionable individual measures. These individual measures are conditional on studies as to whether the use of certain substances should be restricted. The Commission, in cooperation with the Member States, is called upon to find solutions here.

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: On behalf of the Group of President, Commissioner, I would first like to welcome the relevance of Mrs Christel Schaldemose's initiative report.  I would like to go back for a moment to the ban on bisphenol A in all materials in contact with food. Since 2009, I have been alerting the European Commission to the dangers of this chemical compound used in reusable bottles, cans, cans, cash registers, and suspected of increasing the risk of early puberty in young girls, prostate and breast cancers. This endocrine disruptor should be banned in all consumer products, not just in bottles.  That is the message of Amendment No 9, which we are putting down, and I sincerely hope that it will be adopted tomorrow in plenary.  Pending a reassessment of the risks of bisphenol A by EFSA, announced for 2017-2018, the precautionary principle must prevail and our Europe must above all be a Europe protecting all of our fellow citizens.

name: Bolesław G. PIECHA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I would like to congratulate the very reliable and well-prepared report. The most commonly identified risks to human health related to materials and articles intended to come into contact with food mainly concern the penetration of small-molecule substances into food. This is a migration of unreacted or unreacted monomers or other additives used in the production process, especially during plastics processing. Since 2002, the European Commission has recorded notifications of as many as 2000 notifications of materials and articles intended to come into contact with food that did not fully comply with legal requirements and safety criteria and posed, or potentially posed, a risk to human health.  Therefore, not only as a doctor, but above all as a consumer, I fully support the provisions in the report on better and increased consumer protection by lowering specific migration limits, such as the planned changes to Biosphenol A, although I am aware that the timing of the introduction can be cumbersome due to the sometimes lack of adequate testing and sometimes the lack of an alternative to replacing these packages with others.

name: Stefan ECK
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done I am glad that at such a late hour some have still found here. On the subject, however, I can fully support the content of the report on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Thank you, Mrs Schaldemose, for this important report. However, I have to say that when it comes to food safety or transparency for the consumer, some Members work too closely with the food sector. When the Commission is to legislate in this area, there is often an attempt to water down or prevent new regulations. The fact is that the food industry often wants to leave citizens in the dark or even deliberately deceive them. Enough is enough! Our health is at stake because of all the toxins and additives contained in our food and also in packaging material. This House and the Commission must make a U-turn and, above all, focus on consumer health. In any case, I hope that this report will help to ensure that this U-turn is finally carried out. Thank you, Mrs Schaldemose!

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, materials and objects in contact with food are widely present in everyday life, from packaging to kitchen utensils. We know that there is a chemical-physical interaction between materials and food and that the transfer of substances dangerous to human health may occur during contact. We are talking about extremely harmful substances, such as so-called endocrine disruptors, on which there has been a heated debate with the Commission for months on their very definition. Bisphenols, present in bottle plastic, are also disruptors, just to give an example, and counted as the cause of endometriosis and serious problems with the reproductive system.  From the point of view of general rules, the sector has legislated well, but there is no harmonisation of the specific laws of the Member States. Many States, including Italy, have their own specific legislation, notified to the European Union, but there are frequent problems with mutual recognition.  A further aggravation arises from the risk assessment. It happens that the European Food Safety Authority itself, EFSA, which theoretically guarantees our health, does partial work and does not take into account the so-called cocktail effect, nor multiple exposures to different chemicals.  We therefore call on the Commission to harmonise the specific sectors and to avoid the proliferation of rules that can cause market distortions, at the same time ensuring a uniform level of food safety, that EFSA carries out its task of ensuring the food safety of European citizens well and carries out risk assessments worthy of the name, and finally that the Commission 100 % avoids the presence of endocrine disruptors among these substances and finally protects the health of European citizens more than the interests of lobbies.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, food packaging, kitchen utensils and dishes may contain substances of concern, such as endocrine disruptors or nanomaterials. Indeed, these molecules can migrate into food and, as a result, harm our health, as demonstrated by many scientific researches. The text that regulates materials in contact with food must therefore be revised.  The report highlights the shortcomings of the Commission and the European Food Safety Authority. It stresses the insufficient evaluation of these materials when they are approved, the insufficient collaboration between this agency and that of chemicals or the insufficient consideration of the effects of these products on pregnant and lactating women. I have proposed amendments calling for a ban on all forms of bisphenol and not just bisphenol A, a product that has already been banned in France in all food containers since 2015. I hope that the recommendations of this report will be followed by effect. Failing that, the European Union would prove once again that it is incapable of protecting public health.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: – Dear Madam President-in-Office, Commissioner, colleagues. I welcome the report by the rapporteur, my colleague Schaldemosa, and thank her for the attention and engagement on this subject, which has not yet received sufficient attention. That he undoubtedly deserves attention has shown a procedure in which we have checked the implementation of the regulation and found worrying facts. In order to facilitate the implementation of existing legislation and to better achieve its objectives, i.s. the protection and protection of consumer health and to ensure the effective functioning of the internal market, the Commission should review the current legislative framework on the basis of the recommendations of this report. The key finding is that the lack of specific measures for certain materials and the gaps in the risk assessment of traceability, compliance and controls require action at Union level.
