The Commission should prepare the necessary measures as a matter of priority for paper, cardboard, varnishes and coatings, metals and alloys, inks and adhesives, and to use as a starting point a review by the Joint Research Centre of the Commission on national rules. Further research on the interaction between different chemicals and nanomaterials should be supported, as there is still scientific uncertainty regarding the effects and the possibility of emgrating these materials and their effects on human health. Furthermore, particular attention should be paid to substances used in materials and articles intended for the packaging of foods for infants and children, and the definition of vulnerable groups should also include pregnant women and breastfeeding women. Our aim must be to promote the development of materials and products that are safe, fit for reuse and recycled, thereby also contributing to the Union's efforts to create a more efficient circular economy.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: – Madam President, I too would like to acknowledge Mrs Schaldemose's important work, with a magnificent report which highlights the need for the revision of the 2004 Regulation as insufficient. Insufficient, by not covering all materials — comprehensive regulation of materials in contact with food – while demonstrating differences in legislation between Member States.  At the same time, scientific knowledge of new materials has increased greatly, such as endocrine disruptors. That is why new regulation is needed to harmonise and give legal certainty to businesses in the European Union and, in particular, to consumer safety.  That is why I also appeal that the Commission should definitely publish and establish clear criteria focusing on consumer safety with regard to endocrine disruptors in order to make a comprehensive regulation such as that requested here.

name: Julia REID
text: – Madam President, food contact materials which are used in everyday life in the form of food packaging can be made from a variety of materials such as plastics, rubber, paper or metal, and may transfer their constituents to food, thus endangering human health. Consumer health protection is fundamental, so it is important to ensure that any potential transfer to foodstuffs of chemicals that can contaminate or alter the composition of food in a detrimental way is prevented.  Currently, food contact materials are subject to legally binding requirements at EU level. To date, specific measures have been adopted for plastics, ceramics, regenerated cellulose and active intelligent materials, and now the rapporteur calls on the Commission to produce specific EU measures for all kinds of food contact material. There is no doubt that the safety of food contact materials must be seriously evaluated, as chemicals can easily migrate from the material into the food. However, Member States should be free to adopt specific measures at national level for all kinds of food contact material so that these can be manufactured in compliance with good manufacturing practices.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab In his State of the Union address, President Juncker stressed in his previous plenary session that our agriculture is a very important element of the European Community. You can't disagree with that. Our farmers grow and produce the healthiest, varied and safe products. That is why it is so important that at the next stages in the supply chain this highest quality is maintained and protected.  The safety of food contact materials is one of the determining factors here. This is an extremely complex topic and can be a major challenge for packaging manufacturers. It is therefore also important that the rules in this area are clear. I believe that the 2004 regulation introduces a good legal framework. However, it is worrying that so far special measures have only been adopted for four of the 17 substances listed in the Annex to the Regulation. I believe that greater harmonisation of rules at European Union level would have a positive impact on the level of food protection and consumer safety and, consequently, on the functioning of the common market. The new specific rules should, as is the case with plastics legislation, take into account the issue of recycled materials as they may potentially pose other risks. These include, for example, accidental contaminants from previous packaging applications.  The second point that the rapporteur rightly pointed out is the degree of implementation and enforcement of existing rules in individual Member States. In particular, the Commission should examine the difficulties faced by national authorities and producers and make efforts to facilitate their implementation and compliance with these regulations.

name: Damiano ZOFFOLI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I too would like to stress the urgent need for decisive action at European level, on the one hand, to remedy the lack of specific measures concerning certain types of materials in contact with food in the light of the precautionary principle and, on the other, to facilitate and monitor the implementation of the legislation in force. The lack of harmonisation at European level for certain materials in contact with food poses a risk to public health and leads, in addition to a loss of consumer confidence, legal uncertainty and higher compliance costs for operators. The proper functioning of the internal market is at risk.  There are three aspects that I would like to insist on: traceability, which must be guaranteed throughout the supply chain so as to facilitate controls for materials imported from third countries as well; labelling, which is essential for effective consumer information in the transition to a circular economy involving the recycling and reuse of materials; the need to avoid risks to human health and, in particular, specific measures are needed at EU level for recycled paper and cardboard. Finally, it is essential to increase financial support for research and innovation.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: – Madam President, the proposed food contact materials legislation represents a typically EU approach to speculative consumer concern. It will be prescriptive and oppressive, stifling innovation in a fast-moving sector that continuously monitors and responds to consumer concerns.  The last thing that any food manufacturer wants to risk is its corporate reputation by supplying a product in suspect packaging. Consumers can now be highly effective in influencing corporate behaviour through social media campaigns that would be unimaginable 20 years ago. There is now a strong demand from certain elements of society to know exactly how their food is produced and packaged. Those suppliers who show reluctance to divulge information are quickly named and shamed. It is down to these suppliers to demonstrate a scientific argument strong enough to defeat empty rhetoric and clearly and honestly label their products so that the consumer can make the ultimate choice. I can well remember fish and chips being sold wrapped in discarded newspapers before we joined the EU. I can never remember anyone refusing to purchase them for this reason.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. It happens from time to time that I order a pizza, perhaps after a lengthy plenary debate in the evening at quarter past eleven, and this pizza is usually delivered in cardboard boxes. Can I be sure now that there is no health-threatening element in this cardboard box that might pass on to the pizza? That is the question here. The answer is likely or most likely: No. Or rather, the answer depends on which country I live in. Are we in this area that we are now talking about, that is to say, an internal market or not? After all, if only four of the 17 materials laid down in the regulation are regulated throughout Europe, then we are not an internal market, and that cannot be the case. I therefore very much welcome the report presented by Mrs Schaldemose. For me, their message is clear: only a harmonised standard of health is a high standard for people's health in the internal market. This applies in particular to substances such as the so-called endocrine disruptors. This is especially true for an endocrine disruptor called bisphenol. Unlike the party line or the group line, I am very much in favour of banning bisphenol completely in Europe. What is bad for babies is also bad for me. So there is a very simple logic behind this. Consumer confidence is also being played on here. In general, therefore, we in Europe need to achieve uniform standards for all 17 materials and their testing procedures. When assessing the risks, however, not only the individual substances, but also their interaction with other substances, must be assessed. That is very important. In summary, therefore, only common rules guarantee a high level of health protection. And I must be able to rely – and when I say 'I'm speaking on behalf of all consumers' – that the packaging of the food does not make me sick in the long term. This should apply to the whole of Europe. And I know you, Commissioner Jourov, as a committed internal market campaigner: take this issue seriously and come up with wise solutions!

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: - Madam President, the issue of food contact materials is a matter for each of the half a billion EU citizens, as they come into contact with them on a daily basis. Many citizens buy organic food to avoid pesticides, and the contamination potential from food packaging can be a thousand times higher.  The current directive is from 2004, and in the meantime science and toxicology have progressed. That is why I think it is necessary to revise existing rules and procedures to strengthen the common market and better protect public health.  It is necessary to seriously take into account the interaction of compounds and chemicals that can be harmless separately, but together can provoke a reaction in the human body. Furthermore, regulations for paper, cardboard, coatings, inks, metals and adhesives should be harmonized. In conclusion, I would like to thank the Rapporteur for her excellent work and call on the Commission to take the steps proposed in the report as soon as possible.

name: Karin KADENBACH
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done First of all, I too would like to thank my colleague Christel Schaldemose warmly for this really successful motion. It shows something that I had thought was settled two or three years ago. It was a great surprise to me to find that there are so many regulations not in place across Europe that some packaging materials that come into contact with food every day are not yet regulated in Europe, even though we know in the meantime that they are discharging toxic substances.  I believe that, in the context of this combination, as she has mentioned, we should look at REACH and food contact materials. There are things that are forbidden in REACH, but then when they touch our food, that would be fine all of a time, because they are only in the packaging. I believe that we must send out very clear signals here, invest in the confidence of Europeans, because they must know that not only are food in Europe and certainly not harmful to health, but also that the packaging in which it is delivered, bought, transported on the internal market also meets all the requirements for the highest health.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the absence of harmonised and uniform rules on the use of food contact materials poses a risk to public health, environmental protection and the proper functioning of the internal market. We need uniform European rules to encourage the production of contact material with safe or reusable and traceable foods, providing for the progressive elimination of all those substances that could pose a danger to the health of consumers. Particular attention should be paid to those materials that present a high risk of migration and therefore a greater risk to human health, such as materials used to contain liquids and foods rich in fats and also those that are in contact with food products for an extended period of time. Efsa's risk assessments, which are currently limited to individual substances, should be implemented in the clear, not considering the so-called cocktail effect. This effect must be taken into account when determining migration limits that are considered safe for human health.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, the European Union has already adopted regulations on safety requirements for all materials, substances and articles intended to come into contact, directly or indirectly, with foodstuffs, in order to ensure that substances are not transmitted to food in quantities that endanger human health. However, the Commission has only taken specific measures for four materials that come into contact with food: plastic, ceramics, regenerated cellulose and active and intelligent materials. However, for all other materials in contact with foodstuffs, no specific measures have yet been taken, thus endangering human health and in some cases adversely affecting the composition of foodstuffs. It is therefore necessary to take immediate measures on the part of the Union and for other materials in contact with foodstuffs, as well as to fill all gaps in risk assessment, traceability, compliance and control.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I have listened to the views of this House with great care and great interest, and before that you have heard my reflections setting out the Commission’s views on the report and, more broadly, on this complex yet very vital sector and its importance as regards consumer safety. I would like to thank once again Ms Schaldemose and the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety for all their hard work on this file, and I can declare here that the Commission will consider all of the points made in the report, and also in this debate, in the future work.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Rapporteur. Madam President! First of all, I would like to thank colleagues for being here tonight and for supporting our joint report so much. We've had a very good working relationship. That is also why it has turned into a good and solid report with some very clear recommendations. I would also like to thank the Commissioner for being so open and responsive to the problems that are in this area and the solutions we have presented in our report on food contact material.  When the JRC comes up with its report, we will also read it closely, and then we hope that we will be able to engage in a constructive dialogue together on this matter, so that hopefully very quickly we can tighten up the rules and improve consumer safety, while also ensuring that we have a better and better functioning market for food contact materials.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. This report is a clear signal sent to the European Commission but also to consumers! Chemicals in materials intended to come into contact with foodstuffs, including packaging, kitchen utensils, crockery, etc. can endanger human health or significantly alter the composition of the products consumed, and it is essential that the European Commission address this issue.  It is important to harmonize at European level the various measures taken by the Member States, but also to reflect on the gaps in the current legislation. We need to work on better legislation in this area, legislation that will properly inform and protect the citizen. Finally, I would like to raise the issue of the ban on bisphenol A (BPA) in all materials intended to come into contact with food. BPA is a chemical, endocrine disruptor and toxic to reproductive organs. It is found in many consumer products. It is important that this ban is made at European level in order to protect all European citizens!

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. The 1935/2004 Regulation of 27 October 2004 covers all materials coming into contact with food at all stages of the production and consumption chain: containers, packaging, cutlery, etc. It limits the alteration of the composition, taste or texture of food. In its first annex, this regulation lists seventeen materials that can be subject to specific European or national regulation.  At present, only four of them are subject to European regulation. The first objective of the draft report is therefore the harmonisation of European regulations for all these materials. The draft report also aims to take into account the following elements in the above regulation: interference with regulation 1907/2006 relating to the registration, assessment and authorisation of chemicals; interactions between and the reaction introduction of complementary substances.  Other positive elements, such as the protection of pregnant women or technical measures on bisphenol. For all these reasons, I have supported this far-sighted text on the action of the Commission and the European Food Safety Authority.

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Implementation of the Regulation on materials intended to come into contact with food. It has long been known that not only the composition of food products, but also what it is packaged in, affects our health and quality of life. In the packaging, the researchers discovered about 170 types of chemicals, such as biosphenol A, phthalates, styrene, triclosan, formaldehyde, or PFC (perfluorocarbohydrate), which freely migrate to food and then significantly affect our hormonal balance, cause obesity, diabetes, neurological and inflammatory disorders and cancer development. In addition, no one – neither the packaging nor the food manufacturer – is obliged to indicate the chemical composition of the packaging and, moreover, potential cellular or hormonal changes caused by these chemicals are not included in the routine toxicological analysis, which raises serious doubts as to the correctness of the current chemical regulatory procedures. That is why it is so important to pass a law as soon as possible that will mobilise packaging manufacturers to withdraw harmful substances from the packaging process as soon as possible, as well as food itself.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: in writing. – Materials not regulated by specific Union measures endanger public health, the environment and decrease people's confidence in us. It creates legal uncertainty and higher costs for both operators and consumers. I want to completely eliminate hazardous materials that come into contact with food. Then people need to know what they eat and what they feed their children with. Labelling is a very direct and effective tool to inform consumers about product characteristics. We have shortcomings in the development, application and enforcement of the legislation in force; SMEs, for example, in the absence of relevant legislative provisions, are not in a position to receive or transmit information to ensure that their products are safe. Good regulation and strict control protect people's health and stimulate the economy. Let's take them.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: in writing. – The application of the Regulation should lead, on the one hand, to lower the costs of physical entities and to an increase in their food safety and health, and on the other hand to the decrease in the costs of legal entities registered in the field of the MCA, which would be able to develop safe, recyclable and reusable CAMs, thereby helping to increase the efficiency of the circular economy. This can be achieved to the extent that the increase in EFSA funding would materialise in the results of R&D and innovation, scientific research and RISK assessment, identification and classification of all substances present in the SCALE (including their impact on human health). Obviously, ensuring consistency between THE regulations on THE MAs, biocidal products, harmful substances and waste, as well as clarifying the role played by the various institutions and bodies involved in this area are essential aspects. However, we must be aware that not only is it that all Member States have a responsible assumption of the implementation of the relevant legislation and the intensification of compliance checks, but also the exchange of best practices with a view to applying relevant and effective authorisation procedures for the 13 non-harmonised MAs is particularly necessary in this context.
